Africa News


May 1, 1997


Zambia;
Four Post Journalists Discharged


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Windhoek - Four journalists from the privately-owned newspaper, The

Post, charged with criminal libel have been acquitted by the magistrate

court, reports the Zambia Independent Media Association (ZIMA/MISA-

Zambia).

Editor-in-Chief Fred M'membe, former managing editor Bright Mwape,

former reporter (now the paper's business manager) Goliath Mungonge and

former reporter Nkonkomalimba Kafunda were acquitted on April 11 after

the state decided to withdraw the case. 

President Frederick Chiluba's press aide Richard Sakala had sued the

Post four in 1995 for calling him 'tricky dick' and exposing his alleged

extra marital affairs. He also sued the paper for alleging that Sakala

lacked formal journalistic training. ZIMA reports that Sakala, however,

admitted to all allegations reported by the paper as being true. ends

For further information, contact David Nthengwe, researcher, Media

Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), Private Bag 13386, Windhoek,

Namibia Tel. +264 61 232975, Fax. 248016 e-mail:

research@ingrid.misa.org.na


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

2 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 1, 1997


Southern Africa;
MISA Appoints Directors To Regional Fund


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Windhoek - The Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), has

appointed a seven person board of directors to chart the development of

its investment arm, the Southern African Media Development Fund

(Samdef), which will start operating from the first quarter of next

year.

It will be based in Gaborone, Botswana.

The board met in Windhoek over the weekend and appointed as its

chairman, Dr Gilbert Mudenda, an economic consultant from Zambia, who is

also the deputy chairman of the MISA Education and Production Trust

Fund. Ms Nomsa Lorna Maimane, an investment analyst who is also branch 

manager of Tswelelo, a development finance institution in Botswana, was

elected deputy.

Other board members are: Luis =Cabaco, formerly minister of transport

and communications and now proprietor of Ebano Multi Media company in

Mozambique; Bruce Cohen, formerly managing director of the 'Mail and

Guardian' in South Africa and now a media consultant; Elias Shikongo,

partner in the legal firm of Meclaffe and Shikongo in Namibia, Phasha

Shongwe-Mayisela, regional deputy chairperson of MISA who works in the

marketing department of Swazi Television and Maureen Chamane-Gabuza, an

investment analyst with Tibiyo in Swaziland .

Samdef is part of MISA's broader strategy at community mobilisation

and economic empowerment of the emergent independent media within the

Southern African Development Community - SADC.

"Samdef aims to encourage a more pro-active role in the development

processes of this media, through the opening of economic opportunities

and the provision of commensurate managerial and business training,"

says MISA's Executive Director, Methaetsile Leepile.

We hope that Samdef, which has taken two years to plan, will help

build bridges between the independent media and the commercial finance

sector, he said. Samdef will initially provide credit guarantee schemes

and loans through banks and secondary lending institutions but it will

also consider direct equity finance as well as facilitating franchising

mechanisms over the longer term, he added.

MISA has established through exhaustive research that lack of access

to capital in the region remains a serious impediment to the development

of a free, independent and pluralistic media. Samdef is intended to fill

this void.

"We can no expect to build a strong civil society or promote

democratic governance in our countries if access to the free flow of

ideas and information is hindered", said Leepile, who expressed the hope

that Samdef will, in its own little way, contribute to the empowerment

of the media into the next millennium.

Further information please contact: David Nthengwe, Information Unit,

Media Institute of Southern Africa, Telephone: +264 61 232 975; fax

248016; e-mail: research@ingrid.misa.org.na


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997

3 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 1, 1997


Tanzania;
High Court Acquits Journalist, Quashes Conviction


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Windhoek - The High Court in Tanzania has acquitted a journalist

charged and convicted of contravening the 1970 National Security Act,

reports MISA-Tanzania.

Freelance journalist Adam Mwaibabile was on February 28, this year

convicted to one year imprisonment by the Ruvuma Magistrate Court for

being found in possession of a "classified" government document.

Mwaibabile was, however, released on bail on March 21. The High Court 

quashed the conviction and acquitted Mwaibabile on Tuesday, April 29.

(See further background and chronology of events below).

In his ruling, Judge Dan Mapigano said that the Ruvuma Magistrate

Court which had convicted Mwaibabile "had a misconception of the scope

and spirit of the National Security Act of 1970." Mapigano said that the

document Mwaibabile was found with "had nothing to do with state

security." He explained that the National Security Act basically

pertains to matters such as "espionage, sabotage and activities

prejudicial to the welfare and interests of the state." Judge Mapigano

went on to say that the document said to have been "classified" was

itself "an unlawful" because it was meant to deprive Mwaibabile lawful

means of earning a living.

BACKGROUND AND CHRONOLOGY OF EVENTS

Mwaibabile was found in breach of the 1970 National Security Act for

being found in possession of what the state had classified as "a secret

state document".

The letter was, however, from the Ruvuma regional commissioner's

office written to the town council director instructing not to issue a

business licence to Mwaibabile for the year 1995/96. Mwaibabile was, in

addition to freelancing, operating a kiosk and had applied to renew his

licence.

The 1970 National Security Act prohibits the "communication of

classified and protected documents".

February 28: Journalist Adam Mwaibabile (31) is sentenced by Songea

Resident Magistrate Respicius Mwijage to a 12 month jail.

March 9: Four lawyers, Sengondo Mvungi, Chris Peter, Florens Luoga

and Jerome Msemwa of the University of Dar es Salaam declare to process

an appeal application for bail.

March 13: State-run newspaper, Daily News, reports Chief Justice

Francis Nyalali as having ordered the Songea Resident Magistrate Court

to dispatch the file on the jailed journalist to the High Court in Dar

es Salaam.

March 19: Mwaibabile's Defence lawyer Dr. Sengondo Mvungi lodges an

appeal to the High Court for bail; says there was nothing in the letter

to suggest that it had some elements of sabotage, espionage, and state

security which could warrant his arrest and imprisonment.

March 20: High Court Judge Dan Mapigano orders the release on bail of

Mwaibabile. "I order the applicant (Mwaibabile) be released on bail

immediately and without surety pending the outcome of an appeal to

review his imprisonment," Mapigano says.

March 21: Mwaibabile is released on bail from a Songea Prison at

08.30 am.

April 18: Hearing of an appeal to review his imprisonment fails to

start owing to Idd Al Haj holiday.

April 21: Appeal to review Mwaibabile imprisonment begins. State

Attorney Paloot Luena admits before the High Court to wrongful

conviction of Mwaibabile.

April 29: Judgement Day; High Court acquits Mwaibabile, quashes his

conviction.

For further information, contact David Nthengwe, researcher, Media

Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), Private Bag 13386, Windhoek,

Namibia Tel. +264 61 232975, Fax. 248016 e-mail:

research@ingrid.misa.org.na

Africa News


May 1, 1997


Science and Health;
Lassa Fever - Sierra Leone


BYLINE: World Health Organization (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Geneva - Sierra Leone. Lassa fever re-emerged as a public health

problem in Kenema in eastern Sierra Leone during 1996.

From January to 19 April 1996, 799 cases with 148 deaths (CFR 18.5%)

were reported. In the endemic Lassa fever situation an annual average of 

40-50 cases normally occurred in this region. An elevated number of

Lassa fever cases has continued to occur in 1997 with 45 cases reported

in January, 75 in February and 147 in March.

The increased occurrence is closely related to massive population

movements with subsequent crowding, poor sanitation, unsafe food

handling and storage practices combined with an increase in the rat

population. Furthermore, with the improving political and security

situation in Sierra Leone, the populace is moving about more freely to

access health care facilities resulting in increased case reporting.

The Ministry of Health, WHO, the Centers for Disease Control and

Prevention, USA and MERLIN, United Kingdom have worked together to

monitor the outbreak and to mitigate its impact. Patients are brought to

and treated at an isolation ward established in Kenema which has been

expanded to accommodate the increase in cases.

Several workshops have been held to train health staff and to educate

the general public about measures to avoid contact with rodents.

Supplies of ribavirin, the antiviral drug used to treat Lassa virus

infections, were nearly depleted. The Red Cross was contacted regarding

this need and the Chinese Red Cross responded with a donation of 120,000

doses of the drug to the Government of Sierra Leone. WHO is working with

the pharmaceutical industry on a long-term solution.

(Based on a report from WHO representative in Sierra Leone.)

Comment: Transmission of the Lassa virus in the community is mainly

due to contact with rats of the genus Mastomys. Infected rats

continually shed viruses in their urine and humans are infected by

ingestion of food contaminated with rat urine or inhalation of virus-

containing aerosols. Minimizing contact with rodents by the safe

handling and storage of food or restricting access of rats to homes,

remains therefore the most effective preventive measure.

Person-to-person transmission occurs primarily in health care

institutions caring for Lassa patients. Nosocomial spread can easily be

prevented by managing patients in isolation wards and with appropriate

protective measures (barrier nursing). The risk of transmission during

international travel is low unless the traveller is in contact with a

severely ill and bleeding case.

A recent incident involving a virus which causes a similar clinial

syndrome occurred in South Africa where a nurse was infected with Ebola

virus while caring for a patient from an endemic area. This underscores

the importance of health care staff awareness and use of special

precautions when treating patients who have travelled abroad.

Africa News


May 1, 1997


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia News Roundup


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1627 words


 

HARAR (ENA) - 14,000 hides, skin taken out of zone illegally every

year

The East Hararghe Zone agricultural department says close to 14,000

hides and skin are illegally taken out of the zone into foreign markets

every year.

The department said it was unable to meet its annual plan to supply

to the central market over 57,000 hides and skin due to the contraband

trade and use of the skin by the local people for domestic purposes.

The facto that there is no well-organised and sophisticated abattoirs

services in the zone has undermined the quality and quantity of the

hides and skin supplied to the market, it said.

The East Haraghe Zone provided the central market with over 30,000

hides and skin over the last nine months. 

Woman's scorched corpse found unburied for 14 days

NAZARETH (ENA) - A woman's corpse was found scorched and unburied for

14 days inside a residence in Nazareth town owned by a family who are

alleged to be members of a cult which believes "humanibeing can live

without food", police disclosed.

The East Shoa Zone Police said they have discovered on Monday the

remains of the woman of the woman burnt with fire in a residence owned

by an eight-member family belonging to the same cult, which promotes

"humanbeing can live without eating food but live with only holy

spirit".

The crime prevention and investigation head, Ato Girma Tolcha said

the bones of the remains of the deceased have no flesh, besides being

scorched.

Police said the woman died of shortage of food and as a member of the

cult.

They further said the family of the deceased has neither told to

neighbours the death of the woman nor seen mourning, rather resumed

normal life by keeping the corpse inside the house.

The mother of members of the cult whose body had been weakened due to

lack of food as she used to chew only chat, a mild stimulant plant for

many days, was taken by relatives to Wonji town, where she died 20 days

later, according to police.

The funeral service of the mother took place on Monday at Wonji town,

Ato Girma said.

The alleged leader of the cult, 36, is reported to have been a third-

year student of the Alemaya University of Agriculture. he is unemployed

since nine years ago.

Ato Girma said the leader of the cult since his withdrawal from the

university has started to isolate himself and live in one of the rooms

of the always-closed house of his family be preaching that he can cure

patients.

He also preaches people "we who will not be touched by death, do not

need edir(self -help association)," according to police.

The youth has persuaded and convinced members of his family to leave

their jobs, spouses and drop out from school to live together with him

by promoting the cult.

Police said that the members of the cult have not eaten food for the

last 50 days. they used to live on chat and water alone, according to

police.

Although the younger sister of the alleged leader of the cult has

tried to convince people in the area that her elder sister had died of

diarrhoea rather than shortage of food, it has not been possible, to

bury the remains of the deceased as the people in the area refused to

collaborate.

The younger sister who has got a 10 month-old malnourished child said

she left her job in a textile factory on her own will to join the cult

two years ago, according to police.

Police said the cult leader and his younger sister are detained,

while five-other members are being searched.

The woman whose remains have been found by police is survived by her

husband and three children.

Journalists complete training in Bahir Dar

BAHIR DAR (ENA) - Television journalists with the Amhara Culture,

Tourism and Information Bureau who have undergone a three-week skill

upgrading training graduated here on Friday.

During the course of the programme, some 20 journalists working with

the bureau were given theoretical and practical lessons on television

news and programme script writing, filming, sound and film editing and

other related topics.

Swedish radio and television journalists were lecturing at the

training organized by the bureau in cooperation with the Swedish

International Development authority (SIDA).

Meanwhile, a ten-day training programme on tailoring organized for

ten low income group women-opened Thursday in Kemashi town of the

Benshangul-Gumuz Regional State.

The training is organized by the regional women's affairs office in

collaboration with the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP).

It really deserves praise

Late in the week it was reported that the foundation established

after the late Aklilu Lema had signed an education and research

cooperation agreement with the Addis Ababa University. During the

agreement it was indicated that outstanding students and researchers in

about seven faculties of the University would be offered scholarship and

financial assistance every year.

It was also learned that as of next year upto 20 outstanding students

would be assisted besides five researchers who would be entitled to

receive 10,000 birr each year to help bring their research projects to

success. One more point, students selected for their academic excellence

will also be given a stipend of 150 Eth. birr a month, a supply of books

and settlement of payments for tutors on condition that the former keep

their outstanding records.

What is worth noting here is that no matter how modest in financial

terms the incentive given to researchers and outstanding students may

be, yet the idea and intention of it can not go without being commended

especially considering the need of the country for self-sufficiency and

self-dependency. No question, Ethiopia has a hard working people but

unless hard-working is supported and upgraded by Education it will only

have a limited impact on the overall development endeavours. to keep the

country going on the road towards economic self-dependency, an

indigenous innovations and creative are something we cannot afford to

ignore.

But this is only possible by way of a capacity building inn all

aspects of life and the introduction of appropriate reward and

incentives mechanisms for all those who go for it.

Though implicitly and at times explicitly, what had destroyed the

country during the past regimes was its erroneous application of reward

and punishment mechanism which, as it should, was capable of nothing but

an incessant fratricidal war and a primordial economic crisis. What

happened in plain words was that consumption was rewarded while

investment-punished, intelligence was condemned while mediocrity-

blessed, research results that would boost production and overcome

crises was practically taken as an outmoded fashion while irrelevant

say-sos were taken as a mark of excellence.

The price for such inverted mechanism was high-we had to begin from

the scratch and do whatever we can within our capacity to re-introduce

the proper reward and punishment mechanism. it is with this in mind and

on such a ground that the aforementioned foundation really deserve

recognition and praise.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997

Africa News


May 1, 1997


Ethiopia;
AARH expects over rent arrears from embassies


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Agency for the Administration of Rental

Houses (AARH) yesterday disclosed that it expects rent arrears of over

19.4 million birr from 15 African embassies.

Ato Mekonnen Ayalew, head of the registration and contract main

section of foreign national tenants with AARH, said 2.8 million, 2.3

million, 2.2 million and 2 million birr of rent arrears are expected

from the embassies of Gabon, Guinea, the Sudan and Niger respectively. 

According to Ato Mekonnen, from 1.1 million to 1.9 million birr is

also expected from Rwanda, Tanzania, equatorial guinea, Congo and Seirra

Leone embassies.

The head said AARH, moreover, expects from 180,000 to 875,000 birr

from Mali, Uganda, Chad, Mozambique, Burundi and Zaire.

Unless the embassies settle the rent arrears within a short period of

time, the agency will stage by stage cut off electric, water, phone and

other similar services and terminate the rent contract, he added.

7 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 1, 1997


Ethiopia;
President says Ethiopia to step up ties with Denmark


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - President Negasso Gidada yesterday said that

Ethiopia has the desire to step up trade and investment ties with

Denmark.

Receiving the credentials of the newly appointed Denmark ambassador

to Ethiopia, Mr. Klaus Dehilgarad, here at the national Palace,

President Negasso said an enabling environment has prevailed in Ethiopia

for foreign investors to undertake businesses. 

According to a spokesman to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the

President told the ambassador that Ethiopia wishes to strengthen ties

with governments of various countries, including Denmark, in line with

its endeavours for fast economic growth.

President Negasso also briefed the ambassador on the democratization

process, the prevalence of peace and stability and on encouraging

results attained in the economic sector.

The Nairobi-base Danish Ambassador, Mr. Klaus Dehlgaard said on his

part that he has knowledge of the improvements in the economic field

here in Ethiopia.

The ambassador expressed his country's desire to strengthen the

existing friendly relations with Ethiopia.

8 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 1, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
ICRC-OAU seminar on African human rights


BYLINE: Abebe Gelaw, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - The 4th ICRC - OAU seminar for ambassadors accredited

to the OAU on the theme "implementation of IHL-International Criminal

Tribunal" opened yesterday at the Africa Hall.

Ato Kemal Bedri, President of the Federal Supreme Court, said

International Humanitarian law imposes "appropriate sanctions" against

those responsible for grave breaches in the face of the continuing human

tragedies across the globe. Ato Kemal noted, however, that the ongoing

trial of the former Derg officials and other alleged perpetrators of

genocide and other heinous crimes against humanity still remains the

primary role of "municipal law" in dealing with crimes of such

proportions. 

He also expressed hope that the role of domestic law in dealing with

breaches of humanitarian law will be addressed by the two-day gathering.

"I am confident that this seminar will address such questions, identify

issues and advance proposals fitting into our relentless efforts in

ensuring respect for the law," he added.

The OAU Assistant Secretary-General, Ambassador A. Hagag, said on his

part that the seminar for ambassadors accredited to the OAU and also

enlarged to include members of the Security council and Council of

Europe was one vital step forwards the "full and effective"

implementation of IHL through global cooperation which would not only

gave save lives but also ameliorate some of the tragic consequences of

armed conflicts wherever they occur.

Ambassador Haggag pointed out that the OAU had been taking a number

of steps in connection with the protection and promotion of human rights

in Africa. According to Mr. Hagag, the adoption of "African charter on

Human and Peoples' Rights" and the subsequent establishment of the

"African Commission on Human and People's Rights" were significant steps

by themselves. "More recently, a protocol on the establishment of an

African Court on Human and People's Rights has been formulated and re-

examined at the request of OAU Policy organs."

The proposed court on Human and People's Rights should be able to

deal with all violations of human rights but more particularly massive

and systematic violations carried out in this area, he stated.

Ambassador Hagag also hoped that the draft protocol will be formally

adopted by the forthcoming assembly of heads of state and government in

Harare, Zimbabwe.

Mr. Jean Paul Faller, Head of International Organizations at the ICRC

headquarters in Geneva, noted on his part that the seminar was part of

the all-out effort on the part of the ICRC in particular to mobilize

international support for the practical implementation of IHL. He

further indicated that the conclusion and recommendations of the ICRC-

OAU seminar will be forwarded to African heads of state and government

at their summit in Harare in June.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997

9 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 1, 1997


Ethiopia;
House discusses National Seed Agency and trade


BYLINE: Seifu Mahifere, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - The House of Peoples' Representatives yesterday held

the 42nd regular session of its second year of tenure and closely

discussed a performance report of the National Seed Industry Agency.

The general manager of the agency, Ato Gurmu Dabi, said in the report

that a portion of the accomplishment included preparation, licensing and

implementing the agency's structure, securing fairly adequate office

facilities and manpower as well as putting to use transport and

laboratory equipment.

Another major accomplishment of the agency, according to Ato Gurmu,

was conducting, research activities necessary for its day-to-day

operations. these included research on seed regulations, study on

structure, aims, functions and composition of a seed quality approval

and certification committee, study on the gathering of scientific and

technical information on appropriate types of seeds, as well as on seed

multiplication and distribution for peasants in general. Studies were

also conducted on accounting guidelines for seed projects, he said. 

Publicising the agency using various media and fora, issuing licenses

for the import and export of seeds, and implementing seed development

projects were likewise mentioned by the general manager as other

accomplishments.

The seed development project undertakes such tasks as making

available improved seed varieties to farmers, raising the level of

participation of private producers in seed production and distribution,

giving support to government agencies involved in research, seed quality

control and certification activities, and reorganization of the

Ethiopian Select Seed Enterprise, according to Ato Gurmu.

The general manager also spoke of future plans of the agency which

included formulating and implementing a seed regulation, providing wide

ranging services to beneficiaries using laboratory experiments and field

studies on seed quality and control, issuing licences for aspiring

investors in the production and marketing of seeds and providing the

necessary support in seed multiplication by farmers themselves.

According to Ato Gurmu, the agency also plans to facilitate

conditions for the commencement of a seed technology faculty at the

Alemaya University of Agriculture, implement the study for accumulation

of enough seed reserves, and annually publishing documents on select and

approved seed types.

The session which has been especially organized by the House's

standing Economic Affairs Committee, entertained wide suggestions and

questions posed by members of the Assembly to which the general manager

of the National Seed Industry Agency, gave explanations and answers.

Meanwhile, ENA reported that Speaker of the House of Peoples'

Representatives, Ato Dawit Yohannes expressed his belief that the trade

relations existing between Ethiopia and South Africa would further be

strengthened.

During talks with the south African parliamentary delegation, Ato

Dawit said there are numerous sectors of development in which the two

countries, which have been freed from oppressive regimes, can cooperate.

The speaker of the House has told the delegation that Ethiopia has

reorganized regions after removing the command economic system of the

Derg regime and added, in a bid to alleviate poverty, the government has

established several associations that would help enhance public

participation in various development projects.

He further said with the objective of making the country self-

sufficient in food, peasants in the country have been able to produce

surplus grains as they are supplied with agricultural inputs.

The South African parliamentary delegation on its said various

measures are being taken in south Africa in order to help citizens

benefits from the various development activities in the country.

Members of the delegation further said South Africa is one of the

five countries in the world to have requested to organize the 2004

Olympics, adding the International Olympic Committee (IOC) has accepted

South Africa as one of the candidates.

The delegation said south Africa will ask support from the heads of

African countries who will meet in Harare, Zimbabwe, to help win the

competition to organize the 2004 Olympics.

Africa News


May 1, 1997


South Africa;
Police shoot four pro-Mpumalanga demonstrators


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

BUSHBUCKRIDGE - At least four pro-Mpumalanga demonstrators, including

an ANC councillor, were shot and injured by police after one of their

patrol vehicles was burnt by rioting residents in Bushbuckridge on

Thursday afternoon.

The Bushbuckridge South councillor, Doctor Sibuyi, and three members

of the crowd were rushed to Matikwane Hospital and almost immediately

transferred to the Nelspruit Private Hospital.

Sibuyi, who was shot in the head by police while addressing a crowd

of roughly 2 000 demonstrators, was released after receiving treatment

for the flesh wound. 

The three other injured protesters are reportedly in a serious but

stable condition.

The violence began when more than 10 000 protesters who had arrived

at Pauliana Stadium in Bushbuckridge's CBD spilled into the surrounding

streets after Constitutional Affairs minister Valli Moosa failed to

arrive at a scheduled Worker's Day rally.

Demonstrators had hoped that Moosa would address their demands that

the area be ceded from Northern Province and immediately be transferred

to Mpumalanga. Almost 40 000 residents supporting the transfer have,

police said on Wednesday, participated in scattered demonstrations in

the area during the past week.

No violence was reported, however, until Thursday afternoon when

aggressive police fired tear gas into the Pauliana Stadium, sparking an

immediate militant response from youth in the crowd.

Chanting "Moosa, Moosa - Liar, Liar", the protesters streamed out of

the stadium and began re-erecting barricades on the R40 linking

Bushbuckridge with Nelspruit and Marite.

The barricades, consisting of trees and old vehicles, had earlier

been dismantled by police on Wednesday afternoon after tourists and

other travelers were trapped in the area.

White police officers also pushed reporters from African Eye News

Service (South Africa) and SABC Radio News around while they attempted

to cover the burning of a police 4x4 bakkie.

One of the officers screamed that "we don't fucking care if you're

reporters, we want all kaffirs out of this area" when the reporters

protested.

Police also questioned other spectators and asked whether they were

pro- or anti- the transfer to Mpumalanga.

Those who answered 'yes' were beaten with fists and R4 rifle buts by

the policemen.

The crowd dispersed during the tear gassing but later youths began

congregating on street corners and stoned police patrols.

Bushbuckridge was quiet but tense after police began arresting

'loiterers' at 17h30 on Thursday evening.

Northern Province police spokesmen were unavailable for comment.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997

Africa News


May 1, 1997


South Africa;
Litterers may face charges


BYLINE: Scotch Mndebele, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 120 words


 

Ermelo - The Mpumalanga Department of Environmental Affairs has

warned litter bugs in Wesselton, near Ermelo, that they could face

criminal charges if they did not stop their "dirty habits".

Department official, Busi Mbingo, said on Wednesday that

Environmental Affairs representatives visited schools in Wesselton to

"try frighten children into keeping the township cleaner".

She said the school visits were part of the department's Recycling

Project, which also aimed to make children aware of recycling waste.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


12 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 1, 1997


South Africa;
Call for unemployed youth to help police


BYLINE: Landiwe Dlamini, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Nelspruit - Worker's Day celebrations in Mpumalanga's capital city,

Nelspruit, were used to warn police that the province's residents would

no longer allow them to be involved in crime or to be selective in

fighting violence in the region.

More than 200 protesters who marched to the regional police head

office in Nelspruit also demanded in a memorandum that provincial

authorities establish a "Community Youth Cop" programme to draw the

unemployed into the fight against crime. 

"The youth know their townships and also know who the criminals are

in the area. They are young and energetic and are therefore the perfect

partners for an undermanned police force," explained former ANC senator

Jackson Mthembu.

Criticising the police for not acting against known criminals, who

"terrorise our townships", Mthembu added that police also failed to

respond to crime in black areas as quickly as in white areas.

"Racism still exists in the police and is taking place at an

unprecedented pace. The slow response of the police to crime reports

shows it to everyone. The youth will no longer allow corruption and the

ANC will not hesitate to expose it in the police - even if top officials

are involved," he said.

The memorandum, which was handed to Captain P Roodt by ANC Youth

League secretary, James Nkambule, also called for stricter bail

conditions and terms for serious offenders, such as rapists, murderers

and child abusers.

Nkambule is currently fighting arson and assault charges in the

Nelspruit Regional Court.

In addition to the demand for a Community Youth Cop programme, the

memorandum also called for quicker response times to general crime in

black residential areas, and an end to racism and corruption.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


13 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 1, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Profile: Rodney Phillips


BYLINE: Sharkey Isaacs, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Cape Town - The new numero uno at the Baxter Theatre complex, Rodney

Phillips, has no regrets about quitting his promising career overseas

and returning to the land of his birth.

At 50, he resigned as deputy general manager of the prestigious

Sydney Opera House to take over at the Baxter - one of 40 or so

candidates who applied for the coveted post of director and chief

executive.

Phillips, who is also deputy chairman of the Arts and Culture

Committee of the Cape Town City Council, is determined to bring the arts

to a wide spectrum of audiences.

"I have spent practically half my life improving my skills and

talents, starting as a front-of-house worker welcoming audiences to the

Nico Malan Opera House," he said. 

"I have enjoyed every minute of it and I want to give back some of

the expertise to the land of my birth. It is going to be a challenge to

run a theatre in a new South Africa.

"I don't believe in doing it alone and I am sharing my ideas and

different views with others. I network regularly with directors from

other theatres and we hope to find a workable formula. We are confident

we will find the right formula for bringing audiences flocking back to

the theatre. We are seeking to captivate a new audience because the old

audiences we had are fast disappearing."

Phillips said he was prompted to leave Australia "partly because my

12-year-old daughter, Aileen, and my wife, Gillian, were always

hankering to return to Cape Town to meet our relatives".

Tripping down memory lane, he vividly recalled how his career began

with a job as "front-of-house" worker at the Nico Malan Theatre. There

he sought to carve a career for himself in theatre administration, "but

to my great dismay I discovered there was nowhere in Cape Town or

anywhere else in South Africa that one could train for such a

profession".

After obtaining a Bachelor of Commerce degree at the University of

Cape Town, he applied for post-graduate course in London. He mastered

his craft and became sought after by "headhunters" in the theatrical

world.

In addition to being technically and artistically knowledgeable,

Phillips also gained a wealth of experience from appointments to top

posts such as the administrative head of the Nico Malan Opera House, the

Port Elizabeth Opera House, deputy general manager of the State Theatre

in Pretoria and chief executive to the Natal Performing Arts Council

(Napac), which he was credited with transforming and opening up for all

races.

He held his Napac post for several years before venturing overseas.

"I left our shores out of frustration at the slow pace of change and

the general gloom and doom in what was then, unbeknown to everyone, the

tail end of the apartheid era," he said.

He was appointed general manager of the Lyric Opera of Queensland in

Brisbane and held the position for five years before being chosen from

more than 100 applicants for the Sydney post.

Last year, after seeing many changes and experiencing the new

political climate while on a holiday in Cape Town, he decided to return.

"I was heartened by the positive vibe and new spirit and was

overwhelmed by a desire to return to my roots and plough back some of my

skills in the cultural development of the land of my birth.

"The Baxter, which had not had a subsidy for its day-to day

operations for 19 years under the previous government, last year gained

its first small grant from the Department of Arts and Culture.

"I have no illusions about what is expected of me in a new South

Africa. It is a great challenge and I have a great opportunity to build

on a very solid platform established by my predecessor."


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

14 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 1, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ukhozi gets stake in City Press


BYLINE: Thabo Mabaso, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Cape Town - Cape-based black investment grouping Ukhozi has

successfully negotiated with two other up-country partners for a 51

percent stake in Nasionale Pers' City Press newspaper.

The up-country groupings are Durban-based Dynamo Investments, which

is headed by former Inkatha Freedom Party secretary general Oscar

Dhlomo, and New Season's Investment, a company chaired by former

KaNgwane chief minister Enos Mabuza.

Dr Dhlomo told the Cape Argus that the consortium had bought the

stake for R110 million. 

Ukhozi will own 10 percent of City Press, with 20 percent going to

Dynamo and 10 percent to New Season's.

The remaining shares will be made available to City Press staff, six

percent, and distributors, five percent.

Naspers will retain the other 49 percent.

The deal's tax efficiency was recently confirmed by the Receiver of

Revenue.

All that remained to be done was for the parties to sign

documentation authorising the sale, Dr Dhlomo said.

City Press has a weekly circulation of over 250 000 and ranks third

after top-selling Sunday newspapers the Sunday Times and Rapport.

Negotiations for the sale of the paper have been going on for close on

two years.

Ukhozi managing director Lizo Ngcokoto said he was delighted that the

deal had received the green light.

"The deal broadens Ukhozi's media interests. It gives us an

opportunity to have a sound asset base in the media industry."

The sale also means that the consortium acquires Gauteng-based Khaya

FM, a radio station in which City Press holds a stake.

Mr Ngcokoto said Naspers had given the consortium pre-emptive rights

to buy magazines Drum and True Love if they are sold.

Funds to acquire the City Press stake had been raised with a South

African financial institution.

"We engaged one of the biggest banks in the country and the financing

mechanism is structured in such a way that it achieves the goals of

black economic empowerment."

Mr Ngcokoto would not name the bank or give details of the financing

mechanism.

The City Press deal is the fourth empowerment acquisition in as many

months. Other newspapers that black investors have bought into include

the Sowetan, Sunday Times, and more recently, Enterprise magazine.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

15 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 1, 1997


Sports - General;
A tale of two cities, with a twist in the tail


BYLINE: Hugh Roberton, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2107 words


 

Osaka - The scene: a small confectioner's store in a residential

neighbourhood of Osaka, Japan. I am trying to find out what the shelf

life is of the cakes and chocolates on display. Nobody understands me.

An elderly Japanese gentleman enters and translates. He asks

conversationally: "So, where are you from?" I reply: "Cape Town, South

Africa." "Ah," he says, "Cape Town 2004, the Olympic city." He 

translates for the shopkeeper, who raises both thumbs in delighted

support.

Of the many surprises which a Capetonian might encounter in the

bustle of modern Japan, perhaps the most agreeable is the discovery that

Cape Town enjoys far wider, and far more positive, name recognition than

"Johannesborregi" or, for that matter, any other city in Africa. And,

almost invariably, it is because of Cape Town's bid for the 2004 Olympic

Games.

In many encounters with Japanese during a visit to Japan last month

for the launch of the first South African Airways service to Japan, I

found "Cape Town" and "2004 Olympics" to be almost synonymous. The

Japanese knew about Table Mountain, the city's old identifying icon, but

they especially knew that Cape Town was one of the five finalists in the

race to host the 2004 Games - and they were intrigued.

Their interest is understandable and, to some extent, selfish. And it

could be ominous.

Osaka, Japan's second largest city, is a huge, wealthy and sharply

focused contender for the 2008 Olympics. So is Yokohama (which,

confusingly, is also described as the country's second largest city),

and the two are now embroiled in an thunderous face-off. And, of course,

Tokyo hosted the 1964 Olympics and Nagoya will be hosting the next

winter Olympics. So, Japan is Olympics-sensitive to a degree which few

other countries are.

In Osaka, there seemed to be a pervasive belief that Cape Town would

be knocked out of the 2004 race by Athens or Rome, and that Osaka (or,

they reluctantly concede, Yokohama) would face Cape Town in the battle

for the 2008 Games.

"Now we are comrades in the struggle," Takashi Onodera, general

manager of Osaka's Olympic Bid public relations department told me, "but

we may be opponents in 2008 - and we take Cape Town very seriously as a

potential rival. That would be what you might describe as Osaka's worst

nightmare."

His colleague, Shigeyuki Matsushita, felt Cape Town enjoyed vastly

more international recognition than Osaka. "In the Far East, Osaka is

well known. But if you mention Japan to the average European or

American, or African, they think of Tokyo. We are trying to change that,

but we do not have a Table Mountain, or an Eiffel Tower or a Golden Gate

bridge, or anything which can distinguish us in the minds of people as a

city in its own right.

"Cape Town used to be like that. I think some people used to think

that Table Mountain was in Johannesburg because Johannesburg was the

South African city we then knew most about. But your Olympic Bid has

given you a lot of recognition. Ah, people say, the city with that big

flat mountain is Cape Town, it is fighting for the Olympics in 2004, and

maybe in 2008, and that is a battle we understand, which we have

witnessed before in our own country. Cape Town today is a familiar name,

with its own identity, throughout Japan. It has far overtaken

Johannesburg in name recognition."

As domestic interest in Japan's Olympic ambitions has grown, so, too,

has interest in Cape Town and other contending cities as tourist

destinations.

"Cape Town has had a lot of attention in Japan with the Olympic bid,

and now that there is a direct SAA air link between Osaka and

Johannesburg and on to Cape Town, there is a lot more interest - mostly

in Cape Town," said Masuji Takagi, a leading Osaka travel and tourism

analyst.

The twice-weekly SAA link, from Johannesburg via Bangkok to Kansai

(Osaka's new and breathtaking airport), is expected to boost tourism in

both countries, but Chuhei Sanjo, general manager of one of the largest

travel companies in Japan, who has been involved in travel to and from

South Africa for more than 33 years, sounds a warning.

"Japanese tourists are very demanding. They expect good service,

value added service and, given the fact that the typical Japanese

tourist has between eight and 10 days a year for a holiday, 12 days at

the absolute most, and that they would have to forfeit perhaps more than

two days of that in flying back and forth to South Africa, they want

something out of the ordinary; a very special experience.

"Yes, they like Cape Town and they like the game parks of Africa.

They have the money to travel there, but what is crucial to them is the

time and the quality of the experience.

"For these reasons, I would caution against expectations of the new

air service bringing about an explosion of Japanese tourists at this

stage. There will be more, for sure, but not a sudden deluge."

I asked Mr Sanjo what the Japanese tourism industry thought of the

general service quality in Cape Town, the preferred destination of the

15 000 Japanese who now visit South Africa each year. With evasive

politeness, he smiled and replied: "Cape Town is a beautiful city."

A widely voiced Japanese complaint about visiting South Africa is the

difficulty of communicating with South Africans, even in English. The

diversity of South African accents falls confusingly on the Japanese

ear, even the ears of those Japanese who have studied English and who

use it fluently in conversations with English-speaking visitors in

Japan.

"It has something to do with the way South Africans pronounce vowels,

and the difference in pronunciation between white and black South

Africans when they use English. There does not appear to be a standard

form of the language in your country. Also, Japanese pronunciation of

English is sometimes difficult to follow unless you are familiar with

the mistakes we typically make in pronouncing consonants," a

professional translator told me.

"The solution is to train more Japanese-speaking guides, and here

Cape Town should take the lead as the city which most Japanese tourists

want to visit. To my knowledge, there is only one such guide in Cape

Town. That's not good enough. Perhaps you should fly in Japanese

students during our summer vacations. But something should be done."

Will more South Africans visit Japan now that there is a direct SAA

link? They should. Japan is a wonderland of modern efficiency,

politeness and cleanliness - and safety. And it has a rich history and

tradition which makes it easily as fascinating as any of the present

popular destinations in the Far East.

What appears to deter many South Africans from venturing into Japan

are the prices and, indeed, it is a very pricey country even by London

and Paris standards. Like all freemarket economies, though, Japan offers

a wide spectrum of prices for just about everything - if you are

prepared to be adventurous and explore areas of the country where most

tourists might not venture.

The subway systems in cities like Tokyo and Osaka, for example, are

highly accessible to strangers and are the antidote to expensive (and,

late at night, ruinously expensive) taxis. They are clean - and entirely

safe. All maps, notices, directions and names are given in Japanese and

English. There are information kiosks at most of the major stations with

fluent English-speaking assistants. And I discovered that looking lost

with a map in hand is an irresistible temptation to young Japanese eager

to practise their English and show off their city.

The costly tourist hotels, likewise, can be replaced by "ryokan"

(traditional Japanese inns), or by family-run "minshuku" (guest houses),

and many Shinto shrines and Buddhist temples offer overnight

accommodation. Standards of cleanliness and safety are excellent, and

prices are a fraction of what you would pay in a hotel.

The cheaper restaurants in the underground malls of larger railway

stations and shopping centres are not only interesting and authentic,

but usually are delighted to receive foreign visitors. And the

traditional night-life areas of the big cities, such as Dotombori Street

in Osaka or the Akasaka area of Tokyo offer excellent and inexpensive

meals, a bewildering panoply of pubs, sushi bars, hostess clubs, pinball

arcades and specialty stores where not many tourists go.

Japanese trains are efficient, clean and punctual and one of the

great wonders of the country is the Shinkansen, or "bullet train" which

flashes across the countryside at an average of more than 400km an hour

between Osaka and Tokyo.

Osaka offers brilliant shops, symphony concerts, festivals, museums,

markets, harbour tours and a new waterfront development which contains a

spectacular aquarium encompassing marine life of the entire Pacific rim.

Osaka is also a convenient entry and exit point for a brief stay that

could exclude Tokyo, an immense but somewhat trying city.

Kyoto, the old imperial capital, with its magnificent palaces,

castles and stroll gardens, is a 40-minute bus ride from Osaka. It was

spared by American bombers during the war and is today a city of immense

charm and interest - as is the neighbouring city of Nara.

Kansai airport, which serves the entire greater Osaka region, is a

dazzling science fiction feat of design and engineering; an airport to

beat all airports. It offers probably as many connections to other

cities of Asia and the Pacific as does Narita airport outside Tokyo.

While Tokyo is a tiring metropolis, it is also most imposing and has

much to inform Capetonians about the Olympics.

"When we hosted the 1964 Olympics, Japan had no real sense of itself

as a major economic entity and Tokyo did not see itself as a world

city," according to Hidekazu Morishima, general manager of international

planning at the giant Nissho Iwai Corporation. "The '64 Olympics

propelled us into the modern world and gave Tokyo a huge economic boost.

It was a milestone in our development."


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

16 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 1, 1997


South Africa;
2004 team recruits gangs to fight crime


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Cape Town - Turning gangsters into peace-makers is the essence of a

revolutionary Olympic-related strategy being launched today to enlist

the underworld in the fight against crime.

Gangs and their members are to be given responsibility for curbing

violence and lawlessness in terms of a manifesto in which they declare

their willingness to "act as the protectors of the community".

But the drug trade will not be affected by the project at this stage. 

The strategy, dubbed the Olympic Peace Initiative, will run for

three-months, with the emphasis on curbing murder, rape, assaults,

robbery, housebreaking and theft.

The first project from today until May 14 will be to rid the central

city and Bo-Kaap of criminal activity, and clear street kid gangs from

the area.

Township children will be taken back to their homes, in terms of the

plan, and those without homes will be taken to child-care centres. Gangs

have undertaken to "use their influence" to halt central city muggings

and other crimes.

The launch of the potentially controversial scheme follows weeks of

discussions with gang leaders, who on Monday committed themselves to an

inter-gang peace accord, and to stopping all crimes of violence against

the community by their members. More details will be announced later

today.

The gangs' commitment to a peace manifesto will be monitored by an

independent group of prominent community leaders. Ultimately, the aim is

to rehabilitate gangsters and draw them into the mainstream of society.

The leading figure in the project is Brian Williams, chairman of the

Cape Town Community Olympic Forum, an independent, pro-bid body

representing civics and other organisations.

Mr Williams said the approach carried "huge risks", but had the

potential to "dramatically reduce crime", and deserved support since all

other strategies had failed. "The gangs will take ownership of the anti-

crime strategy and be responsible for it. We think this is a coup, to

get gangsters to become peace-makers."

Minister of Justice Dullah Omar had "reacted positively" to the

initiative in a meeting this week. The strategy was also discussed by

the Cabinet at its meeting in Pretoria yesterday. Bid Company chief

executive Chris Ball, who supports the initiative, was present at

yesterday's meeting.

Conditional support has also been given by the Cape Chamber of

Commerce and Industry, and other community organisations.

Mr Williams said Pagad had been informed, adding: "We believe there

is no difference between our objectives and Pagad's objectives."

The Schotse Kloof Civic Association representing an area that is

about 98 percent Muslim has unanimously backed the initiative.

Association chairman Yusuf Larney said: "It's no use fighting and

killing each other, because the problem will still be there. Our

affiliate organisations have backed this 100 percent."

Mr Williams said crime and violence constituted the major weakness of

South Africa's bid, and this had impelled the Community Olympic Forum to

launch the peace initiative.

"I am not afraid of the risks of this initiative because my political

record is sufficiently strong to sustain me against any kind of

integrity attacks. All we are asking for is three months, to see if this

strategy can work. We have tried everything else."


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


17 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 1, 1997


South Africa;
Why we must give peace a chance


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Cape Town - The strategy to engage gangsters directly in a fresh bid

to curb crime deserves to be given a chance, especially since

conventional law and order initiatives have failed to produce results.

This is the view of Brian Williams, one of the key figures in the

Olympic Peace Initiative, being launched today.

He is chairman of the Cape Town Community Olympic Forum, an

independent organisation representing several hundred civics and other

community organisations in promoting the bid. 

Mr Williams, a former unionist, is the director of the Department of

Labour in the Western Cape. He acknowledged that the "law-breakers to

peace-makers" initiative carried "huge risks" but argued that since

gangsterism was at the heart of much of the lawlessness and violence of

the Western Cape, it was foolhardy to assume that a solution could

exclude gangs themselves.

Crime had been singled out as the biggest threat to the Olympic

opportunity, and was a huge cost to the economy.

"We are asking the public to give this initiative a chance. Let us

see what can be achieved. The overall objective is to secure a way to

integrate gangsters into the mainstream of society, to draw them into

rehabilitation and vocational programmes and to help them get jobs."

Mr Williams added: "All anti-crime approaches have been on a level

which excludes direct involvement with gang leaders. What we have done

is to undertake this as a principled campaign."

He also acknowledged there was a measure of scepticism about the

"morality" of concluding peace contracts with gang leaders, a point

raised in an otherwise supportive letter to the forum by Alan Lighton,

executive director of the Cape Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

Mr Williams said: "This is an issue, and we will encourage open and

healthy debate about it.

"While there may be a contradiction in this, we believe the

initiative has the capacity to propel us towards a solution, towards

reconciliation, community healing and ultimately the creation of jobs

and the generation of wealth.

"There is a powerful economic logic embedded in the project which

compels us to go this route. Every other route has been tried. Law and

order budgets of the past few years have increased steadily, but so has

crime.

"So our plea is that we be given the space to attempt this considered

route to achieve a reduction in crime."


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 1, 1997


South Africa;
Promises and delivery (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Cape Town - The government has announced a drop in the rate of some

serious crime and has projected significant breakthroughs in the

delivery of its reconstruction and development promises

Perhaps more so than the promises made by most governments, those

proclaimed by South Africa's new and untried administration when it

first took office were met with acclaim but also with a good measure of

scepticism. And as the country's many problems - especially the alarming

crime rate - continued to grow unabated, the scepticism appears to have

turned into a cynical pessimism.

But in a mid-term "report to the nation", the Government has claimed

progress in delivering on its promises. The report says that the rate of 

serious crime dropped in nine out of 20 categories last year, including

murder, car hijackings and aggravated robbery.

The report also projects imminent breakthroughs in the delivery of

RDP projects, stating among other things that the school feeding

programme will benefit some 5-million pupils by the end of the year,

that 200 000 houses will be built, and that the community water supply

and sanitation programme will serve a further 1,7-million people this

year.

While the projected delivery on RDP projects might still fall within

the definition of promises, the reported national drop in some serious

crime has been presented as a fait accompli and appears to be supported

by available evidence from the police and other sources. This is most

encouraging.

In several surveys crime has been identified as the single greatest

concern of most South Africans, transcending even poverty, and whether

or not the Government is able to meet the deadline it has set for

delivery on social programmes this year, progress in combating serious

crime should help to reduce the debilitating spirit of cynicism and

pessimism which seems to pervade so much of the country.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


19 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 1, 1997


South Africa;
Five hurt in Pagad raid in Bo-Kaap


BYLINE: Johan Schronen, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Cape Town - A small army of about 30 heavily armed Pagad members

invaded the Bo-Kaap early today, opening fire on the home of an alleged

drug dealer with pistols and shotguns before setting fire to it.

Five occupants of the house were injured, two of them seriously, when

they were beaten up as they fled the fire. The house, which the

attackers destroyed with petrol bombs, was listed as a national

monument.

It was the fifth and by far the largest attack this week on suspected

drug dealers, and police have now given top priority to investigating

the conflict. 

Police believe all five attacks were carried out by members of People

Against Gangsterism and Drugs.

The mini-invasion at 3.10am was aimed at three brothers, Noor,

Mogamat and Abdurachman Jardien and their families, in the Chiappini

Street home they shared. It lasted about 15 minutes.

The Jardien family denied dealing in drugs.

A tearful Noor Jardien, 61, said a "squad" of about 30 masked men

carrying shotguns, pistols, pick-handles and petrol bombs surrounded the

house and broke windows with their gun barrels.

"I was sleeping in my room upstairs when I heard glass breaking

downstairs," said Mr Jardien.

"The next moment all hell broke loose. Gunshots rang out, they were

shooting through the windows from the outside - and then they lobbed

petrol bombs through three of the windows at the front, side and back of

the house. We were trapped.

"I ran downstairs, but smoke and flames drove me back up. The only

way out was through a window on to the roof." The sickly Mr Jardien had

to jump from the roof of the house to escape the fire.

"It's a miracle nobody was wounded in the gunfire," he said.

"The shooting just carried on - my brothers and the women and

children were hiding under their beds while bullets flew over their

heads."

Meanwhile the attackers assaulted the men one by one as they emerged

from the burning house.

Mr Mogamat Jardien was pistol- whipped and chased to Rose Street by a

man wielding a pistol.

Abdurachman Jardien, 20, was hit over the head and in the face with a

pick handle and collapsed on the ground. Salie Jardien was pistol-

whipped and afterwards had blood gushing down his face from a deep cut

in his head.

A family friend, Patrick Matthews, also had serious head injuries and

was taken to hospital with Mr Abdurachman Jardien.

The attackers damaged a minibus parked in the backyard of the house.

Today's raid followed four previous Pagad-related attacks in the past

five days.

In Athlone a car was damaged early yesterday after a home-made device

exploded on it.

The car belonged to George Smith of Kudu Street. Mr Smith also denied

he was connected to drug-dealing.

Two home-made bombs were hurled at homes of suspected drug dealers

early on Monday and a bomb exploded at the home of an Ottery man on

Sunday, causing severe damage to the house and vehicles.

Police said the home-made devices which were hurled at houses in

Cassel Street and Bolton Road, Crawford, did not explode but broke

windows.

The angry owner of the Ottery house that came under attack early on

Sunday, Hendrik April, challenged Pagad to meet him "face to face" in

daylight.

Mr April said he had been warned earlier to stop dealing in drugs,

but still came under attack.

More than R200 000 damage was caused to a minibus, a car, the house

and garage.

Meanwhile police have intensified their efforts to investigate Pagad,

drug-dealing and gangsterism.

Police spokesman Mark Romburgh said police had prioritised Pagad-

related attacks since the weekend and would would focus their anti-crime

plan on these activities.

Captain Romburgh said the continuous attacks on drug-dealers, or

people thought to be drug dealers, was illegal and could also target

innocent people.

"We will leave no stone unturned to bring the perpetrators to book ,"

he said.

"Police management appreciates the community's stance against

gangsterism and drugs.

"But people cannot be allowed to take the law in their own hands.

The community must supply police with information about drug dealing

or any other illegal activities - then we will act," said Captain

Romburgh.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


20 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1997


Zaire;
Salim Says Zaire Needs Negotiated Transition


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The OAU Secretary-General, Salim Ahmed Salim,

says parties to the Zairian conflict should seek a negotiated transition

rather than military solution to the crisis in the country.

"We (the OAU) have been saying that it is important to put an end to

the war and negotiate a transition that will create a new dispensation

in Zaire," he said on Thursday in Lagos on his way to Abuja for the

African First Ladies peace conference beginning in the Nigerian capital

Monday. 

Salim said the OAU supported the meeting expected to be held Friday

or Saturday between embattled Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko and

Laurent Kabila, leader of the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the

Liberation of Congo (Zaire).

He said although forces of the Alliance which have captured more than

half of the country in a six-month military campaign had an advantage,

the talks would however provide a "unique opportunity to discuss the

question of transition".

The OAU chief was accompanied by a 30-member delegation including a

United Nations representative, as well as delegates from Malaysia and

the Economic Commission for Africa for the Abuja conference.

The OAU and the Commission support the first ladies meeting, which

Salim said would address the problems of refugees and displaced persons.

He said it was a way of mobilizing women on how to deal with crisis

on the continent, citing the Great Lakes region, Liberia and Sierra

Leone as examples.

"Even when the conflict has been resolved, you still have the

problems of the refugees... and what Africans and the international

community can do," Salim added.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


21 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1997


Business and Finance;
Irish Expert To Run Air Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - An Irish airline expert, Brendon Donohoe,

takes over as Air Zimbabwe chief executive on Monday, following an

agreement reached between the national airline and Air Consult

International (ACI) of Dublin, Ireland.

Donohoe, who has been appointed on a two-year contract, is expected

to steer the commercialization of the troubled airline, which is

expected to be transformed into a profit-making company registered under

the companies act.

His appointment comes at a time the government of Singapore has been

pushing for its own national to take over at the helm of Air Zimbabwe

following discussions held between President Robert Mugabe and Prime

Minister Goh Chok Tong of Singapore when he paid an official visit to

Zimbabwe in March. 

An Air Zimbabwe statement released on Friday said under the

agreement, "ACI will provide consultancy services...to assist INL002

from SSS.059 (970502-17:46) QN PANAINL .PANADKR MSG058G/02E PANA PANA

PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PAN(2) the airline specifically

in the management of the commercialization of the airline".

"The consultancy will also assist Air Zimbabwe in the general

management of the business of the airline during this commercialization

period for a minimum of 24 months."

The Air Zimbabwe board has already presented the ministry of

transport and energy with a draft memorandum and articles of association

for the new company, while the ministry is finalizing legislation to

repeal the Air Zimbabwe act.

The statement said discussions were underway to establish a special

relationship between Air Zimbabwe and Singapore Airlines, adding: "this

relationship will further revamp and strengthen the operations of Air

Zimbabwe in various areas, including training and lease of aircraft."

Donohoe was chosen from a group of "highly experienced" personnel

offered by two Irish consultancies and has 33 year's experience in the

airline industry, 16 of them with the Irish national airline, Aer

Lingus, and the others with airlines in Europe, the West Indies and

Africa.

Air Zimbabwe has been without a substantive head for over one year

following the dismissal of former managing director, Huttush Muringi.

The director of technical operations, Peter Chikumba, has been

acting.

LANGUAGE: English
