Africa News


May 2, 1997


Burundi;
Burundi Denies Links with Zairian Rebels


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Burundi's agriculture and livestock

minister, Damase Ntiranyibagira, on Friday in Harare, refuted

allegations that his country is aiding Zairian rebels led by Laurent

Kabila.

Ntiranyibagira told journalists after paying a courtesy call on

Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe that Burundi had its own problems and

could not afford to assist other countries in any way. 

Zairian authorities have alleged that the Tutsi-led military

government in Bujumbura together with Rwanda and Uganda, were helping

Kabila's Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo

(Zaire).

"These are unfounded allegations. Burundi has its own enormous

problems and has no intention to interfere with affairs involving her

neighbors," he said.

Kabila's troops are already in control of more than half of Zaire and

are reportedly poised to over-run the capital, Kinshasa, anytime, to end

President Mobutu Sese Seko's 32-year old rule.

The rebel leader and Mobutu are, however, expected to hold a meeting

either Friday or Saturday to try and find a negotiated settlement to the

six-month crisis.

Ntiranyibagira also said he had brought a "brotherly" message from

the Burundi leader, Maj. Pierre Buyoya, who seized power in a military

coup on July 25, 1996.

"This is a message in which our leader expressed his gesture to the

Zimbabwe government for what it did for the Burundi people and hope that

the two countries will accompany each other in their peace paths," said

Ntiranyibagira.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


23 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1997


Business and Finance;
African Fund Loans Zambia 20.8 Million Dollars


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The African Development Fund, an affiliate of

the African Development Bank, has loaned Zambia 20.8 million U.S.

dollars for agricultural investment in the country's eastern province,

the fund said Friday.

The agricultural project is aimed at increasing the Gross Domestic

Product, eradicating poverty, increased household income, providing

greater mobility and access to information on markets and prices. 

So, the programme will focus on developing plant production and

cattle rearing, research, training, construction, building access roads

and water distribution networks. Other aims are to provide for rural

investment, and an agricultural loan fund.

Also in the programme are provisions for supporting agro-forestry and

soil conservation.

The loan will enable Zambia to pay for all foreign currency costs of

the programme, estimated at 38 million dollars.

So far, the African Development Bank group has approved 38 loans and

11 grants (not including three multinational operations) to Zambia,

representing total commitments of 455.21 million units of account (about

631.32 million dollars).

At least 42 percent of amounts approved came from the fund.

The loans and grants have been used for 27 projects, five credit

lines, three structural adjustment programmes and nine studies.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


24 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Kanu May Play For Nigeria In Next World Cup Tie


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerians Friday welcomed reports that their

soccer star, Nwankwo Kanu, has fully recovered from his heart problem,

raising the hope that he could feature in the June 7 World Cup African

zone qualification match against Kenya.

The country's sports minister Jim Nwobodo was philosophical on

hearing the news. "The Lord has done something wonderful for the

country. We should all be grateful," he said. 

"It is a welcome development for Nigerian football," declared Rtd

Col. Abdulmumuni Aminu, chairman of the Nigerian Football Association

(NFA).

Aminu, who led a government delegation earlier this year to see Kanu

at the Cleveland hospital in the U.S. where the player underwent surgery

to rectify a defective aorta valve, said "Kanu has so much to offer not

only to Nigeria but the entire soccer world." The Nigerian government

sent Kanu 50,000 U.S. dollars to help settle his medical bills for the

heart operation.

News of the player's recovery featured prominently Friday in

Nigeria's vibrant press. The story was competing for space with results

of the British general election.

"Kanu For France 98," screamed the "Nigerian Tribune", in a reference

to Nigeria's campaign for the World Cup qualification.

The "Daily Champion" came up with the banner "Kanu Now Fit To Play,"

a sentiment shared by most other national dailies.

Kanu was the skipper of the Nigerian under-23 squad that won Africa's

first Olympic soccer gold in Atlanta in 1996. He was later voted the

African Footballer of the Year 1996.

But trouble started when the striker decided to change clubs,

switching from Ajax of the Netherlands following a two-year contract he

signed with Italy's Inter-Milan.

Inter-Milan's cardiologists alarmed the soccer world with news that

Kanu had a heart problem that could end his career.

But on Thursday, the Cleveland hospital surgeons, who operated on him

five months ago, certified him fit to resume his soccer career.

One of the doctors, John Kramer said Kanu, 20, "is stronger now

physically than he was before the operation".

Popular opinion in Lagos is that Nigeria's search for a play-maker is

now over with Kanu's recovery.

Without the lanky player, Nigeria's campaign for the World Cup ticket

has been described as lack-lustre by soccer fans.

The country's next match is against Kenya on June 7 in Lagos. To keep

its chances for qualification, the team needs a win, after both teams

played a 1-1 draw in Nairobi in the first leg, in Nairobi. Although

Nigeria is currently on top of Group I, which also includes Burkina Faso

and Guinea with 10 points, the Super Eagles need a convincing win

against Kenya, which is second, to clinch the France '98 ticket.

Aminu says he has no objection to fielding Kanu in that match against

Kenya, although the decision is for the national team's technical crew

to make.

Nigerian FA sources indicated that the new "Super Eagles" technical

adviser, frenchman Phillipe Troussier, who is soon to embark on an

European tour aimed at assembling Nigerian players, is expected to

contact Kanu for the crucial match on June 7.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


25 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1997


Zaire;
All set For Zairian Peace Talks


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

KINSHASA, Zaire (PANA) - The Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko has

left Kinshasa for Pointe Noire, Congo, to attend crucial talks with

rebel leader Laurent Kabila, whose Alliance of Democratic Forces for the

Liberation of Congo (Zaire) has seized at least half of the country.

The peace talks, to be brokered by South African President Nelson

Mandela, are to be held Friday or Saturday aboard a naval ship provided

by Pretoria, which will anchor in international waters off the Congolese

Atlantic Ocean oil seaport. 

Reports from Lome indicated that the Togolese President, Gen.

Gnassingbe Eyadema, will join Mobutu in the talks aimed at bringing a

peaceful end to the Zairean war, launched six months by the Alliance

from the eastern part of the country.

Eyadema, who hosted a summit of the Organization of African Unity

(OAU) central organ for the prevention, management and settlement of

conflicts in March, was invited to the talks by the Zairean Foreign

Minister, Gerald Kamanda wa Kamanda.

The talks will also be attended by Mohamed Sahnoun, the United

Nations and OAU Joint Special Envoy to the Great Lakes, as well as an

envoy of President Bill Clinton, Bill Richardson.

The American envoy has for the past few days been shuttling between

Kinshasa and the rebel-held territory, in an effort to reconcile the

positions of the two sides over the planned talks.

Initially, the Mobutu-Kabila meeting was expected to be held in

Libreville, Gabon. However, Gabonese officials said the port of

Libreville lacked the capacity to receive the South African naval ship.

For what were described as health reasons, Mobutu, who is suffering

from prostate cancer, objected to an earlier suggestion that the talks

be held in South Africa.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


26 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
WFP Emergency Report No. 18 - Africa (05/02)


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3240 words


 

Rome - This report includes: A) Burundi, Rwanda, Zaire and Tanzania

B) Uganda C) Sierra Leone D) Angola

Note: because of the holiday on 1 May in Rome and in many of the WFP

offices reporting on countries below, most information in this issue of

the Emergency Report is as of 28/29 April.

PART I - HIGHLIGHTS (Details below in Part II)

A. EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE AND

TANZANIA

1. Zaire - information as of 29 April

a) Air and road survey missions to locate Rwandan refugees south of

Kisangani continue. Some 10,000 refugees located near Biaro camp.

b) On 29 April, a limited number of trucks are allowed to deliver

supplies and return with refugees from Biaro. A train loaded with 115 

metric tons of WFP food commodities is delayed awaiting clearance, but

as of 1 May had reached Biaro.

c) Rebels move several hundred refugees from Biaro to Kisangani by

train.

d) Alliance authorities set deadline of sixty days for UN to

repatriate Rwandan refugees, but deadline may be flexible. Authorities

agree to open up roads and airports for the repatriation. First airlift

of refugees directly to Kigali takes place on 27 April. Both WFP and

UNHCR planes are involved in the repatriation operation.

2. Rwanda

a) Plans for a Food Assessment Unit under discussion between WFP,

USAID, FAO and the National Food Committee. Ongoing discussions with

SCF-UK concerning a Food Assessment Monitoring and Household Food

Security Survey Unit.

3. Burundi

a) Short-term assistance required in Gatara commune, Kayanza

province, as a result of recent crop damage caused by a violent storm.

b) Clearance sought from AFDL to move food to Uvira via Burundi, to

prepare for return of Zairian refugees now in Tanzania.

4. Tanzania

a) Some 7,000 refugees from Burundi cross into Kasulu district

through the Biharu and Kitanga border points between 21 and 27 April.

The most vulnerable refugees are moved by truck by UNHCR to transit

centres in Kasulu.

b) Repatriation of Zairean refugees in Kigoma to Uvira to start once

clearance for operation obtained in Uvira. Of the estimated 80,000

Zaireans in Kigoma, 5,000 have registered for repatriation.

c) Deteriorating road conditions in Kigoma hamper food deliveries.

B. UGANDA

1. Update

a) Attacks on refugee settlements reported in several parts of

northern Uganda. Clashes between government and rebels and deteriorating

security situation constrain work of aid agencies in Gulu.

C. SIERRA LEONE

1. Update

a) Three-month resettlement rations distributed by WFP to 220,000

resettled internally displaced persons in early April; operations now to

concentrate on rehabilitation and development.

b) Spontaneous demobilisation of small groups of RUF rebels

continues, but power struggle within RUF is threatening the peace

process.

D. ANGOLA

1. Update

a) FAO/WFP Crop and Food Supply Mission begins.

b) Demobilisation process gains momentum with the establishment of

the Government of National Unity and Reconciliation.

PART II - DETAILS

A. EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE,

TANZANIA

1. ZAIRE - most information as of 29 April

1.1 Aid agencies continue to carry out air and road survey missions,

trying to locate Rwandan refugees scattered in forests south of

Kisangani. As reported last week, over 85,000 refugees left their camps

at Kasese and Biaro, following attacks by local villagers and rebels. On

28 April, a group of some 10,000 refugees was found between km 30 - 41,

in the vicinity of Biaro camp. Hungry and exhausted refugees continue to

emerge from the forest and the number of refugees at Biaro is now

estimated to be between 10,000 and 15,000. Arrangements have been made

to provide food and medicines to the refugees at this site, which is

expected to become a temporary centre and transit point until the

refugees are repatriated to Rwanda.

1.2 Despite guarantees given by rebel authorities, access and safe

passage for staff and vehicles carrying relief assistance for Rwandan

refugees is still problematic. On 29 April, an eleven-truck convoy

loaded with food and medicine left Kisangani, towards the south. It was

planned that the trucks would deliver food and medicines to the refugees

concentrating at Biaro, and then return to Kisangani carrying refugees

for repatriation to Rwanda. Only three trucks were allowed to pass by

rebel authorities and only a small number of refugees could return to

Kisangani. A train loaded with 115 metric tons of WFP food commodities

and some non-food items also waited several days for authorisation to

leave Kisangani for Biaro. Update: as of 1 May, the train had reached

Biaro.

1.3 Alliance authorities have given the UN sixty days to track down

and repatriate Rwandan refugees, but in more recent discussions with the

American envoy to the UN, Ambassador Richardson, they have indicated

that this deadline may not be strictly applied. Authorities have agreed

to open up roads and airports for the repatriation. The plan is to move

the refugees who are between Kisangani and Biaro to Kisangani and from

there by air to Rwanda. The refugees who are concentrated between Biaro

and Ubundu will be moved to the airstrip at km 95 from where they will

be flown to Rwanda. The first airlift of refugees directly to Kigali

took place on 27 April. On 30 April, several hundred refugees were moved

from Biaro to Kisangani by train, a trip organised by rebel authorities.

These and other refugees arriving in Kisangani are being flown to Kigali

in WFP and UNHCR planes.

1.4 The international airport at Kisangani is now open for aid

flights. WFP planes airlifting food from Entebbe in Uganda and Mwanza in

Tanzania started landing there on 30 April, instead of at the Municipal

airport used so far. From 21 and 27 April, WFP delivered over 550 metric

tons of commodities to Kisangani. WFP stocks as of 29 April total 1,040

metric tons of various food, representing a 22 days supply for cereals,

14 days supply for pulses, 37 days for oil, 31 days for salt and a 3

days supply of corn soya blend, for a caseload of 100,000 beneficiaries.

1.5 ICRC has airlifted some 3,000 displaced Zaireans from Kisangani

to Goma, since the beginning of this operation on 15 April. It is

estimated that the total number of internally displaced persons still

remaining in Kisangani is around 6,000 to 7,000 persons, a much lower

figure than previously estimated. A new registration exercise is under

process, to determine the new caseload for purposes of food

distributions.

2. RWANDA

2.1 From January to end April, WFP delivered 53,455 metric tons of

food to projects and distribution centres in Rwanda. Of this total, 36,

510 metric tons were provided for distribution to returnees and

displaced persons, amounting to 2.9 million rations of mixed food

commodities. WFP plans to move some 14,000 metric tons of food

commodities to Rwanda during the month of May.

2.2 WFP has released the first instalment of funds to support relief

food distributions by the National Food Committee (NFC). WFP is

presently procuring vehicles and bicycles for delivery to the NFC. The

procurement process is due to be completed by mid May. In total, WFP

will provide up to USD 293,000 to the NFC.

2.3 WFP is discussing with USAID, FAO and the National Food Committee

the establishment of a Food Assessment Unit. Discussions have also been

maintained with SCF-UK related to a Food Assessment Monitoring and

Household Food Security Survey Unit. It is expected that this unit will

identify pockets of poverty and areas considered to be vulnerable,

helping WFP to target programme activities more accurately and assisting

in building the capacity of the Government in the management and use of

food aid.

3. BURUNDI

3.1 WFP has conducted a road transport assessment of the route to

Uvira, in anticipation of planned road convoys through Burundi to Uvira.

This is in view of the expected pre-positioning of food in Uvira for the

returning refugees from Kigoma camps in Tanzania. All clearances have

been received from the Burundian Government and clearances from AFDL

authorities are now awaited.

3.2 WFP is considering the provision of short-term assistance in

Gatara commune, Kayanza province, after a storm devastated crops in the

area.

3.3 Current food stocks in Burundi stand at 2,586 metric tons. This

is sufficient to cover requirements for the next month, except for

pulses which are sufficient to cover requirements for two weeks. From 21

to 27 April WFP distributed 527 metric tons of food to 173,336

beneficiaries.

4. TANZANIA

4.1 Close to 7,000 Burundian refugees crossed the Biharu and Kitanga

border points and entered Kasulu district in Tanzania, between 21 and 27

April. UNHCR is trucking the most vulnerable refugees while the others

are walking to transit centres in Kasulu.

4.2 The repatriation of Zairean refugees in Kigoma has not yet

started, pending clearance from UNHCR in Uvira, Zaire. There are an

estimated 80,000 Zaireans in Kigoma and 5,000 have already registered

for repatriation. It is considered likely that if a first group

repatriates successfully, most of the others would follow. Food to Uvira

will be transported either by barge from Kigoma or by truck through

Burundi, as described above.

4.3 Deteriorating road conditions in Kigoma continue to hamper food

deliveries. Trucks are stuck 75 km away from Kasulu, heading towards

Lugufu camp. This is affecting the stock position of food commodities in

the camp. Very poor road conditions are also affecting the supply of

water to the camp.

B. UGANDA

1. UPDATE

1.1 Security remains uncertain in many parts of northern Uganda.

Rhino Camp, a Sudanese refugee settlement in Arua was attacked on the

night of 21 April. An NGO compound in Arua was also attacked. In

Palorinya, another settlement for Sudanese refugees located in east

Moyo, refugees and local populations have reported harassment and

looting. In Gulu, the deteriorating security situation is limiting

movements of aid agency personnel and the road between Gulu and Pakelle

is described as unsafe, with clashes between Government soldiers and

rebels reported in the Atiak area.

1.2 The Government of Uganda wants all Rwandan refugees who arrived

from Tanzania during December and January, and who are presently in

camps in south-western Uganda, to repatriate by 15 May. Government

officials visiting the camps have been passing this message to the

refugees and advising that no food or other form of assistance will be

provided after this date. Some 7,000 Rwandan refugees came to Uganda

from Tanzania but many have since left the camps. Presently there are

only 3,000 such refugees in camps in Uganda.

C. SIERRA LEONE

1. UPDATE

1.1 WFP completed distribution of three-month resettlement rations to

more than 220,000 resettled internally displaced persons in early April

and is now concentrating assistance to rehabilitation and development-

oriented programmes. Some 50,000 families are currently involved in

food-for-work and food-for-agriculture activities nation-wide. Food-for-

agriculture activities include the rehabilitation of thousands of acres

of coffee, cocoa, oil palm, citrus fruit, banana and pineapple

plantations to jump start the local economy. Food-for-work activities

include the construction of housing and shelter in areas of resettlement

and the rehabilitation of roads leading to villages.

1.2 The National Technical Committee is implementing a combined food

basket monitoring and food security survey to gauge the effectiveness of

targeted feeding programmes and ensure that they are meeting the needs

of people during this transition period. WFP continues to provide

emergency rations to displaced populations where and when necessary as a

result of isolated security incidents.

1.3 A total of 57 rebels have surrendered to local authorities and

spontaneous demobilisation continues. Although this kind of

demobilisation is seen as a positive sign, the peace process is at a

standstill as the power struggle among the rebels continues since the

ousting of RUF founder Foday Sankoh in March. On 29 March, three members

of the Commission for the Consolidation of Peace were abducted by RUF

fighters loyal to Sankoh. The Government of Sierra Leone has urged the

international community to put pressure on the RUF to release the

hostages and move forward with the peace process.

D. ANGOLA

1. UPDATE

1.1 A two-week FAO/WFP Crop and Food Supply Mission began on 28 April

in Luanda. The mission will visit the provinces of Bie, Bengo, Benguela,

Cunene, Cuanza Norte, Cuanza Sul, Huambo, Huila and Moxico to assess

national food production levels and review overall relief requirements

for the next year.

1.2 The demobilisation process has gained momentum since the

establishment of the Government of National Unity and Reconciliation. A

total of 2,567 soldiers have been successfully demobilised from Central

Region quartering areas of Vila Nova (1,009), Londuimbali (203) and

Quibala (897) and from the special war disabled centre of Bonga (458).

The exercise is currently continuing at the N'Gove and Chicuma

quartering areas in the Southern Region. Overall, 3,505 soldiers have

been demobilised since the exercise first began with under-age soldiers

in September 1996.

1.3 A large-scale government resettlement plan is scheduled to begin

in June in Huila province as the impact of the overall peace process

extends further. WFP Lubango staff will assess food and other conditions

at proposed resettlement sites for some 14,700 families residing in

displacement camps in Huila and Namibe provinces, in early May. WFP also

plans to assist in the transportation of families to their areas of

origin. Food and seed protection packages along with non-food items such

as building materials and agricultural tools will be distributed to

returnees.

1.4 Under a WFP-assisted food-for-work project supporting both

internally displaced persons and local villagers, work was completed on

the 185 km-long Luanda-Dondo (Cuanza Norte province) railway on 26

April. This is the first time since 1991 that the railway has been

operational.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


27 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1997


Swaziland;
Government Plans Editorial Policy For State-Media


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Windhoek - The Swaziland government says it is in the process of

designing an editorial policy for all government-controlled media, a

statement issued on April 21 from the Prime Minister's office reads.

"This policy will take cognisance of the Swazi Nation's interest for

balanced information instead of being hijacked and controlled by certain

pressure groups," it states.

The statement has been signed by the Director of Public Policy

Coordination Unit in the Prime Minister's office, Meshack Shongwe.

However, privately-owned newspaper, Times of Swaziland, reported that

government's statement was coming barely after reports that authorities

criticised Swazi Television for its full coverage of opposition

Swaziland Democratic Alliance (SDA) demonstrations. The article appeared 

in the papers April 22 Edition.

The SDA went on a demonstration on April 12 against the 1973

Proclamation banning free political activity. April 12 marked 24 years

of the King Sobhuza 1973 Decree.

The Decree effectively nullified the 1968 Constitution as well as

free political activity and the right to free expression.

Swazi Television had covered and broadcast in full police disruption

of the opposition SDA protest demonstrations on April 12.

A senior journalist for the weekend state-controlled newspaper, The

Swazi Observer, told MISA that about 18 people were brutally assaulted

by the police during the crackdown.

Afraid to be named, the journalist said: "Journalists were barred

from taking pictures of the police crackdown on demonstrators." The

journalist spoke to MISA on Friday, May 2.

The Swazi Observer newspaper reported in its April 23 edition that

the Swaziland National Association of Journalists (SNAJ) condemned the

government's attitude towards the media.

The Association's Secretary-General, Banele Ginindza said in a

statement that censorship, in any form, does not augur well with a

nation that claims to embrace the principals of democratic governance.

Ginindza reportedly said that if what government spokesman, Meshack

Shongwe had said was not dictatorship "then SNAJ does not know what to

call it." Adding: "Censorship of the media in any form is self

misleading of a government that aspires to develop the lives of its

people."

By attempting to censor the media, Ginindza reportedly went on,

government is leaving the whole nation in the dark about what goes on in

the country. "'Surely,'" Ginindza reportedly said, "'the nation can read

between the lines on the kind of governance it will be subjected to if

the new (media) policies are successful.'"

Gininzda was also reported as saying that "'the question of who makes

the news has never been left at the discretion of the government for

precisely the same reason that governments are easily dictatorial.'"

Meanwhile, on April 15, the government issued a press statement in

which it said it was concerned by media reports that "journalists were

not given or afforded the freedom they so deserve."

The statement, however, said the government wished to reaffirm that

freedom of the press was guaranteed in line with acceptable

international standards and other relevant conventions.

The statement adds: "It is not the intention of this Government to

dictate media policy for private sector media houses, and in turn, we do

not expect these media houses to dictate policy to Government."

Apparently referring to the April 12 SDA protests, the statement

adds: "It is the responsibility of Government, however, not to promote

illegal activities, hence Government owned Media Houses shall not be

encouraged to promote illegal activities."

Minister for Public Service and Information, Muntu Mswane, issued the

statement and was aired on Radio Swaziland on April 15.

MISA-Swaziland has equally criticised government's move saying: "The

media in Swaziland will be facing yet another pillar of censorship."

For further information, contact David Nthengwe, researcher, Media

Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), Private Bag 13386, Windhoek,

Namibia Tel. +264 61 232975, Fax. 248016 e-mail:

research@ingrid.misa.org.na


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


28 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1997


South Africa;
Mpumalanga's fun also lays across the border


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1254 words


 

Nelspruit - Gauteng socialites relocating to Mpumalanga may find the

experience to be a traumatic trek into a cultural desert where Afrikaans

folk singers and awkward school plays are presented as "art" by

municipal theatres.

The shortage of bookshops and cinemas will also make the move more

alarming, but the province does have redeeming features which, once

found, may turn the trek into a voyage of discovery.

Not only is the province home to international tourist destinations

such the Kruger National Park, Pilgrim's Rest and the Blyde River

Canyon, it also borders Mozambique and Swaziland, two international

tourist destinations offering a touch of the exotic at cheap prices.

But, being a tourist in Mpumalanga is a lot different to being a

resident, especially once the novelty of living in the "Land of the Big

Five" begins to wear off. 

So what do the regular residents do for fun, especially considering

that the provincial capital, Nelspruit, has only one cinema which has

three theatres specialising in movies of the Jean-Claude Van Damme and

Leon Schuster variety.

Those who have escaped from Gauteng for whatever reason, say they

have successfully adapted to Mpumalanga's more "rural" lifestyle,

despite the lack of big city sophistication.

"We don't go looking for fun, but create it ourselves," says Leigh

Voigt, a well-known wildlife illustrator who moved to the Lowveld from

Johannesburg 20 years ago, to build a home on a mountain top with her

artist husband and former advertising executive, Harold Voigt.

She explains that the province has the best book discussion club in

the country, which has been meeting for the past 20 years, and that a

film society at one stage hired movies from Johannesburg to be watched

and discussed by society members.

Today, the numerous video shops in town are popular and where those

art movies not shown at the cinema are readily available.

Attempts to promote the Nelspruit Art Gallery were, however, a dismal

failure, says Voigt, who was also curator at the gallery for eight

years.

"There was just no culture in this town. I'd organise an art exhibit

and only 20 people would come, and then they'd all be my friends," she

laughs.

The Nelspruit town council recently built a yellow-brick theatre with

government-style floor tiles which so far has presented numerous school

plays, hypnotists, and, overwhelmingly successfully for a conservative

town, the Soweto String Quartet.

In general however, residents of especially Witbank and Middelburg

happily drive the hour-or-so journey to Johannesburg or Pretoria to

attend the big city theatres and art galleries.

Those in the Lowveld do so too, but have also found Maputo City to be

a fulfilling attraction.

"Mozambique is very much the in-thing at the moment," explains Auke

Keyser, chairperson of the Nelspruit Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

Not only does it offer an African-Portuguese flavour, but also pristine

beaches, unspoilt reserves and some of the world's best fishing spots.

"The hijacking of visitors to Mozambique hasn't put anyone off either

- they always believe it will happen to their neighbour," Keyser

explains.

One person who frequently socialises in Maputo and has a flat there

is Orna O'Reilly, an internationally acclaimed interior decorator who

decorates ambassadors homes in Maputo.

"I go to lots of dinner parties in Maputo and on holidays or weekends

spend time on the beaches where we lie in the sun and drink beer," she

says.

"We often go to Piggs Peak in Swaziland as well and try our luck at

gambling," she adds.

One place in Mpumalanga that is no longer quiet at weekends or

holidays is Dullstroom, the trout fisher's paradise. Over weekends,

Pajeros and 4X4s which seldom hit dirt roads in Gauteng suddenly clog

Dullstroom's main street and the fly and tackle business booms.

You'll also find numerous locals waist high in cool lakes and happily

throwing a line, despite the intrusion by the loud "city types".

What initially attracts those "city types" to the Lowveld, says

Nelspruit Publicity Association agent, Christelle Thompson, is the good

weather and scenery of the region.

"We have about 150 people a day showing an interest in moving here,

five to 10 percent of which actually relocate," Thompson says.

"Obviously the fact that all the big businesses are also in Nelspruit

plays a big role," she adds.

Young entrepreneurs and career starters in Gauteng who have kept an

eye open for business opportunities, soon heard of the Maputo Corridor

and have arrived in swarms to start up small businesses.

Initially balking at the lack of nightclubs and "hang-outs" the self-

starters have instead joined local hiking clubs and para-gliding

outfits, as well as sport clubs such as the local mountain biking club

and golf club.

The old Nelspruit, a one-horse town surrounded by rich burly farmers

and their burly wives has quickly given way to a more genteel society

which has learnt to accept that yoga classes are not as evil as the

dominee said.

The three cars which constituted home-time traffic, has swelled to

about 50 and the end of month traffic stretches across three consecutive

traffic lights as the small town groans under the pressure of a

population explosion last seen during the Gold Rush.

Nelspruit has become a mini city where farmers coming into town for

their monthly shopping sprees have learnt that driving slowly in their

Toyota Hiluxes is just as hazardous as those city types whizzing by in

their Pajeros.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


29 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1997


South Africa;
Court challenge to affirmative action policies fails


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Nelspruit - Legal opposition to the Mpumalanga Tender Board's policy

of awarding contracts to provincially based black companies crumbled

this week after the Pretoria High Court dismissed the only serious

challenge to the policy.

The legal challenge, mounted by Tricor Industries in September 1995,

accused the Tender Board of racism, bias and malpractice for failing to

award a R1-million sign board contract to it.

Tricor submitted the lowest tender offer but made no attempt to

comply with the Tender Board's stated policy of favouring companies

which set up local offices or brought in a black joint venture partner. 

After loosing the tender, Tricor charged that the Tender Board had

ignored all economic or technical criteria and had instead used its

affirmative action and black empowerment policies as the sole criteria.

High Court Judge Kirk Cohen said on Wednesday that even if the

original contract was set aside, Tricor would not benefit as the one-

year contract had already been completed and a second related contract

had also recently been lost by Tricor in favour of the same company

which previously won; Matane Nameplate Joint Ventures.

He added that the case was therefore only of academic interest and

that it appeared as if Tricor want to use the issue to build a damages

claim against the Mpumalanga Provincial Government.

"The ruling is quite a victory for us, as it vindicates our policy of

trying to empower local black companies. Previously, because we are a

new and quite rural province, all the large companies operated from

Gauteng," said Tender Board member, Vincent Khoza.

"This meant that all the potential wealth creation resulting from

government projects flowed out of Mpumalanga. Our policies are designed

to keep that money here, where it does our people the most good."

Khoza added that the stipulation that companies should include some

form of joint venture with black or other disadvantaged companies had

also been abused by tender bidders who used black faces as "window

dressing".

"This use of front men is one of our biggest problems at the moment.

The policy was designed to force experienced companies to share their

expertise with emergent businesses but instead, we have a few front men

getting rich for doing nothing while the predominantly white companies

continue doing all the work," he explained.

As a result, the Tender Board has just launched a 'Joint Venture Task

Team' to redesign the criteria for valid joint ventures and now place

the emphasis on measurable forms of capacity building.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


30 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1997


South Africa;
Police call for public to finger bad cops


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

BUSHBUCKRIDGE - Following allegations that police fired

indiscriminately on protesters in Bushbuckridge this week and threatened

journalists, Northern Province police have appealed to the public to

come forward with information so that an internal investigation can be

conducted.

Bushbuckridge residents blocked major roads, including the road to

the Kruger Gate of the Kruger National Park, with burnt-out vehicles on

Wednesday in an attempt to force the Northern Province and Mpumalanga

governments to agree that Bushbuckridge be incorporated into Mpumalanga.

On Thursday, police were again sent in when a crowd of about 10 000

people went on the rampage after Minister of Constitutional Affairs,

Valli Moosa, failed to arrive and address them at the Paulianah stadium.

Secretary of the Border Committee, Sizile Ndlovu, said demonstrations

had been peaceful, until hundreds of police arrived in five hippos, a

helicopter and police vans. 

"The situation got out of control because the police arrived to shoot

and kill, instead of bringing peace and stability," Ndlovu said.

Northern Province police spokesperson, Superintendent Phuti Setati,

said the demonstrations were not peaceful, as a complex of more than 10

Home Affairs offices was burnt, as were a tractor, a government van and

a police bakkie.

Four people were also injured during the shooting, including

Bushbuckridge South councillor, Doctor Sibiya, who was grazed in the

head by a bullet.

On Friday, two large refrigerated trucks were ambushed and set alight

by toyi-toying protesters at Marite near Bushbuckridge. Police arrested

10 people, who are expected to appear in the Bushbuckridge magistrate's

court on Monday.

Minister Moosa said he would not apologise for not addressing

Bushbuckridge residents because "I was not invited to address any rally

in Bushbuckridge".

He was instead scheduled to address a Workers Day rally at

Roodepoort.

Superintendent Setati said police were concerned about reports that

police threatened journalists at the scene with physical violence.

A Sunday Times correspondent was questioned by police for 30 minutes

before being allowed to take photographs.

Journalists, including an SABC radio news reporter who were standing

away from the crowd, were fired at with teargas.

"One policeman shouted at me from a hippo that he would kick my balls

off if I took any more photographs," said correspondent, Leonard

Ndzukhula.

"Another policeman said he didn't care if I was a journalist, but

that I had to leave because they were trying to get rid of all the

kaffirs," Ndzukhula added.

Politicians have been accused of being responsible for the past

week's violence after three years of haggling over whether Mpumalanga

should exchange Groblersdal, Motetema, Tafelkop, Vaalbank and Marble

Hall for greater Bushbuckridge.

In the mean time, no local government elections have taken place in

these towns.

This week, the 40 000 residents from Bushbuckridge and the

surrounding areas of Marite, Shatale, Dwarsloop, Thulamahashe, Casteel,

Manyeleti, Acornhoek, Mkhuhlu and Matibite started two weeks of

demonstrations, in an attempt to expedite their inclusion in Mpumalanga.

ANC regional chairperson, Freddy Mathebula said Bushbuckridge was

supposed to have been included in Mpumalanga by the end of March, 1995,

according to an agreement reached with the both provincial governments

in September 1994.

"But the ANC made a blunder when it tied the Groblersdal issue to

Bushbuckridge. Now Groblersdal doesn't want to go to Northern Province

and Bushbuckridge also wants to go to Mpumalanga," he explained.

Last year, Northern Province MEC for Local Government, John Dombo,

was stoned and shot at by Groblersdal residents demanding inclusion into

Mpumalanga.

Two years ago, Northern Province Premier, Ngoako Ramatlhodi, was held

hostage for more than eight hours by pro-Mpumalanga demonstrators in

Bushbuckridge.

He was only released after Mpumalanga Premier Mathews Phosa flew in

and pledged to incorporate Bushbuckridge into his province.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 2, 1997


South Africa;
Rioting youths arrested for ambushing, burning trucks


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

BUSHBUCKRIDGE - Ten youths were arrested by police in Bushbuckridge

on Friday afternoon after two large freight trucks were ambushed and

burnt by pro-Mpumalanga demonstrators in the Marite area.

The youths were part of a 2000 strong crowd in the peri-urban

settlement who are still demonstrating to demand that the region

immediately be transferred from Northern Province to Mpumalanga.

No one was hurt in the ambush but damage to the trucks, from the

Kiepersol Banana Farm near Hazyview, is estimated to be worth hundreds

of thousands of rands. 

The youths are scheduled to appear in court on Monday, with protest

leaders warning that even worse violence can be expected when residents

take to the street to show their solidarity with the youths.

Elsewhere in the greater Bushbuckridge region, thousands of residents

marched on police stations in Acornhoek, Thulamahashe, Marite, Mkhlulu

and Bushbuckridge CBD to hand over memorandums accusing Constitutional

Affairs minister Valli Moosa of "blatant political betrayal".

Insisting that it was unconstitutional for the government to link the

transfer of Bushbuckridge to Mpumalanga with a similar transfer of

Groblersdal from Mpumalanga to Northern Province, the memorandum said

that the people of Bushbuckridge had no political faith in Moosa

anymore.

The demonstrators also demanded the immediate withdrawal of the

Instability Unit and police re-enforcement's from Pietersburg and

Heodspruit which were sent to the area on Wednesday. Bushbuckridge

Border Committee secretary Sizile Ndlovu accused the "foreign" police of

sparking off the violence by opening fire on protesters with rubber

bullets, live ammunition and tear-gas.

"We demand that the local police be deployed in Bushbuckridge, as

they understand the people and issues better," he explained.

Protesters also burnt a Home Affairs office complex in Shatale, near

Bushbuckridge, a government tractor and flat-bed truck and police 4x4

patrol van on Thursday after four demonstrators were shot by white

police officers.

One of those injured was Bushbuckridge South councillor Doctor

Sibuyi, who received a flesh wound on the head while addressing a small

impromptu rally.

The Border Committee said on Friday night that it did not plan any

marches on Saturday but would be launching a series of protests over the

next 14-days.

Tourists to the Kruger National Park have been advised to use the

Malelane or Numbi gates, instead of the Kruger or Orphen gates until

police have issued an 'all clear'.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 2, 1997


South Africa;
Leaders refuse to help launch anti-crime plan


BYLINE: Lindsay Barnes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Cape Town - The Cape Town Olympic Bid Company's novel plan to harness

gangs to fight crime had a setback when four prominent community leaders

refused to attend the launch.

Hours before yesterday's ceremony, the four, who had been asked to

monitor the initiative, had requested a postponement on the grounds that

it was "premature", said businessman and former political activist Peter

Jones, speaking on the group's behalf.

The four community leaders had committed themselves to work for

"significant community peace" and had been approached by Olympic bid

chief Chris Ball's team to monitor the initiative. 

Their refusal to take part in yesterday's launch at the Civic Centre

was not a snub to the programme, Mr Jones said. "It is not ominous. We

are not ready," he said.

"We have not fully satisfied ourselves as to the sustainability of

the initiative in the manner in which it is now being put forward and we

think it is premature."

The group consists of Mr Jones; Nombulelo Mkefa, chief executive

director of the Community Peace Foundation; Matt Esau, a prominent

Anglican cleric in Mitchell's Plain; and Gavin Pieterse, Western Cape

president of the Black Management Forum .

"We need to understand fully what is being proposed and what it is we

are supposed to monitor, and the level of seriousness and commitment of

all parties," Mr Jones said.

At yesterday's launch there was an unlikely "marriage in brothership"

between Rashied Staggie, a gang leader who says he has reformed, and

Brian Williams, head of the Community Olympics Forum to make Cape Town a

safer place.

Mr Williams denied any knowledge of the community leaders refusing to

join the initiative because of the gangster element. At the ceremony,

the gangsters signed an agreement to help slash crime - starting with

the city centre - in the next few months in the run-up to the

announcement in September of the 2004 Olympic Games host city. The new

anti-crime initiative was put to the Cabinet in Pretoria this week, but

Mr Williams would not divulge details of the discussion and said it was

up to the Cabinet to make a statement.

LANGUAGE: English

33 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1997


South Africa;
Stephen Smith: Gentile who founded UK's Holocaust memorial


BYLINE: David Yutar, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1427 words


 

Cape Town - Beth Shalom means "house of peace".

This was the name chosen by a remarkable young man called Stephen

Smith, when, in the autumn of 1995, he founded Europe's first dedicated

Holocaust Memorial Centre.

Situated in a serene, sylvan setting on the edge of Sherwood Forest

in Nottinghamshire, the centre provides a lasting and functional

memorial for the millions of Jews who died in the Nazi death camps.

Originally a Christian retreat, Beth Shalom was also conceived as a

place where the Holocaust and its implications for humanity could be

confronted by Jew and non-Jew alike. 

But Beth Shalom is unique for another reason. It is also the world's

first such museum to be conceptualised, established and run by a

Gentile.

Unassuming and modest, dignified and articulate, 29-year-old Stephen

Smith explains how almost single-handedly he established what in the

almost two years of its existence has been universally acknowledged as a

remarkable achievement for humanity.

Born in Derbyshire, Smith "grew up in the coalfields in

Nottinghamshire" where he attended a local comprehensive school.

When he was about 13, his parents took him and his younger brother,

James, to Israel on a holiday.

"We went as a Christian family to discover the Holy Land, but while

we there we discovered that Judaism, which previously had been

restricted to the Old Testament for us, was alive and well."

The experience inspired Smith to embark on the study of theology and,

in particular, the relationship between Judaism and Christianity.

"It stimulated one big concern for me and that was the history and

development of anti-Semitism."

Smith then decided to research Christian theological responses to the

Holocaust.

"I felt that the Holocaust was a pivotal moment in this relationship,

which involved Jews as victims and Christians as perpetrators, this time

with even more disastrous consequences."

It was at about this time that Stephen Smith and his brother James

visited Yad Vashem (the Holocaust memorial in Jerusalem).

"We went asking: 'What does the Holocaust mean to us as young people

at the end of the 20th century?'

Stunned by what they saw, the two men felt compelled to respond to

what they had witnessed.

"I suppose we felt we couldn't see that, understand what was

happening and then just go on with our lives as if we hadn't seen it."

Smith returned to England, where he was struck by the abysmal lack of

concern about the Holocaust.

With the help of his brother, he decided to do something himself.

After a year at the Oxford Centre for Hebrew and Jewish Studies,

Smith began his Ph D at Leeds University on "the impact of the Holocaust

on Christian thought and practice".

In the years before Beth Shalom first opened, Smith had toured the

sites of the death camps as well as Holocaust institutions in Europe,

the United States and Israel.

"I felt this was important because there was little experience in

Britain on what to create and how to create it."

It was during this time that the vision for Beth Shalom began to take

shape in his mind. After attending a four-week Holocaust educators'

course at Yad Vashem, he held discussions with some Christian

organisations and lay educators who "failed to show any particular

interest".

It was with "little money and little hope" that Smith eventually

turned to his family for a solution.

His parents had bought the 19th-century farmhouse in Sherwood Forest

in north Nottinghamshire and had set it up as a Christian retreat under

a family charitable trust.

"They were more than happy to turn the place over to set up a

Holocaust education centre."

Helped by his family and a handful of volunteers and with the modest

family savings as well as the profits from his own confectionery

business, Smith established the $1,5-million (R6,7-m) project.

The idyllic setting, in the heart of Robin Hood country, sheltered as

it was from large urban centres, provided the perfect environment for a

commemorative and educational centre.

"It's a strange combination, Robin Hood and the Holocaust, but

actually the rural setting and the tranquillity adds quite a powerful

dimension to it."

The fact that it is not only provincial but rural, means that people

have to make the effort to visit and when they do, they are usually

"ready to engage with the issues", says Smith.

To counter the relative isolation of the centre, Beth Shalom runs

three travelling exhibitions entitled Another Time, Another Place, which

tell the story of the Holocaust in a manner ideally suited to secondary

school students approaching the subject for the first time.

Stephen Smith explains why he felt it important to seek financial

assistance from individual donors and sponsors who were all exclusively

non-Jewish.

"In my reading of Holocaust literature, it became clear that the

majority of people who were documenting the Holocaust were Jewish.

"That's important because obviously it has a huge impact on the

Jewish community in this century and will have in the centuries to come.

"But what concerned me was that there had been such a minimal

response from outside the Jewish community.

"I was very disappointed because society in general, and the church

in particular, did not appreciate what the Holocaust was as a historical

phenomenon," says Smith, who was brought up as a Methodist in a

relatively religious home.

"I felt strongly that there should be a significant response to the

Holocaust from a Christian perspective. It was important for the Jewish

community to know that we cared about it; and that we cared enough to

actually do something. But even more important was for non-Jews to see

that other non-Jews cared about it."

During its first year, more than 20 000 schoolchildren visited the

centre and Smith, who lectures in Holocaust studies at the centre, aims

to reach many more in the years to come.

But Beth Shalom is not just an education centre.

Says Smith: "We want Beth Shalom to live up to its name, to be a

house of peace for the sake of the survivors and victims."

o Smith will be the main speaker at a Holocaust Remembrance Day

service at Pinelands Cemetery on Sunday at 11am.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


34 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1997


Business and Finance;
JSE pessimism about Sea Harvest 'unwarranted'


BYLINE: Llewellyn Jones, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Cape Town - The pessimism shown towards Sea Harvest on the

Johannesburg Stock Exchange was understandable but not justified,

managing director Louis Penzhorn said at the release of the Cape fishing

company's results yesterday.

Although Sea Harvest's share price tumbled to a low of 400c this week

against 525c at the beginning of the year, Mr Penzhorn said the

company's business was stronger than ever.

The company's results certainly reflect Mr Penzhorn's confidence with

net profits rising 18 percent to R27,9 million in the six months to

March. 

Mr Penzhorn attributes investor pessimism to the uncertainty with

regard to fishing quotas.

"Everybody was hoping that this year would produce some tangible

results and would bring a degree of finality for the industry - instead

the industry remains in limbo," he said.

While the 1997 total allowable catch of hake was increased to 153 700

tons, the entire industry has been allocated provisional quotas which

are four percent lower than last year.

Mr Penzhorn said he was hopeful that Sea Harvest's quota would be set

at a similar level as last year's once the Quota Board reviewed the

unallocated portion of this year's total allowable catch.

Mr Penzhorn remained confident for the company's long-term prospects.

"We have just gone through a huge asset renewal programme and

continue to diversify our portfolio."

The company had just completed a R12,5-million upgrade at its

processing plant in Hout Bay which was geared to producing seafood and

other products based on non-quota fish.

The impact of the upgrade should start flowing through in the second

half of the financial year, he said.

"We also made a very important investment in an abalone (perlemoen)

farm 20km east of Port Elizabeth."

He said it would take three to four years to show a return on the

investment because "abalone take that long to grow".

They would be sold mainly on the export markets.

Mr Penzhorn said most of the investment in new vessels and in

upgrading facilities was already bearing fruit.

"We have held market share and increased exports by our ability to

deliver quality frozen products that consumers know that they can rely

on."

In the shorter term, Mr Penzhorn did not expect the company to match

first-half earnings growth in the second half of the year.

"Unfortunately the authorities have decided to further disadvantage

the fishing industry by withdrawing fuel tax subsidies from March.

"This makes the fuel price paid by South African fishing companies

among the highest in the world and, coupled with a stronger rand, this

will hamper export opportunities in the months ahead."


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


35 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1997


South Africa;
Britain's election and South Africa (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Cape Town - Britain's labour party scored a record victory yesterday

in a general election which has attracted the interest of governments

and political analysts throughout the world

Britain's decline as a world power has tended to obscure the

country's contemporary contribution to social and economic change around

the world. It was, for example, the country which conceived and launched

privatisation and which was the first to begin to fundamentally

challenge the socialist precepts of organised labour and Marxist

ideology which have so pervasively influenced the world for the greater

part of the century.

For South Africa, and many other countries which now face the painful

transformation that comes with privatisation, welfare reform and budget

austerity and which have hitched their wagons to the concept of a market

driven economy, yesterday's general election in Britain holds much

interest. For the first time in 18 years of momentous change, a new 

government with a new outlook and ethos is in charge of a country which

played a pioneering role in changing the way modern societies organise

themselves.

The new British government faces daunting problems that are products

of this change, and how it deals with them will be of compelling

relevance to South Africa and other countries which in many important

respects have followed the British lead.

The extent to which the new Labour Party government will influence

South Africa's fortunes in the field of investment and trade could also

be significant. It has a longer and closer relationship with South

Africa's ruling party than its predecessor did; it also has a more

constructive approach to Britain's role in the European Union. These are

encouraging portents for South Africa, which potentially stands to

benefit from the change in Whitehall and which also needs friends and

influence in Europe at this critical stage of its development.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


36 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1997


Sports - General;
RUGBY: Control crime or I'll stay in UK - Stransky


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Cape Town - South Africa's World Cup rugby hero and former Western

Province darling Joel Stransky has threatened to quit the country unless

crime is brought under control.

Speaking to the London correspondent of Die Burger, the former

Springbok flyhalf said he was weighing up the possibility of applying

for British citizenship when his three-year contract with Leicester

expires. 

He said South Africa was the most beautiful and most wonderful

country in the world.

But he now had a family - his wife Karen had a daughter, Sabrina,

eight months ago - and if safety in the country did not improve, he

would stay in England.

>Top Johannesburg economics consultant Ronnie Bethlehem was shot dead

during a hijacking - his third in two years - at his northern suburbs

home.

Police said Dr Bethlehem returned home about noon yesterday and was

parking his car in the garage when two armed men accosted him.

The robbers shot him twice before fleeing with his Mercedes Benz. He

died on the scene.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

37 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1997


Ethiopia;
A History of Twentieth Century Ethiopia, Part 17


BYLINE: Dr Richard Pankhurst, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1347 words


 

Addis Ababa - Ethio-American Post-War Relations

We saw last week that Ethiopia's Post-World War II Relations with

Britain were far from satisfactory, and the Emperor, in the mid 1940s.

reduced his contacts with that country. Now read on:

Post-War Reconstruction

The 1940s and early 1950s constituted an important period of post-war

reconstruction. Decrees designed for the most part to bring the entire

country under centralised, and standardised, administration, were issued

as early as 10 March 1942. Dealing with a wide variety of subjects, 

including significantly enough taxation, they were from that date

published regularly, in the Negarit Gazeta, of official gazette. They

bore the signature of the Minister of the Pen, or official writer of

proclamations, which gave them the stamp of imperial authority.

President Roosevelt at Bitter Lake

Development, as the years went by, were based on steadily increasing

American economic, military, and other assistance. Ethiopian ties with

the United States were symbolised by a meeting between the Emperor and

President Roosevelt, held by the Suez Canal Bitter Lake at the beginning

of 1945. The British Minister in Addis Ababa, Robert Howe, hearing the

Emperor's Egypt-bound aeroplane flying over his legation, before day-

light, at once investigated the cause of the unusual noise. Ascertaining

what this was, and perhaps fearing an Ethiopian opening to the United

States, he commissioned a small 'plane to pursue the monarch to Egypt.

The State Bank of Ethiopia, Ethiopian Airlines, and American Silver

Post-war Ethiopian contacts with the United States had in fact

started three years earlier. A new government bank, the State Bank of

Ethiopia, established in 1942, was run at first by an American governor,

George Blowers. A new national currency, inaugurated in 1945, owed its

successful introduction to the United States. The latter provided the

silver needed to mint 50 cent coins, whose intrinsic value ensured

popular acceptance of thenew paper money. The country's first national

air services, Ethiopian Airlines, at first almost entirely

Americanmanned, was set up in close collaboration with the American

carrier Trans World Airlines, in 1946.

The Imperial Highway Authority American financial assistance made

possible the establishment of an Imperial Highway Authority, IHA. Funded

with assistance from the American-sponsored International Bank for

Reconstruction and Development, IBRD, it restored old and built many new

roads.

An Important Landmark An important landmark in Ethio-American

relations was the signing by the two countries, on 22 May 1953, of a 25-

year Treaty of Amity and Economic Relations. This provided inter alia

for an American communications base, the Kagnew base as it was called,

just outside Asmara, which was by then under Ethiopian rule. Training of

Ethiopian soldiers, by a British Military Mission to Ethiopia, BMME,

withdrawn in 1951, was carried out, after 1953, by an American Military

Assistance Advisory Group, MAAG. American staff, including deans, were

prominent in the country's institution of higher learning, Haile

Sellassie I University, in educational development and planning, through

the United States Point Four Program, and in secondary school teaching,

through the US Peace Corps. The majority of Ethiopian students studying

abroad, including many members of the military, went to the United

States, and Ethiopian soldiers fought, under American command, in the

Korean War, of 1950-3.

Continuing, though perhaps less consistently than in Menilek's day,

Ethiopia's old policy of avoiding dependence on any one foreign power,

Haile Sellassie's government also made use of foreign assistance, and

expertise, from other lands. The Air Force, the Imperial Bodyguard,

telecommunications, and schoolbuilding, were thus entrusted to Swedes,

the police to Germans and Israelis, planning to Yugoslavs, and the

country's principal Military Academy, at Harar, to Indians. Teachers

from the sub-continent were also extensively employed, particularly in

the provinces.

Educational Developments This period witnessed many promising

developments in the educational sector. These included the re-opening of

pre-war schools, and the establishment of many new ones. The most

prestigious schools in the capital were the Haile Sellassie I Secondary

School, founded in 1943, and the General Orde Wingate Secondary School,

in 1946. Useful teaching was also given at vocational schools, for

commerce, handicrafts, and technology Education, contrary to the

situation prior to the war, was now extremely popular. Almost every

school had a waiting list for new student intake. The Emperor, when

driving in his car, was frequently mobbed by children crying, "School!

school!".

Increasing numbers of students were sent for study abroad, mainly to

English speaking countries: first to Britain, and later to the United

States, Canada, and India. The growth of secondary education made

possible the establishment, in 1950, of the country's first institution

of higher learning, the University College of Addis Ababa. This

educational establishment was later merged with other colleges,

specialising in agriculture, building, commerce, engineering, public

health, technology, and theology, to form the nucleus of Haile Sellassie

I University, established in 1961 (later renamed Addis Ababa

University).

It subsequently also comprised colleges of business administration,

education, law, and medicine, a school of social work, and Institutes of

Ethiopian Studies, Patho-Biology, and Development Research. The

University's administraion, and some of the faculties, were housed in

the former Imperial Palace, and its well-kept grounds, which the Emperor

donated for the purpose.

Two New Hospitals A number of new hospitals were also established.

The most presigious was the country's first modern teaching hospital,

named after the Emperor's daughter, Princess Tsahay, who had served as a

nurse in Britain in 1940, during the London Blitz. This institution,

founded in 1951, was funded by international subscription, mainly in

Britain. A Russian Red Cross hospital was also set up, named after

Dajazmach Balcha, who had fought at Adwa, and later in the patriotic

resistance to the fascist occupation.

Next Week: The Priorities, and Imperatives, of Ethiopia's Post War

Foreign Policy.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

May 2, 1997


Eritrea;
Eritrea Appalled at Distortion of President's Speech


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Eritrean Embassy in Addis Ababa has released a

statement expressing itself appalled, "at the gross distortion

perpetrated by the AFP to attribute words and declaration to the

president that he had not uttered."

The AFP report in question said that President Isaias Afeworki told a

seminar Thursday 24 April that Eritrean troops were involved in the

fighting in Sudan and had suffered some losses. The report went on to

say President Isaias Afeworki remarked that the troops had crossed over

into Sudan to fight Eritrean dissidents that were supported by the

Khartoum government.

The press statement from the Eritrean People's Front for Democracy

and Justice (EPFDJ) -- for whom the seminar was organised -- said

however that President Isaias Afeworki's speech had touched on the need

to fight corruption and focused on, "various phases of restructuring

that the government had been undertaking for the last three years to

create a lean and efficient civil service.

In relation to regional issues, the president elaborated on the NIF

regime's act of regional de-stabilisation and subversion and reiterated

the government's policy of sympathy and support in conjunction with its

regional partners to the democratic opposition in Sudan."

Reacting to the AFP corespondent's report, the Sudanese Information

Minister Al Tayeb Ibrahim Mohamed Khair was quoted to have said, " The

confession by the Eritrean tyrant is tantamount to a declaration of war

on Sudan and Afeworki has to bear the responsibility." On Sunday 27

April Sudan lodged a complaint with the UN security council saying

Eritrea had attacked it.

Ethiopia;
UNICEF Deputy Executive Director Visits Ethiopia


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Deputy Executive Director of the United Nations

Children's Fund (UNICEF) and U.N. Assistant Secretary General Ms. Karin

Sham Poo arrives in Ethiopia on Sunday for a four-day visit.

The purpose of Ms. Sham Poo's visit is to participate in the Mid-Term

Review of the government of Ethiopia-UNICEF 1994-1999 country programme

of co-operation. She will be accompanied by the UNICEF Director of

Programmes, Mr. Sadig Rasheed, and the UNICEF Regional Director, Ms.

Shahida Azfar.

Ms. Sham Poo joined UNICEF in 1989 as comptroller and has served in

her current capacity for the past ten years. UNICEF has more than 7,000

staff serving in some 130 countries world-wide, and expenditures that

amounted to US$1.023 million in 1995.

Since the start of the five-year country programme in 1994, UNICEF

assistance to Ethiopia has exceeded US $47 million. UNICEF assistance to

Ethiopia is the third largest in the world for the agency, following

assistance to India and Bangladesh.

UNICEF Press Release

Business and Finance;
Wegagen Bank Share Company Formed in Addis


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 133 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Wegagen Bank Share Company was formed Saturday

April 26 in Addis Ababa in conformity with the licensing and supervision

of Banking Business.

The Endowment Fund for the Rehabilitation of Tigray (EFFORT) is the

largest shareholder with 9,600 number of shares followed by the Amahara

National Regional Rehabilitation Development Organisation (Endeavor)

with 9,000 number of shares.

Fourteen other companies functioning in Addis Ababa, Awassa, and Dire

Dawa are also shareholders with 41,400 number of shares in total.
