LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


88 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1997


Ethiopia;
Over 30,000 benefit from ERO-run Project


BYLINE: Abebe Gelaw, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

SEKOTA - The Sekota Zuria Integrated Rural Development Project being

undertaken by the Ethiopian Relief Organization has benefited over

30,000 people in 3 woredas of Wag-Humara Zone in North Wollo since it

was launched in 1993.

The head of the project, Ato Anmut Belete, told a visiting team of

reporters here recently that since the project was launched in Sekota,

Ziquala and Dahna wordas, such services as distributions of relief aid,

environmental protection and rehabilitation animal husbandry, micro-

credit service have been rendered and basic infrastructure expanded.

According to Ato Anumt, over 30,000 people have directly benefited from

the program in one way or other. 

In its relief aid distribution programme, which mainly focused on

Sekota and Ziquala, ERO reportedly dispensed aid among over 70 thousand

peasant farmers, for a nine month period last year based on the

assessment of the year's harvest. the project head pointed out that the

area is one of those parts of the country which are affected by

recurrent cycles of drought and that over 30,000 people are being

assisted during the current year. Some 750 metric tones of reserve food

aid are in stock in Sekota and Ziqual woredas, he added.

Noting that peasant farmers in the region were impoverished owing to

inclemency and protracted civil war in the region, Ato Anmut indicated

that the project is also involved in rehabilitation activities by

distributing oxen, agricultural implements and seeds. This hand-out,

however modest, has greatly benefited over 1500 mostly affected peasant

farmers he said.

With respect to environmental the conservation programme, the head

explained, the project has established 5 nursery sites and two "closure"

areas covering over 357 hac. of land in addition to launching soil and

water conservation activities. "In this regard, the project was engaged

in the construction of checkdams, and drainage basins," it was noted.

Ato Anmut indicated that the project was also involved in assisting

agricultural activities with a view to increasing productivity,

improving nutritional status and creating income generation to

beneficiaries. Accordingly, it is undertaking horticulture at three

sites besides promoting modern agriculture, sheep and goat rearing,

poultry as well as establishing two veterinary posts.

In an effort to increase agricultural productivity in the region, the

head pointed out, the project has distributed 600 quintals of DAP and

300 quintals of selected-seed to farmers in some areas. "In addition to

that, we have distributed such agricultural implements as sickles, flat

hoe and finger hoe to about 300 beneficiaries," he stated.

Ato Anumt noted that irrigation activities were also given due

attention in the face of erratic rainfall in the area, adding that

irrigation works on two sites have already been completed. he also

hinted that the project plans to launch extensive irrigation activities

in various districts.

Complementing its preoccupation, Ato Anmut explained, the project is

also involved in supporting the extension programme, training

activities, access road network constructions, installing flour mills

and safe water supply. Accordingly, the project undertook the

construction of over 70 km of access roads in various districts through

its food-for-work programme.

The project head said that by the end of 1996 two hand dug wells went

operational while others were under construction in various localities.

"this is expected to greatly alleviate shortage of safe water supply in

the area," he said.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


89 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 3, 1997


Zambia;
Journalists Appear For Trial


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Windhoek - Two Zambian journalists jointly charged with "Publishing false news with intent to cause fear and alarm to the public" appeared for trial on April 28, 1997.

Editor Lweendo Hamusankwa and reporter Boyd Phiri for a privately-owned newspaper, The Chronicle, were charged under Section 67 of the Penal Code for publishing an article in the February 11 - 13 edition alleging that arms and ammunition had been stolen from a barracks in Lusaka. Hamusankwa also faces a "Criminal libel" charge for publishing an article in February 14 - 17 edition alleging that a presidential aide Everisto Mutale was using a stolen car. He was charged under Section 69 of the Penal Code. The case has been adjourned for mention to May 28; trial begins June 12 

Meanwhile, the state has recruited a cabinet minister in the Office of the President, Eric Silwamba, to assist in the prosecution of the two journalists. However, Hamusankwa told MISA May 7, the inclusion of Silwamba is clear testimony that the state wants to get a conviction. "Their ultimate goal is to get a conviction and make an example of us. They lost the Jambwa case and they don't want to lose another one," he said.

BACKGROUND Hamusankwa was on February 16 arrested and detained for publishing in the paper two offending articles in February 11 - 13 and 14 - 17 editions of The Chronicle. He was on February 17 charged with "Publication of false news with intent to cause fear and alarm to the public" contrary to Section 67 of the Penal Code. On February 18, he was released on a bail of ZK500,000 (about US$383) after spending two days in prison. Hamusankwa, however, denied both charges.

While Boyd Phiri was arrested February 17 and jointly charged with his editor Hamusankwa in connection with the article appearing in the February 11 - 13 edition. He was, together with a colleague, George Jambwa, summoned (on February 17) to police headquarters for questioning. Jambwa was released without charge. Phiri was later taken into custody until his court appearance on February 18, when he was also released on paid bail.

For further information, contact David Nthengwe, researcher, Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), Private Bag 13386, Windhoek, Namibia Tel. +264 61 232975, Fax. 248016 e-mail: research@ingrid.misa.org.na


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


90 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 3, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Namibia, Zambia, Zimbabwe Cited For Restricting Press Freedom


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The Media Institute of Southern Africa, or

Misa, has cited Zambia, Zimbabwe and Namibia as some of the

democratically elected governments in the subregion where freedom of

expression and of the media were being eroded, despite constitutional

guarantees.

Misa has expressed concern that the polarisation of Zambian media

around ownership has made it difficult for journalists to defend

themselves. Reporters in state-controlled media have been pitted against

their colleagues in the private sector. 

In its book entitled "So This Is Democracy?" officially launched

Saturday in Lusaka, Misa said that the division among Zambian

journalists was being exploited by all politicians who have taken to

ridiculing reporters of media organisations considered to be opposed to

their political view.

The book was launched by the president of the Zambia Independent

Media Association, David Simpson, during the local commemoration of the

World Press Freedom Day.

Misa said that if the Namibian National Assembly had, in 1996, passed

the Privileges and Immunities of Parliament Bill, it would have

seriously restricted the media's coverage of parliament.

Zimbabwe, too, was criticised for "stubbornly refusing to release its

stranglehold" on the airwaves and on telecommunications.

However, Misa commended journalists from Angola, Swaziland and Zambia

for continuing to report events in their countries without fear, despite

the hostility of their governments.

"Notwithstanding this discouraging scenario, journalists in all Sadc

countries continue to show courage in the face of adversity and

independent media tenaciously send their messages to the public," Misa

says.

Speaking Saturday at the commemoration of the World Press Freedom

Day, Zambian journalists reiterated their demand for the withdrawal of

the proposed Media Council Bill table in parliament by government.

Media Liaison Committee Chariman Robby Makayi said that journalists

had rejected the establishment of the council which intended to regulate

journalists and "criminalise" the profession.

"We have totally rejected the media council. it is not reasonally

justified in a democractic society," he said.

In April, government suspended its decision to table the

controversial media council draft bill in parliament after a heated

debate in the country by journalists who opposed the bill.

Government said it had withdrawn the bill to allow for further

consultations and provide an opportunity for debate and exchange of

views with stakeholders.

The bill seeks to ensure the compulsory registration of journalists,

to set minimum qualifications for them and institute a legal

disciplinary body for media practitioners.

"It belongs to the era of thought control in dictatorial regimes,"

Makayi said.

Zambia Information Minister David Mpamba said Friday on television,

in a programme to mark World Press Freedom Day, that it was unfortunate

that journalists had rejected the media council without looking at its

"merits."

He said the bill was basically drawn by government to help

journalists come together.

World Press Freedom Day, which is observed May 3, is an occation

declared by the United Nations to give international recognition to the

important contribution the media makes to their societies and the

international communities.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


91 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 3, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
African Ministers Meet Monday On Boosting Information


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Efforts to build an Africa information

superhighway get closer to reality Monday when ministers responsible for

economic and social development, and planning meet for four days

beginning Monday to review a report on the implementation of the African

Information Society Initiative.

The United Nations Economic Commission for Africa said Saturday, from

its Addis Ababa headquarters, that attention will be given to the role

of information and communications technologies in promoting trade and

investment.

Another meeting organized by the commission in 1996 decided that, in

the least, each African country needed to be connected to the internet

over two years as a mark of progress in linking Africa to the

superhighway. 

The report contains a policy awareness project on the dissemination

of the Information Society's Initiative framework in Africa and beyond.

With government officials, international and regional organizations

interested in information technology as its target groups, the project

is widely distributed in its original and packaged forms for different

audiences in major languages of the region.

A video programme entitled Building Internet to Ethiopia was produced

by the U.N. commission and the World Bank. This was part of the

commission's series on Building Africa's Information Highway -- a focus

on success stories using information and communication technology from

Egypt, Mozambique, Senegal and South Africa.

On Monday, ministers will also note that the commission has developed

a Web site on the Africa Information Society Initiative currently housed

at Bellanet, in Ottawa, Canada.

The society's report states that democratization of access to

information is one of the focus areas it advocates.

"Moving access from relatively wealthy urban centres to disadvantaged

communities is the target," the commission said.

An major effort is being formulated to support the Information

Society. It evolves around an appropriate approach to language and

literacy development content, the development or conversion of content

into usable electronic forms.

Others are the definition of learning, evaluation and impact

assessment mechanisms through which best practices could be fed into

future projects; and the impact of new technologies on gender.

A major symposium will take place May 7, involving senior industry

chiefs. This is organized by the commission together with the Global

Information Infrastructure Commission. It is scheduled to be broadcast

live by satellite.

The Information Society Initiative originated from the African

Symposium on Telematics for Development organized by the commission in

1995. This was done in cooperation with the International

Telecommunications Union, the United Nations Education, Science and

Cultural Organization, working through the African Networking

Initiative.

Since then, the initiative has been endorsed by the Organization of

African Unity, African Ministers of Telecommunications and some 29

partner bodies involved in African development.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


92 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 3, 1997


Zaire;
As Peace Talks Open, Thousands of Malians Flee Kinshasa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - Thousands of Malians arrived in

Brazzaville's Maya-Maya International Airport on Friday, as they fled

Kinshasa, the Zairean capital, from advancing anti-government forces.

Police in Brazzaville, capital of neighbouring Congo, said that some

4,000 Malians had arrived on the way home to West Africa. 

Many of them, particularly women and young children, lay tired on the

ground with their few bundles of clothes. They said they feared looting

and fled amid growing tension as forces of the Alliance of Democratic

Forces for the Liberation of Zaire closed in on the city.

Meanwhile, Zaire President Mobutu Sese Seko, is in Pointe-Noire,

Congo, awaiting the arrival of alliance leader Laurent Kabila aboard a

South African naval supply ship. They are to hold talks to end Zaire's

political impasse, which for Kabila, means Mobutu's immediate

resignation.

The negotiations were to have taken place Friday but Kabila failed to

show up demanding increased personal security.

Kabila is demanding that Mobutu step down immediately before the

fighting could end.

Three other head of states are in Pointe-Noire to facilitate the

face-to-face meeting. They are presidents Pascal Lissouba of Congo,

Nelson Mandela of South Africa and Gnassingbe Eyadema of Togo.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


93 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 3, 1997


Zaire;
Burundi Denies Links with Zairean Rebels


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Burundi's agriculture and livestock

minister, Damase Ntiranyibagira, on Friday in Harare, refuted

allegations that his country is aiding Zairean rebels led by Laurent

Kabila.

Ntiranyibagira told journalists after paying a courtesy call on

Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe that Burundi had its own problems and

could not afford to assist other countries in any way. 

Zairean authorities have alleged that the Tutsi-led military

government in Bujumbura together with Rwanda and Uganda, were helping

Kabila's Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo

(Zaire).

"These are unfounded allegations. Burundi has its own enormous

problems and has no intention to interfere with affairs involving her

neighbours," he said.

Kabila's troops are already in control of more than half of Zaire and

are reportedly poised to over-run the capital, Kinshasa, anytime, to end

President Mobutu Sese Seko's 32-year old rule.

The rebel leader and Mobutu are, however, expected to hold a meeting

either Friday or Saturday to try and find a negotiated settlement to the

six-month crisis.

Ntiranyibagira also said he had brought a "brotherly" message from

the Burundi leader, Maj. Pierre Buyoya, who seized power in a military

coup on July 25, 1996.

"This is a message in which our leader expressed his gesture to the

Zimbabwe government for what it did for the Burundi people and hope that

the two countries will accompany each other in their peace paths," said

Ntiranyibagira.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


94 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 3, 1997


United States and Africa;
Text of State Department Briefing: Zaire


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2494 words


 

Washington - Text of comments on Zaire by State Department spokesman

John Dinger at the May 2 briefing:

QUESTION: Could you bring us up to date on Zaire?

MR. DINGER: Well, as we all know, a meeting between President Mobutu

and rebel alliance leader Kabila is scheduled for today, May 2nd.

President Mobutu has left Kinshasa for Point Noire, Congo, and I do

believe he is aboard a South African ship at this time. Alliance leader

Kabila arrived in Luanda this morning from Lubumbashi. The last I have 

seen, Mr. Kabila remains in Luanda. Since the meeting has not yet begun

and since at least Mr. Kabila's travel would involve a relatively

lengthy helicopter flight to the ship, I think we have to be frank and

realize that it is very much in question whether the meeting is going to

take place today.

I would note that the South Africans, we believe, are still confident

that the meeting will take place soon, if not today, we would certainly

hope tomorrow. President Mandela, of course, is hosting the conference

on board a South African ship. We expect it to be in international

waters off the coast of Zaire. Ambassador Richardson and South African

President Mandela are currently in Point Noire. President Mandela and

Congolese President Lisuba have asked Ambassador Richardson to attend

the shipboard talks. As we said yesterday, Ambassador Richardson is most

happy to fulfill whatever role President Mandela, the UN special

representative Sahnoun and others believe will be useful. He does plan

to remain and, hopefully, participate in the meeting which will take

place possibly today, but it now seems more likely tomorrow.

I would just point out that these are very, very important talks.

These talks are very important for President Mobutu, very important for

alliance leader Kabila but, most importantly, very important for the

people of Zaire. We believe it is essential that these talks take place

and we urge the leaders to make that happen. At the same time, we also

need to stress that a Mobutu-Kabila meeting, while an important step,

does not mean that all of the very difficult issues remaining before

them will be resolved. Nevertheless, we do urge the leaders to make sure

this meeting takes place.

QUESTION: John, how complicating has been the French Government's

efforts to keep Mobutu in power?

MR. DINGER: The reports that perhaps we all saw this morning in the

press clearly involved alleged intelligence reports and, for that

reason, I am not going to discuss reports of French involvement in

supporting President Mobutu. What I would like to say though is that

France and the United States have worked very, very closely throughout

this crisis. You will remember before the conference in Loma we jointly

demarched, I think it was, some 20 or 30 African capitals. We believe

that the United States and France share the same objectives. Those

include obtaining a cessation of hostilities, seeing a negotiated

transition to a democratic government, responding to the urgent

humanitarian needs of refugees in eastern Zaire, and facilitating the

repatriation of Rwandan refugees. So while I can't comment on these

intelligence reports of French covert support for President Mobutu, I

would like to stress how closely the United States and France have

worked towards the same goals in Zaire.

QUESTION: I didn't mention the word "intelligence" at all

deliberately.

MR. DINGER: The press reports have, though.

QUESTION: But I didn't refer to them at all. I just asked you whether

French efforts to support Mobutu have complicated your efforts to try to

get some sort of a peaceful transition here.

MR. DINGER: We worked very, very closely with the French towards the

same goals in the same efforts, and those include finding a cease-fire,

achieving a cease-fire, pursuing a negotiated transition, responding to

the humanitarian need. So I guess in that way I am indirectly responding

to your question, I think.

QUESTION: You're saying that - well, let me try to break it down.

MR. DINGER: I'm saying that we're working together closely. So should

you ask in what way has it inhibited us, I would say very much the

contrary; the United States and France have worked cooperatively on this

issue for some months, particularly in this immediate crisis.

QUESTION: Does the United States though feel that France was trying

to beef up Mobutu as he was weakening in power and the rebels were

advancing?

MR. DINGER: I don't have any reason to confirm that sort of attitude.

As I say, very much the opposite, that France and the United States very

much share policy in the goals in Zaire.

QUESTION: Have you seen the reports that Angolan armored units have

become involved in the fight?

MR. DINGER: We have seen the reports of Angolan involvement. I can't

confirm any of the specifics about Angolan involvement. I certainly saw

the reports today about bridging equipment and armored carriers, etc. It

is quite clear though that the Angolans have been providing support to

the alliance. We have very strongly urged the Angolans, privately and

publicly, at the very highest levels that they should end their military

involvement and that they should support international efforts to

achieve a negotiated end to the conflict in Zaire.

Having said that, we also have to allow that we continue to see these

reports of continued Angolan involvement. Ambassador Richardson was just

in Luanda and one of his principal purposes was to discuss Angola's

involvement in Zaire and to underscore in the strongest terms that we

believe it is clearly in Angola's interest not to become involved in

Zaire because that involvement is only likely to contribute to unrest in

Zaire, which borders on Angola. That simply can not be in the interest

of Angola to contribute to instability in Zaire. So Ambassador

Richardson just yesterday was in Luanda making these points very

strongly. This is not the first occasion that we have had to make our

position known to Angolans.

QUESTION: Well, does this suggest to you that the spillover of the

war has already begun to occur in the neighboring countries?

MR. DINGER: There have been allegations since the current, shall we

say, crisis some six or eight months ago that there have been various

outside forces from many of the neighboring countries involved in the

conflict in Zaire. We have, from the very beginning, said in the

strongest terms that we don't believe there is any useful role for

foreign forces to play in Zaire. We have said that publicly and we have

been in touch with all those countries which are alleged to be involved

urging them to stay out of this conflict because it can have no positive

impact on the situation in Zaire, very much the opposite.

QUESTION: Is it clear that this could lead ultimately to the breakup

of the territorial integrity of the country which is now known as Zaire?

MR. DINGER: It is very difficult to say with any confidence what the

impact could be. Clearly, it threatens to create more instability in

Zaire; therefore, we don't believe any foreign country or forces have

any useful role to play. We believe this is a conflict that must be

limited to the people of Zaire and must be resolved by them. In that

context, we are working very, very vigorously -- particularly the

President and the Secretary have just sent Ambassador Richardson to

Zaire -- in a very strong effort to reach a cease-fire and to lay out,

develop, a plan that will eventually lead to a stable and democratic

Zaire. The involvement of foreign forces in Zaire can not contribute to

that goal, very much the opposite.

QUESTION: (Inaudible) on the list of those countries which you have

seen reported to be involved?

MR. DINGER: Well, I will let you review the reports of which

countries are reported to be involved. I will say that we have been in

touch with all of them and on more than one occasion to stress our

point. The bottom line here is that it is not in their interest to be

involved in this; what is in their interest is for there to be a stable,

democratic and, frankly, prosperous Zaire. Now, that goal is some ways

away. But that is the goal and, in order to achieve that goal, what we

need is for President Mobutu and alliance leader Kabila to meet, for

there to be a cease-fire, and that there be a transition to an inclusive

democratic process and government in Zaire. That is what we all need to

be working on and that is where people should be concentrating their

efforts.

QUESTION: John, there have been reports of UNITA involvement on

behalf of Mobutu. Did Richardson meet with Jonas Savimbi and did this

issue come up?

MR. DINGER: I don't believe that Ambassador Richardson met on this

occasion with Mr. Savimbi. I can tell you, however, that we have been in

touch with all the parties in Angola who may be involved in Zaire and we

have made this point.

QUESTION: John, is there evidence based on Kabila's contacts with

American officials that he has a good understanding of what a transition

to democracy would mean and that he is prepared to carry it out?

MR. DINGER: Well, of course, our contact with Mr. Kabila has been

conducted on various levels. We have an officer from our embassy in

Kinshasa who is now in eastern Zaire. I am not positive he has met

directly with Mr. Kabila, but Mr. Bogosian has been in contact with Mr.

Kabila and, of course, we have a very persuasive special envoy at the

present time there who has just met with Mr. Kabila. Ambassador

Richardson is very persuasive. He has certainly, in the strongest terms,

expressed our policy and our point of view to Mr. Kabila. We certainly

hope that Mr. Kabila will understand that this is in the interest of

everybody involved but, most especially, the interest and the people of

Zaire.

QUESTION: What kind of response did he get from Kabila? Did he get

any assent?

MR. DINGER: I don't think I will be able to offer you any replies

from Mr. Kabila, but I just leave it that we have made it very clear and

that Ambassador Richardson is a very persuasive person and that I am

certain that he made these points in a most convincing way. We are

certainly hopeful that Mr. Kabila recognizes this and, no matter what

happens in Zaire, that he will be a force for democracy and stability

and progress.

QUESTION: Is it fair to say that his commitment to democracy still is

an open question?

MR. DINGER: The fact that he is not someone that we have had

extensive contact with over many years. It is certainly obvious that we

can not say with any certainty what his ultimate goals might be. Of

course, we don't want to speculate on what his ultimate achievements

might be. I think what we would say is that, regardless of what happens

in Zaire, we would hope that Mr. Kabila is a positive force.

QUESTION: John, is there some doubt that the two men will meet or do

you just attribute the fact that the meeting hasn't happened today to

some of the logistics that have been involved?

MR. DINGER: It is very difficult to know with precision what has

caused the meeting not to take place today. I think we have probably all

seen the reports, whether they be on television or on the wires, about

the problems that have arisen. Clearly, there are issues involving the

health of President Mobutu. There are issues about long helicopter

rides. There are all these issues. Logistics are a problem, but is very

difficult to understand exactly what happened.

We certainly hope that both leaders will make every effort to make

this meeting take place. We really think it is in their interest. I'll

just repeat once again, it is in the interest of Zaire, the country and

its people, that they meet and that they: one, achieve a cease-fire, a

cessation of hostilities; and that they, two, develop a reasonable plan,

a workable plan, that will lead to a transition towards democracy.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


95 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 3, 1997


South Africa;
ANC Exec to Apply for Amnesty


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Johannesburg - In response to a number of media queries regarding the

Business Day story on the possible applications for amnesty by members

of the ANC National Executive Committee (NEC), the ANC wishes to make

the following statement:

* the ANC confirms the report that the NEC sub-committee on Truth and

Reconciliation chaired by Deputy President Thabo Mbeki has made a

recommendation to the effect that past and present members of the

National Executive Committee and various Command Structures of Umkhonto

We Sizwe should apply for amnesty.

* this is in line with the decision of the NEC to adopt the principle

of collective responsibility for all acts conducted within the broad

parameters of ANC policy against the apartheid regime. 

* this recommendation was considered by the recent NEC meeting and

ratified. In this regard, legal representatives and the ANC's Truth and

Reconciliation Desk are currently processing the matter with a view to

submitting application for NEC members and MK Command structures for

amnesty.

* the application for amnesty by members of the NEC and Command

structures of Umkhonto We sizwe, should encourage all members of the

ANC/MK who have served under these structures previously to apply for

amnesty.

For more information contact Ronnie Mamoepa at 082-990-4853

Issued by Department of Information and Publicity P.O. Box 61884

Marshalltown 2107 2 May 1997


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


96 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 3, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
ECA Forges Ahead With Information Initiative


BYLINE: UN Economic Commission for Africa (ECA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Addis Ababa - ECA will be taking its leadership role in building an

African information superhighway one step further when African Ministers

responsible for economic and social development and planning meet at the

headquarters of the Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) on 5-8 May

1997.

The ministers and African experts will consider a report on the

implementation of the African Information Society Initiative (AISI).

Key attention will be given to the role information and

communications technologies in promoting trade and investment. A major 

symposium -- organised by ECA together with the Global Information

Infrastructure Commission and scheduled to be broadcast live by

satellite on Multichoice DSTV by MNET -- will take place on 7 May,

involving senior industry chiefs.

AISI has its origins in the African Symposium on Telematics for

Development organised by the ECA in 1995, in cooperation with the

International Telecommunications Union (ITU), the United Nations

Education, Science and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) and the

International Development Resource Centre (IDRC) working through the

African Networking Initiative.

The report notes that since then AISI was endorsed by the

Organisation of African Unity, African Ministers of Telecommunications

and some 29 partner organisations involved in African development.

Another meeting organized by the ECA in 1996 decided that some

benchmarks, articulated around a minimum prerequisite consisting of the

availability of internet connectivity in each African country, were

needed to mark progress over the following two years, according to the

report.

It contains a policy awareness project on the dissemination of the

AISI framework in Africa and beyond. With government officials,

international and regional organisations interested in information

technology as its target groups, the project is widely distributed in

its original and packaged forms for different audiences in major

languages of the region.

The report points out that ECA worked with the World Bank to produce

a video programme entitled "Building Internet to Ethiopia" as part of

its series on "Building Africa's Information Highway" -- a focus on

success stories using information and communication technology from

Egypt, Mozambique, Senegal and South Africa.

The Ministers will also note that ECA has developed an AISI Web site

currently housed at Bellanet, in Ottawa, Canada.

The report makes it clear that the democratization of access to

information is one of the focus areas advocated by AISI. Moving access

from relatively wealthy urban centres to disadvantaged communities is

the target.

A major activity here, the report continues, is the Acacia Initiative

being formulated by IDRC in support of AISI. It evolves around the

following:

- An appropriate approach to language/literacy content development,

and the development or conversion of content into usable electronic

forms;

- Definition of learning, evaluation and impact assessment mechanisms

through which best practices could be fed into future projects;

- Impact of new technologies on gender.

For further information please contact Peter da Costa, Cabinet Office

of the Executive Secretary, UN ECA, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia Tel: +251-1-

51-29-17 (direct) or 251-1-51-72-00 (main switchboard), Ext. 476 Fax:

+251-1-51-22-33 E-Mail: ipspdc@harare.iafrica.com


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


97 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 3, 1997


Zambia;
Minister Bans Advertising In The Post


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Windhoek - The Zambia Independent Media Association (ZIMA/MISA-Zambia

reports that Health Minister Katele Kalumba has ordered the Central

Board of Health (CBOH), to stop advertising in the privately-owned

newspaper, The Post.

ZIMA says the paper reported in its April 22 edition quoting a CBOH

source as saying: "We have given the paper a lot of business but we have

been directed (by the minister) to stop it and place adverts with the

(government-owned) Times of Zambia or Daily Mail". No reason has been

given for the order but ZIMA believes the paper's criticism of

government may have been the cause. 

CBOH spokesman Dr. Ben Chirwa has, however, denied the allegation.

Chirwa told ZIMA on May 2, "there was never such a directive from

Kalumba, neither was the issue ever discussed by the CBOH board... If we

want to advertise we look at our financial position and based on that,

we advertise in either all the papers or a selected paper(s)." Chirwa

further said CBOH dictates decisions and not the ministry.

ZIMA chairperson David Simpson, in a letter dated April 23, to

Kalumba, protested the minister's reported order prohibiting the CBOH

from advertising in The Post. Simpson pointed out in the letter that the

role of an independent newspaper was not to "respect" the government,

but observe and report events at home and abroad. "It would be

hypocritical of the media to maintain an adulatory stance if they

observe the principles of good governance being sometimes deliberately

neglected," he said. Simpson added in the letter that the Ministry of

Information had assured ZIMA there was no "deliberate policy" by

government to ban advertising in the private media, only commercial

considerations were used in such decisions.

While Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) president, Alfred

Zulu, said April 21, the decision prohibiting the CBOH adverts in the

Post would be counter-productive because of the paper's popularity. Said

Zulu: "It's at the peril of those who don't advertise because the paper

commands a respectable and wide readership." But Zulu added saying the

order was "draconian, unacceptable and attempted blackmail." ends

For further information, contact David Nthengwe, researcher, Media

Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), Private Bag 13386, Windhoek,

Namibia Tel. +264 61 232975, Fax. 248016 e-mail:

research@ingrid.misa.org.na


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


98 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 3, 1997


Demonstrators looted shop in protest against arrests


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

BUSHBUCKRIDGE - Protesters looted at least one shop in the disputed

Greater Bushbuckridge on Friday night, after smashing the Marite Trading

Store's windows with rocks and bricks, police report.

The crowd of youth reportedly carried off an undisclosed number of

full mielie meal bags and systematically ripped open those they were

unable to take, with sharp instruments. Police spokesperson, Senior

superintendent Phuti Setati told African Eye News Service that the

looters were allegedly armed with knives and pangas. 

"It is now obvious that we are dealing with thugs and not with

politically motivated demonstrators who want their town incorporated

into Mpumalanga Province," said Superintendent Setati.

Police also reported that the densely populated Bushbuckridge area

was calm on Saturday and that no further arrests had been made.

On Friday ten youths were arrested after two large freight trucks

were ambushed and burntby pro-Mpumalanga demonstrators in Marite.

No one was hurt in the ambush but damage to the trucks, from the

Kiepersol Banana Boys Farm near Hazyview, is estimated to be worth

hundreds of thousands of rands.

Both police and members of the Bushbuckridge Border Committee,

however, expect a resurgence of violence on Monday when residents take

to the streets to pledge their solidarity for the arrested youths who

are scheduled to appear in the Mapulaneng Magistrate Court on arson

charges.

A member of the Bushbuckridge Border Committee, Mathews Madonsela,

told African Eye News Service on Saturday that a 'mother of all

meetings' would be held at Mapulaneng College of Education on Sunday

with "all the stakeholders" in the greater Bushbuckridge area. He added

that the Committee's 14-day blockade was officially suspended 'for only

time being' on Friday after a memorandum addressed to Constitutional

Affairs minister Valli Moosa was handed to five police stations in the

area.

"The meeting on Sunday is aimed at letting the residents of this area

decide our way forward. They must decide whether we should resume the

blockade or not," said Madonsela.

He added that the Committee will also review its wider program of

action during the meeting. - African Eye News Service

LANGUAGE: English

99 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwean Industrials Active


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwean industrials began the week

active Monday but the index lost 39.95 points to close at 10,754.42 on

the back of losses by most major counters.

Publishing group Zimpapers had a share split of nine for one and a

three for one bonus issue, and traded at 160. Copper cable company Bicaf

put on 20 to 400 zimbabwe cents, and Alloys and Natfoods each gained 25

to 475 cents and 515 cents, respectively.

There are about 11 Zimbabwe dollars to one U.S. dollar.

Counters to lose included the financial group UDC down 20 to 300

cents, sugar producer ZSR dropped 25 to 1,475 cents, banking group

Barclays shed 50 to 3,050 cents, while National Merchant Bank, in

reasonable turnover, also shed 50 to 3,300 cents.

Cement producer Porthold was down 150 to 1,700 cents and First

Merchant Bank closed 200 down at 5,100 cents.

Other counters to trade were largely within five cents of previous

levels.

Meanwhile in minings, Bindura and Wankie traded at previous levels.

Mhangura, in reasonable turnover, lost five as did Alloys Prefs at 25

cents and 95 cents. Ashanti closed 100 down at 10,500 cents.

The index shed 3.63 points to close at 1,018.54.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


100 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Business and Finance;
Mugabe Calls for Removal of Trade Barriers


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

KASANE, Botswana (PANA) - President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe

implored Monday countries in southern Africa to remove impediments to

wider and more trade, in order to forge sounder economic partnerships.

Mugabe, who was chairing the Southern Africa International Dialogue

session which discussed the development of Southern Africa as a growth

area, cited tariffs as one such impediment.

"By the year 2004, for instance, we must have lowered tariffs to zero

percent," he told nine Southern African leaders, and some 140 captains

of industry from the region and abroad. 

The leaders and business executives are seeking to forge economic

ties, in an arrangement dubbed Smart Partnerships. The conference, which

started Sunday, ends Wednesday.

"You can grow without developing," Mugabe said.

He added that governments in the region had inherited economies from

colonialists which were at different stages of growth, with the economic

giant being South Africa.

However, he said, while South Africa was relatively developed, there

was no matching human development pertaining to improving the standard

of living of its people.

Mugabe also called on governments to improve the lives of its rural

folk, encourage them to grow cash crops and establish marketing boards

which would help sell these foods.

This, he said, was much more beneficial than "just growing large

volumes of crops."

Addressing the session, Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano said

the economies of Southern African countries had improved lately. For

example, each had reduced inflation by an average 5 percent per year.

He said in the past four years, about 380 projects valued at a total

of 8.1 billion U.S. dollars had been approved in the various economic

sectors in the 12-nation Southern Africa Development Community

countries.

"Governments in the subregion undertook considerable market reforms

and liberalized their economies," Chissano said. "They work from the

conviction that we need to pool resources together in order to develop.

We cannot develop separately."


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


101 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Li Peng In Zambia, Pledges Support For Africa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Chinese Premier Li Peng arrived in Lusaka on

Monday, beginning a six-nation Africa tour to consolidate relations with

its remaining friends on the continent.

The visit comes amidst a continuing diplomatic offensive by Taiwan

for recognition, considered by Beijing to be a hostile act from its

renegrade provice.

Li said on arrival in Lusaka that China, with one of the fastest

growing economies in the world, attached great importance to African

development. China, he added, was ready to work with Africa in 

safeguarding world peace and in ensuring development.

He said that China's relations with Africa had survived considerable

political shifts in direction within African and the remaining world.

Some 12 cash-strapped African countries have, in just over a year,

courted and granted Taiwan diplomatic recognition. They have received

considerable money from a Taiwan flushed with cash. So, Beijing has

accused Taipei of exploiting Africa's poverty to buy recognition.

However, Li expressed hope that his visit to Africa would help

consolidate the relations for the mutual benefit of the peoples of

Africa and China.

The Africa nations recognizing Taiwan have been mostly economically

weak and without significant continental political clout. Beijing has

managed to maintain ties with the more important states such as Nigeria

and South Africa.

Li, who is on a three-day official visit to Zambia, was at signing

ceremony Monday in which China gave Zambia a 5.6 million-U.S.-dollar

interest free loan. The money will be for the maintenance of the

Tanzania/Zambia Railway Authority, or Tazara. Another 3.6 million

dollars is a grant to Zambia.

The agreement, was signed by the Chinese minister for foreign trade

and economic corporation, Wa Yi, and Zambian Labour Minister Peter

Machunga.

At the signing ceremony, Li said China would encourage its

businessmen to invest in Zambia in the agricultural and mining sectors.

His visit, he said, was intended to lay foundation for the economic

development of both countries. He leaves Zambia on Wednesday for

Mozambique after holding consultative talks with Chiluba and Miyanda.

Li other visits will take him to oil-rich Gabon and Nigeria,

Cameroon, and Tanzania.

During the 1970s, China helped Tanzania and Zambia build the 1,865-

kilometer railroad from Dar es Salaam on the Indian Ocean coast to

Kapiri-Mposhi in Zambia.

At the time, during the cold war, Western countries refused to

finance the construction and criticized its usefullness. However, China

aided landlocked Zambia, which was facing a military and economic

onslaught form racist Rhodesia and South Africa, with this lifeline to

the Tanzanian port of Dar Es Salaam.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


102 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Burundi;
Buyoya Makes First Cabinet Reshuffle


BYLINE: Ferdinand Bigumandondera, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - Burundi's military ruler, Maj. Pierre

Buyoya, has made his first cabinet reshuffle in an attempt to inject

life to the country's moribund economy.

Burundi has been under economic sanctions from its neighbours since

August 1996, in an effort to restore democratic civilian rule to the

landlocked central African country.

Burundian Prime Minister Firmin-Pascal Ndimira said Monday that the

24 ministers named were chosen for their competence and because of a

need to provide an ethnic and regional balance in the government, and

after three years of inter-ethnic war. 

Buyoya named six newcomers to the cabinet Monday. They will occupy

the justice, trade, public works, energy and mines, transports, posts

and telecommunications and Basic Education ministries.

Buyoya, who seized power July 25, 1996 from the democratically

elected government of President Sylivestre Ntibantunganya. has retained

his ministers of defence, interior, external relations and finance.

The full cabinet list is as follows:

Prime minister - Firmin-Pascal Ndimira

External Relations and Cooperation - Luc Rukingagama

Interior and Public Security - Col. Epitace Bayaganakandi

Justice - Terence Sinunguruza (New)

Defence - Lt. Col. Firmin Sinzoyiheba

Planning, Development and Reconstruction - Evariste Minani

Community Development - Bambasi Pierre

Reintegration, Resettlement of Displaced People and Returnees -

Pascal Nkurunziza (transfered)

Land Development and Environment - Samuel Bigawa (transfered)

Finance - Nibigira Gerard

Agriculture and Livestock Development - Damas Nitiranyibagira

Commerce, Industry and Tourism - Gregoire Banyiyezako (New)

Labour, Crafts and Vocational Training - Bernabee Muteragiranwa

Public Service - Monique Ndakoze

Basic Education and Adult Literacy - Joseph Ndayisaba (New)

Secondary, Higher Education and Scientifique Research - Logatien

Ndoricimpa (New)

Human Rights, Social Action and Women Development - Christine

Ruhaza

Youth, Sports and Culture - Bonaventure Gasutwa

Public Health - Juma Kariburyo

Communication and Government Spokesman - Pierre Claver Ndayicariye

Public Works and National Supply - Kital Nzobonimpa (New)

Transports, Posts and Telecommunications - Venerand Nzohabonayo

Energy and Mining - Bernard Barandereka (Transfered)

Institutional Reforms and Relations With the National Assembly -

Eugene Nindorera

Junior Minister in the Ministry of External and Cooperation -

Leonidas Havyarimana

Junior Minister to the Interior and Public Security - Kazignye Prime

(New)

103 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Mauritania;
Mauritanian Army Plane Hunts For Birds


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

ROSSO, Mauritania (PANA) - Abandoning its traditional role, a

Mauritanian military plane was last Friday seen spraying pesticides to

destroy grain-devouring birds on both sides of the common border with

Senegal.

It was the first time a military aircraft was getting involved in the

joint operation Mauritania and Senegal have been conducting since April

1 to kill the predators along their common border. 

A spokesman from the Mauritanian ministry of Rural and Environment

said in Rosso, southern Mauritania, that the aerial spray was conducted

under a bilateral framework.

The spokesman was speaking in the course of meeting of the bilateral

commission of the operation, which is financially-backed by the United

Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO).

Mauritanian and Senegalese authorities met in Rosso to exchange ideas

and data about the location of the birds.

FAO is financing the campaign to the tune of 350 million U.S. dollars

which is being used to hire the aircraft, other equipment as well as the

training of local personnel.

Quoting data issued by FAO, the spokesman said between two and three

million birds have been cited at Bedoum in northern Senegal.

The 10-hour aerial spraying is being complemented by ground teams

from the Senegalese side, he added. However, he did not reveal the

outcome of the joint operation.

LANGUAGE: English

Sports - Soccer;
Sudan's Al Hilal Beats Ghana's Goldfields


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 106 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Sudan's soccer club champions, Al hilal, on

Sunday beat the their Ghanaian counterparts 2-1 in the first leg match

of the eighth final of the African club champions competition.

Al hilal's goals came from striker A. Alfraj Santo and midlfielder

Ahmed Hadra in the 20th and 30 minutes of the first half, respectively.

Goldfield's replied with a goal in the 44th minute, also before the

breather.

105 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Africa Urged To Exploit Achievements


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

KASANE, Botswana (PANA) - African countries should use their

outstanding achievements in reconciliation and nation-building to boost

the performance of their economies, Namibian President Sam Nujoma said

on Monday.

Chairing a session at the on-going Southern African International

Dialogue Forum in kAsane, in north-eastern Botswana, Nujoma said Africa

had achieved miracles of reconciliation and nation-building which were a

shining example to the rest of the world and could be repeated on the

economic front. 

"We all know that Africa has great potential. We know that the

miracles of reconciliation and nation-building that have been achieved

are indeed shining examples to the rest of the world.

"However, if these examples of victory of the African human spirit

are to be sustainable, they need to be translated into visible economic

successes," said Nujoma.

Only through economic growth could distribution of wealth and

creation of opportunities take place to enable the impoverished people

to make an honest and dignified living, he said.

"The people who have made it possible for our region to achieve major

paradigm shifts towards democracy, respect for human rights and nation-

building through reconciliation can only maintain that momentum if they

are socially and economically empowered," said Nujoma.

Africa was, for the first time, now poised to reap the full benefits

of its rich resources, not simply the gold, diamonds, crops and fish,

"but the most precious resource of all, namely people", said the

Namibian leader.

"It is my belief that Africa has a lot to teach the world. The

entrenched communal and social structures so central to the values of

all African people represent a strong platform for partnership at all

levels, grassroots as well as national levels," he said.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


106 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Benin;
Petroleum Products Cost More In Benin


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

COTONOU, Benin (PANA) - Benin's National Oil Products Marketing

Company (SONACOP) has increased the price of various petroleum products

by between three percent and 30 percent. Announcing the price hikes on

Saturday, SONACOP said Kerosine, widely used here for cooking lighting,

would now sell at 125 CFA francs per litre from 100 CFA previously (500

CFA = 1USD). 

The price of high grade petrol went up by 25 CFA to 200 CFA per litre

while the price of ordinary petrol rose slightly from 170 to 175 CFA. A

litre of diesel increased by more than 30 percent to 175 CFA.

The increases did not come as a surprise for consumers who have been

expecting them since the sector was liberalised last year.

However, authorized dealers of smuggled petrol from neighbouring

Nigeria known here as "Kpayo" continued to sell at 150 CFA per litre.

Labour unions have criticised the hikes which followed similar rises

in the cost of electricity, water and cement, saying they have fuelled

inflation and pushed up cost of living.

The workers listed these among problems they presented to the

government on May Day.

In a statement issued on Friday, SONACOP said the new prices were

simply adjustments to higher prices for petrol imports mainly caused by

the appreciation of the U.S. dollar which is the reference currency in

the oil market.

According to the company, the price of petroleum products had

remained unchanged in Benin since 1988, and in spite of the devaluation

of the CFA in 1994 which doubled the local prices of most imported

products.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


107 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Mauritania;
Mauritania Shifts Presidential Polls


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - The Mauritanian government has decided to

hold presidential polls on 12 December 1997 instead of the initial date

of January 1998, which falls within the Muslim Fasting period of

Ramadan, the minister of interior, Kaba Ould Aliou, has said.

The overwhelming majority of Mauritania's population of about three

million are muslims. 

In a radio interview, Aliou said the decision was taken because of

the holy month, which begins at the end of December.

The minister said that opposition parties were informed of the change

of date last week.

Radio Mauritania reported that if the opposition agrees to the

government proposal, election campaigns would be held in October and

November.

The first round presidential poll would be held on 12 December. The

opposition parties have so far not reacted to the proposal.

Incumbent president, Col. Maouiya Ould Sid Amed Taya was elected

president of the country on 17 January 1997.

Africa News


May 5, 1997


Business and Finance;
Canadian investors interested in Maputo corridor


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Nelspruit - Canadian investors have an "intense" interest in

Mpumalanga, specifically in projects along the Witbank-Maputo Corridor

project, said Mpumalanga Premier, Mathews Phosa on Monday. 

Phosa returned from Alberta, Canada at the weekend, after attending a

week-long investment seminar in Calgary.

"Interest has been shown in areas such as housing, construction,

environmental technology, information technology, as well as gas and oil

related projects,"Phosa said.

He said progress had also been made with the twinning of Alberta

province to Mpumalanga, especially with regards to the establishing of a

tertiary institution in Mpumalanga.

Phosa was accompanied on the trip by MEC for Agriculture, January

Masilela, and MEC for Economic Affairs and Tourism, Jacob Mabena.

Africa News


May 5, 1997


South Africa;
Boy (3) beaten to death for defecating in sleep


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Malamulele - A three-year-old boy from Malamulele in Northern

Provnince was beaten to death by his cousins for defecating in his sleep

while sharing a bed with them on Saturday night, Northern Province

police said on Monday. 

Provincial police spokesperson, Captain Frans Mojabelo, said the

boy's four cousins, who are aged between three and ten, beat the child

while their mother was visiting their father on a nearby farm.

The boy was found to be dead on Sunday morning.

The four suspects appeared in the Malamulele magistrate's court on

Monday and admitted to beating their cousin with their bare hands.

The boys were remanded into the custody of their mother and will

appear in court again on June 23. .

South Africa;
Two boys (8) drown


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

STANDERTON - Two eight-year-old boys drowned while swimming on a farm

near Standerton on Saturday, police said on Monday. 

Provincial police spokesperson, Capt Doep du Plooy, said it took

police and sniffer dogs six hours to find the bodies of Siphiwe Petrus

Lephoto and Buyi Molefe of Early Bird farm.

The boys had gone swimming with three friends on a neighbouring farm

when they ventured too deep into the water and disappeared.

"The other children ran away and told the parents, who called the

police and fire brigade," Capt du Plooy said.

The boys' bodies were found at 6pm. .

Africa News


May 5, 1997


South Africa;
Three prisoners escape


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Wakkerstroom - Police are still searching for three alleged stock

thieves who escaped from the Wakkerstroom police cells on Friday night,

police said on Monday.

The suspects used a crow bar to remove corrugated sheeting covering

the cell wall and climbing through the gap left in the wall, secunda

police spokesperson, Sgt Johannes Seake said. 

He said the three suspects had been in their cells during a routine

check at 10pm.

"Almost an hour later, the duty officer heard a noise at the

neighbouring community centre and upon investigation discovered that the

corrugated sheeting had been removed from the cells walls," Sgt Seake

said.

He said the crow bar was found in the cell.

The three suspects, Mbuyiseni E Nkonde, Johan Dlamini and Bheki

Xhokaza are still at large. .


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


112 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


South Africa;
Traffic cops allegedly burn office complex to hide corruption


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Nelspruit - Traffic officials who were illegally issuing up to 300

fraudulent drivers licenses per day in the former homeland of KwaNdebele

allegedly burnt down their R1,2-million Test Centre in 1995 to destroy

all documentary evidence of their activities.

The four Mpumalanga traffic officials suspected of masterminding the

syndicate and arson were temporarily suspended but were later promoted

and then re-instated without any disciplinary action being taken against

them, the Moldenhauer Commission into Fraudulent Licenses heard on

Monday.

Chief provincial traffic inspector Francois Coombs, who initially

headed an internal investigation into the alleged syndicate, told the

Commission that after interviewing the four officials on a Friday he had

been told he could only get a number of 'master' license books from the

Test Centre safe on Monday.

When he arrived on Monday, however, he discovered that the R1,2-

million Centre had burnt down over the weekend. The only thing reported 

missing from the Centre's fire-proof safe was an attache brief case with

money and license books in it.

A police investigation was unable to trace the arson culprits but

confirmed that the Centre had been purposely burnt down.

Despite handing over "iron clad" evidence and video-tapes of license

corruption by the four officials to provincial traffic director Henry

Brazer, one of the officials was made an assistant director shortly

afterwards.

The official, who was not named, was still being investigated and was

on suspension at the time.

All four officials, two traffic officers and two administrative

officials, also allegedly refused to return the State money they had

accepted as bribes, while a driving school which was allegedly in

cahoots with the officials and which was paid R700 by undercover

investigators, threatened to "cause trouble" for investigators with the

provincial Safety & Security MEC, Steve Mabona.

Both Brazer and Mabona featured prominently in testimony before the

Commission last week, when a number of traffic officials accused them of

irregularly organising and issuing both a learner's and driver's license

to Parliamentary deputy speaker Baleka Mbete-Kgositsile.

Although Mbete-Kgositsile has no personal or constituency links to

Mpumalanga, she received both licenses on the same day, on October 1,

last year after Mabona sent his own car and bodyguards to fetch her from

Johannesburg. Brazer, who was booked off work at the time after a minor

heart attack, drove 350km from Nelspruit to Delmas to personally test

Mbete-Kgositsile - despite not being registered as a certified testing

officer.

No official records of either the test or the licenses were kept and

documentation which was later produced to 'prove' that there had not

been any irregularities instead contained numerous errors or procedural

irregularities.

Coombs also told the Commission on Monday that he had originally been

asked to investigate corruption charges against Brazer after he

allegedly bought a boat and diving equipment for personal use with

departmental money.

Just before launching the investigation, Coombs was told that it had

been taken over by senior traffic inspector Roelf Smith - who currently

shares the same attorney as Brazer during Commission testimony.

"I was then asked to investigate the issuing of up to 300 licenses a

day in Kabokweni but Brazer first forced us to tell him the names of our

undercover officers and decoys," said Coombs.

"We staked the place out for two days and then sent our decoys in.

The moment they asked for licenses and showed their ID books, the

officers chased them away - saying that they had been warned we were

SAPS."

Coombs added that when he complained about the handling of both the

KwaMhlanga and Kabokweni cases, he was threatened with transfer away

from his home in Middelburg and disciplinary action.

He was also suspended without explanation from all investigative

duties in April 1996 and allegedly intimidated by senior departmental

officials. Brazer has allegedly ignored Coombs repeated requests to meet

with him to discuss the threats and intimidation.

Brazer is expected to testify before the Commission on Wednesday,

while the traffic official, John Muller, who first revealed that Mbete-

Kgositsile had irregularly been issued licenses will testify on Tuesday.

MEC Mabona will be the last witness to testify some time next week.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


113 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


South Africa;
Third Force policemen allegedly blew activist's body up


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

MIDDLEBURG - Four senior Mpumalanga policemen who allegedly used

dynamite to blow up the mutilated body of ANC activist Sweet Johannes

Sambo, so as to prevent his death from becoming "another Steve Biko

affair", appeared briefly before the Middleburg Regional Court on

Monday.

According to earlier testimony from notorious Vlakplaas commander,

Colonel Eugene de Kock, two unnamed black policemen arrested Sambo in

Tonga, Near Komatipoort and interrogated him for gun-running in July,

1991.

When he denied any knowledge of the charges, three of De Kock's men,

Peter McIntyre (31), Jacques Else (27) and Andries Venter (33) joined

the interrogation. They stripped him naked, stuffed a tyre's inner tube 

over his head before kicking, beating, clubbing and jumping on him.

When Sambo died of his wounds, the policemen allegedly phoned De Kock

for advise on disposing of his body.

De Kock claims to have told the men to take Sambo to an abandoned

mine near Thabazimbi and to use dynamite to destroy the corpse by

repeatedly blowing it up. The mangled remains, described as "persistent

remains" were then thrown down the mine shaft.

Prosecutor Marike de Kock told African Eye News Service (South

Africa) after the hearing on Monday that McIntyre, Venter, Else and

Phillipus de Beer (39) had pleaded autrefois acquit because the State

had previously failed to provide sufficient evidence linking them to the

murder and the courts had been forced to acquit them.

She added that the State had decided to re-charge the men with murder

instead of assault charges after De Kock's confession and after he

identified the men by name.

De Kock is currently serving 122 years in jail for a series of

murders, assassinations and repeated fraud offenses.

State Prosecutor Anton Ackerman, from the Attorney General's office

in Pretoria, told African Eye News Service (South Africa) on Monday that

de Beer for being accomplice 'after the fact'.

The four policemen's autrefois acquit plea will be argued in the

Pretoria Supreme Court on May 27 before the case can be continue to be

heard in Middelburg on August 22, when both parties expect a judgement.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 5, 1997


Sudan;
'Peace' Agreement Signed


BYLINE: African Faith and Justice Network (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Washington - On Monday April 21, a "peace" agreement was signed

between the government of Sudan and four rebel factions, including those

of Riek Machar and Kerubino Kwanyin Bol. Former President Jimmy Carter

was in Khartoum on the week-end for talks with President Bashir and the

faction leaders. He did not witness the signing.

The document deals with such issues as a referendum for the south

after a transition period of four years, Sharia law and where it can be

lifted, and sharing of power.

The SPLA has called the document a sham. It maintains the only

purpose of it is to absorb the factions into the Sudanese army whose

morale is very low. The fact that faction troops have been sent to Juba,

and the fact that the day after the signing of the deal, the government

bombed Yei, the town where Garang was to meet Carter, does raise serious

doubts as to the actual purpose of the deal.

Some analysts say the peace deal does not amount to much without the

SPLA. They believe it is another manifestation of the government's

tactic, "divide and rule".

Some also fear that there will be more fighting now between the

factions that have joined the government and the SPLA faction.

Distributed by Africa Faith and Justice Network; P.O. Box 29378;

Washington, D.C. 20017; Tel: 202 832 3412. Fax: 202 832 9051; email:

afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


115 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Burundi;
Situation Update: Let us not forget...


BYLINE: African Faith and Justice Network (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1694 words


 

Washington - Before the conflict in Zaire erupted, the country people

were most concerned about in Africa was Burundi. Reports from that

country indicate the situation is still very serious; there is an

undeclared war going on there and massacres remain common in the

countryside.

Since Buyoya took over in a military coup in July, allegedly to stop

the "bloody anarchy", the opposition claims as many as 50,000 have been

killed. During the first week of April alone, 140 died in clashes

between government troops and rebels in the south..(150,000 were killed

in Burundi during the period from October 1993 when Melchior Ndadaye,

the democratically elected president, was assassinated, to July 1996

when Buyoya seized power.)

The recent explosions in Bujumbura, the capital, have added a new

dimension to the crisis. At least ten people have been killed and more 

wounded. There are doubts now that Buyoya can even guarantee the

security of the capital which has been virtually ethnically cleansed.

No group has claimed responsibility for the blasts. A Hutu protestant

priest has been arrested. The blasts appeared to be targeted at the

areas of the well-to-do and the expatriates.

Regroupment Camps

Last year, the government of Burundi (more precisely, the regime of

Buyoya) began rounding up civilians in the rural areas and placing them

in camps, supposedly for their protection. According to human rights

groups, however, the camps are little more than government-run

concentration camps designed to control the mainly Hutu farmers in the

countryside.

The U.S. Ambassador has strongly attacked the regroupment camps.

During a visit to the camps, inhabitants told him how they were forced

into the camps by the army and their homes destroyed. They fear both the

army and the insurgents. Malnutrition and disease were reported

spreading in the camps; housing and sanitation are completely

inadequate. Vital subsistence agriculture has been disrupted.

Clearly the people are there against their will. This violates the UN

Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The Ambassador fears that with

the new fighting in the south, regroupment will spread there. It already

affects five provinces.

Meetings in Tanzania

Easing of Sanctions Pressured from a number of sources, including the

UN Secretary General, the African countries of the region agreed to a

summit meeting to discuss easing the Burundi sanctions. The sanctions

were imposed last August by these countries to express their disapproval

of Buyoya's take-over. To lift the sanctions three conditions were

required: 1) restoration of political parties, 2) reconvening of the

National Assembly, and 3) peace negotiations with all parties to begin.

The summit meeting was finally arranged for April 16 in Arusha. A few

days prior to that, Nyerere called for a meeting of all the political

parties in Burundi. Except for PARENA, an extremist, mainly Tutsi party,

most parties attended, including the two major ones that had formed the

coalition government before the coup, FRODEBU and UPRONA.

Not much detail has been reported on the Arusha talks except that the

opposition, CNDD, called for a tightening of sanctions and regretted

that Buyoya was invited to the upcoming summit.

Present at the April 16 summit were: Julius Nyerere, OAU Secretary

General Salim Ahmed Salim, President Mkapa of Tanzania, and presidents

or their delegates from Ethiopia, Cameroon, Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda,

Zaire, Zambia. Buyoya was greeted as a fellow head of state.

Although the countries had different opinions, in the end they agreed

to the easing of the sanctions. One reason was that the sanctions were

being violated and would continue to be more so. Another reason was that

while there was no evidence that they had been successful politically,

economically they had caused considerable hardship to the vulnerable

population.

Easing the sanctions was a difficult decision for the summit; the

continuing solidarity and perhaps unexpected toughness of the regional

states against Buyoya was due to the fact that he represented the

specter of the further entrenching of military dictatorships in Africa.

In the final communique from the summit, sanctions were lifted on

food and agriculture products, education and construction materials, and

medicine. Commercial exports and imports are still banned. The country

leaders recognized although the first two conditions had been fulfilled,

the third had not; the country had not moved towards a strategy for

peace and reconciliation. The leaders said they hoped that easing the

sanctions would now encourage both sides to begin unconditional

negotiations.

The leaders also called on the government of Burundi to disband the

regroupment camps.

Ambivalence towards Buyoya

On the one hand, there are reports that Buyoya is becoming isolated

in the region. Even relations with Rwanda are strained. On the other

hand, the summit welcomed him as a head of state. This, of course,

angered the armed opposition. Leonard Nyangoma, leader of CNDD, still

maintains he will negotiate only if Buyoya resigns.

It seems that while international attention has been focussed on

Zaire, Buyoya has become more entrenched. Meanwhile the situation in the

country has not improved; if anything, it is more polarized.

Conclusion/Action

Sharing of power has so far been unattainable in Burundi. Since

independence, except for the brief period after the elections in '93

before the assassination of Ndadaye in the same year, the country has

been controlled by the Tutsi minority.

Even when the coalition government was formed after the

assassination, the Tutsi-led army was virtually in control of the

country. Hutus have not remained quiet; extremists among them have

rebelled against the situation and the violence that has racked the

country for years continues.

Julius Nyerere has explained that peace will come only if 1)the

Tutsis can overcome their fear of extermination if they relinquish power

and 2) the Hutus can be assured of their human and political rights.

There are no quick fixes to this deep-seated problem. The hope lies

in the fact that it is only the extremists on both sides that are

continuing the violence. The majority of the population wants peace, and

reconciliation efforts at the grass-roots level have been successful.

Even the first (and only) elections in '93 were not along ethnic lines.

As with Sudan and Somalia, Burundi is forgotten by the media. But we

must not forget; we must do what we can.

Our continuing efforts should be aimed at: - supporting the regional

effort to push for peaceful negotiations among all parties in Burundi -

reminding the international community that Buyoya is not a legitimate

head of state and that he must be willing to submit to elections at the

time chosen, not by him, but by the people - supporting those who are

working to reduce the polarization in the country through grass roots

efforts at reconciliation.

(Letters can be sent to Julius Nyerere, thanking him for his efforts

and encouraging him to continue, and to Salim Ahmed Salim, OAU Secretary

General.)

More immediate action could be aimed at: - pressuring Buyoya's

regime to abandon the regroupment policy and let people return to their

homes - reversing the ethnic cleansing that has taken place in Bujumbura

- pressuring all parties, particularly Buyoya's and the CNDD of Leonard

Nyangoma, to agree to unconditional negotiations.

(Letters can be sent to President Bill Clinton and Secretary of State

Madeleine Albright or George Moose, Asistant Scretary of State for

African Affairs.)

Distributed by Africa Faith and Justice Network; P.O. Box 29378;

Washington, D.C. 20017; Tel: 202 832 3412. Fax: 202 832 9051; email:

afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
