116 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Angola;
Government of National Unity Formed


BYLINE: African Faith and Justice Network (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Washington - Angolans, on April 11, inaugurated their first

government of national unity and reconciliation. The ceremony which was

witnessed by 12 visiting heads of state including South Africa's Nelson

Mandela and Portugal's (former colonizer) President Jorge Sampaio.

Notably absent from the ceremony was UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi, who

said that he could not come to Luanda because of security reasons. He

was represented by Antonio Demba, vice President of UNITA. 

Prior to the inauguration the Angolan Parliament approved legislation

"granting UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi, Special Status as Leader (purely

ceremonial) of the largest opposition group in the National Assembly..."

On April 10, seventy UNITA deputies, who were elected during the

botched election of 1992 when UNITA returned to war instead of accepting

the election results, assumed their positions within the National

Assembly. According to the new political dispensation, UNITA will head

four government ministries and seven junior ministerial posts, all of

whom may be chosen by Savimbi.

Savimbi will receive a salary, keep a retinue of bodyguards at the

State's expense and will receive money for housing.

The installation of the government should have taken place in January

but was postponed because UNITA did not fully cooperate. Since December

the installation has been postponed thrice. In late March U.N. Secretary

General, Kofi Annan, in his first international foray, visited Angola

and met with Savimbi.

During Annan's visit, he urged Savimbi to fully comply with terms of

the agreement. The inauguration is the final stage in the Angolan peace

process but many observers of Angolan politics are skeptical that

lasting peace has finally come to this beleaguered country.

A Portuguese newspaper, Diario de Noticias (7 March ) reported that

"UNITA occupies two thirds of Bie Province, and has recently destroyed

the bridge over the River Cutato on the road between Andulo and

Cucinga."

The Washington Post (April 10) reported that "Recently UNITA and MPLA

forces clashed in southern Benguela province sending about 25,000 people

fleeing to join the ranks of the roughly 1.2 million Angolans displaced

by the long war." The war which began in 1975 has killed an estimated

500,000 Angolans.

Other pointers which suggest potential for conflict include the fact

that about 23,000 of the 63,000 UNITA soldiers said to be demobilized

have deserted their quartering areas.

There are persistent press reports that UNITA may be rearming itself.

The Washington Post (March 20), quoting Western intelligence sources,

reported that "450 tons of Bulgarian arms were sent to UNITA in October

and November 1996." The equipment included "AK-47 assault rifles, 60 mm

and 120 mm mortars and rocket-propelled grenades." The Angola Peace

Monitor (APM) (Vol III *7 March 1997) noted that by November 28, "a

total of 29,698 personal weapons and 4, 521 crew-served weapons..." were

handed over to the U.N peacekeepers.

However, the APM maintains that even "the U.N. admits that between

30-40 percent of weapons handed over were old and unusable." Given this

situation and the fact that "key figures in UNITA's military and

political structures including Jonas Savimbi, are to remain outside the

new parliament and Government" coupled with another factor which is

"that UNITA continues to strengthen the considerable military force it

keeps under arms," suggest more difficulties in the future.

Others have suggested that Savimbi's stay-away attitude is a ploy to

keep a distance between himself and the government. This view suggests

that Savimbi is hoping that the current government "messes" things up.

This would give him upper hand in the next election.

However, UNITA troops, which reportedly joined the Zairian conflict

on the side of Mobutu have not fared well. Some reports suggest high

casualties within their ranks.

Nonetheless, the rearming of UNITA forces and the fact that a

significant number of disarmed UNITA soldiers were not actual soldiers

but peasants who were "press-ganged by UNITA and taken to the quartering

areas to make up the numbers," are factors which must be adequately

addressed and resolved before the international community disengages

from the Angolan peace process.

The U.N. is preparing to significantly reduce its presence in Angola.

The U.N. 6,600 (7,000 in some reports) "blue helmets" known as UNAVEM

III (United Nations' Angola Verification Mission), in Angola is

currently the largest U.N. Peackeeping unit in the world.

Distributed by Africa Faith and Justice Network; P.O. Box 29378;

Washington, D.C. 20017; Tel: 202 832 3412. Fax: 202 832 9051; email:

afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

117 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Liberia;
Peace Process on Course


BYLINE: African Faith and Justice Network (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1414 words


 

Washington - All indications are that the Liberia peace process is

moving in the right direction however unhurriedly. According to the

Commanding General of the West African Peace Keeping Force (ECOMOG),

Major General Victor Malu, the country is safe, refugees can return, and

elections will be held in May.

The United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) is in

agreement with Malu's conclusion and has begun a campaign to convince

Liberian refugees that the country is now safe for them to return. Malu

however cautioned refugees hoping to return "to be mentally prepared for

the massive destruction of villages and towns that took place during the

war." 

A number of refugee representatives from neighboring countries are

undertaking assessment missions to "see for themselves" whether security

has indeed returned to their homeland. So far, some have been impressed

with the conditions they have seen. According to Rev Edwin Lloyd, who

visited Liberia on behalf of Liberian refugees in Cote d'Ivoire,

"Liberian refugees are gratified by news of the high military

professionalism being demonstrated by ECOMOG in pursuing its peace

duties in Liberia," he told ECOMOG commanders. There is no report yet of

a systematic return to the country but some refugees are known to be

trickling in, especially from Guinea and La Cote d'Ivoire.

ECOMOG, whose troop strength has been augmented in the last few

months to 10,000 has been deploying troops throughout Liberia with the

help of the United States Government, which provided aircraft that

airlifted troops from the region to Liberia last March. The additional

troops came from Niger, Burkina Faso, La Cote d'Ivoire, Mali and Benin.

The initial peacekeeping troops were largely Nigerians but included

Ghana, Guinea, Gambia, and Sierra Leone.

There has not been any serious outbreak of violence since December

1996 and disarmament is continuing in the southeastern part of the

country.

However, disarmed soldiers in parts of the country have come under

attack from local people. About 10 former combatants may have been

killed so far. Reports of criminality in many areas abound. Meanwhile

the United Nations said that it has employed about 5,000 ex-combatants

to do various chores including cleaning of streets and clearing of

highways as part of its demobilization program.

Liberia's Election Commission (ECOM) was inaugurated on April 2. It

has the immense task of conducting democratic, free and fair elections

in a country totally destroyed by seven years of war. There is deep

concern that given the logistical requirement and the lack of financial

support from the Council of State (the transitional government) the

election probably will have to be postponed to October. Catholic

Archbishop Michael Francis, called for such postponement but the

Election Commission has not released any statement in this regard.

Charles Taylor, leader of the NPFL is opposed to any postponement.

ECOM Chairman, Mr. G. Henry Andrews, a veteran journalist, has said

that it will cost $12 million to conduct the election. According to Mr.

Andrews, the Commission has assurances from the international community

to contribute about 80 percent of the money. However, the commission is

in arrears of $750,000, mostly wages to its employees. Mr. Andrews also

stated that the commission was installed two months behind schedule,

leaving the commission with a shorter time to carry out its mandate than

anticipated in the Abuja Accord of August 1996.

According to the Election Commission about 11 political parties are

already registered and certificated. The Commission believes that by the

time election day arrives at least 20 political parties will have been

approved. Among the newest parties are the National Patriotic Party of

rebel leader Charles Taylor, the Labor Party and another Party founded

by Harry Moniba, former Vice President of slain military dictator,

Samuel Doe.

The alliance of seven political parties which was announced in early

January and committed to fielding one slate of candidates is now

unravelling. Two parties: the United People's Party of veteran populist,

Bacchus Matthews and the Unity Party have withdrawn from the alliance.

Their action followed the alliance convention at which time Cletus

Wotorson of Liberia Action Party (LAP) was elected.

The Unity Party (UP) has decided to support United Nations

Development Program official, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf as its presidential

contender.

Wotorson named LPP activist and former student leader, Alaric Tokpa,

as his running mate. He told reporters recently that some of the new

political parties recently registered are considering joining the

alliance.

According to political observers in Monrovia, the leading contenders

would include: Cletus Wotorson of the Alliance of Political Parties,

Charles Taylor of the NPP and Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf of the UP.

There are at least five other contenders, including rebel leader

Alhadji Kromah of ULIMO-K, who recently registered his All Liberia

Coalition Party. Kromah was also recently arrested and briefly detained

by the peacekeepers when a large quantity of hidden weapons was

discovered and recovered from his premises. He was later "pardoned"

after apologizing for burying the weapons in his yard. The Election

Commission has said that it will not allow any independent candidate to

contest the election.

The current momentum toward peace building in Liberia has to be

maintained. A close monitor of the region has to take place to prevent

any flow of arms into Liberia.

Continued assistance to ECOMOG is necessary especially in ensuring

that arms captured from rebels do not disappear. In fact some Liberians

have suggested that ECOMOG should destroy the weapons it has collected

in a Liberia's version of "flame of peace" as was done in Mali, one year

ago.

The activities of the election commission need speedy logistical and

financial support and the various warring factions and civilian

politicians need to be prevailed upon to respect the result of the

electoral process while rear-guard strategy needs to be put in place to

absorb any fall-out from the process.

The Liberia peace process may be on course but its derailment is

still possible. The international community must be unequivocal about

what the process should achieve and vigilant about ensuring that this

happens in the best interests of the majority of Liberians.

Distributed by Africa Faith and Justice Network; P.O. Box 29378;

Washington, D.C. 20017; Tel: 202 832 3412. Fax: 202 832 9051; email:

afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


118 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


United States and Africa;
TRADE: The New Panacea for Africa Woes


BYLINE: African Faith and Justice Network (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Washington - Washington is upbeat about prospects for increased trade

with Africa.

During the last Congress a bill, "African Growth and Opportunity: ",

was introduced on the last day but did not get far. This year the bill

was introduced on April 24, and stands a very good chance of passing

Congress.

It has already received Presidential support and has potential

bipartisan support in both Houses of Congress. Essentially the bill 

calls for:

"1. establishment of U.S./sub- Saharan Africa Free Trade Area to

serve as a catalyst for increasing trade and increasing private sector

development in the region;

2. a textile initiative that would exempt sub-Saharan Africa from

provisions of the World Trade Organizations's Textile and Clothing

Agreement until exports from the region 'reach higher levels';

3. a one time appropriation of $500 million for an infrastructure

fund for Africa, which would not come from development funds used by the

U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) to help Africa; and

4. formation of U.S. - Africa Economic Forum that would include

annual high level meetings at the secretary and ministerial levels, and

discussion on 'bilateral and multi-lateral trade and investment policies

and initiatives'."

At a recent meeting held in Chantilly, Virginia, a suburb of

Washington, African representatives and U.S. business leaders were full

of praises for the prospects of increased trade and investment in

Africa.

According to Thabo Mbeki, Deputy President of South Africa, and heir

apparent to Nelson Mandela, this is now the African "renaissance."

Hillary Clinton, speaking on behalf of the Clinton Administration said

that Africa "was on the move."

In the words of Robert Rubin, Secretary of the U.S. Treasury,

"Democracy has started to take root in Africa." He suggests that "market

reforms have also taken hold."

The meeting was sponsored by the Corporate Council on Africa, a quasi

lobby group interested in promoting U.S. investment in Africa. It counts

among its leadership former U.S. government officials including Herman

Cohen, former Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, and

James Woods, a former Defense Department official.

With the bad press Africa gets, one is expected to applaud the

statements of the Chantilly meeting as pointing to the positive

development in Africa, which speaker after speaker stated. But that is

the problem about imaging Africa. On the one hand some see only chaos

and on the other hand is the "success story" syndrome.

Glaringly absent from the deliberations is who benefits from U.S.

investment in Africa. From all accounts, it certainly does not include,

in any significant way, the masses of Africans whose daily drudgeries

are inadequate to secure for them a higher standard of living.

The struggle of the Ogoni people of Nigeria strikingly makes the

case. Shell Corporation's behavior in Nigeria has denied the Ogoni

people the ability to derive a livelihood from their ancestral

occupation, farming and fishing, by destroying the land and polluting

the rivers and streams. The Ogoni people and the Nigerian nation have

not become better off because of Shell's investment, which spanned more

than 30 years and generated billions of dollars. Today Ogonis are

refugees in Benin and the United States and the Nigerian government has

an occupation force on their land. Nine of their leaders were murdered

by the Nigerian regime and 19 others may face a similar fate.

According to current statistics, U.S. investment in sub-Saharan

Africa is about 7% of total U.S. overseas investment. Most of the

investment is in the extractive industries sector, including oil and

mining. Aside from South Africa (where there is some investment in the

manufacturing sector) other African countries with significant U.S.

investment include Angola, Gabon and Nigeria. In all of these countries

there is no evidence that U.S. investment has ameliorated the condition

of the local people.

In Angola, the years of war have meant that U.S. investment largely

resulted in the ability of one of the protagonists to obtain the means

to prosecute the war. As a result Angola has had to mortgage away most

of its future oil income to foreign interests. Essentially, this means

that it will take a long time before the average Angolan will encounter

the benefit of the resources found in his/her area.

As for Nigeria, the military who have ruled that country for 30 of

its 37 years of independence have appropriated all resources and

especially oil which it then uses to create a formidable machinery that

denies the right of the Nigerian people to choose their own leaders or

benefit from the resources of their country.

In the case of Gabon, President Omar Bongo, a seasoned autocrat, has

used Gabonese wealth to thwart democratic elections in his favor and

live a life of luxury and opulence. It will be of little surprise if

some "Kabila" arose in Gabon soon. Bongo, like Mobutu, belongs to a

breed of African leaders referred to as "political dinosaurs" by the

late French President Mitterrand.

Distributed by Africa Faith and Justice Network; P.O. Box 29378;

Washington, D.C. 20017; Tel: 202 832 3412. Fax: 202 832 9051; email:

afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


119 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Zaire;
What Comes Next in Zaire?


BYLINE: African Faith and Justice Network (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1667 words


 

Washington - Everyone now seems to agree that the Mobutu era is at

its end. But there is no common agreement as what is in store for

Africa's third largest country and perhaps its richest.

Laurent Desire Kabila, long time guerilla foe to Mobutu, is said to

now have all the cards in his hands. His recent pronouncement of single-

handedly heading a transitional government is cause for pause. Any

transitional instrument, to be seen as credible and worthy of

international support, must include Zaire's pro-democracy forces as well

as those sectors of the population who have historically championed the

cause of popular participation, economic justice and freedom for all of

Zaire. 

However, the negotiations now mediated by South Africa and the United

Nations do not provide for this. There is a pre-occupation with having

Kabila meet Mobutu "face to face". Not enough attention is given to the

involvement of other sectors of the population in these negotiations.

This is dangerous to say the least especially when multinational

corporations are flocking into Zaire and entering into billion dollar

deals with the rebel leader while he is shooting his way to power. With

the Zairian army in utter disarray and Mobutu's health uncertain, Kabila

can believe that he is the answer to Zairian woes. But no one person has

the monopoly of knowledge on how best to solve Zaire's difficult and

numerous problems.

All the people of Zaire, particularly those who stood up to Mobutu,

without guns, should not be left out of the debate as to which way Zaire

should head. Any hasty decision by the world community to ordain Kabila

the new "strong man" of Zaire would not only be political folly, but

totally callous. What is more, rebels have been accused of massacres and

summary executions.

Most recently, according to press reports, rebels refused to allow

access to refugee camps where Rwandans are dying, about 60 persons a

day. This was done in apparent disregard to instructions from Kabila,

who earlier, gave permission for relief workers to enter the refugee

camps. Arguments that Kabila's forces won't disintegrate don't hold

water. If news about Kabila's deals with multinational corporations,

including diamond mogul DeBeers, trickles to the front line, there is no

telling what the reaction will be. It is even difficult to predict what

would happen when rebels get a taste of new found wealth.

But there are even more compelling reasons why Kabila should not be

allowed to become Zaire's "strongman" by shooting his way to power. In

the region of the Great Lakes, all current governments came to power

through the force of arms: Mobutu of Zaire, Kagame of Rwanda, Buyoya of

Burundi and even Museveni of Uganda.

This is a region awash in arms and numerous guerilla warfares. In

Uganda there are at least three different groups violently campaigning

to remove the regime. They may not pose any immediate threat to the

Museveni government but protracted warfare will severely hamper

development activities in regions where they are concentrated. There are

guerilla armies in Burundi and Rwanda, all involved in violent campaigns

to remove their regimes.

As a result none of those countries are any closer to reconciliation

than they were three years ago when both of their presidents were killed

in a plane crash, an incident which catalyzed the Rwandan genocide of

1994.

More than 150,000 people have been killed in Burundi since its first

democratically elected president, Melchior Ndadaye, was killed three

years ago. In nearby Sudan, the current government came to power

violently and is at war with the SPLA. The situation is not helped when

U.S. policy encourages countries in the region, including Eritrea,

Uganda and Ethiopia, to employ violence as the means to remove the

government of Sudan.

Amidst all this violence, the lives of ordinary persons are taken

away. In many cases these lives have been lost in vain. The blood

spilled by the millions who have died in Sudan has not generated peace.

The death of more than one million in Rwanda (since its independence)

has not achieved anything for those who perpetrated these gruesome acts.

If anything, it has meant greater untold suffering for the people in

"whose interest" they claimed to have acted.

The fact that Kabila is able to put together a war machinery to

remove Mobutu can not be said to be the primary reason he is succeeding.

It is Mobutu's record that is doing him in. His army loots, pillages and

flees; it does not fight. One reason why Mobutu is referred to as a

repressive dictator is because of his response to the resistance mounted

against his regime by unarmed people. These democratic forces recently

held a two-day successful protest in Kinshasa, a city of 4 million

people, with "stay-at-home" actions.

Certainly, they must have significant support among the people of

Zaire. Kabila should not be encouraged to usurp power only because he

carries the gun. There are ample historical justifications that those

who capture state power by force of arms do not necessarily bring peace

and justice to their people. On the other hand those who take the noble

path of peaceful negotiations and popular participation hold great

potential of ensuring stability and the possibility of reconciliation

and reconstruction.

This is one reason why Nelson Mandela of South Africa, stands out

among African leaders. The lessons of Liberia, Rwanda, Angola, Somalia,

amongst others are only too fresh in our minds not to heed the

instructions of the South African model.

What the people of Zaire deserve is perhaps best captured in an

article written by the writer, Louis Kalonji (Africa News bulletin

15/04/97 No. 322). According to him, the people of Zaire expect from any

negotiation the following:

1. They want radical change. Obviously they want the war to end, but

at the same time any negotiation must take a hard long look at the

reasons for Zaire's present lamentable state. Most of all the population

wants to see an end to Mobutu's dictatorship that has ruined the

country.

2. They want to see the election process back on track.

3. They want a solution to the delicate question of Zairian

nationality

4. They want a firm pledge that the democratization process will

continue. The basic terms of reference for this process are the

conclusions drawn up by the Sovereign National Conference, relating to:

a. the formation of a genuine government of national unity, Such a

government must include representatives from the various political

"families and civil society."

b. The re-organization of a truly national army free from all tribal

and ethnic elements.

c. the organization of free and open elections under the supervision

of the United Nations and countries friendly towards Zaire.

d. There must be public accountability when it comes to administering

state finances.

These are minimal and realistic goals which the international

community can support. Kabila needs to be told that popular

participation, economic accountability, good governance and sustainable

peace can not come out of the barrel of a gun.

Multinationals eager to invest in Zaire must consider that those with

whom they allied have the mandate of the Zairian people through popular

consensus. Their investment must not oil any machinery which would deny

the people of Zaire the benefits of their well endowed country and their

right to choose their own leaders in a manner respectful of their

history.

Distributed by Africa Faith and Justice Network; P.O. Box 29378;

Washington, D.C. 20017; Tel: 202 832 3412. Fax: 202 832 9051; email:

afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

120 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Seminar to Examine


BYLINE: UN Economic Commission for Africa (ECA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Addis Ababa - GIIC AND UNECA TO HOLD HIGH-LEVEL SYMPOSIUM IN ETHIOPIA

ON PRIVATE AND PUBLIC SECTOR PARTNERSHIP IN Building THE AFRICAN

INFORMATION SOCIETY

The Global Information Infrastructure Commission (GIIC) and the

United Nations Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) are hosting a high-

level symposium to strengthen private and public sector partnership in

the implementation of the African Information Society Initiative (AISI).

Attending the meeting -- to take place at the ECA's headquarters here

in Addis Ababa on Wednesday 7 May 1997 -- will be representatives of all

fifty-three African countries including ministers of social and economic

development, planning, communications and finance along with information

and communications leaders from around the world. The symposium will be

broadcast live in Africa in an M-Net production on Digital Satellite

Television (DStv.

The GIIC is an international non-governmental organisation of leaders

from over 40 of the world's foremost information and communications

technology companies. 

"The GIIC provides a framework for bridging the gaps between the

public and private sectors, between developing and developed countries,

and between diverse industry sectors from around the world" says Dr.

Derrick L. Cogburn, GIIC Africa Regional Director and symposium

coordinator.

On the same day the GIIC will release its "Statement of Addis Ababa"

which strongly supports private and public sector partnerships in

building the African Information Society. The GIIC Statement proposes a

set of principles that might guide the implementation of the AISI as

plans for National Information and Communications Infrastructure (NICI)

within each African country. Thus, the AISI should:

- Be African led, but within a global context; - Take into

consideration the substantial work on NICI in Africa that has preceded

it, and related work worldwide on developing the Information Society; -

Encourage developing countries to cooperate with each other, as well as

with the developed world; - Promote African and global private sector

leadership in the introduction of NICI in Africa, together with active

participation from the public sector, civil society and international

organizations; - Be driven by applications and services and not by

technology; - Foster transparent plans and policy frameworks for NICI

involving all relevant stakeholders, based on the promotion of: - rights

in information access and use; - global trade and investment; -

diversity of content; - telecommunications competition; -

interoperability and appropriate standards; - privacy, data protections,

data security and intellectual property rights.

Furthermore, the GII Commission encourages the ECA to:

- Develop an on-going mechanism for private sector participation in

the coordination of the AISI; - Facilitate greater coordination of

African countries within the World Trade Organization; - Develop

effective strategies for sub-regional, regional and global coordination.

The GIIC delegation will be co-chaired by GIIC Commissioners Koos

Bekker, CEO of Multichoice Investments Limited and Dr. Hisham El Sherif,

Chair of RITSEC, IDSC and ITI of Egypt. Other leading members of the

delegation will include:

- Souleymane Sall, President, Silicon Valley, Senegal and GIIC

Commissioner;

- Ashiek Manie, head Information Society and Governance, Telkom SA

Ltd, representing GIIC Commissioner Dikgang Moseneke;

- Blaise Judja-Sato, Director Business Development, Teledesic

Corporation, representing GIIC Commissioner Denis Gilhooly;

- Hamadoun Toure, Africa Manager, ICO Global Communications,

representing GIIC Commissioner Olof Lundberg;

- Dr. Robert Day, Strategic Relations Manager, CSIR, representing

GIIC Commissioner Dr. Geoff Garrett.

Joining the GIIC delegation as panelists will be:

- Lucienne Abrahams, Chairperson of the National Information

Technology Forum, South Africa;

- Christine Kisiedu, Director University Library, University of

Ghana;

- Karima Bounemra Ben Soltane, Director ECA Development Information

Services Division; and

- Dr. Steven Ncube, Senior Manager, Development Bank of Southern

Africa.

The media briefing is scheduled for 13h00, 7 May 1997, in the UNECA

Conference Room 2, where the GIIC will deliver its "Statement of Addis

Ababa." Further information on the GIIC and its activities can be

accessed on the GIIC web site at: www.gii.org/giic/ or the ECA Web site

at: www.un.org/depts/eca.

The M-Net production on DStv will be on the PAS-4 satellite on

channel 25 (C-band) and channel 32 (Ku-band), from 09h00 to 16h00

central African time. (All other times in this announcement are Addis

Ababa local time.)

(END)

FOR MORE INFORMATION PLEASE CONTACT:

Dr. Derrick Cogburn, GIIC Secretariat Tel: +1-202-755-3134 Ext 406

Fax: +1-202-452-1340 E-Mail: dcogburn@csis.org

or Mr. Peter K.A. da Costa, ECA Secretariat Tel: +251-1-51-58-26

(direct) or +251-1-51-72-00 Ext 161 (switchboard) Fax: +251-1-51-22-33

E-Mail: <ipspdc@harare.iafrica.com> or <Peter_daCosta_at_UNECA@un.org>

121 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Southern Africa;
MISA Releases Its 1996 State Of Media Report


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Windhoek - The Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA) has released

its 1996 state of the media report on Southern Africa to coincide with

the World Press Freedom Day, May 3.

The report titled 'So This Is Democracy?' is a compilation of media

freedom violations that took place in the year 1996. These media freedom

violations were monitored by the MISA Secretariat here in Windhoek. 

The 1996 report has on record 124 Alerts and 31 press releases. Of

these alerts 116 were issued by MISA's Information Unit.

In part, the report says alerts issued in 1996 show a similar trend

to that seen during the previous year. The same three countries which

headed the 1995 alerts league - Zambia, Zimbabwe and Namibia - again

came out top in 1996 with 49, 18 and 17 alerts issued respectively.

But says the report, MISA's media monitoring work is not about

compiling tables and statistics, and the number of alerts issued is "as

much a reflection of the effectiveness of MISA's information gathering

as it is about the state of media freedom in the countries concerned."

The report says that the monopoly of the media by states and business

conglomerates also stood in the way of media development in as much the

same way as unfriendly media legislation.

"Nonetheless," says the report, "Zambia, Zimbabwe, and Namibia again

stand out because they are all multi-party democracies with

democratically-elected governments where media freedom and freedom of

expression are being eroded despite the existence of constitutions

guaranteeing freedom of expression and, in the case of Namibia, media

freedom."

In other countries such as Angola, Lesotho and Mozambique, media

freedom monitoring work was hampered by largely the poor

telecommunications system. However, further research into countries like

Angola, Lesotho and Tanzania revealed that media freedom situation there

was equally unpleasant.

It adds that the monitoring of and the campaign against violations of

media freedom and free expression, with a view to promoting a greater

understanding of issues which lie at the heart of the democratisation

process, therefore remains MISA's top priority.

In the preface of the report, Chairperson of the MISA Trust Funds

Board, Justice John Manyarara says official and unofficial censorship of

the media exist in various forms in the Southern African Development

Community (SADC) region.

"The practice," adds Justice Manyarara, "operates against media

freedom and editorial independence and justifies monitoring of media

activities."

MISA's Governing Council Chairperson Clara Olsen notes in her

foreword to the report that the outlook on the freedom of expression on

the SADC region continues to be bleak.

"There is little sign that this important human right is recognised

for what it is, a prerequisite to the democratic development of a

country," Olsen says.

Olsen concludes her foreword by saying that media in the SADC

countries must lead the way in informing governments and people in

general about the advent of the new information age - and that the SADC

countries can only be part of this new age if media are free,

unfettered, independent and developed.

FOR FURTHER INFORMATION ABOUT THE 1996 REPORT, CONTACT: DAVID

NTHENGWE; Tel: +264 61 232 975; Fax: +264 61 248 016; e-mail

research@ingrid.misa.org.na.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 5, 1997


South Africa;
Tutu Makes Final Amnesty Appeal


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Cape Town - Archbishop Desmond Tutu has made an impassioned appeal to

South Africans right across the political spectrum who were involved in

political acts which might lead to criminal charges or civil actions for

damages to apply for amnesty within the next six days.

His appeal was recorded for broadcast tonight on SABC Television's

popular programme, TRC Special Report.

The deadline for amnesty applications is midnight on Saturday May 10.

After the deadline has passed, people who have committed acts,

omissions or offences which are associated with political objectives and

who have not applied for amnesty will be liable for prosecution or civil

actions. 

"This is a cry from the heart," Archbishop Tutu said. "I appeal to

all of you, right across the political spectrum, please take this golden

opportunity to apply for amnesty on the most generous terms possible."

His appeal selected a number of categories of people for special

mention: -- Members of the Security Forces, including those involved in

cross- border operations; -- Township activists such as those in Self-

Defence Units; -- Other township residents such as those living in

hostels; -- Operatives of Military Intelligence and the CCB; and --

Leaders of political parties.

The categories identified include elements of the former South

African Defence Force such as the Directorate of Special Tasks, the

Directorate of Covert Collection, Special Forces ("Spesmagte") and

national servicemen who witnessed or have knowledge of acts which could

lead to prosecutions or civil actions.

Also speaking to Special Report, Archbishop Tutu warned: "As far as

the TRC is concerned, blanket amnesty is out."

Dealing with suggestions that blanket amnesty might have to be given

if the Amnesty Committee could not complete its work, he said the

Minister of Justice had agreed to a proposal to enlarge the Committee.

It could also sit until early next year if necessary.

The full text of the Chairperson's appeal follows:

"THE ARCHBISHOP'S APPEAL TO THE NATION:

"Dear Fellow South Africans:

"This is a cry from the heart. May the 10th is just around the corner

on Saturday. That is the deadline for applications for amnesty. I appeal

to all of you, right across the political spectrum, please take this

golden opportunity to apply for amnesty on the most generous terms

possible.

"This applies to you, leaders of political parties, this applies to

you, people who were in the Security Forces. It applies to you who were

involved in cross-border raids, because you are exposed to the

possibility of civil proceedings for damages against you by those who

were victims of your

operations.

"I appeal to you who were in SDUs in the townships, to you in the

hostels.

"I appeal to you who were in the CCB and Military Intelligence."

"This amnesty is one that would expunge any criminal or civil

liability you are likely to have. Please come forward because this is an

opportunity to put the past behind you; to help in the process of your

own healing and the healing of this beautiful land. Please come."

His comments regarding the possibility of blanket amnesty being

granted if the TRC cannot finish its work follow:

"We have asked the Minister of Justice and he has agreed to our

request that the Amnesty Committee should be enlarged. This is in order

to ensure that all the applications are dealt with by our committee. We

hope that it would be able to have finished its work at best at the end

of this year. It just might be necessary for them to continue into the

first part of next year before we present our report in March. As far as

the TRC is concerned blanket amnesty is out. It would make nonsense of

all the work we have done hitherto to say because we are unable to deal

with the applications, let us now grant blanket amnesty. It would be

very difficult to justify to the victims...."


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


123 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Business and Finance;
Seaside Cinderella to become beach front belle


BYLINE: Chene Blignaut, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1374 words


 

Cape Town - Mouille Point, once the Cinderella stretch of the

Atlantic coastline, is set to become the Riviera of the Cape, with major

developments and a massive upgrade of facilities planned for the area.

Plans for a new Waterfront access road, a public park, pedestrian

walkways and cycle paths, improved sport and recreational facilities,

international hotels and a multi-million rand upgrade of the beachfront

are expected to transform this neglected part of the city into a tourist

hub.

By providing improved facilities, the city council hopes to form a

natural link between this area and the Waterfront.

"With the growth of tourism in the Western Cape, Mouille Point has

become an area with enormous development potential," said deputy city

planner Basil Tommy. 

The spectacular views of the sea and the mountains from this area and

its proximity to the beaches of the Atlantic seaboard, the central

business district and the Waterfront all added to the attraction, he

said.

Plans for the area include a new road linking the Western Boulevard

to Beach Rd in Mouille Point, as part of a development framework for the

Green Point common area. The road, parallel to Portswood Road, will

provide easier access to the Waterfront from the Atlantic Seaboard side,

and alleviate traffic congestion.

Other ideas for the council-owned common include pedestrian walkways

and cycle pathways with links to surrounding areas, improved sporting

facilities and a public park. The framework has been negotiated through

an extensive public participation programme and is expected to be

finalised by June.

Meanwhile, private-owned land along the coastline is being snapped up

by developers who see Mouille Point as the perfect location for hotels.

Planned projects along the coastline include the R150-million five-

star sectional title Villa Via hotel at Granger Bay, the R220-million

Gateway sectional title hotel project and a R200-million international

hotel between Surrey and Rothsay roads.

The Villa Via, at the Water Club in Granger Bay, is under

construction and building of the other two hotels is expected to start

later this year.

La Splendida Luxury Suites, a new R10-million hotel development along

this coastline, opened its doors in March.

To increase the viability of their projects some investors have

undertaken to contribute to the upliftment of the beachfront area

between Granger Bay and the lighthouse at a cost of millions of rands.

Plans for this area include extensive landscaping and the creation of

a spectacular ocean boulevard. The beachfront plan is expected to be

completed by the middle of the year and implementation is expected

before December.

"We have the opportunity to reintroduce the kind of activities that

used to take place along the Sea Point promenade at the old Carousel,

which was a place where people met and socialised," said Mr Tommy of the

planned ocean walkway.

Rollerbladers and joggers already frequent the pavement stretch

between Granger Bay and the lighthouse.

Town planners are also negotiating with lease-holders on council land

on the stretch between the lighthouse and the Three Anchor Bay boat ramp

to get them to improve facilities in this area. Among these are the

little blue train, the maze and the putt-putt course.

The possible downgrading of Beach Road, which is a provincial main

road, is being investigated. The plan is to reduce traffic on this road

and make it safer to cross to the beachfront.

Contributing to the area's facelift is the recent upgrading of the

Mouille Point lighthouse, the revamp of the commercial building at 129

Beach Road and the renovation of several older buildings along the

coastline. The historic Fort Wynyard will be upgraded to house a

military museum.

More development opportunities could become available along Portswood

Road, with the consolidation of health facilities at City Park and

Somerset hospitals and the subsequent disposal of surplus land and

buildings, said Mr Tommy.

Inner Cape investment chairman Jochen Buechel, developer of the

Gateway project, will contribute between R1-million and R1,5-million to

the upgrading of the beachfront in front of this hotel.

"This area is fast becoming the Cote d'Azur of the Cape," said Mr

Buechel.

Mr Buechel, who said developers should contribute to the upliftment

of the areas in which they build, has pledged R500 000 towards a

community project to look after street children in the area.

Roy Licht, director of TDC which will develop the still unnamed hotel

between Surrey and Rothsay roads with an international hotel group, is

kicking off the transformation of the beachfront by financing drawing up

of the plan. He will pay another R1-million towards implementation.

"Mouille Point is a fantastic location and it has the potential to

become the jewel of the Cape, it just needs an impetus. This can become

the Riviera of Cape Town and we are planning to give Camps Bay a run for

its money," said Mr Licht.

He said upgrading of the beachfront as the first phase of the

extension of the Waterfront. The beachfront upgrade would make the

Waterfront "work better", because it had become "commercialised".

"The upgrade will melt the Waterfront into the open recreational

areas of Mouille Point," he said.

Mr Licht said Cape Town, with its international reputation, was the

"buzz word" in property and Mouille Point was "the right side of the

railway line".

The Granger Bay Trust, developers of Villa Via, have brick-paved and

landscaped the sidewalk area outside the Water Club as part of their

contribution towards the link between the Waterfront and Mouille Point.

"Our project acted as a catalyst for development in this area," said

project manager Clive Lurie.

Meanwhile, local residents have accepted that they "cannot put a

finger in the dyke" of development in the area, said Bronnie Harding,

chairman of the Mouille Point Ratepayers' Association.

"Providing the development conforms to council regulations, we cannot

stop it. With the ever-increasing Waterfront, Mouille Point has become

the most sought-after area in the city," she said.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


124 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Zaire;
Kabila scores with 'instant democracy'


BYLINE: Ross Herbert, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1640 words


 

Kisangani - While talks on a peace settlement in Zaire continue,

rebel leader Laurent Desire Kabila has introduced an extraordinary third

force that has the potential to upset any negotiated settlement: instant

democracy, which Mr Kabila promises to bring to every captured city.

Mr Kabila's high-speed elections are astounding both for the

simplicity of their method and for the contrast they offer with previous

African liberation movements that have often promised democracy, but

taken years to deliver elections.

Under intense international pressure, President Mobutu Sese Seko

allowed opposition political parties only in 1990. Since then, for seven

years, he has successfully resisted scheduling free elections.

Just six days after Mr Kabila's army captured Kisangani (formerly

Stanleyville), Zaire's third-largest city, Mr Kabila and his advisors

swept into the city to set up a government. Six hours later, the first 

elections were completed for the commissars for each of Kisangani's six

administrative zones. The next day a provincial governor, vice-governor

and mayor were elected.

How does one organise elections in six hours? The process began when

representatives from Mr Kabila's Alliance of Democratic Forces for the

Liberation of Congo fanned out to the six municipal zones.

Hundreds of people gathered around humble meeting halls and

administrative buildings. Earlier in the week, alliance officials

announced the elections would be held, but no schedule was announced.

Most who joined the crowds of voters heard by word of mouth or simply

saw a crowd forming.

In Tshopo, the most populous city zone, alliance justice minister

Nkongolo Mwenze conducted the elections with a few aides and a single

soldier. A chair and two tables were set in front of a crowd of about

400 people. Mr Mwenze climbed atop a table and began explaining, in a

loud bellow, the unusual procedure that was to follow.

The first stage was the campaign: each of 25 Tshopo candidates got a

chance to climb atop the table and present himself to the crowd (there

are no female candidates and few women in the crowd). The first

candidate, Honore Myango, tried to explain that he is not a member of

the party of Mr Mobutu, although his brother is a Mobutist. His speech

was drowned out by a cacophony of shouts in the crowd that gradually

coalesced around a chant of "Mouvancier, Mouvancier," the name for Mr

Mobutu's political family that has become an epithet in Kisangani.

Mr Myango stepped down and a new candidate's name was bellowed out.

He stepped up and shouted: "I have never worked before, but I want to

now." Thunderous laughter and "Ooooooo" sounds leapt from the

increasingly excited crowd.

The third candidate faced raucous cries that he shouldn't run because

he drinks too much. A fourth candidate simply held forth a Red Cross

business card. "Mouvancier, Mouvancier!" the crowd replied.

Poye Poyo, a 33-year-old assistant professor, stepped on the table

and, without a word, tied a white strip of cloth around his head, a

symbol of support for the rebel alliance. The crowd went wild with

cheers and chants of support.

After all the candidates were presented, the list was winnowed down

to four. Voting was by show of hands: each candidate climbed onto the

table and members of the crowd were asked to raise a hand if they

supported keeping the candidate on the short list. Then the crowd was

asked to raise a hand if they opposed the candidate remaining on the

list. If more hands opposed, the candidate is eliminated.

One by one, candidates were cut until only two remained. Mr Poyo, the

Kabila supporter, was the overwhelming favourite. A 28-year-old

university student was elected his vice-commissar.

In Tshopo and other zones, greater age was tantamount to complicity

with Mr Mobutu. Virtually every candidate over 40 was greeted with the

familiar derisive chants.

"We reject this system because it is undemocratic. The university is

very near and there are many students here," complained Mr Myango, the

former vice-commissar for Tshopo.

His comments were drowned with bitter shouts. "Old people have

spoiled this country. They have eaten for a long time and must leave the

place to young people," one young man screamed.

Across Kisangani the results were similar: young opposition

candidates captured all six commissar posts.

However, one Mobutu official, considered an honest man, was elected

vice-commissar. The next day, thousands of residents gathered at the

city soccer stadium to repeat the process to elect a provincial

governor, vice-governor and mayor.

Such a crude voting system is far from perfect. Lack of advance

notice kept many from voting or standing for office. Because voting took

place at a single location, rural voters were effectively excluded.

Still, mob democracy, no matter how flawed, was preferable to no

democracy to most Kisangani residents.

There were squabbles over whether voters could raise one hand or two.

At times it was difficult to determine which candidate had more votes.

In most cases, public opinion was overwhelmingly against Mobutu

officials and in favour of the most hard-core opposition figures.

However, when results were close, the crowds had a clear sense of fair

play.

Although he had broad support, Obotela Rashidi, a history professor,

was eliminated as a candidate for governor and returned to his position

in the heart of a crowd of thousands.

A separate list of candidates for vice-governor had been prepared

without his name and none of Mr Kabila's advisors had thought of

allowing unsuccessful candidates to run again for lower office.

After sustained protest from the crowd, Professor Rashidi was bodily

lifted and passed hand over hand over the crowd and to the stage, and

elected vice-governor.

Despite the flaws, no alliance candidates stood for office while many

Mobutists tried and failed to win.

The leader of the Union for Democracy and Social Progress, the main

national opposition party, was elected governor while UDPS candidates

won in four of six zones.

The Kisangani elections came the same day that Mr Kabila announced he

was banning all political party activity for the duration of the war.

Clearly, Mr Kabila is highly popular in Kisangani, in part because

disdain for Mr Mobutu and his army runs so deep.

However, the alliance has virtually no political organisation and

might lose at levels below the presidency if its candidates were to

stand against better organised national parties, such as UDPS.

Such a rough system of democracy does offer the rebels other

practical advantages: "There is no one here. The officials all fled the

city. We have to have someone in charge before we leave to continue the

fight. This is not perfect democracy, but it is the best we can do,"

explained Mawampanga Mwana Nanga, Mr Kabila's minister of economics and

finance.

It is possible that Mr Kabila, like many revolutionaries before him,

will lose enthusiasm for democracy once he captures complete power.

For the moment, the need to give power to the people, fight

corruption and work hard are the themes of every speech by Mr Kabila and

his representatives.

Such pledges are helping build their popularity and building a bank

of promises that will be hard to renounce.

By bringing elections to occupied territory, Mr Kabila also deftly

increases his leverage in negotiations with Mr Mobutu.

How, Mr Kabila asks, can he return power to Mobutu officials when the

people have elected their own leaders in occupied territory?


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


125 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


South Africa;
Fraud 'undermining growth as police focus on violence'


BYLINE: Thabo Mabaso, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Cape Town - A leading business consultant has urged the government to

deal quickly with violent crime to free police resources to deal with

the constant rise in business fraud.

Deloitte & Touche director Jonathan Briant said businesses also

needed to take the initiative, rather than wait for the government to

tackle the problem.

"Until violent crime is brought under control, the resources of

government will never be properly focused on the insidious crimes that

undermine the foundation on which the new economic prosperity must be

built," he said. 

Mr Briant was responding to a report that fraud in European Union

countries was costing member states up to 60-billion ECUs (R12-billion)

a year.

Most frauds in these states went unreported and there was no reliable

data available on their extent. In an effort to stem the fraud, Europe's

governing body, the European Commission, had suggested that member

states should, among other things, consider co-operating through the

courts.

"The reality for South Africans is that reliance on governmental

action is a luxury we cannot afford. It is very much up to us to protect

ourselves from fraud," Mr Briant said.

Fraud in South Africa's public and private sectors has been on the

increase. Various commissions of inquiry have been set up to probe

reports of impropriety.

These reports include a statement by finance minister Trevor Manuel

that government cheques with a face value of some R15,7-million were

stolen and cashed in 1996, while the office of the auditor general has

reported that between 1991 and 1995 civil servants in the former TBVC

states may have been overpaid by more than R1-billion.

"The report on international fraud in the European Union is a timely

reminder that the effects of fraud and white collar crime are as keenly

felt in Europe as in Africa. The major difference is that the Europeans

are acting on a significant and continent-wide basis," Mr Briant said.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


126 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


South Africa;
Drug dealers won't escape prosecution, says Ball


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Cape Town - The Olympic Peace Initiative launched with local gangs

last week does not oblige gangsters to stop their lucrative drugs trade

and it will not protect them against prosecution.

The issue of drugs is the most controversial element of what Bid

Company chief executive Chris Ball describes as a "brave" initiative. 

But Mr Ball, who made it clear the gangs-for-peace strategy was not a

bid project but an initiative of the independent Cape Town Community

Olympic Forum, emphasised: "Any activity which contravenes the law must

be prosecuted."

On the tricky subject of the exclusion of drug dealing from the terms

of the revolutionary accord between the forum and local gangs, Mr Ball

said: "It would be nice to wave a flag and stop drug activity overnight,

but you could only do that through draconian measures, or a set of

activities over a period of time."

The Bid Company had supported the initiative because "it is better to

have a peace accord, and to attempt to do something positive about

violence and crime than not to try at all".

"This should be seen only as the first stage, and if one wants

criminal activity to cease completely, gangsters need to be integrated

into society," he said.

"The initiative is an unusual type of activity, which is not part of

the bid's job. It is not our task to restructure the social fabric of

the community, but if the bid can be used as a catalyst to achieve

something constructive, then it is to be encouraged."

There was no question of the bid being used to "legitimise

gangsters". The forum's initiative was an opportunity for the gangs to

make a positive contribution.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 5, 1997


South Africa;
Bid media boss quits to work for youth commission


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Cape Town - Bid Company media manager Paul Johnson leaves the bid

team this month to join Deputy President Thabo Mbeki's office as

communications director for the National Youth Commission.

He is the second senior bid official to leave the company in recent

weeks. The first was marketing director Andre Krogh.

Mr Johnson said the opportunity to be part of Mr Mbeki's team was a

"compelling challenge", though he remained an "active supporter and

voluntary agent" of the bid.

He added that "with a low-maintenance, systems-based plan and a sound

media team in place, there is no issue around my departure impacting in

any significant way on the ongoing bid media programme".

Departures from the bid team have required some minor restructuring

of staff, but have not come as a surprise. Whether or not Cape Town wins

the bid on September 5, the Bid Company will be dissolved on that date,

and staff employed on contract will be without jobs. It is natural that

opportunities that arise between now and then will be seriously

considered by staff in this position.

In contrast, most senior staff have been seconded from private

companies and various levels of government, and their professional

future is secure.

LANGUAGE: English

128 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Sports - General;
Marine Costa: taking the plunge to pursue her dreams


BYLINE: Ian Sadler, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Cape Town - When her proud parents had her christened 21 years ago in

Angola, little could they have realised how appropriate their choice of

name would be.

And coupled with her surname (coast in Portuguese) it seemed Marine

Costa, recently of Luanda, was destined for things aquatic.

She's in serious training for her debut at the Berg River Canoe

marathon in July, but before that she will go to Hong Kong for the world

dragon boat championships - last weekend was taken up competing in the

South African river rafting championships on the Orange River.

So what attracted Costa - who has wanted to be a lawyer for as long

as she can remember - to the Mother City? 

About two years ago she met a group of South African pilots in Luanda

where she was living with her mother, who works for the Dutch embassy,

her father who's with the United Nations, and three younger siblings.

"Education in Angola is in a mess. In fact it's a big joke, and one

of the pilots suggested I go to Cape Town to study law. I came for a

week in 1995, absolutely loved it, and returned to Cape Town in January

last year after completing my schooling in Luanda," said Marine.

But an Angolan matric wasn't enough for a ticket to a South African

university so last year was a case of around the course again (in an

educational sense) at Boston College so she could enroll at Unisa to

start her legal studies. She hopes to study fulltime at the University

of Cape Town next year.

This isn't her first time away from home. She lived in Rotterdam for

four years with her mother and grand parents.

"That was great, but the weather terrible. There's also a huge

difference going to first-world Holland from third-world Angola," said

Marine. "I used to swim a lot back home in Luanda and was lucky to be

able to carry on at indoor pools while at school in Rotterdam." Other

ports of call before Holland were short stays in Cape Verde Islands and

Portugal before settling once again in Angola - all this before she was

11.

Then Cape Town beckoned and after her unexpected second matric, she

moved into a flat in Rondebosch with a friend and was introduced to a

sport she had never dreamt of pursuing - canoeing. Apart from swimming,

the only other sport that had interested her at that stage was

basketball, while she was at school in Luanda.

"My new flatmate, Bronwyn Hobbs, who is hooked on canoeing, having

taken the plunge just after last year's Berg River marathon, invited me

along, so I went down to Sandvlei for a couple of training sessions with

her and soon got the hang of it," said Marine.

Truth of the matter is she took to it like a duck to water, joined

the Peninsula Canoe Club and met Edgar Boehm, a veteran of 23 "Bergs".

For the past seven years Boehm has introduced dozens of novices to

the Berg. In January each year his group - called Ducklings - take to

the water. The Ducklings - normally about 15 budding Berg marathoners -

climb into canoes under the watchful eye of Boehm to get the feel on the

calm waters of Sandvlei. About three Sundays later they graduate to the

Breede River for a month of Sundays before hitting the Berg where the

master passes on his tips. When the main event arrives (July 9 to 12

this year) only about five original Ducklings start the punishing event.

Marine is committed to being there. "All my training is aimed at the

Berg. I'll definitely be at the start in Paarl. There is no doubt about

that," she said after another gruelling session at the gym.

She goes to the gym every day, but doesnot use weights. "I tend to

put on muscle very easily and don't want to end up looking like Rambo.

"I am quite strong. After canoeing for only four months I can pull

away from people who have been at it for years."

How did she get involved in dragon boat paddling?

"Many canoeists try paddle skiing, river rafting and dragon boats.

One of my friends suggested it. I enjoy the way you have to work out

there, I like exercise. The SA Dragon Boat Association were looking for

people for Hong Kong and naturally I jumped at the chance."

The team will compete in Macau, warming up for the world

championships to be held on the Shing Mun River, Hong Kong. The event,

from June 12 to 15, promises to be an historic occasion as the regatta

will form part of the festivities celebrating Hong Kong's return to

China on July 1.

And although dragon boat regattas look to be more fun and festive

than conventional canoeing, it's hard work as Marine discovered at the

thrice-weekly sessions at Sandvlei and the Waterfront.

"Each boat has a crew of 22 that includes a pace-setting drummer and

helmsman. So 20 paddlers have to keep perfect timing or there's trouble.

"When I first started I used to drag my paddle, but that didn't last

long, unless you enjoy having your elbow pounded by the paddler behind.

"Timing is important. Each paddler must take their cue from the

person diagonally in front at the same time keeping pace with the

drummer. The action is similar to paddling a river raft."


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


129 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Zaire;
Mr Mandela loses his cool (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Cape Town - President Mandela has presided over the first meeting

between president Mobutu of Zaire and the country's rebel leader Laurent

Kabila after both sides showed reluctance to attend peace talks

The extraordinary spectacle of President Mandela kicking his heels on

board a South African naval vessel for more than a day waiting for the

antagonists in Zaire's civil war to show up for peace talks over the

weekend, demonstrated great forbearance and goodwill.

But by all accounts Mr Mandela let it be known that his patience was

wearing thin. The sharp words he is said to have used in a telephone

call to rebel leader Laurent Kabila to ensure that he eventually arrived

on board the SAS Outeniqua as promised, should demonstrate to both sides

in Zaire's civil war what the limits are, and necessarily must be, of

South Africa's involvement in seeking an end to the fighting. 

There is no compelling reason for the South African Government to be

playing a leading role in securing peace at all, other than an

altruistic interest in ending the immense suffering of millions of

innocent victims of the conflict and ensuring that the economic and

social dislocation in central Africa is contained.

And there is no reason why Mr Mandela should risk squandering his

moral authority and political leadership in trying to secure peace when

Mr Mobutu offers implausible reasons for not boarding the SAS Outeniqua

and Mr Kabila simply does not show up, after both had agreed to attend.

South Africa is not a superpower, but Mr Mandela and his government

have shown that they are willing and able to act as peacemakers in Zaire

- and probably elsewhere in Africa. Their willingness is not

unconditional or open-ended, and it should not be taken for granted.

Their commitment to the quest for peace must be fully and sincerely

shared by all parties for any fruitful result to come from their

efforts.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


130 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


South Africa;
FW DeKlerk weighs amnesty bid


BYLINE: Clive Sawyer, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Cape Town - FW de Klerk and former National Party ministers who held

security portfolios are considering applying to the Truth Commission for

amnesty.

The move is being discussed at a federal executive meeting in Cape

Town today, with just five days to go to the deadline for amnesty

applications.

Those who may seek amnesty could include Mr De Klerk, as former state

president and commander-in-chief, former law and order minister Hernus

Kriel and Roelf Meyer, a former deputy law and order minister and one-

time minister of defence. 

If the Truth Commission allows it, they would seek amnesty in their

official, and not personal, capacities.

Last week, the African National Congress announced its national

executive committee had decided that past and present members of the

committee and the various command structures of Umkhonto weSizwe should

apply for amnesty.

General Constand Viljoen, former head of the defence force, announced

earlier that he would apply for amnesty.

Truth Commission head Desmond Tutu at the weekend made an impassioned

appeal for all those who had been involved in gross violations of human

rights, and had not yet applied for amnesty, to do so by the May 10

deadline.

Archbishop Tutu asked leaders of political parties, security forces,

military intelligence operatives, as well as members of self-defence

units and hostel dwellers, to come forward to the amnesty committee.

Amnesty would expunge them of all criminal and civil liability.

Archbishop Tutu firmly ruled out the possibility of a blanket

amnesty, saying it would make nonsense of the TRC's work.

The NP confirmed today that the subject of amnesty applications was

on the agenda its federal executive meeting. It is understood no

specific recommendation will be tabled at the start of the discussion.

Mr De Klerk has said publicly several times, and in the party's most

recent submission to the Truth Commission, that neither he nor his

security portfolio ministers gave orders for murders or other gross

violations of human rights.

Top NP members have so far declined to apply for amnesty on the

grounds that it is designed for those personally culpable for human

rights violations.

Mr De Klerk has said that he and his ministers accept full

responsibility, because of their official posts, for the events of the

apartheid years.

At the weekend, Dene Smuts, Democratic Party spokeswoman on the Truth

Commission, lashed out at the failure of NP leaders to apply for

amnesty.

Their failure and their claims of "clean hands" meant they had left

members of the former security forces to fend for themselves, she said.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


131 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


South Africa;
City elderly under siege


BYLINE: Ashley Smith and Johan Schronen, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Cape Town - Police have warned elderly people living on their own to

exercise "extreme caution" after two women were murdered at the weekend

- and at least one of them opened the door to her killer.

The body of 76-year-old Maureen Botha of Longacres Flats in Sans

Souci Road, Newlands was found on Saturday evening by her son Lewellyn

Botha, a well-known environmental law consultant, after her family had

tried to phone her throughout the day.

Mrs Botha, who would have celebrated her 77th birthday yesterday, had

been strangled. 

Police say her flat was ransacked and there were several appliances

missing.

Her body was discovered about 7pm. She was last seen alive at 3pm on

Friday, but someone had spoken to her on the telephone at 7pm that

evening.

A R50 000 reward is being offered for information leading to the

successful conviction of her killer.

Mr Botha said his mother had been a compassionate person who had a

"broad family" because even strangers she met had felt "close and

comfortable" with her.

"But she was also very security-conscious and would not let strangers

into her flat. I am convinced her killer was some one she trusted," said

Mr Botha.

This is the second murder in the area in two days. A 64-year-old

woman was stabbed to death in her Claremont home on Friday.

The body of Anne Catherine Steele was discovered by her son Laurence,

who last saw her alive when he left for work.

Mrs Steele's body was found in the passage of her home in Mountain

Road.

Police have described the murder as one of the most brutal killings

they have ever seen. Mrs Steele was stabbed in the face.

A worrying aspect of the murder, say police, is that here too they

believe the victim opened the door for her killer.

Police spokesman Mark Romburgh said senior citizens needed to be very

cautious about who they let into their homes.

He also called on elderly people to register themselves at their

local police stations.

"We are also asking that neighbours and family members call on the

elderly on a regular basis, so that they do not become isolated and

vulnerable to attacks," Captain Romburgh said.

The latest attacks come in spite of last month's arrest of a gang

targeting elderly people in the southern suburbs. The gang gained access

to people's homes through a member posing as a messenger after finding

their names on post in letterboxes.

They were linked to an attack on a woman and her elderly mother in

Kenilworth in February in which the mother's arms were broken.

In January the gang allegedly lured another victim out of her home in

Kenilworth by telling her an elderly woman had fallen on the pavement

and needed help.

Another gang, allegedly linked to last month's murder of 83-year-old

Constantia widow Frances Thomson, was arrested soon after the murder.

Another among the spate of elderly women attacked at home was

botanist Elsie Esterhuysen, 84, who survived.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


132 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 5, 1997


Western Sahara;
Sahara Weekly News Update (04/28 - 05/04)


BYLINE: Western Sahara Referendum Support Association


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 960 words


 

Geneva - 26.04.97 -- Waiting for Baker

In occasion of Baker's visit about sixty reporters were in the

Sahrawi camps. They could visit the refugee camps and make themselves an

opinion about the harsch life conditions of the refugees. They could

also encounter Moroccan POWs.

European parliamentary groups and 25 political VIPs from Europe and

Latin America were present to prove to Baker that the Sahrawi issue is

not a marginal conflict, and to show that the Sahrawi people is not

alone. They handed over to Baker a document ( spanish or french), in 

which they express their concern, asking Baker to do all his possible to

save the peace plan.

In a press release (french) the Polisario Front resumes its position,

it exposed to Baker in a memorandum.

27.04.97

Baker's visit

Arriving by plane at Tindouf from Nouakshott Baker reaches the wilaya

of Smara by car. A sand storm did not allow to use a helicopter. Tens of

thousand of refugees lined the dusty road into Smara welcoming Baker'

convoy of jeeps like a liberating army with women ululating, children

cheering, men in flowing robes giving peace signs and eveyone waving the

Sahara flag.

Some 2000 soldiers also stood at attention, many of them aged and

bent, veterans of the war. The talks with Sahrawi officials began

immediately in a tent. To the media James Baker terms his talks as

excellent. He says that the problem was complex and extremely difficult,

but it was not hopeless "or I wouldn't otherwise be here".

"I am convinced that the people in this region are overly weary with

this issue and this problem and are ready for a just lasting and

definitive solution".

"I will present my report to the UN Secretary General after my return

to USA. He has to decide if the peace plan can actually be implemented

or not."

He is likely to return to the region in June, after the UN Security

Council meets to define its position.

Liberation of Moroccan POWs

Baker announced that the Polisario Front was releasing 85 prisoners

of war in a surprise move that he said was "a very, very generous

humanitarian gesture of support for our mission".

The AFAPREDESA, in a communique (french), exprimes its satisfaction

concerning this liberation and hopes the POWs could go home rapidly. The

Sahrawi Human Rights Organisation exprimed the wish Morocco could do

same.

On demand we can give informations to relatives about the identity of

the released prisoners.

27.04.97

Denial

The wives of the Ambassadors of European Union at Rabat refused an

official invitation to visit El Ayoun the main city of the occupied

Western Sahara.

01.05.97

Communique of the Sahrawi Workers Organisation

In occasion of May the first the UGTSARIO in a communique appeals to

all workers organisation to call the Moroccan authorities to stop the

repression against the Sahrawi workers in occupied Western Sahara.

New Sahrawi NGO

On April 18th some technicians and communication specialists have

started in the refugee camps a NGO named ASC, Association pour la

Communication. It will install a reliable communication network, using

modern technology, in order to join the refugee camps with the whole

world.

The ASC is supported by APC, Association for Progressive

Communication, whose membership it will obtain. An International

Conference about Communication and Information concerning Western Sahara

will take place in San Sebastian, Spain, next 6/7/8.of June.

New address of the Representation of the F. Polisario in Switzerland

Mr. Habiballah, Rue de Vermont 9, CH-1202 Geneva, phone + fax: + 41 22

740 34 39

Prepared by ARSO (Association de soutien a un referendum libre et

regulier au Sahara occidental). CP 2229, CH-2800 DELEMONT 2. Tel./Fax:

0041 32 422 87 17. E-mail: arso@hei.unige.ch. WWW:

http://heiwww.unige.ch/arso/.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
