Africa News


May 6, 1997


South Africa;
'Housing, housing housing' - our No 1 problem


BYLINE: Andrea Weiss, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

Cape Town - An acute shortage of low-income housing has been identified as Cape Town's most pressing problem.

Major difficulties facing the city include R50-million owed in rental and rates on council-owned property, racially segregated waiting lists, massive overcrowding in hostels - which are housing thousands of families - and the limited amount of money available through the state housing subsidy scheme.

City manager Andrew Boraine told the Cape Town Press Club recently that " housing, housing, housing" was the most serious problem with which Cape Town had to deal.

The Cape Town municipality is in the process of formulating a strategic development framework to address the housing crisis. Also in the pipeline is a new housing department which will begin to look at both the existing rental stock belonging to the council as well as new housing projects. 

Fourteen key issues affecting housing delivery have been identified in a document which is to be tabled at a series of workshops.

According to Ahmed Vawda, Cape Town municipality's new executive director of community development, the workshops will be an important step towards formulating a housing framework - something which both Durban and Johannesburg have already tackled.

In his view, the priorities are to identify the roles of responsibility of the various roleplayers - the province, the metropolitan council and municipalities - and to get agreement on common systems.

These agreements should cover issues such as the allocation criteria for new housing and the methodologies used in new housing projects.

Other matters that have to be dealt with are transitional arrangements arising out of the inherited situation, and ensuring delivery of existing projects is not held up.

Among the 14 key issues to be laid on the table at the workshops are:

* The Cape Town municipality waiting lists, previously limited to coloured families, have about 44 000 names on them. There are two lists - the first, dating from 1968 to 1987, has 16 596 names on it, and the second, from 1988 to the present day, has

29 097 names. As there is an average 12-year wait for a vacancy in rental schemes, the second list is not in use. There are also waiting lists for Ikapa and Crossroads, but the status of the lists and numbers is not known.

* There is an urgent need for public land to be made available for housing in the low-income market but a comprehensive data base of all vacant city land is still being prepared. There is no agreed policy for the release of land and there are competing uses, such as between housing, recreational and commercial uses. The cost of serviced land also takes up almost 70 percent of the available housing subsidy.

* Housing finance and affordability. One of the problems to have emerged out of the housing subsidy scheme is the inability of low-income earners to raise small loans to top up the available subsidy. This means there is little money left for the dwelling itself - most goes on the provision of services - because an estimated 75 percent of people in Cape Town earn less than R2 500 a month.

* Subletting is widespread in council rental estates but the tenure of the tenants is insecure and they are open to exploitation. Overcrowding is also widespread. While there is a demand for rental accommodation, a national policy is not ready yet. There is also illegal renting of state land in squatter areas although this is being ironed out through the integrated Serviced Land Project, which is providing 34 000 serviced sites on a freehold title to beneficiaries.

* Housing delivery in the Cape Town municipality is mainly confined to the integrated Serviced Land Project (iSLP) which is constrained by the limited amount of money left over for the actual houses.

* There are an estimated 25 000 backyard shacks in the Cape Town municipality, and possibly 55 000 to 100 000 in the metropolitan area. These shacks do not meet building regulations and have not been approved by the local authority. They also lead to services and facilities overload. Planning needs to recognise that given the housing shortage, subletting and backyard shacks are inevitable.

* In the Ikapa area, hostels provide on average one bed per family with consequent massive overcrowding, overloading of infrastructure, a breakdown in administration and no rental payments coming in. Upgrading will displace some families who will have to be accommodated elsewhere. An estimated 96 000 people share 22 000 bed spaces in public hostels, while a further

15 000 are accommodated in 3 360 beds in 54 private hostels.

* While higher density affordable housing has been identified as desirable in planning terms, high construction costs do not make it affordable for the poor. The existing housing subsidy scheme means that higher density housing is affordable only for those earning above R3 500 a month.

* The council administers and manages about 63 724 rental units which are plagued with arrears. Some people living in these houses are enjoying highly- subsidised rentals because they may be earning well above the income levels which would normally qualify them, but there are no up-to-date income assessments.

* Homeless people living on the streets of the city need to be catered for, whether through shelters, skills training or rehabilitation programmes. Street people impact on business confidence in the city and often find themselves in conflict with permanent residents or businesses.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


152 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


South Africa;
Here on the Flats, there's a place called the Waterfront .. .


BYLINE: Andrea Weiss and Jermaine Craig, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Cape Town - Glamour, glitz and upmarket shopping might be the hallmark of Cape Town's Waterfront, but there's another Waterfront in town which speaks volumes for the housing problems facing the city.

The Waterfront is an informal settlement at the edge of Guguletu, sandwiched between Lansdowne Road, the railway line and a foul sewer canal - hence the name Waterfront - which serves as a general rubbish tip.

It stands cheek-by-jowl with the neighbouring settlements of Polla Park and Fezeka. 

More than 800 families live at the Waterfront, mostly in one-roomed shacks.

Residents have between them 15 toilets and there are an estimated 300 people to one water tap.

Conditions can best be described as squalid even though a handful of residents are making a brave attempt at decorating their shacks, whether with bright paint or a few potted plants .

There are no services to speak of and certainly no recreational facilities.

Most rubbish seems to end up in the canal.

Shopping is limited to three spaza shops, and entertainment is laid on by the four shebeens in the settlement.

Preschool children whose mothers work may attend a creche in nearby Polla Park.

The risks of fire and the squalid conditions, including concrete-lined gutters which run through the settlement, are sufficient reason for residents to aspire to move out - possibly to one of the integrated Serviced Land Project's new developments.

The integrated Serviced Land Project is the largest housing project in the country and currently Cape Town's only major housing initiative.

The Waterfront is not much more than two years old.

Its residents consist mainly of overflow from the nearby Kiki hostels, with many women setting up home after attempting to join their husbands in Cape Town but finding that their husbands were already ensconced with another family.

Another major component of the Waterfront's population are young people from Guguletu who leave home and set up shacks on their own in a bid for freedom and independence.

Then there are the new arrivals from the former Transkei and Ciskei who have come to Cape Town to seek work.

A committee of 15 is in place at the Waterfront to regulate community activities and will be pivotal in determining who is allocated housing should it become available elsewhere.

In the meantime, they're hoping for more toilets - but a wall which separates the settlement from the railway line has been cited as a barrier by the council, according to a local committee member.

On any given day, the stench of raw sewerage hangs over the settlement and toddlers scrabble in the dirt outside their homes with little prospect of a patch of lawn or a swing to play on, let alone a real house.

One is left to wonder whether the name - the Waterfront - is an expression of hope for better prospects or simply a name thought up by someone with a very wry sense of humour.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


153 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


South Africa;
Water on tap, electricity for 600 Crossroads families


BYLINE: Andrea Weiss and Jermaine Craig, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Cape Town - More than 600 families are to benefit from the first development to have taken place in the once war-torn Crossroads, ravaged by conflict in the mid-1980s.

The development of 604 sites in Phase 4 is part of the integrated Serviced Land Project (iSLP), the largest housing project in the country and currently Cape Town's only major housing initiative.

The Crossroads sites are due to be ready by September this year, and beneficiary families are to be given an education and information programme before they take occupation. 

The local elections last year have been cited as a reason for "peace breaking out" in Crossroads as former warlord Jeffrey Nongwe was roundly beaten by African National Congress councillors at the polls.

But the integrated Serviced Land Project has come under fire from councillors in the Cape Town municipality who voted to have the project suspended recently on the grounds that the houses being delivered were not up to scratch.

The Cape Town municipality is not, however, in charge of the project.

It is a presidential lead project with a budget allocation of R1,2-billion and it will provide 34 000 serviced sites to families, the bulk of whom earn less than R800 a month.

One of the problems which has beset the iSLP is that there is little money left over from the state subsidy to build a "top structure" - or actual house - with the bulk of the subsidy being spent on servicing the land.

Municipal engineers maintain that high service standards are necessary to save on long-term maintenance costs.

Another problem is that low income-earners cannot raise loans to supplement the subsidy. Thus the houses that are built are extremely small and in the " matchbox" mould.

Also, a strategy to upgrade informal settlements once their occupants have moved to new sites is being hampered by the fact that other people move in as soon as the former occupants move on.

Some informal settlements are also located on land which cannot be upgraded because of its poor quality, such as the 1 000 families who live in the settlements known as Barcelona and Europe on the old municipal rubbish dump alongside the N2 near the airport

While politicians have been arguing over the iSLP, many residents have already moved into their new homes or on to the sites allocated to them for self-build schemes, indicating that those desperate for housing are willing to take what they can get.

Mbuyi Nombembe, a facilitator with the iSLP, feels that the way in which the houses are viewed depends on where people are coming from.

For those who have been living in unserviced squatter settlements such as Barcelona, Europe or the ironically named Waterfront, it is definitely a step up to live in a house which has water on tap, a flush toilet and electricity.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


154 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


Business and Finance;
Durbs, Cape in tourism row


BYLINE: Alan Cooper and Chene Blignaut, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Cape Town - The tourism industry has been hit by a war of words over where international delegates to a tourism indaba would prefer to be - Durban or Cape Town.

Durban is miffed because one of South Africa's tourism bosses has said the visitors to the conference in that city would prefer to be in Cape Town.

Durban's pique surfaced as Indaba '97 opened yesterday at the Durban Exhibition Centre, attracting nearly 1 000 foreign delegates and journalists. 

Remarks by Reg Swarts, acting chief executive of Satour, which organises the hugely popular expo, have drawn criticism form Durban's metropolitan council and tourism promoters.

In an interview with the Cape Argus, Mr Swarts said: "All the international people would love to be at the Indaba in Cape Town, but you (Cape Town) just don't have the facility to accommodate all of them."

Durban's marketing bosses are seething at the remark, which they said implied that Cape Town would be a better choice of venue than Durban for the country's top tourism and travel expo.

Mr Swarts also described the Western Cape as one of the "icons" of the show, because of its scenic beauty and newly discovered cultural opportunities such as Robben Island.

With Durban already losing ground to Cape Town in the race to attract overseas visitors, the remarks have struck a raw nerve with city promoters.

Metro council communications director Peter Bendheim said: "If Mr Swarts has been quoted correctly, his comments are extremely unfortunate, coming from someone who is supposed to represent South African tourism as a whole, not individual cities."

He said the foreign delegates he had spoken to were more than impressed with Durban and its conference facilities.

"Even if Cape Town were to come up with better exhibition facilities, which is unlikely, given the fact that our International Convention Centre comes on line in August, Durban would still be the better venue.

"It's South Africa's only truly African city. In Cape Town, delegates might as well be in Europe with a pretty mountain in the background."

Tourism Durban declined a direct response, but privately, officials say the last time Cape Town hosted the Indaba in 1991, the "shambles" that ensued resulted in Durban's being awarded the show for the next six years running.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


155 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
ECA Looks to Boost Trade and Investment


BYLINE: UN Economic Commission for Africa (ECA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1294 words


 

Addis Ababa - ECA CHIEF CALLS ON AFRICA TO PURSUE "MORE PURPOSEFUL ENGAGEMENT" IN WORLD TRADE, UN SECRETARY GENERAL PRAISES ECA FOR INITIATIVE ON INFORMATION AND COMMUNICATION TECHNOLOGIES

There has been a distinct change of attitude in Africa, an embrace rather than an avoidance of business and private sector development as well as the willingness of governments to create environment that allow investors and entrepreneurs to flourish, a senior UN official has said.

These promising trends -- including the emergence of a new generation of reform-minded leaders in many African countries -- "are the reasons for much hope and optimism about Africa", said UN Under-Secretary General and ECA Executive Secretary K.Y. Amoako.

Addressing the opening ceremony of an ECA conference of African ministers responsible for economic and social development here Monday, Amoako added: " To foster and nurture these positive trends requires perseverance and commitment. Nowhere is such perseverance and commitment needed more than in accelerating trade and investment". 

'Accelerating Trade and Investment in Africa' is the theme of the three-day conference, which brings together senior African experts and policymakers, including a number of ministers.

Amoako's point was bolstered by Kasu Ilala, Deputy Prime Minister of Ethiopia, who in his statement to the conference said that with the exception of a few countries "the general economic situation in Africa in terms of growth domestic products (GDP) has, by and large, been improving since 1995".

His optimism notwithstanding, the ECA Executive Secretary stressed that Africa has steadily lost world export market shares for its principal exports which, in turn, have seen their relative importance in world trade decline -- from 6 per cent in 1980 to 2 per cent in 1995.

"In regard to trade expansion, we must embark on a more dynamic course marked by increased participation in world trade and a more purposeful engagement in international exchange of resources", Amoako said.

He added: "In view of the weakening of traditional resources of development support, financing additional investment to spur vigorous growth and to reduce poverty in Africa is likely to emerge as one conspicuous challenge facing our continent".

A few hours before Amoako spoke, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) in a statement preceding the Addis Ababa world launch of its 'World Investment Directory in Africa' revealed that foreign direct investment (FDI) flows in Africa were moving into service industries, particularly into the finance and insurance sectors and manufacturing, leaving behind Africa's traditional concentration on primary commodities.

Meanwhile, reported UNCTAD spokesman Jagdish Saigal, the liberalization of investment and trade regimes were spawning a new phenomenon: the emergence of African Transnational Corporations (TNCs) in countries such as South Africa, Morocco and Zambia.

African TNCs include: Anglo-American Industrial Corps (South Africa) the largest in the region; Barlow Rand Ltd., a conglomerate in South Africa; Conserverie Cherifinnes, a food TNC in Morocco ; and Zambia's Consolidated Copper Mines.

However, compared with other parts of the world, overall volumes of FDI flows for Africa remain low. Between 1991 and 1995 Africa attracted only 5 per cent of total FDI flows to developing countries and 2 per cent of world's FDI. Moreover, FDI in Africa is concentrated only in a handful of countries.

Nigeria and Egypt accounted for over 50 per cent during the first half of the 1990s. Morocco was the largest recipient during the same period with average annual flows of US$0.5 billion.

In his address, Assistant Secretary General of the Organization of African Unity, Vijay S. Makhan, argued that due attention should be given to such parameters as sound policy and institutional frameworks particularly to regulatory environments, efficiency of the banking system, monetary regimes, incentive packages and infrastructure.

In terms of commodities, said African Development Bank (ADB) vice-president Ferhat Lounes, Africa has lost market shares in cocoa beans, coffee and timber (mainly to Asia) and in iron-ore and cotton (to Eastern Europe).

"The loss in market share is attributable to lack of competitiveness at both price and non-price levels", he added, warning that it was the income- dimension attribute of global competition that worried him most: as global income grows, so does the demand for more sophisticated goods. The majority of African countries produce primary commodities which were progressively becoming unattractive in international markets.

In a message read to the conference by Amoako, UN Secretary General Kofi Annan applauded the Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) for prioritising the issue of information and communications technologies on the conference agenda.

The conference sub-theme, relating to the African Information Society Initiative (AISI), is reflected in a collaborative effort between ECA and the Global Information Infrastructure Commission (GIIC) -- an international non- governmental organization of leaders from 40 of the world's foremost information and communications technology companies.

The GIIC provides a framework for filling the gaps between the public and private sectors, between developing and developed countries and between diverse industry sectors from around the world.

ECA and GIIC are holding a high-level symposium on private and public sector partnership in building the African Information Society, the basis of which is AISI, a framework for developing Africa's information and communications infrastructure signed by African ministers in 1996.

The Symposium will be broadcast live in Africa in an M-NET production on Multichoice digital satellite television (DStv). The GIIC will release its " Statement of Addis Ababa" on 7 May, which its Africa regional director Dr. Derrick Cogburn says will strongly support private and public partnerships in building the African information society. It will also propose a set of principles intended to guide the implementation of AISI plans for National Information and Communications Infrastructure (NICI) within each African country.

For further information please contact Peter da Costa, Cabinet Office of the Executive Secretary, UN ECA, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia Tel: +251-1-51-29-17 (direct) or 251-1-51-72-00 (main switchboard), Ext. 476 Fax: +251-1-51-22-33 E-Mail: ipspdc@harare.iafrica.com


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


156 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


Ghana;
Soldier's Recipe For Peace


BYLINE: Samuel Sarpong, APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1347 words


 

Accra (APS) - It is a fact, most high level peace negotiations hardly involve grass roots representatives. But traditional rulers particularly in Africa, a continent bedevilled by internal strife, can make a major contribution to conflict resolutions and peacemaking.

Retired Lt-Gen. Arnold Quainoo might well be remembered for his role as one- time Commander of ECOMOG, the military wing of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) charged specifically to ensure peace in war-torn Liberia. 

Nicknamed "Buffalo Soldier" for his tenacity and military acumen, he served his tenure during the heady days of the Liberian insurgence and was unit commander when ex-President Samuel Doe was arrested and killed by some factional forces led by Prince Johnson.

Prior to that appointment, he had been General Officer Commanding military personnel in Ghana, the highest military position in the country, and also a member of the then ruling Provisional National Defence Council headed by Flt- Lt. Jerry John Rawlings, now President of Ghana.

Since his retirement from the military in 1995, Lt-Gen. Quainoo has found it fitting enough to put the expertise acquired during his military career to good use. He has established a centre to develop peace initiatives.

"I have lived through an era and I feel I have an experience and skill to impart to society," Lt-Gen. Quainoo says with much enthusiasm.

The Centre for Conflict resolution (CENCOR), of which he is the Executive Director, is bent on promoting peace in Ghana, the African sub-region and within the international community through the search for viable means of ending violent conflicts.

Lt.Gen. Quainoo says "the goal of CENCOR is to institutionalize and professionalize the work of preventive diplomacy, peacekeeping and peace building and other endeavours for social justice and international peace." The centre has been running training programmes for its targeted groups.

CONCOR recently organised a workshop for traditional rulers in Kumasi, Ghana's second largest city. The 32 participants were given an insight into the different models of negotiation, mediation and arbitration and their role in the field of conflict resolution. The traditional rulers also shared experiences and reflections on matters they had helped to mediate in.

Lt.Gen. Quainoo explains that traditional rulers were targeted because of the role they play or could play in conflict prevention and resolutions. "The workshop was meant to sharpen their skills, make them share experiences and learn from each other on the numerous responses needed for the prevention and resolution of conflicts," he says.

In this West African country as obtains elsewhere in Africa, traditional rulers otherwise known as chiefs, wield a lot of power and their ability to broker peace is very paramount in their communities.

When an ethnic conflict broke out in the northern part of Ghana in 1995, resulting in the death of scores of people, the government braced up to confront the situation by setting up a committee headed by a chief to broker peace in the region.

The committee's work eventually paid off as it was able to restore peace to the ravaged communities of the northern region where an unrelenting war was waging between some ethnic groups over the issue of who was supposed to be the overlord.

The destruction, in terms of human loss and properties, have compelled many of Ghanaians to look further afield in order to halt the emerging canker and other chieftaincy disputes which abound among its 18 million people.

It is in this light that CENCOR sees chiefs as important collaborators in the search for peace, says Lt-Gen. Quainoo. He, however, dismisses the view that with the current constitutional arrangements, the powers of traditional rulers have lost much bite. "They are still a force to be reckoned with even today," he says and adds that, "their decisions carry a lot of weight."

Lt-Gen. Quainoo maintains that the respect chiefs have, makes them automatic arbitrators in most cases except those that demand certain legal propensities.

The chiefs believe they need a supportive framework within which to operate. This was given credence in a declaration they issued after their workshop in Kumasi.

According to the traditional rulers, the institution of chieftaincy could be brought to bear much more effectively on the process of conflict prevention, management and resolution if adequate resources and other ancillary logistic support necessary for them to translate their immense potential into reality are enhanced.

They also requested that capacity building resources should be made widely available for them. Besides, they urged CENCOR to organise studies to analyze conflicts in Ghana, both actual and potential, with a view to drawing up an accurate and usable conflict map of Ghana.

They were of the view that as a matter of urgency, action should be taken to establish a mechanism for Early Warning and Preventive Diplomacy throughout the country.

One thing that stood out clearly from the workshop was the collaborative will of the chiefs to work together for social justice, peace and development.

"We have always believed that the destiny of the country lies in our hands hence the need for us to evolve programmes that would reconcile our people and also better their lot," says Nana Akuoko Sarpong of the Chieftaincy Secretariat.

Throughout the era of colonialism and to date, chiefs have been symbols of unity and have helped in moving the country forward. They were also very instrumental in the granting of independence to the then Gold Coast, now Ghana.

"We share a common desire to obtain the very best for our communities and nation," the chiefs stressed.

Lt-Gen Quainoo says the Kumasi Declaration is receiving serious attention and assures that subject to the availability of funds, much would be done to meet the aspirations of the traditional rulers.

He is convinced this is the beginning of a worthwhile process and a lot would be done to ensure that conflict prevention and resolution becomes a hallmark in Ghanaian socio-political standards.

"We should be able to build for ourselves and leave for posterity a truly national setting devoid of the perils of social conflict and pointless disharmony," he stresses.

With this new initiative, most people are hopeful that a new sense of direction is dawning on Ghanaians to give peace its due in the scheme of things.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


157 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


East Africa;
Alternatives To Repatriation


BYLINE: Sam Gonza, APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1494 words


 

Nairobi (APS) - Following reports of mass killings of Rwandese Hutu refugees in camps near Kisangani, Zaire, the United Nations is caught up in an unprecedented row with rebel leader Laurent Kabila, who has dismissed UN accusations of atrocities against refugees as a smear campaign.

The leader of the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo- Zaire (ADFL) claims UN agency bosses are buddies of embattled President Mobutu Sese Seko.

And it seems the atrocities against refugees have clouded the Zairean rebels' seizure of Kikwit, the last important town before Kinshasa. However as we went to press, UN Secretary General Kofi Annan commended ADFL leader Laurent Kabila for intervening in the Rwandan refugee crisis but cautioned him against setting a deadline for repatriation. 

In contrast to his earlier critical stance on Kabila, Annan indicated in a statement issued at the United Nations last week that he was encouraged and pleased that the rebel leader had travelled to Kisangani last weekend to take personal charge of the situation.

Meanwhile, French humanitarian agency Medicins Sans Frontieres (MSF) has made perhaps the most practical suggestion regarding the tens of thousands of Rwandese refugees on Zairean territory who are currently facing death, disease and starvation as they move deeper into the forests west and south of the city of Kisangani in eastern Zaire.

According to a spokeswoman of the MSF in Paris, instead of United Nations agencies feverishly trying to airlift the refugees from Zaire to Rwanda, a third country - maybe Central African Republic - should be asked to host the refugees and be supported to ensure their security and well being.

Medicins Sans Frontieres says the basis for this proposal is that most of the Rwandese refugees are determined not to return to Rwanda which is the fundamental reason they have continued to flee while some two million of their compatriots decided to return home from Zaire in the past two years.

Some 500,000 returned last November after Tutsi Zairean rebels defeated the hard line Hutu elements in the refugee camps in Goma, eastern Zaire following the Banyamulenge uprising against the government of President Mobutu Sese Seko in late 1996.

But Ephraim Kabaije, Rwandese Presidential advisor was very critical of the MSF proposal. He refuted the suggestion that the Rwandese refugees currently in Zaire are a hard core group who fear retribution if they should return to Rwanda. "I can assure you most of those who committed the genocide are currently in Rwanda.

"It is wrong to say Rwanda does not want its people now in Zaire back home. In fact I have personally visited the camps in Kasese and Byaro outside Kisangani to talk to the refugees and urge them to return to Rwanda. I did this at considerable risk to myself."

Kabaije says he visited the makeshift camps across River Zaire before the attacks on their inhabitants in the third week of April by Zairean villagers and rebels which has scuttled some 50,000 refugees, many too ill or physically exhausted to undertake extremely demanding flight through the thick jungle west and south of Kisangani.

That incident together with the reported seizure allegedly by Zairean rebels of 50 children receiving treatment at a feeding centre in Bukavu, eastern Zaire have given the Zairean rebels a bad name internationally.

United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan used these serious humanitarian failures by the rebels to wage an unprecedented attack on rebel chief Laurent Kabila who was 2,000 kilometres away in Goma when the attacks on the camps at Kasese and Byaro occurred.

But Kabila launched a tirade of his own on Kofi Annan and his Special Representative in the region, Mohammed Sahnoun. Speaking on the Swahili service of the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC), Kabila said both men were "great personal friends of Mobutu" and suggested that the United Nations Secretary General was involved in a smear campaign against his ADFL rebel alliance movement. He insisted there were armed elements among the Hutu militants in the camps, saying the killing of Zairean civilians by these Hutu elements had precipitated the crisis.

The American government spokesman Nicholas Burns subsequently joined the fray casting aspersions on Mr Kabila's past - saying a socialist revolutionary "was suspect." And the British paper the Independent has suggested that Kabila may not be in control of the rebels and that there is a likelihood of international implosion of anarchy in Zaire.

Some African observers now detect a complex web of international intrigue to try and stop Kabila's rise to power as ADF rebels move closer to the final showdown against the forces of the incumbent President Mobutu Sese Seko.

African critics still do not want to forget too quickly that Annan's former boss Dr. Boutros Boutros Ghali ordered the pull out from Rwanda of United Nations peacekeepers at the height of the genocide in April 1994 - a move, it is believed contributed to the current refugee crisis in eastern Zaire.

Observers say the point is -- the United Nations has a very low image rating among the Banyamulenge rebels as well as the Rwandese government.

Despite Kabaije's claim that Rwanda would be very happy to receive back the tens of thousands of refugees currently stranded in Zaire, elements in Rwanda are worried by the level of insecurity in parts of Rwanda caused by the unprecedented return of refugees from Goma (last November) and Tanzania (last December).

Indeed even as we went to press, Rwanda security sources announced the massacre of 17 schoolgirls and their headteacher, a nun, in Gisenyi, by people the government describes as "militants".

There are indeed serious ethnic tensions in Rwanda blamed on "militants" among the refugees, who were allowed to return straight into their communes through the Rwanda government's policy of welcoming back refugees with open arms.

Further internal tensions in Rwanda are the results of some 90,000 incarcerated in inhuman conditions in jails since the genocide three years ago.

As for Laurent Kabila, he seems unperturbed by the vicious campaign against him that is spearheaded by the United Nations.

He is clearly pleased by reports from his commanders that Kikwit, 400 kilometres from Kinshasa, has fallen to his rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces without a fight from Mobutu's forces who have promised to fight to the last man in the battle for Kinshasa, Mobutu's last stronghold.

Kikwit in Bandundu is the major supplier of foodstuff for Kinshasa's 3-4 million people. Predictions are soon prices of available commodities will rise beyond the average person's purchasing power and an exodus from the city will start.

Kabila has predicted Kinshasa will fall to his forces by June.

Bill Richardson, the United States of America ambassador to the United Nations is already in Kinshasa and will subsequently see Kabila in Goma or Kisangani as part of America's initiatives to broker a peace- ful resolution to the seven-month old conflict.

Richardson, a staunch Catholic who told a recent Breakfast Prayer meeting in Washington of the power of prayer in his work, may perhaps succeed in convincing Mobutu to relinquish power in a peaceful way, without necessarily having to travel to Gabon or South Africa to negotiate his own exit from the Zairean political scene after 32 years in power.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


158 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


Kenya;
Pastoralists: 'Old Ways Die Hard'


BYLINE: an APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1547 words


 

Nairobi (APS) - Mzee Lesayon Lungungwani, in his 60s, was a wealthy man by average standards. He owned 30 camels, 56 cattle, 240 goats and 15 donkeys.

For a pastoralist, this was indeed a great achievement. But misfortune has no respect for age or social status. He lost all the animals except one camel and 10 goats to Rendille raiders who invaded Baragoi, north-western Kenya last February. Today, he is a watchman (guard) at Baragoi shopping centre, earning a weekly wage of Kshs 100 ( under 2 US dollars), barely enough to cater for his family of six.

Recently, a kind neighbour gave him a calf which he is nurturing in the best way possible. "I know God will provide; I will get others," he says quietly, pondering over the incident that has deprived him, making him dependent. However, he adds "I am lucky because I only lost the animals. My friend was killed in the attack. They also took all his animals." 

Baragoi is in arid Samburu district in Northern Kenya where pastoralism is the people's mainstay. Pastoralists depend entirely on livestock and when misfortunes such as the one that befell Lungungwani strike a family the entire community is threatened.

For instance, during drought or when there is a disease outbreak, most families live on the brink of disaster. It is for this reason that ways and means are being sought to secure the future of such communities whose livelihood is so fragile.

"Since livestock is such an important aspect of these communities' culture and economy, animal health is key to their survival and everything must be done to protect the livestock otherwise their lives are in jeopardy," says a veterinary officer Dr. Jacob Wanyama.

It was with this in mind that the workshop was organized under the auspices of a non-governmental organization working in the area, with the aim of bringing together traditional healers from Turkana and Samburu communities to discuss and exchange views on traditional healing.

Enthnoveterinary Knowledge (EVK) is a people's accumulated knowledge over the years about treating animal diseases. It covers areas of identifying disease nomenclature, symptoms, pathology, treatment and prevention. This knowledge is orally passed on from generation to generation.

EVK is gaining wider recognition not only because it has been used by communities throughout centuries but also because even with the introduction of modern veterinary practices, the majority of people cannot afford these services.

In the case of Samburu and Turkana pastoralists of Northern Kenya, the effects of economic structural policies have been adverse. Government extension services have been severed or minimized with the result that pastoralists do not have alternatives. The fact that they are constantly on the move does not make their situation any better.

"The role of EVK in complementing modern approaches to the control of livestock diseases in developing countries is gaining recognition from development and research institutions," Dr Wanyama observes adding that "... this is because modern veterinary services have become either too difficult to obtain or too expensive to afford."

"The pastoralists have a reservoir of knowledge on the use of a large variety of medicinal plants and there is significant agreement on symptoms of diseases and their conditions," the doctor observes. He explains that such was the reason that led to a detailed investigation into these practices in order to identify useful ones that could be promoted instead of unnecessarily replacing them with the conventional ones.

This view is supported by the livestock officer in the division, Mr. Simon Belewa. He observes that traditional practices should be encouraged to supplement modern drugs.

In remote areas such as Samburu, the situation is made worse by the fact that government veterinary services are not easily available. "Even if they were, the extra expense of buying modern veterinary drugs is a burden to most families, therefore many of them rely on the traditional methods of treatment, " notes the livestock officer.

But as it was observed at the workshop in Baragoi, the traditional knowledge is slowly fading and disappearing with the older generation and may soon be extinct.

Mzee Lengungwani, for example, laments the death of his friend more because of "what information he died with. Nobody will ever know how much he had," he says sadly. He adds that it is important to encourage the younger generation to pick up such information for the benefit of future generations.

A traditional healer Alice Loriot appeals to "...all those good people who are encouraging this work to go on." She observes that although traditional treatments are effective, they are often shunned by some people who would rather let their animals die than utilize such services. "Yet modern medicine is very expensive....sometimes you have to sell up to three goats to treat one! And they don't always get healed."

Another medicine man Mr Albert Leleshep, who is also a chief in South Horr appealed to NGOs working in the area to liaise with other development agencies and government to conduct research so that they can improve the present traditional herbs and medicines for the people's use. "This will reduce the expenses that most people incur when using modern medicines to treat their livestock," he argues.

Participants at the mid-February workshop, comprising a cross-section of men and women from Samburu and Turkana, made several recommendations. They urged NGOs,government extension workers and other development agencies working in the area to encourage participatory and interactive processes which will facilitate information sharing on traditional treatment between groups in the district and beyond.

They were also concerned that similar information be promoted through schools to encourage passing on the knowledge to the younger generation. The effectiveness of traditional treatment currently being used should be tested for efficacy, they urged.

During one session that involved boys from Baragoi High School, healers explained to students the different plants/herbs that are used for different diseases and students were encouraged to ask questions about the herbs. Later, all the plants that had been brought to the workshop by the healers were handed over to the school to start a herbarium.

"Many of us who are your parents are 'blind'. No one knows about all the knowledge that we have, because we cannot write it down," Mzee Lengungwani told the boys. He passionately appealed to them to continue their interest in traditional medicines so "that one among you can pick up this important work."

The school currently runs an EVK club under the patronage of Mr. Munyi who enthusiastically notes: "The club is relatively young but we would like to make an impact and be an example to other schools around. We would like to display something related to EVK at the forthcoming National Science Congress. " The congress is scheduled for this month. The club also plans to start a newsletter on EVK.

The EVK work in Samburu aims at integrating the ethnoveterinary knowledge into community-based animal health programmes by validating and improving on effective remedies together with Samburu and Turkana traditional healers. Diseases and remedies to be investigated will be selected by the herders.

Other activities will include developing training manuals for community- based animal health projects in the area, liaising with relevant research institutions to investigate the efficacy of various identified EVK treatment and documenting and disseminating the results and experiences to interested parties. A set of two books is in the process of publication to exemplify the work so far done.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


159 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


Burundi;
Massacres Reported At Catholic Seminary


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Bujumbura (APS) - The Burundian army claims that Hutu rebels have massacred more than 40 people during a raid on a Roman Catholic seminary at Buta in the south of the country.

An army spokesman told the independent Ijambo Radio that the rebels killed 34 pupils and seven lay members of the seminary in the attack on the seminary on April 29.

Another 34 seminarians were seriously wounded, the army spokesman said, adding that the Tutsi-dominated Burundian army had killed almost 300 Hutu rebels in far southern Makamba province since the outbreak of fighting in the region on April 4. 

The rebel attack is the second such massacre reported by the army in two weeks in the Makamba province.

On April 18, military spokesman Colonel Isaie Nibizi said that the army had discovered the bodies of about 100 civilians massacred by Hutu extremist rebels in the southern province.

Colonel Nibizi said the slaughter took place in the Kayogolo zone of the Vugizo district.

"Our troops found the bodies of about 100 civilians. The rebels called them out and killed them," Nibizi stated, after saying that rebels were continuing to infiltrate the extreme south of Burundi, at Kabonga and Nyanza-Lac, from Tanzania.

The same day, Makanda provincial governor Gilbert Manirambona told Radio Burundi that heavy fighting was taking place in Vugizo and that hundreds of people had been displaced and hundreds of houses razed to the ground.

About 1,000 displaced people were living in a church in Makamba town, the provincial capital, Manirambona added.

The charity Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF - Doctors without Borders) said some 1,000 other people had fled the fighting and taken shelter in Mabanda district, Ijambo Radio also reported.

A week earlier, the Defence Ministry had also said that 140 Hutu rebels and three soldiers in the government army had been killed in battles in Makamba province.

The opposition Hutu National Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD), which has an armed wing, denied this claim and said the 140 dead "rebels" were civilians.

The attacks come less than two weeks since Burundi's strongman Pierre Buyoya expressed regret that regional leaders had long imposed crippling sanctions on his country but had no "recipe" to end its ethnic civil war.

On returning from a regional summit on the crisis held in Tanzania on April 16, Major Buyoya told a press conference on April 17 that "our friends in the region, our friends in the international community, want peace in Burundi, but we also note that the heads of state, the mediator and others have no recipe to bring peace. This is a clear indication that peace in Burundi is our business."

The more than three year-old civil war pitting guerrillas from the Hutu majority against the minority Tutsi-dominated army has cost more than 150,000 lives, many of them peasants massacred by both sides. Tanzanian former president and elder statesman Julius Nyerere stepped in as mediator.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


160 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


East Africa;
East Africa Launches Economic Plan


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Arusha, Tanzania (APS) - East Africa has taken a major step towards integration following a recent move by the presidents of the three-member states of Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda to launch a development plan that would draw them closer through to the year 2000.

At a ceremony held at this northern Tanzanian town's Sheikh Abeid Karume Memorial Stadium on April 29, President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya, Benjamin Mkapa of Tanzania and Yoweri Museveni of Uganda launched a common internal passport to be used by the three countries' estimated 80 million population for their day-to-day inter-state activities.

They also inaugurated a flag for the region's economic grouping -- the East African Cooperation -- which was established by the three countries in March last year to replace the former East African Community which collapsed in 1977 due to ideological differences between the three partners. 

In a communique, the three presidents noted progress in harmonising fiscal and monetary policies, the introduction of convertibility of the three countries' Shillings currencies, and regular consultations among central bank governors and heads of revenue authorities.

Other moves also included formation of an East African Business Council and an East African Law Society, mechanisms to enhance cross-border trade, and removal of unnecessary police road blocks.

The leaders also noted preparations for the start of a 69-million-dollar digital telecommunications project which is being undertaken with assistance from the European Investment Bank and the East African Development Bank.

The communique reaffirmed their commitment to strengthening and deepening cooperation for equitable development in their three states and stressed the need to ensure environmental preservation, women's rights, peace and stability.

The three presidents reasserted their commitment to creating a single East African market, stressing the role of the private sector.

Moi, who is chairman of the grouping noted the recent reduction by the Kenya Posts and Telecommunications Corporation of its regional tariffs by 62 per cent and appealed to the international community to assist the new regional grouping.

Museveni himself hailed measures to harmonize tax rates in the three states, saying that discrepancies encouraged smuggling, and also stressed the need for implementation of an integrated roads project and common standards on human rights.

Mkapa, on his part, hailed the development strategy plan as a new mechanism for balanced development in the region, stressing the effects on peace, stability and trust of stronger political, economic and social links among the people of the countries.

The communique did not, however, mention an application by Rwanda to join the grouping, although the Tanzanian Foreign Ministry officials had said on April 28 that it might be added to the presidents' April 29 summit agenda.

However, the move was strongly supported by former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere who had said earlier that it "would be good for Rwanda, good for East Africa,and good for Africa generally."

Nyerere had also said that he was certain that neighbouring Burundi would also apply to join once it had a legitimate government capable of speaking and acting on behalf of its people -- a reference to the bloodless military coup in Bujumbura on July 25 last year, bringing back Tutsi strongman Pierre Buyoya to power.

Both countries are former Belgian protectorates with economies shattered by ethnic strife, though Rwanda's is fast recovering.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


161 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


Kenya;
Kenya's Presbyterians Want Constitutional Reforms


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Nairobi (APS) - The Presbyterian Church of East Africa (PCEA) is calling for facilitative constitutional reforms in Kenya before general elections slated for late 1997.

In a press statement dated April 26, 1997, and signed by PCEA's Secretary General Rev. Patrick Rukenya, 600 elders and ministers of the church said they were concerned about the widespread corruption, immorality violent crimes and general insecurity in Kenya and the anxiety of the coming general elections.

The church leaders who met at St. Andrews Church here from April 22 to 26 for the 15th General Assembly of the PCEA, said without a constitution with checks and balances, there exists abuse of power and lawlessness which may lead to anarchy and disintegration of the country.

"The Constitution is the supreme law of the land from which the three arms of the Government draw their exclusive authority for check and balance of each other," noted the church leaders. 

They called on the government to immediately put in motion the necessary facilitative process for fair and free peaceful democratic reforms before the general elections. The current constitution does not allow a form of governance that addresses these issues effectively, they added.

The leaders further called for urgency in creation of an impartial Electoral Commission which can be acceptable to all political parties, churches, religious organizations, civic organizations and other sectors of the society.

Members of the public, the opposition and civic bodies have often criticized the current Electoral Commission, saying it plays partisan, favouring the ruling Kenya African National Union (KANU) party.

They however called for fair and free access to the public electronic media so that all views from a truly representative cross section of Kenyans can be heard.

Kenya's public electronic media have since the advent of the multiparty system (1992) come under criticism for their bias towards the ruling party.

The PCEA statement called for the repealing of the Public Order Act, Chief's Authority Act and other discriminating and oppressive laws in order to create a conducive climate for peaceful and democratic elections.

Referring to the book of Hosea 4:6, the PCEA leaders called on all their presbyteries to embark on civic education, prayer meetings and Bible study, " so that our people may not be destroyed by lack of knowledge."

The newly installed PCEA Moderator Dr. Jesse Macharia Kamau said in an interview with APS that his church had sent representatives to the recently concluded convention for constitutional reforms held in Limuru, Kenya.

He said that the church has a strong belief that people should always feel free to discuss issues.

Aimed to force the government to agree on constitutional reforms, the early April convention was attended by leading churches, civic bodies, non governmental organizations and opposition parties. The government has shown little interest in the convention and its objectives.

Further, the Catholic Church Justice and Peace Commission on April 19 said Kenya risks sliding into anarchy if the constitutional reforms outlined by the Limuru convention were not put in place before the general elections.

"We do not need to wait for anarchy before these reforms are effected," stated the commission.

In a related development, the National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK) on April 11 also expressed concern over what they called dismal performance of the current parliament in pushing for constitutional reforms and warned that time was running out.

The NCCK General Secretary Rev. Mutava Musyimi told a press conference in Nairobi that there have been promises of reforms by the government but upto date, there are no drafts of Bills to show that anything is being or has been done.

Elsewhere, the opposition Democratic Party of Kenya (DP) Secretary General Mr. Joseph Munyao said the Limuru convention organisers and participants are awaiting reaction from the President and the government on the resolutions forwarded to them about their deliberations.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 6, 1997


Angola;
Angola Wary Of Rwandese Refugees


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

LUANDA (APS) - Alarmed by the large number of Rwandese Hutu refugees about to enter Angolan territory from Zaire, the Army in this Southern African country have increased their presence in Dundo in the north to deter their entry. General Jorge de Matos is reportedly in charge of these operations.

State radio reported early last week that as many as 30,000 Rwandese refugees are heading towards Angola with some 7,000 already at the common border with Zaire.

Sources said the Angolans were worried that a large component of the refugees were ex-army or Interahamwe, whose presence on their territory may result in trouble for the Angolan Army.
