LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


163 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


Sudan;
Faithful Guard Threatened Church


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Khartoum (APS) - Vigilant Christians continue to garrison their church in the Kalakala Gubba area of southern Khartoum following clear signs that state police and Muslim extremists intend to demolish it in the near future.

Missionary sources told APS that on April 2 at approximately mid-day, a lorry full of police came to the parish centre at Kalakala Gubba and sealed off the whole area. The police and extremists then proceeded to mark the walls of the parish with large "X" signs, denoting the buildings were for destruction. However, forewarned, many Christians turned up and garrisoned the church thus foiling the intended knockdown. 

Fears by Christians in southern Khartoum followed the bulldozing of a small church in the village of Terenyaa on March 31. The 96 square metre church was constructed with steel and bricks. A government bulldozer from the Ministry of Planning and Works was used to demolish it.

Missionary sources said the church was demolished without prior notice and without giving some time to remove benches, and a wardrobe containing vestments of the priests. It is not clear if the Blessed Sacrament was desecrated in the process.

A Christian present on the spot by chance, courageously jumped on the bulldozer to ask the reason for the destruction from the driver. "Some angry Christian women threw stones at the bulldozer but to no avail. They were arrested and later released by police," said the eyewitness.

On April 1 Archbishop Joseph Erwin Ender, the Apostolic Pronuncio, along with a large group of clergy and Christians organized Mass within the rubble of the demolished structure.

A number of European ambassadors have also visited the demolished church to register their solidarity with the Christians.

The government paper Alwan later accused the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) of distorting public opinion charging that the incident did not occur.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


164 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


South Africa;
Truth Commission Amnesty for Woods' Friend


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 987 words


 

JOHANNESBURG (APS) - A man who helped journalist Donald Woods escape from South Africa in 1977 has been granted amnesty by South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC), the commission announced on April 28.

Two other people were also granted amnesty, one for the illegal possession of a firearm and ammunition, the other for malicious damage of property.

Donald Card, former mayor of the south coast city of East London, the truth body said in a statement, was granted amnesty for two offences he committed in helping in the escape of Woods, friend of black consciousness leader Steve Biko whose story was told in Richard Attenborough's movie, Cry Freedom.

Card, 68, said in his application to the Truth Commission that he had assisted in the escape because he disagreed with the former apartheid government's banning of Woods under the Suppression of Communism Act. 

Under the ban, Woods' movements were severely restricted and he was effectively prevented from carrying out his functions as editor of East London's Daily Dispatch newspaper.

Two members of President Nelson Mandela's African National Congress (ANC), Thami Robert Ntshobane and Simon Orapeng Ntsitsi, were also granted amnesty by the Truth Commission, which is probing human rights abuses during the apartheid era, and which under certain circumstances, may grant amnesty to perpetrators who make full confessions and show a political motive.

Ntshobane, 23, was convicted in 1992 of being in possession of an unlicensed firearm and ammunition in Guguletu black township outside Cape Town.

Ntsitsi, 35, was convicted on four counts of malicious damage to property after four vehicles were damaged during a protest march in Kanana township outside Orkney, in North-West province, in 1991.

The amnesty came only a day after Mandela had called on those guilty of human rights abuses during 40 years of apartheid to come forward and confess their misdeeds.

In an address on April 27, marking the third anniversary of South Africa's first all-party elections, Mandela urged the culprits to speak to the TRC, charged with investigating decades of inhuman treatment, and said: "We are encouraged at the growing numbers willing to help the commission uncover the truth about human rights abuses, and hope that their example will be followed by many more."

Speaking on "freedom day" in the agricultural town of Upington in Northern cape, Mandela's words echoed a similar appeal he made on April 26 to South African Defence Forces, few of whom have so far presented themselves before the commission.

Candidates, hoping for amnesty, which the commission will grant in some circumstances to those who confess taking part in as yet unsolved crimes, have less than two weeks to declare themselves.

By April 15, the date which marked the first anniversary of the TRC, some 6, 000 candidates had come forward.

"The work of the TRC has shown us, beyond what anyone could have foreseen, the power of the truth to heal," Mandela was quoted by South Africa's SAPA news agency as saying.

According to Mandela, the best recompense for victims of the apartheid era is "our success in building a new society" freed from the burden of the past.

Turning to the new constitution, which came into effect last January, Mandela declared it had "strengthened our unity, both in the democratic manner it was written in and in the hopes it embodies.

"Our deepest aspirations are enshrined now in the basic law of our land," he said.

A programme of festivities and political speeches took place throughout the country on April 27 and 28 to mark three years of multi-racial democracy under Mandela's ANC.

But in the face of the ANC's widespread influence, following the departure of Frederik de Klerk's National Party, the country lacks a convincing opposition and it also lacks a powerful successor to the 78-year-old president.

Mandela's mandate runs out in December and he has indicated he will not be seeking a second term, sparking intensive jostling between the ANC's various wings.

While Mandela can take satisfaction from a successful transition from a minority white government to a democracy and one of the most liberal constitutions in the world, the country faces intractable problems such as unemployment and crime.

Far from being conquered, rape, theft and all manner of trafficking steal the headlines day after day, particularly in Gauteng province, which includes Johannesburg and Pretoria.

There is also growing discontent over reform -- seen as too slow by blacks, destructive by whites and unfair by coloureds.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


165 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


Rwanda;
Churches Urged To Help Rwandese Refugees


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Nairobi (APS) - Churches and religious organizations have been urged to mobilize material and spiritual resources in order to alleviate the sufferings of the Rwandese refugees caught up in Zaire.

Recent media reports have focussed on the destitution of tens of thousands of Rwandese (Hutu) refugees at the mercy of disease, starvation, death and other difficulties as the rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) led by Laurent Kabila advance to wrest from President Mobutu Sese Seko the remaining stronghold, Kinshasa.

In a statement issued at the end of a five-day meeting of the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) International Affairs Board, Refugee and Emergency Committee here, the continental body called on all political parties involved in the Zairean crisis to engage in urgent constructive dialogue for the restoration of durable peace and security in the Great Lakes region. 

Denouncing recently reported massacres of Rwandan and Burundian refugees in Zaire, the AACC urged leaders in the Great Lakes region and the international community to immediately take all the necessary peaceful measures to put an end to this new genocide.

The 35 participants, drawn from South Africa, Zimbabwe, Togo, Nigeria, Senegal, Zaire, Burundi, Cameroon, Kenya, Sudan, Liberia and Congo, also denounced what they called a "slow and inadequate attention of the African leaders and the international community.

"This kind of slow and inadequate attention is increasing the death toll of men, women, young people and children on a daily basis, for lack of food, medicine and protection," the AACC said in the statement entitled, The Plight of Rwandan and Burundian Refugees in Eastern Zaire.

The statement, signed by the organization's General Secretary Rev. Jose Chipenda and the chairman of its Continental Committee on Refugee and Emergencies Rev. Dr. Silas Ncozana, reminded all internal parties as well as the international community that the victims of this tragic situation are human beings, created in the image of God, whose lives must be preserved by all peaceful means.

Prior to the issuing of the statement, delegates reviewed the refugee situation in Africa. They also agreed that the absence of peace, justice and reconciliation has contributed greatly to the multifacet problems facing the refugees and other displaced people on the continent.

Meanwhile, the delegates at the AACC meeting also registered their concern about the current political upheavals resulting from the more than 13-year- old civil war pitting the Islamic Khartoum government against the rebels in the south.

The AACC urged the church in the Sudan to continue to hold the Sudanese together, and more so during the current political crisis which they said was responsible for both the starvation and displacement of thousands of people in the country.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


166 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


Nigeria;
Death at varsity beauty contest


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Lagos (APS) - The Lagos State University (LASU) has been closed temporarily following clashes in which two students were killed and about a dozen others injured, Lagos-based African Independent Television reported here on April 29.

The clashes occurred on April 24 between members of two rival campus cults during a contest to choose the university's Miss LASU, the private TV station said.

The authorities decided to close the university for three weeks after the violence, during which a number of people had been arrested and would appear in court soon, the police said. 

Campus secret cults, whose origins date back to the 1950s, have in the past 10 years turned into gangs which kill, maim and rape on Nigerian university campuses.

The first campus secret cult, the Pyrates Confraternity, was formed by the 1986 Nobel literature laureate Wole Soyinka and was aimed at peacefully correcting campus social ills.

But other cults which followed swiftly resorted to gratuitous violence.

LASU, one of the youngest and most populous universities in Nigeria, has been closed several times in the past six years because of student unrest or due to teachers' strikes over conditions and funding.

All universities in Nigeria are owned and funded by the government.

The students' violence comes amid continuing inter-ethnic clashes in Nigeria's southern Delta state in the past one month.

On Monday April 28, at least five people were killed and two villages torched in new inter-ethnic clashes in the state's two villages of Ebrohimi and Omadina, according to eyewitnesses.

The two villages are both dominated by the Itsekiri ethnic group, which has been clashing for the past month with Ijaws in Nigeria's oil belt.

The ethnic unrest has forced the Anglo-Dutch Shell oil group to close down some of its facilities, resulting in production shortfalls of more than 20 per cent.

At least five Itsekiris were killed in Omadina, whose village leader Sunday Kake was abducted by Ijaw attackers, while the casualty toll from the attack in Ebrohimi was unknown, the witnesses said.

Omadina is near Warri, a key oil city of the Niger delta where clashes broke out in mid-March.

Nearby Koko was the scene last week of violent clashes between the two groups, during which more than 80 people have died, forcing the Nigerian military authorities to order the army to intervene there the previous week in an attempt to stem the fighting.

The turmoil was sparked when Nigerian authorities decided to relocate the headquarters of the Warri municipality -- and the concomitant government funding -- from an Ijaw town to an Itsekiri area.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


167 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
'Be Bearers Of Hope,' Churches Told


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Nairobi (APS) - African churches have been called to give hope to their continent whose resources have been heavily plundered during the colonial and post-independence periods.

Meeting at Karen, near here from April 21 to 25, some 15 African theologians from Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, South Africa and Cameroon, offered one consolation -- that despite this heavy exploitation and plundering of the resources, the Africans are full of hope for a brighter future.

The theologians, whose subject of discussion was, The Role of Churches in the Reconstruction of Africa, reminded fellow scholars of their responsibility to lead the process of social reconstruction. 

And they also reminded churches, which they stressed have direct contact with ordinary people in rural and urban areas, of their capacity and central role in raising hope and encouraging Africans as they enter the 21st century.

The theologians were also concerned about the way some sections of the mass media had portrayed the continent. "Although Africa continues being portrayed negatively in the mass media, the continent has great potential as an integral and indispensable part of the global community," the scholars said in a communique issued at the end of their meeting.

They also urged the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) to facilitate networking between groups involved in the social reconstruction of the continent.

They also recommended that the ecumenical body should encourage national councils of churches (NCCs) to promote discussions on reconstruction.

The AACC, they further proposed, should contribute effectively in promoting networks of hope among Africans spread out in the diaspora, Africans exiles as well as African students abroad.

They suggested AACC's involvement in the facilitation of a series of consultations on the reconstruction of Africa with particular emphasis on culture and identity, Christianity/religion in Africa, democratization/popular participation, knowledge-based political economy and development among others.

The AACC was also urged to establish working relations with the Conference of African Theological Institutions (CATI) and other regional associations of theological institutions.

The theologians also recommended that AACC explore possibilities of launching a continental scholarly journal with social reconstruction of Africa as its main focus.

The ecumenical body, delegates felt, should explore ways and means of working more closely with relevant departments of the Organization of African Unity (OAU), the Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) and regional bodies such as the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD), Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA) and the Southern African Development Community (SADC) .

The national councils of churches and confessional communions, the delegates recommended, should take the responsibility of furthering civic education among the general population.

Such education, they noted should include conscientisation on a pan-African approach to solving social, political and economic problems.

The four-day theological meeting was organized by the Research and Development Unit of the AACC and was co-ordinated by its Executive Secretary Prof. Jesse Mugambi.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


168 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


Liberia;
Liberian Elections To Go On


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1134 words


 

Monrovia (APS) - Liberia's long-awaited general elections are to go ahead as planned by a peace agreement concluded in August last year, despite recent calls within Liberia for their postponement.

In a statement issued here on April 27 after a four-day assessment visit, Nigerian Foreign Minister Tom Ikimi said only heads of state of the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) were empowered to change the may 30 scheduled date of presidential and general elections in Liberia.

"Only the ECOWAS heads of state can take a decision on such a critical and fundamental matter, and indeed after considering all aspects of the peace agreement," Ikimi told a press conference at the end of the visit to assess the implementation of the ECOWAS-brokered peace pact agreed on by Liberian warring parties in the Nigerial capital Abuja in August 1996.

The peace deal called for ceasefire, disarmament, repatriation of refugees and set May 30 this year for the holding of democratic elections. 

Ikimi, who headed the ECOWAS committee of nine foreign ministers on Liberia, told the press conference after a four-day meeting at the Nigerian embassy here, "We remain optimistic that free and fair elections can now indeed be safely conducted throughout Liberia."

He said those advocating extension of the elections date do not realize the consequences of the extension for the integrity of the entire peace process.

Ikimi noted some parties favoured a postponement of the elections date due to the lack of preparations, but ECOWAS was determined to remain within the framework of the Abuja accord, which set May 30 for general and presidential elections in Liberia.

Ghana's deputy Foreign Minister Victor Gheho also told reporters on April 26 that "even if we consider a change, it will just be slightly. It may be between 15 and 30 days."

The Foreign Minister disclosed that his committee had met with leaders of political parties who wanted the elections rescheduled and expressed fears of insecurity in the country.

Many civilian officials, some Liberian religious leaders and political analysts had argued that the country is not yet ready for polls.

A fortnight ago Roman Catholic bishops in Liberia called for a postponement of the elections, saying, "the minimum condition necessary for free, fair democratic elections have not been met."

However, said Ikimi, the commander of ECOMOG African peacekeeping force Major General Victor Malu, had offered to conduct the politicians on a tour of every constituency and location where elections will take place to reassure them of the high level of safety and security they can realistically expect from ECOMOG.

Ikimi also said that the assessment mission had taken serious note of their arguments, but the matter was for ECOWAS leaders to decide.

The suspicions that the election might be delayed rose on April 23 when the Independent Electoral Commission (ECOM) suspended key party activity until further notice after complaints that the country was not ready for the elections.

ECOM chairman Henry Andrews at the same time delayed the start of party conventions, the submission of party lists and the official opening of the campaign, complaining that the political parties, mostly representing the former warring factions, were failing to cooperate in the peace effort and were intimidating candidates from other parties from operating in areas they controlled.

Andrews said the commission had received reports of harassment, obstruction, intimidation and extortion of Liberians returning to the country and said that some former armed factions were preventing genuine campaigning, but did not go into details.

He slammed political parties set up by the main factions which fought the war here and are competing in the elections for misinforming the electorate and urged all political parties to inform and educate the electorate in the process of democratic competition.

Any delay in the elections - the first in the country since a six-year war that cost the lives of more than 150,000 people - could risk upsetting some of the former warring factions.

The European Union and United States have backed the calling of the elections and the United States embassy here said officials of the US justice department and the African peacekeeping force will begin training 500 Liberian police officers on election security.

On the ECOM budget, Ikimi said ECOWAS maintains that the budget "be realistic and realizable, and not bloated."

He said the new ECOM budget was now reduced from 12 million US dollars to 7 million dollars, of which the international community will make available seven million dollars, while the Liberian Government would foot the rest.

Meanwhile a minister with the United Methodist Church in Liberia told APS he is convinced the electoral process in the country is adequate for holding for the holding of free and fair elections on May 30.

In an interview with APS, Rev. Julius Nelson said the Electoral Commission has now ensured the security necessary for the electoral process to go on uninterrupted, adding that many Liberians would see further delay as an impediment to the consolidation of the peace and development in their country.

He however noted that long after the elections, this West African nation will still need additional relief ministries, continued repatriation and resettlement and counselling programmes among other forms of assistance.

"It would be illusive to think that once the elections are held, the conflict will be over," Rev. Nelson stressed.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


169 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 6, 1997


Business and Finance;
Business South Africa Interdict Against COSATU


BYLINE: Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Johannesburg - Legal papers were served today on COSATU by Business South Africa aimed at interdicting our May 12th mass action focusing on the Basic Conditions of Employment Standards legislation.

The papers claim that Section 77 of the LRA, the provision protecting procedural mass action, has not been observed in the calling of the May 12th action. Section 77 provides that those embarking on action need to serve notice on Nedlac more than 14 days in advance of such action. Nedlac lawyers are of the view that COSATU did indeed follow the required procedure. 

By bringing this court action, BSA is showing contempt for the processes agreed to in Nedlac's Executive and Management Committees, which discussed this matter. These Committees had agreed that Nedlac would receive legal opinion as to the legal meaning of aspects of Section 77, no later than the 9th of May.

Further, that where necessary procedures would be drawn up for future mass action, to guide Nedlac in implementing the provisions of Section 77. It is therefore disturbing to say the least, that BSA is bringing a court action on May 8th, a day before the decision which they were party to, is due to be implemented. This raises the obvious question as to why BSA is pre-empting an agreed process- it suggests that they are not confident that the legal opinion which will be given to Nedlac will support their argument. COSATU will propose a motion of censure at the Nedlac Executive Council on Friday, in protest at BSA's conduct.

Despite their protestations, we do not believe that the BSA action is legally motivated.

Rather, it is an abuse of the courts to try, as employers have in the past, to intimidate workers embarking on legitimate mass action. Further, it is an attempt to get the court to limit the scope of the action. BSA is worried about the fact that the LRA protects workers embarking on such action from victimisation, and that the May 12 action will be the first major national action to be protected in terms of the new legislation.

They are also particularly concerned that COSATU will be taking action not only in support of our members, but also in support of the fundamental rights of all unorganised and vulnerable workers. This will deal a serious blow to employers attempts to create a dual labour market in which different rights are accorded to organised and unorganised workers.

COSATU is convinced, and we have legal opinion to this effect, that we have complied with Section 77 of the LRA, and that we followed the necessary procedures. We will therefore vigorously defend the court action. We believe that the application of BSA will be laughed out of court.

However we hope that this doesn't mark the beginning of a trend by employers to attempt to use legal action, both in the ordinary courts and the Constitutional Court to chip away at, or limit fundamental rights which workers have won in the Constitution and legislation. Such an approach will only damage trust, both in Nedlac and industrial relations generally.

It is disturbing that BSA has given notice of this action today, exactly at the time when negotiations on the Basic Conditions of Employment Bill are resuming. By taking this action employers are showing that they have no intention on settling on the critical issues in the four days set aside for negotiations, and therefore are not focusing on averting the May 12 national mass action. Indeed their approach is likely to intensify the conflict.

From our side, we are more determined than ever that the action will continue. We are calling on our members to redouble their efforts. Marches and rallies will take place throughout the country from 12h00 on Monday May 12. The majority of workers will proceed to these actions from work. We are calling on workers to attend in their tens of thousands in support of our call for a 40 hour week, for paid maternity leave, and for no downward variation of basic rights in the Bill.

Issued by John Gomomo, COSATU President


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

May 7, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe Industrial Index Falls


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe's 59-counter Industrial Index, the main measure of the country's economic activity, tumbled a further 122.63 points Wednesday to close at 10,598.16. 

Industrials continued fairly active although weaker with IHL being the only counter to gain 50 cents to 250.

Seed producing companies Seed-Co, and Zimpapers each lost 15, to 315 and 145 cents respectively.

Other counters to lose included Trans Zambezi Industries, a leading hospitality group, Zimsun, National Foods and Tedco.

Minings were also down 11.11 to end the day at 1,006.17 points.

Bindura and Rio Tinto traded at previous levels, while the gold producing group, Falcon Gold, lost four to 65.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


171 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


Science and Health;
World Conservation Union To Avoid Ivory Debate


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The World Conservation Union will not intervene in the lobby by some African governments for lifting of a ban in the international trade in elephant products.

Union President Yolanda Kakabadse, told the Zimbabwe Inter-Africa News Agency on Wednesday that the conservation body would not take sides on issues involving the down-listing of the elephant, for fear of losing credibility as an organization whose members had different interests.

Kakabadse arrived in Zimbabwe on Tuesday for a four-day visit. She is on a tour of Southern African countries to meet union members and visit projects funded by the organization, 

She said that said the union would only be able to supply concerned African governments with technical information to enable them to make decisions on the issue.

"African elephant range states (with rangelands) are the ones that will have to face this situation," she said.

The union, which has both governments and private sector representatives as members, would not she said "take any pivotal role in this, even at the June Cites meeting in Zimbabwe.

In June, Zimbabwe hosts a meeting of parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, or Cites. Most Southern African countries are expected to use the platform to lobby for the down-listing of the elephant from appendix one to appendix two, which allows controlled international trade.

On environmental awareness in Africa, Kakabadse said governments on the continent should take a firm stance against environmental degradation.

"Decision makers should put in place policies that will deal with such issues as desertification," she said. "Even those countries that still have to suffer from that problem will have to put in place such policies before the situation gets out of hand."

However, she said the union was "impressed by environmental projects being undertaken in the region."

Kakabadse, who had a briefing with union members in Zimbabwe, also held talks with Environment and Tourism Minister Chen Chimutengwende on her organization's current programmes in the country and its future initiatives.

The union's mission is to conserve the diversity of nature and utilize natural resources in an equitable and ecologically sustainable way. It sponsors the Zimbabwe District Environmental Action Plan, the Save Catchment Area Rehabilitation Programme and INL002 from the strategic environmental assessment of developments throughout the country.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


172 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


Africa;
Africa-Bound FDI's Tilt Toward Service Sector


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York (PANA) - Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) flows to Africa is shifting from traditional concentration on the region's primary commodities to service industries, a new United Nations report has said.

In the report released Tuesday, the U.N. Conference on Trade and Development says FDI flows to Africa are moving into the finance and investment sectors, as well as to manufacturing.

The 462-page "World Investment Directory on Africa," which surveys 53 African countries, is the most complete and authoritative source of data on investment trends and statistics. 

"It is a tool for potential investors to facilitate the process of investment stimulation for African countries," said Georg Kell of the Unctad office in New York, while launching the report.

The agency says that FDI flows to Africa, though still modest in absolute terms (4.5 billion U.S. dollars in 1996), were responsible for a significant share of Gross Domestic Capital formation and Gross Domestic Product.

In spite of the encouraging news, the agency says that compared with other parts of the world, the overall volumes of FDI for Africa remain low.

"Between 1991 and 1995, Africa attracted only 5 percent of total FDI flows to developing countries and two percent of world FDI flows.

"Moreover, FDI in Africa remains concentrated in only a handful of countries. Nigeria and Egypt accounted for over half of FDI into Africa during the first half of the 1990s," the agency says.

It also says that Western European investors, mostly from France and Britain, still dominate FDI in Africa. The United States accounts for about 20 percent of inflows from developed countries.

The agency notes that the liberalization of investment and trade regimes in Africa are responsible for a new phenomenon: the emergence of the African Transnational Corporation.

It said that firms from Africa were becoming transnational corporations as they emerge as outward investors following the privatization process in many countries. Firms from South Africa and Nigeria lead in this area.

Asked what could be done to increase FDI flows to Africa, particularly when many African countries have already liberalized their regulatory frameworks, Kell said that alleviating Africa's huge external debt was a major issue.

"External indebtedness is a major constraint for improving investment climate," he said


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


173 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


Liberia;
Female Presidential Candidate Unperturbed By Male Challenge


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

ABUJA, Nigeria (PANA) - Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, the only female candidate in Liberia's upcoming presidential election, says she is equal to the challenge of the male dominated race.

"Liberian men know what I am capable of," she told PANA Wednesday in the Nigerian capital, where she is attending the Africa First Ladies Summit on peace and humanitarian issues.

Johnson-Sirleaf, 59, an accountant, economist, banker, diplomat and politician, resigned her United Nations job five months ago to join the Liberian presidential race. 

She said her male rivals knew she had been "long in the struggle" for a better Liberia.

"I may not have the huge resources because all I have I earned by my sweat but I do not feel any gender barrier," she said. "The election is not about money. It is about the future of the people of Liberia, someone who can deliver."

Johnson-Sirleaf, who was involved in Liberian politics before, said her mission now "was to restore the glory of Liberia," Africa's first republic founded in 1847 by freed slaves from the United States.

"I have been to jail twice in my political life and I know what I am talking about," she said.

Johnson-Sirleaf, who can claim a brilliant diplomatic career, said she had the national and international clout to clinch the presidency and that she had confidence in the Ecowas-supervised electoral process.

Some 16 political parties have sprung up to contest power in Liberia's post war elections slated for May 30, although there are indications the polls could be postponed by at least one month to allow for the mobilization of funds, thereby giving an equal chance to all the contenders.

For the election, Johnson-Sirleaf's Unity Party is up against serious challenges from former warlords Charles Taylor of the National Patriotic Party and Alhaji Kromah, leading a coalition of other parties.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


174 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Africa First Ladies Summit Ends


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

ABUJA, Nigeria (PANA) - The maiden Africa first ladies conference on peace and humanitarian issues ended Wednesday in Abuja, the Nigerian capital, with a resolution to send peace missions to conflict areas in Africa.

In a 15-point declaration, after three days of deliberations, the first ladies agreed to constitute a "team of mediators to respond to crises and emergencies that threaten peace and stability in Africa."

They resolved to assist "in ongoing conflict prevention, management and resolution efforts aimed at re-establishing peace in conflict areas through peace missions." The first ladies are also to engage in humanitarian activities in order to alleviate the effects of war. 

They called on parties to armed conflicts in Africa to desist from recruiting child soldiers. They urged the international community to declare child-soldiering a war crime and to set up a tribunal to try recruiters.

They also condemned child labor and child prostitution, calling for a worldwide ban.

The communique denounced the use of land mines and illegal trafficking of arms across borders. It called greater mobilization of relief and rehabilitation services for the victims of these weapons.

They called for the promotion of programmes for the economic and political empowerment of women and their full participation in the civic and political processes.

The first ladies also pledged to encourage "public sensitization and the introduction of education on peace, human rights, democracy, rule of law as well as a culture of tolerance at all levels of education."

They recommended that governments and international organizations provide appropriate health and socio-educational facilities to women, children and victims of conflicts.

To mobilize resources for humanitarian assistance, the women urged the holding of fund raising, sports events exhibitions and fashion shows.

The summit, attended by some 20 African first ladies, was initiated by the Nigerian first lady, Maryam Abacha, as a follow up to the 1995 World Women Conference held in Beijing, China.

To underscore their concern for peace, the summit decided to send a delegation of first ladies to the June 2-4 summit of the Organization of African Unity in Harare, Zimbabwe.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 7, 1997


South Africa;
STATEMENT by the Truth Commission's Amnesty Committee


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Cape Town - The amnesty application of one of the people currently serving a prison sentence for the murder of American Fulbright scholar, Amy Biehl, will not be heard when the Amnesty Committee sits in Cape Town from 19 May.

Biehl was murdered in Guguletu in 1993. Her parents will visit South Africa from June, and the hearing of the application in respect of her murder will be heard on 8 and 9 July this year. 

The Amnesty Committee will however hear applications from up to ten other people.

They are:

Mzingisi Patrick Ndlumbini, who is asking for amnesty in respect of the attempted murder of a policeman, Ndumpiwe Ntekiso, in 1991 near Guguletu. The matter is currently under prosecution in Athlone. Ndlumbini states in his application that he was a member of the ANC and MK.

Maxim Pkakamisa and TwoBoy Jack are asking for amnesty for the attempted murder of a number of policemen in Khayelitsha in 1993 during an alleged fight between Self-Defence Units and the Internal Stability Unit of the police and illegal possession of firearms and ammunition. They claim to be ANC members.

Madoda Tisana, Crosby Ndinisa and Philemon Maxam, who have applied for amnesty in respect of the murder of Rholion-Ann Foster and John Geyser in April 1986 at a Paarl farm to obtain arms. The matter was brought before the TRC at a Human Rights Violations hearing in Paarl last year. The applicants say they were members of a UDF affiliate organisation at the time of the murders.

Ndithimi Thyido has applied in respect of an incident in Khaylitsha during 1993 where a policeman, Bongi Mpisane, was killed. He was then a member of the self-defence unit.

Four applicants have applied in respect of an attack on a Milnerton Cafe in 1993, but do not mention the names of their victims. The applicants are: Hilbrow Yeki, Christopher Katu, Mbulelo Kalipa and Sidney Hewu.

The hearings will take place at the Cape Town offices of the TRC at 106 Adderley Street and start at 10 am on Monday, May 19.

Issued May 6.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 7, 1997


Burundi;
Reported Massacre of 36 Pupils


BYLINE: The World Organisation Against Torture (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Geneva - The International Secretariat of OMCT requests your intervention in the following situation in Burundi.

Brief description of the situation: The International Secretariat has been informed, by various reliable sources, of the alleged massacre of 36 pupils at the Buta Seminary, South Burundi, by members of FDD/FROLINA/EX-FAR, an armed Hutu paramilitary group, during the night of the 29th to 30th of April 1997.

The following is a list of the 33 pupils who are alleged to have been killed during the attack. Three other were killed, but the names are still unknown. 

First Scientific B class (Baccalaureat) : Gatabazo Leonidas, Habarugira Wilherman, Harerimana Joseph, Kanani Jean Marie, Mbazumutima Longin, Ndayitwayeko Pie, Ndikumana Alexis, Nduwayo Boniface, Niyungeko Pasteur.

Second Scientific B class (one year before the Baccalaureat) : Barinakandi Gilbert, Dusabumukama Remy, Muhengeri Joseph, Murerwa Jimmy Prudence, Ndayumvaneza Emery, Nduwimana Desire, Ninganza Diomede, Nininahazwe Patrick, Niyongabo Prosper, Niypnkuru Protais.

Third Scientific B class (two years before the Baccalaureat) : Bayishemeze Alain Basile, Bitangwanimana Sebastien, Dushimirimana Robert, Gahungu Eloi, Hakizimana Pascal, Manirakiza Adronis, Mutore Gilles, Nibaruta Phocas, Niyondiko Emile, Niyongabo Egide, Ntakiyica Alphonse, Ntungwanayo Pierre Claver, Nzisabira Lenine, Sebahene Gabriel.

Please note Baccalaureat refers to the examinations that are taken normally at the age of eighteen. It is alleged that 39 other students were injured during the attack, some of them severely.

According to sources close to the victims, the group tried to divide the pupils between Hutus and Tutsi. As the pupils refused, they were allegedly killed.

According to other sources, the pupils were allegedly armed. Last year, the army overthrew the constitutional President, who was replaced by Major Buyoya. The coup was not recognised by the majority party (FRODEBU). In order to strengthen his position, Major Buyoya allegedly called for students to arm themselves.

Action requested : Please write to the Burundian authorities urging them to :

i. guarantee the respect of the physical and psychological integrity of the pupils injured and ensure they receive adequate medical assistance;

ii. carry out an impartial and exhaustive enquiry into this alleged facts, identify those responsible, bring them before a competent and impartial tribunal and apply the penal, civil and/or administrative sanctions provided by law;

iii. guarantee the full respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms in the country in accordance with national laws and international standards.

Addresses : Major Pierre Buyoya, President de la Republique, Presidence de la Republique. Fax : + 257 22 74 90 Monsieur Gervais Rubashamiheto, Ministre de la justice et Garde des sceaux, Ministere de la justice. Fax : + 257 22 21 48 Lieutenant-Colonel Epitace Bayakanakandi, Ministre de l'Interieur, Ministere de l'Interieur. Fax : + 257 22 21 48/21 30 55 Madame Christine Ruhaza, Ministere des droits de la personne, Ministre des droits de la personne. Fax : + 257 21 61 02

Geneva, 7 May 1997

For further information, contact Ben Schonveld, Projects Manager OMCT-SOS- Torture Fax 4122 733 1051 Ph 4122 733 3140. OMCT is l'Organisation Mondiale contre la Torture / The World Organisation Against Torture. OMCT@IPROLINK.CH http://www.omct.org/


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


177 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


South Africa;
ANC National Working Committee Statement


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Johannesburg - The ANC National Working Committee (NWC) and leaders of the nine ANC provinces met in Johannesburg in one of its regular meetings on Monday 5 May. The meeting was attended by among others President Nelson Mandela and Deputy President Thabo Mbeki.

Among other issues the NWC was briefed on preparations for a second ANC submission on military operations and security and intelligence activities to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) scheduled for 12-13 May in Cape Town. 

The NWC had noted that the first and second submissions will create a climate conducive for members to apply for amnesty as part of the ANC's contribution to healing and nation building.

In this regard, past and present members of the NEC, Revolutionary Council, former members of the various Regional Political Committees (RPC), former leaders in the Politico-Military Committees (PMC) and Self-Defence Units (SDU) will apply for amnesty.

Past and present members of the NEC will apply for amnesty within the context of the broad principle of collective responsibility for the conduct of the struggle where their conduct might have resulted in acts, omissions or offences envisaged in the TRC Act.

The ANC's operations document will list military actions undertaken by Umkhonto Wesizwe (MK) and those not listed will be verifiable by the relevant military-politico structures.

ANC legal representatives as well as the Truth and Reconciliation Desk of the movement will submit these applications in terms of the Truth Commission Act section 19(5)(b) by Friday 9 May in Cape Town.

We join TRC Chairperson Archbishop Desmond Tutu's appeal for all our cadres and members who eligible in terms of the act to apply for amnesty.

PROVINCIAL BOUNDARIES

The NWC further considered proposals regarding provincial boundaries with particular reference to Bushbuckridge, Taung/Kuruman and East Griqualand.

The NWC was of the view that boundaries are for administrative purposes and will not disadvantage people living on either sid of the provincial boundaries. We are people of one country with one national policy to redress the imbalances of the past. This national policy is applicable to all people irrespective of provinces in which they may reside.

The current disputes around borders have a negative impact on the reconstruction and development programme in the specific areas affected by such disputes. In this regard, the NWC expressed its unequivocal condemnation of the use of violence in the Bushbuckridge area as a means of perpetuating political objectives.

The NWC agreed to meet with the Executive committees of both the Northern and Mpumalanga Provinces to discuss a proposal on the Grobelarsdal and Bushbuckridge situation. With regard to Taung/Kuruman boundary dispute, the NWC was of the view that discussions on the matter should await the recommendations of the Shubane Commission in this regard.

WOMEN'S LEAGUE

The NWC had also noted the recent ANC Women's League conference and expressed its congratulations for the newly elected leadership of the League, and in its ability as a collective to meet the challenges facing women with regard to peace, development and reconstruction.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


178 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


Southern Africa;
COMESA: Mutharika Responds


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Blantyre - In reference to an article that appeared in Malawi News Online No. 28, entitled COMESA SECRETARY GENERAL DISMISSED, Africa News Network prints a letter from Peter Mutharika and a press release from Dr. Bingu Mutharika:

1. In Malawi News Online No. 28 you carried in item 8 that COMESA Secretary General had been dismissed. As the forwarded press release shows, Dr. Mutharika was not dismissed. He resigned. The story that he had been dismissed was obviously promulgated by those elements in Malawi who are believed to be behind Dr Mutharika's difficulties at COMESA I would appreciate if you would correct the story in your next issue. Peter Mutharika. .

2. Press release: I announce that I have resigned as Secretary General of COMESA effective 17 April 1997. My decision to step down has been taken following the recent developments at the secretariat of COMESA in Lusaka. I am very happy, however that allegations made against me for financial mismanagement or impropriety could not be substantiated.This is because there had been no financial mismanagement in the first place. Therefore I am leaving this organisation with my head high and with honour and dignity. I have served my term of office as COMESA Secretary General with distinction , dedication, competence and integrity. 

COMESA has now established a well-proven track of success. COMESA is now being emulated by other regional economic groupings. I am deeply satisfied with the regional framework which COMESA has been able to achieve under my leadership.

I have developed PTA and later COMESA to the highest standards of regional cooperation and integration. COMESA now has a clear vision, a clear mission and a clear sense of direction. I was also able to develop a political consensus among the Heads os State that the common market offers a viable alternative for sustained growth and development of our countries.

COMESA is truly an organisation of African people, executed by Africans for the benefit of African people. Another matter of great satisfaction for me has been the consensus and compact which I have promoted between COMESA and the donor communities, international organisations and the private sector.

These organisations now play a positive role in regional economic integration in Eastern and Southern Africa. For instance. when I came to PTA in 1991, the total aid package of PTA was only about US$12 million. By 1996, this had risen to over US$100 million.I therefore believe a sound framework has been created for COMESA to work positively with the donor communities in the future.

I pay tribute to all donors who are supporting COMESA. My greatest reward is that COMESA is a reality and is viable. Since taking over its leadership, the volume of intra-COMESA trade rose to nearly US$2 billion and has been growing at an annual rate of over 10 per cent.Tariffs have largely been reduced by the majority of the member states and many non-tariff barriers have been abolished.Trade information systems have been implemented and inter- country transit facilitation measures are in place.

I now take this opportunity to publicly express deep appreciation to the COMESA Heads of State and Government and, to the COMESA Council of Ministers , for having given me the opportunity to serve as their Secretary General for the past six years. More specifically, for the various Heads of State who served as Chairmen of COMESA during my tenure I owe them a deep sense of gratitude for their guidance and support for me.

I also wish to thank the Government and people of Zambia for cooperating with me during the past six years and for making me feel at home here in Zambia. The support of the Government of Zambia made my task much easier and indeed very pleasant. I pledge that I will continue to promote and support COMESA in future.

Dr. Bingu Mutharika Lusaka Zambia 17 April 1997


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


179 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


Malawi;
Malawi News Roundup


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1947 words


 

Blantyre - 1. Ex-president Banda discharged in fraud case

Kamuzu Banda has been discharged from a K137 million (U$ 9.13 million) fraud court case when the judge said that the ailing 99-year old would be unfit to attend court.

Judge Duncan Tambala said 6 April: "Our constitution provides that the right to a fair trial includes the right to adduce and challenge evidence and the right to be tried during his presence."

The others accused in the case, John Tembo, Cecilia Kadzamira, and former Louis Chimango, all put in not guilty pleas to theft and conversion of funds charges relating to the Press Trust.

2. UDF Secretary general to appear in court on defamation charges 

United Democratic Front (UDF) Secretary General, Sam Mpasu, who is awaiting a court verdict on the 1994 Fieldyork notebook scam, has earned himself another lawsuit for accusing Women's World Bank Malawi Affiliate Executive Director that she was using the organisation's resources to unseat the incumbent head of state in the next elections.

The lawsuit follows the publication of a letter Mpasu wrote to President Bakili Muluzi, alleging that Mary Nyandovi-Kerr was using WWB's money for personal use and ambition, included in which were her aspirations to the presidency. The letter also accuses Kerr of allegedly making disparaging remarks about Muluzi's educational qualifications. She had said that they were "not good enough".

Muluzi responded to the letter saying as a result of the allegations he had instructed the Reserve Bank of Malawi, which has been one of WWB's credit lines, to scrap the organisation from the central bank's list of participating institutions in the Small and Medium Enterprise Fund.

Nyandovi-Kerr has denied the allegations saying they were baseless and aimed at crippling her reputation.

Nyandovi-Kerr fell out of favour in UDF mainstream politics when she stood as an independent candidate in the 1994 general elections which pitted her against a fellow UDF bigwig for a parliamentary seat in a Zomba (South Malawi) constituency. She lost the seat.

3. Improved tobacco prices on Auction Floors

Tobacco prices improved on the third day of recent sales in the capital, Lilongwe, to the relief of both farmers and officials. Tobacco is Malawi's biggest foreign exchange earner.

Tobacco sold at an average price of U$2.15 per kilogramme up from US1.60 per kilogramme on the first two days of sales. Farmers, unhappy with the low prices offered by buyers on April 15 and 16 caused a stir at the floors as they went on the rampage scattering tobacco in protest against the prices.

Government expected 115 million kilogrammes of burley tobacco and about 15 million kilogrammes of dark fired tobacco.

General Manager for the Tobacco Control Commission Dr Godfrey Chapola said although the country experienced heavy rains this year, the tobacco that had been brought to the Auction Floors had been dry and of good quality.

Sales in Blantyre and Mzuzu started April 21 and May 5, respectively.

4. Muluzi blames strike on opposition

President Bakili Muluzi has accused the opposition Alliance for Democracy (Aford) for fuelling the on-going strike by civil servants in order to gain political mileage.

The allegation is contained in a letter which Muluzi wrote to the Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions (LO-Norway) in response to concerns raised by that organisation over the harassment of civil servants trade union members by the Malawi police.

Muluzi, who only on April 26 made an impassioned plea for unity in the country, claims that the vast majority of the civil servants in south and central Malawi had abandoned the strike because, he alleged, they did not agree with what the trade union leaders were doing.

"It is only in the Northern Region where the Alliance for Democracy (Aford), is desperately trying to hijack the strike that acts of violence by civil servants on fellow civil servants are continuing," Muluzi alleged.

LO-Norway wrote Muluzi expressing its concern about reports of police brutality against striking civil servants who have been on strike for four weeks now. Muluzi, however, claimed that Lo-Norway was largely misinformed about the strike saying the civil servants were refusing to accept the most historic pay rise given to them ranging from 10 to 47 percent.

Aford has dismissed the allegations saying Muluzi was well aware of what had caused the strike. Aford's publicity secretary Dan Msowoya said Aford was the party that championed democracy in the fight for political pluralism in Malawi and could not now contradict itself by destroying the very tenets of democracy it fought for.

5. Police increase action against strikers

Police in all the country's three regions have stepped up their action against the striking civil servants, resorting to teargas, allegedly beating some of the strikers and arresting others. Acting on orders from the Inspector General of Police, Patrick Chikapa, to deal with the strikers participating in demonstrations, police in the commercial city of Blantyre, the administrative capital Lilongwe and the northern city of Mzuzu, allegedly beat up and arrested union leaders for organising the demonstrations.

The civil servants want government to implement the Chatsika Report which recommends civil servants salary increments and an improvement in their working conditions. The civil servants have rejected salary rises ranging from 47% for the lowest paid to 10% for the highest paid civil servants.

Teachers, who have been on holiday since the strike started four weeks ago, joined their fellow civil servants April 29 and called for the speedy implementation of the Teaching Service Commission. In Lilongwe, several teachers who were demonstrating peacefully were bitten by police dogs which were let loose by police. So far government has shown no willingness to come to the negotiating table with the union leaders.

6. 7 die in mini-bus accident

Seven people died April 28 when a Blantyre-Lilongwe mini-bus overturned in Ntcheu, central Malawi. Police in Ntcheu said five of the victims died on the spot while two were pronounced dead on arrival at Ntcheu hospital. They said several more people were injured in the accident which happened after the driver of the mini-bus failed to negotiate a corner at Njolomole.

In another incident, a 16 year old girl committed suicide on the same day over a love affair. The Chichiri Secondary schoolgirl, Emma Mutuku, who was said to have been pregnant committed suicide allegedly after she discovered that her boy friend had a relationship with another girl at the same school. Her grief-stricken grandmother said Emma killed herself by swallowing five packets of rat poison.

7. British couple murdered

A British couple, resident in Malawi, was murdered in neighbouring Mozambique on or about April 13 while on their way to Malawi from Zimbabwe.

Andrew and Carloyn McDown, who were teaching at Bishop Macknenzie School in the capital Lilongwe met their fate on the border between Zimbabwe and Mozambique. Marilyn Bennet, Information Officer at the British High Commission in Lilongwe, said on April 20 that investigations were underway jointly between the Maputo government and her country's embassy in Mozambique.

8. MHC loses case on rents

The Malawi Housing Corporation, the country's housing utility company, has lost a major lawsuit against its tenants on the corporation's decision to hike rentals on its housing units aimed at making it operate on a commercial basis.

The High Court ruled on April 27 that the MHC, which raised rents by more than 100%, violated Section 7 of the Malawi Housing Act which states that the organisation is a non-profit making entity.

The MHC increased rents in April 1996 by more than 100% in a bid to make the institution operate on a commercial basis and to enable the organisation to put up more housing units as well as improve the maintenance of existing houses. Some MHC tenants with the help of the Consumers Association of Malawi challenged the increase of the rentals in court.

In his ruling, Justice Duncan Tambala ordered that the tenants be credited the rents paid since April 1 last year. MHC chairperson Mrs Joyce Banda said following the ruling the parastatal would have to lay off staff and suspend most of its contruction projects.

9. National soccer coach dismissed

National soccer coach, Reuben Malola has been dismissed. The verdict to fire him was made at a meeting held on April 30 and attended by officials from the Malawi National Council of Sports (MNCS) and the Football Association of Malawi (FAM).

At the meeting it was unanimously agreed that Malola's performance with the national soccer team had not been impressive. The national team has been losing game after game due to what is believed to be a result of poor coaching. "Malola had run out of ideas," said a FAM official who asked for anonymity. The straw that broke the camel's back was Malawi's 4-0 defeat at the hands of Zambia on 12 April in the Africa Castle Cup competition.

A source at the MNCS said it was only by sheer luck that Malola remained coach of the national soccer team as a decision to fire him had already been made sometime in February but he was spared the axe by Malawi's 2-0 win against Mozambique in the Africa Cup of Nations in February. This is the second time that Malola has been fired as coach of the Malawi National soccer team. He was last given the boot as national team coach in 1989 when Malawi lost 4-0 to Zimbabwe. Malola later had a stint with a leading Kenyan soccer team which he coached for four years.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


180 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


Malawi;
The Dismantling Of Banda's Economic Empire


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Blantyre - If former president Kamuzu Banda did not fulfil all legal requirements pertaining to the acquisition of his business undertakings while he ruled the country, he might eventually find himself cash-strapped and 'stripped to the flesh' as the ruling UDF-led government goes on dismantling the remaining bastions of his economic empire.

First to be targeted for dispossession or nationalisation by the present government was the huge and largely successful trading conglomerate, the Press Trust, which until 1995 was widely believed to be Dr Banda's private business enterprise. It was Aleke Banda, Finance Minister, who once headed Press Corporation Limited, who convinced parliament that Dr Banda fraudulently turned to personal ownership an organisation founded with public funds. To this effect, he moved a motion in parliament to reconstruct the Press Trust Act. Naturally, the motion received heavy protests from the opposition Malawi Congress Party. 

Even before the dust had completely settled over the wrangling on the Press Trust issue, the beleaguered former dictator was slapped with what Director of Public Prosecutions, Kamudoni Nyasulu termed a master fraud case involving K137 million (U$9.1 million) from the Press Trust. Nyasulu argues that the money was drawn on the pretext that it was going to be used in the construction and running of the Kamuzu Academy, the grammar school that Dr Banda built in his home district of Kasungu. The Kamuzu Academy is also believed to have been constructed and run with funds from Dr Banda's personal finances.

The latest development concerning Dr Banda's assets is the reallocation of 2,000 acres of land in south Malawi to the ordinary people. This, according to the UDF, is because while Banda ruled he dispossessed or grabbed from the ordinary folk this huge chunk of land knowing they could 'not say no to a life president.' Dr Banda never obtained a lease on the land.

Fachi told the nation on May 4 that acting on powers vested in him as Lands and Valuation minister, he had directed that the disputed land on which Banda established a cattle ranch be distributed to the ordinary people. Following the directive, Dr Banda will lose annual profits to the tune of K15 million (U$ 1 million) from the cattle raising business.

"The country is systematically witnessing the stripping naked of a once powerful personality whose influence in Malawi could be felt from thousands of kilometres away," said an observer who did not want to be named nor say which side he favours in the on-going strike.

While the MCP wishes to undertake a campaign to prove that Dr Banda never grabbed any piece of land from people in the lower Shire by force, leaders in the ruling camp are also determined to see to it that their viewpoint emerges victorious.

A race has thus been started by both camps to win the support of the local populace in the area. On May 5, Fachi was in his land of birth in the lower Shire where he told the people there that Dr Banda had been given two weeks, starting May 5, to dismantle his ranch and either move the 2,000 strong herd of cattle to another area, or to auction or slaughter them. The land, said Fachi, would be given to those who owned it before Dr Banda grabbed it from them in 1978 when the ranch was established.

"We cannot have one man owning 2,000 acres of land in an area where many people have nothing at all," said Fachi.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


181 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


South Africa;
Security officials warned against intimidating witnesses


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Nelspruit - The Moldenhauer Commission into Fraudulent Licenses had to reprimand a group of plain clothes officials from Mpumalanga's safety & security department on Wednesday after they allegedly intimidated witnesses.

The group of six or seven officials had stationed themselves in the court room where the Commission was hearing testimony, as well as in a corridor outside the court room and on the front steps of the court building in Nelspruit.

Commission chairman, chief magistrate Heinrich Moldenhauer has reported the incident to both Mpumalanga premier Mathews Phosa and the official's head of department. He threatened to have them arrested if they were caught harassing witnesses. 

The Commission's scheduled hearings also had to be cut short on Wednesday when provincial traffic director, Henry Brazer, failed to appear.

Brazer, who has been implicated in issuing an invalid drivers and learners license to Parliamentary deputy speaker Baleka Mbete-Kgositsile, was informed on Monday afternoon that he would have to testify but was "unexpectedly" admitted to hospital for a stress and heart related ailment on Tuesday.

His doctors have reportedly said that he may only be able to testify next week. Brazer was also booked off work after a minor heart attack on October 1 last year when he never-the-less drove 350km from Nelspruit to Delmas to personally test Mbete-Kgositsile for her licenses "as a sign of respect".

Brazer is not the only implicated official who was booked into hospital for stress this week. Magistrate Moldenhauer announced on Wednesday that he had been forced to postpone safety & security MEC Steve Mabona's scheduled testimony next week after being informed that Mabona has also been admitted to hospital for an unspecified stress related ailment.

Mabona had been asked to appear to explain why he specially sent his State vehicle and personal bodyguards to drive Mbete-Kgositsile from Johannesburg to Delmas and why he had asked Brazer, who is not registered as a certified testing officer, to test Mbete-Kgositsile.

This is the second time since African Eye News Service (South Africa) first revealed irregularities in Mbete-Kgositsile's license that Mabona has been admitted to a private clinic for stress. Mabona's head of department, Advocate Stanley Soko, who has been accused of quashing an internal investigation into Mbete-Kgositsile's licenses, was also admitted to hospital with an unspecified stress ailment on Wednesday and has declared himself unavailable for testimony this week.

The unavailability of the three key witnesses may, Magistrate Moldenhauer said, force Premier Phosa to extend the Commission's term of reference beyond May 20.

None of the safety & security officials, who were smartly dressed in suits and ties, would say what they were doing at the commission on Wednesday.

They were however seen questioning court orderlies about who the witnesses were, what exactly their testimony had revealed about Mpumalanga safety & security MEC, Steve Mabona, and about who else was still expected to testify.

The security men also allegedly tried to question witnesses as they left the court room about what they had said before the Commission.

Chief magistrate Heinrich Moldenhauer publicly reprimanded the officials at the hearing after first summoning one of them, assistant director Phillip Mahlangu to his chambers.

"I told him that this Commission will in no way allow even the impression that there is intimidation here. We have the power to immediately summon the police to deal with anyone accused of threatening or harassing witnesses or court officials - whether those accused are government officials or not," he told African Eye News Service (South Africa) afterwards.

Moldenhauer added that Mahlangu had claimed Mabona had sent him to attend the hearings "to listen to what was said here".


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


182 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


Swaziland;
Bumper cotton crop predicted for Swaziland


BYLINE: Jabu Matsebula, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Manzini - For the first time in seven years, the Swaziland cotton farming industry expects to net more than R48-million from an anticipated 46 000 tonne bumper crop this year.

This will be the highest yield since the 1990, when a crippling drought which only ended last season, first gripped the small landlocked Kingdom.

According to the Swaziland Cotton Board Chief Executive Tom Jele, the industry only managed to produce 14 000 tonnes last year, as it started to recover from the drought. 

Because cotton is cultivated manually and harvested by hand in Swaziland, it is reputed to have a higher quality visual appearance, as well as stronger and longer fibre micronaire which is highly sought after in the shirt-making and bed sheet industries.

The Kingdom is the second highest cotton producer in the Southern African Customs Union after South Africa. The total SACU cotton crop this year is expected to be 190 000 bales of lint, of which Swaziland will account for 46, 000 tonnes.

Unlike Swaziland's other agriculture products such sugar, citrus and beef that are favoured for the European Community market, the bulk of cotton is sold in South Africa.

It is also increasingly being sold to the growing local textile industry.

This year's cotton price was fixed at R2.40 per kg on April 23, 1997 (1997$$$] by the five nation SACU cotton boards. The price is a 0.20 cent improvement on last year's price.

To encourage cotton cultivation, the price of cotton is protected from the effects of market fluctuations by price stabilisation funds established in each country. The Kingdom's cotton stabilisation fund, which is raised through levies, currently stands at R2 million.

In 1993 the board intervened to top 10 cents to bring the price of cotton to R1.60.

Farmers who abandoned growing the crop during the drought are reportedly returning to cotton cultivation in their droves. This year, 10,000 individual growers registered themselves as growing cotton on both Swazi National Land and private sector title deed farm.

The figure is the highest since the drought first gripped the country. The crop which had dropped to an all-time-low of 6,000 farmers at the height of the drought, is expected to return to the 16000 peak before the drought.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


183 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


South Africa;
Passenger bus torched by protesters


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

BUSHBUCKRIDGE - A Lebowa Transport bus was ambushed and torched by pro- Mpumalanga demonstrators on Wednesday morning after more than 20 passengers were first forced off the bus by the protesters. The ambush, which has been condemned by both the police and the Bushbuckridge Border Crisis Committee, occurred in Marite near where a large Home Affairs office complex was torched last week.

The demonstrations are part of a two week defiance campaign by greater Bushbuckridge residents, who are demanding the immediate transfer of their region from Northern Province to Mpumalanga.

Demonstrations last week also resulted in a police 4x4 patrol van, two large freight trucks and a number of government vehicles being torched after police allegedly fired rubber bullets, live ammunition and tear gas into a peaceful Workers Day rally. 

Police patrols in the heavily populated peri-rural area were also stoned on Tuesday night but no arrests or injuries were reported.

Although Crisis Committee spokesmen have condemned the violence, Themba Godi, said on Wednesday afternoon that the heavy police and army presence in the area was aggravating the situation.

"These are the same people who shot at us last week. People are therefore understandably agitated when they are around. We also hear that the police have been instructed to keep the road from Nelspruit to the Kruger National Park open at any cost - now who is more important, the citizens of this country or tourists," he asked.

Godi confirmed that the Border Crisis Committee would enforce a list of eight resolutions adopted by more than 10 000 pro-Mpumalanga protesters who met at the Thulamahashe Stadium on Tuesday.

The resolutions include a call for residents to rebuild the barricades on all major roads in the area which sparked riots and ultimately led to the arrest of 30 protesters. Other resolutions include a stipulation that local residents will remove all Northern Province registration plates from their vehicles.

Residents also resolved to prevent buses belonging to either Lebowa or Gaza Transport from operating in the area and to boycott all rent and service charges levied by local authorities. Bushbuckridge Border Crisis Committee secretary, Sizile Ndlovu, told African Eye News Service (South Africa) after the meeting that residents were also demanding a meeting with all local councillors and MECs from both the Mpumalanga and Northern Province provincial governments.

"These people must come and explain to us why they are playing political games with our futures. We are toyi-toying on the streets while they are swimming in sweet gravy-train soup," he explained.

To re-inforce their demands for an immediate transfer, Ndlovu said that all local pupils, teachers and government employees would embark on a stay-away.

Regional women's organisations and burial societies have also been asked to organise a march by naked women on the Union Buildings in Pretoria.

The women have been asked to march naked to show their disrespect for local politicians.

"We don't plan to be, or want to be the cause of violence or property damage. But we have been promised this transfer for almost two years now, and are still chained to the Northern Province," Ndlovu added.

"The people of Bushbuckridge work in Mpumalanga, shop there and entertain themselves there. We are historically part of Mpumalanga and demand to be recognised as such."

All 30 suspects appeared in court on Monday afternoon, where 21 were released on their own recognisance until their case is heard on 30 May.

The remaining nine suspects have to pay R100 bail each before they will be released. None of the suspects could afford the bail and are still being held at Bushbuckridge Police Station

One of the nine prisoners smuggled a letter out via a visitor, claiming that they have not been fed properly, had been refused baths, had not been given water to drink and had been assaulted by police guards.

The police were also earlier accused of sparking violence by shooting at crowds and beating pro-Mpumalanga protesters.

Police spokesman Captain Thomas Ramatseba denied the prisoner's claims on Tuesday but appealed to the wider Bushbuckridge community to report the specifics of the alleged beatings during demonstrations so that the incidents could be properly investigated.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 7, 1997


South Africa;
National Party executive murdered


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

SHEEPMOOR - Police are investigating the murder of an executive member of the National Party in Sheepmoor, Mpumalanga, who was found dead along the road to Sheepmoor prison on Saturday after being stabbed in the neck and groin.

National Party regional secretary for the Eastvaal region, Arisja Chantler, said on Wednesday the party believed the two suspects arrested in connection with the murder of Saul Nkosi were ANC members.

She said NP members in Sheepmore were regularly threatened and intimidated, including the chairperson of the Sheepmoor NP branch, Moses Nkosi. 

She said the Youth Action chairperson of the eMbalenhle branch in the Highveld Ridge area had also been stabbed several times and rushed to the Evander hospital where he is in a stable condition.

Nkosi was allegedly stabbed at his house at Sheepmoor squatter camp and then attempted to walk to the police station but died along the way and was found on Saturday morning.

The suspects, Elphas Bhembe of Ermelo and Daniel Mtshali of Dundonald, were arrested later in the day at Nkosi's house were they were arguing with his girlfriend's friend.

They appeared in the Amsterdam magistrate's court on Monday where they were not asked to plead.

The case was postponed to May 9 for a bail hearing.

Investigating officer, Sgt Mbongeni Moyeni, could not confirm whether the suspects were ANC members or whether Nkosi was a NP member.

Provincial NP chairperson, Dr Lucas Nel, said if the murder and other alleged threats against NP members in Sheepmoor were politically motivated, the essence of democracy, reconciliation and nation-building were in jeopardy.

NP Member of Parliament, Watty Watson, said every means would be used to safeguard party members.

"It would be a pity if other parties start resorting to uncivilized actions leading to the deaths of innocent people," he said. .
