LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


185 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


South Africa;
Illegal licenses reason for staggering road death rate


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Nelspruit - The tens of thousands of illegal driver's licenses issued by corrupt traffic officers in Mpumalanga are the reason for the high accident rate in the province, the Moldenhauer Commission heard in Nelspruit on Wednesday.

Chief provincial traffic inspector Johan Hermanus Visagie told the Commission that many of the applicants who were issued with driver's licenses at four centres in the province had not been able to handle their vehicles in test yards, "never mind on the roads".

Visagie also said that he had personally witnessed people from as far afield as the Eastern Cape and KwaZulu/ Natal being tested for Code 10, or heavy truck licenses in small bakkies or saloon vehicles on test centre courses which were "hopelessly" inadequate. 

"One of the centres was using a soccer field as a testing yard, while others were simply open pieces of veld. At Ekangala, where I was sent as centre head, we didn't even have offices and had to work out of our cars in an open field," he added.

Visagie insisted that he had repeatedly objected to the conditions he and his officers were forced to work under but was told "not to interfere" by provincial traffic director, Henry Brazer.

Brazer failed to arrive to testify before the commission on Wednesday after reportedly being admitted to hospital with a stress related heart ailment. His doctors said that he may only be able to testify next week.

Commission chairman, chief magistrate Heinrich Moldenhauer, had requested that Brazer appear to explain the circumstances surrounding his issue of a learners and drivers license to parliamentary deputy speaker Baleka Mbete- Kgositsile on October 1 last year.

Brazer issued the license on incorrect license certificates, made factual errors on the application forms and allegedly failed to test Mbete-Kgositsile on at least two of the prescribed practical skills stipulated by traffic legislation.

Her license is therefore invalid, say traffic officers.

Brazer is also not registered as a certified license testing officer and was book off work on October 1 after suffering a mild heart attack.

"I even told Brazer that I would refuse to continue testing applicants, because although they were being issued with legal licenses, not one single license was actually valid - I mean, these people were given licenses literally 15-minutes after entering the centres," Visagie said.

"Again I was told just to observe and not to interfere - but I was never promoted. Even people with only Standard Eight certificates were made assistant directors, but I remained a testing officer."

Visagie told Magistrate Moldenhauer that the only way to address the " licensed road murderers" was to either re-test all drivers who had got their licenses from the affected centres or to introduce a national system where all drivers had to re-test for licenses after certain period.

"This way we will be able to gradually phase them out," he explained.

Visagie also said that the torching of a R1,2-million centre in KwaMhlanga could have been motivated by officers who were afraid that an internal investigation into fraudulent licenses might reveal that they had not actually qualified for the ranks they claimed their salaries on.

"When I was there, there were some officers with absolutely no personnel files at all and some whose files showed they were junior officers - and not assistant directors as their uniform badges showed," he said.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 7, 1997


South Africa;
PAC activist in court on double murder charges


BYLINE: Benjamin Shabalala, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

AMSTERDAM - Prominent Highveld Pan Africanist Congress (PAC) activist, Sipho Daniel Mbatha, is scheduled to appear in the Amsterdam Magistrate's Court on Thursday after allegedly murdering two ANC members last year.

Mbatha was previously charged with only one murder and pleaded not-guilty. The charge was however later changed to double murder after Smangele Nkosi (32) died of her head and kidney wounds last year.

Nkosi was the girlfriend of Mbatha's first alleged victim, Elias Mpanza, and was allegedly shot by Mbatha a couple of months after Mpanza's murder.

Mbatha was not asked to defend his actions during previous court hearings and court documents give no motive for the alleged murder. The greater Amsterdam community has staged two protest marches to the Amsterdam Police Station, where Mbatha is being held, to demand that he be given the death penalty or life imprisonment.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


187 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


South Africa;
Half a billion rand shortfall for education


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Nelspruit - The Mpumalanga Education Department faces a shortfall of R594 million for the 1997/98 budget year, said MEC for Education, David Mabuza during his budget speech in the Mpumalanga legislature on Wednesday.

Mabuza said his department needed an extra R372 million alone to cover personnel costs.

"The total budget allocation is R2 billion which is a far cry in relation to the mandate given to this department," Mabuza said. 

He said the department had received 1 046 applications for voluntary severance packages, 16 of which had been approved, and which would cost the department R2,2 million.

He said 1 132 promotional posts also had to be created and filled by August 1, which would cost an additional R57 million.

"It must be noted that, unlike in the public service, the award of voluntary severance packages to educators does not mean freezing posts, because of the ever-increasing numbers of learners who are entering the formal education sector," Mabuza explained.

He said teachers preferred the redeployment option to accepting voluntary severance packages, as was indicated by the fact that the province had reached an equilibrium with regards to the number of learners and educators.

Mabuza said those accepting voluntary redeployment came from former black schools, whereas "some quarters" were reluctant and resisting redeployment and rightsizing.

"It is being addressed," he said.

Mabuza added that an unforeseen problem was that of rapid urbanisation and the influx of foreigners from neighbouring states, which had led to an increase in squatter camps.

"This in itself places great pressure on the department's ability to provide the most essential education facilities timeously," he explained.

Mabuza said the financial allocation to his department had major inadequacies considering South Africa had to adapt to globalisation of the economy which demanded skilled human resources.

In the past budget year, the department of education provided and improved 957 classrooms, 90 special rooms, 50 administration blocks, and 1 519 toilets in the past year as part of 331 separate projects. .

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 7, 1997


South Africa;
'Border war' protests set to escalate


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

BUSHBUCKRIDGE - More than 10 000 pro-Mpumalanga protesters resolved on Tuesday to rebuild barricades on all major roads in the area in an attempt to force the government to transfer the region from Northern Province to Mpumalanga.

Similar barricades last week led to clashes between police and protesters after a large Home Affairs office complex, three trucks and a police 4x4 patrol vehicle were burnt out.

Thirty protesters were arrested after the unrest and charged with arson and disrupting public order. 

Eight resolutions were adopted during the rally at Thulamahashe Stadium on Tuesday, including a stipulation that local residents will remove all Northern Province registration plates from their vehicles.

Residents also resolved to prevent buses belonging to either Lebowa or Gaza Transport from operating in the area and to boycott all rent and service charges levied by local authorities. Bushbuckridge Border Crisis Committee secretary, Sizile Ndlovu, told African Eye News Service (South Africa) after the meeting that residents were also demanding a meeting with all local councillors and MECs from both the Mpumalanga and Northern Province provincial governments.

"These people must come and explain to us why they are playing political games with our futures. We are toyi-toying on the streets while they are swimming in sweet gravy-train soup," he explained.

To re-inforce their demands for an immediate transfer, Ndlovu said that all local pupils, teachers and government employees would embark on a stay-away.

Regional women's organisations and burial societies have also been asked to organise a march by women on the Union Buildings in Pretoria.

"We don't plan to be, or want to be the cause of violence or property damage. But we have been promised this transfer for almost two years now, and are still chained to the Northern Province," Ndlovu added.

"The people of Bushbuckridge work in Mpumalanga, shop there and entertain themselves there. We are historically part of Mpumalanga and demand to be recognised as such."

All 30 suspects appeared in court on Monday afternoon, where 21 were released on their own recognisance until their case is heard on 30 May.

The remaining nine suspects have to pay R100 bail each before they will be released. None of the suspects could afford the bail and are still being held at Bushbuckridge Police Station

One of the nine prisoners smuggled a letter out via a visitor, claiming that they have not been fed properly, had been refused baths, had not been given water to drink and had been assaulted by police guards.

The police were also earlier accused of sparking violence by shooting at crowds and beating pro-Mpumalanga protesters.

Police spokesman Captain Thomas Ramatseba denied the prisoner's claims on Tuesday but appealed to the wider Bushbuckridge community to report the specifics of the alleged beatings during demonstrations so that the incidents could be properly investigated.

189 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


South Africa;
MEC illegally re-instated 3000 illegal licenses


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

Nelspruit - Mpumalanga safety & security MEC, Steve Mabona, illegally ordered the re-instatement of 3 000 suspected fraudulent driver's licenses while they were still being investigated by the police, the Moldenhauer Commission into Fraudulent Licenses heard on Tuesday.

Principal traffic inspector, John Muller, told the Commission that the licenses had been suspended from the Home Affairs population register computer system in 1995 after his investigations had revealed that they had been issued irregularly.

Mabona, however, sent a letter to Home Affairs director, Piet Colyn in August 1995 saying that the investigation had been completed and that the 3000 odd licenses had been cleared and should therefore be re-instated on the computer system.

Muller, who has received death threats, had his salary stopped, had his State issue car repossessed and who has been publicly branded a racist on national radio by Mabona, reported the matter to the Justice Department and the provincial Director General, Frank Mbatha, but was allegedly ignored. 

Repeated requests for national intervention and a Commission of Inquiry were also ignored, he said, until Muller told African Eye News Service (South Africa) that one of the irregular licenses had been issued to Parliamentary deputy speaker, Baleka Mbete-Kgositsile.

Subsequent press reports in Sunday Times resulted in the immediate establishment of the Moldenhauer Commission.

"I have been investigating this issue, often in the face of severe opposition, since 1988 when I first joined the traffic department. But, even now that it is out in the open, my future looks very bleak - I don't see how I will ever have any control over it again," he said.

Despite having no personal or constituency links with Mpumalanga, Mbete- Kgositsile was issued both a learners and drivers license on October 1 last year after she was driven from Johannesburg to Delmas in MEC Mabona's State issue car by his personal bodyguards, as "a sign of respect".

Provincial traffic director, Henry Brazer, who was booked off work sick at the time after a minor heart attack, drove 350km from Nelspruit to Delmas on the same day to personally test Mbete-Kgositsile.

Brazer is not registered as a certified testing officer and reportedly used incorrect test procedures and application forms while issuing the two licenses. No official records of the tests or license were kept.

Muller testified on Tuesday that two additional bags of fraudulent licenses, which he had discovered hidden in a dustbin at a test centre, had been stolen from his office and that 11 of the 20 license testing officers currently operating in the former KaNgwane were not in fact properly qualified to do so.

He also told the commission that after two 'master' license books, containing 200 blank licenses were irregularly issued to Brazer in 1993, he and two other senior officials were ordered to retrieve them.

Muller said that they confronted Brazer at Nelspruit's Private Hospital where he was recovering from an unspecified sickness and while Brazer admitted to having the books, he refused to give the investigators his safe keys.

A couple of days later, he claimed that the books had been stolen from the safe - although he conceded that there was no forced entry or other proof of burglary.

Muller also testified that at least one traffic officer who was charged with fraud and corruption by police had been promoted by Brazer after being suspended and had been paid R13 000 'back-pay'.

"I also think the Commission should look at appointments in the department in general, because Brazer and his wife interviewed people on their own for posts over weekends. Brazer's wife doesn't work for the traffic department - she works in the Premier's office," he added.

During cross-examination by chief magistrate Heinrich Moldenhauer, Muller also said that he had seen a possibly irregular license for Brazer's son, which had been issued at the Kabokweni test centre on his 18th birthday. Mbete-Kgositsile's licenses were issued on Kabokweni letterheads.

Confirming that the 3000 fraudulent licenses which were re-instated by Mabona and tens of thousands of others all appeared legal at face value, Muller said that the government only had two options; scrap all licenses issued in KaNgwane since 1988 or accept them and immediately tighten control of testing officers and centres.

This, he said, should preferably be done by an outside agency such as the Department of Justice.

"It is practically impossible to just scrap all suspected licenses as some of them may actually be legal - but perhaps we should begin retesting all suspects," he added.

Confirming he had been intimidated and victimised, Muller said that he was uncertain whether he would be able to continue working for the traffic department.

"I would like to appeal to all law enforcement personnel throughout the country to persevere in their investigations and to remember that no-one is above the law. In the end, righteousness and justice will prevail," said Muller.

"I am one of the most highly qualified traffic inspectors in Mpumalanga and am not a junior trouble maker, lair or racist as referred to by my so-called superiors."


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


190 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


Sports - General;
Ball Says Olympics Can 'Turbocharge' Development


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Cape Town - Turbo-charging the engine of change in South Africa through sport and economic development is the essence of the opportunity offered by the Olympic bid.

This is the message Bid Company chief executive Chris Ball will convey in a special edition of a business report to be published soon by Cape Town company Omega Investment Research, headed by former politician and diplomat Denis Worrall. 

"By combining sport and the undeniable economic benefits of hosting a South African Olympics, we believe we can take a giant's stride in fulfilling Nelson Mandela's dream for a new republic," Mr Ball says.

He also makes the point that South Africa is not in the Olympic race merely "to win silver", but is going for gold.

The special report, edited jointly by political scientist David Welsh and consultant and former journalist Vuyo Bavuma, offers foreign investors and business people an insight into the opportunities and risks of doing business with the new South Africa into the next millennium.

It will provide exposure for Cape companies abroad but also boost the lobbying process, particularly in the sense of providing the material for a reasoned assessment of South Africa's political and economic future.

This has emerged as a key issue in the Olympic lobbying process - there is a perception that the stability of South Africa's nascent democracy depends more than anything else on the presence at its helm of President Mandela.

Concerns about a post-Mandela South Africa will be addressed directly in the business report.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


191 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


South Africa;
Protecting SA's fishing resources (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Cape Town - France has dispatched a frigate to the South Atlantic to prevent the fish poaching around French possessions and has offered to help South Africa deal with a similar problem

France's decision to send a frigate to the South Atlantic to prevent poaching of the Patagonian toothfish by fishing vessels from Europe and the Far East is an indication of how serious the problem has become and reinforces the warnings from environmentalists that fish resources throughout the region are now under serious threat.

The French action also demonstrates South Africa's disturbing vulnerability to this growing international crime. Most of the fish resources now being taken illegally around the French islands of Crozet and Kergeulen also exist within South Africa's own exclusive economic zones, especially around Gough and Marion islands, where poaching is now reported to be extensive and brazen. 

While the offer by France to co-operate with South Africa in preventing the rape of marine resources will be appreciated, it is clearly far from being a satisfactory answer to the problem. South Africa should not have to depend so helplessly on others to protect its economic interests, least of all within its own economic zones, and urgent attention will have to be given to an effective national response to poaching.

Providing the South African navy with warships to prevent poaching is one option. Another, mooted in the past, is to share the huge costs involved in dealing with the problem through the formation of a multinational force to deal with the threat to the maritime resources of all countries with interests in the region.

The dispatching of a French frigate to the region, and the warning yesterday by French ambassador Tristan d'Albis of the extent of the illegal activity, serve as a jarring wake-up call. The longer poaching is allowed to continue the more intractable and menacing the problem will become.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


192 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


South Africa;
I gave go-ahead for CCB, Malan admits


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Cape Town - Magnus Malan, former defence minister and earlier chief of the South African Defence Force, admitted in Cape Town today he had approved the establishment of the Civil Co-operation Bureau (CCB) in the 1980s.

He disclosed to the Truth Commission tha he had at times given orders which had resulted in the deaths of "innocent civilians in crossfire".

He sincerely regretted such deaths, but had never issued any orders for political assassinations, nor had he ever been approached to authorise such assassinations, he said. 

"The killing of political opponents of the (then) government, such as the slaying of (Witwatersrand University academic) Dr (David) Webster, never formed part of the brief of the SADF," he said.

Recently, the TRC was told in an affidavit that a former CCB member, Ferdi Barnard, had admitted privately to friends that he had shot Dr Webster.

Under cross-examination, General Malan said former CCB members involved in assassinations should be prosecuted.

General Malan also denied that a so-called "Third Force" - a parallel force to the SADF and the SA Police, specifically to combat unrest - had ever been established.

He confirmed such a force had been proposed and then investigated by a sub- committee of the State Security Council headed by the then Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok, but the council had finally decided not to institute such a force. He had always been opposed to the establishment of such a force.

"This is the stark reality which this commission will have to face up to I want to lay this ghost to rest once and for all," General Malan said.

In his voluntary submission to the commission, General Malan said he assumed full moral responsibility for the actions of soldiers who had been under his command. He offered his "unqualified apologies" for any unlawful actions by them.

Both the SADF and the ANC had acted in a "bona fide" manner to promote their cause, "painful though it may be".


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


193 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


Sports - General;
Chay Blyth: Bringing the excitement back into ocean yacht-racing


BYLINE: Henri du Plessis, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Cape Town - When Chay Blyth took to the ocean wave in the early Seventies to go around the world - the so-called wrong way, without stopping - he thought he had a fair idea of what he was letting himself in for.

The fact that he succeeded in becoming the first man to sail around the globe non-stop, against the prevailing trade winds, had little to do with luck and a lot more to do with good preparation and a good boat.

Afterwards, however, in his book about his adventure, The Impossible Voyage, he admitted it was a greater challenge than he could ever have imagined.

It was a tough call. His steel yacht, named British Steel after his main sponsors for that event, pointed into the wind all the time and took a buffeting for months on end. 

"No-one will ever say that there is no God without my remembering all these situations," he wrote.

"To atheists I say: go sailing single-handed for a few weeks. Alone in a fierce sea you feel the ocean is making a determined effort to get you. Man is pitifully small against such gigantic forces. You feel over and over again that it is God's will that you survive."

The rigours of sailing to weather is appreciated in all sailing circles, from the beginner in Optimist dinghies to the most experienced ocean racers. The boat's deck is always at an acute angle, the bow is always smashing into the chop and the surf breaks over the bows every time the boat pitches into the dark waters.

It is impossible to stay dry. Gear failures will call the sailor on deck at all times of the night or day, as the strain of sailing uphill often is hard on the hardware.

Chay Blyth knows all that and sports the experience. He knows all about the vulnerability, the loneliness - even when surrounded by a crew in cheek by jowl circumstances - and the inherent dangers.

Now Chay keeps busy helping others go through the same rigours in search of self-fulfilment. As safely as possible, too, considering the knowledge he can input in the design and preparation of the yachts.

Chay is in town after seeing off the fleet of 14 BT Global Challenge yachts on Sunday when they left Cape Town on the penultimate leg of their race around the world, against the rotation of the earth. That is to say, against the prevailing trade winds.

The second last leg of the race, from here to Boston in the United States, is one of the easier legs. After this the yachts face a relatively short hop across the North Atlantic to finish at Southampton in time for Cowes Week, one of the top sailing regattas held in British waters.

Chay is organiser, race director, planner, shoulder-to-cry-on and advisor of the race skippers and their crews. Above all though, he is their mentor.

A tough Scotsman with a dry sense of humour which no doubt stood him in good stead during his own voyages, Chay projects an attitude that proclaims nothing is impossible if you put your mind to it. His greatest pleasure in all that he does, though, is to work with people.

Ordinary people.

"The best part of this race for me is to work with people," he said. "To give ordinary people the opportunity to sail like this. You must realise that most of the crews on board these yachts have never sailed before. Once they succeeded in securing their financial support, we trained them from the start, taught them to sail. Even some of the skippers."

Blyth has sailed in many top order ocean races since his record-setter in British Steel. His vast experience has taught him what he would like to see in this kind of racing.

"I find it difficult to get excited about these single-handed races in open class boats," he said. "It usually ends up being an affair which is won by the guy with the biggest budget. Look at that non-stop race of the French, for instance. The winner came in about two thousand miles ahead of the second- placed yacht.

"That is not racing. That is a display of technology and design. It turns into a parade. That is why we have 14 yachts that are exactly the same, fitted out with the same equipment and crewed by the same class of crew, in most cases."

What you get then is a much more competitive event, where the leader is continually under pressure from the boats behind.

Chay is convinced that "his" race will now become a regular. But he doesn't sail in this sort of race himself anymore.

"No, I think I am too old for this now. I am not in the sort of shape to do it. I find sufficient pleasure helping others realise the dream now," he said.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


194 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


South Africa;
Sigcau warns W Cape on sale of state assets


BYLINE: William-Mervin Gumede,, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Cape Town -Public Enterprises Minister Stella Sigcau has warned the Western Cape and other provincial governments that they may not go ahead with selling state-owned assets in the provinces without consulting national government.

Ms Sigcau was responding to plans by the Western Cape government to sell off provincial state assets to fund capital projects, such as the construction of roads and buildings.

Finance MEC Kobus Meiring, in his budget speech in the provincial legislature, announced that all unused and costly fixed assets in the province would be sold and the proceeds transferred to a loan fund to bankroll new capital projects. 

The Western Cape government also plans to rationalise office space in Cape Town saving up to R110 million over three years.

Mr Meiring has set aside R13 million for 1997/98 to kick start what he called the "most ambitious provincial privatisation programme in South Africa" .

Ms Sigcau warned that any privatisation drive by the Western Cape or any other province, should follow a structured route, approved by national government.

"National government has to agree with the route of privatisation taken by the provincial government before privatisation can take place," she said.

Ms Sigcau said national government had laid down strict criteria for the selling off of state assets. She expected the Western Cape government to follow the guidelines.

An inter-ministerial cabinet committee has already been appointed to oversee all privatisation of state-owned assets.

She said her department would meet soon, preferably next month, with provincial governments to outline the national government's position on the privatisation of provincial state assets.

The national government's preferred method of privatisation was to seek strategic equity partners for each provincial state-owned company.

Privatisation should also be to the benefit of historically disadvantaged groups in the provinces.

Ms Sigcau said the committee overseeing privatisation had agreed that shares in restructured enterprises should be sold, at a discount, to the National Empowerment Fund (NEF) which would be set up to empower historically disadvantaged communities.

It was the national government's intention that funding schemes would be developed with the private sector to enable the disadvantaged to get shares in the NEF.

"These principles have been accepted by the inter-ministerial cabinet committee and will soon be discussed at the level of the portfolio committee and with labour and other stakeholders," she said.

She said the national government had also agreed that the employees of state-owned enterprises that are privatised should benefit through employee share ownership schemes. The inter-ministerial cabinet committee had endorsed the share scheme with a limit of approximately R10 000 per employee.

Ms Sigcau announced this week that the Government expected the restructuring of five large state-owned enterprises - South African Airways, Safcol, Alexkor, Aventura and Eskom with a joint turnover of R40 billion - to be completed or to be nearing completion in the next 12 to 18 months.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 7, 1997


South Africa;
ANC Cadres urged to apply for TRC amnesty


BYLINE: Clive Sawyer, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Cape Town - The African National Congress' most powerful body, the national working committee, has urged all cadres and members eligible for amnesty to apply to the Truth Commission.

Amnesty applications by ANC political and military leaders will be submitted to the commission's Cape Town offices by Friday. 

While not mentioning names, the ANC expanded on its previous decision that leaders of the liberation movement who were eligible for amnesty should do so.

This included past and present members of the national executive committee, the revolutionary council, former members of the regional political committees, former leaders of the politico-military committees and of self- defence units.

"Past and present members of the NEC will apply for amnesty in the context of the broad principle of collective responsibility for the conduct of the struggle where their conduct might have resulted in acts, omissions or offences envisaged in the Truth Commission Act," the national working committee said in a statement.

The ANC's second submission on military, security and intelligence operations will be made to the Truth Commission on May 12 and 13.

Meanwhile, the commission has delayed the amnesty hearing of one of the killers of American Fulbright scholar Amy Biehl to allow her parents, who live in the United States, to attend, Sapa reports.

In a statement yesterday, the TRC said Ms Biehl's parents were due to visit South Africa from June. The application would then be heard on July 8 and 9.

Africa News


May 7, 1997


South Africa;
ANC denies blame for terror acts


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Cape Town - The African National Congress is convinced its cadres were not involved in some of the acts of terrorism attributed to it by its political opponents, such as the bombing of Wimpy bars, says Deputy Defence Minister Ronnie Kasrils.

But the ANC acknowledged being responsible for the 1983 Church Street bombing in Pretoria, in which 19 people died and more than 200 were injured; the 1986 Magoo's Bar bombing in Durban; and "at least" a further five or six car-bomb attacks, Mr Kasrils said.

He also acknowledged the ANC had laid landmines in border areas, which had caused the deaths of white civilians and black farm labourers, but said this practice had been stopped because of the deaths. 

Mr Kasrils was speaking during a public debate, "The Just War and Reconciliation", organised by the Truth Commission and held in the Old Town House yesterday.

After detailing these actions in response to a question about the ANC's policy regarding "non-combatant" deaths, he said: "And that's about it You can't put all the violence at the door of the ANC and MK (armed wing Umkhonto weSizwe)." The ANC had expressed regret for the lives that had been lost, especially civilian lives.

"For us the end didn't justify the means. We attempted to meet that and we think we did pretty well," Mr Kasrils said. "Actually, a very small proportion of the action involved civilians, but at the same time we profoundly regret that."

Constand Viljoen, Freedom Front leader and former chief of the SA Defence Force, argued that neither the former apartheid government nor the liberation movements could pass the full test of having fought a just war - "at least not in the classical sense of this theory".

"But let me hasten to remind you that this war, if it could be called war, is so unique that the traditional 'just war' theory cannot easily be applied."

He said the politicians had failed the SADF, because he had given at least five formal briefings to the Cabinet between 1976 and 1985 in which "good advice" had been given on the need for alternatives to the continuing war.

But this advice had been ignored on each occasion.

South Africa;
Winnie likely to face TRC on Stompie death


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 106 words


 

Cape Town - Winnie Madikizela-Mandela will "more than likely" be subpoenaed to appear before the Truth Commission to answer questions about the death of 14-year-old activist "Stompie" Moeketsi Seipei in February 1989.

Mrs Madikizela-Mandela may also face questions about the alleged disappearance of at least two other children at the same time.

Her expected subpoena was confirmed today by Truth Commissioner Yasmin Sooka.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


198 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


South Africa;
Kids tell of picnic horror


BYLINE: Joseph Aranes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Cape Town - Children involved in a school bus crash at Cape Point have told how their fun picnic outing became a nightmare when one of the buses suddenly overturned at Buffels Bay.

The pupils, from Ridgeville Primary School in Mitchell's Plain, were singing in the packed bus, with many standing in the aisle. But the singing turned to screams and crying as the bus toppled over, said one pupil. 

She described the incident as her "worst nightmare come to life".

The bus driver has been charged with reckless and negligent driving.

A helicopter flew one seriously injured pupil to Constantiaberg Medi-Clinic from the accident, another nine children were rushed to hospital in ambulances, and 36 were taken to hospital in a privately owned bus.

Four of the pupils, aged between 10 and 12, suffered dangerous back injuries.

A teacher and a parent were also injured when the bus overturned.

The four school buses on the jaunt had gone down the steep road leading to the picnic site in the Cape of Good Hope Nature Reserve, apparently in spite of clear signs warning that buses were not allowed on the road. The bus that overturned was the last in the convoy.

In a recent statement, the Cape Town City Council said buses may drive down the road to Buffels Bay on weekdays but not on public holidays or at weekends.

Standard 3 pupil Ilhaam Davids, 10, who was in the bus, said all she could remember was the screams of fellow pupils as the bus overturned.

She and her schoolmates had been excited about the outing and had been singing moments before the crash.

"Some of the pupils were standing as there were not enough seats for all of us in the bus. I fell to the floor immediately as the bus toppled over and hurt my back, but not too seriously ... this is what the Metro Rescue doctor told me.

"Everybody was screaming and crying and the experience was like one of my worst nightmares come to life."

The deputy director of Metro Rescue Services, Wayne Smith, said emergency units, including the civil defence, fire brigade, the police and army medics were rushed to the scene after initial reports indicated that the incident involved a collision between two buses.

"Thankfully it was not as bad as that and besides four pupils, who suffered quite serious back injuries, most of the other injuries involved scratches and bruises," Dr Smith said.

Most of the injured were taken to False Bay Hospital, where they were treated and given hot soup while waiting for their parents to collect them. The more seriously injured were taken to Victoria Hospital and by late last night most had been discharged.

Police were investigating whether the bus was roadworthy, a spokesman said.

This morning parents and pupils gathered at the school, anxious for information about the children involved in the crash. A school spokesman said they were told as many details as possible.

Not all the children on the crash bus were at school this morning and by 9am school was dismissed for the day.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

United States and Africa;
White House Expects Mobutu to Return Home


BYLINE: White House


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 186 words


 

Washington - Comments by White House spokesman Michael McCurry, in Mexico City traveling with President Bill Clinton, regarding the situation in Zaire and President Mobutu Sese Seko, who is attending a regional summit in Libreville, Gabon:

His aides have indicated that he's expected to remain in Gabon only until Friday, when he is to return to Zaire. We have not received any indication that president Mobutu has decided not to return to Zaire. ...

We've continued our conversations about how to achieve an orderly transition to a political process that will lead to free and fair elections. We'll continue our diplomatic support of the efforts that are underway by the United Nations and the government of South Africa to achieve agreements that will lead to both the cessation of hostilities in Zaire and the type of orderly transition to a new government that the international community seeks.

200 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 7, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigerian Journalist Ladi Olorunyomi Released from Jail


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

New York - Ladi Olorunyomi, a Nigerian journalist who has worked for the Concord and the Herald newspapers, was released yesterday from the Lagos prison where she had been held without charge since March 20, the Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) has learned.

CPJ's Africa program coordinator Kakuna Kerina spearheaded the campaign for her release in collaboration with other international organizations.

Mrs. Olorunyomi is the wife of exiled Nigerian journalist Dapo Olorunyomi, who was brought safely to asylum in the United States by the joint effort of CPJ and Amnesty International in December 1995, just days after the bombing of his office. Mr. Olorunyomi was editor of Independent Communications Network's "TheNEWS" and "Tempo" news magazines. 

"The government finally gave in to the pressure brought to bear by CPJ and others," said Mr. Olorunyomi from Washington, where he is a fellow at the Panos Institute. "This shows that campaigns really work. I am profoundly grateful for the help given to my wife and to me by CPJ."

Mrs. Olorunyomi was arrested on the night of March 20 at her home in Lagos by military intelligence and army officers. They did not remove anything from the premises and gave no reason for her arrest. She was taken to a holding facility in Apapa, where she was detained incommunicado.

CPJ, in conjunction with Amnesty International and Reporteurs sans Frontiers, sought her release. A March 21 letter from CPJ's executive director, William A. Orme, Jr., to Nigeria's ruling leader General Sani Abacha calling for her unconditional release strongly protested her arrest " as a grave and blatant attack on press freedom, journalists, and their families" and a violation of journalists' rights worldwide as guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights and other international covenants and codes.

"We are relieved that Ladi Olorunyomi has been released from her wrongful, unwarranted detention and that she can return home to comfort her two young children," said Ms. Kerina. "Regrettably, military intelligence is subjecting her to continued injustice by requiring her to report twice weekly to the facility where she was held."

Reuters reported today that another journalist, Godwin Agbroko, editor of The Week magazine, who had been detained since December because of reports published by his magazine about disagreements within the ruling military government, was also released.

For information, contact Committee to Protect Journalists, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York NY 10001, U.S.A. Tel:+1 212 465 1004, Fax:+1 212 465 9568. Kakuna Kerina (x 103), kkerina@cpj.org, or Selam Demeke (x 118), demeke@cpj. org. Internet: http://www.cpj.org/.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 8, 1997


Ghana;
Ghanaian Fighter Plane Crashes, Killing Pilot


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - A Ghanaian Air Force jet fighter crashed Wednesday as it escorted President Jerry Rawlings's plane which was returning home from Kasane, Botswana.

Rawlings was in Botswana to attend an international business forum of Southern African leaders. 

The Ghana News Agency reported that the plane crashed into the bush near the air force base in Accra.

The plane, whose type has not yet been disclosed, went down minutes after it broke formation with the Presidential jet. There was loud a bang followed by a huge ball of flames and thick black plumes of smoke.

Guards, policemen and dignitaries who had gathered to welcome Rawlings watched in awe as the fighter, after escorting the presidential jet, pulled upwards, rolled on its belly, then nose-dived into the ground.

Seconds after the crash, members of the presidential guard and police and some of the dignitaries, including Vice President John Evans Atta Mills, sped across the tarmac and the runway to the crash site.

A witness who was in the presidential jet said Rawlings, a former fighter pilot, was the first out of his plane and ran to crash. A Ghana Civil Aviation Authority fire tender sprayed foam into the area where the black smoke was a coming from because it was beyond reach.

Parts of the aircraft, as well as the body of the pilot, lay strewn meters from site of impact. The larger chunk the body was charred.

Air Force Commander T.A. Bruce and aides were seen giving instruction as they collected body parts.

Officials prevented journalists from going to the crash site where bulldozers were frantically clearing a path for fire tenders. Officials also refused to comment on the crash.

May 8, 1997


United States and Africa;
Addis Ababa Hosts U.S Trade Exhibition


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The United States and Ethiopia, erstwhile allies, then enemies, and now friends again are hoping to increase their volume of bilateral business, with a U.S. trade exhibition now underway in Addis Ababa.

The four-day exhibition, in which 12 co-sponsors are involved, is the second of its kind in the Ethiopian capital. In the first, organized by the U. S. Embassy in November 1995, 12,000 people visited the stands.

Citing the growth of the exhibition, U.S. Ambassador to Ethiopia David Shinn said the number of participants had risen from 40 in 1995 to 150 presently.

The bilateral aspect of the event, he said, demonstrated the importance the U.S attached to its investment in Ethiopia and the flow of trade in both directions.

Opening the exhibition Wednesday, Ethiopian Vice Minister of Trade and Industry Bruk Debebe said Ethiopian-U.S. economic relations had improved significantly since the downfall, in 1991, of the Marxist military regime of Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam.

Without giving figures, Bruk said bilateral trade had been rising steadily and that U.S. investment has been increasing most significantly in mining, energy, tourism development.

May 8, 1997


Libya;
Kadhafi Arrives In Niamey


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

NIAMEY, Niger (PANA) - Libyan leader Moammar Kadhafi arrived in Niamey Thursday on a two-day visit at the start of a tour that will also take him to Nigeria, South Africa and other African states.

"I am happy to come to Niger to pray on this (Hegira) occasion and show to the world the power and potentials of Islam," Kadhafi said on arrival. 

He was met Niger's head of state, Gen. Ibrahim Mainassara Bare, the cabinet, religious and opposition party leaders. Kadhafi was to attend Hegira prayers marking the New Year in the Islamic calendar.

On Friday, he will be in the northern Nigerian city of Kano, where he will also join in similar prayers, expected to be attended by ranking Nigerian Islamic leaders, including Sufi sub-sect Imams, political and trade union leaders.

The Libyan news agency, Jana, reported Wednesday that Kadhafi spoke at length on the telephone with Moroccan King Hassan II, the chairman of the Al- Qods (Jerusalem) Committee, and with Saudi King Fahd Ben Abdel Aziz, on the prevailing situation in the Islamic World.

Jana said that both monarchs asked the Kadhafi to encourage African leaders in their efforts to defend Islam and its adherents.

204 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 8, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Role Of Information, Private Sector In Africa's Development


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - African Ministers responsible for economic and social development and planning ended a five-day meeting Thursday with a declaration on accelerating trade and investment in the region, in which they endorsed the role of information and the private sector in Africa's development.

In the "Declaration on Accelerating Trade and Investment in Africa," the ministers, who met in Addis Ababa, said they were "convinced that trade and investment are essential components in any credible strategies to accelerate our countries' development and sustain high rates of economic growth."

Broadly-based high rates of economic growth geared toward creating employment and generating rising incomes are recognized as essential components for poverty reduction and its eventual eradication. 

The ministers said there was need to boost domestic savings and investment, attract private foreign capital transfers and expand trade with the rest of the world, Africa must change the negative perception of the region as a high- risk place and improve information flow on development in Africa.

It must also modernize, expand and diversify production; reduce the cost of establishing business; and strengthen international competitiveness.

However, they noted that though Africa had created a conducive environment for the expansion of trade with the rest of the world, protectionist policies on the part of others with regard African agricultural, textile and clothing had frustrated that expansion.

The conference endorsed the implementation of the African Information Society Initiative, a framework adopted by ministers in 1996 to build Africa's national information and communications infrastructure. This is seen as a part of a strategy to harness information and communication technologies towards development.

Welcoming the debt-reduction initiative for highly indebted poor countries, recently proposed by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund as a first step in the right direction, the ministers called for additional and more generous resources to reduce substantially "all Africa countries' debt stock."

The cost of servicing external debt is estimated to have exceeded 340 billion U.S. dollars by the end of 1996.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 8, 1997


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian Police Kill Leader, Arrest Other Members


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Ethiopian Police said Thursday they shot and killed the leader of a clandestine organization and arrested a number of his followers.

Police said they shot Assefa Maru, the leader of Ethiopian Patriotic Front, while he resisted arrest. Reporting this, the Ethiopian News Agency gave no details of when and where the shooting took place.

The agency quoted the Federal Police Investigation unit as saying that Assefa and his group were found "making preparations to destroy economic establishments and assassinate individuals holding public offices."

His accomplices, Lt. Tegenu Jinka and privates Bogale Tessema, Tesfaye Getachew, Shimelis Ayele, Solomon Tekle Wolde, Yibeltal Simegne and Mengistu Kibret, all ex-servicemen, were arrested. Three assault rifles, seven hand grenades and a pair of binoculars were seized.

Police has mounted a crackdown to hunt members of the group still at large.

Africa News


May 8, 1997


Nigeria;
Five Arrested Over Wednesday's Lagos Bombing


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Five people have been arrested in connection with Wednesday's bomb explosion near an army barracks in Lagos, a Nigerian defence spokesman said Thursday.

Col. Godwin Ugbo, the acting director of defence information, said the suspects were arrested in the vicinity of the blast, along Herbert Macauley Street, downtown Lagos.

The explosion occurred in front of Masrda Army Barracks, causing minor damage to a military truck and buildings in the area. 

Ugbo confirmed there were no deaths but at least five people were injured, including soldiers.

He said the injured soldiers, among them a woman, were treated at a military hospital in Yaba and discharged.

Witnesses said the explosion narrowly missed a 25-seater military bus, the apparent target. The bus was heading for Lagos island from the northern city suburb of Ikeja.

Lagos State Police Commissioner Abubakar Tsav said investigations had been launched into the incident, the sixth in the city in the last seven months.

An explosion in November 1996 killed Olushola Omoshola, the chief security officer of Murtala Muhammed International Airport, in Lagos, and two others in his car.

On December 16 that year, the Lagos state administrator, Col. Mohammed Warwa, escaped unhurt after another blast hit two vehicles in his convoy, injuring three persons.

Two days later, another bomb rocked a bus conveying members of a task-force on environmental sanitation to work. Some 16 persons, mainly soldiers, were injured in that explosion.

On January 7, 1997, a device exploded at the Ojuelegba area, killing two soldiers and injuring many others, while another explosion went off in Maryland in February. All but one of the explosions were targeted at the military.

The police have blamed the prodemocracy groups, especially the National Democratic Coalition, or Nadeco, for the explosions.

Sixteen people have been charged with alleged terrorism in connection with the bombings. Four of the accused, including Nigeria's exiled Nobel literature laureate, Wole Soyinka, are being tried in absentia. The offence carries the death sentence on conviction.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 8, 1997


Sports - General;
Cape Town team in Asia drive


BYLINE: Norman Joseph, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Cape Town - Cape Town is marketing its bid to host the 2004 Olympic Games among influential Asian sports administrators in South Korea, where the East Asian Games are being held later this month.

Senior bid officials and VIPs left yesterday for the South Korean city of Pusan at the invitation of the International Olympic Committee. 

Included in Cape Town's team are Bid Company head Chris Ball, Cape Metropolitan Council Mayor William Bantom, bid director Ngconde Balfour and lobbyists Tidi Khobane and Anita Soni.

Mr Ball said they would be attending the largest gathering of IOC members before September 5, when the host city would be announced. At the meeting would be "people from the Middle East to Japan".

Representatives from rival bid cities Rome, Athens, Stockholm and Buenos Aires have also been invited to meet the 40 IOC members in Pusan this week. Each city will have a display stand promoting its bid.

"This is all part of a process of getting the full confidence of IOC members," said Mr Ball.

Africa News


May 8, 1997


South Africa;
Lubowksi: SA spy claim reaffirmed


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Cape Town - General Magnus Malan has confirmed his allegation in Parliament in February 1990 that murdered Swapo lawyer Anton Lubowski was a South African spy paid by the SADF's Military Intelligence.

He told the Truth Commission he stood by his claim, but that he no longer had documentary proof as this had been given to the Harms Commission. 

According to the official inquest into Mr Lubowski's death, headed by Namibian judge Mr Justice Levy in 1994, there was prima facie evidence that several members of the SADF's Civil Co-operation Bureau (CCB) had been directly involved in the murder.

General Malan said he had not read the inquest report and could not comment on this. Later, when he was asked to confirm a report in the Cape Argus quoting him telling Parliament that Mr Lubowski had been a paid spy and that he had done "good work" for the SADF, General Malan said the report sounded a correct version of what he had said.

Commission deputy chairman Alex Boraine put it to General Malan that it was "a very strong allegation", which also affected Mr Lubowski's family.

General Malan said: "I feel very sorry for that family, make no mistake about it, but I have to reply to questions."


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 8, 1997


Namibia;
'SADF caught Swapo's Nujoma in 1960s - then let him go free'


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Cape Town - The SA Defence Force captured Namibian President Sam Nujoma while he was a Swapo officer in about 1966 or 1967, but sent him back to Zambia because it would have been "unfair" to keep him prisoner and to give him the status of prisoner-of-war, General Magnus Malan told the TRC.

His revelation came in response to a question by commission chairman Desmond Tutu about what he had meant by authorising "disruption" of the forces of the liberation movements. 

General Malan replied that such disruption had never included killing, and that it had referred to action against Umkhonto weSizwe (MK) soldiers and not political leaders and activists. He then gave the capture and release of Mr Nujoma as an example of how it would have been counter-productive to have targeted a leader.

Africa News


May 8, 1997


South Africa;
General won't seek amnesty for raids that killed civilians


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Cape Town - General Magnus Malan has told the commission he does not intend applying for amnesty for cross-border raids by the SADF and operations in which innocent civilians died.

But he said he would consider a suggestion by commission deputy chairman Alex Boraine that he should apply because he may have contravened international law by admitting he ordered such operations. 

During his testimony over more than two hours, followed by more than three hours of questions, General Malan said: "As a professional soldier, I issued orders, and later as minister of defence I authorised orders which led to the death of innocent civilians in cross-fire. I sincerely regret the civilian casualties, but unfortunately this is part of the ugly reality of war."

Referring specifically to cross-border raids, General Malan said he considered these operations to have been lawful.

"Cross-border raids cause bloodshed. As a Christian I regret the loss of life. I, however, do not intend to seek amnesty for those operations," he said.

Dr Boraine told General Malan the killing of innocent civilians was defined as a gross human rights violation under international law.

"I say with great respect that you may be placing yourself in some jeopardy - would you not consider the need for applying for amnesty?" Dr Boraine asked.

General Malan said all that commanders could do was "be horrified" by civilian deaths and try to prevent them.

"That's all I can say Thanks for your good advice (about applying for amnesty), I will consider it," he said.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 8, 1997


South Africa;
Mandela 'backed chemical war project'


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Cape Town - The SA Defence Force's chemical and biological warfare programme never had "sinister connotations" and President Mandela had approved its continuation after being fully briefed, General Malan told the commission.

The programme, code-named Project Coast, had been directed at developing " effective counter-measures" against the chemical and biological threat posed by the Soviet and Cuban forces in Angola. 

It had been approved by him in 1981 "at a stage when the Republic of South Africa possessed no chemical or biological capability and could not rely on the assistance of any major power for assistance should such threats materialise," the former defence minister testified.

General Malan gave the Truth Commission a "top-secret" document from then brigadier Dr Wouter Basson, dated March 16, 1990, and requesting financial approval for amended procedures for the project.

He said it was "interesting" to note that the secret Basson document failed to report "any sinister motive or intention of killing people".

"I have been informed that the members responsible for the project briefed President Mandela fully on the existence, scope and ambit of Project Coast and that he thereafter granted his approval for its continuation," General Malan told the commission.

According to the document, there were four "sub-projects" of Project Coast: Bluet, Kassa, Rod and Chancelor.

The total costs of the project in 1985-86 were R28,79-million, and in the following years, to 1989-90, respectively R27,34-million, R32,9-million, R45, 46-million and R31,7-million.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 8, 1997


South Africa;
'I was surprised to hear of CCB hit squad activities'


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Cape Town - General Magnus Malan told the Truth Commission he had authorised the establishment of the Civil Co-operation Bureau (CCB) as a component of the South African Defence Force special forces, but had been unaware of hit squad activities.

He said in Cape Town yesterday he that he had been unaware that the CCB's " Region Six" - members of which were implicated in the murders of Swapo lawyer Anton Lubowski and Witwatersrand University academic David Webster, among others - had been activated. 

"I was quite surprised," he said.

He told the commission that the special forces had been an integral and supportive part of the SADF and that the role of the CCB had been envisaged as "the infiltration and penetration of the enemy, the gathering of information and the disruption of the enemy".

He added: "The CCB was approved as an organisation consisting of 10 divisions or 'regions', as expressed in military jargon.

"Eight of these divisions or regions were intended to refer to geographical areas. The area of one of these regions, Region Six, referred to the Republic of South Africa. "The fact that the organisation in Region Six was activated came to my knowledge for the first time in November 1989.

"The CCB provided the SA Defence Force with good covert capabilities," General Malan said.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
