213 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 8, 1997


South Africa;
Nats on the ropes (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Cape Town - The national party is reeling after leader FW de Klerk's shock decision to disband the task team looking into the party's future

The National Party was always going to have a difficult time after losing power in the 1994 elections. It was, after all, the party that had inflicted the grossest of human rights abuses on the citizens of the country it had governed.

Revelations on the extent of those abuses has not helped the NP's cause since then. Even the most myopic of South Africans will now be aware of the horrors visited upon the country by the NP's earlier manifestations. 

To survive, the NP had, therefore, to cast off all traces of the past. Party leader FW de Klerk turned to Roelf Meyer, perhaps the most enlightened of the party's younger guard, for solutions.

Meyer probed three options: the forming of an alliance; the forming of an election pact; and the creation of a new "umbrella" movement.

It appears the mere whisper of the third of these options - which would effectively require the party to disband - set off alarm bells among party leaders, particularly those that might be characterised as the old guard.

Today Meyer is paying the price. His task team has been disbanded without any indication where he may be going. It will be a body blow to the "verligte" ranks of the party if Meyer is forced into the political wilderness and would follow the loss of the likes of Leon Wessels.

Tomorrow the NP could be paying the price. There is little chance, given the reality of politics in South Africa at present, that the party will be able to form alliances or pacts without the enlightened thinkers.

Ironically, it is likely to discover in the months to come that the best solution will be to disband. The alternative would be a slow death, as last experienced by the United Party.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


214 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 8, 1997


South Africa;
Elda Mahlentle: bringing education to deprived squatter children


BYLINE: Sabati Ngcai, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Cape Town - Eight years ago an Eastern Cape woman, Elda Mahlentle, was so overwhelmed by the plight of children living a life of degradation and deprivation in Western Cape squatter camps that she was inspired to open a school for them.

Her mercy and kindness indirectly cost her the lives of her husband, daughter and a granddaughter during the "witdoeke wars". But in spite of these tragedies she courageously and unselfishly continued her work because she had a driving ambition - to bring the light of education to communities living in darkness in the squatter camps.

As you go into Marconi Beam squatter camp near Milnerton, a bumpy, dusty road leads to a skewed row of scores of rusty wood-and-iron shacks. The only thing that differentiates Elda's home from the others is the name "Zizamele Mampinga" ("Try hard" Mampinga, the last being her clan name) painted prominently outside. 

Inside the shack is a well-built woman of average height in her 60s who welcomes people with a broad smile.

Elda was born in Stutterheim in the former Ciskei in 1934. The last of 10 children, she completed her Junior Certificate in 1953, after which she did a two-year teachers' training diploma in Blythswood in the Transkei. She could not get work as a teacher and so joined the staff of the Frere Hospital in East London, where she trained as a nurse for one year.

In 1957 she came to Cape Town and worked in a Robben Island hospital where she met a policeman, who became her husband. After passing a course in midwifery at Woodstock Hospital in 1962, Elda returned to her home in Transkei.

She returned to Cape Town in 1973 and for the next 12 years she was jobless. In 1985 she got a job as a social worker for one year for the Roman Catholic Church in Old Crossroads - and it was here she found her mission in life.

"My heart was touched by hundreds of children who were loitering in the streets with nothing to do," she said. "They could not find a place in a local primary school because it was full to capacity. Many of them had come from Transkei for holidays. Their parents, most of whom worked on farms, did not have enough money to bring them back home. They were being exposed to crime and other dangers."

With the permission of the church, Elda opened a school in 1988.

"I started with 516 children and I was the only teacher," she said. "We used a shack which served as a church hall and which had no roof. Other classes had to be conducted in the shade of a tree. The children were divided into four classes - sub-A to Standard Two.

"I advertised on radio and got one teacher after a week and later another."

Then tragedy struck. Elda's husband and granddaughter were burnt to death in the violent "war" in Crossroads between the Witdoeke and the Comrades. Elda sought refuge in the nearby New Crossroads and the school closed down.

In June 1990, she was persuaded to return by the leader of a youth group, who told her the children were suffering. She opened a creche in Section Four.

"This was the time when the fighting between the two groups was hotting up," she said. "Children who lived in Section Four could not go to school in the rival Section Three because they were beaten up and shot at. I took classes up to Standard Two and had to accommodate other children who could not go to school because of the war."

In 1991 Elda's daughter was shot dead and she was forced to flee the chaos in 'rossroads and re-settle in Marconi Beam.

"My life was in danger," she said. "I had no other option. Life has taught me that you don't only become an enemy doing what is wrong, but you can also become one by doing good."

In Marconi Beam she found the same desperate situation - children walking about the streets with nothing to do.

"It broke my heart to see girls and boys of school-going age dancing in shebeens," she said.

She talked to parents and discovered there were many children who wanted to go to school but did not know where to go.

"I got assistance from Zimasa Primary School in Langa township which offered to take some children. We arranged for lower fares with Golden Arrow buses, and the children went to school,"said Elda.

Then it transpired that many children were not going to school because their parents, most of whom were unemployed, had no money for bus fares. "So in1993, I opened a school from Sub A to Standard Five here in Marconi Beam."

The community named the school Elda Mahlentle Primary School in her honour. It has gone from strength to strength in spite of the fact that it has had to be rebuilt several times after being destroyed in fires that have swept Marconi Beam.

It now has12 classes from Sub A to Standard 7. The classrooms are metal ships' containers donated by various companies.

And with a growing demand for schooling from the elderly, Elda, with the help of the community, opened a night school for literacy classes from Sub A to Standard 10.

Last year a number of elderly people, some on walking sticks, graduated and received certificates for the first time in their lives.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


215 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 8, 1997


Business and Finance;
Government boost for businesswomen


BYLINE: Business Reporter, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Cape Town -The Department of Trade and Industry is to start a drive to boost women's participation in small businesses, according to Alistair Ruiters of the department's Small Business Promotion Centre.

In a speech to this week's International Conference on Women in Small, Medium and Micro Enterprises at the University of Stellenbosch's Centre for Entrepreneurship, Dr Ruiters said the department had set up a gender forum.

This was designed to make women's access easier to all the programmes and incentives run by the department. 

An annual work plan had just been finalised, Dr Ruiters said, and "very soon" this would be translated into actions which would make a "lasting impact" on the role of women in small business.

"The structure of business ownership in South Africa illustrates the daunting challenge that faces women," Dr Ruiters said.

Seventy-two percent of micro businesses were owned by women, 36 percent of sewing or clothing businesses, 9,4 percent of manufacturing enterprises and 0, 5 percent of building and construction businesses.

Strategies which did not tackle the specific needs of women ran the risk of failure, he said.

Women in rural areas faced unique challenges, while all over the country, traditional stereotypes and attitudes towards women blocked their access to opportunities.

"In most cases, women will not have assets to put down as security in order to access finance.

"It is common practice to expect them to gain approval from their partners in order to access opportunities, " Dr Ruiters said.

"In most households, they are always expected to make more sacrifices to keep their families happy.

"And there is a tendency to expect women to demonstrate superwoman qualities in order to gain recognition," he said.

The Government had targeted women for support in its small business promotion strategy, channelled through agencies such as Ntsika, which provided non-financial support, and Khula, for financial support. Apart from the Centre for Small Business Promotion in the department, and the National Small Business Council set up as a watchdog for small business interests, small business desks had been set up in each province's economic affairs department, Dr Ruiters said.

"Problems such as lack of self-confidence, fear of failure and low self- esteem among women can be attributed to both historical and societal pressures under which women have been and must continue to operate.

"No amount of external interventions by the Government or private sector can successfully eradicate these without the determination and a concerted effort on the part of women themselves."


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


216 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 8, 1997


Sports - General;
SA will bring new 'spirit' to Olympics


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1947 words


 

Cape Town - The Hollywoodian fizzle of the archetypal Olympic Games of the past two decades, hyped to the nines, brash and brassy, has worn a little thin as a model for the future.

The air of excess, the expense, the commercialism - these things have come to be regarded as inimical to the ideals that are meant to instil faith in the wholesomeness of Olympism.

Last year's event in Atlanta was possibly the apotheosis.

Driven almost entirely by private enterprise, it was the biggest commercial event in the 100-year history of the modern Olympic movement.

Critics said the organisers overdid the commercialism, selling sponsors the right to put the Olympic rings on everything from game shows to hamburgers. 

Feats of endurance and record-breaking achievements in the sports arenas were matched by a merchandising bonanza of mind-boggling proportions on the streets outside, attended, unsurprisingly, by a certain queasiness, a sense that the Olympics was less about taking part and struggling well (the precepts at the heart of the Olympic movement) than making the most bucks by the easiest means.

The idea that the Olympic spirit is just another saleable item is tacky. It makes the IOC itself look a bit tacky, too.

Which is why Cape Town's plan for 2004 is especially appealing to the influential grandees touring the world to find the best site for the Games after Sydney.

Cape Town's proposal is quite different from those of its rivals - Rome, Athens and Stockholm in Europe, and Buenos Aires across the ocean in South America.

For a start, it is what, in business-speak, is called a "right-sized" event, a realistically modest proposal, about half the size of the Atlanta Games and tailored to South Africa's economic capacity.

Furthermore, the considerable public-sector component of the budget will effectively prevent, or obviate the need for, the kind of rampant commercialism that a wholly private-sector affair cultivates.

And both the capital and operating budgets, fully underwritten by the national government, carry substantial contingency reserves that provide financial security, and allow a pragmatic degree of flexibility as the project unfolds.

In adding a fourth "developmental" pillar to the traditional three pillars of Ol-ympism - sport, culture, environment - the Cape Town plan comes into its own as an instrument of good and a symbolic opportunity for the IOC to redeem and reinvigorate the ideals of Olympism and refresh its own image, through a unique, and genuinely consequential landmark event.

This occurs on three levels.

The least tangible is the impact the bid will have - and already is having - on the nature of Cape Town as a city.

Today's planners have inherited a warped, inefficient, and costly urban matrix shaped by the unjust and impractical dictates of apartheid ideology.

Political reforms have overtaken, but not redressed, the myriad deficiencies in the physical make-up of the city and, unless they are tackled, the social and economic costs will mount.

The Olympic plan on its own, especially given its modest scope, is not to be regarded as the ultimate panacea, but it is already proving to be the most significant catalyst the city has seen.

It is being used effectively to "seed" new development where it's most needed, re-focus transport and land-use planning, and provide tight time- frames for the achievement of realistic developmental goals.

The creation of Olympic, or sporting, facilities is only one by-product of the overall scheme.

These are being strategically located to stimulate new business and service opportunities which, in the absence of the Olympic projects, would not have a foundation on which to grow.

Coupled with this is a deliberate stratagem to spread the benefits equitably, to ensure that contracts and projects will help small and emergent businesses gain a foothold in the economic mainstream, and provide advantage to previously disadvantaged communities.

In this way, the developmental pillar of the bid is intended as a means of practical empowerment.

And in macro-economic terms, one is looking at an event that has the potential to raise the Gross Domestic Product of southern Africa by one percent a year for 10 years.

The predicted growth for South Africa is R30-billion over 10 years, with additional tax revenue of R8-billion.

The job-creation potential is immense - between 90 000 and 100 000 permanent jobs.

And contrary to the arguments trotted out - this week again - by the abysmally ill-informed, anti-bid lobby, these are not merely jobs on Olympic stadium construction sites, or jobs that will end once the athletes pack up and go home.

They are genuinely permanent jobs in tourism and all the industries that feed off it. In effect, these cover the entire spectrum of the economy from agriculture and food production to manufacturing, financial services and commerce.

However you look at it, it's an impressive impact.

Chris Ball likes to illustrate the point in another way. He says you could put the Olympic Games in London and the Gross Domestic Product of Britain would hardly reflect it.The British capital already attracts visitors in their millions, and foreign investment on a bewildering scale.

Without having to say it in so many words, the real point is that if you really want to make a difference to the lives of millions of people, and positively influence the future of a city, a country, a whole continent, don't put the Games in yet another European capital (read Rome, Athens, Stockholm), where the impact will be barely evident.

It is the sense that the African bid really is an opportunity to show that Olympism need not be overblown and overly commercial and can be inspirational that is, by all accounts, being appreciated by visiting IOC members.

It is the right bid for the right time.

With less than four months to go before the September 5 vote, getting this message across, personally, to as many IOC members as possible, is the bid team's priority. It is difficult to judge accurately, but it seems to be making its mark.

In tandem with this, there are a number of other initiatives under way.

President Mandela and his deputy Thabo Mbeki are living up to their promise to campaign for the bid more visibly, and to do all they can to allay what is on the face of it an irrational concern on the part of some in the IOC about the prospects of political stability in a post-Mandela setting.

South Africa is not immune to Afro-pessimism, and this is a reflection of it.

Tackling the other key concern - crime - is the goal of an unusual and risky initiative launched last week by the Cape Town Community Olympic Forum.

It is founded on the idea that if it is possible to secure peace accords between gangs, and between gangs and society as a first step towards drawing gangsters into a peaceable existence in the mainstream, then crime and violence will be dramatically reduced.

The Achilles heel of the initiative is the exclusion of drug dealing from the accords, so that while gangsters may well reduce violent crime by virtue of ceasing the ir own criminally violent activities, they are not going as far as ceasing to be criminals.

There is a view that the bid is working with criminals in an unholy alliance.

Can one fault that view? Of course, the forum is independent from the bid, so it is not technically a bid initiative. That aside, forum chairman Brian Williams does contest the negative view.

He argues that everything else has been tried, and has failed. He argues, too, that if the problem of gang warfare is to be seriously tackled, then the gangsters must somehow be engaged. What better way, he feels, than to give gangs a measure of responsibility to prove their bona fides, and to be given the chance to take the first step away from crime by themselves.

Time will tell whether this novel approach bears fruit.

A lingering weakness in the bid as a whole is, of course, the apathy, the careless inertia, in which too many of Cape Town's often most influential residents invest a perverse pride.

It is spurred on by the effete and tiresome bluster of commentators who ought to know better.

There is no doubt there are legitimate concerns, but it is doubtful any of the most vocal detractors has bothered to establish whether they are being addressed or not, how and by whom. If they did, they would find a level of planning, expertise, vigilance and concern in the broader bid team which far exceeds their own.

African National Congress MP Willie Hofmeyr made the point succinctly this week when he said: "I must emphasise that it is good to be sceptical about the Olympic bid - as some people are - but let us try to stick to the facts. It would be sad if we threw away a huge opportunity for our country because of prejudice rather than fact."

And he added that "it is quite wrong to argue that the money spent on the Olympics could be better spent on education, housing and other social needs. Without the Olympics, the money simply would not be there to spend".

That's the crux of it.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


217 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 8, 1997


South Africa;
'Abandon gangsters or we'll stop Olympic Bid'


BYLINE: Ashley Smith, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Cape Town - Pagad national commander Aslam Toefy has threatened to " mobilise the masses" against Cape Town's Olympic Bid if it continues to associate with known gangsters such as Rashied Staggie.

Speaking at a People against Gangsterism and Drugs (Pagad) meeting at Spes Bona High School in Athlone last night, Mr Toefy said although Pagad was not against the city hosting the 2004 Olympic Games, it would oppose the bid if it was promoted in this way. 

"There can be no Olympics without the people and liberation hasn't reached us yet. Pagad is going to bring about true liberation, justice and dignity for our people," he said.

Mr Toefy said the Olympics must benefit the oppressed masses in the Western Cape, and children should be given every chance to develop and have a fair chance to take part.

But gangsterism and drugs would prevent them from being able to rise to the occasion.

He said the Olympic Peace Initiative signed by gangsters who said they had reformed, led by Mr Staggie, and the Community Olympic Forum, was a scam to pull the wool over the eyes of people on the Cape Flats who yearned for peace.

Pagad member Madelief Botha said the "marriage" between Brian Williams of the Community Olympic Forum and Mr Staggie had been made in hell.

She blamed the current political climate for allowing known gangsters to sit on a public platform without making a commitment to stop selling drugs.

n Mr Williams was wrongly associated with the Community Outreach Forum in a caption on yesterday's Cape Argus Attitudes page.

Africa News


May 8, 1997


South Africa;
Nats pull back from Rubicon 2


BYLINE: Hugh Robertson, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Cape Town - The National Party stands on the brink of disintegration after crisis talks yesterday between party leader

F W de Klerk and the movement's provincial leaders.

After the talks Mr De Klerk took the surprise step of disbanding the NP taskforce aimed at bringing about a new political alignment, saying it was creating tensions in the party.

The taskforce was headed by the party's foremost reformist and its Gauteng leader, Roelf Meyer, who has been at the centre of bitter infighting for more than a year. 

A clearly unhappy Mr Meyer said last night that he would "reconsider" his options, and the party's Gauteng Youth leader, Paulo Andrade, said he would review his position in the party.

Both have urged the NP to consider the option of disbanding as a prelude to the emergence of a new political movement - an option rejected earlier this week by the party's federal executive after angry exchanges.

The Nats' Western Cape leader, Hernus Kriel, who has emerged as one of Mr Meyer's strongest critics, welcomed Mr De Klerk's announcement.

But there was seething discontent in NP ranks in Gauteng, where the provincial head committee is to meet on Saturday.

The NP now faces two no-win options: it can continue as it has since it lost power to the African National Congress, or it can continue to seek a new political alignment.

If it pursues the new alignment option, it will quickly face a hard and unchangeable fact which Mr Meyer and his supporters have encountered in their months of consultations - other political groups of consequence have insisted that the NP would have to disband before any new movement could emerge.

If it goes for the stay-as-we-are option, it can have little hope of further growth and virtually no hope of ever becoming a serious rival to the ANC-led alliance.

The latter course would leave the NP in the Western Cape as the only viable provincial division of the party, and there has been strong speculation - conceded by Mr Meyer and others in the party - that it could break away if the rest of the NP decided to disband.

One of the most important parties Mr Meyer has held discussions with on a new alignment, the Democratic Party, spelled out the NP dilemma today.

DP leader Tony Leon said Mr De Klerk had delivered "a silver bullet to the heart of the NP" and added: "Before others can make common cause with enlightened democratic members of that party, the NP must disband."

Mr Leon said only the anti-defection clause in the constitution preserved the NP's unity and it was certain the NP would disappear in its present form.

Another group with which Mr Meyer has negotiated, the National Consultative Forum headed by former Transkei leader Bantu Holomisa, has also urged the NP to disband.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


219 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 8, 1997


South Africa;
I never ordered murders of opponents, says Malan


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Cape Town - Former defence minister Magnus Malan has told the Truth Commission he never ordered, or was party to, the assassination of political opponents.

He questioned the authenticity of a report compiled by the then SA Police and SA Defence Force recommending that five Renamo (Mozambican National Resistance) members be eliminated because they were a potential political embarrassment to South Africa.

General Malan, the former head of the SADF and minister of defence in the cabinet of President P W Botha, was testifying voluntarily yesterday before a panel of commissioners and their investigators in Cape Town. 

He declined to comment on a top-secret report in the possession of the commission, extracts of which were read to him, in which it was recommended that five Renamo members suspected of murdering their secretary-general, Orlando Cristina, on a Defence Force farm near Pretoria in April 1983, should be assassinated.

The SADF was at the time secretly supplying Renamo with weapons and other equipment to wage war against Samora Machel's Frelimo government in Mozambique. The five were reported to have become a potential danger to South Africa because of their knowledge.

One of them, Boaventura Bomba, was a relative of Lieutenant Adriano Francisco Bomba, a Mozambican pilot who defected to South Africa in his MiG 17 fighter in 1981. The pilot was subsequently killed, reportedly also by Renamo.

The four-man panel that made the recommendation in the report consisted of two policemen - one the officer investigating Mr Cristina's death - and two senior Defence Force officers, one of whom was controversial surgeon and chemical weapons expert Wouter Basson.

Dr Basson, now facing charges of dealing in drugs, was fired from the SADF by then President F W de Klerk as part of a purge of senior officers allegedly involved in unauthorised covert operations.

But he was subsequently re-employed in controversial circumstances by the present National Defence Force after allegedly trying to sell details of South Africa's chemical weapons programme to Libya.

General Malan acknowledged that he had been told about Mr Cristina's murder while he was minister of defence, but said that he had been told the issue had been handed to Renamo "to decide on, or words to that effect".

He said he had never seen the secret document referred to and would not have approved it if he had.

"I see it's not signed. Is it an official document?" he asked. "I'd like to read the document fully. I'd like to know who the author was. I'd like to know how authentic this document is."


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

220 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 8, 1997


South Africa;
Truth Commission Opens Amnesty 'Hotlines'


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Cape Town - The Truth and Reconciliation has opened special amnesty " hotlines" in its offices to handle calls from people wanting to apply for amnesty.

People wanting to make inquiries about amnesty applications can call the following numbers during working hours this week:

Cape Town: 021- 26-2028, or 24-5161 (switchboard)

Durban: 031- 3052678, or 031-307-6767 (switchboard)

East London: 0431- 432746, or 0431- 43-5223 (switchboard)

Johannesburg: 011-333-1425, or 333-6330 (switchboard). 

The final deadline for the receipt of amnesty applications is Saturday May 10.

The law establishing the Truth and Reconciliation Commission gives those responsible for acts, omissions or offences which might lead to criminal prosecutions or civil actions for damages the opportunity to apply for amnesty if their actions were associated with political objectives.

Archbishop Desmond Tutu has issued a national appeal to people right across the political spectrum to "take this golden opportunity to apply for amnesty on the most generous terms possible."

At the moment we have about 5500 amnesty applications registered in our database, but more have been received. Nearly 60 applications which involve gross human rights violations have been heard in public, while about 787 have been dealt with in chambers. Altogether 39 people have been granted amnesty and 797 denied. Many of these were from people who applied for actions which does not fall in the TRC's mandate.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


221 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Experts Tackle Improvement in African Statistics


BYLINE: UN Economic Commission for Africa (ECA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

Addis Ababa - The state of information development in Africa is characterized by lack or poor quality of data, weak or inadequate telecommunications systems, lack of a critical mass of trained personnel and laws and regulations that impede information flows, a senior United Nations said here today.

K.Y. Amoako, United Nations Under-Secretary General and Executive Secretary of the Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) made this remark in an address to the beginning of 7th Meeting of the Coordinating Committee on African Statistical Development (CASD).

With ECA as its Secretariat, CASD was established in 1992 as an inter-agency committee to "coordinate and direct efforts to revitalize and develop" African statistical systems following the complete loss of infrastructure and disintegration of some statistical services in the 1980s.

Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Ethiopia, Madagascar, Morocco, Mozambique, South Africa and Uganda represent African Member States in CASD with Afristat, Eurostat, UK-ODA, US Bureau of the Census, World Bank, UN statistical Division, Institut national de la statistique et des etudes economiques, Statistics Sweden as the multilateral and bilateral component. The Institute of Applied Economics (ISAE), Makerere University, Ecole Nationale Superieure de Statistique et d'Economie Appliquee de Ctte d'Ivoire stand in for African regional training centres. 

An integral part of the Addis Ababa Plan of Action for Statistical Development in 1990s adopted by the African Planners, Statisticians and Demographers in 1990, CASD is also an implementation mechanism for the Plan of Action.

Having dissolved its sub-committees at its 6th Meeting in March 1996, CASD is at a cross-roads. On the table for discussion is an ECA initiative to replace Task Forces for the old sub-committees that managed training; research, methods and standards; data processing and organisation and management of National Statistical Systems.

The Task Forces would develop:

1. Connectivity of CASD members; 2. Electronics Data Processing (EDP) capability for African countries; 3. Promotion of gender desegregated data in Africa; 4. Measurement and Monitoring of poverty in Africa;

Strengthening of the Statistical Training Programme for Africa (STPA) Centres and establishment of an African Household Data/ Archive Service Centre are also to come within the mandate of the Task Forces.

Assuring the meeting of ECA's commitment as it performs its role as a "catalyst in driving forward the statistical agenda in Africa as a central issue of the information services and development", K.Y. Amoako added that the CASD secretariat should be "enabled to function more effectively in addressing the priority needs of coordination and facilitating the implementation of the Addis Ababa Plan of Action".

A burning issue on the Committee's agenda is the mobilization of resources. Aware that the United Nations Regular Budget and Regular Programme Support for Technical Assistance were unlikely to rise to the occasion because of the United Nations financial crisis, ECA has tabled fresh solutions to CASD's financial crunch:

- Taking advantage of UNDP's Support Services for Policy and Programme Development (SSPPD)

Changes have taken place in UNDP after the evaluation of the 5th UNDP Programme Cycle. The agency has recognized the coordinative role of regional policy support and has recently changed policy by including the Regional Commissions for funding under SSPPD. UNDP's change of tack affords Regional Commissions the opportunity to "focus mainly on upstream work to support national and regional programme development".

- Tapping funding agencies

This would entail an active review of funding agencies' policies, particularly with regard to sectoral decision making.

- Establishment of a specific Statistics Development Fund under the United Nations Trust Fund for African Development

ECA has ear-marked some activities for which funding could be considered:

(a) Needs Assessment and strategy development (b) Monitoring the implementation of the Plan of Action at national and regional levels (c) Management training for Directors of national statistical services (d) Improving methodologies for collection, processing, analysis and dissemination of data

The meeting could well add some other activities. In this connection K.Y Amoako said:

"As partners in statistical development, we welcome new proposals from you regarding the strengthening of statistical activities in Africa".

For further information and background documents, contact Ali Farah, Information Officer, Cabinet Office of the Executive Secretary, UN Economic Commission for Africa, P.O. Box 3001, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Tel: +251-1-51 60 27 (direct) or +251-1- 517200 Ext 33648 Fax: +251-1-51 22 33


LOAD-DATE: May 28, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


222 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Business and Finance;
Unctad Recognizes Zimbabwe's Performance


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - A United Nations trade body singled out Zimbabwe on Friday as one of several countries in sub-Sahara Africa which is benefiting from a liberalized economy by attracting huge inflows of Foreign Direct Investment.

Other countries enjoying renewed foreign investor interest included Botswana, Morocco, Nigeria and South Africa, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, or Unctad, said in its recently released directory on World Investment in Africa.

The agency said most of the foreign inflows, amounting to 4.5 billion U.S. dollars, had been mainly in the services and financial sector. Intra-regional investment was also rising on the back of increased realization of the benefits of increasing trade and economic cooperation. 

"Although still modest in absolute terms, FDI (Foreign Direct Investment) flows to Africa are responsible for a significant share of gross domestic capital formation and gross domestic product," Unctad said.

Foreign direct investment, it said, represented 4.8 percent of capital formation "approaching levels recorded in Asia and Western Europe" and 10 percent of GDP, compared with about 13 percent in other parts of the world.

Countries which had been traditionally open to foreign direct investment, such as Zimbabwe and Kenya, it said, had liberalized their regulatory frameworks to attract more investment.

To take advantage of investor interest, Unctad said many countries were concluding bilateral treaties on investment and trade. The agency said that this new phenomenon would benefit future investments.

Zimbabwe's investment drive, which started in earnest in 1991, has, so far, yielded several million-dollar projects in the manufacturing, tourism and mining sectors.

The single largest project, so far, is the 272-million-dollar platinum mine project near Harare, being implemented by Australian companies.

In addition, a Malaysian company and a local partner are preparing to implement the first phase of a 1.3-billion-dollar 15-year Industrial Park project 15 kilometers east of Harare.

In 1996 alone, foreign investment reached nearly 91 million dollars, expected to create at last 12,000 jobs over a five-year period.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


223 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Business and Finance;
Bank Lending Rates Could Rise In Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The chief executive of Barclays Bank Zimbabwe Ltd, Isaac Takawira, warned Friday that bank lending rates could rise again in the country.

He told the Zimbabwe Inter-Africa News Agency, or Ziana, that with money rates on an upward swing, and inflation expected to rise further, it was inevitable lending rates would be increased. 

Analysts warned this week that monetary policy would be have to be tightened further as evidence showed inflation targets set by the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe could not be met.

The major cause of the rise in inflation, other than the growth in money supply, was the expected spate of administered price hikes in the next few months. These would dash the reserve bank's inflation target of 19-21 percent by June.

Takawira said treasury bill rates were rising, so were other money market rates.

"This will inevitably affect lending rates," he said.

The treasury bills went to over 22 percent Thursday, he said, and had gone up by about 4 percent in the last week.

Commercial banks cut lending rates by about three percentage points six weeks ago following a similar reduction in the reserve bank's rediscount rate to 23.5 percent.

According to analysts, an increase in the rediscount rate would inevitably result in tightening of lending rates, further increasing the cost of money.

That alone would help curb demand for credit by the private sector, which in 1996 soared by 29 percent compared with the previous year.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 9, 1997


Zaire;
Kabila Agrees To Hold Second Round Of Talks


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

LUBUMBASHI, Zaire (PANA) - South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki said Friday his talks with Laurent Kabila, to prepare for a second round face-to- face discussions between the rebel leader and ailing Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko, were successful.

He told reporters at the Lubumbashi Airport that Kabila assured him that the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo (Zaire), which has almost captured the entire country, was willing to attend the talks proposed for Wednesday. 

However, the venue for the talks has not yet been agreed on by the warring parties. Nonetheless, Mbeki said that the meetings will take place on a South African naval ship, just as were the first face-to-face meeting between the two rivals.

Kabila and Mobutu met last week on the South African navy supply ship, the Outeniqua, under the chairmanship of South African President Nelson Mandela.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


225 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Zaire;
U.S. Company To Invest in Zaire


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

LUBUMBASHI, Zaire (PANA) - A United States mining company, America Mineral Fields Inc., says it has signed contracts of 21 billion U.S. dollars with the rebel Alliance Of Democratic Forces For the Liberation of Congo (Zaire), under which it will work with the local Gecamines Company to mine zinc at Kipushi and copper at Kolwezi in the southern Shaba region.

The deal was disclosed by the company's director of finance, Earl Young, who arrived in Lubumbashi on Friday, leading a group of international financiers interested in investing in Zaire's mining industry.

Young told PANA in Lubumbashi that the contract was part of his company's program to expand mining activity in Zaire and neighboring countries. 

He said America Mineral Fields Inc. had also won an exploration contract for minerals in the Solwezi area in north-western Zambia, close to the Zairian Kipushi zinc mine.

Young said that satellite pictures of the Zambian site indicated the presence of minerals, possibly copper, cobalt or zinc.

He added that if the Zambian reserves proved viable, the company would consider the launching of cross-border mining projects.

Young's group of financiers have come to examine further prospects of investment in Zaire's vast mineral industry, which includes copper and cobalt in Shaba, diamonds in Kasai and the Kivu provinces, and gold in various parts of the country.

These areas are now in the control of Kabila's forces, whose minister of mines, Florent Kambale Kabila Mututulo, told PANA Friday in Lubumbashi that the new government intended to woo foreign investment to the mining industry to help rehabilitate operations and increase production.

He said the country's mining industry was operating at only 10 percent capacity and that full production could be achieved within the next two years under the current re-investment program.

Kabila's alliance accuses Mobutu's regime of running down the country's mining industry which he allegedly used as a source of personal wealth.

Mututulo said the alliance had started compiling figures of mineral production in the country by the government-owned Gecamines and other companies.

Recently, Kabila sacked the Mobutu-appointed chief executive of Gecamines, as part of the program to resuscitate the country's mining industry.

Kabila's forces, who are fighting to remove Mobutu from 32 years of power, last week captured the southern Shaba region, the heart of Zaire's mining industry.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


226 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Ministers Endorse Role Of Information And Private Sector


BYLINE: UN Economic Commission for Africa (ECA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Addis Ababa - African Ministers responsible for economic and social development and planning ended a 5-day meeting at the headquarters of the Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) with a set of resolutions and a declaration on accelerating trade and investment in the region in which they strongly endorsed the role of information and the private sector in Africa's development.

The 'Declaration on Accelerating Trade and Investment in Africa' clearly sets out its purpose, saying: "We are convinced that trade and investment are essential components in any credible strategies to accelerate our countries' development and sustain high rates of economic growth".

The Declaration comes out strongly in favour of partnership with the private sector in general and Transnational Corporations (TNCs) in particular as a policy choice.

Broadly-based high rates of economic growth geared towards creating employment and generating rising incomes are recognized as essential components for poverty reduction and its eventual eradication. 

The Declaration stresses that to boost domestic savings and investment, attract private foreign capital transfers and expand trade with the rest of the world Africa must, among other things:

(a) change the negative perception of Africa as a high-risk place; (b) improve information flow on development in Africa; (c) modernize, expand and diversify production; (d) reduce the cost of establishing business; and (e) strengthen international competitiveness.

It takes the Uruguay Round Agreement in its stride by noting that it offers Africa both challenges and opportunities. It however goes on to point out that, though Africa has created a conducive environment for trade expansion with the rest of the world, protectionist policies on the part of others with regard to African agricultural, textile and clothing have frustrated that expansion.

Welcoming the debt-reduction initiative for highly indebted poor countries (HIPCs) recently proposed by the World Bank, and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) as a first step in the right direction, the Declaration calls for additional and more generous resources to "substantially reduce all Africa countries's debt stock". The cost of servicing external debt is estimated to have exceeded US$340 billion by the end of 1996.

The conference -- which met from 5 to 8 May -- came out decisively in favour of implementing the African Information Society Initiative (AISI), a framework adopted by ministers in 1996 to build Africa's national information and communications infrastructure as a part of a strategy to harness information and communication technologies towards development.

"The next step is for African governments in implementing aspects of AISI at national level," said Nancy Hafkin, ECA's AISI focal point. "We at ECA are going to be placing emphasis on action-oriented interventions and are here to work, with our partners, to assist African governments."

Key attention was given to the role information and communications technologies in promoting trade and investment in a major symposium -- organised by ECA together with the Global Information Infrastructure Commission (GIIC). The symposium was broadcast live by satellite on Multichoice DSTV by MNET Wednesday.

An executive summary of the GIIC Statement of Addis Ababa is attached below. A full version -- as well as the full text of the Declaration on Accelerating Trade and Investment in Africa -- is distributed under separate e-mail cover.

This and other press releases and background documents relating to the conference are available either by e-mail or post, or at the UN ECA Web site: www.un.org/depts/eca

UN ECA's African Information Society Initiative (AISI) home page is at: www. bellanet.org/partners/aisi, and it includes the full text of the AISI framework.

GIIC Statement of Addis Ababa - Executive Summary

The Global Information Infrastructure Commission (GIIC) strongly supports the forward looking thinking of the Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) in its call for active and on-going private sector participation in the implementation of the African Information Society Initiative (AISI).

As the leading intersectoral global private sector organization which seeks to actively involve the developing countries in the process of building the Information Society, the GIIC was pleased to contribute to the formulation, launch, coordination and dissemination of the AISI.

To further contribute to the success of the AISI, the GIIC proposes a set of principles that should guide the implementation of the AISI within each African country. This Brief Statement is drawn from a longer Policy Statement. The GIIC statement focuses on the following four points:

The Information Revolution is partially driven by information and communications technologies (ICTs) and is fundamentally important for all societies around the world; The ICT revolution is especially important for developing countries and their people; While a modern imperative for all countries, diffusing ICT effectively and equitably, is neither easy nor automatic; We support and encourage the ECA's commitment to adopt a concrete implementation plan for the AISI as plans for National Information and Communications Infrastructure (NICI) within each African country; We recommend that the implementation of the AISI should take place with as much cooperation as possible between the relevant societal sectors.

For further information please contact Peter da Costa, Cabinet Office of the Executive Secretary, UN ECA, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia Tel: +251-1-51-29-17 (direct) or 251-1-51-72-00 (main switchboard), Ext. 476 Fax: +251-1-51-22-33 E-Mail: ipspdc@harare.iafrica.com


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


227 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
ECA Declaration On Accelerating Trade And Investment


BYLINE: UN Economic Commission for Africa (ECA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1827 words


 

Addis Ababa - PREAMBLE 1. We, the African Ministers responsible for economic and social development and planning, meeting in Addis Ababa, during the thirty-second session of the Commission/twenty-third meeting of the Conference of Ministers from 5 to 8 May 1997,

guided by the principles and spirit embodied in the Charters of the United Nations and of the Organization of African Unity, the Abuja Treaty establishing the African Economic Community, the Cairo Plan of Action for Relaunching Africa's Development, the Marrakech Final Act of the Uruguay Round Agreement on Multilateral Trade Negotiations, UNCTAD IX Midrand Declaration "A Partnership for Growth and Development", and the Comprehensive and Integrated World Trade Organization (WTO) Plan of Action for the Least Developed Countries, endorse the resolutions and declaration adopted by the recently concluded Conference of African Ministers of Finance at its session of 31 March to 2 April 1997.

PURPOSE 2. 

We have taken stock of Africa's position within the emerging global economic system at the threshold of the twenty-first century. We have deliberated on the appropriate orientation of the development of our countries in the era of a liberalizing and integrating world economy, and the necessary measures that we need to implement in Africa at the level of government, with support from bilateral and multilateral development partners, and in full partnership with African and foreign private enterprise. We reaffirm that African countries assume the primary responsibility for restructuring their economies to the challenges and opportunities of a globalizing and liberalizing world economy.

TRADE INVESTMENT AND DEVELOPMENT

3. We are convinced that trade and investment are essential components in any credible strategies to accelerate our countries' development and sustain high rates of economic growth. We are also convinced that poverty, which constitutes the most serious problem facing African society today, can be reduced and eventually eradicated by sustained high rates of economic growth that is broad-based and geared to creating employment and generating rising incomes. This objective requires a sustained high rate of investment and production.

DEVELOPMENT RESOURCES

4. We are convinced that this requires considerable resources which can be obtained mainly from an increased rate of domestic savings (by households, private enterprises, and governments), supplemented by official development finance and foreign investment (foreign direct investment, portfolio funds, and finance tapped from international capital markets). We are concerned about the long-term declining trend of official development assistance (ODA) in spite of our economic restructuring efforts and continuing need of development resources. We deplore the marginalization of Africa, at a time when significant positive developments are taking place in our countries.

5. In the light of intensifying globalization, we realize that private local and foreign investment is destined to assume increasing importance. We also recognize the central importance of mobilizing domestic financial resources, to boost our domestic savings. Furthermore, our countries have created an environment conducive to expanding trade with the rest of the world. Unfortunately, these efforts have been frustrated by continuing protectionist practices hindering our countries' exports, particularly agricultural products, textiles and clothing, by our trading partners.

EXTERNAL DEBT BURDEN

6. The cost of servicing external debt which, for the continent as a whole, is estimated to have exceeded US$ 340 billion at the end of 1996, siphons away considerable resources which could have been productively invested in the development of Africa. We welcome the debt reduction initiative for the highly indebted poor countries (HIPCs Initiative) recently proposed by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF). This is a first step in the right direction. We are hopeful that it will be reinforced by additional more generous bilateral and multilateral measures to substantially reduce all African countries' debt stock.

TRANSNATIONAL CORPORATIONS AS PARTNERS

7. We believe that any fruitful and long-lasting business relationship must be built on the hallowed principles of equity, mutual responsibilities and mutual benefit. It is in this spirit that, in recent years, our countries have adopted new investment codes and instituted many economic reforms. Foreign partners who believe with us in these principles will make good on their investments and reap the expected dividends. In this regard, we invite transnational corporations to play their rightful role in securing the flow of foreign direct investment while respecting the principles adopted by our countries.

TRADE AND INVESTMENT: OPPORTUNITIES AND CHALLENGES

8. We recognize that boosting domestic savings, local and foreign investment, and the productivity of capital together constitute a real challenge. Regarding trade, the entry into force of the Uruguay Round Agreement, mandating significant cuts in tariffs on most tradeable products and limiting countries' recourse to non-tariff measures, offers Africa both opportunities as well as challenges. The thrust of the social, macroeconomic, sectoral, and trade policies that we are implementing in our countries is towards meeting these challenges and grasping the opportunities, so that our countries can realize the full potential of their natural comparative advantages in the world economy.

PREREQUISITES FOR EXPANDING TRADE AND INVESTMENT

9. We are aware that in order to achieve our goals (i.e., to boost domestic savings and investment, attract substantial private foreign capital transfers, and expand trade with the rest of the world) our countries must accomplish at least the following prerequisites:

(a) Changing the negative perception of Africa as a high-risk place;

(b) Improving information flow on developments in Africa;

(c) Modernizing, expanding and diversifying production;

(d) Reducing the cost of establishment and doing business;

(e) Strengthening international competitiveness;

(f) Striving for genuine regional economic integration; and

(g) Participating more effectively in the multilateral trading system.

POSITIVE POLICY TRENDS

10. We are convinced that the steps taken by our countries in each of the above areas will contribute to efficiency in our economies. The economic fundamentals are more solid today than they have been in decades. In a number of our countries, fiscal deficits have been reduced, the money supply has been disciplined, inflation is falling, currencies are finding their realistic levels guided by market forces, pressures on the current account have been reduced, economic recovery is under way, and the local private sector is resurgent. To that effect, the reforms undertaken and performances attained will be intensified.

AREAS FOR ENHANCED

11. We invite domestic and foreign investors to take advantage of the opportunities that have been created by the improved policy and economic environment in our countries.

12. We urge Africa's bilateral partners to continue to provide direct financial support, on concessional terms at increased levels, and to extend indirect support through tax incentives to their national investors participating in infrastructure development projects in Africa.

13. We trust that multilateral development finance institutions, notably the African Development Bank, the African Export-Import (AFREXIM) Bank and the World Bank, will continue to play an important role, not only in providing substantial financial resources, but also in providing technical assistance to our countries in carrying out analyses of profitability, risk, and environmental factors of projects, especially in infrastructures.

THE ROLE OF ECA

14. We request the ECA secretariat to identify issues crucial to accelerating trade and investment, and to come up with appropriate strategies, in collaboration with African Governments and leading African and global multilateral institutions, inter alia, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) and the World Trade Organization.

We recommend that emphasis be placed especially on practical strategies, and economic and social policy innovations, with particular emphasis on regional cooperation, public-private partnership, and international competitiveness, thereby pointing to new approaches to accelerate Africa's development process. ECA should also function as the clearing house for gathering and disseminating experiences and best practices from within Africa as well as from other regions.

For further information please contact Peter da Costa, Cabinet Office of the Executive Secretary, UN ECA, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia Tel: +251-1-51-29-17 (direct) or 251-1-51-72-00 (main switchboard), Ext. 476 Fax: +251-1-51-22-33 E-Mail: ipspdc@harare.iafrica.com


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


228 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Kenya;
'Reign Of Tyranny Must End' in Turkana District


BYLINE: African Faith and Justice Network (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Nairobi - Statement from the Kenya Episcopal Conference Catholic Justice and Peace Commission

As a church committed to truth, justice and the service of the Turkana people, we feel that we can no longer remain silent in the face of intimidation, violence, threats and imminent death meted out on Church personnel, Justice and Peace activists, potential politicians and innocent wananchi by the provincial administration and the M.P.s of Turkana North and Central.

What we are experiencing at the moment is a reign of tyranny and oppression that surpasses anything that we encountered in the days of one party rule. Let us clarify by highlighting some of the incidents that have taken place in the last six months that indicate the extent of the coercion that exists in Turkana District

-In October a Justice and Peace seminar was broken up by the police and the D.O. in Lokitaung, under instructions of the D.C., Mr Reuben Rotich.

-The same D.C. in public on Kenyatta Day demanded that the Diocesan Magazine, Sauti ya Jamii, should cease publication. 

-Church Adult Education teacher's in Loima Location have received written instructions on the orders of the D.C. to cease teaching. Their 'crime', according to the letter issued, was that they were teaching justice and peace. They were warned if they continued their classes they would be arrested.

-A voluntary catechist faces court charges of incitement for teaching the 1997 National Lenten Campaign in church in Lorengippi.

-Parishes have received written orders that they cannot hold seminars or meetings without licenses.

The people of Loarengak and Lokitaung have been told by their M.P. to beat any members of the Diocesan Justice and Peace program found in their areas and the same politician at different barazas on March 17th and 22nd called for the expulsion of some missionaries, claiming that the church had a plan to bring chaos and anarchy among the Turkana.

Seven separate incidents of armed robbery on church workers-four resulting in injury have taken place in Lodwar in 1997. All were reported to the police but no affirmative action has taken place. Complaints and reports over corruption in the distribution of famine relief food have been met with abuse and contempt by the administration." Threats made by the-Turkana North MP against the justice and Peace personnel led Bishop Mahon to write to the D.C. late last year. Again no acknowledgement of the complaint was received and the threats and intimidation have further increased.' However, the last straw for us was the incident of Tuesday, April 1 st, when two armed men dressed in police uniform attacked and beat two Dutch brothers.

Their aim this time was not to steal or plunder. Rather they came looking for Bishop Mahon. Fortunately they did not find him and ran away shooting when the alarm was raised.

We feel that the aim of that assault was to intimidate if not kill Bishop Mahon, who has been a constant thorn in the flesh of the local M.P.s and the local administration and is a man who is committed to justice and good governance.

The orchestrated campaign against the church and its people results from its commitment to civic education justice and the Gospel values of tolerance, freedom and the rights of God's people. The harassment and intimidation also comes from desperate politicians aided and abetted by a partisan and oppressive provincial administration.

If this type of tyranny is reaching such heights in April, we dread to think what it will be like by the time of elections. President Moi promised just this week that security would be guaranteed in this year elections.

However, we reiterate that we have no confidence in those entrusted with the responsibility for security in this district; either to protect church personnel or to bring fairness and impartiality to Turkana in this election year.

We wonder is it necessary that people die before appropriate action is taken.

From: The Catholic Church-Diocese of Lodwar Clergy, Sisters and Brothers. Signed by: Archbishop R. S. Ndingi Mwana a' Nzeki, Bishop Chairman, CATHOLIC JUSTICE AND PEACE COMMISSION.

Distributed by Africa Faith and Justice Network; P.O. Box 29378; Washington, D.C. 20017; Tel: 202 832 3412. Fax: 202 832 9051; email: afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


229 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
ANC RICHMOND COUNCILLOR ASSASSINATED


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Johannesburg - The ANC in KwaZulu Natal is shocked by the assassination of its Richmond Councillor, Mr Rodney van der Byl yesterday night. He was shot about eight times as he was going out of his house to take newspaper deliveries to Kokstad at around 12.15 a.m. in the night.

His car was found still running which rules out ordinary crime. Mr Van der Byl is one of the two ANC councillors who refused to be intimidated to resign as an ANC councillor recently. He and Mayor Ragavaloo remained loyal and irrepressible in the face of death. 

1. The ANC's assertion that Richmond has become a virtual concentration camp has been vindicated by this political assassination of Councillor Van der Byl.

2. That conditions are being created that the new Richmond Council must be determined not by vote but by a gun. The ANC will not allow that situation.

3. The police must explain what measures did they take to police the area and protect Mr Van der Byl and the Mayor when they clearly became targets of the Third Force for refusing to resign as ANC Councillors in the recent past.

4. The failure to police the area and to protect these two councillors vindicates the ANC's assertion that while elements of the Third Force are found in the security forces all over the country, in Greater Pietermaritzburg and the surrounding areas the Third Force is indeed in control of the police.

5. The ANC calls upon the Minister of Safety and Security, Sydney Mafumadi and National Police Commissioner, George Fivaz, to immediately set up a commission to investigate policing in and around Greater Pietermaritzburg and root out the Third Force in the region at the commanding level.

5. The Mayor of Richmond, Mr Ragavaloo and his family must be provided with 24-hour police security.

6. The ANC calls upon its supporters in Richmond to galvanise themselves and exercise maximum vigilance. The ANC also calls upon the people in the area, especially those who have been promised monies if they kill ANC leaders, to come to the fore and report that to ANC offices.

Issued by the ANC KwaZulu Natal Leadership. For further information, contact Dumisani Makhaye at 082 551 9192 or Dr Zweli Mkhize at 082 5553551. Date: 8 May 1997


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


230 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


United States and Africa;
Richardson Issues Statement from Paris


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Washington - Written statement by Bill Richardson, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations and President Clinton's special envoy to Zaire, issued May 8 in Paris:

Ten days ago, I went to Africa at the request of President Clinton because of his personal concern for the situation in Zaire and the impact of the war on its people and to Central Africa. This effort was undertaken to support the lead role taken by South Africa and the U.N. and OAU.

My first goal was to help bring the parties together. I met with the leaders in Zaire and in the region. Working with the Government of South Africa, under the inspiring leadership of President Nelson Mandela, we were able to secure face-to-face meetings between President Mobutu and Alliance leader Mr. Kabila aboard a South African naval vessel in Pointe-Noire, Congo. 

We hope that a dialogue for a peaceful resolution to the conflict has been established. We believe that there must be no military solution to the political and economic crisis in Zaire. Our long-standing goal has been a negotiated settlement. This should lead to an inclusive transitional government and fair and free elections. We pressed hard in all our meetings for a soft landing to the crisis, that is a peaceful transition of power avoiding further bloodshed in the country and chaos and violence in the capital.

The other reason I went to Zaire was to assess the dire humanitarian situation in eastern Zaire. In Kisangani I saw first-hand the suffering of children -- many of them orphans -- and adults as they struggled to return to their homes in Zaire and Rwanda. I pressed Mr. Kabila to permit full access for international aid organizations and the United Nations and condemned the abuses, deaths and murders of innocent civilians. Mr. Kabila assured me that international aid organizations and the U.N. would have adequate time to repatriate the refugees, that they would be given full access to the refugees and that those Alliance soldiers found guilty of abuses would be punished.

I was encouraged by meetings with Mr. Kabila as we discussed both the political crisis and the situation of refugees and displaced person and the future course Zaire must take.

I came to France -- our oldest ally -- because of her historic and important role in Africa to discuss where we should go in dealing with the crisis. We are both working to get the two sides in Zaire to cooperate in the talks mediated by the Government of South Africa and the U.N. and OAU and to agree on an end to the fighting and the establishment of an inclusive transitional arrangement that would lead to democratic elections and creation of a free market economy in short order.

The United States will continue to be involved because of the long-standing friendship between the people of the United States and the people of Africa. We share their desire for establishing a democratic Zaire that promotes tolerance, economic development and stability in the country and the region.

I would like to reemphasize what I told Mr. Kabila in Lubumbashi. An Alliance military victory is within reach. But the political future of Zaire is at risk. The citizens of Zaire, the international community and history will judge the Alliance on the decisions and actions taken in the coming days.

It is critical to avoid further bloodshed, especially in Kinshasa, and to work with South Africa and the United Nations and OAU Envoy Sahnoun for a negotiated, inclusive transitional arrangement, leading to democratic elections. It is important to cooperate with humanitarian agencies to deal with the critical situation in eastern Zaire.

I have urged Mobutu to delegate authority to negotiators to work with the South Africans for a peaceful transfer of authority.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
Agricultural training under threat due to budgetary cuts


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Nelspruit - The number of black students at the Lowveld Agricultural College had increased from two in 1995 to 72 this year, said Mpumalanga MEC for agriculture, January Masilela on Thursday.

He said 40 students received their higher certificates last year, including the college's first black student. 

Masilela warned, however, that the budget allocation for human resource development in his department had been cut by eight percent to R10,21 million this year.

"Agricultural training is, unfortunately, expensive," he said.

"To train and retrain people and equip them with the best knowledge and skills, we need to develop and expand.

"If this is not possible, it will eventually lead to stagnation and lower standards and quality of training," Masilela warned.

He said the current budget would only allow non-formal training facilities at Mzinti and Funda Mlimi to be maintained this year.

Last year, 124 non-formal short courses were held across the province, reaching more than 8 600 trainees, he said. .

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
Slack farmers won't get aid


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Nelspruit - Farmers who failed to maintain their infrastructure and take risk reduction measures would not receive disaster aid in future, warned Mpumalanga MEC for Agriculture, January Masilela, on Thursday.

He said his department had spent R27,1 million on aid to farmers who suffered flood damage during the February floods in the province last year, although it had only been granted R18,1 million by central government. 

"It was alarming to note that most of the claims were received from applicants who did not maintain their conservation structures or build their dams to specification," said Masilela.

He said 652 applications for assistance had been received by his department to repair cultivated land, water works, soil conservation works and other infrastructure damaged by flood waters.

"In future, disaster aid will only be considered in exceptional cases and farmers will be expected to reduce their vulnerability by practising sound and environmentally friendly farming practices," Masilela said. .

Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
Mpumulanga agriculture budget down


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Nelspruit - The Mpumalanga department of agriculture's budget for the 1996/97 year had decreased by 4,1 percent to R92,664 million, said MEC for Agriculture, January Masilela on Thursday.

Presenting his annual report and budget speech, Masilela said R25,015 million of the budget would be spent on agricultural extension, and R15, 761 million on veterinary services. 

"Mpumalanga, as far as its veterinary regulatory function is concerned, is the most important province in South Africa," Masilela explained.

He said Mpumalanga played a pivotal role in safeguarding the rest of the country by controlling foot-and-mouth disease and African swine fever which are endemic to the Lowveld.

He said agricultural extension services operated from 60 offices across the province where staff dealt with drought or flood relief, land potential assessments, and with beneficiaries of the government's land reform project.

"No wonder 26 percent of our budget is spent here," he said.

Masilela said R12, 761 million will be spent on agricultural engineering services such as the provision of engineering technology, while R10, 210 million will be spent on agricultural training.

A further R9,115 million will be spent on technology development, R7, 375 million on administrative support and R5,108 million on soil conservation.

He said spending 5,5 percent of the budget on soil conservation was, however, "not good enough" to sustain agricultural production. .

LANGUAGE: English

234 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
Secret negotiations between ANC & protesters


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Nelspruit - A large government delegation, led by safety & security minister Sydney Mufamadi, held secret negotiations with the Bushbuckridge Border Crisis Committee in Nelspruit on Wednesday in an attempt to defuse growing militancy in the region.

The negotiations at Arbor Park, aimed at getting the Crisis Committee to call off their campaign to have the area ceded from Northern Province to Mpumalanga, were however inconclusive.

Immediately after the meeting, another government office complex and timber yard was burnt by pro-Mpumalanga protesters at Greenvale and a third freight truck was torched by demonstrators on Thursday morning. 

The defiance campaign, which is about to enter its second week, was sparked off by the alleged failure of Constitutional Affairs minister Valli Moosa to address a rally on the issue on Worker's Day.

Police attempts to disperse almost 15 000 demonstrators after the rally led to a series of widespread protests including barricades on majors roads to the Kruger National Park, the torching of a police patrol van, a Home Affairs office complex, two large freight trucks and two government vehicles.

A number of shops in the area have also been looted.

ANC spokesman Ronnie Mamoepa refused to say why the meeting was secret or what it had achieved, insisting that "the ball is now in the Committee's court. It's up to them".

Crisis Committee secretary, Sizile Ndlovu, also refused to comment, insisting that it had been agreed that all statements would be made through Mamoepa.

African Eye News Service (South Africa) has, however, been able to confirm that the national ANC delegation headed by Minister Mufamadi also included environmental affairs deputy minister, Peter Mokaba, Communist Party secretary-general Charles Nqhakula and ANC executive committee member Nosiziwe Nghakule.

Mpumalanga's delegation was led by premier Mathews Phosa and included seven of his MECs, plus Mpumalanga's legislative chief whip Jackson Mthembu and the House's deputy speaker, Cynthia Maropeng.

The Northern Province delegation was headed by provincial ANC chairman George Mashamba and seven other senior provincial working committee members.

Sources reveal that Northern Province premier Ngoako Ramatlhodi was not present at the meeting.

Meanwhile, more than 6 000 protesters marched on the Mkhulu Police Station near Hazyview on Thursday afternoon, where a memorandum was handed to the station commander, Sam Shabangu.

Shabangu, who declined to give his rank, refused to release a copy of the memorandum to the press.

No incidents of violence or arrests were reported during the march. Bushbuckridge residents are also scheduled to meet at a rally at Paulianah Stadium in the town's CBD on Friday, possibly to discuss the Nelspruit negotiations.

Police spokesman Captain Thomas Ramatseba told African Eye News Service (South Africa) on Thursday night that police had managed to dismantle all remaining barricades on the region's roads and that the area was now "safe to travel through".


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


235 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
Breakdown of services imminent if key posts not filled


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Nelspruit - Ten percent of staff at the Mpumalanga department of agriculture accepted severance packages last year, resulting in vacancies in key areas which urgently needed to be filled, said MEC for agriculture, January Masilela, on Thursday.

Presenting his annual report for 1996/1997, Masilela said if the vacancies were not filled, there may be a breakdown in services.

"Key posts in management and communication have been filled, but the filling of vacancies in agricultural economics and soil conservation remains a problem," Masilela said. 

He said a more serious problem, however, was acquiring funds to fill the 400 approved vacant posts.

"To fill the 400 vacant posts...will cost more than R18 million - more than our total budget for 1997/98," he said.

Masilela said financial management had also been a major problem during the past year after a shortage of skilled staff led to the misallocation of expenditure and the incapacity to spend the allocated funds.

"A few cases of misappropriation of funds have been dealt with decisively," he added, stressing that the incidents were an "inherited" problem.

Despite the setbacks, Masilela said his province had also delivered a significant amount of services to the province during the past year.

He said services regarding mechanisation, soil conservation and irrigation engineering had been rendered to the farming community.

He said rural communities had also been given dipping facilities, dams, small scale irrigation systems and roads.

Rural farmers were also informed as to methods of watering stock and the necessary precautions to take regarding human consumption.

Small scale farmers were also trained with regards to debushing, and the installation and maintenance of community gardens.

"That is delivery," Masilela said.

He said it was important that farmers understood the importance of soil conservation, but said only 5,5 percent of the budget would be allocated to this division.

"This is just not good enough if we want to sustain agricultural production in this province," Masilela said.

LANGUAGE: English
