236 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
Commission hearing stalled after witnesses fail to arrive


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Nelspruit -The Moldenhauer Commission into Fraudulent Licenses had to postpone its scheduled hearings in Nelspruit on Thursday after none of the witnesses turned up.

All three scheduled witnesses, did however send last minute excuses to Commission chairman, chief magistrate Heinrich Moldenhauer, asking to be allowed to testify about their involvement in the control of licenses next week Monday.

Mpumalanga traffic director Henry Brazer, who was scheduled as the day's lead witness was again unable to appear because of an unspecified stress related ailment. 

Brazer also failed to appear before the Commission on Wednesday after he booked himself into the Nelspruit Private Hospital under a pseudonym just hours before his scheduled testimony at 14h00.

Hospital general manager Sarel van der Walt told African Eye News Service (South Africa) that Brazer had left strict instructions that no information about his medical condition, the name of his doctor or expected date of discharge should be released.

Conceding that it was unusual for patients to book in under pseudonym, Van der Walt said that Brazer believed this "anonymity" was the only way he would get the rest he needed.

Hospital staff confirmed that tight control was being kept on Brazer's room and added that his condition was definitely related to heart and thrombosis problems which were aggravated by stress.

Brazer's legal representative declined to comment, saying that he did not have time to speak with the press.

Brazer is the third senior official to be booked off work on sick leave just before their scheduled testimony at the Commission.

Provincial safety & security MEC Steve Mabona has been booked off work since Monday and, according to his office, will only be able to testify before the Commission next week Wednesday.

He is reportedly recovering from the unspecified stress related illness at home after being discharged from a Johannesburg clinic on Tuesday.

This is the second time that Mabona has been booked off sick for stress since investigations into the irregular issuing of a drivers and learners license to Parliamentary deputy speaker Baleka Mbete-Kgositsile began three week ago.

Despite having no constituency or other links with Mpumalanga, Mabona arranged for her to be specially tested for the two licenses in Delmas on October 1 last year. He has admitted to sending his state issue car and personal bodyguards to Johannesburg to fetch Mbete-Kgositsile.

Brazer, who was also reportedly booked off work at the time after a minor heart-attack, drove 350km from Nelspruit to Delmas to personally test Mbete- Kgositsile "as a sign of respect".

He is not however registered as a certified testing officer and also made errors while filling in the application forms - which were also from the incorrect area.

The third senior official who booked himself off work this week is departmental head, Advocate Stanley Soko, who has been accused by traffic officers of halting an internal investigation into the allegations.

According to Soko's office, he was admitted to the Pretoria East Hospital with stress related "back-ache". He is currently recovering at home in Pretoria and will be ready to testify next week.

The two other witnesses who failed to appear before the Commission on Thursday are unidentified residents of KwaNdebele thought to be connected to driving schools. They contacted the Commission after reading about the investigation in the Press.

"These two people told me that they were still compiling vital documentation for the Commission and could not testify before everything was ready," confirmed Commission chairman, chief magistrate Heinrich Moldenhauer.

The Commission will reconvene on Monday.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

237 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
Despite 15 million exam papers - not one leaked


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Nelspruit - Although 15 million copies of the matric examination paper were printed in Mpumalanga last year, not one paper was leaked, said Mpumalanga MEC for Education, David Mabuza, on Wednesday.

"Not only did we succeed in managing this process, but we were able to improve our overall matric pass rate by 6,3 percent," Mabuza told the provincial legislature during his budget speech. 

He said that this year, his department had made a special commitment to take the physically disabled into consideration when building schools.

"Although this will have serious financial implications, it is our hope that this legislature will support us in carrying these costs," Mabuza said.

"These people live with us in our communities and therefore there is no rationale why they are conspicuously absent in our schools, offices and even in this legislature," he said.

Mabuza said the previous government had also neglected development of black children until the age of nine.

He said four colleges in the province had thus started providing Early Childhood Development training for teachers from Grade 0 to Grade 3.

"Experts argue that the development of a child, especially their thinking capacity, is critical between the ages of 0 and nine," he said.

Mabuza also said that the issue of subsidising independent schools was still under discussion.

"Nevertheless, I need to state upfront that the previous funding levels which were higher than those applied in public schools will definitely have to change," he said. .

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


238 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
'Obnoxious apartheid remnants' removed from school curricula


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Nelspruit - The remnants of "crude" apartheid language and other "obnoxious" representations of content in past school curricula have been removed, said Mpumalanga MEC for Education, David Mabuza on Wednesday.

Presenting his budget speech to the Mpumalanga legislature, Mabuza said words such as "homelands" had been removed from all school curricula in the province. 

He said his department would introduce a new curriculum for Grade 1 and Grade 7 (Standard Five) at the beginning of next year as part of the national Curriculum 2005 programme.

He said the new curriculum would emphasise thinking and reasoning skills, as determined by the National Qualifications Framework.

"This will be followed by the introduction of a new curriculum in other grades, up to the year 2005," he said.

Mabuza said the new curriculum would also emphasise career guidance at schools.

"We cannot afford to have students choosing areas of learning that only guarantees them a place in the unemployment basket," he explained.

He said teachers would also be given additional training in Science and Economics so they were able to teach pupils marketable skills.

"At primary level, our Mpumalanga Primary School Initiative pilot project with the aid of the British Government Overseas Development Agency, which focuses on mathematics, science, technology and communication, is already underway," Mabuza said.

He said a mobile career guidance unit was also in operation and that several schools in the province had already received computers.

Mabuza warned that only 40 percent of residents in Mpumalanga were literate, which would impact on the economic growth rate of the province.

The province's Adult Basic Education Training project aimed at increasing literacy levels, he said. .


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


239 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Zaire;
Zaire Strife Ongoing


BYLINE: International Committee of the Red Cross


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

Geneva - Despite the expectation that Sunday's long-awaited direct meeting between President Mobutu and Mr. Kabila would be a move towards easing the plight of the many victims of Zaire's six-month old conflict, the situation is becoming more dramatic by the day.

Delegates from the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) based in Kinshasa, Kisangani, Goma, Bukavu, Uvira and Lubumbashi, are working with other humanitarian organizations to help alleviate the suffering of the local Zairian population and Rwandan refugees.

Kisangani Airbridge In Closing Stage

More than 3,700 displaced people had been repatriated from Kisangani to Goma and Bukavu, as of Friday, May 2. ICRC planes flew 31 rotations and UN organizations another six. 

Under a second repatriation operation started in Kindu, 440 of an estimated 1,200 internally displaced people had been flown back to Bukavu by Friday, May 2. The operation is being organized by a team of ICRC expatriates temporarily based in Kindu.

In Kalemie, five expatriates are currently assessing the number of internally displaced present in the area and trying to arrange transport for those trying to leave. To gain access to displaced persons outside Kalemie, two landcruisers had to be shipped to the town. Some 120 unaccompanied children have already been identified.

In Uvira, the stream of refugees and internally displaced returning from Kalemie, Fizi and Kigoma has slowed considerably. Food assistance to the returnees continues.

Support Services for Repatriation

In Kisangani, some 45 Zairian Red Cross volunteers and two ICRC nurses offered medical assistance to families waiting at the site there.

To restore family links disrupted by the conflict and to provide an additional incentive for internally displaced to return home, several thousand Red Cross messages have been sent to and from Kisangani and Kivu over the past four weeks.

In Bukavu, delegates have set up a tracing team at the airport itself: disembarking families are asked whether any family members are missing and, if so, they are referred to a center for unaccompanied children.

Over the past few weeks, the Red Cross message network in Kivu has been using the services of local radio stations and churches, which has helped the Red Cross respond rapidly to the increased demand for tracing services.

As far as relief assistance is concerned, internally displaced have been assisted with food on disembarking. Resettlement kits will be distributed once beneficiaries have been registered.

Support for Rwandan Refugees

The ICRC remains highly preoccupied by the desperate plight of the Rwandan refugees in Zaire.

In Kisangani, 185 Zairian Red Cross volunteers are fully supported and coordinated by the ICRC to carry out food and non-food distributions to Rwandan refugees. They are working in close coordination with other humanitarian organizations.

Following reports that some 7,000 Rwandan refugees are traveling westward, from the area around Mbandaka, down the Zaire river, the delegation in Kinshasa has organized reconnaissance flights to locate the refugee groups.

Preparations in Kinshasa & Brazzaville

In cooperation with the Zairian Red Cross, priority has been given to emergency preparedness.

Throughout the 24 districts of Kinshasa, Zairian Red Cross first aid teams will be on standby, prepared to help the wounded and the sick and to evacuate the most seriously injured to one of eight reference hospitals.

In total, some 2,700 Red Cross volunteers, most of them specially trained, are ready to respond to medical emergencies.

Medical delegates have evaluated the health structures in Kinshasa and an inventory was drawn up to provide them with the right medical material, should the need arise.

Relief distributions in Kinshasa will be carried out by Zairian Red Cross volunteers, with technical and material support from the ICRC.

As of today (May 7), the Zairian Red Cross will start distributing food and non-food relief to some 16,000 people; among them internally displaced persons recently arrived in Kinshasa, as well as to hospitals, prisons, orphanages and other institutions throughout the capital.

To minimize the risk of a cholera epidemic, increasingly likely as the influx of internally displaced further raises population density in the city, ICRC supported clean-up and hygiene campaigns have been stepped up in markets and other public places. Water treatment facilities of the state water company have been assessed and measures taken to provide assistance if necessary.

The ICRC in Brazzaville has been reinforced with personnel and logistics and has prepared emergency stocks of food and non-food assistance, enough for 5,000 families for one month.

Ongoing activities in Kivu and Shaba

In Kivu, medical and tracing activities continue, although they have recently been hampered by increasing insecurity around Goma and Bukavu.

Water and sanitation delegates, who have so far concentrated mainly on water treatment plants in the main centers (Goma, Bukavu, Uvira, Kisangani), will now shift their attention to smaller towns, particularly in the north (Bunia, Isiro).


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


240 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
Groups Seek Release of Court Martial Proceedings


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Windhoek - The Freedom of Expression Institute (FXI) and the Mail and Guardian (M&G) newspaper (M&G) have appealed to the Cape Town High Court to make public the proceedings of a court marshal involving two soldiers charged with leaking "sensitive information" and accusing their superior of racism.

The M&G reports that the two soldiers, staff sergeant Herman Phieffer and corporal Desmod Booysen, were court marshaled for accusing their commanding officer Colonel Pat McLoughlin of racism during investigations by a military intelligence officer into allegations of arms smuggling in the Western Cape.

Coordinator of the FXI's Defence Fund, Alec Kuhn, told MISA May 8, the case would involve among others, challenging the constitutionality of the South African Defence Forces Act and the Protection of Information Act, the provision of which were invoked by the court marshal to have the hearings in camera. The two organisations argue hearing of the case in camera would deny the accused a fair trial. "This is the first known case of challenging the Defence Forces Act and the Protection of Information Act with regards to court marshals," she told MISA. 

An application on April 7 by FXI and M&G to have the proceedings heard in public was denied by the court marshal on the grounds that the two had no " locus standi" or right to make such an application before it. Kuhn said the whole case bordered on the right to free expression by the soldiers, including the right of the public to have access to court marshal proceedings.

And the lawyer representing FXI and M&G, Karin Norval, told MISA the two organisations want the hearings to be made public because this was a constitutional right of the accused persons; besides, the case had generated a lot of public interest. "We want public hearings because we believe the accused are entitled to that," she said. The application is likely to be heard in June, meanwhile, the proceedings of the court marshal have been suspended pending the outcome of the appeal.

For further information, contact David Nthengwe, researcher, Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), Private Bag 13386, Windhoek, Namibia Tel. +264 61 232975, Fax. 248016 e-mail: research@ingrid.misa.org.na


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


241 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Swaziland;
Union Charges Interference At Swazi TV


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Windhoek - The Swaziland Media and Printing Allied Workers Union (SMEPAWU) claims that Swazi Television (STV) failed to cover Labour Day celebrations in Mhlambanyatsi area due to "possible political interference."

SMEPAWU president Lwazi Hlophe told MISA May 7, it was strange that STV failed to cover the event when there had been earlier indications that it would be covered. "I spoke to the news editor on the eve of Labour Day and he assured me that he would personally cover the May 1 celebrations after finishing a recording with the minister of information, Muntu Mswane," Hlope told MISA adding: "I don't know what happened later, whether the minister told the editor not to go, or the editor decided this on his own."

STV management has, however, denied this. STV acting manager Mike Cornwell told MISA the failure to cover the event was due to the Labour Day holiday itself. "Neither daily newspaper was published on May 1 and do not publish on any public holiday... whereas STV journalists generally fill the news gap left by the print media. Workers Day seemed an appropriate public holiday to allow them (time off). At STV we do not have a large news department and the few who man it work long shifts and enjoy few privileges," Cornwell explained. 

Cornwell further denied May 4 press reports quoting him as blaming some journalists for the failure to cover the event. "I was misquoted when the Times of Swaziland said I did not know where our journalists were. I knew they were at the Labour Day celebrations and were attending as workers as is their right to do so," he said.

However, in February this year, Swaziland cabinet ordered a blanket ban of the state-controlled radio and television broadcasters from covering the country-wide strike. The ban had reportedly been effected under Section 12 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Act, 1997, which bans all materials likely to "incite the public against the government".

While workers at the television station told MISA that on January 22 and February 5, live talk show programmes related to the labour strike were prevented from being broadcast on the Swazi Television.

Meanwhile, on April 21 the Swaziland government announced it was in the process of designing an editorial policy for all government-controlled media. However, the media said that government's statement was coming barely after reports that authorities criticised Swazi Television for its full coverage of opposition Swaziland Democratic Alliance (SDA) demonstrations. The SDA went on a demonstration on April 12 against the 1973 Proclamation banning free political activity. April 12 marked 24 years of the King Sobhuza 1973 Decree which effectively nullified the 1968 Constitution as well as free political activity and the right to free expression.

BACKGROUND

Swaziland is a southern African Kingdom which has to date resisted political reforms and has been widely reluctant to introduce a written constitution. The royal proclamation in April, 1973 by King Sobhuza II annulled the 1968 Constitution. The Decree effectively outlawed party politics and annulled the Bill of Rights contained in the 1968 Constitution which included the right to free expression.

Traditionally, the King rules by the King Sobhuza 1973 Decree which does not provide for freedom of the press and the right to free speech. On July 26 last year, however, King Mswati III appointed the first ever Constitutional Draft Committee following calls from media workers, opposition parties, human rights organisations and labour unions for a written constitution to be re- introduced.

Progress towards drafting the constitution, however, has been retarded by a lack of political will on the part of Swaziland authorities.

For further information, contact David Nthengwe, researcher, Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), Private Bag 13386, Windhoek, Namibia Tel. +264 61 232975, Fax. 248016 e-mail: research@ingrid.misa.org.na


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


242 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
W Cape Nats may yet have to split, says Kriel


BYLINE: Clive Sawyer and William-Mervin Gumede, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Cape Town - The National Party in the Western Cape is not yet planning to go it alone, although a split is one of its options, says Hernus Kriel, the NP provincial leader and premier.

Speaking as cracks in the party widened between his hardline faction and NP verligtes under Gauteng party leader Roelf Meyer, Mr Kriel told the Cape Town Press Club yesterday he did not believe the province should leave mainstream South African politics.

"But if things go very wrong in the NP, it will have to split," he said. 

Commenting on the disbanding of the NP task force, led by Mr Meyer, to investigate the formation of a new political movement, he said Mr Meyer had acted outside the mandate NP leader F W de Klerk had given him.

Rejecting accusations that he was "verkramp", Mr Kriel - who described himself as "a full-blown liberal" - said the Western Cape NP fully supported the sacking of Mr Meyer and his task team.

He said he and Mr Meyer shared the same goals to realign political parties, but their methods differed.

He believed a wide-ranging political reorientation was necessary across the country, involving not just the NP but the Democrats, Freedom Front "and "the ANC-SA Communist Party-Cosatu alliance".

People who shared ideas and value systems would have to be brought together, he said. Meanwhile Mpumalanga NP leader David Malatsi, the first black provincial head of the party, who was part of Mr Meyer's task team, said yesterday he accepted Mr De Klerk's decision to scrap it.

But retired minister Pik Botha told a Cape Argus correspondent in Pretoria the NP had no future and should disband if it wanted to have any hope of opposing the African National Congress.

Mr Meyer will seek guidance on his own political options from his Gauteng head council on May 17, as the party's future for the moment lies in the hands of his Gauteng allies.

One is to lead like-minded Nats out of the party into a quest for a new home; the other is to challenge Mr De Klerk for the leadership.

Even the second option would be sure to result in a bruising battle ending in defections from either the old guard or Mr Meyer's supporters, depending on the outcome of a leadership contest.

But the first option, should Mr Meyer quit as an MP, with other Nationalists following him out of the party, would mean exile from mainstream parliamentary politics because of the bar on MPs keeping their seats if they change party allegiance. Mr Meyer will spend the days ahead in consultations with colleagues in Gauteng.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
That ding-dong with Durban (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Cape Town - Tourism authorities in Cape Town and Durban have been at daggers drawn over comments by a Satour official on the respective merits of the cities

We hope that readers have enjoyed reading as much as we have enjoyed reporting in the Cape Argus the recent to-do regarding the relative merits of Durban and Cape Town as venues for an international tourism indaba.

It's been welcome respite from the more serious and dour social issues which fill our lives to be able to give voice to our beloved city's attractions. It's also nice to be on the side that's winning palpably. 

The exchanges were sparked by a comment - with which citizens of the Peninsula could only agree enthusiastically - by Satour acting chief executive Reg Swart. He suggested delegates to the tourism conference being run in Durban would have preferred, given the choice, to be in Cape Town.

This did not go down too well on the Indian Ocean side. Reported a Durban newspaper: the city's "marketing bosses are seething". A stung Peter Bendheim, Durban metro communications officer, offered this opinion: "It (Durban) is South Africa's only truly African city. In Cape Town, delegates might as well be in Europe, with a pretty mountain in the background."

Well. We Africans who live in the shadow of that pretty mountain are getting fairly tired of this oft-repeated "Cape Town is out of Africa" argument which one hears constantly from people who do not have the good fortune to live in this part of the continent. Africa is made up of countries and cities of unimaginable variety. None is more or less quintessentially African than another.

But we understand the Durban sulk, and promise faithfully to get to work on our conference facilities - if only to ensure that future tourism delegates from Durban can fully enjoy a spell under the spell of the "pretty mountain".


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


244 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Liz McGrath: rich, famous and royal visit our woman of the world


BYLINE: David Yutar, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1134 words


 

Cape Town - "Dear Ms McGrath, congratulations on your selection by the National Foundation for Women Business Owners (NFWBO) as one of the 'Women to Watch'."

Chatting over scones and cream on a dreamy autumn day in the exquisite gardens of the Cellars-Hohenort hotel, this hotelier extraordinary with the Midas touch recalls her surprise on reading a letter from France that began thus in March this year.

"It hit me quite between the eyes as I wasn't expecting it. At first I thought it must be a hoax as I couldn't believe anyone would be interested in us," Liz said. 

NFWBO is a non-profit research and leadership development foundation whose mission is to strengthen women who own businesses and their enterprises throughout the world.

For the first time, the foundation has identified 50 leading women entrepreneurs of the world and 10 upwardly mobile "Women to Watch".

Staying at two of Paris's greatest hotels, the De Ville and the Hotel de Crillon, the women were hosted by the mayor of Paris and feted as special guests. They also visited the fashion houses of Hermes, Lanvin and Christian Dior.

The 50 Leading Women Entrepreneurs of the World that were identified represent 23 countries and collectively $139-billion in annual sales.

The 10 Women to Watch represent nine countries - Brazil, Canada, Greece, Japan, Malaysia, Poland, Scotland, South Africa and Britain - and collectively generate more than $209-million in annual sales, while employing more than 8 000 people.

"The first thing we did when we got to Paris was to say 'How did you find us?' " says Liz.

"Of course we did have to give our turnovers, which was rather frightening because when mine was translated into dollars it was peanuts compared with some of the others. I was a junior, junior and I was very honoured. It was like being in fairyland and, of course, I felt proud to be a South African and to represent my country. I have always been an addicted builder, decorator and gardener. Owning a hotel feeds my addictions."

It has also fed her company's profits, which have grown from R5-million in 1992 to R17,8-million last year and has seen its employees double to 345.

When her husband died in 1985, Liz felt the only way to find meaning in her life was to devote herself to what, until then, had been one of her passionate hobbies.

She bought the virtually derelict but superbly situated one-star Plettenberg Hotel (formerly the Lookout overlooking the famous beach) and within no time at all had transformed it into a five-star establishment where the world's rich and famous could enjoy one of the most glorious views in the world.

Next Liz purchased the Cellars Country House, a nine-room guesthouse in the forests of Constantia, and likewise turned it into one of Cape Town's most exclusive country house hotels.

"I'm not a feminist but I'm starting to get a bit that way, because every one of these women had the same experience as I did - the banks and people they had to work with didn't believe they could do it."

"I had deputations coming to me to tell me to stop it and to settle back and enjoy my life. I started the Plettenberg at a time when we were in the middle of apartheid, when we didn't have all that tourism, but I had a vision of turning a dump that my husband and I bought into something worthwhile," said Liz.

Having visited more than 50 Relais & Chateaux hotels while travelling with her husband, she had a good idea of what was being done overseas and knew how to adapt it to South African conditions.

Although English by birth and in manner, Liz is passionately pro-South African.

"We live in paradise. I was born in England, and only came to South Africa on holiday. When I met my husband-to-be, I decided to stay. That's when I became a South African and a passionate one. From the minute I arrived I loved it."

Liz's husband was himself an immensely successful businessman - he was Gallo Africa chairman and director of the Premier Group. But she took no part in the business. What Liz has learnt she has learnt without any training.

"When I started I couldn't read a balance sheet and I couldn't do a budget. I just learnt because I had to and I was determined to because I wasn't going to let anyone else do it for me. I pinch myself sometimes and think how crazy because I wasn't trained."

Liz says she always believed that South African tourism would take off.

"If you've got a country like this people must come and see it."

Who have been some of the more interesting guests?

Queen Elizabeth's entourage stayed at the Cellars-Hohenort during her visit, her ladies in waiting and even the footmen from Buckingham Palace.

The King and Queen of Sweden stayed incognito and Zaire's Mobutu Sese Seko was a guest too.

One of Liz's favourites was Sir Alfred Beit, after whose ancestors Beit Bridge, which links South Africa and Zimbabwe across the Limpopo River, was named.

"He asked whether he could stay for three weeks and I thought 'Oh no, he's going to be too difficult' and tried to dissuade him, and three months later when he and his wife left we were all standing here with tears running down our cheeks."


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
Malan risks civil action over SADF raids - Boraine


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Cape Town - Magnus Malan may have laid himself open to civil claims for damages from victims of SA Defence Force cross-border raids and internal operations in which innocent civilians died, Truth Commission deputy chairman Alex Boraine warned today.

He called on General Malan to apply for amnesty "even at this 11th hour" - the deadline for amnesty applications is midnight tomorrow - for the sake of reconciliation in the country and in his own interest.

Dr Boraine's remarks follow a statement by General Malan after his voluntary testimony to the Truth Commission in Cape Town this week, saying he stood by his decision not to apply for amnesty. 

Dr Boraine told the Cape Argus today there were two reasons why he believed General Malan should apply for amnesty.

The first was because the former defence minister had told the commission he had agreed to testify in order to further the cause of reconciliation.

"He played a dominant role as head of the SADF and as minister in the implementation of a policy that damaged and destroyed many people, both in South Africa and in the surrounding countries."

General Malan had also publicly acknowledged he had given orders for raids and had accepted responsibility for the killing of innocent civilians by soldiers under his command.

"Violations of fundamental human rights were committed by the SADF and in the final analysis he was responsible they were his orders," Dr Boraine said.

"In my opinion he puts himself at risk of possible civil claims from victims and their relatives of military manoeuvres, both inside the country and out.

"So he should seek amnesty both in terms of his own commitment to reconciliation, and in his own self-interest."

n Former state president P W Botha has not yet replied to a comprehensive set of questions by the commission, but his attorney told Dr Boraine this week he and Mr Botha were working "flat out" on the submission, which was a " huge undertaking".

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
New plan to curb money laundering


BYLINE: Alide Dasnois, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Cape Town - Banks, attorneys, stockbrokers and others could soon have to report all transactions over R50 000 or R100 000 to a new Financial Intelligence Centre, in terms of moves by the authorities to curb money laundering.

Measures under consideration to tackle the spreading evil of money laundering include the creation of a unit with powers to investigate a range of people and institutions including banks, attorneys, insurance brokers, estate agents, coin and bullion dealers and accountants, according to Reserve Bank official Charles van Staden.

In a speech to the International Forensic Conference in the Waterfront yesterday, Mr Van Staden said a draft Money Laundering Control Bill, as revised by the Law Commission, was being considered by the Department of Finance. 

The bill suggested the creation of a Financial Intelligence Centre, which could be housed in the Department of Finance, the Reserve Bank, or be a separate entity, with powers similar to those of the Office for Serious Economic Offences.

Banks, attorneys, brokers, traders, estate agents, stockbrokers, casino managers, coin and Krugerrand dealers, accountants, stokvel directors and other "accountable institutions" would be obliged to report to the centre details of any transaction involving cash above a set limit.

Mr Van Staden said the threshold had not yet been set but "one can safely assume that it would be between R50 000 and R100 000".

In the United States, cash transactions from $10 000 had to be reported, he said, and the US equivalent of the proposed Financial Intelligence Centre processed 11,5 million deals a year.

"As a threshold-based reporting system is automatic, it leaves less scope for corruption and errors of judgment," Mr Van Staden said. Transactions which might appear innocent when seen in isolation could be shown to warrant investigation when seen as part of the broader picture.

Institutions would also have to report all international electronic fund transfers and cross border cash transfers, as well as all "suspicious transactions", within a maximum of 10 days.

The obligation to report would override any duty of secrecy to the customer or client, and anyone making such a report would be protected by law from any breach of confidentiality, Mr Van Staden said.

The Financial Intelligence Centre would not only collect and analyse information and pass it on to the relevant investigating authority, but could also conduct its own investigations into money laundering. The director of the centre would be able to demand access to records and could order an institution to suspend a deal.

Mr Van Staden quoted international figures suggesting that in 1990 nearly US $233 million in drug money was available daily for laundering around the world.

In South Africa alone there were more than 278 international crime syndicates operating and the country was increasingly seen as a convenient place to market and transit drugs.

So far banks had been the main agents for "washing" and recycling illegally acquired wealth, but non-banking institutions were likely to be used more and more, he said.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


247 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
Cash for kids: how much is enough?


BYLINE: Jenny Viall, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1814 words


 

Cape Town - Child maintenance grants from the State are the first line of defence against poverty and malnutrition for many people.

In South Africa an estimated 14,3-million children under the age of 15 live in poverty, of whom only 349 692 get maintenance grants.

Administrative barriers and lack of information have severely restricted access to the grants and the system clearly needs to be changed.

Welfare Minister Geraldine Fraser-Moleketi says the new benefit system is premised on the need to de-racialise government policies. "We have a moral and constitutional obligation to extend benefits to those people who have not had access to public assistance in the past." 

Everyone agrees with that, but not with the proposals.

The new system recommends that the primary caregiver gets a flat rate benefit of R75 a month per child under six. This payment will be subject to a means test (still to be determined). Ms Fraser-Moleketi has said she hopes to reach three million of the 5,1-million children under six by 2005.

The present maintenance system gives a parent allowance of R430 (which falls away under the new system) and a child allowance of R135 for up to two children under 18 years old. These grants will be phased out over five years.

The proposed new system, based on recommendations by the Lund Committee on child and family support, has met with opposition from the Non-Governmental Organisations Coalition, Cosatu, church groups, human rights groups and the Gender Commission.

They say the grant is too little and too limited and will have disastrous consequences for the most vulnerable members of society: children living in poverty.

They claim there has been inadequate consultation on the new system, saying the Lund Committee did not call for representations from civil society before the report was published in August 1996.

The Cabinet accepted the recommendations in March this year before the portfolio committee on welfare had the chance to discuss or hold public hearings on the recommendations. In April, when the portfolio committee did hear from civil society, warnings were sounded that the recommendations could seriously damage the welfare of children in South Africa.

Mrs Fraser-Moleketi responded last week by saying there was no turning back. "The new child support benefit will become a reality," she said.

While government argues that it cannot afford to spend more than the R2- billion it will cost to implement payouts for children, critics argue that it cannot afford not to.

Conrad Barberton of Idasa's poverty monitoring service said debate on the proposals had tended to focus almost entirely on what the new system was likely to cost the fiscus in terms of actual expenditure.

"What it hasn't done is to look in depth at negative consequences of the proposal," he said. "Fiscal constraint is used to defend choices, but we need to look at other kinds of costs and consequences."

One of these is the high infant mortality rates in South Africa.

"A decent system of social security will not be able to solve this but it could go some way to averting its worst consequences," Mr Barberton said.

UWC's Community Rehabilitation Project has said it is unrealistic for a child to survive on R75 a month, a sentiment echoed by many organisations. The household subsistence level for a low-income household in Cape Town is R96,83 a month, excluding rent and transport (calculated by University of Port Elizabeth Institute for Development Planning).

The new system will have a disastrous effect on women and children from impoverished communities, the New Women's Movement has said. "The minister has failed to reprioritise women and children's needs by reviewing the budget. She is determined to go ahead with the Cabinet decisions despite fierce opposition from women who live in dire poverty."

The Women on Farms project warned that while self-reliance should be encouraged, many mothers would not be able to provide for their children on R75 a month.

Long-term impacts on children included malnutrition, which impaired a child's mental development and caused stunting. This in turn increased the burden on the health system and mental institutions, reduced the effectiveness of education spending, and reduced the future productivity of the labour force.

Other negative impacts were an increase in child abuse due to poor economic conditions at home, which increased the burden on policing and the judicial system and increased social welfare costs.

Kumi Naidoo, executive director of the NGO Coalition, said that until there was an effective cross-departmental strategy to combat poverty, the new proposals would exacerbate problems of child labour, prostitution and crime.

"Is it not more cost-effective to invest government resources in social security for children than to spend resources on dealing with the consequences of child poverty?" said Mr Barberton.

The decision on the child benefit system has been based on fiscal constraints - what the country can afford - and the minister has taken a conservative approach, one she says is fiscally sustainable in both medium and long term.

But critics say child maintenance grants should be based not only on what the Government says it can afford, but on what children need.

Mr Barberton said the Government had allocated little more than a "couple of crumbs" of the budget cake to address child poverty.

"If the department was serious about asking for an adequate slice of the budget cake it would have taken these costs into consideration, and worked out the costs of not implementing an adequate system. It has not done that," he said.

"It is assumed that the Government cannot afford to spend more than R2- billion on social security for children. No one - the Lund committee, the minister of welfare or the department - has explained why financial constraints on social security for children should be R2-billion and not more. Are these real or self-imposed?" said Mr Barberton.

In the 1997/98 Budget only 0,6 percent of the Budget was allocated to social security for children.

A third of the Budget, at least R66-billion, was "top-sliced" for priority spending on interest on government debt, improvements in civil servants' service conditions, carry-through costs for social pensions, RDP projects and commitment to the housing programme, among others.

"The Budget Council, which consists almost entirely of men, did not regard providing social security for children to be sufficiently crucial to include in the priority category of expenditures," said Mr Barberton.

Critics ask whether the new child maintenance system is being used to limit government spending on social security for children. Studies have shown that because of a lack of administrative capacity, the proposals will lead to a huge reduction in overall spending on child and family support.

Administrative barriers and lack of information continue to be a problem in allocating grants, with rural areas worse off than urban areas.

"The Lund report did not address problems of administration in any detail," said Mr Barberton, "and this is the greatest constraint on access to the present system of state maintenance grants or any new system.

"Unless it's improved drastically and equally spread over provinces, take- up of new grants will be the same as the old system.

"Every aspect of the present cabinet recommendations is aimed at limiting expenditure to the absolute minimum without the system becoming a sick joke."

The Lund Commission was established because the Government was concerned about the future affordability of grants.

The commission came up with projected figures of between R5-million and R20- million a year if equitable access was to be achieved.

"These figures are so divergent. To use them as the basis of drastic policy change is ridiculous, suggesting other motives," said Mr Barberton.

"The argument that the present system (of R135 a month per child) is fiscally unsustainable is based on two very optimistic and unrealistic assumptions, namely a perfect administration system and take-up rates of 100 percent. These are unheard of anywhere in the world."

Both Cosatu and the NGO Coalition have asked Mrs Fraser-Moleketi to delay implementation of the proposals and review the budget allocation to child support.

The NGO Coalition has given the minister until June 10 to come up with revised proposals or face action.

Mrs Fraser-Moleketi, however, is standing firm. She has not given any indication that she is prepared to move on the proposals and at a conference organised by the Ecumenical Foundation of Southern Africa this week she said: "There will be a time when government must take decisions that are not popular and civil society will engage the state.

"It's a necessary creative tension which will only strengthen our democracy and we need to respect arguments forwarded from either side."


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 9, 1997


Sports - General;
R750-m GDP boost seen for Cape


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Cape Town - Olympic-related transport spending of R250-million has the potential to raise the Western Cape's gross domestic product by up to R750- million and create considerable employment.

This was spelled out yesterday at a conference at the Waterfront. Contractors are to start work on 49 priority projects across the metropolitan area by September. They will be completed whether or not the bid succeeds.

The investment of R250-million - which is coupled with supplemental projects costing a further R233-million - has been approved by the treasury.

Rob Vos, technical director of the Southern African Bitumen Association (Sabita), told the Bituminous Materials Liaison Committee meeting yesterday that research "repeatedly underlined the pivotal role of roads in generating short-term employment and long-term economic growth".

"This in turn leads directly to social reconstruction because people have lower transport costs, cheaper consumer goods, easier access to schools, recreation facilities, jobs and business opportunities, and entrepreneurs are encouraged to expand into areas which to date have been commercially sterile," said Mr Vos.

"One of our findings is that a one percent growth in infrastructure value, particularly on the road network, results in a net increase in gross domestic product of between 2 and 3 percent.

"In this scenario the impact of the metropolitan transport planning priority projects on the Western Cape economy must be obvious."

He said the priority projects, most of which were in the public transport network, had been designed to provide economic links between economic hubs and dormitory towns left over from the apartheid era.

They included key road, rail and interchange projects. "Whether or not the Olympic bid is successful, its kick-start value in setting this process in motion will have inestimable benefits for the economy and the people of the Western Cape," he said.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
Cape Town's shame - Death in a wheelbarrow


BYLINE: Jenny Viall, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Cape Town - A Khayelitsha man has described his anguish as he pushed his dying wife in a wheelbarrow from one clinic to another in a vain bid to save her life.

Thobeka Madayi died during the heartbreak journey after nobody would help her husband, Vuyani Magazi, call an ambulance this week.

Infuriated by what they regard as appalling medical services in Cape Town's townships, residents threatened to stone the cars of nurses leaving a clinic. 

Health authorities regretted that no ambulance was called, saying the service was overloaded by hoaxes and emergencies.

But township residents say they have had enough of long queues and rude staff at overcrowded clinics.

Mr Magazi said he walked to the Nolungile Clinic in Khayelitsha on Wednesday to ask for transport for his wife. Staff told him he would have to fetch her.

He found a wheelbarrow and pushed her to the clinic, where, he said, he was turned away because it was closing for the day.

However, Edmund Michaels, who heads the Community Health Services Organisation, said Ms Madayi was seen by a doctor about 3.45pm. "It was felt that she was chronically terminally ill and that nothing could be done for her at the day hospital," Dr Michaels said.

The doctor on duty had told Mr Magazi he could wait for an ambulance which was coming to fetch other people.

Because ambulances could take a long time to arrive, the doctor had said Mr Magazi could otherwise take her to the larger Site B clinic, which has a 24- hour service and where an ambulance might arrive sooner.

While Mr Magazi was wheeling his wife there she died in the wheelbarrow. He stood stunned in the street and a crowd soon gathered. When police arrived and went to the Nolungile Clinic, they were told there was nothing staff could do as the woman had not died there. And only when a bystander phoned the emergency police number was the body taken away.

Anne Brand, director of the Western Cape's Health Support Systems, said the incident was "unfortunate".

"We really shouldn't be in this position where patients are dying on the street. This would be the exception rather than the rule. I'm sorry the day hospital didn't call an ambulance to take the woman directly to hospital."

Dr Brand said the ambulance service was trying to give the best service possible but was having to weigh priorities.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 9, 1997


Ethiopia;
Prosecution witnesses testify against Derg Officials


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Witnesses at the trial of former Derg officials yesterday testified that they had seen the torture and killings of members of the Ethiopian Peoples Revolutionary Party (EPRP) in 1997.

Corporal Zeleke Desta, and Ato Gebru Haile-Michael and Ato Zewde Mezgebu who were serving as security personnel in 1977 told the First Criminal Bench of the federal High Court that they had seen the dead bodies of five individuals. 

Corporal Zeleke said that he and his colleagues had spent a night guarding the dead bodies. the next morning, the father of one of the deceased asked whether his son was dead, the corporal said and added that he had refrained from telling the father the truth. The father was forced to join the revolutionary squad on the very day, he added.

Ato Zeleke Mezgebu, the other prosecution witness, said that he had seen the dead bodies of two individuals, whom he identified as Yodit and Ato Assefa. He said he had seen a poster which read 'EPRP' posted on the body of Yodit, and the pictures of the late crown prince and the emperor on the corpse of Ato Assefa.

The third witness also said he had seen the body of an individual identified as Ato Tadesse Kormesa and fainted because he thought the body was that of his brother who was imprisoned.

Three other witnesses, who were imprisoned said they were jailed and tortured, and were made to witness the torturing of others.

Lawyers of the defendants, Brigadier General Bekele Nedi and Corporal Telahun, cross examined the witnesses, saying where there was any law that allowed the formation of political parties.

The witnesses responded there was none.

The trial was adjourned for May 13, 1997.

May 9, 1997


Ethiopia;
Over 30,000 people benefit from potable water projects


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Construction of potable water supply projects with a capacity to serve over 30,000 people have been completed in North, Wollo and South Omo Zones.

the projects included digging of 27 water wells and developing six springs in five woredas of North Wollo zone, according to the woreda mines and energy: The department said the water supply projects have benefited over 10,000 people. 

the 2.7 million birr budget allotted for the implementation of the projects was secured from the government, the United Nations Development Programme and the Ethiopian Social Rehabilitation and Development fund.

Meanwhile the South Omo Zone mines and energy department said 61 water wells have been maintained in four woredas during the past nine months.

Ato Henok Tekeste, head of the department said the water wells have the capacity to serve over 18,000 people in the woredas.

Only 185 water wells out of the total 244 sunk by government and non- governmental organizations are rendering service at present, sources indicated.

In a similar development, nine of the 25 clean water projects under construction in Gurage zone at a cost of 4 million birr have been completed, zonal mines and energy department said.

Africa News


May 9, 1997


Ethiopia;
Police kill leader, apprehend members of anti-peace group


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Police said they have apprehended members of the self- styled clandestine organisation the Ethiopian Patriotic Front (EPF) and killed the group leader while trying to escape.

The Federal Police investigation Coordinating Main Section in a statement it issued here yesterday said leaders of the group who were found making preparations to destroy economic establishments, and assassinate individuals holding public offices were apprehended earlier and their case pending decision at the court of law. 

Assefa Maru, who came to be the group leader following the arrest of the leadership of the EPF, was shot dead when he refused to surrender after found plotting with accomplices to mount terrorist acts, the statement said.

Accomplices of the group leader, ex-servicemen Lieutenant Tegenu Jinka, Private Bogale Tessema, Private Tesfaye Getachew, Shimelis Ayele, Solomon Tekle-Wold, Yebeltal Simegne and Mengistu Kibret were caught with three assault rifles seven hand-grenades and a binocular, police said.

The statement further said police have mounted a crackdown to hunt members of the group still at large and the case will be referred to the court following investigations.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

253 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Ethiopia;
Ambassadors' seminar takes stand on human rights


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

by Elias Abebe

ADDIS ABABA - A two-day international human rights seminar organized for the first time for African Ambassadors based in Addis Ababa ended on Wednesday.

The objective of the seminar which brought together 63 participants, including observers from united nations specialized agencies and the international community was to initiate discussions on ways of enhancing the protection of human rights in Africa. The need for support for the mechanisms established within the framework of the OAU was stressed in this connection.

Among others , the seminar discussed the role of OAU organs and the obligation of States parties in the implementation of the African Commission on Human and Peoples' Rights (ACHPR), the domestic implementation of the ACHPR, and the proposed African Court.

The seminar is said to have noted that human rights violations continue to occur in many parts of the continent and recommended that human rights issues be "a permanent item on the agenda of the Central organ" at all levels, it was disclosed.

The gathering, which also recommended that more such forums be organized in the context of strengthening the promotion and protection of human rights in Africa, suggested that 21 October be designated as African human Rights Day as recommended earlier with "special dimension" in Addis Ababa - the seat of the OAU.

The seminar was organized by the International Commission of Jurists in collaboration with the OAU and the African Commission on Human and Peoples' Rights.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

254 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Ethiopia;
Teacher's Union Leader Killed in Raid


BYLINE: Ethiopian Information Service Network (Amsterdam)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Amsterdamm - The incumbent Tigrean government has today illegaly broken into the premise of the Ethiopian Teacher's Assocaitin (ETA) and killed Mr. Assefa Maru executive committee member of ETA.

Seven other members of ETA have been imprisoned. The Tigrean regime in a news broadcast has alleged that Mr. Assefa Maru was killed while resisiting imprisonment. It has further alleged that weapons were found and that Mr. Assefa Maru and his colleagues were members of an underground organisation by the name of Ethiopian Patriotic Front. 

It is to be remembered that similar trumped-up charges were concocted to decapitate ETA's leadership and imprison Dr. Taye Wolde Semayat. What is clear from the Reuter's news broadcast regarding the killing of Ato Assefa Maru is that the incumbent government has tried to implicate ETA's leadership with the recent spate of bombings that took place in Addis Abeba and Dire Dawa.

Reuter's report which verbatim echoes police reports has stated that weapons were found. Of course this is a baseless allegation meant to justify the killing of Mr. Assefa Maru. Mr. Assefa Maru has been an elected leader of ETA. In all this the bigger prize for the Tigrean regime is the dismantling of ETA which has proved a hard nut to crack.

Unable to legally get rid of this organisation and having repeatedly failed to organize teachers on ethnic lines save for Tigrean teachers in the Tigrean region (the hot-bed of Tigrean nationalism), the incumbent Tigrean regime has to resort to such violent measures against a professional organisation whose only weapon is peaceful protest.

In its radio and TV broadcast which attempted to portray ETA as violent organisation, the incumbent government sought to :

1 - show that weapons were found in ETA's head office.

This the Tigrean government can do by putting weapons in ETA head office after it has killed Mr. Assefa Maru and detained seven other ETA leaders.

2 - prove that the recent bombings of hotels and resaturants were the work of the so- called "Ethiopian Patriotic Front" which is allegedly targetting foreigners.

By so doing the Tigrean regime is trying to garner continued support from its western patrons who have continued to project its image as a democratic one. Remember that Dr. Taye was accused of being the alleged leader of this organisation and for allegedly masterminding an attack on US premises and US ctzen.

It is apposite here to let readers know that the court which was deliberating on the case of Dr. Taye on February 28, 1997 has dismissed and rejected as unfounded the charges that were brought against Dr. Taye by the icumbnet Tigrean government.

3 - to do away with ETA and decapitate its leadership by taking such violent actions.

Today's violent posture against a legally constituted civic organistion heralds a new turn in the anti-democratic record of the Tigrean regime. It is also meant to give a warning signal to ETA leaders like Mr. Gemorraw Kassa who have so far proved a hard nut to crack. It is a preemptive measure to undermine the growing solidarity being shown to ETA by international organisations like EI, western institutions, etc.

The contours and pattern of the present move of the Tigrean regime are not difficult to discern. Look what they did to CETU. Legally they failed to get rid of CETU. So according to the letter which was recently posted on EDDN and received from CETU's leaders who escaped to neighbouring Kenya, the Tigrean regime was trying to imprison the CETU leaders by concocting trumped-up charges against them.

Luckily they were apprised of the plot and were able to escape arrest. The fact that the Tigrean regime should pick out and blame a non-existent so- called "Ethiopian Patriotic Front" for the bombings that took place in a country where there are more than half a dozen armed movements which have made their presence a public knowledge shows how determined this regime is to decapitate the two organised memebers of the Ethiopian civil society (ETA and CETU).

The recent replacement of CETU by a puppet organisation in the image of EPRDF is a case in point. Now the same will happen to ETA once its genuine leadership is decaptiated. Who will be next ? It is any one's guess. Infering from the recent posting of one of TPLF's supporters on Ethiolist, we would say that the next group which will be targeted by EPRDF would be EHRCO. We do not know how and what EPRDF is going to concoct to justifly EHRCO's demise.

But surely we know that EPRDF is going to establish its "Human Rights Commission". That at least is what we have infered from a recent posting on Ethiolist by one of EPRDF's ardent supporters who usually releases such test baloons. Any way we have to be vigilant.

Let us not forget how the Nazis burned the Budstag or German parliament and blamed it on the Jews. Today we are witnessing similar things in Ethiopia. Look how EPRDF has tried to concatenate or connect the recent bombings in Addis Abeba and Dire Dawa with the non-existent "Ethiopian Patriotic Front". Any body remotely acquainted with the TPLF (EPRDF) and its rise to prominence cannot for a moment loose sight of the fact that EPRDF leaders and cadres can go to any length to prolong their political tenure.

EPRDF leaders and cadres and their supporters know no scruples and their actions know no moral boundaries nor have moral thresholds. We in SHINE express our grief about the untimely and cruel death of Ato Assefa Maru and pass our condolence to the family of

Mr. Assefa Maru. Blessed be his soul !!!

Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
Politicians: no time for queues


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Nelspruit - South Africa's national deputy speaker of parliament, Baleka Mbete-Kgositsile, insists that it is in everyone's common interest to ensure that politicians don't have to stand in queues, so that they can get on and do the "important" work they were elected to do.

Explaining that she is an abnormally busy person, with a constituency in KwaZulu Natal, an office in Cape Town and children scattered all over the country, Mbete-Kgositsile insists there is nothing wrong with a little " facilitation" to avoid queues at airports or government offices.

And if this appears to be an abuse of the power entrusted in her, then she regrets the perception but she is not sorry for her actions as she did nothing wrong, Mbete-Kgositsile insisted in a public letter this week. 

She followed all the normal procedures and was tested by the most senior official in the province, so how could it be illegal?

She can not, however, remember exactly what this test consisted of, or what the official who tested her looked like or even how she got to Johannesburg from Cape Town.

Nor can she explain why it would be quicker, as a busy person, to drive all the way to Delmas to be tested when she could have followed the procedures like everyone else in Johannesburg where her children live, in Cape Town where her office is or in Durban where her constituency is.

She also conceded that there were factual errors on her application forms, which she insisted she had filled in and signed in person.

"Look, I am not saying the politicians are not normal human beings. I queue at the ATM, the supermarket and the doctor. I have even queued at the bank - it is rare, but I have done it," she said.

"It is just ... that if you want delivery ... there are situations where people must realise that it is in the common interest that things should be facilitated for certain people."

It doesn't seem that the deputy speaker is alone in her views, following her confirmation that she had heard that three other female parliamentarians were also scheduled to be tested "with all the necessary respect" at Delmas on October 1.

They did not turn up, and Mbete-Kgositsile had not heard what their names were.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


256 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


South Africa;
A small favour brings a department tumbling down


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2267 words


 

Nelspruit- What started as a small favour amongst friends, to make life a little easier at the top, has instead revealed massive corruption, intimidation and victimisation within Mpumalanga's law enforcement agencies.

The Moldenhauer Commission, which was established three weeks ago on the strength of Sunday Times' original report about alleged irregularities in two licenses issued to Parliamentary deputy speaker Baleka Mbete-Kgositsile, has heard that special licenses for friends, family and paying clients is in fact a multi-million rand business in Mpumalanga.

It is so prevalent, the Commission has been told, that officers who were afraid that the extent of their activities would be discovered by newly appointed investigators who had not yet been "assimilated into the department's culture", actually torched their own R1,2-million Test Centre in KwaMhlanga two years ago to destroy license records.

The ploy worked with everyone except a tenaciously stubborn junior officer, John Muller.

Muller found out that a license had been secretly issued to one Baleka Mbete of Cape Town and that the matter was considered so confidential that no official records were kept of the licenses. 

"I had no idea who this person was until, one day, while I was sitting in my car listening to the radio, I heard her name. I already knew that the information had been covered up once, so I immediately went to the press," he told the Commission this week.

Safety & security MEC, Steve Mabona, immediately accused Muller of being a racist counter-revolutionary who could not accept that black women had the right to drive, and suspended him from work.

Mabona continues, when not in hospital being treated for stress, to insist that there was nothing special or irregular about the arrangements he made for Mbete-Kgositsile. In fact, he says that he would do exactly the same for any South African citizen who asked him.

So, what exactly did Mabona do for the deputy speaker?

According to testimony and documentary proof before the Moldenhauer Commission, Mabona ordered his traffic chief Henry Brazer to organise for Mbete-Kgositsile to be tested for both her learners and drivers licenses " with all the necessary respect".

To ensure this, he sent his own luxury State-issue vehicle and personal bodyguards to fetch her from Johannesburg and escort her to Delmas for the test.

Brazer apparently held Mbete-Kgositsile in such high esteem that he got out of his sick bed, where he was convalescing after a minor heart attack, phoned his brother-in-law chief traffic inspector Frederick Bezuidenhout and ordered him to fetch all the necessary forms and stamps from the Kabokweni Test Centre safe after-hours and without informing the centre manager.

Then, on the morning of October 1, he drove almost 350km from Nelspruit to Delmas, where he personally tested Mbete-Kgositsile for both licenses.

Not wishing to inconvenience the deputy speaker too much by making her write down her own answers, Brazer decided to give her an oral learners license test - usually reserved for illiterate or similarly impaired applicants.

After she did "extremely well" in the test, he then took her out into the streets of Delmas in a State issue Jetta VR6 for her drivers license test.

Brazer forgot, however, to tell her that he was not registered as a certified testing officer, nor that she wasn't legally entitled to be issued a driver's license on Kabokweni License certificates unless she lived in the region.

Mbete-Kgositsile, in turn, was seemingly so used to officials making life easier for her that she failed to remember vital parts of the practical test she supposedly took and repeatedly insisted to the Commission that she had not been required to execute a three-point turn or an emergency handbrake stop.

Transport Department officials point out that Mbete-Kgositsile's drivers license test was therefore incomplete and is invalid.

The deputy speaker also claimed not to remember how she got from Cape Town to Johannesburg just before the test, nor whether Brazer was wearing a uniform when he tested her.

Mbete-Kgositsile was adamant at the Commission that she had done nothing wrong and had followed all the procedures "a normal applicant would".

She failed, however, to explain why she had decided to travel from Cape Town to Delmas to do her license despite having no personal or constituency ties to Mpumalanga.

Three days later, she released a statement saying that she regretted if it had looked like she had used her influence to "jump the queue" but lashed out at newspapers which interpreted her statement as an apology.

Brazer was scheduled to testify before the Commission twice this week, but a second stress-related heart ailment was unfortunately more difficult for Brazer to shake, forcing him to book himself into hospital under a pseudonym just hours before he was supposed to testify before the Moldenhauer Commission.

Staff at the private R500-per day hospital say that he was initially thought to be suffering from stress and thrombosis related heart problems, but now appears to be fine.

Brazer is still in hospital and has issued strict instructions that neither the name of his doctor nor any comment about his condition be released.

Brazer is not the only senior official who booked himself off ill this week with stress related ailments just before they were scheduled to testify before the Commission.

Both Mabona and his deputy, Advocate Stanley Soko, also booked themselves into Gauteng clinics near their homes, where their doctors pronounced them too ill to answer the allegations before them until late next week.

Adv. Soko has been asked to appear before the Commission after internal investigators accused him of quashing their probe into Mbete-Kgositsile's licenses just 16-days after they were issued.

The three stressed out witnesses managed to postpone their appearances before the Commission to next week but earlier testimony from a flood of frustrated traffic inspectors have revealed that Brazer and Mabona ran the safety & security department as their personal fiefdom, where senior positions were allegedly 'sold' to friends and family in return for favours.

Junior officers who did complain about the irregular promotions and the issuing of tens of thousands of licenses to mail-order applicants or drivers who could barely control their vehicles were told, the Commission heard, to stop meddling.

If the persisted, they were simply transferred and told they would not be promoted ever again if they did not stop their questions.

" As recently as February this year, I was called in to Brazer's office and told that he had a proposal for me. He then told me that if I trained an unskilled man who had just been appointed as a principal inspector, he would finally give me my promotion and would transfer me to a big town like Standerton," explained chief provincial traffic inspector John Visagie at the Commission

"I obviously refused and have been passed over for promotion since then."

Some of Brazer's closest confidants, such as his brother-in-law, Bezuidenhout, and long time friend chief traffic inspector Roelf Smith, also testified how that had set up license tests for their own children, friends or Brazer's children.

Bezuidenhout has admitted to personally arranging a learner's license test for his daughter, Hannelie Bezuidenhout, during December 1996.

Bezuidenhout also admitted to organising both a learner's and driver's license test for his brother's daughter, Leizel Bezuidenhout, during the second half of 1996. The woman, who lives in Barberton and is therefore not a KaNgwane resident, was specially tested on a Monday when the tests are normally conducted on Wednesdays.

Bezuidenhout also admitted that he had personally fetched Brazer's daughter, Lindie Brazer, from Nelspruit in a State vehicle to write her learner's license test in Kabokweni after a request for assistance from Brazer during January of this year.

"I tested her and marked her results but did not personally take her home afterwards. I instead ordered one of my officials to do so - in a State vehicle. I admit that this was a favour or gift," he said.

Another distant or removed relative, from Pretoria, Hercules Visagie, was tested twice for a driver's license at Kabokweni after he failed his initial test. Two of Bezuidenhout's juniors tested Visagie.

The Commission also heard that the daughter-in-law of another witness, principal traffic officer Roelf Smith, was tested in similar circumstances at Kabokweni.

The most shocking aspect of testimony to date, chief magistrate Heinrich Moldenhauer said, is that it appears that although they all appear legal at face value, none of the licenses issued from least three test centres in Mpumalanga are valid.

This, he said, was because even where tests were conducted without bribery, the centres themselves were completely inadequate and applicants could therefore not be properly tested. Visagie told the Commission that many of the applicants who were issued with driver's licenses at four centres in the province had not been able to handle their vehicles in test yards, "never mind on the roads".

Visagie also said that he had personally witnessed people from as far afield as the Eastern Cape and KwaZulu/ Natal being tested for Code 10, or heavy truck licenses in small bakkies or saloon vehicles on test centre courses which were "hopelessly" inadequate.

"One of the centres was using a soccer field as a testing yard, while others were simply open pieces of veld. At Ekangala, where I was sent as centre head, we didn't even have offices and had to work out of our cars in an open field," he added.

Visagie insisted that he had repeatedly objected to the conditions he and his officers were forced to work under but was told "not to interfere" by provincial traffic director, Henry Brazer.

"I even told Brazer that I would refuse to continue testing applicants, because although they were being issued with legal licenses, not one single license was actually valid - I mean, these people were given licenses literally 15-minutes after entering the centres," Visagie said.

"Again I was told just to observe and not to interfere - but I was never promoted. Even people with only Standard Eight certificates were made assistant directors, but I remained a testing officer."

Visagie and a number of other officers also all testified to witnessing applicants playing up to R1500 for a drivers license. This they said, when remembering that each centre could issue up to 3000 licenses per year, represented a million rand business.

None of those who have testified to date have been able to even suggest how to practically address the problem, other than scrapping all licenses issued from 1989 to 1997 at the affected centres and demanding that all current license holders be re-tested.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
