324 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Business and Finance;
Exorbitant Rent Hikes in Ethiopia


BYLINE: Our Economics Correspondent, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1867 words


 

Addis Ababa - It is by now well-known that high office rents are a major constraint on private domestic investment. The manifest cause of the skyrocketing rents is, as anybody with only a nodding acquaintance with economics would readily guess, the shortage of office space.

This in turn is caused by the relatively very small number of new buildings and houses being constructed. How come? In the Ethiopian development context, putting up a house or a building has practically and always been a passionately pursued investment venture. In the scheme of things related to investment, our feudal background has always given pride of place, particularly among traditional folks, to owning a piece of land and building a house on it. 

This is as it should be for at least four reasons: first in Ethiopian culture, owning a piece of land and a house is equivalent to being somebody or to socially coming of age; second, although it is not economically speaking, necessary always true, land and houses are thought to be unfailingly appreciating assets and therefore the safest types of investment an Ethiopian could possibly make; third, barring destruction by volcanic eruptions, lightning and fire, the average probability of occurrence of which is extremely low especially with proprietor care, it follows as a corollary of the second traditional perception about real estate in general that the stream of rental incomes from such, an investment are the safest and the longest-running; fourth, there is no need for overheand or variable costs (apart from maintenance cost) or for complicated daily, monthly or annual accounting work (it is all simple: collect the rent and maintain the house).

Why then the housing shortage? It used to be said, "any fool can build a house, rent it out and become a rentier". This was the case during the days of Emperor Haile Selassie. The "house to let" signs were to be seen everywhere in town, in Addis Ababa and other town and cities. Without exaggeration, an individual could in those days move house at least three times in a single day!

Educated persons thought it more fashionable and more difficult to invest in a new car, which was more expensive than building a "chika" (mud) house on 300 square meters of land on the outskirts of Addis, which could be bought for less than fifty cents per square meter despite the fact that most of the land was occupied by only a fraction of the population!

That urban land and house prices should in the long run tend to move upwards is almost a matter of common sense, given the fixity of the supply of land and the increasingly burgeoning human population, be it urban or rural. But land and house prices such as those we have been witnessing lately can hardly be a manifestation of this natural, moderate long- term upward movement of nominal values.

How do you explain a land lease (not purchase mind you!) fee of 10 million birr for no more than 2000 meters of land in Addis? How would you account for the price of a hovel on 250 square meters of land that borders on the ludicrous sum of 400,000 birr?!

And, above all, how do you explain an astronomical rent hike of 30,000 percent ("Trade and Development", Amharic, Meskerem 1989E.C.) by an organisation none other than the government itself and of 6000 percent by that most unworldly of Ethiopian institutions, the Ethiopian Orthodox Church?! Of what use is it to reduce customs, business income, sales and excise taxes by a few percentages each if all the reductions are to be completely nullified by unbearably exorbitant rent hikes?!

A proud Ethiopian lady in Addis who was operating a bar in an apartment shop room the ownership of which reverted to the Ethiopian Orthodox Church and which therefore became subject to the recent rent increases imposed by the Church's property managers said : " If those who preach against avarice can suddenly become so grasping, it sure is time for me to leave before they impound my bar furniture and equipment for rent arrears!". She kept her word and left before the new rent for the first month fell due!

A woman who, against all the heavy odds facing women in this country, had managed to put up her own business and helped create employment for a few of her compatriots, was thus hounded out of her small- scale investment by a rent increase which easily beats the record for any one-time price increase anywhere in the world outside Ethiopia, in which country, however, the record is surpassed by several rent increases imposed by the government!

At a time when the business community should be actively encouraged by a government whose declared economic objective is the promotion of a market- based national economy, how is it that rents are being increased in such a way as to virtually drive that business community out of business?

It will not be long before nearly every major section of the Ethiopian business community is adversely affected by exorbitant rent rises as the Rental Houses Administration is now said to be almost through with the preparatory phase of implementing a similarly high increase in its rent tariff, which it had already tried to put in practice before and failed but would now be likely to be fully implemented following the central government's unrestrained backing for the scheme.

Does it really make much sense to talk about a liberal investment code and tax reform to encourage private investment when all this admittedly positive effort is being badly vitiated by unprecedented rent increases? Why is it that there should be an unmistakably perverse problem in broad economic policy in this country? Why is the correct path generally forsaken in favour of the wrong one? Why is common sense abandoned in favour of obvious folly?

Why indeed is every major piece of policy in reverse order and topsy-turvy? Might there be some invisible Frankenstein which is whispering into our ears Orwellian types of inverted logic such as: black is white; truth is falsehood; right is wrong; common sense is nonsense; hate is love, etc?!

The root cause of the shortage of business premises and office space is the fact that land is not readily available for their construction, because land in this country is under the strict control of the state. As a result, whatever little office space is constructed by the private sector commands such high rents that only businesses with very high profit margins can bear them. Businesses with low, moderate and even reasonably high profit margins are automatically put off by the unbearably high house rents. So, it can safely be concluded that high house rents on the indirectly controlled domestic private housing market are a very significant deterrents to investment.

When this in fact is the case on the unfree private housing market, how is one to explain the move taken by the government and the property managers of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church to raise rents to levels that compete with rent trends on this unfree private housing market? At any rate, the effects of the steep rent increases have been devastating so far : rented business premises are being vacated for fear that unpayable rent arrears would accumulate; many businesses have been forcibly shut down on the pretext of being behind with rents; unable to make a final decision as to whether to leave or stay, thousands of business people are accumulating arrears which they may never be able to pay; some business people are timidly increasing the prices of their goods and services in the hope of offsetting at least partially the impact of the exorbitant rent increases, and this is already drawing bitter complaints from customers across the country; some business persons are eating into their reserves just to pay rent; some are so badly traumatized by the "rent shock" that they appear to have all but lost their motivation for doing business at all; as yet an unknown number of people have joined the ranks of the unemployed.

What the members of the business community in particular and the public at large are now waiting to see is the sorts of people who are going to move into the business premises vacated by previous renters because of the exorbitant rent hikes! There have been quite a number of cases of much take- overs and many believe that this is perhaps the Achilles' heel of the business community that is badly undermining its efforts at forming a united front against the injustice that has been forced upon it.

If such back-stabbing can somehow be averted, there is little doubt that it would constitute an added force to persuade the government to back down on its so far stubborn stance on the rent hikes. Collaborating with the government bureaucracy and the property managers of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church on the question of the rent hikes would be tantamount to a betrayal of the basic principles of a market-driven economy. The exorbitant rent increases are not even remotely determined by the free play of demand and supply. Rather, they are unambiguously the outcome of an unwarranted monopoly of the state on land and its well over 50 per cent ownership of the urban housing stock in the country! Capitulate to state monopoly power and the result is invariably state monopoly capitalism which in many respects is worse than communism!

It is a great pity that some positive steps taken to encourage private investment through tax and other investment incentives should now Tbe almost completely nullified by the "rent shock"! It all lends credence to the often echoed theory that economic reforms in Ethiopia are at best only cosmetic in nature and that a spanner is frequently thrown into them by a sometimes invisible, systemic and largely inexplicable perversity in economic policy in general!


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


325 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Ethiopian Football: Taferi Agune


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Addis Ababa - In January when Taferi Agune went back to Switzerland where he had lived since the age of eight, and announced that he had formed a football club in his home country Ethiopia, some three thousand letters came flooding in, full of congratulations.

And not only did he receive tons of equipment in ten days, but the world football governing body, FIFA, and International Olympic Committee contacted him and asked that he come to Ethiopia to put together a project proposal.

Three weeks ago, Taferi arrived back in Addis and has now some two-hundred- fifty young players under his charge. Taferi, who has played for many Swiss clubs since 17, explained, "The objective is to make the sport widely known throughout the country. These youngsters, aged between six and eighteen, should have the chance to grow up in the sport. Ours is a poor country and there is little opportunity open ,except maybe in sport. So we are trying to give the children a sort of balance in their life." So taking one of the six zones in the capital as a model, Taferi plans on finding ways of introducing an infrastructure much like that in Europe where recruitment of young talent is easier. 

Taferi, 29, joined his elder brothers in Switzerland when he was just eight. His passion for football was complemented by good training and he was spotted by one of the Swiss professional clubs at the age of seventeen. "I was given the choice between continuing my education or taking up football professionally," he recalls, adding ,"it did not take me a second to make up my mind." For the next seven years Taferi made his way from the junior league to play--mostly in the number 7 jersey-- in such teams as Vevey Sport, Montreux Sport, Old Boys, and CS Chnois. When he turned twenty-five, Taferi suffered a knee injury and was forced on the bench for one year. "I had time to think," he said, "I began to ask myself how many years I had left in the game; what I would do after I stopped playing. " His reflections led to him taking up his studies once more and go to university.

Understandably, the first year was tough and there were many instances when he was ready to quit. "I'm a fighter," Taferi exclaimed in his French accent, and true to his words he stayed on to graduate with a degree in economics and languages last year.

When he came back to Ethiopia this time, sponsored by FIFA, Taferi was walking on air from all the encouragement he had received when he had first announced his plans. But he was quickly disillusioned--or woke up to reality as the case may be-- when upon arriving he realised that aid or no aid he was expected to pay duties for the football equipment he had brought in for the children. These are still held in customs and FIFA has decided not to send more until the issue has been cleared up, Taferi said.

There seems to be a lot of acceptance by the sport authorities that what Taferi is trying to do is the right thing. However, there always seems to be a 'but' in their every statement that slows down progress, he moaned. "What I want now is for the sport federation and the government to be concerned with the problem and make facilities available. " With the right infrastructure in place, those with high talent will be selected and pushed in the right direction. One thing is clear however, those who neglect their education will not be allowed to participate. "We will not be responsible for them," Taferi stated.

Though he has not been in the country long, his observation that professional football in this country still has a long way to go, is right on target. In the 1980's Taferi had come to Ethiopia to train for ten days with the national team. He recalls that he only found one player who looked good enough to play for a European club. The general atmosphere lacked what he described simply as "professionalism". However, with his plan in action we may see a noticeable change for the better in some ten years time.

What Taferi is trying to accomplish goes beyond the realms of football. He is just an example of the many Ethiopians who, if given the right encouragement from the concerned authorities, would only be too willing to return home and make a difference. Going abroad seems to be the ultimate goal of many Ethiopians, but Taferi noted, that would not be a wise move. "When I first arrived in Switzerland I was unique, and every kid wanted to be my friend. Now in Europe, there is racism--you saw how the French are treating the emigrants."

Many people are fooled by the act that Ethiopians coming from abroad put on, he said. "Some clean toilets there," he remarked," and come here to act as ministers." Visiting Ethiopia once in a while is no longer enough for Taferi Agune. If things work out for him, he wants to reside here permanently and for a change he says, "I will go back to visit my friends in Switzerland."


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 9, 1997


Ethiopia;
Germany Commits 68 million Birr to Ethiopia


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Addis Ababa - Vice-Minister Dr. Melatu Teshome and the German Ambassador Mrs. Wiltrud Holik signed agreements on five projects in the field of technical assistance between the Federal Republic of Germany and the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia Wednesday April 30, stated a German Embassy press release. The agreements provide for new commitments of about 68 million birr and the prolongation of one project for which there is already a commitment of 22 million birr in the past. 

Since the German policy intends to assist all regions in Ethiopia, the projects signed Wednesday will be implemented in Tigray, Oromiya and the Southern Region. The special emphasis will be on the field of water supply, increasing of food production and resource management, which is in line with the current priorities both governments agreed upon.

The five projects to be undertaken are the second phase of the co-operation with the Arba Minch Water Technology Institute, "Improvement of Water Supply Systems in Oromiya and Tigray Region" , the Integrated Food Security Programme in Shire/Tigray and the Project "Resource Management at Village Level".


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 9, 1997


Ethiopia;
Fire Strikes Merkato


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Addis Ababa - Fire broke out, this time in what is known as Africa's largest market place, 'Merkato', destroying some 33 shops and many stalls in the early evening Sunday 4 May.

The fire is presumed to have started out in a tea shop and there were no human casualties, according to ENA. It took around three hours for fire fighters to put out the flames--with the proximity of the stalls hampering their progress.

This is the second fire to occur in a market place in exactly two weeks. The previous one at 'Aware', some 200 meters from the old palace, destroyed around 44 shops and much property. Police have yet to reveal the cause of the fires.

An earlier fire at yet another market place in the city, 'Cherkos' in February caused the destruction of 990 shops and some residential houses. According to police report, the fire was deliberately started by a man whose brother had lost his shop following regulation prohibiting sub-leasing.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 9, 1997


Ethiopia;
Former Official Appears on Charges of Genocide


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Addis Ababa - Former administrator of Wollo regional state and Chairman of the Revolutionary Campaign Coordinating Committee (RCCC), Lieutenant Col. Nadew Zkarias appeared in court last week facing charges of genocide, including the killing of two priest as well as twenty-nine other individuals during the 'Red Terror' and 'Menter' campaigns.

Lieut. Col. Nadew also charged alongside with other high officials of the former regime, told the bench that he should not be facing two courts, ENA reported. 

Others who appeared at the First Criminal Bench of the Federal High Court last Wednesday charged with genocide included former administrator of the Haykochina Butajira Province, Major Getachew Mengistu, who, along with his accomplices allegedly killed "anti-revolutionaries" and EPRP members in the mid-'80s. Master Technician Tesfaye Gebre-medhin, chairman of the Woreda 20 Revolutionary Campaign Coordinating Committee and others were brought before Third Criminal Bench of the Federal High Court. The above are alleged to have killed 30 people and arbitrarily jailed 211 to long periods of time.

LANGUAGE: English

329 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Ethiopia;
Swiss Grants 9.4 million Birr to Ethiopia


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Addis Ababa - A 9.4 million birr grant agreement aimed at supporting soil conservation research projects was signed between Ethiopia and the Government of Switzerland last Thursday.

The grant will also be used for capacity building of soil conservationists in Oromiya. The agreement was signed by Dr. Mulatu Teshome, Vice Minister of Economic Development and Co-operation and Mr. Paolo Brogini, Ambassador of Switzerland to Ethiopia. At the signing ceremony, the Swiss Ambassador handed over an agro-ecological map of Ethiopia to Dr. Mulatu Teshome. In his address, the Swiss Ambassador said "The map comes in two versions, namely as three separate sheets covering Northern, Southern and South-eastern Ethiopia, and in one Tcomposite sheet of the same scale (1:1'000'000), suitable for wall- fixing."

According to the Ambassador, the agreement is the result of eight years of cooperation between the Ethiopian Ministry of Agriculture, the Ethiopian Mapping Authority and the Center for Development and Environment of the Institute of Geography of the University of Berne, Switzerland.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


330 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Ethiopia;
A Time To Wake Up (Editorial)


BYLINE: Tamrat Bekele, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Addis Ababa - The 23rd meeting of the ECA Conference of Ministers responsible for economic and social development and planning was held from May 5 to May 8.

The theme of the conference was "Promoting trade and investment to promote Africa's development." Important personalities have addressed the conference. The conference has also addressed the role of information and communications technologies in promoting trade and investment.

This sort of conference has been held in the past and it will be held in the future. Discussion alone will not solve Africa's problems. At times there are not even genuine discussions that touch on the core of the problems. How can one trade if there is no law and order? Who will dare to invest when there is civil war? Who will dare to invest where there is no infrastructure?

There should be an open and genuine discussion and a mechanism to implement the result of the discussion with designated time. Mr. K.Y. Amoako, United Nations Under-Secretary General and Executive Secretary of the Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) was one of the high-placed Africans who made an opening remark. He said that some African countries have posted a growth rate of more than 4% in 1996 and many countries have reduced their current and fiscal deficits. But he was quick to add "...in spite of the recovery and positive changes taking place in this continent, social indicators remain below those of other regions." Africa is behind in all respects. We need to wake up. Our leaders need to wake up. As Mr. Amoako said, "Unless our countries gear up for the increased competition in the integrated global market, they will not share in the gains."


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


331 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Ethiopia;
Human Rights Council Denounces Bombings


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Addis Ababa - Ethiopian Human Rights Council (EHRCO) has issued a report denouncing the recent bomb explosions in a hotel, restaurant and a department store in Addis Ababa killing one person and injuring a total of seventy-five.

EHRCO stated that it was regrettable that the assailant had chosen places where innocent people were the victims. Speaking against last year's bombing concentrating mainly on government hotels, EHRCO also had strong words for the government. 

"Such acts of terrorism generally occur when it becomes impossible to hold a roundtable dialogue, when some individuals and groups which claim an interest in national affairs are denied a forum for imparting their views and aspirations to the public and hence feel marginalized, and when they lose hope in peaceful struggle," the report said. It went on to add, "In our country, there is no tradition of open discussion and dialogue between opposition groups and the government. What one repeatedly hears from those who hold the highest public office is : let he who wants to raise arms in rebellion dare to do so! "

EHRCO goes on to explain that the ruling EPRDF "controls all the major aspects of political and public life (and) the opposition groups with a vested interest in Ethiopian affairs have been marginalised from the political scene." The activities of some opposition groups have been restricted to the capital and "those that set up branch offices outside Addis Ababa in 1992 and 1993 have been driven out of the provinces, and they can not operate even in Addis Ababa without the permission of the EPRDF." Civil organisations such as the Ethiopian Teachers Association (whose president is currently in jail charged with forming and heading an underground organisation) and the Confederation of Ethiopian Trade Unions have been " prevented from conducting its normal function by uncalled for government intervention."

EHRCO also made mention of the case of the university students who were " detained and tortured" without being charged for holding a demonstration that was alleged by the authorities to be "illegal". The students were within their right to stage the demonstration and had done all that was required of them by informing the appropriate government office about the event 48 hours before hand.

"The ethnic politics which are nurtured and promoted by the EPRDF also appears to be creating xenophobia," according to the report , HRCO said, " the material and moral support directly or indirectly extended by the West to EPRDF's ethnic politics is giving rise to a dangerous attitude in which the West are summarily regarded as being responsible for the problems prevailing in Ethiopia.

"EHRCO is opposed to acts of violence perpetrated by any party," the report said, remarking that, "it is with sadness that we recall that the Derg's 'Red Terror' was vindictive response to such acts of violence."


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


332 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Ethiopia;
Former Deputy PM Challenges Court's Jurisdiction


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Addis Ababa - Lawyers of Former Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defence Tamrat Layne (charged with three counts of abuse of power) said Wednesday 7 May that the five-man panel at the Federal Supreme Court had no jurisdiction over the case.

They said if his case was seen by the present court, it would violate his constitutional right to appeal. They also pointed out that the articles, enabling cases of high government officials accused of abuse of power to be first seen by the Federal Supreme Court, did not apply to their client. At the time the first and third counts of abuse of power were supposed to have taken place, Tamrat was an official of the Transitional Government and not the Ethiopian Federal Democratic Republic--for whom the law applies, the lawyers stated. 

There were none of the smiles and laughter between the accused--one government employee and the rest business people-as was the case during the first two appearances in court. Tamrat's downcast face was mirrored by the other seven in the dock as they solemnly listened to the 15 - page document put together by Tamrat's three lawyers, Seleshi Kessela, Kaleayu Mehari, and Assefa Negussie.

Accusing the prosecution of not making its evidence available , the defence asked the court to order the evidence to be availed to them. The document also noted that the prosecution's charges were not clear and lacked details, in some cases did not make the connection with the crime apparent, did not distinguish between the World Bank and IMF, and furthermore did not prove how the formation of Ramis company was illegal-- or even Tamrat's association to it.

The lawyers also raised objections to the use of the special penal code in trying the case. They explained that the code was formulated under the previous government to dispense inhumane punishment on people, and had no place in the present society. And going back to their first point, they stated that the panel had no jurisdiction to see the case of individuals charged under the said code.

Ato Arega Asmamaw, lawyer for Ato Gulilat Tilahun,former head of the PM's office during Tamrat's premiership at the time of the transitional government, also questioned the court's jurisdiction on the grounds that Gulilat was not a government official, and moreover should have the right to appeal. The lawyer added that not only were the charges not clear, (and the special penal code should not be used for reasons mentioned above) but that it did not have access to the prosecution's evidence. It was also noted that the accused should not be charged as an accomplice since he was only following orders and the prosecution had not shown whether he had acted willingly to benefit himself or a third party. It would be in the interest of the said individual if his case were to be seen in separation from that of the former deputy prime minister's, the lawyer said.

The court also heard the replies to the charges from the lawyers of Shadia N. Kassim and her son Wassim A. Kassim. Jointly represented by Yoseph G/Egzihaber and Abera Tasew, they also objected to their case being seen by the court as it would deny them the right to appeal.

The trial was adjourned until 30 May when the prosecution is expected to answer to the objections raised by the defence.

The court said it will rule at a later date on the case of Hussien A. Kassim, who had disappeared since investigations into the affair began. Police revealed that they have now discovered that the accused had left for Dubai in October last year.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

May 9, 1997


Ethiopia;
ETA Executive Committee Member Shot


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Addis Ababa - Assefa Maru, executive committee board member of both the Ethiopian Teachers Association (ETA) and Ethiopian Human Rights Council (EHRCO) was shot and killed at his home yesterday, 8 May by the Federal Police as he resisted arrest, state radio said.

The radio quoted Ethiopian News Agency that said Assefa Maru was wanted by the police in connection with the alleged formation of the armed underground organisation that ETA's president, Dr. Taye Woldesemayat, is under arrest for. The radio also said that police had captured others also in connection with the same case.

According to EHRCO sources, their office was contacted yesterday and told to collect the body of Assefa Maru, who, they were told, had died in a car accident. When they went to Black Lion hospital they saw two bullet holes in his body. Police had surrounded his home and ETA office yesterday.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


334 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1997


Ethiopia;
"Africa is Emphatically not a Place of Gloom and Doom"


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1614 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Thirty Second Session of the Economic Commission for Africa and the Twenty Third Meeting of the Conference of Ministers Responsible for Economic and Social Development were held here in Addis Ababa between May 5 and 8, 1997.

The major theme of the Conference was "Accelerating Trade and Investments in Africa" Coupled with the role which effective information and communication systems could play in furthering those two important aspects of economic activity.

In his opening speech, H.E. Dr. Kassu Yilala, Deputy Prime Minister of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia, said:

"This forum and its annual meetings have always provided you with the occasion to review the economic and social conditions in our continent and to deliberate on ways and means of addressing the economic and social challenges that Africa has faced. It is in this same spirit that this session will afford you a unique opportunity to exchange views on some of the critical economic, trade, investment, information and other related issues of our continent, with a view to taking joint and collective steps to ensure for Africa sustainable growth and development. No doubt, you could not have chosen a better theme for this session than 'Accelerated Trade and Investment'. Except in few instances, the general economic situation in Africa in terms of GDP growth has, by and large, been improving since 1994. These developments underscore the fact that despite difficulties here and there in our continent, which usually draw the disproportionate attention of the mass media, Africa is emphatically not a place of gloom and doom". 

Several other distinguished personalities also spoke at the conference or sent messages, including H.E. Mr. Kofi Annan, Secretary General of the UN, Dr. K.Y Amoako, Executive Secretary of the ECA, H.E. Ambassador Vijay S.Makhan, Assistant Secretary General of the OAU and H.E Mr. Ferhat Lounes, Vice- President of the ADB.

In his message to the conference, the Secretary General of the UN made the following statements:

"The African continent today is at a crossroads. Prospects for development appear in many ways brighter than they have been for some time. Evidence includes rising economic growth rates, an increasingly strong commitment to economic reforms, the consolidation of democratic rule in many countries, and a growing dynamism of the private sector and of civil society .

At the same time, there remain many conflicts and a great deal of strife in the continent, which continue to generate emergencies of tragic proportions. The Economic Commission for Africa has been and will continue to be an important agent in promoting Africa's development. In this regard, I trust that your deliberations at this session will take the process of renewal of the Commission a step further by focusing on various institutional reforms, including the review of the intergovernmental machinery . The theme of your conference this year - Accelerating Trade ad Investment in Africa' is important and timely. African countries must strive for greater participation in world commerce and finance. Finding ways to increasing Africa's share of exports and to enhance its access to private capital follows is vital to sustaining the economic recovery of the region".

On his part, the Executive Secretary of the ECA made the following remarks:

"As you know, the three principles that have guided the reform and renewal of the Commission are strategic focus, cost effectiveness and strategic partnerships. The first two considerations have been fully reflected in the managerial and organizational reforms undertaken in the past one year. Today, I can confirm that the organizational restructuring of the secretariat has been completed. The revised work programme for 1997 and the 1998-1999 work programme embodies fully several of the new modalities for programme implementation. For example, there will be fewer reports, fewer but more productive meetings, improved quality for documents, periodic survey to measure client satisfaction, enhanced media and communications strategy for ECA's work and more use of policy forums".

Concerning trade and investment issues, H.E. Dr. Amoako made the following observations:

" We are witnessing an Africa which is emerging as a more dynamic continent, replete with trade and investment possibilities. A new generation of reform- minded leaders is in charge in many capitals . Governments are creating environments which allow investors and entrepreneurs to flourish. There has been a distinct attitude change which embraces rather than shuns business and private sector development. Any credible strategy to accelerate the development of Africa must include the promotion of trade and investment among its key elements. A policy framework to promote increased investment in Africa must address issues relating to the political climate; a conducive economic policy framework; increased public savings and investment; increased private savings; attracting foreign investment; and enhanced regional cooperation and integration".

The stalemates made by H.E. Ambassador Vijay S.Makhan shed light on the broad policy measures that African governments should pursue in order to enhance trade and investment as may be appreciated from the following excerpt:

"In considering the conditions and prospects for accelerating trade and investment in Africa, attention should focus on such important parameters as sound policy and institutional frameworks, in particular the regulatory environment, the efficiency of the banking systems, the monetary regime, the nature of incentive packages and the physical infrastructure. Trade acceleration, in particular the promotion of new and fast moving export products, is very important. The package of measures and actions called for in this regard should be directed at the supply side, in terms of enhancing Africa's productive capacity in respect of these new export product lines as well as Africa's competitiveness. As regards investment, it is my view that two actions are urgent: one, to mobilize domestic resources and make it possible for the return to our continent of flight capital, and two, to create the proper environment to attact FDI."

Coming as they do from some of the most experienced African personalities of the day, all the statements excerpted above are without a doubt highly enlightening . But could some mechanism be worked out through which the collective will of the African economic leadership may be made to bear on individual African countries? Concerning the theme of this year's conference, namely "Accelerating Trade and Investment" could , for example, the ECA prepare a report ranking African countries on the basis of their respective performances in the area of accelerating trade and investment using some selected yardsticks such as the following:

- the number of non-traditional exports emerging as major foreign exchange earners;

- the number of days required to obtain an export trade license;

- the average level of export taxation, if any;

- special measures taken to promote exports such as the establishment of export processing zones;

- the average level of customs and other import taxation;

- the absolute and relative amounts of FDI inflows;

- the number of days required to obtain an investment license;

- the number of days necessary to get water, telephone and electricity connections to an investment project etc..

Such a ranking report would then be distributed at high -level conferences and meetings of African countries whereby delegates may be encouraged to learn from each other's experiences. High-ranking performers should be praised for their accomplishments and low-performens should be encouraged to emulate the examples of the former. Particular trade and investment constraints in each low-performing country should be highlighted with a view to recommending corrective policy measures. Call it what you will, but such a positively competitive spirit in policy-making may well help render the ECA an effective forum for bringing about desirable economic and social reforms on the African continent.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 10, 1997


West Africa;
Abacha, Biya to meet Over Bakassi Peninsula


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Nigeria's military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, and President Paul Biya of Cameroon will meet in the "next few weeks in Lome" in a bid to find a final solution to the two countries dispute over the Bakassi peninsula, according diplomatic sources.

The sources told PANA both Abacha and Biya have agreed to meet, under the mediation of the Togolese president, Gnassingbe Eyadema. 

The sources added that UN Secretary-General Koffi Annan might attend the meeting.

A four-member UN delegation visited the oil-rich peninsula in the Gulf of Guinea and the two countries in Sept. 1996 as part of efforts to resolve the conflict.

Troops of the two countries have regularly clashed sinced 1994 over the disputed territory.

Cameroon has taken up the issue with the UN Security Council and the International Court of Justice.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


336 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 10, 1997


Liberia;
Students Body Calls For Postponement Of Polls


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - The All Liberia Students Union has appealed to ECOWAS and its allies to postpone the May 30 elections for three months to give time for adequate preparations for a free, fair and transparent polls.

The president of the union, Joseph Wehjla, Friday told a press conference in Accra that while ALSU lauds the unrelenting efforts of ECOWAS and other facilitators to bring peace to Liberia, it has realised that the proper infrastructure and the necessary conditions for a lasting peace are still not in place.

These range from security arrangements, voluntary repatriation and participation of refugees, civic education, voters registration and intensive but orderly campaigning by the political parties. 

Wehjla said these are necessary for the electorate to participate massively in the polls and bring the war-torn country back to democracy.

He said the recent discovery of a huge cache of arms in Nimba county "put question marks on the security situation" in Liberia.

"We wish to recommend that the elections be postponed for a period of three months from May 30, 1997 to August 30, 1997 by which time we envisage that these critical issues would be addressed to bring real democracy to our beloved country," he said.

The three-month postponement of the polls, he added, would also serve as a platform for preaching peace and reconciliation since the more than seven- year war had created apathy and enmity among Liberians.

ALSU, whose membership represents about 50 percent of Liberian refugees in Ghana, called on the international community to support and supplement the " tireless efforts" of ECOWAS with resources to ensure successful elections.

He said there are about 700,000 Liberian refugees in five West African countries and there is the need to allocate maximum time to voluntary repatriation of as many as would want to return home to take part in the polls.

"We hold the view that with the exclusion of such a sizeable number of Liberians from the voting process, the result of the elections would not reflect a true representation of the choice of the people," he said.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

May 10, 1997


Business and Finance;
Stocks Gains Made At Ghana Stock Market


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Market indicators appreciated again Friday at the close of trading on the Ghana Stock Exchange as volume of shares traded improved.

The GSE All-Share Index climbed for the third time in a week gaining 1.9 points to 377.58 points, up from Wednesday's close of 375.68 points. 

Volume of shares traded went up to 423,470 from an offer of 676,890 as against bids of over five million shares. Shares traded on Wednesday stood at 181,589.

Market capitalisation appreciated once more closing at 2,817.25 billion cedis as compared to Wednesday's close of 2,814.46 billion cedis out of a total of 933.19 million issued shares.

On the broader market, there were five gainers and two losers.

Standard Chartered Bank (SCB) topped gainers with a 100-cedi rise to close the week at 5,300 cedis.

Ghana Commercial Bank (GCB) followed with 10 cedis gain to finish at 645 cedis, while Accra Brewery Limited (ABL) and Mechanical Lloyd Company (MLC) appreciated by two cedis each to end at 608 cedis and 77 cedis respectively. Unilever went up by three cedis to close at 858 cedis.

FML lost two cedis to close at 386 cedis while PZ went down 20 cedis, finishing at 200 cedis.

The following were the closing prices of listed equities quoted in cedis:

Africa News


May 10, 1997


Libya;
Gadhafi Ends Nigerian Visit


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA)- The Libyan leader, Col. Moammar Gadhafi, ended Saturday a two-day official visit to Nigeria that featured bilateral talks with his host Gen. Sani Abacha.

Gadhafi flew in Friday from Niger in a Libyan jetliner as part of a West African trip that has generated criticism from Washington, which called it a violation of the UN air embargo on libya. 

Accompanied on the trip by President Ibrahim Mainassara of Niger, he was hosted to a state banquet after a warm welcome by thousands of Nigerians in the country's northern city of Kano. He last visited Nigeria in 1982.

He was also honoured with a mini-durbar, a horse riding ceremony reserved for top dignitaries.

At a sermon during a Friday prayers, Gadhafi urged African leaders to unite and fight neo-colonial tendencies that tended to impose Western culture and imperialism on the continent.

He said unless African nations defied Western pressure they would remain enslaved.

The Libyan leader also denounced western countries for associating Islam with terrorism.

"Islam is a religion of peace," he said. "It does not tolerate terrorism and rebellion."


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


339 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 10, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Bid To Restore Old Monument Sites


BYLINE: Tambayi Nyika, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1040 words


 

MATOBO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The local chapter of the International Council of Monuments and Sites (ICOMOS), predominantly a group of archaeologists, has embarked on a mammoth task of identifying, preserving, restoring and reclaiming thousands of historical sites scattered around Zimbabwe.

The council also has plans to run a massive awareness campaign against vandalism of tourist sites and commercialisation of sacred spiritual places.

"The ultimate objective is to combine traditional and professional preservation of the sites as the two are not in conflict, but complementary," said Tafirenyika Masona, ICOMOS chairman .

This may also lead to some of them being recommended for listing on world heritage sites like Khami and Great Zimbabwe ruins, Victoria falls and Mana pools. 

Though Zimbabwe boasts of a rich historical heritage, some of the sites' locations are still not known as they were either swallowed up by development projects or lie hidden in communal and commercial farming and mining areas.

The 18-member ICOMOS is already processing guidelines for developers and planners to ensure that where it involves the turning of the earth an assessment study becomes imperative.

"There are sites that are destroyed in the process of development or out of sheer ignorance or mischief," Masona said. "There are also some monuments which have not been accorded the protected status under the Museums Act.

Zimbabwe has the challenging task of identifying all the sites, particularly those with traditional and spiritual significance and accurately re-write some of their history free of colonial bias.

Joseph Muringaniza of the National Museums and Monuments says no one knows the exact number of sites, but they could run into thousands.

"In Matabeleland alone we have over 5,000 sites, while in the Matopos national parks we have over 3,000," he said.

But hundreds of san rock paintings in Matopos and Silozwane, now commercial sites, have been vandalised with Ndebele king Mzilikazi's grave lying almost abandoned.

The Njelele rain making shrine remains a curious tourist site that has progressively lost its spiritual awe and significance.

Ntabazikamambo, another 19th century rain making shrine in the Midlands province, is now out of bounds to locals as it has become part of a commercial farming concern.

Mt Muoz in Manicaland, where locals appeased spirits, was vandalised. The hot springs in the same province were diverted by a commercial farmer into warm bath water for a holiday resort.

The construction of Zhovhe dam in Matabeleland South province destroyed the ancient stone walls, while in the Zambezi valley baobab trees and pools sacred to the Nambya people have been disregarded by tourists and rafters.

These are just a few of the historical sites which have been victims of 100 years of colonial neglect.

This in sharp contrast to the preserved symbols of subjugation like the grave in Matopos of empire builder Cecil John Rhodes and other monuments erected throughout the country in recognition of colonial conquest.

Now ICOMOS is of the opinion that though the national museums and monuments has done a commendable job in preserving Zimbabwe's historical sites, since the country gained independence 17 years ago, its capacity has been limited by lack of funds and its archaeological thrust.

"What is being identified and preserved as of value by museums is not of value to the people," said an ICOMOS member who requested anonymity. "One wonders whether we are out of touch with the spiritual world. We are not protecting Zimbabwe's living traditions. Njelele is an obvious example."

Though the sacred Njelele Shrine has not been officially commercialised as a tour attraction, it appears to have been progressively disregarded because of its spiritual outlook.

It has now become a playground for tourists who leave all manner of paraphernalia, including foreign coins as souvenirs.

There is no accessible road leading to the shrine except a treacherous strip, while three supposed custodians of the sites are locked in a bitter wrangle over its control.

There is no substantive documented post-independence research of the shrine except one said to have been carried out in the 1960s.

"Even the so-called custodians are desecrating the place by introducing white values, yet they should have maintained the traditional ones," one archaeologist said. "One of the custodians explains the history of the shrine in English and even wears Western attire."

Despite these setbacks, Masona says the level of public appreciation of historical sites is gaining momentum. People from areas that are still highly spiritual have in the past helped identify some of them.

"We used to give them a small reward and we are trying to revive it to make it more meaningful," he said.

And added Muringaniza: "We, as museums, have an obligation to support the revival of these traditional and spiritual values and practices as part of our heritage management."


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


340 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 10, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Atrocities In Matabeleland A Mistake - Mugabe


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - President Robert Mugabe on Saturday said the atrocities allegedly perpetrated by the army during anti-dissident operations in Matabeleland and the Midlands be regarded as a historical mistake which should never be repeated.

A recent report by the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace and the Legal Resources Foundation detailed horror killings and rape of villagers in the two provinces by troops of the North Korean trained 5th brigade in their operations in the 1980s. 

Mugabe has taken time to respond to the allegations but warned that such reports threatened the national unity of the country.

"If we dig up past history, we wreak the survival of the nation and can tear our people apart into tribes and villagism will prevail," he said at the burial of veteran politician Stephen vuma at the National Heroes Acre in Harare.

He said what had happened should not be repeated and "...we must never oppress man."

Mugabe has in the past said there was no need to apologise for the killings and sufferings as it was a war situation.

A catholic himself, Mugabe warned people to be wary of detractors to unity, who disguised themselves in religious garb.

Giving himself as an example of true reconciliation and forgiveness, he said people should not go by happenings of the past.

"If we go by the past, what cause would compel us to keep Ian Smith (former Rhodesian prime minister), perhaps I would be first to cut his throat," he said.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


341 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 10, 1997


South Africa;
Another corruption scandal in Mpumalanga


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Nelspruit - Another high-level corruption bombshell is set to explode over Mpumalanga's already embattled MEC for safety and security, Steve Mabona, following allegations that he irregularly used State funds to pay for private air charters, regular personal flights to Gauteng and accommodation expenses.

A Sunday Times investigation has discovered that Mabona has run up a R47 900 account with just one air charter company in Nelspruit which on at least one occasion provided a fixed wing plane for a private trip after the funeral of a government colleague.

Mabona, who lives in Houghton, almost 400km away from his office in Nelspruit, uses a State sponsored house in Nelspruit during the week. The house's rent is not deducted from his salary or subsistence allowance. 

Mabona earlier told Sunday Times that he had decided to live in Gauteng because it was too expensive to buy a house in Nelspruit and also because " the schools are better in Johannesburg".

Mabona is not the only senior safety & security official who currently lives in a State sponsored house or townhouse. At least seven other directors or deputy directors, including the financial director, all live in a townhouse complex in Nelspruit's poshest suburb, Steiltes.

The complex was especially built for the department, which signed a long lease on its six units.

Department head, Advocate Stanley Soko, confirmed on Saturday that there were "problems" with the accommodation arrangements and said that the rentals, ranging between R2200 and R2600 per month, would have to be deducted off official's salaries.

"I know it's wrong, but the situation already existed when I joined the department and as most of the department's senior staff come from KwaNdebele, 300km away, it is not easy to just end it," he said.

Soko also confirmed that he was aware of extensive repairs to a luxury rented car which was crashed by a woman unconnected to the department in Durban some time ago.

He denied, however, that the woman was the girlfriend of a senior official and that the vehicle had been hired at State expense for her exclusive use. He was unsure if the government had paid for the R80 000 damages. "I have a statement saying that the vehicle was hired by Captain Fanie Malapo from Mabona's special investigation unit and that the woman who crashed it was a witness for their license scam investigation," said Soko.

"Malapo was in the car but for disguise purposes had to act as a passenger. I am still going to take the matter up with the State Attorney."

He denied all knowledge of a similar incident in Johannesburg this earlier year.

Soko insisted that while he knew that Mabona flew up to Gauteng to go home roughly once a week on scheduled SAA Airlink flights, he had no idea how much this cost the department.

He also denied all knowledge of the various private charters.

Soko's acting head, Rina Charles, was given the financial files detailing both these and the various accommodation accounts on Friday but consistently refused to divulge the costs.

Charles also refused to give finance deputy director, Mr Ngomo, permission to release the details, "until the matter has been discussed departmentally".

Mabona was unfortunately unavailable for comment and is still reportedly recovering from a stress related ailment in Johannesburg. He will, however, testify before the Moldenhauer Commission on Wednesday regarding his part in the irregular issue of a learners and drivers license to Parliamentary deputy speaker, Baleka Mbete-Kgositsile.

Soko, who was also booked off sick last week due to a back injury, will testify before the commission on Tuesday or Thursday.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


342 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 10, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Urges Companies to Go Slow in Zaire


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1320 words


 

Washington - Text of questions and answers by State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns on Zaire at the Department's May 9 briefing.

QUESTION: Have you confirmation that the rebel alliance in Zaire will not go to a second meeting with the Mobutu Government?

MR. BURNS: No, we don't have the confirmation of that, Jim. As you know, the South Africans are trying to set up a meeting for next Tuesday or Wednesday, again on board a South African naval vessel. We heard today earlier, there was a couple of reports that there might even be an agreement for a meeting, but we can't confirm that for you. 

What I can tell you is the following about Zaire. Our embassy reports that the situation in the capital, Kinshasa, is relatively calm. The town of Kenge, where there was fierce fighting yesterday is now in rebel hands. Fighting continues around Bukanza-Longo, which is a town west of Kenge. We have also seen reports that the alliance has taken the town of Bandundu, which is about 185 miles northeast of Kinshasa.

We have strongly urged Mr. Kabila again today to negotiate a soft transfer of authority, rather than to take Kinshasa by force. We have also urged him to stop the rebel alliance military movement in its tracks while the negotiations with President Mobutu are proceeding. We think that would be a good-faith gesture on the part of Mr. Kabila that he wants a soft landing, that he wants a peaceful, rather than a violent, transfer of authority. We are very strongly urging the rebel alliance to stop its military movement forward.

Yesterday, President Mobutu, in the Libreville communique, declared that he would not be a candidate for the presidency of Zaire if national elections are organized. We hope very much that elections can be organized in this transition period because that is the best way to identify the future leadership of a country. In fact, it's the only way to do that democratically.

We would be very pleased to help to prepare those elections, to give any possible assistance we could to that. So our watchword is, Kabila should stop the military offensive in order to allow room for negotiations. There ought to be a peaceful transfer of authority. There ought to be elections that allow the people of Zaire to decide their future, and there ought to be a continuing attention to the plight of the thousands of refugees in Kisangani. The United Nations is doing a powerful, superb job in trying to bring them out to safety.

QUESTION: All right, it may be that Mr. Kabila is saying different things to different people. But reports that we see from there says that he's not planning to go to a second meeting. But you don't think that's a final.

MR. BURNS: I don't believe we have a conclusive answer on the question of who will go to meetings and whether, in fact, the meeting will take place. Our own view is, it's just logical. It makes common sense, and it's the best way forward Mobutu and Kabila to meet.

QUESTION: Has there been a response to the U.S. message to Mr. Kabila?

MR. BURNS: I don't believe Mr. Kabila has made a commitment. He certainly did not to Ambassador Richardson, with whom I spoke this morning, about stopping the rebel military offensive. Of course, that is disappointing. There is nothing to be gained by killing people on the way to Kinshasa. It seems to us that this transition is going to take place. It seems inevitable. Therefore, why can't it be done peacefully, rather than militarily, rather than by violence?

QUESTION: Another subject.

MR. BURNS: I think we want to stay on Zaire just for a minute. Yes.

QUESTION: Do you know where President Mobutu is? You know, the wires are reporting that he was going to return today to Kinshasa.

MR. BURNS: Well, last I checked, which was about an hour ago, he was in Libreville, in Gabon. He had not yet left. We don't know whether or not President Mobutu is going to return to Kinshasa, whether he will stay in Libreville, whether he will go someplace else. We are watching that very anxiously, as are all of you.

QUESTION: Has the embassy given you - in Kinshasa - given you any indication of what the response might be in the streets of Kinshasa where President Mobutu to return?

MR. BURNS: No, I have not seen any account, any predictions from our embassy in Kinshasa about that. David.

QUESTION: Can I raise a consular case with you?

QUESTION: Zaire.

MR. BURNS: Still on Zaire. Carole, yes.

QUESTION: I'm just - have you heard this delegation of 30 investors led by an American company? It's called American Mineral Fields that arrived in Lubumbashi today to discuss investment prospects.

MR. BURNS: Yes, we know that there is a group of American companies in Lubumbashi trying to make contact with the rebel alliance. We think this is most unwise. There is always a time for profits to be made. We think it is important for companies to keep their employees out of harm's way.

Lubumbashi is a dangerous place. There is a civil war underway in that part of Zaire. Why in the world companies would want to risk their own people for short-term profits is beyond me. We strongly advise American citizens to stay out of Zaire. It's a dangerous place. We urge Americans who are living in Zaire to leave the country immediately.

You can get out by boat to Brazzaville. There are still flights out of the country to Europe and other parts of Africa. That is our advice to American citizens and the American business community. Zaire is a strategically important country. It has got enormous economic wealth, mineral wealth. But we think American companies ought to exercise some good common sense here and keep their people out of harm's way.

QUESTION: Along those lines, Nick. James Wolfensohn of the World Bank said that he would be sending a delegation in June.

MR. BURNS: Well, that is different. That is entirely different. The World Bank has an obligation to help countries in transition, to help countries with severe economic problems. I know the World Bank will make the best possible decision about when to send a delegation in. They certainly would not send a delegation into the middle of fighting.

We do have enormous respect for the people who work for the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees and the International Committee for the Red Cross who have inserted themselves in the middle of the fighting. But that is because their job is to help people in need. But people who are simply looking for profits, they ought to exercise some good judgment here.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


343 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 10, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Asks Nigeria to Seize Qadafi's Plane


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Washington - Text of questions and answers by State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns on Zaire at the Department's briefing May 9.

QUESTION: Do you have anything to say about Qadafi's trip to --

MR. BURNS: Oh, boy, where do I start?

(Laughter.)

Where do I start on Qadafi's trip? Yes, I do have a lot to say about Qadafi's cavorting with various dictators in Africa. He's a dictator himself. Let me tell you what we know about this. There are very reliable reports that a fleet of aircraft flew from Tripoli to Niamey, the capital of Niger. Colonel Qadafi was one of the passengers. He got off and had some meetings with Nigerian government officials in Niger, in Niamey. He then left Niamey and apparently now is in Lagos. He's cavorting with General Abacha in Lagos. One wonders what they talk about. 

What we are concerned about is the United Nations sanctions on Libya, which absolutely prohibit Libyan registered aircraft from flying anywhere in the world. Now, what we are doing now today, we've asked our embassy in Niamey, we've asked our embassy in Lagos to go to both of those governments and to inquire about the facts of this case. Believe me, we will be very disappointed with both of those governments if in fact they aided and abetted the Libyan dictator to fly - in violation of the UN sanctions - to both of those countries.

We are asking the Nigerian Government in Lagos to detain the aircraft on the ground in Lagos. Now, it probably stands to reason, if they let the aircraft come in, they're probably going to let the aircraft leave. What we'll do when we establish the facts in these cases - we want to go to both these governments and give them the opportunity to tell us if they've been involved. We will go to the United Nations, to the UN Security Council and to the Sanctions Committee, and we will request strong action by the United Nations in the form of a condemnation of the Libyan government actions.

This will have a very definite effect, and negative effect on Mr. Qadafi. The effect will be this - from time to time, we have to review the sanctions on Libya. There are some countries who argue that the sanctions ought to be lifted. Well, the next time that review comes around and we can establish the facts in this case, there ought to be a very strong decision by the Sanctions Committee and by the Security Council that there has been a significant violation. That ought to defeat any attempt to allow Libya to have these sanctions lifted. The sanctions were put in place because we believe that two Libyan agents placed a bomb on board Pan Am 103 in December 1988 and killed over 269 people.

We haven't forgotten those people. American foreign service officers were on that flight, innocent people were on that flight. We owe it to their families to try to bring these two terrorists to justice either in the United Kingdom where the plane crashed or in the United States, where these people can get a fair trial, but where we believe justice will be served. So Mr. Qadafi may think he's got some - that he's pulled a fast one on the West and on the United Nations, on the world community. He may delight in flying from one country to another. But this will simply reinforce the commitment of the United States and the international community to keep these sanctions in place on him. He will not be able to fly easily beyond his immediate region.

QUESTION: Nick, what about Niger and Nigeria? Is there any penalty for them cooperating with the violation of UN sanctions against Libya?

MR. BURNS: Well, we are going to, as I said, our ambassadors in Niger and Nigeria are going to have some very frank discussions with both governments today and tomorrow. If we establish the facts that these governments were involved in violating the UN sanctions, obviously it's going to have a negative impact on our relations with both countries. It's hard for me to imagine a more negative relationship with Nigeria than we already have, but perhaps we'll be able to take that relationship to lower depths. I don't know.

What I do know, just in the last couple of minutes, is that the UN Sanctions Committee has agreed to look into this. It looks, on the face of it, to be a pretty clear violation of the UN sanctions.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 10, 1997


Science and Health;
Somalia - Cholera Cases


BYLINE: World Health Organization (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Geneva - A total of 4437 cholera cases with 146 deaths have been reported since the end of November 1996 to 7 May 1997. The real number of cases is believed to be higher because of the difficulty of data collection. 

Weekly reports have been made by NGOs working in the country as well as by the local authorities where available. A total of over 2000 cases with 74 deaths has been recorded in the epidemic in Mogadishu, but it appears that it has now passed its peak, although high levels are still being reported.

Intensified efforts are still necessary to guarantee sufficient supplies to all NGOs involved and continued vigilance is needed, especially in those areas not yet affected by this epidemic. WHO is supporting the NGO's and local authorities by providing technical support and supplies.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


345 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 11, 1997


Mali;
Malians Vote In Calm Atmosphere


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

BAMAKO, Mali (PANA) - Ignoring calls by opposition parties to boycott Sunday's presidential polls, Malian voters turnout normally to cast ballots for the outgoing Head of State, Oumar Konare and his lone challenger Mamadou Maribatouro Diaby.

Konare is the candidate of the Alliance for the Democracy in Mali, ADEMA, which was the parliamentary majority party in the previous legislature while Diaby is standing for the Party for Unity, Development and Progress. 

In Bamako, the capital, security forces maintained a vigilant eye as voters strolled to polling stations in small groups.

Speaking after he had cast his ballot, Konare reiterated that if he gets re- elected, he would extend a hand to the grouping of opposition parties which boycotted the polls and threatened not to recognise the victor from the poll.

The opposition parties had called for the cancellation of Sunday's presidential polls and threatened to use all means, including civil disobedience, to prevent its smooth running.

The opposition even filed a petition with the Constitutional Court. The petition was rejected.

However, the court accepted the other opposition demand to nullify the results of the April 13 parliamentary elections, which were characterised by numerous irregularities.

The opposition parties also demanded the disbanding of the Independent National Electoral Commission, the resignation of the cabinet and the creation of an interim administration to oversee the holding of fresh polls.

The government rejected the demands, saying they could lead to a constitutional vacuum capable of undermining the country's democracy.

Konare won the first multiparty presidential electionin 1992, which were held after the fall of Gen. Moussa Traore.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


346 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 11, 1997


Burkina Faso;
Over Four Million Vote In Burkina Parliamentary Polls


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso (PANA) - More than four million Burkinabe voters are casting ballots Sunday to choose 111 members of parliament from 569 aspirants presented by 13 political parties.

The voting, which started at 6.00 GMT and ends at 18.00 GMT, is taking place in 6,517 polling station in all of Burkina Faso's 45 electoral provinces of at least 50,000 people each. 

A low turnout was observed early Sunday morning but observers expected the situation would improve in the course of the day.

The attention of most political observers in Ouagadouo is focused on the level of participation, hoping that it would not be as low as in 1992, when the turnout was less than 40 percent.

The parliamentary election was preceded by a 21-day low-key campaign, as most political parties lacked the funds to wage a more vigourous battle.

In fact, it is only the Congress for Democracy and Progress (CDP), the former parliamentary majority party, which has been able to field candidates in all the 45 provinces.

CDP's only potential opponents are the African Democratic Rally (RDA) of Gerard Kango Ouedraogo, which has candidates in 25 provinces, the Party for Democracy and Progress (PDP) of Prof. Joseph Ki-Zerbo, which is fielding contenders in 35 provinces and the Alliance for Democracy and Federation (ADC) of Herman Yameogo which is present in 33 provinces.

The Burkina electoral commission has said that the legislative elections are expected to cost 3,346, 209.630 F CFA ( 1USD=500 F CFA).

Burkina Faso is expected to hold presidential elections in 1998 during which the incumbent, Capt. Blaise Compaore, is expected to seek a new mandate.

Compaore came to power on Oct. 15.1987 following the assassination of the former President, Capt. Thomas Sankara. He stood for the 1992 multiparty polls and won.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.
