Africa News


May 11, 1997


Libya;
Kadhafi Shortens African Tour


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Libyan leader Moammar Kadhafi returned to Tripoli Saturday evening, abruptly ending an African tour which was expected to take him to South africa, after his lightining visit in Niger and Nigeria Thursday and Friday, respectively.

Kadhafi had annonced after new Islamic calendar year prayer sermons in Niamey on Thursday that he intended to travel to South Africa and several other African states.

"The prayers we are going to perform here in Niamey, at Kano (northern Nigeria) and other African regions are aimed at showing theworld thepower of Islam and to mobilise the Islamic masses to counter the conspirators seeking to destroy Islam," he had declared. 

While preaching in Niamey and Kano, Kadhafi launched a scathing attack against the anti-Islamic policy of the United States in particular and the west in general.

No official explanation has been given in Tripoli as to why the Libyan leader cut short his African tour.

However, the United States had asked the United Nations Security Council to denounce what it termed as Col. Kadhafi's breach of the air embargo which was imposed against Tripoli on April 15, 1992 under the Lockerbie affair.

The air embargo is part of sanctions which were imposed after tripoli refused to surrender for trial in Britain or America two of its nationals who were suspected to have planted a bomb that belw up an American plane, killing 270 passengers over the Scotish town of Lockerbie in December 1988.

Libya said it was prepared to let the suspects appear for trial in a neutral court presided over by a Scotish judge or at the International Court of Justice in the Hague.

Kadhafi flight to Niamey and Kano became the second violation of the UN embargo. In June 1996, Kadhafi flew aboard a Libyan Airlines plane to Cairo, to attend an Arab League summit in the Egyptian capital.

The Libyan leader's mobilisation call on muslims against the United States anti-Islamic policies and Washington's moves to stiffen anti-Libya sanctions within the UN are clear signs that the tug-of- war between Tripoli and Washington is getting tougher.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


348 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 11, 1997


East Africa;
Uganda, Sudan To Swap Captives


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Uganda and Sudan have agreed to exchange captives, including 114 Sudanese soldiers and abducted Ugandan children, according to the Kampala-published Sunday Vision.

The state-owned Sunday paper reported that the pledge is contained in a resolution which was adopted on Saturday at the end of a meeting held in Kenya by the Ugandan, President Yoweri Museveni and his Sudanese counterpart, Gen. Omar el Bashir.

The paper said the meeting in Eldoret, Eastern Kenya, was convened by President Daniel arap Moi. Museveni travelled to Kenya straight from Rwanda where he had gone on a one day working visit. 

In a concluding communique, the two leaders also asked Moi, who is chairman of the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD) to urgently call a meeting to find a peaceful solution to the civil war in southern Sudan.

The Sunday Vision reported that the two leaders also agreed to bring rebel leader John Garang into the peace process, initiated by the signing of a peace agreement of April 22.

The paper wrote that the talks were held behind closed doors with Moi first meeting Museveni and Bashir separately. He later left them to hold face to face talks.

Also present in the background was former Sudanese rebel leader Dr Riek Machar, who told journalists at the airport he had travelled to Kenya on his own initiative to beef up the peace process initiated by President Moi.

Machar was this week in Uganda on a controversial visit where his statements on the peace process in Sudan were refuted by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Kampala.

Uganda and Sudan have traded accusations of harbouring and assisting each others' rebels.

Uganda recently paraded 114 Sudanese troops who were captured at the common border allegedly on a special assignment to invade Uganda and prepare ground for a new offensive by the anti-Kampala Lord's Resistance Army of Joseph Kony.

Sudan in turn also paraded two Uganda army officers of junior rank who were captured inside Sudan.

The Kampala authorities later confirmed those were Ugandan soldiers who had been on an intelligence gathering operation in Sudan.

Sudan is also suspected to be holding hundreds of Ugandan children, including those abducted from Aboke Secondary School in Gulu by Kony's rebels combating Museveni'sadministration in the north.

The Eldoret meeting is the latest in a series of diplomatic efforts to mediate between the two countries. Previous ones have included initiatives by the Presidents of Malawi, Libya and Iran.

Over a month ago, Uganda's Foreign Minister Eriya Kategaya and Minister of State for Defence Amama Mbabazi met with Sudanese Gen Omar Bashir, just after the start of the latest offensive by the SPLA.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


349 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 11, 1997


East Africa;
Sudanese President Optimistic About Ties with Uganda


BYLINE: Yahya el Hassan, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - President Omar el Bashir of Sudan has expressed optimism that relations between his country and Uganda were entering a new phase of normalisation.

The President said this in Khartoum Saturday, on his return from Eldoret, Kenya, where he held a lengthy meeting with his Ugandan conterpart, Yoweri Museveni.

According to him, the fact that the meeting took place, in spite of the state of war the two countries were locked in recently, was an indication the two states were now entering a new phase in their relations. 

"Relations between our two countries will witness a tangible improvement after the summit conference that we are to hold in two weeks," Gen. Bashir said on arrival here late Saturday.

He said he hoped his meeting with Museveni, held under the auspices of Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi, would help change the negative stance of other neighbouring states towards the Sudan.

Sudan currently has strained relations with Egypt, Ethiopia, Eritrea and , until saturday, Uganda.

Khartoum and Kampala have mutually accused each other of supporting each other's rebel groups.

Last week, Sudan claimed it had captured a number of Ugandan tanks and held many Ugandan army troops captives in Southern Sudan.

The Sudan national television showed two of the Ugandan captives confessing to the violation of territorial integrity.

Meanwhile, the Ugandan side had also showed a number of Sudanese soldiers who had allegedly made an incursion into its northern territory. Each side denied the accusations.

However, in a joint declaration issued in Eldoret at the end of Saturday's meeting, the two sides have agreed to exchange prisoners of war, students and other captives.

President Museveni, a close ally of Col. John Garang, leader of the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA), has reportedly promised to bring Garang to join the peace agreement signed between Khartoum and some six minor southern Sudanese rebel factions on April 22 this year.

Meanwhile, the Sudanese foreign minister, Ali Osman Mohamed Taha, has told the official daily, al Sudan al-Hadeith, that he hopes the Bashir-Museveni meeting would pave the way for a wider regional and international recognition of the Khartoum peace treaty.

Western countries, including the United States, have praised the content of the peace agreement but advised that the main rebel faction, the SPLA and other dissident groups, should be part of the deal.

The SPLA launched the ongoing civil war in 1983 to oppose the introduction of Islamic laws (sharia) and the domination of the mainly non-islamic south by the Arab north.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


350 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 11, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Zambia's Mighty Mufulira Lift BP Top Eight Cup


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Defending Zambian soccer champions, Mufulira Wanderers on Saturday won the 'BP Top Eight Cup' for the third consecutive year with a 3-0 victory over Zambia State Insurance Corporation (Zamsure) at Lusaka's independence stadium.

Wanderers, who are based in the northern copperbelt town of Mufulira, also walked away with k7.5 million (about 6,500 US dollars), while Zamsure as runners-up got k5.5 million (about 4,500 dollars). 

Wanderers were leading 2-0 in the first half. Bilton Musonda scored the first goal in the 15th minute, while Weston Mumba of Zamsure shot in his own net in the 44th minute, as he tried to clear a dangerous ball.

In last year's final when the two teams met at the same venue, Wanderers beat Zamsure 4-3.

The k50 million Top Eight Cup soccer competition is sponsored by BP Zambia Limited. The third finishers, Zambia National Commercial Bank (Zanaco) got k3. 5 million (about 2,500 dollars) while Nkana Red Devils received k3 million (about 2,000 dollars) for being fourth placed.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


351 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 11, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
OAU To Set Up Conflict Early Warning System


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) is in the process of establishing an early warning sytem to enable it to check on potential conflict areas and facilitate expeditious intervention by the continental body.

The system is being established in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, where the OAU already has a central organ for the prevention, management and resolution of conflicts in Africa. 

The alert system will draw information from a number of focal points comprising member states, sub-regional groupings, United Nations and its agencies, the media and individuals who are renowned for their eminence in conflict resolution.

"We will be soliciting information from them and we will analyse it, summarise it and make recommendations for the secretary-general to consider carrying out an early political action," said Cris Bakwesegha, who heads the OAU's conflict management division.

According to him, the entry point rule often caused delays, resulting in intervention being made when a crisis had already deteriorated.

"All we can do is to appeal to member states to understand that the sooner the OAU is allowed into a theatre of conflict the better because the crisis can be defused quickly," he said.

Bakwesegha said that in addition, the diplomatic approach would continue, despite its limitations.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


352 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 11, 1997


Zaire;
African Leaders Appeal To Zaireans


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Three African leaders --Nigeria's head of State, Gen. Sani Abacha, Col. Moammar Kadhafi of Libya and Gen. Ibrahim Mainassara Bare of Niger, have appealed to the warring parties in Zaire to agree to a cease fire.

In a communique issued in Abuja on Saturday at the end of a two-day visit by the two heads of state, the three leaders urged Zairean to cooperate with peace efforts being made bythe United Nations, the Oranization of African Unity and regional leaders to find a negotiated settlement to the seven month old war in their central African nation. 

Earlier, Col. Kadhafi and Gen. Mainassare received the Grand Commander of the Republic (GCR) award, Nigeria's highest national honours.

Abacha said the awards were in recognition of"their selfless and dedicated leadership and warm and affectionship with Nigeria."

In separate speeches during his stay, Kadhafi restated his call that Nigeria be given a permanent seat at the United Nations Security Council.

Kadhafi denounced Western countries, especially the U.S for associating Islam with terrorism. He said Islam preached peace and tolerance.

The U.S criticised Kadhafi's visit to Niger and Nigeria, saying it violated the UN air embargo imposed against Tripoli in April 1992.

Kadhafi has returned home, although he had originally said that he was travellin to other African states, including South Africa.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


353 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Imagine Caring African Cities


BYLINE: APS Correspondent Samuel Sarpong, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1560 words


 

Accra - Most children in Africa's urban cities would not live to realise their innate qualities by the year 2025 if the current trend of high population growth continues, experts warned during an African mayors meeting in Ghana recently.

This is in view of the lack of adequate resources to match up to the trend as well as lack of clear policy options and commitment on the part of African mayors for them.

Incidentally, the growth trend is occurring at a time when most African urban areas are experiencing serious deterioration, resulting in a reduction in living standards and worsening access to infrastructure, basic services, education and health.

This mix of rapidly increasing needs with fewer resources has meant a worsening of the conditions of children in urban areas. 

In a bid to overcome this trend, mayors from 56 African cities and other stakeholders in child development and survival met in the Ghanaian capital, Accra from March 11 to 13 to explore policy options and develop recommendations for African mayors to commit themselves to the plight of the African urban poor child.

The Accra Metropolitan Authority (AMA) which organised the workshop in collaboration with the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) and the United Nations Centre for Human Settlements (UNCHS) says it was compelled to share ideas with fellow African governance institutions and stakeholders in child development and survival in view of the precarious situation in Accra and other emerging cities.

Says Mr. Nat Nuno-Amarteifio, Mayor of Accra; "We have a lot of street children all over the place, we believe it is high time we did something about their plight and we can only do this if we learn from and share experiences with our fellow African countries.

Indeed, Accra today boasts of a high concentration of street children and hawkers eking out a living in very difficult circumstances, with some barely able to get anything to survive on.

Some of the disadvantaged children have been caught in the trap of vices in their desperate struggle to survive.

Bemoaning the situation, Ghana's First Lady Nana Konadu Agyeman Rawlings notes that "the family, a strong and functional unit which the child needs for security, guidance, social and emotional development, is now under attack."

The Ghanaian situation might not be an isolated one. All over Africa, the lack of appropriate responses to match up to the high incidence of population growth, has led to a situation where families are faced with a lot of unmet needs.

Most cities of the continent have grown several fold over the last few decades and the implications have been obvious - lack of resources to match the growth.

From Abidjan to Dar-es-Salaam, Cairo to Cape Town, urban slums are mushrooming across the region with little or no investment for infrastructure and social services.

In Togo, a study of urban investment levels in the four five-year plans spanning the period from 1966 to 1985 showed a steady reduction from 17.9 per cent of total investment in the first plan, to 16.7 per cent in the second plan, to 10.6 per cent in the third plan and 6 per cent in the fourth plan, says a 1996 UNCHS report.

Disinvestment in urban sanitation, a major service that controls and prevents the spread of severe gastrointestinal diseases, has also suffered a 10 per cent coverage reduction in urban areas, from 65 per cent in 1990 to 55 per cent in 1994.

Lack of clean water, safe sanitation and waste management is expressed in recurrent epidemics of cholera and recurrent episodes of diarrhoea, spread of dengue fever and malaria, and increases in respiratory diseases.

These diseases are alarming indicators of a degrading urban environment with a direct and severe impact on the health of children and women living in urban slums.

The reduction of basic services and infrastructure coupled with increasing urban poverty as a result of declining formal employment, has contributed to a growing informal sector and increased urban discontent.

What is needed to counter this unacceptable urban reality is a commitment by Africa's mayors, local authorities and local governance institutions, in partnership with civil society, to identify and undertake sustainable development models, participants at the Accra conference indicated.

The models, they argued, must strive to realise the rights codified in the Convention on the Rights of the Child by ensuring the survival, protection, development and well-being of African children and converting African cities into caring (child-friendly) cities.

They also noted that governance institutions, from large metropolis to small towns, are usually ill-prepared to face the alarming situation of the urban poor and therefore recommended that scarce resources must be managed more efficiently and targeted to meet the most vulnerable.

Kwame Ampadu, a participant, believes that a tremendous effort with concrete capital investment is needed to change the current situation in Africa's urban settlements.

As a first step, he thinks support must be given to the staff of municipal or city council institutions for their training and to improve their capacity to address the needs of the poor and children living in their cities.

The participants were of the view that support of community activities through non-governmental organizations should be encouraged in order to foster civil society's full participation. They called for an integrated approach to community development with the active participation of all stakeholders.

An important component to these efforts is to build up the local capacity of community leaders and local authorities to bolster project durability and replicability on a larger scale while children should also be placed at the centre of the planning and development equation.

But above all, African cities should take an active role in responding to the challenges facing humanity. They should fight strongly against poverty, ignorance, insecurity, environmental degradation, and promote and strengthen the rights and well-being of their people.

Perhaps if they are able to do these, the future would after all not be so bleak for the African urban poor child say in the next decade or so?


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

354 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


Science and Health;
Rescued from the Sukuma Charm: Surviving Acute Leukaemia


BYLINE: APS Correspondent Robert Otani, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1987 words


 

Nairobi - Like a judge delivering his ruling, Dr. Henry Fung, the head of the bone marrow department at the Vancouver General Hospital in Canada told the minister's wife; "After the first round of chemotherapy pending the transplant, your husband will have a 30 per cent chance of survival.

"After the second, he will have only a 15 per cent chance. Please arrange to take him home to Kenya immediately to avoid unnecessary expenses, for he will surely die within the next six months."

Then followed the most crucial question; "Do you still want him to go through the chemotherapy and transplant?"

Looking at her husband, lying in the hospital bed obviously in excruciating pain, Nancy Odwaro had only one wish, that this man would get better. An emphatic "Yes!" was the answer she had to the doctors last question. She believed he would survive no matter how slim the chances. 

Hosea Odwaro was born in Tigoi of the present Vihiga District, Western Kenya, in 1950. He recalls having been a strong, ebullient young man who revelled bullying his peers. He attended the local primary school for his early education but his dreams of completing high school were cut short when his father, then working in the coastal town of Mombasa, lost his job and thus could not afford school fees for his children.

If Hosea and his two younger brothers thought their father's loss of job was the worst stroke of luck coming their way, they had quite some thinking to do when the parents moved to neighbouring Tanzania in search of greener pastures, leaving the three boys, including Zephaniah, the youngest who would later be his elder brother's saviour, to plod along with their aunt in Kisumu.

Life became hell on earth as the elderly woman could not adequately cater for the boys, forcing them to do odd jobs, including hawking, to get even a morsel of food in the evening.

But one day Hosea hit upon a brainwave. Ostensibly, he would go to Tanzania to persuade his parents to either come back or have the boys join them.

He would visit a Sukuma magician for a good luck charm. The Sukuma of Tanzania are famous for their prowess in "performing the impossible". Hosea wanted the charm for three reasons - protection against any evil, a love potion such that no lady would resist him, and a well-paying job to enable him fend for himself and the brothers.

His mission accomplished in Sukumaland, Hosea returned to Kisumu to face the hostile world with greater confidence. In 1977 he completed his secondary education but before he could land his dream job, he had his first brush with death.

The Sukuma charm had given him so much confidence that he was back to his bullying ways. One night, at a night club in the town, he picked a quarrel with some town toughs whose thorough roughings landed Hosea in hospital.

This incident became a turning point in the young man's life. Lying in the hospital bed, it began to dawn on him that traditional charms were nothing against the earth's ills and what he actually needed was God's protection.

Upon his release from hospital, he quickly joined life ministry with the Christ Church of Kisumu, an extension of the Pentecostal Evangelistic Fellowship Africa (PEFA) of the United States. The church organized ministry courses for him in Nairobi, so that when the American missionaries left for home in 1986, he took over as the church's senior pastor. This was after he had been appointed the evangelism director when the church was established in Kisumu in 1980.

In 1984, Pastor Odwaro decided that he could use some leave after working non-stop for about nine years. His bosses had no objection, suggesting that he take the deserved rest in Nairobi. But he rejected the offer, arguing that he knew he would be recalled every now and then in times of crisis. The destination had to be Canada where he would also pursue a degree course in theology.

September 1984 found Hosea at the Pacific Bible College in Surrey, British Columbia, determined to complete his studies. But he began feeling ill. "I began feeling what I believed then to be malaria symptoms," he told this writer in an interview in his office at the PEFA church compound in Kisumu recently.

A blood test at the college health clinic indicated nothing about malaria. Hosea had blood cancer, or leukaemia. "Maybe it is not that serious after all," the pastor told this writer how he had consoled himself, as he tried to come to terms with the reality of the implications of the usually fatal disease.

To confirm the clinic's and his fears, Hosea was transferred to the Vancouver General Hospital where he was diagnosed as being an acute leukaemia case.

His wife Norah travelled from Kenya to join her ailing husband and funds were raised for the intensive regimen of treatments that were to follow. However, Nancy did not panic. Like the strong and dutiful woman that she was, she consulted with Hosea's friends at the college and elsewhere on the best way to raise the funds.

Besides, as if by premonition, Hosea had started subscribing to a medical insurance scheme in Surrey. Together with the money raised from friends, the pastor was able to meet the cost of the chemotherapy and the transplant.

After only three months of medical attention, including the chemotherapy, the bill had spiralled to 285,000 Canadian dollars (about 11 million Kenya shillings). This is not to mention the cost of the transplant and other related expenses.

After the two rounds of chemotherapy, Hosea recalls; "I had lost not only much weight but also all the hair on my head. My finger and toe nails were also gone. I could not talk or eat. I was fed by an intravenous system. The light skin pigment had gone and the skin itself was peeling off in scales all over the body. Gone too way my memory."

When she arrived from Kenya, Nancy had carried blood samples from Hosea's two brothers and his daughter. She had been instructed by his doctor to do this to see if any of the samples matched the patient's blood. It was the sample from Zephaniah, the younger brother.

Soon Zephaniah joined his brother and sister-in-law to donate some bone marrow to try save his brother's life. Hosea now recalls how his family back home organised to raise his donor's ticket. They had to sell almost all the livestock and other property.

In a six-hour operation which involved removing two litres of marrow from young Zephaniah's bones and transplanting it into Hoseah's, the church minister's life had been saved. Full recovery followed in a matter of weeks.

Recalls Pastor Odwaro; "Even the doctors were amazed at the results. I recovered so fast that on June 6,1995, I was discharged. The biopsy test showed that I had fully recovered although I reported to the hospital regularly after that for routine check-ups."

What proved to all and sundry, including himself, was that Hosea was able to do the equivalent of two semesters' work in one to make up for lost time. He accomplished this feat so successfully that he was positive the memory the chemotherapy had taken away was fully back.

When this writer recently attended Sunday worship at Christ Church of Kisumu, it so happened that Pastor Hosea Odwaro was the day's preacher. He had just arrived from Canada. The sermon was based on the subject, "Which Report Should I Believe?" and referred to the Old Testament book of Isaiah 53:1.

During the moving sermon, the pastor recounted in English, and translated into Kiswahili, how God had led him to believe the report of hope and not that of despair and despondency. "My doctor of great learning and experience gave me the report of despair and hopelessness, and God gave me that of hope and encouragement," he told the congregation.

He recounted how, as he lay in his hospital bed in Vancouver, God had spoken to him, saying; "I am raising you up to be a living testimony. As I was with Paul, so shall I be with you."

The pastor said, "after those words, the excruciating pain all over my body disappeared even before the transplant. How great faith is!"


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


355 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Bringing the Bible Closer Home for African Christians


BYLINE: APS Writer Osman Njuguna, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2907 words


 

Nairobi - A recent publication, The Bible in African Christianity, attempts to examine the historical aspects of the Bible among African Christians and its current ministry among the faithful on the continent while it suggesting various ways the church could bring the Bible message closer to African realities.

Published in 1997 by Acton Publishers, Nairobi (Kenya), the 209-page volume contains 12 theological essays by a cross- section of theologians drawn from Uganda, Tanzania, Kenya, Ghana, Nigeria and one Canadian. It is edited by two renowned Kenyan and Uganda scholars, Dr. (Mrs) Hannah Kinoti and Prof. John Waliggo respectively.

In their essay, Biblical Hermeneutics in African Instituted Churches (AICs), Kenyan theologians Dr. Zablon Nthamburi and Dr. Douglas Waruta discuss out the Bible's contribution to African literacy.

"We cannot over-estimate the importance of the Bible to the African communities. In most cases, portions of the Bible became the first readers for literacy classes. Those who went to school found that they had to begin reading biblical passages as they became literate as there were no other books available in their mother tongue," the authors say. 

In many instances, ability to read, particularly the Gospel, was a requirement for baptism in many churches. Through the translated scriptures, people conceived that the God who spoke in the Christian scriptures was the same God whom they knew from their forefathers. They could identify with such a God and felt at home with the written word of God, the theologians explain.

Nthamburi and Waruta point out that many of the locally founded churches use vernacular Bibles, which play a very significant role. The translation of the Bible into African languages became a medium through which biblical hermeneutics/interpretation was promulgated by indigenous churches, the authors stress.

In his essay, Bible and Catechism in Uganda, Dr. Waliggo cautions that when discussing the Bible in African Christianity, it is necessary to bring out the distinction between Catholic and Protestant traditions and approaches, and evaluate the type of Christian life each has produced.

It is from such critical studies that the contribution of both the Bible-centred and catechism-centred Christian approaches can truly emerge, he says. The two traditions are not mutually exclusive but they can enrich each other, he adds.

The Catholic clergyman says the language used in both Bible translations and catechisms must make the message clear rather than obscure, otherwise, more proliferation of new African Christian churches or communities will increase. Both traditions need to be more ecumenical in interpretation of the Christian message, he says.

Kenyan Catholic nun Anne Nasimiyu-Wasike, writing on Mary, The Pilgrim of Faith For African Women, challenges the African Christian woman to stop playing it safe and influence the world by affecting it with her dynamic response as Mary, the mother of Jesus did. It is also the responsibility of every African Christian woman to remain faithful to who she is as Mary did many centuries ago, Wasike says, adding, it is through Mary that God confided His divine plan for human destiny to the world.

Canadian theologian Dr. Gosnel Yorke, who has taught religious studies in various parts of Africa says some attempts are being made to work with a hermeneutics of suspicion and liberation from within, with the hope that creative ways will be found to bring about reconciliation and fellowship between Black Christians and White Christians - since African Christians in the diaspora have always felt that unity (and not disunity) in the human community is what God in Christ not only desires but also deserves.

Discussing The Bible and the Black Diaspora Dr. Yorke cites Malawian Catholic Bishop Patrick Kalilombe as an example. Rt. Rev. Dr. Patrick Kalilombe and others helped to establish a ecumenical centre for Black and White Christian partnership in Birmingham, England. The centre, is jointly sponsored by the Council of Churches for Britain and Ireland, the Selly Oak Colleges and the University of Birmingham.

In the name of the cross of Christ, the African Church is challenged to discard whatever is compromising the revolutionary message of the gospel. Uganda theologian Dr. Peter Kanyandago, in an essay, The Cross and Suffering in the Bible and the African Experience, urges the church to operate a critique of her theology, her way of exercising power and pastoral practices. The biblical message is un-unequivocal, whatever is responsible for causing human suffering must be rejected, he says.

The author also reminds that the church that she cannot be revolutionary without being truly African. Thus the need for a response that is grounded in the African cultural heritage and which takes into account the history and humanity of the African. Symbols which have no meaning for Africa would have to be replaced with meaningful and participatory ones, the Uganda theologian suggests. He adds that rehabilitating African symbols and the culture which carries and passes them on is a prerequisite for liberating the African from all that causes his/her suffering.

Tanzanian theologian Rev. Fr. Laurent Magessa notes it is precisely biblical interpretation informed by actual experiences of Africans in their socio-economic, political and religious environs what will move hermeneutics from its captivity of privatization. In other words, he adds, it will transform the exercise of interpretation away from the sphere of ideology towards the arena of truth.

But this cannot be achieved if the people or the local community is not involved in the exercise, the Tanzanian theologian argues in his essay, From Privatized to Popular Biblical Hermeneutics in Africa. Somehow, the community itself and its struggles and its perception of the world must influence, if not determine, the orientation and the findings of biblical interpretations, he recommends.

In his essay, The Use of Biblical Critical Methods in Rooting the Scriptures in Africa, Ghanaian theologian Prof. Emmanuel Obeng laments that a critical study of the Bible has not been encouraged in Africa. This, he says, is unlike in the early centuries of the Christian Church when Africa and North Africa were the centre of biblical scholarship. North African cities like Alexandria and Carthage became Christian centres known for their academic deliberations on the Bible.

In addition, North African personalities like Clement of Alexandria, Origen and Augustine have influenced Christian thought for centuries. Origan was the first Christian scholar to give serious attention to textual criticism, a tool which is still relevant to the study of the Bible today, Prof. Obeng notes.

The Ghanaian theologian suggests that the study of the Bible must be left to the theological schools and seminaries. He decries "Biblistists" in Africa, who he notes have failed to make a lasting impact in biblical studies in Africa. Many have turned their attention to African Christian theology which has been the vogue in Africa for some years now, others trained in universities in America, Britain and other European countries, are still under the influence of Western scholarship such that they have not seriously reflected on how to make the knowledge acquired relevant to Africa.

Kenyan theologian Nahashon Ndungu says although the Bible has been translated into many languages, it still portrays the Jewish world view and metaphors, some of which are not easy to conceptualize especially in the vernacular languages. This "problem" calls for African theologians who can write commentaries of the Bible and possibly translate them in the local languages, he proposes.

"Some of the theological disputes in the African Independent Churches which have led to several schisms in these churches could be minimized if the leaders had a proper understanding of the scriptures," the Kenyan scholar points out. And goes on to describe the Bible as a library from which people will find what they regard as relevant to their situation.

It is in this respect that the Bible has been instrumental in shaping the African Independent Churches, he says. "The leaders have selected the practices which they consider to be relevant to their social-cultural set-ups," Ndungu writes in his paper, The Bible in an African Independent Church.

Nigerian theologian Prof. Tuesday Adamo exploring the subject, Peace in the Old Testament and in the African Heritage, says in the African context, there is a social dimension of peace. Shalom is not simply the absence of war, it also means tolerance and respect for one another. This tolerance is an important aspect of shalom, rooted in the teaching of African traditional religion, the author explains.

And religious intolerance, often heard in such statements as; "My religion is the only right one/the best," has led to chaos, says Prof. Adamo. Such opinions have been the cause of barbaric inquisition in which many devotees have been murdered. He gives examples of crusades during the medieval period and explains that the war in northern Ireland and the early destruction of lives by religious fanatics in northern Nigeria are due to religious intolerance. Shalom, means tolerance in political, religious and all affairs, the Nigerian author explains.

Kenyan theologian Dr. (Mrs) Hannah Kinoti notes the Bible has proved a strong symbol of hope and ultimate victory because it records the history of Israel, Jesus Christ and his mission to liberate, redeem and restore.

Millions of peasants, she says in her essay; Well-Being in African Society and the Bible, read the Bible with the same interest as they listen to news of the daily happenings of a continent in travail. Their only cry is, "How long, O Lord, how long?", (Rev.6:10).

According to Dr. Kinoti, the majority of African Christians find potent words in the Bible. These words, she explains, have come directly from God or from his appointed agents, including parents, prophets, priests, the apostles and others God has freely used. And the Bible also portrays a real world which in many aspects corresponds to the African world.

In his paper, The Bible and Ecumenism in African Christianity, Kenyan Prof. Jese Mugambi points out that all scriptural religions are held together by common scriptures. He explains that Judaism is held together by the Torah, Islam by the Qur'an and Christianity by the Bible. And vedic religions are held together by the Vedas.

"But paradoxically, the scriptures which bind together the religions derived therein, are also a source of tension and division," argues Prof. Mugambi, saying that scriptural religions are torn apart by differences in interpretation of the same scriptures which are commonly believed to be the source of divine inspiration.

Non-scriptural religions do not face the "binding book" problem. Prof. Mugambi says this is because their doctrinal teachings are fluid, flexible and spontaneous with a generally accepted world-view. It is normal, for example, to expect Africans in a particular ethnic community to differ on the doctrinal formulae of their cultural and religious heritage, he further says.

Looking at The Bible as a Tool for Ecumenism, Kenyan theologian Dr. Mary Getui says for the Bible to serve as an effective tool for ecumenism, the greatest challenge is for individual believers to study the word themselves and find out what God has to say about their unique situations.

Prayers become paramount, because it is the channel through which the believer communicates with God. It is the contribution and participation of each individual that can make ecumenism possible and sustainable, she says.

The thought provoking title is published under the African Christianity series, managed by the Ecumenical Colloquium of East African theologians, a consultative forum, instituted in 1987. The book sells at a cover price of Kshs.500 in East Africa and US$ 15.00 outside the region.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


356 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


Zaire;
Intrigues Deepen In Zaire


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Kinshasa - The Zairean Red cross says 10 of its workers have been murdered in the town of Kenge as Special Presidential Guard (DPS) withdrew from the town, 200 kilometres east of Kinshasa in the face attacks by Laurent Kabila's Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) rebels.

Other unconfirmed reports said as many as 200 civilians have been killed in the battle for Kenge, among them an entire local church choir. Reports early last week said young men in Kinshasa, suspected to be supporters of ADFL had been abducted from their homes and have not been seen again. The abductions are reportedly the work of the DPS. 

The reported heavy fighting in Kenge appears to be taking on international dimensions with reports that the forces of Angola's Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA) rebel movement were helping pro-Mobutu forces to stall or defeat attempts by the ADFL to enter Kinshasa without a fight. The ADFL have swept Mobutu's forces from much of Zaire without serious fighting.

At the same time, Angolan government troops - as well as "Portuguese speaking conscripts - are reportedly helping the ADFL in the battle for Kinshasa.

Observers are worried by this specific development, charging that the UNITA and President Eduardo dos Santos' Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) forces have simply transplanted the Angola civil war into Zairean territory.

George Moose, the United States Under Secretary of State for African Affairs was the first to sound the alarm in mid- April after intelligence sources informed Washington about the respective troop movements. Moose is concerned that the acrimony between UNITA and the government (MPLA) army, which had been substantially diminished by the recent peace accord in Angola could be rekindled in the Zaire fighting.

Meanwhile other observers say ailing President Mobutu who is on a two-day visit to Libreville, Gabon, to attend a hastily organized Franco-phone summit, is trying to get his best friends in the region to help him with forces to stop the rebel advance on the Zairean capital. Mobutu flew out on May 7 as some speculated that he may never return to Zaire.

Observers say since Mobutu's credibility remains very low, one strategy involves encouraging calls for Archbishop Laurent Mosengwo Pasinya, former President of the Transition Parliament, to offer his candidature leadership in any post- Mobutu scenario.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


357 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


South Africa;
Truth Commission: The Hearing That Spares None


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

Johannesburg - Leaders of South Africa's ruling African National Congress (ANC) are to present a collective demand for amnesty before the country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC).

President Nelson Mandela's ANC said in a statement on May 2 that it had decided to "adopt the principle of a collective responsibility for all acts conducted within the broad parameters of ANC policy against the apartheid regime."

The statement said the party will provide the TRC, set up to probe human rights abuses during the apartheid era, with a list of its senior officials and of operations carried between 1961 -- when it was decided to use violence as a mans of countering apartheid -- and 1994 when South Africa's first multi-party elections ended white minority rule.

South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki was expected to head the list which will hold some surprises, according to the statement. 

Mbeki would present the list before the Truth Commission next week, together with a report on the legitimacy of the armed struggled against the apartheid regime, various sources said.

Defence Minister Joe Modise, who headed the armed wing of the ANC, said last year that he was ready to face his responsibilities.

In common with other South African political parties and movements, the ANC put forward its version of the facts to the TRC last August.

Frederik De Klerk's National Party, which was in power until 1994 has not opted for a collective admission of guilt, but has urged its members to individually accept blame.

So far, former government officials have not rushed to come forward. Despite the overwhelming confessions of several former police and military officers, they have argued that they were not responsible for the atrocities committed and were deliberately misinformed by security services.

Candidates hoping for amnesty, which the commission will grant in some circumstances to those who confess taking part in as yet unsolved crimes, have until May 10 to declare themselves.

Meanwhile, former South African Defence Minister Magnus Malan has taken full responsibility for secret apartheid-era raids into neighbouring countries, but said they were all state-sanctioned and legal, and apologised for the acts.

Malan became the first senior military chief to apologise before South Africa's truth and reconciliation Commission for covert operations committed in defence of the now-defunct white minority regime.

Soldiers under his command committed abuses that led to "the deaths of innocent people" as part of their "duty" to their political masters, Malan told the commission on May 7.

The former minister said the apartheid regime state security council, grouping the president, military officials and senior ministers, had authorised "legal" raids against anti-apartheid bases in neighbouring countries "that caused much bloodshed."

"I authorised orders to cross-border operations, which led to the killings of innocent people," he said. "I regret it, but unfortunately, this is the reality of war."

Malan, who was acquitted last year of charges of ordering the 1987 massacres of eight people in Kwa Zulu-Natal province, acknowledged that some soldiers' judgement had suffered "in the heat of battle.

"I take full moral responsibility (for) when members of the South African National Defence Force acted unlawfully, and I offer my unqualified apologies," Malan told the panel.

Malan, who served as Defence Minister during the 1980s, likened the role of the apartheid military to Umkhonto we Sizwe, the ANC's armed wing, which he said also committed abuses for their anti-apartheid cause.

"The cruelty of man against man can often appear inexplicable and difficult to justify," Malan said, adding that all participants in historical conflicts had committed terrible acts.

Successive white minority governments under the National Party led by Frederik De Klerk, should bear the blame for immoral,a yet "lawful" acts committed in defence of the state, Malan added.

Malan criticised the truth body for having "no military experience," saying he hoped commission members would understand that any excesses committed by military personnel should be seen in the context of a "war against terrorism."

De Klerk, the last apartheid era president, testified last year that he regretted the abuses but was not personally responsible; panel officials said he is due to appear again before the commission with other National Party leaders.

Secret government documents show De Klerk and other former ministers discussed forming paramilitary units to combat terrorism "using their own methods," according to South African press reports.

Last year, convicted police hit squad boss Eugene de Kock told a pretoria court that De Klerk, his predecessor P.W. Botha and other senior ministers directly ordered or were aware of murders, bombings and other abuses committed in defence of the state.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


358 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


Somalia;
Fighting Mars Peace Efforts In Somalia


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Mogadishu - Heavy fighting has erupted again in the streets of the Somali capital, only days after leaders of two armed Somali clan factions agreed to make peace.

At least 30 people have died and nearly 50 others were wounded in heavy clashes in south Mogadishu since May 2 between militia supporters of Somali factional leaders Hussein Mohamed Aideed and Osman Hassan Ali Atto.

Both rivals belong to the Sa'ad sub-clan of the Habr Gedir clan of the Hawiye Somali tribe, which is dominant in south Mogadishu, but lead different factions of the United Somali Congress/Somali National Alliance (USC/SNA), which controls the southern part of the city. 

Heavy fighting first erupted on May 2 between the supporters of the two groups, leaving at least 24 people dead and 38 others wounded, before the fighting subsided, but continued sporadically.

On the night of May 6 and the morning of May 7, the fighting intensified again, this time leaving at least five people dead and seven others wounded.

The clashes came as Atto had begun negotiating with fellow clansman Aideed, after an apparent cooling in relations with his former north Mogadishu ally, Ali Mahdi Mohamed, leader of the Somali Salvation Alliance (SSA) controlling the northern half of the city.

The fighting comes a month before 26 Somali factions were due to meet at the Somali north-eastern town of Bosasso on June 10 in a final effort to appoint an interim parliament and administration to run Somalia united democratic elections are organized country wide.

Political analysts have pointed out that the two men have not been close since Atto failed last year to attend a conference convened in Ethiopia that was aimed at pacifying Somali warring factions at home.

Other political analysts also attributed the source of the fighting to extremist supporters of Aideed who had rejected a new peace deal concluded between the two warlords in the Yemeni capital, Sanaa, on April 27.

The extremists are believed to be angry with Aideed for not honouring the armed struggle waged by his late father, General Mohamed Farah Aideed, "by associating with the enemy of Somalia," a term used by Aideed's supporters to describe Atto.

Under the Sanaa agreement, the details of which have not yet been made known, the two leaders are reported to have agreed to implement a ceasefire concluded in a peace accord at Nairobi in neighbouring Kenya last October.

Three Somali newspapers -- Maandeege, Qaran, and Mogadishu Times -- also suggested on May 7 that as a result of the peace deal between Aideed and Atto in Yemen, a new president could be named in south Mogadishu.

Aideed succeeded his father in August 1996 as the head of an interim government, declared by a conference of his father's supporters in Mogadishu in June 1995, but which is not recognised by other armed Somali factions and the international community.

Somalia has been without a government since the fall of dictator Mohamed Siad Barre in January 1991.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


359 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


Mali;
Pre-Poll Violence Forces Schools' Closure


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Bamako - The Mali government closed all schools and colleges in the country to curb a "spiral of violence" in the run-up to May 11 presidential elections, amid appeals by the opposition for boycott of the poll.

Speaking on television late May 6, government spokesman Bakari Traore alleged that students were meeting with politicians "to work out strategies for agitation with the aim of causing bloodshed," and claimed that the aim was to create a climate of insurrection to prevent the election being held.

A student demonstration on May 6, in which portraits of President Alpha Oumar Konare were torn up, led to scuffles with the police, who threw teargas and made some 10 arrests. 

"Faced with such a serious situation, which imperils the achievements of our democracy, the government asks the whole nation to bear witness," Traore said, adding that "the government is convinced that our people will foil plots hatched to seize power by other means than the ballot box."

On May 7, Malian opposition parties urged their supporters not to turn up for the first round of presidential elections at the weekend, claiming organizational defects.

A coalition of 23 opposition parties issued a statement reiterating demands that the elections be delayed, that the government resign and the electoral commission be dissolved.

Noting that these demands had so far gone unmet, the statement added: "This situation shows a lack of goodwill on the part of the high authorities of the republic."

Parliament was dissolved early March, but the constitutional court annulled a first round of legislative elections on April 13 because of poor organization.

But one opposition party leader, Mamadou Maribatrou Diaby, broke ranks on May 1 by announcing that he would run against President Konare in the elections.

Diaby, head of the Party for Unity, Progress and Democracy (PUDP) was one of nine opposition leaders who had said they would boycott the two-round vote on May 11 and 25. Others were expected to follow his lead in declaring their candidacies.

The party asked its supporters to abide by "the law of the republic, an indispensable condition for the flourishing of Malian democracy," and called on the opposition to press for better organization "while safeguarding social peace and the uninterrupted pursuit of the democratic process."

Diaby won just 2.16 per cent of the vote in the first round of the 1992 presidential elections, against Kenya's 44.95 per cent.

On April 25, the Constitutional Court annulled the first round of the legislative elections held on April 13, due to what it called "serious irregularities."

Twenty two opposition parties united to reject the result of elections, which the court said had been hampered by the wide spread lack of proper electoral lists.

On May 1, Konare called on opposition leaders to abandon their boycott of presidential poll, and Mali's politicians to join hands in overcoming the current difficulties in the country.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 12, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Abidjan Archbishop Urges Africans To Change Attitude


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Nairobi - The Catholic Archbishop of Abidjan, Ivory Coast, the Most Rev. Agre Bernard, has urged Africans to ensure that the millennium celebration at the start of the year 2000 finds a completely changed attitude in the minds of the people of the continent.

Speaking in the Kenyan capital where he was attending an African regional bishops' meeting late April, Archbishop Bernard told APS: "Let us work hard to change within ourselves because the millennium is coming. Let us use that as a turning point in our minds and perception." 

Archbishop Bernard said the kind of turmoil one witnesses in Africa such as the current events in Zaire were "a shame for us in the continent. We have to change our mind and be more serious in behaviour."

Africa's biggest ills, said the Ivory Coast prelate, are egocentrism, tribalism and corruption. "These are the things that have torn our continent asunder.

"We suffer from short sightedness in the way we see and conduct our affairs. Corruption is everywhere so we have to fight against this ill and egocentrism all the time," said the Archbishop.

He continued; "Tribalism is everywhere in Africa, because the man in charge thinks about his tribe first in order to promote or give them opportunities for work or business. Everywhere you find this kind of cancer in the judiciary, customs, police or other government departments," he charged.

The Archbishop said the churches in Africa have done what they could to make people in leadership positions appreciate that many things were either going or had gone wrong. "The churches have no police or gun and cannot say to errant leaders, "if you don't do the right thing we will put you in jail."

About his own country, the prelate said the nation of some 13 million people had improved greatly in macro-economic terms - meaning that investment and international trade had risen. However, he lamented there was increasing of poverty among the ordinary persons in the West African country.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


361 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


Sudan;
Peace Must Involve All Sudanese


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Nairobi - Any agreement that does not involve all the conflicting parties is unlikely to bring lasting peace to Sudan, Bishop Lod T. Erkolano of Yei, about 1,200 kilometres south of Khartoum, has said.

Bishop Erkolano, whose see recently fell to the rebel Sudanese People's Liberation Army (SPLA)-mainstream, made the remarks here on May 6 while commenting on the recent peace agreement signed between the Khartoum Government and rebel groups in the south.

The agreement, aimed at ending the 14-year-old civil war, did not include the SPLA-mainstream led by Dr. John Garang. Also excluded from the pact was the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) which links Dr. Garang's group and six banned political parties that decided to take up arms late last year. 

The southern rebel groups that signed the April 21 peace pact were South Sudan Independent Movement/Army (SSIM/A) of Dr. Riek Machar, Sudan People's Liberation Movement/Army (Bahr al-Ghazal group) of Kerubino Kwanyin Bol, Kawa Makwel-led South Sudan Independent Group (SSIG), Equatorial Defence Force (EDF) of Dr. Theophilus Ochang Loti and the Union of African Parties USAP) led by Mr. Samuel Aru Bol.

"The agreement," said Bishop Erkolano, "is a commendable effort towards peace." "It is a good effort towards peace, but a very partial effort. It is non-comprehensive in the sense that it only involved the government and factions of the SPLA, excluding the SPLA-mainstream which is still fighting.

As it were, asserted the 54-year-old clergy, the war in Sudan is far from over and confusion was likely to arise, especially among the civilians as to which of the groups stood for their interest.

The way to lasting peace in Sudan, according to Bishop Erkolano, was for all the conflicting parties to come to the table and talk sincerely, honestly, understand the root cause of the Sudanese conflict and make appropriate recommendations aimed at terminating the war.

"I think the root cause of the current conflict is not difficult to understand - it is basically a question of race and religion. There is a tendency to make Sudan an Arab- Islamic country, which means a country that has to be Arab in culture and Islamic in religion. This has no basis for peace and equality as it leaves out non-Arabs and non-Muslims, who are also genuine Sudanese citizens. If this issue of inequality is not going to be addressed by the government in power, then the war in Sudan will continue for a very long time," observed the Yei bishop.

Under the recent agreement, Sudan's 10 Southern states' inhabited mainly by Christians and traditionalists, will fall under a Transitional Co-ordination Council, which will oversee the local state governments. National security, foreign policy, banking and tax collection will remain in the hands of the federal government in Khartoum.

If the pact is not violated, a referendum will be held in the year 2001 in the South to determine whether its people want a separate state or wish to remain united with the predominantly Muslim north.

The SPLA-mainstream has called the agreement a sham and continues to fight in the south and with its NDA allies in the east.

Like the former Sudanese Prime Minister Ali Mahdi, Bishop Erkolano does not rule out a possibility of two Sudanese nations if the northern Arab-Muslims find it impossible to co- exist with their non-Muslim brothers in the South. Dr. Garang is totally opposed to the division of Africa's most expansive country.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


362 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


Kenya;
Church Cautioned Against Leadership Wrangles


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

Nairobi - The killing of a 50 year-old faithful of the (Anglican) Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK) St. Stephen's Shikomari Church of Maseno North Diocese has elicited condemnation from the provincial secretary of the CPK, Rev. Canon Enos Ashimala.

The victim, the late Murunga Musita from Shamboko archdeaconery was stoned to death in an incident that also left a pastor seriously injured, when two rival groups battled it our over what incumbent diocesan bishop, Rt. Rev. Simon Oketch claimed was an agitation by one group to split the Maseno Diocese and create their own to be named River Nzoia.

The May 4, 1997 incident in Shikomari Church brings to mind one witnessed last year at the CPK Kajiado Diocese, in which Rev. Bernard Njoroge was hurt when a physical confrontation ensued between his supporters and those opposed to him, when Archbishop David Gitari, then in acting capacity was officiating at a function in the see.

Canon Ashimala said the Anglican church promotes peace and justice and when an incidence like the one in Maseno North takes place, "then something is terribly wrong and it needs to be addressed quickly." 

While maintaining that he was not in a position to comment on the issue since it involved a diocese under the jurisdiction of a bishop, the provincial Secretary nevertheless observed that the incumbent diocesan head should work to solve the problem since the unity of the church revolved around the bishop.

Rev. Ashimala told APS such incidents undermine the credibility of the church as a peace maker, adding that it had caused shame and disgrace to the church as a whole and to the CPK fraternity in particular.

Rev. Ashimala further observed the wrangle in the church was as a result of some faithful not being satisfied with the administration of the diocese. He however, advised that their aspirations must be listened to.

On whether the CPK constitution was the contributing factor to the many wrangles within the Church of the Province of Kenya, the administrator simply quipped that "constitutions are made by human-beings and broken down by human-beings."

Contacted by APS to shed more light on the incident at St. Stephen's Shikomari Church, Bishop Oketch declined to comment, saying he could not discuss such issues on telephone.

However, according to earlier press reports, Bishop Oketch had on May 6, announced the defrocking of seven priests following the violent clash, a pointer that they could have been part of the group rebelling.

Bishop Oketch reportedly declared that the splinter River Nzoia Diocese could only be granted if the followers put their request in writing.

The bishop further explained that the withdrawal of the priests was under Canon Law Number II Sub-section 3B of the CPK constitution.

Since 1993 when he succeeded Bishop Israel Mundi, Bishop Oketch has encountered in his diocese with accusations to the effect that he had lied about his age.

He had apparently given two different years of birth - 1955 and 1953. According to the CPK constitution, the minimum age for one to become a bishop is 40 years.

The much publicised incidents at the Maseno North and Kajiado dioceses are not isolated cases in the CPK. Over the last decade or so, notable events have taken place, pointing to dissatisfaction among the faithful in the church's 22 dioceses.

In 1989, a splinter group agitating for their own diocese staged a sit-in demonstration in the Nairobi compound of the then head of CPK, the Rt. Rev. Manasses Kuria. The group was dissatisfied with the administration of the Nambale Diocese Bishop Isaac Namango, whom they accused of nepotism and a host of other ills.

The group was granted their own Katakwa diocese in 1990. Nambale is in Western Kenya.

Such unpleasant incidents in the Anglican Church have prompted observers to remind the church of its own commitment to issues it has been known to champion in the secular field particularly concerning governance.

Indeed even the current CPK head has made public his awareness that part of the church's constitution has to some extent become a stumbling block. During his enthronement early this year Archbishop Gitari expressed hope that the Provincial Constitution would be reviewed with the aim of amending some clauses "which have been more of a problem to the church than a blessing."

In his Archbishop's charge, Rev. Gitari also referred to the theme of the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) 7th Assembly slated for October, 1997, and acknowledged that the African church is not only troubled from without but also from within.

The Assembly in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia will discuss the theme, Troubled But Not Destroyed.

Archbishop Gitari then challenged the church of Jesus Christ to do all it can to put its house in order if its ministry is effective.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 12, 1997


Gabon;
Bucherons Excluded From Gabonese Opposition Grouping


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

LIBREVILLE, Gabon (PANA) - Gabon's High Resistance Council (HCR), a grouping of radical opposition parties, has decided to exclude the country's main opposition party, the National Rally of Bucherons (Wood Cutters) for boycotting its meetings.

The country's news agency reported on Monday from Libreville that the expulsion of the Bucherons was announced by the HCR Chairman, Leon Mbou Yembit, at a political rally held in the Gabonese capital on Saturday. 

Besides the Bucherons, whose leader is also the Mayor of Libreville, the Rev Father Paul Mba Abessole, three other political parties were expelled from the HCR, thus reducing its number to some 10 political parties.

The HCR rally was the first of its kind by opposition parties since the parliamentary and senatorial elections of December 1996 and January 1997.

Among other issues at the rally, the opposition leaders reviewed the forum they held in April, which was boycotted by the Bucherons and the other expelled parties.

During Saturday's rally, the HCR leaders opposed the proposed introduction of the post of Vice President in Gabon.

"Such a personality will have no power", said Pierre Mamboundou, leader of the United Democratic Front (FDU) in parliament and a member of the Gabonese People's Union (UPG).

The post is expected to be created under a constitutional amendment, which also extends the presidential term of office from five to seven years.

LANGUAGE: English
