Africa News


May 12, 1997


Science and Health;
Anyaoku Warns Of Global Environmental Damage


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

VICTORIA FALLS, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Commonwealth Secretary-General, Chief Emeka Anyaoku, on Monday said the current deforestation and land degradation in the world threatens planetary survival and the maintenance of a habitable biosphere.

He was presenting the keynote address at a Commonwealth forestry conference on "Forestry in a Changing Political Environment: Challenges for the 21st Century".

Anyaoku said the relationship between deforestation and global warming, the likely impact of climate change on health and the consequences of a continuing loss of biodiversity and extinction of plant and animal species had become a global problem. 

"At local level, the dislocation of landscapes by erosion, siltation and loss of habitat is often played out well away from the media attention but is no less a tragedy for the people, often poor and living on marginal land, who depend on forests for a livelihood," Anyaoku said.

However, Anyaoku said efforts to save the forests and promote sustainable management of the environment had yielded little results because they lacked a political dimension.

"In fact, there are a number of common themes emerging from these international debates which recognizes that the forest principles adopted at the Rio Earth Summit five years ago have not been sufficient to stem the tide of forest loss," he said.

Anyaoku said some of the themes coming out were a realization that forest loss could only be done with political commitments on the part of governments supported by all stake holders including the professional forestry community.

"Others are the idea that it is in the public interest to manage forests sustainably and equitably and a recognition that to do so we need to engage civil society and ensure that people are drawn into decision making at all appropriate levels," he said.

Apart from the Rio conference, Anyaoku cited previous Commonwealth forestry conferences in Oxford in 1974 and in Malaysia in 1993 which also yielded little change to the problem.

The themes for the conferences were "the forest and the global environment, and people, the environment and forestry."

"However, while there are abundant reasons for concern, there is no excuse for gloom and doom either. There a number of international initiatives which have captured the imagination of many and the Commonwealth countries are leading the way," Anyaoku said.

He cited the pioneering Canadian Model Forest Programme which involved communities and stimulated partnership arrangements where there was potential conflict between logging interests and other users.

The other is the Iwokrama Rain Forest Programme for Guyana where the government set aside 387 hectares of its pristine tropical forest, which is close to two percent of the country's land for this conservation and development venture.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


365 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
PANA Begins Privatization Program In December


BYLINE: Kibaniakina M. N., PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The Interim Board of the Dakar-based Pan African News Agency (PANA) has decided that December will be the deadline for the commencement of the privatization of the continental wire service.

The month of December will mark the end of PANA's recovery programme, which is being undertaken in conjunction with the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO).

However, the board, which met in Dakar on Monday and Tuesday last week, said that before the recovery programme comes to an end, member states will be required to pay off the agency's outstanding debts, estimated at is 4.7 million U.S dollars.

According to a spokesman of the Board, Ibrahim Dagash, who heads the Information division of the Organization of African Unity (OAU), one of the meeting's major decision was to appeal to African media organs to buy shares in the new PANA. 

"A large part of the share capital in the new PANA would be sold to the continent's public and private media," Dagash said.

He said that the board's crucial meeting was attended by all its delegates - - from the OAU, Cameroon, Egypt, Nigeria, Senegal, Sudan and Zimbabwe -- as well as experts from an audit firm, Price Waterhouse, and Citibank in Dakar.

The meeting's spokesman said PANA had now entered the last phase of the recovery plan which was submitted to the 1992 African Conference of Information Ministers in Abuja and adopted by the OAU summit in Dakar the same year.

The plan, drawn by UNESCO and the OAU, envisages the transformation of PANA from being an inter-governmental body, into an agency operated by private as well as public shareholders, at the end of a three-year transitional period, which started in 1993.

However, the transitional period has been hampered by financial and administrative hitches, especially the inability of member states to pay their assessed annual contributions.

To date, the accumulated arrears of contribution stand at about 30 million U.S dollars. The agency's annual budget is about 4.2 million dollars.

However, thanks to the commitment of several member states, the inter- governmental PANA was gradually emerging from the zone of turbulence.

Among its decisions, the PANA Interim board affirmed that the change of its legal status should not be done at the expense of its staff.

"Whatever is owed to any member of staff all over Africa will be fully paid, " Dagash said, adding that "there will be no privatization until staff will have received the totality of their rights."

The board adopted what it termed as a "flexible, practical and pragmatic" concessional mechanism to enable member states settle their arrears of contribution.

Under this system, the six or seven member states who are viewed as the " major debtors" with arrears of between one million and 3.5 million U.S dollars, will now be required to pay only one million.

On the other hand, the debts of 14 countries regarded as "small debtors" have been slashed to 25,000 U.S dollars.

Thus, member states whose arrears of contribution are below one million U.S dollars, have been encouraged to settle half of the arrears, under a mechanism which will be submitted, together with the conclusions of the last board meeting, to the Conference of African Information Ministers, slated for Cairo, Egypt, from June 16-19.

According to Dagash, the agency is expecting two major financial contributions from Libya (1.1 million U.S dollars) and UNESCO (720,000 U.S dollars).

Elaborating further on the share capital, Dagash said that in the new PANA, 25 percent of the share capital will belong to member states through their national news agencies while 20 percent will be reserved for other African media organs.

Some 55 percent of the share capital will be reserved for telecommunication bodies and other private interests, some of whom have already shown interest.

Dagash said an information campaign to publicize and promote the PANA project will be undertaken in conjunction with partners who are conversant with the African financial market.

The publicity campaign will involve round tables in at least 16 countries while the information on the commercialization programme will be available in all African states through the network of "Citibank" and ministries of information.

The PANA interim board says that although the agency's privatization is " irreversible" this does not indicate that Africans were surrendering their important development tool into the hands of non-Africans.

The objective is to make the agency viable and efficient by providing it with "the means to ensure its efficiency and competitiveness of its products on a highly sensitive market."

Another member of the PANA Interim Board, Abdou Gningue, the director of the Senegalese News Agency, noted that " in the final analysis, the future PANA should be some sort of a cooperative of African media organs, along the lines of the Associated Press of the United States.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


366 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


Kenya;
Flamingoes Return To Kenya's Lake Nakuru


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - Some 100,000 flamingoes have returned to their Lake Nakuru sanctuary, in the Kenyan section of the rift valley, which they had deserted when it started drying up, a game warden has said.

The warden of the area, Daniel Kilonzo, said a large number of the flamingoes had migrated to the neighbouring rift valley lakes of Bogoria and Elementaita, in Kenya. 

He said recently that the birds had returned to the sanctuary by the end of March and that the numbers had increased sharply since the onset of the heavy rains now pounding the whole country.

Almost the entire flamingo population, which at best swells to 1.5 million when the water level is high and their food, blue green algae is abundant, had fled in 1996 when the lake receded leaving only strips of water.

Kilonzo said that seasonal rivers such as the Ndarugu and the Nderit, which had dried up, were now flowing into the lake, whose inflow is swelled by treated affluent from neighbouring industries.

Apart from the flamingoes that had migrated, he said, Lake Nakuru National Park did not lose any other game due to the drought and those animals that had been weakened by lack of pasture had now gained weight.

The park also boasts a rhino breeding herd introduced a decade ago, hundreds of buffaloes, water bucks, warthogs and giraffe.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


367 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


Sudan;
Dinder Park Survives Ravages Of War


BYLINE: Yahya El Hassan, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Sudanese wildlife authorities have said that animals in Dinder Park, eastern Sudan, have remained unharmed by the ongoing war between government and rebel forces in the surrounding areas.

Dinder, is the world's third largest natural park, surpassed only by Tsavo Game Park in Kenya and Radoum Park in western Sudan. Dinder's 2,352 square kilometers (908 square miles) is a landmass greater than Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Malta and Monaco combined.

Recently, the director of protected areas in the Sudanese Wildlife Conservation Administration, John Awang Awok, denied Ethiopian territory had originated from Dinder Park. 

"The park is firmly protected and game wardens are on absolute alert and full control," he told PANA.

Dinder stretches into neighbouring Ethiopia and Eritrea and has for decades been Sudan's major tourist attraction, by virtue of its varied flora and fauna.

Although the road to the area is rudimentary, foreigners still flock there to take photos of wild beasts, birds and plants, as well to experience the thrill of spending a night among the calls of animals and birds.

However, Awok conceded that the war had affected the life of animals outside the park's perimeters.

"Migration of animals from one country to another has always been the result of wars and natural catastrophes like drought and desertification," he said.

Tourists and game rangers from the area, he said, told him recently that " no single animal had left the reserve since the outbreak of the fighting" in the area January 12.

As regards western media claims that 33 rhinos were found dead in Ethiopian territory, he said "We can precisely say that the Dinder Park has nothing to do with the matter as we do not have any rhinos in that park.

However, he warned that unlicensed farmers and poachers constituted a threat to the park's plants and animals.

The main threat started in the 1980s when 400 families moved into the park after one of the most severe droughts. These families came and settled down with their cattle, goats and sheep.

Unlike parks elsewhere in Africa, Dinder has not yet been invaded by foreign poachers. The only threat, Awok said, came "from nationals who smuggle themselves inside the area to chop down trees" for making charcoal. Some trees are also destroyed by people looking for honey.

The other issue of concern is the presence of commercial farmers "who use such advanced equipment as tractors to plough as much land as they can for cultivation."

Mechanized farming has led to soil degradation and loss of fertility, thus limiting the chances for plant diversity, a major tourist attraction.

Illegal hunting is also posing a threat to animal species like antelopes, deer and other animals whose meat is easy to dry using traditional methods. Guinea fowl are the most targeted birds.

In spite of these man-made disasters, Awok said: "Our park, like any park everywhere in the world, plays the role of recreation, education, scientific research and ecological awareness."

However, he said that greater protection was required to safeguard certain animals from extinction.

He said that The National Centre for Research reported in 1994 that 266 species of the mammalia class and four of 938 avian kingdom were under threat of extinction.

To preserve biodiversity, Sudanese wildlife authorities have since the 1930s created a number of natural protected areas. These include eight national parks and 17 reserves where no one is allowed to hunt or farm.

Sudan's Environment Protection Association says that five of these areas are in northern Sudan and the rest in the south.

Among the association's complaints are the transformation of the Rahad Protected Area, about 880 kilometers (550 miles) south of Khartoum, into a mechanized agricultural farm.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


368 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
WFP Emergency Report No. 19 - Africa (05/09)


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2694 words


 

Rome - This report includes: A) Burundi, Rwanda, Zaire and Tanzania B) Uganda C) Sudan D) Sierra Leone

PART I - HIGHLIGHTS (Details below in Part II)

A. EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE AND TANZANIA

1. Zaire - information as of 8 May

a) Ninety-one refugees die in overcrowded train going from Biaro to Kisangani. Train operations temporarily suspended but resumed two days later. Trucks also used to shuttle refugees to Kisangani. b) A total of 12,024 refugees repatriated by air to Rwanda between start of operation on 30 April and 7 May. c) Access of expatriate aid staff beyond Biaro still restricted by the authorities. d) Some 50,000 refugees reach Mbandaka, near Zaire/Congo border. Attempted looting of barges carrying WFP food takes place but 765 metric tons of food safely delivered for distribution by the Zairian Red Cross and IFRC. 

2. Rwanda a) Tension still high in prefectures of Gisenyi and Ruhengeri due to ongoing repatriation. Seventeen students, a Belgian teacher and four others killed during an attack on a school in Gisenyi, and nine others seriously wounded. b) Rains affect delivery of food in many parts of the country and hamper project activities.

3. Burundi a) Bujumbura and the northern areas of the country relatively calm, but situation reported volatile in southern Burundi. Clashes reported along the border with Tanzania. In Bururi, 36 students killed when large group of rebels attack a seminary killing 36 students and 7 instructors and injuring 40 persons.

4. Tanzania a) Heavy rains continue to hamper food movements in districts of Kigoma, Kasulu and Kibondo.

B. UGANDA

1. Update a) Food deliveries continue for displaced persons in Gulu and Kitgum districts; supplementary food delivered to hospitals.

C. SUDAN

1. Update a) WFP airlift into Juba began on 10 April, to cover urgent food aid needs of 14,540 displaced persons and refugees. b) WFP and UNICEF humanitarian flights into Sudan airspace suspended by Sudanese authorities. Issue currently under discussion between UN and the Government of Sudan. c) WFP to supply 5,100 metric tons of food for 100,000 returnees in the Yei area from April through August 1997. Food is on the way to the area from Uganda.

D. SIERRA LEONE

1. Update a) Two UN vehicles ambushed 5 miles from Makeni en route to Freetown; a UN driver is killed and a UN official injured. UN road travel to Bo and Kenema from Freetown suspended. In earlier incident at mile 91 in Makeni on 17 April, some 32 metric tons of WFP food looted. b) WFP and other relief staff temporarily evacuated from Kenema due to heavy fighting between government soldiers and Kamajors. c) Food is supplied by WFP to first group of 600 refugees returning from Liberia. Some 2,400 refugees are to be repatriated by UNHCR during May.

PART II - DETAILS

A. EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE, TANZANIA

1. ZAIRE - most information as of 8 May.

1.1 Ninety-one refugees were trampled to death or suffocated in an overcrowded Kisangani-bound train, on Sunday 4 May. Panic seized the refugees while they were boarding the train at Biaro and the safe capacity of the train was exceeded. As a result of this accident and in order to allow better coordination of refugee movements, the transport of refugees by train was temporarily suspended. Train operations resumed on 6 May and in addition to the two trains, there are now 11 trucks shuttling refugees from Biaro to Kisangani.

1.2 Since the beginning of the air repatriation operation on 30 April, until 7 May, 12,024 refugees were flown home to Rwanda. Three WFP planes are involved in this operation. The two Il-76 are flying the refugees directly to Kigali while the Hercules C-130 takes refugees to Gisenyi and Cyangugu. The same planes continue shuttling food and non-food items into Kisangani. From 28 April to 4 May, WFP delivered 182 metric tons of food.

1.3 A transit centre has been established near Kisangani International Airport to accommodate the refugees while they are waiting for air transport to Rwanda. An average of 4,000 refugees have been staying at the centre, planned to host a maximum 1,000 persons. WFP has provided food commodities for a wet feeding programme, run by the NGO OMNIS. Community kitchens are also operating at Biaro, where some 40,000 refugees await repatriation. Presently eight kitchens, run by OMNIS, EUB and Caritas, provide meals to over 5,000 refugees, mainly unaccompanied children and sick refugees. WFP plans to increase the number of kitchens at the camp.

1.4 Biaro refugees are now also benefiting from general distributions. Since 30 April, WFP has moved 70 metric tons of food to this site, despite an acute lack of trucks to shuttle food between the rail depot and the refugee camp. There has also been an improvement in the provision of health services and water, however these still need to be augmented to cover the number and state of the refugees.

1.5 It has been reported that some 5,000 refugees are presently at Obilo, km 82 and a few also at Ubundu. As of 8 May, WFP was awaiting clearance to despatch 26 metric tons of food by train to these locations. Access of expatriate staff from aid agencies beyond Biaro is being restricted by the authorities, and it is now more than three weeks since aid workers were last able to visit there.

1.6 Approximately 50,000 refugees formerly in camps in Goma and Bukavu have reached Mbandaka, near the border Zaire/Congo and have started to receive food assistance. WFP has transported 765 metric tons of maize by barge from Kinshasa to Mbandaka, for distribution to these refugees. Upon arrival at the port, a large number of people attempted to loot the maize from the barges and these had to be moved offshore. Update, 9 May: the 765 metric tons have been safely received by the Catholic diocese of Mbandaka, the Zairian Red Cross and IFRC, who are undertaking the distribution.

1.7 In eastern Zaire, humanitarian traffic along parts of the Bukavu/Goma road has been suspended owing to insecurity. In Bukavu, a curfew is now in place, allegedly due to the infiltration of armed ex-FAR and Interahamwe into Rwanda. Access to refugees and way stations is restricted to two axes, Walungu and Mwenga.

2. RWANDA

2.1 Tension remains high in the prefectures of Gisenyi and Ruhengeri with the ongoing repatriation from Zaire. Various incidents were reported in the area, the most serious being an attack by a group of armed men on a school in Gisenyi. Seventeen students were killed along with four residents of the area and a Belgian teacher, and nine other students were seriously wounded.

2.2 Over 1,000 unaccompanied children have so far arrived in Rwanda from Zaire. Supplementary rations are being provided to these children. All arriving returnees are being provided with high-energy biscuits and wet feeding while at the transit centres. A one-month food ration is also distributed to all returnees.

2.3 Rains are affecting the delivery of food in many parts of the country and hampering project activities. A land slide damaged already completed sections of the Mizingo/Arusha road. No food deliveries could be made to the communes of Gituza and Cyumba in Byumba, as the roads have become impassable.

3. BURUNDI

3.1 Bujumbura and the northern areas of the country remained relatively calm, with a single mine incident reported, killing two people. In southern Burundi, the situation is however volatile. In Makamba, rebel attacks caused the displacement of some 20,000 persons. Clashes were also reported along the border with Tanzania and in Bururi, a large group of rebels attacked a seminary killing 36 students and 7 instructors and injuring another 40 persons.

3.2 Joint assessment missions visited Bubanza, Bururi and Muramvya provinces. In Bubanza, 86,190 Burundians are grouped in 36 displaced and regroupement camps. In this province people in camps have access to their fields and military escorts are provided for harvesting. A good harvest is anticipated. In Bururi and Muramvya, WFP is considering options for food assistance to some of the most vulnerable areas.

4. TANZANIA

4.1 Another 6,165 Burundian refugees were registered at the Kasulu and Kibondo camps in Tanzania, fleeing violence in Burundi. Tanzania now hosts over 390,000 refugees: 105,000 in Kagera region and 285,652 in Kigoma region.

4.2 Deplorable road conditions due to heavy rains in the districts of Kigoma, Kasulu and Kibondo continue to hamper food movements. Seven trucks carrying food commodities from Isaka to Kibondo got stuck and had to be diverted. A shortfall of pulses was experienced in all camps in Kigoma, caused by the late arrival of trucks and wagons. Further shortages are likely if road conditions are not improved. Efforts to repair some of the worst road stretches continue.

B. UGANDA

1. UPDATE

1.1 Food deliveries to Gulu and Kitgum districts, for distribution to displaced persons continue. From 28 April to 4 May, 80 metric tons of maize meal were despatched to Kitgum and 181 metric tons of various commodities were sent to Gulu. WFP also despatched to Kitgum 28 metric tons of seeds procured by the French Embassy. ICRC and ACCORD/OXFAM are planning distributions of seeds and hoes and WFP food will be supplied at the same time.

1.2 All five major hospitals in the districts of Gulu and Kitgum were supplied with corn soya blend, sugar, pulses and vegetable oil for supplementary and therapeutic feeding programmes.

1.3 Eighty people who had been abducted were recovered by the Ugandan Army at the border of Sudan and were handed over to the World Vision Trauma Centre in Gulu. Some of these were severely malnourished and dehydrated and were admitted into Lacor Hospital, for supplementary or therapeutic feeding.

C. SUDAN

1. UPDATE

1.1 WFP began a 200 metric ton airlift operation into Juba on 10 April to cover urgent food aid needs of 14,540 displaced persons and refugees. A total of 132 metric tons have been delivered to date. Displaced persons and refugees in Juba (caseload 162,000) are receiving full rations. Nutritional status in Juba is reported as stable.

1.2 During the month of April, a total of 166 metric tons of food commodities were distributed to 52,640 displaced persons and returnees in Equatoria. Beneficiaries received food in Mundri (6,000), Maridi (3,840), Yambio (7,000) and Yei (35,800). WFP has agreed to supply some 5,100 metric tons of food to partly meet the relief food needs of a total of 100,000 returnees in the Yei area from April through August. Some 350 metric tons of maize meal are currently en-route to the area via Uganda.

1.3 Due to extended delays in obtaining Government clearance for the departure of a barge loaded with 3,960 metric tons of food in Kosti since early April, WFP has decided to cancel the operation. Food intended for Juba will be utilised for other projects requiring immediate assistance, while the balance will be distributed in Tonga/Fanjak, pending government clearance.

1.4 The recent suspension of WFP and UNICEF humanitarian flights into Sudan airspace, under the Operation Lifeline Sudan umbrella, is the subject of high level discussions between the UN organizations concerned and the Government of Sudan.

D. SIERRA LEONE

1. UPDATE

1.1 On 6 May, two vehicles carrying UN and Concern Universal staff were caught in an ambush in Madina, approximately 5 miles outside of Makeni en route to Freetown. Gunfire hit both vehicles, leaving a UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs (DHA) driver dead and injuring the DHA head of operations in Sierra Leone. UN road movements to Bo and Kenema from Freetown have been suspended in light of this incident and other security problems at mile 91 in Makeni, where more than 32 metric tons of WFP bulgur wheat, vegetable oil and CSB were looted on 17 April following fighting between soldiers and Kamajors (traditional hunters who form militia units).

1.2 In Kenema, heavy fighting between government soldiers and Kamajors resulted in the temporary evacuation of WFP and other humanitarian agency staff to Freetown early this week. To date, a total of 25 people have been killed and 60 injured due to the fighting, which broke out on 2 May. Additionally, at least 180 people are reported displaced as a result of fire to houses. In response to open soldier and Kamajor fighting, President Kabbah has established a commission of inquiry to investigate the situation.

1.3 WFP is providing a three-day wet ration and a one-month resettlement ration to the first batch of 600 refugees returning from Liberia. A total of 2,400 refugees are expected to be repatriated by UNHCR over the next month. Meanwhile, WFP continues to distribute one-month resettlement rations to returning internally displaced persons from Freetown camps. From 16 April to date, 950 internally displaced persons have been resettled in Bonthe, Kenema and Kono districts.

(End WFP Emergency Report No. 19 of 1997 - May 9, 1997)


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 12, 1997


South Africa;
ANC Statement on the Meeting with the TRC


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Johannesburg - Deputy president Thabo Mbeki, national chairperson Jacob Zuma, acting secretary general Cheryl Carolus, Defence Minister Joe Modise and SACP secretary general Charles Nqcakula will lead a 20-person ANC delegation to submit the organisation's second major submission to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission in Cape Town on Monday, 12 May to Tuesday, 13 May.

The submission will in the main deal with the conduct of the movement's military and security and intelligence aspects within the context of a just war against apartheid - designated a crime against humanity by the international community. 

The submission to be made by deputy president Thabo Mbeki will also seek to answer honestly and as comprehensively as possible to questions posed by the TRC to the ANC on the conduct of our noble struggle for peace, freedom, democracy and justice.

The delegation includes amongst others, Ronnie Kasrils, premier Mathews Phosa, Mac Maharaj, Penuel Maduna, Dullah Omar, Nosiviwe Nqcakula, Joe Nhlanhla, Abu Baker, Joel Netshitenzhe, Ka Shabangu, Mongezi Tshongweni and Ronnie Mamoepa.

Issued by ANC National spokesman Ronnie Mamoepa.

Africa News


May 12, 1997


Western Sahara;
Sahara Weekly News Update (05/05 - 05/11)


BYLINE: Western Sahara Referendum Support Association


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Geneva - 03.05.97 Algerian declaration -- In an interview with the Algerian newspaper El Khabar, the Algerian foreign minister said that his country's policy regarding the Western Sahara issue is governed by two principles: "Any solution has to provide for self-determination, and a peaceful solution to the dispute would be in the interests of security and stability in the region. " He added that Algeria is awaiting "tangible proposals" from Baker. 

05.05.97 Solidarity

The Canarian Institute of Women together with the Canarian Women Organization of Solidarity with the Sahrawi Women and the Sahrawi People organized several activities with the participation of representatives of the National Union of Sahrawi Women. At last a twinning agreement was signed between the Institute of Women and the NUSW, in presence of the president of the Canary Islands government.

07-08.05.97 Colombia's president visits Morocco

Mr. E. Samper, president of Colombia and actual president of the Nonaligned Countries, held talks with King Hassan II concerning the political situation in Maghreb especially the Western Sahara conflict.

08.05.97 UN Secretary-General report

Mr. Kofi Annan recommends a four-month extension of the MINURSO mandate, which is due to expire at the end of May. After his recent "exploratory" mission in the region , Mr. Baker will return in June, and then make recommandations to the UN Secretary-General on the future of the disputed territory.

09.05.97 Chad suspends recognition of SADR

Chad prime minister announces his country "suspends its recognition of SADR" , accorded 1980. Mr. Koibla signed in Rabat an agreement creating a bilateral cooperation committee between Morocco and Chad. (MAP)

Prepared by ARSO (Association de soutien a un referendum libre et regulier au Sahara occidental). CP 2229, CH-2800 DELEMONT 2. Tel./Fax: 0041 32 422 87 17. E-mail: arso@hei.unige.ch. WWW: http://heiwww.unige.ch/arso/.

371 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
The mystique of Manchester United


BYLINE: Archie Henderson, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1307 words


 

Cape Town - They owe an allegiance to a sports club in an English industrial city, but you will find them across the world. In Cape Town they are especially strong. They are the fans of Manchester United Football Club.

And they are celebrating this week because, once again, United are the English league champions. 

These fans, who identify so closely with the club that they use the personal pronoun, often talk about "us" and "we" when they mean Manchester United FC, and hardly a season goes by without "them" winning some trophy or other. This year they won the league, ironically on a night when they weren't even in action.

On Thursday, when rivals Liverpool were beaten and Newcastle held to a draw, the league became theirs for the 20th time.

But Man United, as they are widely known, are not only champions. They are also the most famous soccer team in the world, probably the most popular, and a global marketing device.

Last year, sales by Manchester United Merchandising Ltd reached R381- million.

Across the world there are 150 000 official members of the supporters club and in South Africa there are 1 000 of them.

But the last figure is hardly an indication of the club's real support. Multiply the number by about 100, says local supporters' club chairman Bernard O'Neill, and you'll get a better idea of just how many people in this country back the Red Devils.

Two years ago, when Man United played fellow English Premier League team Arsenal at Ellis Park, the match attracted 63 000 spectators. Mr O'Neill, a Cape Town businessman, believes only 3 000 were Arsenal fans. "The rest were Man United fans, so that gives you some idea of how big we are in South Africa."

Kaizer Chiefs, South Africa's most popular club, has 23 000 card-carrying members, according to spokesman Farhad Garda. About two years ago, he says a poll found that their "unofficial" support was 1.5 million.

Local businessman Eduard Sjouerman, who imports soccer memorabilia, estimates that about 50 percent of the strong support for British soccer in this country is made up of Manchester United fans.

"Thirty percent are Liverpool supporters and the rest are spread between Arsenal, Spurs and some of the other clubs," he says.

The popularity of Man United partly explains why so many South African soccer fans have an obsession with the British game. The club's sales pitch also contributes to it. "It's an amazing market operation," says Mr Sjouerman, who imports jerseys, caps and key-rings from the Man United shop at their Old Trafford home ground. He even sells, if not in great volumes, Man United wall-paper and Man United women's underwear.

If marketing is one reason, sentiment may be another.

The air crash at Munich in 1958, in which eight of the club's players died, created an aura of triumph in adversity about the club which exists to this day.

Charles Rodgers of Umbro, which makes replica Man United jerseys and tracksuits, believes this is one of the reasons. "The air-crash tragedy has contributed to the sentiment surrounding the club. But, also, they keep on winning."

Does that explain the unusual diversity of support? From Bonteheuwel to Bishops-court, from Mowbray to Manenberg, there are Man United supporters. Where did this come from?

Veteran soccer administrator Vincent Baartjes believes the roots lie in the old political system. "This has come about over many years when South Africa was fed a diet of white football," he said. "People were led to believe that 'white was right' and it's a worrying factor especially in the Western Cape."

When Man United played Arsenal at Ellis Park, Mr Baartjes pointed out, the " hue of the crowd" was significant.

The implication is there: black soccer fans feel at home with Chiefs and Bafana Bafana. Can it be that white, coloured and Indian fans look to M-Net for their heroes?

Television obviously has played a big role. M-Net Supersport shows live matches in the English Premier League at least three times a week and researchers say those which feature Man United draw the biggest audiences.

Even before the TV era in South Africa, Andreas Gabriel, an official of local club Hellenic, showed recordings of British matches at the Whitehouse Hotel in Strand Street. The shows ran to packed houses at lunch times and in the evenings.

There, the seeds for a Man United mania may have been laid.

Michael Augustides, whose family owns Mike's Sport in Woodstock - one of the biggest soccer retailing outlets in South Africa - says: "The TV coverage has helped create the hype about British clubs."

The hype has also turned South Africa into a Man United customer. Andrew Seed, who is the strategic development manager of Manchester United Merchandising Ltd, says that outside Britain the biggest buyers are from Scandinavia, Ireland and the Far East.

"We see our brand name in global terms now. But we still have a long way to go and there is obviously a lot of potential in South Africa and the Middle East."

Among the individual customers is Stephen White, a 46-year-old Transnet worker, who has collected what amounts to a Man United shrine in his Parow home.

He has a great variety of jerseys, caps, shirts and trinkets, but pride of place goes to an item not on the Man U mail-order list - a club banner of pure silk which he bought in a small shop in the back streets of Hong Kong.

Another collector, although not on such a grand scale, is Clive Titus of Grassy Park, who remembers getting hooked on the club while a young teenager in District Six. "I got a book, Father Of Football, from the library," he recalls. "It was about Matt Busby (legendary manager of the club who survived the air crash) and I was hooked."

Whatever the reasons behind the Man United phenomenon, it knows no boundaries.

>From people like Graham Jones, a young, unemployed man from Retreat to Tessa Dasopatis, a businesswoman from Welgelegen, to Cecil Lindsay, 47, an electrician's assistant from Manenberg, they will tell you: "We are the champions."


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


372 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


Business and Finance;
Johnson now sole owner of Zevenwacht estate


BYLINE: Llewellyn Jones, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Cape Town - The Johnson Consortium, led by Johannesburg businessman Harold Johnson, has become the sole owner of Zevenwacht Wine Estate in a deal sanctioned by the High Court.

The consortium consists of Mr Johnson, his wife Denise and the Harold Johnson Family Trust.

The saga began in the early 1980s when the previous proprietor, Cape Town architect Gilbert Colyn, decided to raise finance from the public for various developments and the day-to-day running of the farm. 

The idea of owning a piece of the Cape winelands, albeit a rather small one, tempted many investors to pay between R1 and R3,50 a share for the 4,5- million or so shares Mr Colyn eventually sold to investors.

But by 1992 it had become apparent that the estate was hopelessly insolvent - and Zevenwacht's bankers foreclosed on its loans.

Mr Colyn's other business venture, architects Colyn and Meiring, was also liquidated about the same time.

This was when the estate first came to Mr Johnson's attention.

Mr Johnson, a Johannesburg businessman well known in the construction industry as the owner of Johnson Crane Hire, read the report of the the estate's pending liquidation in a newspaper and called the estate's bankers " to find out what the story was".

"I essentially bought Gilbert Colyn's 95 percent stake in the company by settling the company's debt," said Mr Johnson.

"If I hadn't paid the banks, the farm would have been liquidated.

"It was harvest time when I arrived and the previous vintage was still sitting in the vats because there were no bottles - so I bought bottles in order to bring in the harvest."

Mr Johnson has invested about R50-million in the farm, including the purchase price for his shares, over the past six years, establishing the estate as a premier tourist attraction.

This included a complete renovation of the original farm buildings with a first-class restaurant and building a plush "country inn", cottages and conference centre.

The most recent addition has been a cheese factory.

"The wine on its own will never be profitable - you need to add value- adding businesses," said Mr Johnson.

But the estate has remained unprofitable.

Indeed, Mr Johnson does not see it returning to profitability "within the next generation".

The losses were exacerbated by the cost of maintaining Zevenwacht Wine Estate as a public company and, with this in mind, Mr Johnson proposed the scheme of arrangement which saw the Johnson Consortium buy out the remaining five percent of the shares in the estate not controlled by his family.

The consortium offered 13c a share, which was accepted by 97 percent of the outside shareholders at a general meeting to ratify the scheme.

"I fell in love with the farm and the area," Mr Johnson said.

He has also bought Zevenrivieren, another farm on the other side of Stellenbosch, and recently sold Johnson Crane Hire to Murray & Roberts so that he could move to the winelands.

Zevenwacht, he says, is a bottomless pit, "but it's a very nice one".

But Mr Johnson has kept his finger in the profitable business pie with other ventures in and around Cape Town, most notably the Simon's Town waterfront development at the town's old pier.

The development will include a hotel, shops and restaurants, with negotiations in progress with a Victoria & Alfred Waterfront tavern to open a similar business in the Simon's Town development.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


373 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


South Africa;
Community leaders will back peace moves after all


BYLINE: Joseph Aranes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Cape Town - Influential Cape Town community leaders who refused to attend the recent launch of the Olympic peace initiative which included gangs have agreed to take part in the process and monitor crime.

This comes as a boost to the plan, which has been labelled "naive" because it includes gangsters.

People Against Gangsterism and Drugs (Pagad) has criticised the initiative, which aims to to bolster Cape Town's bid to host the 2004 Olympics by reducing crime . 

The group of community leaders withdrew from the Community Olympic Forum initiative at the last minute,, saying the launch was premature.

Mitchell's Plain Anglican priest Matt Esau, Community Peace Foundation executive director Nombulelo Mkefa, its programmes manager Sulayman Isaacs, businessman and former political activist Peter Jones and Gavin Pieterse president of the regional Black Management Forum, were initially asked to monitor the Olympic Peace Initiative.

Ms Mkefa said the Olympic bid could serve as a catalyst to help combat crime in the city centre and on the Cape Flats.

"We hold strong beliefs in the need for ongoing focus on the collective responsibility of Cape Town to integrate all communities into a common stream by the reconstruction and development of the total social fabric of communities.

"The people of the Cape Flats are historically traumatised through their physical and social dislocation from their own city. The culture of gangs and criminality have permeated these communities over many years," she said.

The group wished to help in the emergence of a comprehensive and holistic approach to the healing and normalisation of communities and accept the Olympic initiative as an opportunity to raise public awareness to reduce crime and violence.

Mr Jones said the Olympic peace initiative was part of the process the group would be monitoring but this would be done in consultation with various bodies such as the secretariat for safety and security, anti-crime forums, street committees and neighbourhood watches.

He said this initiative was not bound to any Olympic timetable but was a serious attempt at getting communities to become normal again.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


374 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


South Africa;
The shameful death of Thobeka Madayi (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Cape Town - A Khayelitsha woman died last week after being denied treatment at a clinic her husband had pushed her to in a wheelbarrow and after the failure of authorities to call an ambulance

It was a horror image from the old South Africa: a desperate Khayelitsha husband loaded his sick wife onto a wheelbarrow and took her to a clinic where she was denied treatment because the establishment was about to close for the day. Instead of summoning an ambulance to take the "chronically terminally ill" woman directly to hospital, authorities urged the husband to take her to a larger 24-hour clinic from where a routine ambulance service ferried patients to hospital. In the nightmare journey by wheelbarrow to the second clinic, the woman died. 

In the past, many black patients suffered and died because the petty bureaucratic rules of apartheid forbad white hospitals and ambulances to attend to them. It matters little to the bereaved family of Thobeka Madayi, or to the Khayelitsha community, that her undignified and traumatic death last week was not the result of racial laws. In large measure it was caused nevertheless by the callous enforcement of petty bureaucracy; by placing rules above the compassionate treatment of people in urgent need of help.

It is widely known that the health care system is in the process of radical transformation and that it is operating under severe budget constraints. And there is much sympathy for the staff at day hospitals who are battling to cope with an influx of patients following the introduction of free primary health care. But surely a woman who had been terminally ill for a long time could have been made comfortable at the first day hospital until an ambulance arrived?

Health Minister Ebrahim Rasool has said that the top priority for the provincial health service is to make it more caring. Nothing could illustrate the urgent need for this more compellingly, than the shameful death of Thobeka Mayani.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


375 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


South Africa;
City centre the home of crime in Cape Town


BYLINE: Lindsat Barnes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Cape Town - Surprising new crime trends have emerged in Cape Town's suburbs with the release of police statistics this month.

They show Cape Town central reported the highest number of incidents by far 1 934 for seven types of crimes committed from January to March this year followed by Mitchell's Plain (1 553 ), Woodstock (664), Claremont (658), Sea Point (597), Bellville South (516) and Khayelitsha (512).

Statistics on murder, rape, armed robbery, attempted murder, residential burglaries, business break-ins and theft out of motor vehicles were collected at 19 police stations in the Peninsula area. 

Crime figures for the first three months of this year were compared with the same period in 1995 and 1996.

Of the seven crimes surveyed in the city centre, 70 percent of incidents involved theft out of motor vehicles, followed by theft from residences and businesses.

But figures showed this was a 23 percent decrease on last year. Armed robberies were also down 30 percent on 1996 figures.

Mitchell's Plain has shown an overall drop in crime so far this year but violent crime remains rampant, along with theft from houses and cars.

Khayelitsha has particularly high figures for murder, attempted murder, armed robbery and rape, and low rates for theft from motor vehicles and businesses. Most of the murders occur in or near the 1 000-odd illegal shebeens, and police are planning to tighten control of them, station commander Hennie Haarhof said.

Khayelitsha's shocking rape statistics 102 incidents between January and March this year are closely followed by Mitchell's Plain, Nyanga, Bellville South and Guguletu, while figures remain high for Manenberg, Bishop Lavis, the city centre, Elsies River and Grassy Park. The suburbs of Rondebosch, Kirstenhof and Camps Bay reported the lowest rape statistics.

Nyanga and Guguletu are the third and fourth most violent suburbs, according to the police figures, yet their overall crime rates are relatively low. This was because instead of reporting to police, Guguletu residents tended to rely on street committees to solve problems of petty theft, assault and malicious damage to property, head of the crime prevention unit, Bertie Brink, said.

Taxi violence accounts for most of the violence perpetrated in Nyanga, but a new police strategy is expected to make a dent in these figures, head of communications Robbie Robberts said.

Crime levels had also taken a knock from the efforts of a strong community policing forum and the effective functioning of the community-based peace and development project, he said.

Levels of violence remain high in Bishop Lavis and Elsies River with figures for attempted murder up this year, but murder rates have declined.

Bellville South was the sixth most violent of the suburbs surveyed and also had high figures for house break-ins and theft out of motor vehicles. Yet the levels of most of the measured crimes have dropped in the are over the last three years.

Murders in Manenberg have stabilised nine each for the first three months of 1996 and this year, compared with 25 in 1995. But attempted murders, armed robberies and rape statistics remain high.

In the southern suburb of Claremont, armed robberies and house break-ins have increased steadily in the past three years, while the risk of murder or rape remains fairly low.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.
