Africa News


May 12, 1997


South Africa;
'Disinformation used to discredit, demonise MK'


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Cape Town - The apartheid government actively used "disinformation" against the movement, the ANC report to the Truth Commission stated.

"No effort was spared to discredit and demonise Umkhonto we Sizwe (MK), and certain attacks on civilian targets portrayed as the work of MK were carried out by the regime," said the report. 

The ANC cited the 1988 hand-grenade attack on Labour Party leader Allan Hendrickse's home: "In 1992 the SA Police took legal action against Vrye Weekblad to prevent it publishing allegations that police were directly involved in this attack. Law and Order Minister Hernus Kriel then twice avoided answering questions, put to him in parliament, as to whether the State had been responsible." n Mr Kriel is now Western Cape premier.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


377 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


South Africa;
Pretoria bomb 'planned as highly visible attack on military'


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 146 words


 

Cape Town - The 1983 Pretoria car-bomb attack - in which 19 people died - followed a raid by the security forces into Lesotho and the assassination of Ruth First in Maputo, the ANC said in its report.

Giving the Pretoria attack as a case study of an Umkhonto weSizwe operation, the report said the objective was to carry out a highly visible attack against SA Defence Force personnel in uniform.

The report said "discussions were held on the possible loss of civilian life after careful consideration, it was decided by (then ANC president) Oliver Tambo that Special Operations should proceed with the operation, taking great care to ensure that the target was unmistakably military".


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


378 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


South Africa;
Quatro only long-term ANC prison camp


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Cape Town - The ANC's Morris Seabelo Rehabilitation Centre in Angola - also known as Camp 32 or Quatro - was the only camp at which prisoners were held for significant periods, the ANC report stated.

It was 200km north of Luanda, between two MK training camps and, because of the war and the condition of the road, took four hours to reach from the Angolan capital. 

None of the three camps had running water.

"Difficulties with transport , food, water and medical supplies were general in the region, and common to all camps. "The camp (32) did have a truck, but when it broke down it was not replaced.

"In the absence of transport, inmates had to push a water tank to the nearest source of water, a river about three kilometres away."

Camp 32 had no doctor but relied on some medical orderlies - who were not equipped to deal with complex medical problems. "Overcrowding and the unhealthy conditions in the cells created conditions for disease and did result in some deaths - although most deaths happened because of malaria."

The problem of overcrowding at Camp 32 got "steadily worse" over the years, before being reviewed in 1987. There were certain cases of the abuse of prisoners by guards belonging to the ANC's Department of Security and Intelligence, who resented what they considered to be a "dead-end" posting at the camp.

All ANC camps in Angola, including Camp 32, were closed down in 1989 and all but 32 prisoners were released. These prisoners were transferred to a jail in Uganda and released and allowed to return to South Africa in 1991, the ANC report stated.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


379 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


South Africa;
Six cadres died after being beaten, TRC told


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Cape Town - Six Umkhonto weSizwe members died between 1979 and 1981 after being beaten and their names have been handed to the Truth Commission, the African National Congress report states.

One, Joel Mahlatini, was severely beaten on the orders of his camp commander, Kenneth Mahamba, and was dead on arrival at Camp 32 (Quatro). 

The ANC's leadership had viewed this incident so seriously that it instituted an investigation which resulted in a spy network - of which Mahamba was a leading member - being uncovered, it claimed.

This led to the execution of Mahamba and three others and the execution of a further four spies.

"There were other cases over the years of executions of agents a list of these names has been submitted," the ANC said. Serious breaches of discipline by MK members at times resulted in capital punishment, but there had been no cases of summary or unauthorised execution.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


380 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


South Africa;
Apartheid profiteers 'must pay reparation'


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Cape Town - South Africans who benefited under apartheid should be made to pay reparations to victims, says the latest African National Congress report to the Truth Commission.

The ANC suggests that the doctrine of "odious debt" be applied to ensure those who benefited directly from apartheid helped to contribute to a fund from which reparations could be made to victims. 

The ANC said in its report it believed firmly that reparations were necessary, particularly to victims of gross human rights abuses.

"Unless there are meaningful reparations, the process of ensuring justice and reconciliation will be flawed." Reparations could include such things as special pensions, educational grants, skills training, medical aid, welfare, special medals, memorials and a museum in memory of those who had suffered injustices.

Available resources would never be sufficient to provide reasonable reparations, the ANC said.

"Nonetheless, there is widespread recognition that there are individuals and strata within our society and abroad who have directly benefited from the system which was sustained by apartheid repression."

The Truth Commission should consider recommending the application of the " odious debt" doctrine to help mobilise resources for reparations.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


381 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


South Africa;
ANC unit's plot to kill Buthelezi


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Cape Town - An African National Congress unit planned to assassinate Inkatha Freedom Party leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi - but the plan was stopped by the ANC's leadership as soon as it found out about it - Deputy-President Thabo Mbeki told the Truth Commission today.

The admission is made in a 139-page document presented to the commission in Cape Town.

"When ANC headquarters found out, it countermanded this (plan) and this operation was never carried out," Mr Mbeki said. The ANC leadership had never taken a formal decision to attack the IFP militarily, he said. 

"We did not, could not, regard the IFP and its members as legitimate military targets and at no stage was a decision taken to attack the IFP," Mr Mbeki said. In the IFP's submission to the Truth Commission last year, Chief Buthelezi provided substantial details of the 1986 assassination plot.

The report also admits that former African National Congress president Oliver Tambo personally approved the 1983 car-bombing of air force headquarters in Church Street, Pretoria, in which 19 people died and more than 200 were injured.

The report also contains some details of 15 ANC members executed for spying or mutiny and nine members publicly executed in Angola for murder and the rape of Angolan women. It gives some background detail of deaths in its Angolan camps, at least seven of which were the result of severe beatings, and describes conditions in the camps and the response of the organisation's leadership to problems.

The report, in which the ANC responds to questions put by the commission following its first submission during the special hearing for political parties last year, was presented by ANC deputy-president Thabo Mbeki, who led a 20-member delegation of party heavyweights.

It includes 33 pages of responses to questions and requests for elaboration by the Truth Commission. It deals with "necklacing" murders, operations by the ANC's military wing, Umkhonto weSizwe (MK), civilian targets, its use of landmines in border areas and allegations of "excesses" against its cadres and captured agents, and what steps were taken to prevent such excesses.

The ANC repeats its earlier insistence that its leadership had strongly condemned some of the methods chosen to kill alleged informers and collaborators, particularly necklacing - burning victims with a petrol-filled tyre. "The extent to which the National Party has consistently tried to use the phenomenon of 'necklacing' to damage the ANC raised the suspicion that they were involved in some of these incidents," the report states.

Included as appendices are a list of hundreds of MK operations in which very brief details of dates, places and events are provided, a list of about 100 incidents of "armed action" - including several bomb attacks on Wimpy Bars, amusement arcades and snack bars in 1988 for which responsibility is either uncertain or specifically denied.

Also included are case studies of 12 agents of the apartheid government uncovered by the ANC. South Africans among the 12 who are still living are identified only by "travelling names" but the ANC said it would provide real names if the TRC wanted these for specific investigations.

The ANC said it was not possible to give a detailed account of every MK operation, but that more details would be available in amnesty applications. " We did not keep records of this nature, mainly for security reasons," the report stated.

It was evident MK had acted with "great restraint". It had sought to avoid civilian injury and death but mistakes had been made. There had been a number of attacks not in line with ANC policy, some of which were the result of anger at the "unprecedented violence" in the 1980s.

The ANC took collective responsibility for all bona fide MK operations. It acknowledged that the car-bombing of the Magoo's and Why Not bars in Durban was an official MK operation. It described it as one of the operations which was "apparently" senseless and caused civilian deaths but which was in fact aimed at police or SADF members.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


382 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


Zaire;
Churches Rush Aid to Kisangani


BYLINE: Action by Churches Together(ACT)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Geneva - At noon today Monday, ACT-Norwegian Church Aid send a first flight of 13 tons of essential medicine to Kisangani in Eastern Zaire. In Kisangani a local church NGO, Cepza-Celpa, will be responsible for the distribution of the medicine to Rwandan refugees as well as internally displaced Zairian in and around Kisangani.

Especially ACT has been asked to provide some of the high energy biscuits for two camps with respectively 500 and 200 Rwandan children awaiting repatriation. And while the medical situation in Kisangani is being covered by the combined actions of several NGOs, Cepza-Celpa and the local churches are among the few who can address the needs for medicine in areas outside the town of Kisangani. 

A further 7 tons of medicine and 20 tons of high energy biscuits will be flown to Kisangani in the coming days to be distributed through the same channels. In a separate move ACT International is looking into procuring and transporting 24 tons of sugar and a 120 tons of Unimix to Kisangani as a contribution to the World Food Programme pipeline for the most vulnerable of the remaining Rwandan refugees. Although the airlifting of refugees back to Rwanda is progressing well there is a need to feed a substantial number of refugees in and around Kisangani while they await transport back home.

Some of the remaining refugees are in very critical conditions. Apart from the approximately 30.000 refugees at Biaro, press reports today said that 5. 000 to 6.000 refugees have been found at a village 82 kilometers south of Kisangani. A UNHCR official said to Reuters that *many people have died there and many more are on the verge of death*.

Every day about 1.700 - 2.000 refugees return by the UN airlift to Rwanda which has by now brought close to 20.000 refugees back over the last weeks. The majority of the returnees are in tolerable conditions, but still there are about 7 death among the returnees every day, mainly due to the ordeals they have gone through in Zaire. In Rwanda ACT/LWF is involved in supplying the refugees with food and non-food items like blankets, jerry cans and kitchen sets. These things are distributed by UNHCR and NGOs but all originate from ACT/LWF run warehouses across Rwanda.

For further information, please contact: ACT Co-ordinator, Miriam Lutz (phone ++41 22 791 6032 or mobile phone ++ 41 89 203 6055) or ACT Communications Officer, Nils Carstensen (phone +41 22 791 6039 or mobile phone ++ 41 79 358 31 71)

Ecumenical Centre / 150, route de Ferney / P.O. Box 2100 / 1211 Geneva 2 / Switzerland. Phone: ++41-22-791.60.33 / Fax: ++41-22-791.65.06 / E-mail: act@wcc-coe.org / Telex: 415 730 OIK CH


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


383 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 12, 1997


United States and Africa;
Consolidated Great Lakes Report No. 34


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 4267 words


 

Washington DC - GREAT LAKES - Complex Emergency Situation Report #34, Fiscal Year (FY)1997, May 9, 1997. Note: The last situation report was dated May 2, 1997.

ZAIRE

Background

In mid-October 1996, fighting broke out in South Kivu, Zaire between the Zairian army (FAZ) and the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (Alliance) led by Laurent Kabila. The fighting caused Rwandan and Burundian refugees to flee, forcing over 700,000 Rwandans and 62,000 Burundians to repatriate by the end of 1996. Hundreds of thousands of refugees also fled west, scattering in small groups deeper into Zaire. The fighting spread north, west, and south, with the Alliance rapidly gaining territory on all fronts. The Alliance now controls most of Zaire and is poised to seize Kinshasa.

Diplomacy and Peace Talks

Kinshasa has remained generally quiet, amid apprehension that FAZ troops may loot the city before the Alliance launches its final drive. On May 4 Alliance leader Kabila and President Mobutu met for the first time aboard a South African navy ship docked at Pointe Noire, Congo. The meeting was chaired by South African president Nelson Mandela and U.N./Organization of African Unity (OAU) mediator Mohamed Sahnoun was also present. Although Mobutu offered to turn over power to an interim figure who would be authorized to organize elections, Kabila insisted that the Alliance have transitional authority. Both sides agreed to meet again in about eight days. 

Mobutu flew to Gabon on May 7 to attend a meeting of regional leaders. Bill Richardson, U.S. Ambassador to the U.N., arrived in the region on April 28. Richardson's mission is to contribute to diplomatic efforts to bring Kabila and Mobutu together for talks, and to help create conditions for a "soft landing" -- his description for the peaceful transfer of power following the Alliance's arrival in Kinshasa. Richardson is also conveying the USG's increasing concern about alleged human rights abuses in Zaire and the repatriation effort. On May 5, Richardson met with Vice-President Paul Kagame in Kigali and with Kabila in Lubumbashi, and flew to Botswana on May 6 to meet with Ugandan president Yoweri Museveni.

Acrimony, Fuel Shortages, Accidents

On April 27, the Alliance agreed to a new repatriation plan for the refugees who had gathered along the rail line south of Kisangani. The plan stipulated that the U.N. had 60 days from May 1 to move all the refugees from Eastern Zaire. Kabila subsequently called the deadline flexible, as long as there was a good-faith effort underway to repatriate the refugees.

Since April 29, when the first Rwandans were flown from Kisangani, 12,024 Rwandan refugees have been flown to Kigali, Cyangugu, and Bukavu airports in Rwanda as of May 7. The number is notable, given the obstacles that have arisen in the path of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in the past week. On May 1, the Government of Rwanda (GOR) declared it "objects to the deliberate move by the U.N. to prolong the suffering of the Rwandan refugees; that the repatriation from Eastern Zaire be handled with utmost urgency," and that with resources from the international community, it could undertake the repatriation operation itself, completing it in two weeks.

Then, from May 2 through May 4, repatriation flights were hampered by a regional aviation fuel shortage. The shortage was due to the rejection of a fuel delivery, attributed to poor quality, at a regional depot in Kenya. By May 5, the shortage had eased, and that day a record 2,606 refugees flew on ten sorties to Rwanda. Within hours more obstacles impeded the repatriation. On May 4, 91 Rwandan refugees, including women and children, were crushed or smothered to death on a train that became overloaded at Biaro, at km 41 on the Kisangani- Ubundu railroad. Another 47 refugees were injured during the trip, and an unknown number are believed to have died falling off the packed train. On May 5, the scheduled train trip was cancelled because of the accident; however, the Alliance transported 11 truckloads of refugees to the railhead at Lubunga, km 0, without UNHCR coordination. On May 7, the relief train broke down, and consequently only several hundred refugees were taken to the Kisangani transit center for onward transport to Rwanda.

To hasten repatriation, the UNHCR on May 7 added six more trucks to its fleet of 22, and on May 8 added a fourth Ilyushin-76, based in Entebbe. As the repatriation operation proceeded in fits and starts, Dr. Ephraim Kabaija, the Government of Rwanda (GOR) advisor on refugees, charged on May 6 that the UNHCR's "gross inefficiency and mismanagement" had been responsible for the deaths of refugees on the train from Biaro.

Alliance-UN Efforts to Cooperate

On May 2, Moise Nyarugabo, Kabila's chief of staff, met with UNHCR officials in Kisangani and agreed to give the UNHCR control and management of the truck, train, and ferry movements along the rail line. Nyarugabo also agreed to permit U.N. and relief organizations to provide emergency lifesaving assistance to the refugees, and to erect temporary structures at Biaro; and to allow the severely ill and wounded refugees access to Kisangani general hospital.

After Nyarugabo's meeting in Kisangani, the UNHCR and relief agencies worked to improve conditions at Biaro. Oxfam installed a temporary water treatment station; Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) set up triage teams to identify the refugees who required immediate evacuation due to gunshot and machete wounds or malnutrition; the World Food Program (WFP), local Red Cross, and Caritas began food distributions to both refugees and local Zairians, and built communal kitchens for wet feeding; UNICEF and Save the Children (SCF) identified and began transporting unaccompanied children (UAC).

Alliance Dissatisfaction and Cooperation

The relief community is concerned that recent local radio broadcasts in Kisangani are hostile to the presence of the refugees and to the assistance they receive. A May 7 broadcast criticized the UNHCR for defending the refugees, while local Zairians continued to be victimized by their presence. Alliance soldiers continue to deny humanitarian workers access to the rail line below km 42. No one from the international community has been permitted below km 42 since April 20.

More encouraging news also emerged on May 7, however. At a meeting with U.N. and NGO representatives and a member of the USAID/Disaster Assistance Response Team (DART), the vice-governor of Haut-Zaire province in Kisangani announced that 11 Alliance liaison officers would be assigned to work in Kisangani in two-man teams at Biaro camp, the ferry crossing, the transit center, and the international airport. The vice-governor has also announced that a weekly meeting will be held to review the coordination, and investigation of the May 4 train deaths revealed that neither the Alliance nor the relief community could be singled out for blame.

In all, about half of the 91,000 refugees who had gathered along the 125-km corridor last month are unaccounted for. Since the Alliance reopened the corridor, surviving refugees have stated that armed, uniformed men massacred refugees in the corridor. In the face of international criticism, Kabila went to Kisangani on April 27 to meet with UNHCR officials. He denied that his troops had killed refugees. U.N., European, and USG officials, including Ambassador Richardson, however, have continued to press the Alliance on the importance of guarding the refugees' human rights.

Other Refugees in Zaire

The WFP has dispatched a mission to assess the composition and needs of about 51,000 Rwandan refugees who have gathered in and around Mbandaka, Equateur province, near Congo. They are believed to be refugees who had fled Tingi-Tingi in March. There are reportedly three clusters: 16,100 refugees are in Wenji; 15 km from Mbandaka; 25,000 are in Ingende; and 10,000 are in Lola, near Ingende. Some may have begun to cross the Zaire River into Congo. WFP plans to distribute 765 MT of food from river barges at Mbandaka. There are unconfirmed reports that local authorities disarmed 1,200 of the refugees and isolated them on an island in the river. In Brazzaville, about 400 Rwandan refugees have arrived, joined by 5,000 other Rwandan, Burundian, and Zairian refugees. Near the Angolan border in Zaire there are about 7,000 Rwandan refugees.

Internally Displaced Returning

>From April 7 to May 5, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and U.N. agencies returned about 3,800 internally displaced persons (IDPs) from Kisangani to Goma and Bukavu. On May 4, Caritas reported that its survey of remaining IDPs in the Kisangani area showed there were only 3,500 in a 100 km radius of the city, and there may be fewer than 1,000 IDPs left to be airlifted. It plans to end its air service between Goma and Bukavu by this weekend. A USAID/DART field officer visited Punia on April 29 and found 511 Rwandan refugees. Most were in good condition and were eager to return home. There were also 300 IDPs who were in good health and who intend to return home. UNHCR hopes to secure a Buffalo aircraft that would repatriate the refugees.

Human Rights

An advance team for a U.N. commission of inquiry met with the Alliance justice minister in Lubumbashi this week. Roberto Garreton, the U.N. special rapporteur on human rights in Zaire, is waiting in Kigali with a team of nine investigators, including forensic specialists, for Alliance permission to enter eastern Zaire. Their mission follows Garreton's April 2 report on a fact- finding mission he conducted in Eastern Zaire in late March. His report mentioned 40 alleged cases of mass murders, summary executions, and enforced disappearances in Alliance-controlled territory, allegedly committed by Alliance troops as well as ex-FAR/Interahamwe members. The mission follows a U.N. Security Council resolution that calls for an investigation of human rights abuses in Eastern Zaire since September 1996.

In late April, the secretary-general of the U.N. Security Council issued a statement, noting its alarm over human rights abuses in Eastern Zaire, and on April 28, the secretary-general of the OAU expressed "deep concern" about reports of killings of refugees in Eastern Zaire.

RWANDA

Massacre in Gisenyi Prefecture Seventeen schoolgirls, a Belgian religious lay worker, and four residents were murdered by armed men, allegedly members of the Interahamwe on April 28 in Satinsyi commune, Gisenyi prefecture. The attack echoed an assault in March in Kibuye prefecture. In both cases, the attackers reportedly ordered the victims to separate by ethnicity. When they refused, the attackers opened fire on everyone. On May 2, Rwandan state radio reported that 19 of 150 suspects in the attack had been killed by security forces in the area.

Human Rights Violations Cited

The Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda (HRFOR) reported that in the first three months of 1997, 45 genocide survivors and persons associated with them were killed, and that 28 persons were killed in three incidents, presumably because of their Tutsi ethnicity. HRFOR also noted a "significant number" of killings by army troops occurred while the victims were allegedly trying to evade arrest, or escape. While noting that the start of the genocide trials were an important step to overcome a culture of impunity, HRFOR also recommended that the GOR improve conditions of detention; review its system of arrest and detention; provide HRFOR with full and confidential access to persons in military detention; strengthen the judiciary, and promote human rights.

BURUNDI

Reports of Heavy Fighting in the South

Two days of heavy fighting between rebels and government forces in Rutana province led the International Medical Corps (IMC) to evacuate six of its staff to Bujumbura on May 4. On April 27, rebels allegedly killed 36 students and seven staff, and wounded another 34, in Buta, near Rutana. During the last week, rebel attacks reportedly took place along National Route 3, which runs north and south of Rumonge, in Bururi province. There are also reports of recent fighting in Makamba town, capital of Makamba province. The fighting in southern Burundi is noteworthy because Rutana, Bururi, and Makamba provinces have traditionally been quiet and in the Buyoya government's firm control. On May 2 in Mutambu, Bujumbura Rural province, a car exploded when it went over an anti-tank mine, killing a Swiss nun and the Burundian driver.

Regroupment Policy Criticized

The African leaders at the April 16 Arusha summit called for the disbandment of the regroupment camps, which the Buyoya government began in Karuzi province in March 1996. The practice has spread to Bujumbura Rurale, Bururi, Makamba, Kayanza, Cibitoke, Bubanza, and Muramvya over the past year.

On April 21, the State Department criticized the Buyoya government's regroupment policy for the second time in one month. Its statement described the U.S. Ambassador's visit to camps in Kayanza and Karuzi provinces in the previous week, where he encountered malnutrition and disease. The USG will provide humanitarian assistance to the regroupment camps only under the following conditions: Aid will not be given immediately upon the formation of the camps; a needs assessment must precede any assistance; aid will be restricted to limited and temporary emergency work; and humanitarian workers' safety and freedom of movement must be guaranteed during the project.

On April 28, the WFP temporarily halted distribution of BHR/Food For Peace (FFP) P.L. 480 emergency Title II food to the Karuzi regroupment camps because the military governor of the province had repeatedly failed to allow the WFP to conduct an assessment. The food shipments, destined for about 74, 000 people in six regroupment camps in the province, resumed after the governor accepted that distributions would be based strictly on need, after thorough assessments.

Buyoya Shuffles Cabinet

On May 4, Major Pierre Buyoya, the Burundian leader, replaced six ministers and changed the portfolios of three others. The most important posts of defense, interior, foreign affairs, and constitutional reform remain unchanged. The cabinet shuffle is the first since Buyoya named his government last August.

Border Tensions with Tanzania

Buyoya sent a delegation, led by his health minister, to Tanzania on May 3- 4 to discuss border security with Tanzanian president Benjamin Mkapa. A Burundian military spokesman claimed on May 5 that Burundian rebels based in Tanzania had caused 3,000 peasants to flee their homes and take refuge in government buildings.

TANZANIA

Nearly 400,000 Refugees

As of April 1, Tanzania was host to 368,000 refugees, according to the United Nations Department of Humanitarian Affairs (UNDHA). Of the total, about 90,000 were Zairians and 278,000 were Burundians.

In Nyaragusu, some 3,000 Zairians, many of whom originate from the Uvira region, are registered to return to Zaire, and 1,000 of their compatriots from Lugufu have also requested permission to return. To date, about 5,000 Zairians have reportedly returned to Uvira on their own. In recent weeks, the number of Zairian arrivals has dramatically dwindled.

Recent fluctuations in the number of Burundian refugees into and out of Tanzania are largely the result of fighting in the Ngara refugee camps in Tanzania, along the northern border of Burundi, and fighting in Bururi and Makamba provinces in southern Burundi. Unrest in the Tanzanian camps led 6, 025 refugees to return to Burundi between March 1 and April 24, while on April 28 alone, about 7,000 Burundians entered Tanzania after fleeing unrest in southern Burundi.

Wounded Burundians in Kigoma hospital

At least 61 wounded Burundians, were admitted to the hospital in Kigoma after they fled fighting in Burundi, a Tanzanian newspaper reported on May 5. According to the account, in which several of the wounded were quoted, some of the victims were caught in crossfire between Burundian army (FAB) troops and rebels in Makamba and Bururi provinces. Others had been singled out by FAB soldiers, who suspected them of disloyalty.

USG ASSISTANCE

BHR/OFDA deployed a USAID/DART to Kigali, Rwanda from October 26, 1996 to February 26, 1997, and an assessment team to Zaire from February 12 to 26. The current USAID/DART was deployed on March 14, and has an information officer in Nairobi and field offices in Goma and Kisangani.

Africa News


May 12, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Urges Civilians to Leave Zaire


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Washington - Text of questions and answers by State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns on Zaire at the Department's daily briefing May 12.

QUESTION: You want to swing over to Zaire and let us know if Kinshasa is about to fall or whatever?

MR. BURNS: Okay, Barry, what I can tell you is that we hope very much that the South African Government's proposal to have President Mobutu and Mr. Kabila meet on a South African naval vessel on Wednesday, we hope that that meeting is held. We hope that the two leaders can agree on a peaceful transition in Zaire. 

There has been a lot of turbulence over the weekend, a lot of rumors in Kinshasa. Because of the uncertainty in Zaire, Ambassador Simpson, the United States Ambassador to Zaire, has decided to reduce American staff further at our embassy in Kinshasa from 37 people to 25. So we are down to a core of 25 people. Most of the people have left overnight by ferry to Brazzaville, by commercial aircraft to other African capitals and to Europe. We think this is a prudent move given the fact that fighting is drawing nearer to Kinshasa. The security situation is stable today. Our embassy does not report anything untoward today, but you never know.

We are taking all appropriate precautions to safeguard the official Americans in Zaire. We continue to ask the private American community, which numbers still roughly 300 people, John?

MR. DINGER: Three hundred twenty-five.

MR. BURNS: Three hundred twenty-five people, we urge those people to leave - business people, NGO's, missionaries. The situation is too precarious, too unstable for them to stay. We have a travel advisory out to that effect, and we reaffirm that today.

QUESTION: It sounds like over 120 people have left in the last week or two. Is that about right?

MR. BURNS: Official Americans?

QUESTION: No, as I recall, the last time I looked at this, there were 440 of all stripes.

MR. BURNS: That's right, roughly. We don't have specific numbers, George, at least not right now. But I think that's true that the numbers have declined. That is a good thing. People ought not to take chances in a situation like this.

Now, we hope that the transfer of power is going to be peaceful, but that is not certain. The rebel army continues to march towards the capital. It is unclear whether or not this meeting will be held on Wednesday. It is unclear what the Zairian Army in Kinshasa will do, currently in its barracks. It doesn't have a great track record about civil law and order in the past. We are mindful of that. There have been a lot of rumors over the weekend, as you know, including some rumors that the Zairian Government was prepared to kill expatriates in order to draw in foreign intervention forces. Now, we don't believe that rumor was true, but we have a responsibility to take it seriously.

So we have taken some very significant security precautions over the weekend, and we have asked these people to leave. So we're down to 25 official Americans.

QUESTION: What about the rumors of looting in the capital?

MR. BURNS: We saw the reports today, but our embassy has not reported anything like that. They report a quiet city. But it is a big city, so I'm not sure they know everything that is happening all around the city.

QUESTION: Would you say these rumors are partially responsible for this draw-down of a dozen or so?

MR. BURNS: It's certainly one of the factors, but not the only factor, yes. We have a fundamental responsibility to protect our people. As you know, Secretary Albright has been watching this daily. She's asked for a daily report on the security situation at our embassy in Kinshasa for two and a half, three weeks now. We just feel, given the fact that the endgame is approaching in Zaire, the transfer of power is going to happen one way or the other, we ought to be down to the absolute minimum number of people that Ambassador Simpson needs to run his embassy.

We are going to keep the embassy open, obviously as long as possible. We would like to keep it open because the United States ought to be represented when the transition occurs. Laura?

QUESTION: The number of private Americans in the country still seems to be fairly high given these rumors that you have referred to surfacing over the weekend. Is there some other effort, you know, beyond your making the call from the podium and encouraging Americans to leave there or not to travel there at all? Are there any phone calls going out from the embassy to encourage the Americans to leave before it becomes a situation where an evacuation might be necessary?

MR. BURNS: Well, we have encouraged American citizens to leave for many months. We are not in a position to force American citizens to leave Zaire. Each American has to make his or her own decision about their own personal welfare. There are missionaries there who believe, obviously, that they are doing necessary work. There are business people there who are chasing profits, chasing contracts, and obviously they and their companies have decided it is worth the risk.

We think it is a high risk, frankly. In a situation like this, in a country like this where you have a major, potent rebel force which is marching on the capital; where you have a rather undisciplined central government Army with a very poor track record in its barracks in Kinshasa, we cannot predict what is going to happen. So our message is clear as a bell to the American private community -- get out of Zaire. Get out of Zaire before you find yourself in harm's way. They ought to listen to that message.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


385 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


Science and Health;
New twist in CITES battle


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Windhoek - Namibia's bid to have its elephant population downgraded at the upcoming CITES conference has received a significant boost with a major wildlife organisation giving support to Namibia's proposals.

Traffic, the wildlife trade monitoring programme of the WWF World Wide Fund for Nature and the World Conservation Union, has announced its qualified backing for the proposals of Namibia, Zimbabwe and Botswana.

The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species summit takes place in Harare, Zimbabwe, in June. 

Hoping to end the seven-year international commercial trade ban in elephants and elephant products, the three SADC countries have petitioned CITES to move their elephant populations from Appendix I to Appendix II.

"Traffic recommends that the 136-country strong Convention accept the three southern African proposals but impose a zero quota for trade in ivory from each country, and for trade in elephant hides from Zimbabwe," a statement from Traffic said.

The reputable conservation organisation said this would allow trade in live animals and hunting trophies, "but not in elephant ivory or hides for the time being".

"Although it is premature for ivory to be traded now, it's clearly time to reward good conservation," said Tom Milliken, the Director of Traffic's programme for east and southern Africa said.

"In Botswana, Namibia, and Zimbabwe, the elephant is an abundant species and clearly does not meet the criteria for the highest level of protection under CITES."

Traffic's decision comes in the wake of a CITES-commissioned report by a Panel of Experts which found that the three countries' elephant populations did not meet the biological criteria for continued listing on Appendix I, which prohibits international commercial trade in endangered species.

"Limited trade in live animals and sport hunting trophies and other products in the future would help Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe recoup part of their considerable investment in conserving elephant populations.

All countries have undertaken to return revenues to local communities living among elephants."

Traffic noted that the cost of elephant protection and management was high, estimated at US$200 per square kilometre, "a burden most African countries bear alone with great difficulty".

Namibia is highly commended by Traffic, which said the country had passed all the precautionary requirements for its elephant populations to be transferred to Appendix II, according to the CITES report.

However, Traffic said, Botswana needed to improve its control over ivory stocks, while Zimbabwe needed stricter implementation of domestic controls on trade in ivory. "Both countries have asked Traffic to help put corrective measures in place."

On the importing side, the CITES panel found domestic ivory trade controls in Japan to require improvements at the retail level in order to prevent the infiltration of ivory products from illegal sources.

Traffic, in a recently released report on domestic ivory trade controls in Asia, confirmed this finding.

Once Botswana, Zimbabwe and Japan addressed the concerns noted in the CITES report, Traffic said it believed trade in ivory could resume subject to strict regulatory measures. The London-based Environmental Investigation Agency (EIA) has come out vehemently against the three countries' bid to have the elephant downlisted and is mustering opposition to the move ahead of the CITES meeting.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


386 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


Mali;
Konare Assured Of Second Term In Office


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

BAMAKO, Mali (PANA) - President Alpha Oumar Konare has virtually been assured of a second term in Office as President of Mali, after winning more than 85 percent of the votes cast in polls held Sunday.

Konare, who ran on the ticket of the Alliance for Democracy in Mali (ADEMA) secured 85.15 percent of the vote, according to provisional results released by the Independent National Electoral Commission (CENI) Tuesday. 

Mamadou Maribatourou Diaby, leader of the Party for Unity, Development and Progress (PUDP), won 4.09 percent of the vote.

The remaining votes were shared by the candidates of other opposition parties which boycotted the elections.

The voter turn-out rate was 27 percent and the provisional results do not include polling stations in Konare's native region of Kayes, as well as Sikasso and the fourth commune of the Bamako district, where vote counting has been delayed.

Malian opposition parties said Monday that it would not recognize the legitimacy of a president elected from Sunday's ballot.

In a statement released to the national news agency (AMAP), the parties said they were happy with "the low turn-out in polling stations and the voters response to the call for a peaceful boycott of the May 11 electoral masquerade".

However, Konare has in the course of his campaigns said if he won, he would include members of the opposition in a broad-based government.

Under the Malian constitution, the president is elected for a five- year renewable term of office.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


387 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


Zaire;
Zairians Want Kabila To Improve Economy


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

LUBUMBASHI, Zaire (PANA) - The war being waged by Laurent Kabila's rebel forces, who have vowed to topple President Mobutu Sese Seko has generated unprecedented anxiety among Zairians in Lubumbashi, the country's second largest city and capital of the mineral-rich Shaba Region.

The two million or so Lubumbashi residents, like their compatriots elsewhere in the vast Central African region regard Kabila's current offensive against Mobutu as the only chance to end his 32 years of exploitation that has turned the country into one of the poorest on the African continent.

"Mobutu Ni Mwizi. Tunataka Kabila Amukamate. (Mobutu is a thief, We want Kabila to catch him," Mwamba Ngoy told PANA in Swahili in Lubumbashi in an interview recently. 

Ngoy, 37, a mining engineer by profession, was speaking for what he said were thousands of fellow Zairean university graduates thrown out of employment due to Mobutu's neglect of the national economy.

Like many ordinary Zaireans in Lubumbashi, he ekes out a living by doing odd jobs, including vending an assortment of merchandise and foodstuff brought across the borders, mainly from neighbouring Zambia.

"This man (Mobutu) is a devil. He has reduced Zaireans to paupers when our country is supposed to be among the richest in Central Africa and the continent because of our vast mineral wealth," he said.

Ngoy says he monitors Kabila's war against Mobutu launched in 1996 almost "centimeter by centimeter". "I want Mobutu to go quickly for Kabila to take over and end this deprivation."

Lubumbashi residents have a reason to be excited about Kabila's entry. He has already taken steps to redress people's suffering in the "liberated areas" including parts of Lubumbashi itself, which currently serves as the headquarters of his Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of the Congo (Zaire) or AFDL.

He has ordered reduction of the exchange rate of the New Zaire, the local currency, against the United States dollar from 400,000 to 140,000 per dollar. Similar exchange readjustments have been ordered in other liberated areas including Kisangani (80,000 NZ) and Kasai (60,000NZ) per dollar.

The measure is intended to help lower the country's import bill particularly of essential foodstuff and other commodities and hence the high cost of living.

Bread, in Lubumbashi, for example, now costs an average of 200,000NZ from between 500,000 NZ and even 600,000NZ before Kabila's orders. Other foodstuff such as mealie meal, milk, sugar and commodities like charcoal have had their prices reduced by half. The same goes for public transport service.

The price decrease has, however, not been of much benefit to most Lubumbashi residents due to the high levels of unemployment.

"Now we want Kabila to bring in investors to rehabilitate our mines and open up others for us to get jobs, said Kasongo Wamwanza, a cobbler along the dilapidated Mobutu Street in the city centre.

Kabila has since signed contracts with various firms, especially from the United States, Europe and South Africa to invest in the country's gold, diamond, copper cobalt and other mines which AFDL officials say are currently operating at less than 10 percent capacity.

Last week, he received a delegation representing 32 foreign business houses organised by America Mineral Fields Incorporated, to finance mining operations in the country.

According to Kabila's economic and finance minister, Mawapanga Mwanananga, it is intended that full mining production will be attained in the next two years.

"We are in a hurry here. President Kabila is a no nonsense man. He wants to get all Zaireans back to work because we realize that this is the only way we can turn around the fortunes of this great country, Mwanananga told PANA in Lubumbashi recently. Similar sentiments were expressed by his mines counterpart Florent Kambale Kabila Mututulo.

Most of Zaire's minerals are currently mined by the government-owned Gecamines Company mainly based in Shaba Province. It employs an estimated 36,000 workers and is regarded as the country's highest employer.

The other state mining companies include Miba which is mainly engaged in diamond exploitation in the Kasai Region and Kilomoto, which deals in gold in Kisangani. All the regions are under the control of the AFDL.

AFDL officials say that there are no reliable mineral production and revenue records for Zaire's mining industry. These are now currently being compiled by Mututulo's ministry.

Mobutu is alleged to have been privately selling Zaire's minerals to make a personal fortune estimated to be in billions of dollars at the expense of his 45 million subjects.

Now they look up to Kabila to share the wealth equally among all Zaireans.

"Come back tomorrow and you will find Congo and the Congolese changed," said Ngoy as he went off to listen to Kabila's radio broadcasts on "La Voix Du Peuple" (the Voice of the People) as the AFDL soldiers advance towards the capital, Kinshasa, to dislodge the ailing 66-year-old Mobutu from power.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


388 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


Science and Health;
Zambia Support Ban On Ivory Trade


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia on Tuesday stated that it now supports the ban in ivory trade enforced in 1992 under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES).

Speaking in Lusaka, the country tourism minister, Amusaa Mwanamwambwa, said the government had reversed the position that was adopted in 1989 against the listing of the African elephant as an endangered species.

Mwanamwambwa was officially opening a preparatory national workshop on the forthcoming 10th CITES conference scheduled for June 9-20 in Harare, Zimbabwe. 

To prevent the slaughter of its dwindling elephant population, he said, the government of President Frederick Chiluba is opposed to the resumption of trade in ivory and elephant.

The African elephant is listed under Appendix I of the convention, banning trade in ivory and other parts, to boost the elephant's dwindling population on the continent.

Mwanamwambwa stressed that Zambia would not support a lifting of the ban which is sought by some neighbouring Southern African states, saying this would open the "floodgates of senseless elephant slaughter due to demand for ivory."

He said that the decision was taken after the government noted a sharp decline in Zambia's elephant population from about 250,000 in the early 1960s. This had dropped to 100,000 by 1975 and between 22,000 and 24,000 at present.

He said that the elephant population had suffered from severe depletion due to poaching which he said was prompted by illegal trade in ivory.

The minister said Zambia had also decided to review its position on the listing of African elephant on Appendix I to allow the elephant population to reach verifiable recovery. Appendix I listing of the CITES convention calls for trade prohibition in ivory and other endangered species.

Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe have been calling for the repeal of the ban on ivory trade so that they could "sell" their excess elephants.

Mwanamwambwa said while he did appreciate the sentiments of the neighbors, Zambia still felt that the ban should be maintained to save some of its own elephant populations which occasionally wander within the region.

"Most of our African elephant range forms a continuous ecosystem spreading across our common political borders," he said.

He said the major challenge is to evaluate the movement of elephants across national boundaries, control of illegally obtained ivory and reducing conflict between human beings and elephants.

Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe have submitted proposals to the UN Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, seeking the re- opening international trade in ivory, by "down-listing" their elephants from Appendix 1 to Appendix 11 of the convention.

A decision on the proposals is expected to be made at the forthcoming conference in Harare.

Conservationists from all over Africa and Asia are voicing concern that if the international ivory trade is re-opened, large scale elephant poaching will resume.

These argue that say that there is evidence that poaching is increasing and ivory is being stockpiled by smugglers in anticipation of an increase in ivory prices once the ban is lifted.

Well over 500 tons of ivory are now estimated to be stored in Africa.

The overriding concern of parties to CITES is that there should never be a return to the situation in the 19970s and 1980s when illegal ivory trade overwhelmed legal trade and Cites controls which was proved totally inadequate to prevent illegal ivory entering legal trade.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 13, 1997


Nigeria;
Police Probe Ibadan Bomb Bast


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Bomb experts were on Tuesday still analyzing fragments from Monday's explosion in Nigeria's western city of Ibadan, suspected to be a bomb planted by dissidents.

The Assistant Inspector-General of Police, Hassan Alli-Jos, said it was after the meeting that the police could determine the nature of the device, which went off as top military officers were heading for a seminar several kilometres away from a barracks. 

The explosion, which occurred at a junction on the Eleyele-Jericho road, ripped through the police truck conveying soldiers and policemen to work, witnesses said. No death occurred but two soldiers and a policeman were injured.

The device also smashed the windscreen of a white Mercedes Benz car, owned by one Banji Adeleke, who is being questioned by the police in connection with the blast.

Adeleke's car was said to be behind the police truck when the explosion occurred. The Oyo state administrator, Col. Ahmed Usman, has visited the scene, accompanied by the state director of security service.

Usman was quoted as having described the perpetrators as "cowards," who were out "to embarrass the government because of a few dollars and pounds." He pledged that government would track down those behind the act.

Present at the seminar organised by defence headquarters, were Nigeria's Chief of Defence staff, Maj.-Gen. Abdulsalam Abubakar, the Chiefs of Army and Naval Staff, and other senior military officers.

Last Wednesday, a bomb went off in Lagos, the sixth such explosion in Nigeria's economic hub in the last seven months, all but one of them targeted at the military.

Nigeria's military government has accused pro-democracy groups in the country of being behind the explosions.

Sixteen people, including exiled Nigerian Nobel Literature Laureate, Wole Soyinka, are facing charges in connection with the explosions.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 13, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Britain Freezes Development Aid


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The new Labour government in Britain has frozen its Aid and Trade Provisions (ATP) scheme worldwide to allow the recently appointed minister to review it.

A spokesman of the ATP Harare office told the Zimbabwe Inter-African News Agency (Ziana) the new British minister, Clare Short, heading the department of International Development, needed to look at the existing policy of the scheme. 

"All ATP projects are on hold until the new minister in the United Kingdom has considered her position," said the spokesman.

Short took over from Baroness Lynda Chalker as head of the former Overseas Development Agency (ODA) after a landslide victory by Tony Blair's Labour Party, which ended 18 years of Conservative Party rule in Britain.

In Zimbabwe, the freezing of the scheme will affect two projects -- the Zimbabwe Republic Police (ZRP) 'Land Rover" vehicle deal and supply of equipment to the National University of Science and Technology (NUST).

A senior British official told Ziana in Harare that the new minister was "not overly keen on the ATP scheme," under which funds were allocated to projects British companies with a strong commercial orientation.

Under the scheme, the Zimbabwe police was expected to get at least 1,500 Land Rovers, supplied by a British firm. The contract's cost was to be paid by ODA, in the form of a 35 percent grant and 65 percent loan.

The Land Rover deal was valued at 25 million pound sterling, equivalent to 19.7 million U.S dollars.

"The ATP scheme is a good project and will have to be put before the minister," the official said.

There were no details available on the value of the NUST educational equipment deal.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 13, 1997


Ethiopia;
Six Girls Commit Suicide Defying Traditional Marriages


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

NAZARETH, Ethiopia (PANA) - Six Afari girls committed suicide in Gewane Woreda community on Ethiopia's eastern region, over the past nine months, as they objected to "Abusuma", a traditional marriage under which cousins are forced to marry each other.

The Ethiopian News Agency (ENA) on Tuesday quoted Ali Boyina, a representative of the Afar People Democratic Organization, as saying the desperate girls shot, hanged or threw themselves into rivers. 

The number of young women, most of them around 15 years old, preferred death to being the spouses of men 80 years old, he said. Ali Adem, who heads the Economic development and social sector in the area, said the traditional marriage is practiced throughout the Afar region including Gewane. He added that efforts are geared toward curbing such practices.

"Abusuma" violates the right of women to marry the man of their choice and thus pertinent bodies should work to bring about behavioral change in the community," he noted.

"The traditional marriage is tantamount to slavery of women," Woizero Fatuma Seid, a resident at Melka Sedi said.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


392 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


Business and Finance;
Uganda's Risk Rating Improves, But Not Fast Enough


BYLINE: David Musoke, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Although Uganda's economy is considered to be among the best performers in Africa, its risk rating has not been improving fast enough to match the score.

The pearl of Africa - the name given to Uganda by Winston Churchill - is still seen as more risky than the African average, and much more risky than some of the countries most notorious with investors, such as Nigeria.

This is contained in a commentary on the Ugandan economy written by Paul Collier an economics professor at The centre for the Study of African Economies at Oxford University. In a report prepared for the European Union, Collier says a recent survey of investor attitudes to Uganda identified risk as the most deterrent to private investment. 

The survey, conducted for the World Bank found that of the different types of risk identified in Uganda, non-commercial risk was the largest component. Within this category, it was fears of policy reversal which was dominant.

In 1987, just as Yoweri Museveni's National Resistance Movement government came to power, Uganda had the worst rating of the 25 African countries then rated. By September 1989, this rating had further deteriorated to just 4.5 on a scale ranging from 0 to 100.

It recovered slightly, only to fall back to 5.2 as of September 1992, against the lowest of the 29 African countries then rated. From then to March 1996 (the most recent rating), progressive and rapid up-rating, now standing at 14.5 This up-rating has coincided with a large increase in both private capital inflows and private investment.

There is a relationship across countries between the risk ratings and private investment: risk deters investment. Collier says in his commentary that the rising risk rating is gradually introducing Uganda into the world capital market, so that, as long as the rating does not deteriorate, the capital flows should be reasonably secure.

"An implication is that Uganda has not really harnessed private capital inflows on the scale which is to be expected in the next decade," he said.

"This is because, despite the remarkable improvement in the ratings, Uganda is still rated as far more risky than seems warranted by its current performance as the star among African countries.

"It is sill rated as one of the world's most risky economies. Of the 34 African countries now rated, only eight have lower ratings. The Kenyan rating has never been below 18.1 and currently stands at 30 in contrast to the Ugandan rating of 14.5. Uganda is thus still more risky than the African average, and much more risky than some of the countries most notorious with investors, such as Nigeria"

The British economist attributes this to information lagging behind events. "Given the sustained fast growth rate, the sustained low inflation and the successful election, all of which compare favourably with Kenya, it does not seem to be so obviously a higher risk environment than Kenya," he said.

Addressing an investors forum organised by the Uganda Investment Authority (UIA) in Brussels in April 1995, Collier said Uganda was regarded as risky despite its economy being the best performing in Africa partly because of ignorance of Uganda on the part of the international business community.

The three foremost facts about Uganda thrust upon the international community by the media are probably Amin, AIDS and proximity to Rwanda. Although there has been some media coverage of the recent good economic and political performance, wars are more media worthy than economies, so that this has been offset by reports of fighting in the north of the country, he said.

"Thus (mis) informed, businesses make the entirely reasonable calculation that it is not worth incurring the high costs (which are mainly opportunity costs) of learning more. Hence Uganda seldom gets on the short list of investors and so they never incur the costs which would make them better informed," he added.

On average, African countries are rated as being significantly more risky than warranted by objective circumstances. Uganda is probably currently a victim of this phenomenon. This low rating cannot simply be overcome by advertising Uganda's achievements (although this will undoubtedly help), Collier said even when they learn of these achievements, investors tend to react by prognoses that they are not sufficiently likely to persist: either the country could relapse into an economic control regime or even into civil wars, presumably, the risk rating agencies know the basic economic facts but are skeptical of their persistence.

He said dealing with the fear of relapse is much more difficult than dealing with ignorance of present conditions. If the businesses can be persuaded to digest a page of economic and political facts they can be dramatically disabused of their beliefs about the present conditions. By contrast, the fear of relapse is based not on superficial errors about Uganda but on extrapolation from experience elsewhere and from Uganda's own past.

Neither of these extrapolations is intrinsically foolish, the professor said. About half of the liberalisations in African have been reversed and statistically, a past civil war is the single best predictor of a future civil war.

"The government needs to be able to signal that the transition is more secure, which is different from advertising that it has taken place," Collier said. "Somehow the country has to live down its past and dissociate itself from its neighbourhood. Unless this happens, the main foreign investment will be by the group which has an information advantage, namely, the returning Asians. The risks of economic policy reversal and of civil wars are to an extent distinct," he added.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 13, 1997


Business and Finance;
Kenyan Turnover And Share Prices Improve


BYLINE: Sam Mugo, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - It was a busy and exciting week at the Nairobi Stock Exchange (NSE) as turnover and share prices improved over the previous week's features.

According to Loitta Asset Market analysts, a total of 5.2 million shares worth sh 195.4 million changed hands in 1,610 deals during the week ending Friday, compared to one million shares valued at sh 59.6 million traded during the previous week. 

The NSE 20-Share-Index gained a total of 75.65 points during the week to 3379.54 with most of the index constituent counter posting gains.

The analysts said bonds worth sh 238.8 million were sold over the same period, compared to bonds worth sh 391.5 million traded the previous week. The Central Bank of Kenya treasury bonds worth sh 38.8 million were traded at prices ranging from 102.7779 percent to 103.0000 percent, up from last week's closing rate of 102.4907 per cent.

The East African Development Bank sold sh 200 million worth of bonds at between 98.87 percent and 99.6 percent ex-coupon, down from the previous closing of 104.57 percent cum-coupon. Foreigners transacted 112,300 shares of Sasini at between sh 76 and sh 80.

Kenya Airways sold 1.6 million shares at sh 9 per share, while Uchumi Super Markets sold 320,000 shares at between sh 40.50 and sh 42 a piece. Firestone sold one million shares at between sh 27 and sh 30 per share.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


394 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


Zaire;
Final South African Bid For Peace In Zaire


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa's Deputy President Thabo Mbeki left Cape Town on Tuesday for what is being seen here as a final bid to ensure that the next scheduled round of Zairean peace succeed in securing a peaceful solution for the country's crisis.

Mbeki's latest diplomatic shuttle to Zaire is aimed at ensuring that the next meeting between President Mobutu Sese Seko and Zairean rebel leader Laurent Kabila -- scheduled for Wednesday -- does take place. 

Speaking to reporters before his departure, Mbeki -- who has been the chief negotiator in international mediation efforts to end Zaire's seven-month civil war -- said that tomorrow's meeting was the last chance for a negotiated political settlement.

I think, he said, that as things stand we are in that kind of danger that the meeting on Wednesday may very well be the last chance to find a negotiated solution to this crisis. He added the warning that if the meeting did not take place as planned then in reality it opens the way to a military solution being the only option.

Both the South African negotiators and United Nations and Organization of African Unity's special envoy Mahomed Sahnoun are consulting both sides in an effort to move to a position where the principal issues -- the timetable for President Mobutu to hand over power to a transitional authority, and the composition of that authority -- can be resolved tomorrow.

"We are hoping," he said, "that there will be sensitivity on both sides that it is better to enter into an agreement on this matter, rather than resorting at this final stage to the use of force."

The talks are scheduled to begin tomorrow morning aboard the South African navy supply vessel, SAS Outeniqua, off the Congolese sea port of Pointe Noire.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


395 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


Namibia;
Journalists Express Concern At Government;
Intolerance


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

Windhoek - The Journalists Association of Namibia (JAN) has expressed concern at increasing intolerance of Namibian government officials towards the right to freedom of expression, including calls for restricting this right and attacks on the integrity of media practitioners.

JAN executive member Tom Minney said this May 9 in Windhoek at a function to mark this year's World Press Freedom Day, which JAN used to resubmit a petition handed to Namibian President Sam Nujoma, United Nations Secretary General Butros Butros-Ghali, UNESCO director General Federico Mayor and SADC secretary General Kaire Mbuende in 1994 in Windhoek on World Press Freedom Day.

The petition, whose contents Minney said were considered still valid, called for an end to the harassment of journalists and respect of the right to freedom of expression by SADC governments and other UN member states. Minney called on the Namibian government to restrain its members from launching "further unwarranted attacks on the media, educate its members about the indispensable role of a free, independent and pluralistic media in a democracy, and take urgent steps to encourage respect for the principles proclaimed in the Windhoek Declaration of Promoting an Independent and Pluralistic African Press." 

In return, JAN pledged to continue to promote and uphold the "highest attainable standards of journalistic ethics and practices" among its membership.

Also, the 1994 petition called for an end to the harassment and imprisonment of media workers by governments in the SADC region, creation of conditions which allow free, independent and pluralistic media to flourish, abolition of all forms of registration and/or licencing of journalists by governments and withdrawal of governments from running media councils and other bodies regulating the media.

In addition, it called for the abolition of excessive taxes "which hinder public access to media and thus the free-flow of information," ensure that state-owned media is run in the "interest of the general public and not in the interests of those in power", and end to "monopolistic control on the means of media production," actively encourage the establishment of community radio stations, and impress upon senior government officials and those in authority "the need to be readily accessible to media workers, whoever they represent" in order to facilitate the free-flow of information from government to the public.

The journalists called upon the UN, UNESCO and other relevant bodies to hold accountable those responsible for violations of media freedom.

Meanwhile, MISA's 1996 State of the Media report released on May 3, highlights three SADC countries as main offenders of media freedom in the region. The three include Namibia, others are Zambia and Zimbabwe.

For further information, contact David Nthengwe, researcher, Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), Private Bag 13386, Windhoek, Namibia Tel. +264 61 232975, Fax. 248016 e-mail: research@ingrid.misa.org.na


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 13, 1997


South Africa;
ANC Press Statement On Tokoza Violence


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Johannesburg - The ANC Gauteng Province sympathises with the grievances of the evicted people, but we can't condone their destructive tendencies, violence and unconstitutional methods as means of obtaining their political objectives.

In this regard, the ANC Gauteng Province condemn in the strongest terms the brutal and senseless killings of the three elderly ladies on Sunday 11 May 1997. The ladies were shot and killed after they moved back into their houses last week.

We are further outraged at by the senseless acts of destruction of properties, the stealing of doors and roofing. The elements involved in these anti-social activities should be brought to book immediately. We urge the Alberton City Council to take steps against those individuals calling for evicted residents to occupy and build shacks on all available land in Tokoza.

The situation in Penduka section in Tokoza remains a major concern to the ANC and every effort must be taken to arrest the situation from further havoc. We would support measures from the Safety and Security Ministry to bring the situation under control as soon as possible.
