397 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


Zambia;
Zambian Media Council Elects Chairperson


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Windhoek - The Zambia Independent Media Council (IMC) has elected Justice Florence Mumba, a judge of the level of the Supreme Court, as its Chairperson.

Justice Mumba, who is the Ombudsman in Zambia, was elected at the Zambia Independent Media Council's (IMC) first meeting held in Lusaka on May 9. Justice Mumba said soon after being elected that it was a good thing that the independent media had led the way in forming a self regulatory body for its journalists. 

She said the onus was now on the IMC to instill confidence in the public by the decisions it will make. Father Ignatius Mwebe who is the Secretary General of the Catholic Secretariat was elected Vice Chairperson.

Other members of the council include an evangelist, Doctor Nevers Mumba of Victory Ministrie, lawyer John Sangwa of Simeza & Sangwa Advocates, and Ms Aida Opoku-Mensah, Director of Panos Institute Center for Policy Debate in Southern Africa.

Others are: Mr. Abbey Maine Managing Director of Palesa News Agency, Mr. Arthur Simuchoba, Executive Editor at the Post Newspaper and Mr. Fackson Banda, an author and Director of Information at the Christian Council of Zambia.

The IMC was initiated by members of the Zambia Independent Media Association (ZIMA/MISA Zambia) early this year, in response to threats by the government of President Frederick Chiluba to impose a legislated media council. One of the main objectives of the IMC is to uphold and maintain the freedom of the media in Zambia, including the freedom of expression and the right of the public to receive information free from interference or intimidation from any source.

The IMC will also assist in ensuring that the media adhere to the highest professional standards by strict compliance with the code of ethics. Among the procedures laid down is that the hearing of the IMC shall be open to the public unless there is something "not for public interest" especially in the gathering of evidence. "But all findings/decisions must be made public."

Some of the functions of the IMC shall include receiving complaints from the public, investigating and coming up with a verdict. The IMC is also empowered to make an order for correction in a manner determined by the IMC, or reconcile the parties without any further action.

The IMC shall undertake an investigation into any matter of public importance concerning the conduct and output of ZIMA members. If an organisation or individual is dissatisfied with the decision of the IMC they can appeal to the general meeting of ZIMA through the Chairman, David Simpson.

For further information, contact David Nthengwe, researcher, Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), Private Bag 13386, Windhoek, Namibia Tel. +264 61 232975, Fax. 248016 e-mail: research@ingrid.misa.org.na


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


398 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


Business and Finance;
COSATU Rejects Appeal Court Ruling


BYLINE: Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1334 words


 

Johannesburg - COSATU PRESS STATEMENT ON THE PROTEST ACTION IN FURTHERANCE OF DEMANDS ON BASIC CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT BILL.

COSATU held a special EXCO on 12 May 1997 in the wake of the Labour Appeal Court's ruling on the protest action which was scheduled for 12 May 1997. The meeting rejected the majority judgment made by the Labour Court on the protest action planned for Monday 12th May 1997. It took note of the fact that this was not a unanimous judgment. 

In the judgment, the two judges whose majority view is the decision of the court, found that COSATU had complied with the provisions of section 77 (1) save for section 77 (1)(c) which provides that the matter giving rise to the dispute be considered by NEDLAC.

Judge Nicholson on the other hand, found that COSATU had complied with section 77 (1) in all respects. He further criticised Business South Africa for its conduct in NEDLAC, for introducing red herrings, for claiming it had no mandate, and for evading the issues raised by COSATU. In particular, he found it "strange" that BSA claimed to have no mandate in meetings held in April 1997, on matters which had been the subject of negotiations for a period of more than one year. The same applies to government whom despite negotiations on the Green Paper and the Bill, gave the impression that this is a new process altogether.

The EXCO reiterated the view that since the release by the government of the green paper on employment standards in February 1996, numerous meetings had taken place. In fact COSATU has attended more than 11 formal meetings at Nedlac and a large number of bilaterals with both business and government. In this regard, we reject the argument that the issues giving rise to the protest action had not been considered and that the onus was on COSATU to ensure that the issue was considered by NEDLAC.

As regards the negotiations it was reported that there had been no meaningful proposals and movement by the other parties in NEDLAC on the core issues. In fact business is said to have told the meeting that their positions are the same as reflected in their founding document of last year.

They are also rejecting the 45 hour week for mining workers, domestic workers, agricultural workers and security workers. They would want the phasing in to be left to collective bargaining rather than the bill. They have placed an unacceptable model on variation on the table whose result will be that all rights can be varied down. They remain firm on three months unpaid maternity leave, have rejected the issue of family responsibility leave as well as payment for Sunday work. Consequently we remain in deadlock on the core issues.

After careful consideration, the COSATU EXCO resolved as follows:

1. It is clear that there is a widening of the gap as well as a hardening of attitude by business and the government (on certain core issues) in the negotiations. 2. Reiterated it's position on the following core issues manner.

. Paid maternity leave COSATU's position remains that the law must provide for six months maternity leave of which at least four months should be paid. (That women who go on maternity leave should enjoy job security as well as the fact that in the event that the UIF is used as a mechanism for payment, women who lose their jobs soon after returning from maternity leave should not lose on the UIF benefits.)

. Hours of work COSATU has maintained throughout the negotiations that while there are some improvements in working hours in so far as there is a reduction (phased in in certain sectors) in working hours for security workers, farm workers, domestic and mining workers, the bill makes no provision for a phased approach to a legislated 40 hour working week. Consequently, our demand remains that the bill should provide for a 40 hour working week phased in over a period of not more that 5 years. The approach in the negotiations by government and business on the 45 hours for mining workers, farm workers, domestic workers and security workers means that even where we thought that there was a gain for such workers it has vanished into thin air.

* Sunday Work -- COSATU proposed that the status quo of the Basic Conditions of Employment Act in respect of pay for work performed on a Sunday, be extended to all workers. This would provide that workers who work for less than 4 hours will receive a full day's salary, while those who work for more than 4 hours would be paid at double the rate. Further, that workers who elect to take a day in lieu of Sunday work should be paid at time and a half. Business's attitude to Sunday being regarded as a day of rest and consequently double payment, means that we are now in deadlock on this issue as well.

* Child labour -- The COSATU position is that while we welcome the definition of a child in the bill, we remain of the view that the threshold for prohibition on child labour should be 18 years.

* Variation -- COSATU is opposed to the variation model in the bill in so far as it seeks to allow for downward variation of certain rights, the wide discretionary powers given to the minister to vary rights downwards and the provision for individual agreements to change the provisions of the statute.

3. To ratify the NOB's proposal to postpone the action of 12 May 1997 to the 2nd of June 1997. The form of the action will be a 24 hour strike. This is because of the widening of the gap in the negotiations as well as their hardening of attitudes.

4. To condemn both the government and business on the approach they took to the discussions of the issues raised by COSATU in our letters of 18 February 1997 as well as the one of 21 April 1997.

5. To mandate the NOB's to approach our lawyers to seek legal opinion and to mandate them to apply for leave to appeal against the constitutional findings in the judgment and the right to appeal to the Constitutional Court in respect of those findings. It has also been agreed to run a petition amongst our members. ( see attached )

6. Mandate regional structures to hold discussions with progressive formations to win their support for our demands including those ANC members who serve in the NCOP.

7. Mandate NOB's to seek an urgent meeting with the ANC parliamentary caucus to appraise them of our positions.

8. Mandate the NOB's to inform the Alliance and other progressive formations of our positions as well as our revised programme of action.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


399 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


Swaziland;
Senate Threatens To Close Times Of Swaziland


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Windhoek - The Times of Swaziland today, May 13, reports threats by Senate to close it for reporting in its May 12 edition, that King Mswati owed the Mbabane City Council Elangeni 30,000 (US$6,382), in unpaid rates for a hotel he owns.

The Times quotes Senator Bhekimpi Dlamini, a member of the royal family, as threatening to sponsor a motion to close the newspaper. "We are bringing a motion here. What can prevent us from closing down this newspaper?" the Times quotes Dlamini telling the senate May 12. 

The paper reports further that the Senate voted to discuss the matter in a parliamentary caucus where Dlamini said he would raise issues to be investigated by the Minister of Public Service and Information Muntu Mswane, before the motion was brought to parliament. "I want the minister to investigate this as it is not the first time the newspaper has written such an article. My anger is so extensive that I am prepared to die for this. The newspaper should have stated that the person owing the rates is Kal Grant," the Times quotes Dlamini telling the Senate before the caucus.

Times editor Mashumelo Twalo told MISA May 13, Senate had over- reacted to the story because it was embarrassing to the King, but he hoped with time the Senators would look at the issue soberly. "It is difficult to say if they will carry out their threat, I hope they will ultimately cool down. Right now emotions are running quite high because we dared write about the King," he said.

A reporter on the Times, Nkululeko Dlamini, told MISA in a separate interview it was ironic that the Senate had taken offence with the present story, when last year a related story about the King buying the hotel from businessman Kal Grant at Elangeni 8 million (US$1.9 million) went without comment from any of the Senators. He further said the story was not disrespectful of the King, besides, the newspaper had an obligation to inform the public. "In this case, the King is more of a businessman than a monarch. We reported that he had bought the property and if he owes rates, it is our obligation to disclose that," Dlamini said.

Last August, the Times of Swaziland reported moves by the ruling monarch to close it after a series of articles alleging official corruption, however, the government denied this.

For further information, contact David Nthengwe, researcher, Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), Private Bag 13386, Windhoek, Namibia Tel. +264 61 232975, Fax. 248016 e-mail: research@ingrid.misa.org.na


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


400 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


United States and Africa;


BYLINE: United States Information Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1774 words


 

Pretoria - Text of an address by South African Minister of Provincial Affairs and Constitutional Development Valli Moosa on May 11 to a gathering of civic educators in Pretoria sponsored by the United States Information Agency: (Begin text as prepared for delivery)

Chairperson, honored guests, ladies and gentlemen -- it is indeed an honor and privilege for me to be addressing a gathering of so many luminaries as I have noticed when I looked at the guests list. It is a special honor for me to be addressing you on the eve of what I think would be a very important conference for this region and the African continent. On behalf of the South African government I wish to express appreciation to the United States Information Service, the Institution for a Democratic South Africa and members of CIVITAS for what is indeed a most welcome initiative.

South Africa is a particularly interesting laboratory I think when it comes to the question of civic education. We had begun what I consider to be a rather unique process of civic education over the past few years. For us it was not a case of drafting a democratic constitution and then going about to educate the public about why this constitution is so good and why people should be loyal to the constitution and respect it. We had started in a sense at an earlier stage. 

The first step was to go out to the public and talk about why a constitution would be a useful thing for this society to have and then to talk about what should be in this constitution. And therefore we had designed the entire constitution-making process in this country in a manner that would involve the public and a broader society as much as possible.

The first thing we had done is that we had thrown (open) every meeting of the constitutional assembly which had taken place over the past two years and every meeting of the constitutional negotiations which had taken place prior to 1994 open to the public. Not a single meeting was held behind close doors and even meetings of the management committee of the constitutional assembly -- the management committee was made up of about 10 of us -- was open to the public. So we had more observers at that meeting than members of the meeting which took place on a weekly basis.

We'd also called on members of the public to write to the constitutional assembly indicating what in their view should be in the constitution. And we received literally thousands upon thousands of written submissions from members of the public. And I must say here not only from constitutional experts, lawyers and law professors, but just members of the public.

We also realized that a very large number of South Africans would not have the confidence or perhaps the ability to put down the ideas on paper and send it off to the constitutional assembly. Therefore, an important part of the process was what we refer to as the public participation program. We broke up the Constitutional Assembly into teams of members who held people's forums in various parts of the country.

Particularly in the rural areas, in the informal settlements and in those parts of the country where we knew that literacy perhaps was not as high as it should be. And at these forums, members of the public were invited and constitutional assembly members were tasked just with the duty of sitting up front on the stage and listening to what people had to say. The format of those forums was such that there were no speeches, no inputs at all. The meeting opened with a request to the audience to say whatever they wanted to the constitutional assembly who had taken notes. And that in itself was a part from a process of consultation, I believe, was an important element of the beginning of civic education.

In drafting the constitution, we had then decided that it should be written in plain language; that there was absolutely no reason why a constitution should be written in legalese. And therefore we had drafted every clause of the constitution in plain language. We did everything that was possible to draft a short constitution -- not a very lengthy document -- so that it was possible for people to actually read it. And immediately after drafting the constitution we translated it into all 11 official languages that we have in this country.

Recently, we embarked upon National Constitution Week from the 17th to the 21st of March, during which week we sent every member of the Constitutional Assembly -- which is every member of parliament -- back to their home bases, to their constituencies, in order to themselves physically distribute copies of the constitution. And explain the contents of the constitution to people.

Copies of the constitution were also made available -- every post office in the country -- it was distributed to members of the security forces, to the police services, at hospitals, at schools, other educational institutions -- we printed 7 million copies of the constitution. And I must tell you that such was the hunger and thirst for copies of the constitution that before the end of that week it was impossible to lay one's hands on a single copy. And we had complaints throughout the country that the post offices had run out of copies of the constitution -- some by midday on the first day of constitution week had run out of copies of the constitution.

The South African constitution has a number of safeguards built into the constitution. Checks and balances, if one may want to call it that. The constitution cannot be easily amended by a simple majority in parliament. It establishes a number of constitutionally protected institutions like the Human Rights Commission; the Gender Commission; an independent electoral commission; public protector; an independent auditor general and, of course, an independent constitutional court. Institutions aimed at protecting, safeguarding and upholding the constitution.

But I must say that in my view that institutions provided for in a constitution do not in themselves build a democracy and constitutionally entrenched checks and balances are good enough when it comes to disputes that land up in court. But in the final analysis, it is the people of a country; a society which itself can make a constitution work, and can insure that the constitution endures.

And this is the importance of civic education. That unless the people of South Africa hold the constitution close to their hearts, understand the constitution, and learn to love the values embodied in the constitution, we cannot be certain that the order would survive for generations to come.

And it is for that reason that we are leaving no stone unturned when it comes to civic education. And I must say here that civic education and constitutional education is not just the preserve of government; that we are encouraging NGOs and other organizations and institutions in organs of civil society to participate fully in this program of constitution education. The task perhaps that we could play, is perhaps, coordinate and facilitate. But as all of you would know that there's no single interpretation of any constitution. And it is for that reason that it would be against the spirit of the constitution if we have a government line on what the constitution says.

The constitution is not a mere statute. It's not just another very important act of parliament -- more important than other acts of parliament. And it's not simply a legal instrument in my view. Yes, it does serve to regulate the affairs of society; regulate matters between the state and between citizens, but I think it's much more than that. We view our constitution as a document which embodies the values of our society and the hopes and aspirations of the people of this country. The constitution grants inalienable rights to all citizens. But it also imposes duties, and in our own context it imposes, it grants both individual and collective rights. And it also imposes individual and collective duties. Everybody enjoys the freedom of expression, but everybody also has the duty to promote everybody else's freedom of expression.

In conclusion, chairperson, I wish you well in your deliberations over the next few days and I hope that as you converse and debate and discuss how to deepen civic education in this country, on our continent and around the world, that you would at least get a whiff of the dawning of the African renaissance.

Thank you.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 13, 1997


South Africa;
Winnie asked to disown 'necklacing'


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Cape Town - Exiled African National Congress president Oliver Tambo sent a message to Winnie Madikizela-Mandela and other ANC leaders in the 1980s asking them to distance themselves from the practice of "necklacing".

This was disclosed to the Truth Commission yesterday by Defence Minister Joe Modise during the ANC's second submission. 

At the time of Mr Tambo's appeal, Mrs Madikizela-Mandela was married to ANC leader Nelson Mandela, who was in jail. In April 1986, she drew strong local and international condemnation for a speech at Munsieville, outside Krugersdorp, during which she brandished a box of matches.

Yesterday, the ANC was questioned by the commission's chief legal adviser, Hanif Vally, about whether Mrs Madikizela-Mandela had been an ANC member at the time and whether she had been subject to party discipline.

Transport Minister Mac Maharaj confirmed that Mrs Madikizela-Mandela had been an ANC member and that the leadership in exile attempted to contact her in various ways from time to time. "But the movement had extreme difficulty in establishing lines of communication," he said.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


402 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


South Africa;
'We stuck to Geneva accord'


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Cape Town - The African National Congress signed the Geneva Convention on the just conduct of war "in all seriousness" and denied that its subsequent warning in 1985 about a "blurring" of hard and soft targets was a contravention of the convention, the Truth Commission has been told.

Transport Minister Mac Maharaj said yesterday the ANC's commitment to the convention, which it signed in 1980, had to be measured against the conduct of the struggle in "the real situation". 

He said prime military targets were sometimes located in the heart of residential areas, and he conceded that long and insecure lines of communication and the particular discipline of its guerrilla force had made the ANC's commitment to the convention problematic at times.

Mpumalamga premier Mathews Phosa said the ANC had chosen not to use anti-personnel mines at all to avoid civilian casualties.

Mr Maharaj commented: "The ANC unreservedly apologises to all civilians who lost their lives. It was never our intention to target them."

LANGUAGE: English

May 13, 1997


South Africa;
Women sexually abused by Angola camp chiefs


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 133 words


 

Cape Town - Certain commanders of African National Congress camps in Angola used their power to sexually abuse female cadres, the ANC has told the Truth Commission.

These commanders, guilty of what the commission termed "gender specific human rights violations", had been disciplined by being removed from their posts.

Defence Minister Joe Modise said during the ANC's submission:"I think the allegations in many instances are true, and because we believed in gender equality in the ANC, we took steps to correct this."

Africa News


May 13, 1997


South Africa;
22 spies killed - 'ANC faced collapse'


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Cape Town - The African National Congress executed 22 spies and mutineers between 1982 and 1985, most of them after serious infiltration that came close to destroying the organisation, the ANC has told the commission.

Details of the executions and the names of spies who took part in the infiltration, but were "rehabilitated" and/or released by the ANC, were given to the commission in Cape Town in a confidential appendix to the ANC's second submission yesterday. The ANC was told its request to keep the names of the spies and agents secret put the TRC in "an awkward position".

Transport Minister Mac Maharaj said the ANC was highly sensitive about releasing the names of such people because their lives could be destroyed. "This is not the type of information which should be just leaked without managing it," he said.

Commission chairman Desmond Tutu said the TRC would need to be persuaded to withhold the information. It would be discussed at a full TRC meeting on Thursday.

Mr Maharaj said the ANC leadership had been "surprised" by the level of infiltration. "What we were facing was an extremely serious threat to the survival of our organisation."


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


405 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


South Africa;
Arie Katz and Susan Seely: their great adventure


BYLINE: David Yutar, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 987 words


 

Cape Town - One of the less intelligent things Thomas Jefferson said during his life was that travelling "makes a man wiser but less happy".

Not so for Arie Katz and Susan Seely.

Contrary to Jefferson's aphorism, it seems that travel has made both these explorers wiser and a lot happier too.

To put it another way, this is a good old-fashioned love story. 

Boy meets girl, they fall in love, get married, quit their jobs, sell their worldly goods, say goodbye to friends and set off to see the big, wide world.

This is a real 20th century love story, you see.

The protagonists are corporate lawyer and a trade director and the setting is the city. Arie Katz met Susan Seely at a dinner in Washington DC in January, 1993.

He was studying law while Susan, having just completed her Masters in Middle Eastern studies in Seattle, was working part-time in the city.

They really did fall in love and, as Arie puts it so succinctly: "It's been one long date since then."

Ten days after they tied the knot on May 19 last year, the newlyweds left Boston on their epic journey.

After visiting Hawaii, they travelled to Australia, New Zealand, Indonesia, Singapore, Thailand, Hong Kong, India, Dubai, Jordan, Israel - and they finally reached the shores of the Cape of Good Hope.

For Arie it has been not just a physical journey but also one of rediscovering his roots.

A former South African (from Johannesburg) who emigrated to the United States in 1973, Arie studied law in Washington DC and has spent the past three years practising as a corporate attorney in a large Boston firm.

Arie's paternal grandfather came to Port Elizabeth from Lithuania and became a stalwart of the Jewish community there.

So when he visited the city it was a deeply nostalgic experience.

"Part of this trip has been to learn more about my family. My grandfather died when I was only a year old and I was amazed to find his reputation was very much alive when I attended a Saturday morning service at a local synagogue."

His great-grandparents ran a kosher hotel in Muizenberg and Arie still has memories of going to the synagogue in Muizenberg as a child.

Susan is from Newport Beach in California and was the director of the Middle East and Africa for the Massachusetts Office of International Trade and Investment. This is her fourth visit to this country in three years, most of which were made on business.

But why should two highly-successful professionals decide to embark on such an adventure?

Arie explains: "We had just had two of the worst winters in the history of Massachusetts.

"One day we just decided to quit our jobs, leave our flats and get married and then travel around the world. The world is really big and a year really short.

"Susan has always had this wanderlust. I figured that if we travelled enough she'd be so tired she would just want to settle down. But that's not how it worked out ... we always find that there's a new place that we want to visit."

Next on the globetrotting couple's itinerary is England, after which they plan to visit Portugal, Gibraltar, Morocco and Turkey.

But there's another unusual aspect to this sabbatical.

As they've been criss-crossing the world, Arie and Susan have been keeping a chronicle of their travels and making it available on the internet for all to read.

Of particular interest to them as observant Jews has been the history and profiles of local Jewish communities, wherever they have visited.

Susan has also been writing a regular column about their pilgrimage for a newspaper in Southern California.

The best part about the project, they say, is that it has generated interest wherever they have been and with more and more people offering information, it has evolved beyond what was originally envisaged.

"People have E-mailed us from around the world," said Arie. "One couple read about us in the Jerusalem Report and gave us a list of people to contact in Portugal."

Arie and Susan have not restricted their research to Judaism but have also gleaned a lot about other religions and cultures en route.

* If you want to read all about this great adventure or are looking for the relevant information, the web-site is http://www.jwconnection.com.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


406 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


South Africa;
The sinister menace of fog (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Cape Town - Twelve people died and many were injured in a multiple vehicle pile-up on the N2 on Saturday which was caused in large measure by dense fog.

By all accounts Saturday's horrifying multi-vehicle pile-up on the N2, in which 12 people burnt to death in a blazing inferno, was largely caused by dense fog, which was at its worst between Somerset West and Khayelitsha - exactly where the multiple collision took place.

Inexplicably, traffic authorities apparently did nothing to to warn motorists of the treacherous conditions, and no special patrols were deployed, even though visibility had been reduced to only a few metres. 

Fog is hardly a rarity in the Western Cape, least of all in areas close to wetlands, and the fact that many cars, trucks and buses daily plough blindly into the thick of it on the N2 at speeds well in excess of their ability to stop suddenly in an emergency, ensured that at some stage a disaster was bound to occur.

Traffic police err in their duty if they fail to ensure that motorists stay well below normal speed limits in the sort of conditions that existed on the N2 on Saturday and they should be prepared to warn motorists throughout the province - by radio, through newspapers, and on the spot - of hazardous conditions on the roads.

Illuminated warning boards drawing attention to mist and fog ahead and setting a safe speed limit, should become standard features on our roads. Such warning systems are widely used in other parts of the world where similar weather conditions exist.

While traffic officials should urgently review their management of traffic in fog conditions, other public officials deserve high praise for their efforts during Saturday's tragedy. Metro rescue workers and firemen, assisted by many volunteers at the scene, showed great courage in their efforts to extract people from burning vehicles and in bringing the inferno under control in such a short time.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


407 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


Business and Finance;
South Africa: In the public's interest to go private


BYLINE: William-Mervin Gumede, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2254 words


 

Cape Town - Barely a month after pulling off the continent's biggest privatisation deal to date by selling 30 percent of Telkom for $1,26- billion (about R5,54-billion), Public Enterprises Minister Stella Sigcau rolled out the Government's plans to put another five state-owned companies under the hammer.

She briskly announced in Parliament last week that the privatisation of five State-owned companies with a joint turnover of R40-billion was expected to be completed or would near completion in the next 12 to 18 months.

The companies in which significant restructuring progress should be made were the Airports Company, Spoornet, Safcol, Aventura and Alexkor.

A new bill also would be tabled in Parliament to regulate the privatisation drive and the restructuring of State assets, added Ms Sigcau.

South Africa, the continent's economic leader, had been very careful to embrace privatisation so far, with the ruling class in the African National Congress only recently being prepared to use the "p-word". 

Zambia, arguably the continent's foremost privatiser, moved into top gear earlier this year with the sale of Zambian Consolidated Copper Mines, the mining company which accounts for about 90 percent of its national export earnings.

Ghana, Kenya, Uganda, the Ivory Coast, Uganda and Mozambique were among other countries that had opted to go on a privatisation spree.

The mood in South Africa has changed since with the sale of the 30 percent stake in Telkom to SBC Communications and Telekom Malaysia.

Communications Minister Jay Naidoo said: "Even though we have decided each restructuring will be done on a case-by-case basis, I think we've put into place a number of very important milestones in the Telkom process."

Ms Sigcau said Pretoria had embarked on the largest and most far- reaching process of restructuring State assets on the African continent.

The sale of the five State-owned companies now, according to Ms Sigcau, would bring South Africa up to speed with several other African countries where reformist governments had been pushing privatisation aggressively.

The sudden increased activity on South Africa's privatisation front comes as a bit of a surprise, although President Mandela referred to it when he mapped out economic reforms for the year ahead, including the imminent privatisation of key State assets, in his opening speech to Parliament at the beginning of the year.

When President Mandela was released from jail, the African National Congress still had nationalisation "of the commanding heights of the economy" as a pillar of its economic strategy.

The ANC's new economic blueprint, the Growth, Employment and Redistribution (Gear) strategy, backed by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, presses for a sweeping privatisation programme, deregulation and fiscal prudence.

It will be interesting to see though, while Ms Sigcau claims she has trade union backing, how the Congress of SA Trade Unions will respond to privatisation moves.

Although Cosatu has formally pinned its colours to a nationalisation mast, it is also a signatory to the National Framework Agreement of January 25, 1995.

This agreement between the ANC's alliance partners - Cosatu and the SA Communist Party - allows for a degree of privatisation under the label "restructuring of State assets".

The agreement attempts to strike a balance between the conflicting demands for continued State control and the need for "restructuring of State assets" to allow partnerships with, and sales to, private corporations.

The debate between the ANC and its alliance partners is not over the whether there should be restructuring of state assets; rather, it is over what assets should be restructured, how and when this should be done and what safeguards should be built in to protect public-sector workers against retrenchments by private sector entrepreneurs.

Cosatu general secretary Sam Shilowa said some time ago: "The goals of the RDP will be defeated if restructuring benefits a new black elite while the delivery of services is fundamentally undermined."

Ms Sigcau said the Government's preferred method of privatisation was to seek a strategic equity partner for each of the companies.

Unveiling the privatisation time-frames for the first time, Ms Sigcau told the National Assembly that an inter-ministerial cabinet committee had agreed that privatisation should also benefit historically disadvantaged businesses.

The Government agreed to two policy objectives which would enable historically disadvantaged businesses and the 174 430 employees at the five State-owned enterprises to benefit directly from the enterprises' privatisation, said Ms Sigcau.

To this end, shares in restructured State-owned companies would be sold at a discount to a National Empowerment Fund (NEF) which would be set up to empower historically disadvantaged communities.

Ms Sigcau said it was the government's intention that funding schemes would be developed with the private sector to enable the disadvantaged to acquire shares in the NEF.

The employees of privatised enterprises also would benefit through employee share ownership schemes.

The share scheme will allow employees to purchase shares to the value of R10 000.

"These principles have been accepted by the IMCC and will soon be discussed at the level of the portfolio committee and with labour and other stakeholders," she added.

She said Aventura - the group of state holiday resorts - would be sold off completely.

The tender for the sale of Aventura holiday resorts to a consortium of companies specialising in holiday resorts and groups of historically disadvantaged investors, would be completed within the next 18 months.

She said the restructuring of Alexkor, which is involved in diamond mining in the Northern Cape, was a priority in order to inject fresh capital to fund exploration and development programmes.

"The restructuring process for Alexkor is at a fairly advanced stage and has taken into consideration the importance of the economic role it plays in Namaqualand." She anticipated that the restructuring process should be complete by the end of 1997 or early next year.

She said Safcol - the State company which runs commercial plantations - would be restructured by the end of this year.

The restructuring of the Airports Company and South African Airways would be completed this year.

It had been acknowledged that in view of SAA's importance as a national asset and the highly competitive market within which it operated, its restructuring should be considered a priority.

The SAA experienced a net loss of more than R300-million last year. Ms Sigcau said the loss was attributed to fuel increases, increased foreign and local competition, the unfavourable rand-dollar exchange rate and industrial action by staff members at the SAA's technical division.

The SAA workforce had problems with morale and ways needed to be found to motivate them to be "more patriotic concerning the airline".

Turning to Eskom, Ms Sigcau said 1996 had seen an increase in payment levels from previously black local authorities, from 39 percent in 1995 to 62 percent last year.

The amount of money owed to Eskom increased to R1 413-million in 1996 from R1 192-million in 1995.

Eskom was on track with its aim to reduce the real price of electricity by 15 percent by the year 2000.

Since it had spelled out the commitment in 1994, the real reduction to date had been 8,1 percent, she said.

The organisation had set itself the target of electrifying 1 750 000 homes by the year 2 000 and since the start of its programme 1 259 520 homes had been electrified.

Eskom's success in providing electricity to hundreds of thousands of South Africans who were traditionally not considered part of the electricity market "is a success we must look up to".

Referring to Spoornet, Ms Sigcau said it had developed world market leadership over the years in the running of heavy-haul trains carrying minerals such as coal and iron ore.

The technologies and competencies it had developed were not only sought after the world over, but they provided the company with a competitive tool that had the potential to carve out a niche for it in the global market.

Therefore Spoornet was in the process of bidding, in the context of local and international partners, for the operation of freight and heavy-haul systems in Brazil.

Ms Sigcau said one of the challenges her department had faced had been to nudge public enterprises to move from antiquated and authoritarian management styles and to embrace all the management levels that flowed from South Africa's new constitution.

The public enterprise committee had passed this year's budget "not without reservations" which included greater clarity on how the restructuring of enterprises was to serve black empowerment.

Patricia de Lille of the Pan Africanist Congress said shares in some State assets, including Aventura and Safcol, could only be sold with the approval of Parliament.

Ms de Lille said she would call on parliament to put pressure on the government to table a bill "within the next two or three months" which spelled out who would implement the restructuring programme and what parliament's role would be.

Kobus Jordaan of the Democratic Party said privatisation would succeed only if the process was transparent, and quoted an economist saying that sale of equity to foreign investors could provide South Africa with more than R50-billion.

The DP called on the government to announce a policy on privatisation for the major state enterprises through a mixture of stock market listings and selling large stakes to strategic foreign investors.

"The privatisation of large State enterprises could only boost the market's capitalisation by 20 to 25 percent.

If foreign investors purchased only 20 percent, it would provide SA with an additional $8-billion (about R35,2-billion) to $10-billion (about R44-billion) in foreign investment, said Mr Jordaan.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 13, 1997


Business and Finance;
No plant closures after Romatex buyout


BYLINE: Alide Dasnois and Llewellyn Jones, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Cape Town - There will be no plant closures following Frame's planned buyout of the other shareholders in Romatex, Frame chief executive Roy Sable has promised.

Last week it was announced that CG Smith would sell its remaining 28 percent stake in Romatex to the Frame group, and that Frame would offer to buy out the minority shareholders, giving it sole ownership of Romatex and opening the way to rationalising the operations of the two groups. 

The Frame group took a controlling stake from CG Smith in September.

In an interview yesterday, Mr Sable said management was "still trying to make sense of the whole operation".

Mr Sable said the proposed buyout was triggered by continued losses at Romatex and the need to give Frame a free hand in rationalising operations. Initial rationalisation would target Romatex Home Textiles and Berg River Textiles, where there were common areas.

He would not give any guarantees that no jobs would be lost.

"Romatex's difficulties are no different from the industry at large.

"The whole industry needs to put in new equipment, have fewer workers and improve productivity. But nobody need worry about massive job losses," Mr Sable said, adding that Frame did not intend reducing any capacity at any plant.

"We don't plan to close anything down."

Regional secretary of the South African Clothing and Textile Workers' Union Wayne van der Rheede said the union had met Romatex management late last year for preliminary discussions on the possible consequences of Frame's taking control of Romatex.

A further meeting was scheduled soon, he said.

May 13, 1997


South Africa;
New Xhosas at 10111 say white staff are racists


BYLINE: Lindsay Barnes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Cape Town - Xhosa-speaking people recently hired to operate telephones at Cape Town's 10111 police emergency radio control centre are on the verge of walking out because of alleged racism.

They say this includes white staff disinfecting telephones after black people have used them. The allegations have driven another wedge in the already deep division along colour lines among staff at the police crime reaction unit in Pinelands. 

Last week two coloured telephone operators alerted senior officers to the practice of white operators using disinfectant to wash the telephone receivers after black staff went off duty.

This was the latest in a host of alleged acts of racism, said Greg Goss, second in charge at the unit and Western Cape vice-chairman of the Police and Prisons Civil Rights Union (Popcru).

This year he shuffled staff in the unit to make it more racially representative. But he had been stifled in his attempts by a moratorium placed on the process last month by Fanie Bouwer, provincial head of crime prevention, after Director Bouwer had complaints from white staff, Superintendent Goss said.

Superintendent Goss and Popcru shop steward Johannes Campher alleged that whites at the unit had put up strong resistance to the hiring of black and coloured staff, with the result that most blacks and coloureds were hoping for transfers.

Sergeant Campher said: "We are bitter. It is clear that the white staff don't want blacks here."

The nine new Xhosa-speaking volunteers in the radio control centre had been subjected to verbal abuse by their white superiors, Superintendent Goss alleged.

The unit management is to meet provincial police commissioner Leon Wessels and his deputy Adam Blaauw next week.

The volunteers were appointed after the Cape Argus disclosed that there were no Xhosa-speaking people to take emergency calls. An estimated 35 to 40 percent of callers from areas such as Khayelitsha are unable to speak English or Afrikaans.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 13, 1997


South Africa;
Wheelbarrow death probe


BYLINE: Jenny Vial, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Cape Town - Western Cape Health Minister Ebrahim Rasool today slammed the "unprofessional attitude" of staff at day hospitals after Thobeka Madayi died in a wheelbarrow in Khayelitsha.

The Cape Argus exposed the shame of her death last week.

Mr Rasool said "a good dose of discipline and commitment" was needed from staff at primary health care institutions. 

Action would be taken to prevent day hospitals becoming virtual ghost facilities after 1pm. "By that time, in many instances, the last patients have been seen for the day. As early as 11am the gates have been closed and many patients sent home without care, simply because some staff members believe they've dealt with their 'quota' for the day. This must end."

Mr Rasool has appointed a task group to investigate the circumstances surrounding Mrs Madayi's death in a wheelbarrow after her husband Vuyani Magazi was refused help at a Khayelitsha day hospital last week.

He said budget difficulties could not be an excuse for everything that went wrong at a health facility. Spending on primary health care centres had in fact increased over the past three years.

"The budget is not the reason for an ambulance not being called. It is not a reason for turning away a terminally ill patient."

Mr Rasool said it was with "regret and embarrassment" that he had learned the circumstances of Mrs Madayi's death.

"It will forever be a blot on the record of health care in this province. Without reservation I wish to record my profound apology to the family and friends of Thobeka Madayi. If there is an opportunity to be identified ... it must be that the outrage is turned into a resolve to make the health system a decent, caring one."

The inquiry, headed by provincial Deputy Speaker Mampe Ramotsamai, would report within a week, "so that we can learn from this tragedy and ensure that a sense of discipline and commitment again becomes part of the health services."

Africa News


May 13, 1997


South Africa;
Whistle-blower's corruption warnings ignored for one year


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Nelspruit - Mpumalanga's head of the safety & security department, advocate Stanley Soko, admitted to the Moldenhauer Commission on Tuesday that he had been warned repeatedly over the past year that the province's traffic director was corrupt.

Soko said, however, that he had dismissed the charges because the junior official who made them, principal traffic inspector John Muller, was "problematic".

Muller eventually turned to the press after discovering that irregular learners and drivers licenses had been secretly issued to the parliamentary deputy speaker, Baleka Mbete-Kgositsile, on October 1 last year. 

Traffic director Henry Brazer personally issued the licenses after interrupting his sick leave to drive 350km from Nelspruit to Delmas to test Mbete-Kgositsile, after a minor heart attack.

Brazer, who is not registered as a certified license test officer, used incorrect application forms, filled in incorrect information on the forms and allegedly only tested Mbete-Kgositsile on parts of the required driver's license test.

No official records were kept of either the licenses or the tests.

"Muller made allegations of general corruption three times last year, starting in February and also called for a Commission of Inquiry into Brazer's activities after alleging that Brazer had used State funds to send four relatives on a holiday to the USA," explained Soko.

"But, I was discouraged by Muller's actions and attitude after he refused to work under Brazer or anyone else whom he called corrupt."

Other allegations against Brazer by Muller include charges that he promoted officers who had been suspended for license fraud or corruption, that he had irregularly bought a boat and diving equipment with State money for personal use and that he only has a Standard Eight certificate.

All these charges are now being investigated by the Moldenhauer Commission and have been repeated by a string of frustrated traffic officers who say that uncontrolled corruption has resulted in hundreds of thousands of fraudulent licenses being issued to drivers.

"I had heard all the rumours but no-one made an official written complaint and the lack of discipline and refusal to co-operate by my own directors made it very difficult to investigate anything," said Soko.

Admitting that he should have investigated Brazer never-the-less, Soko said that Brazer had simply ignored his requests to submit reports on some of the charges.

Brazer could not testify as scheduled before the Commission last week after booking himself into a private hospital under a pseudonym with a stress related heart ailment. He issued strict instructions with the hospital not to release information about his condition or doctor's name and was secretly released on Sunday afternoon.

When the Commission found out on Tuesday that he had been released but had not informed the Commission, Brazer's attorney, Tom Dreyer, said that Brazer had taken a powerful sleeping pill and could not speak to the Commission.

Mpumalanga safety & security MEC, Steve Mabona, will testify before the Commission on Wednesday after also being booked off work due to an unspecified stress related ailment.

Mabona initially organised the two licenses for Mbete-Kgositsile and send his State-issue car and personal bodyguards to ferry her from Johannesburg to Delmas, where she was tested.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


412 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


South Africa;
Nepotism in traffic department stalls anti-corruption drive


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Nelspruit - Most of the unruly junior traffic officers who are allegedly involved in widescale license fraud in Mpumalanga are family members or other relatives of the department's directors, the Moldenhauer Commission heard on Tuesday.

The Commission, which is investigating the irregular issue of hundreds of thousands of fraudulent or irregular licenses including one to the deputy speaker of Parliament, Baleka Mbete-Kgositsile, heard in Nelspruit that it was impossible to discipline these corrupt officials without interference from the directors.

"The moment you point out that they have broken regulations or you attempt to discipline them, they simply pick up the phone and call their relatives who have no problem about transferring you," explained chief traffic inspector Hermanus Meyer.

"In the most recent incident, when I confronted officers at Kwaggafontein about cooking the books on May 2, they said that my rank meant nothing and started threatening me with death. It got so bad that license applicants forced their way into the office and joined the riot." 

Meyer testified that he had been forced to flee the centre to avoid being assaulted. At least three officials at Kwaggafontein are directly related to department head, advocate Stanley Soko and department director general, Cello Mahlangu.

No disciplinary action was taken against the officers for the incident. Meyer also told the Commission that none of the seven testing officers at Kwaggafontein were actually registered as certified testing officials and that the centre itself was also unregistered. "So, legally speaking, these people are breaking the law with the full knowledge of all their superiors. Every license issued from this place is therefore invalid, despite being issued on legal forms and certificates," he said.

Other problems which he had repeatedly attempted to get his superiors to investigate, he said, included regular overclaims by traffic officers on their transport and accommodation allowances.

Officers also insisted, Meyer said, on closing their offices at 12h00 on Fridays while collecting a salary for a full day's work.

More worrying, he said, was proof that officers had sold the centre's learners license book to local Driving Schools, who then taught their pupils to learn the answers off by heart.

"So, instead of learning the rules of the road, these people learn that the answer to question one is 'A' and so on. Nine out of ten applicants pass in this way," he explained.

To prove that there had been a leakage, Meyer said that he had changed the sequence of the questions on one occasion. Every single applicant who wrote the test failed.

"Licenses are being given to people who cannot even handle the steering wheels of cars, never mind drive. This is the reason for the high death rate on our roads and the people who are condoning it are murderers," he said.

Meyer also confirmed earlier testimony that the all vehicle test centres in KwaNdebele were "pathetically inadequate" and that most were simply bare pieces of bulldozed veld.

"When I have attempted to apply normal test standards, I was been reprimanded by my superior who told me to have some sympathy and be more understanding," Meyer added.

Control officers, who are meant to monitor for problems were also never in office more than two days a week he said and had on occasions used work time, vehicles and funds to go watch cricket.

Meyer called for the establishment of an internal but semi- independent inspectorate which could "swoop" on centres and check every file, document and procedure.

"The only way we are going to stop this corruption is by creating a policeman for policemen. Some team of dedicated investigators with real power who can root out corruption and then monitor to ensure that it never comes back," he said.

LANGUAGE: English

South Africa;
14 pro-Mpumalanga demonstratos to appear in court on Wednesda


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

GROBLERSDAL - Fourteen people will appear in the Motetema magistrate's court on Wednesday in connection with ambushing and setting alight a Lebowa transport bus while demanding that Groblersdal be incorporated into Mpumalanga.

Northern Province police spokesperson, Supt. Phuti Setati, said 10 suspects were arrested on Monday, when the bus was burnt, and another four suspects were arrested on Tuesday afternoon.

"We expect more violence on Wednesday during the court hearing, but will deploy more soldiers and police to monitor the situation," said Motetema police spokesperson, Inspector Matjokotja Masinya.

The 30 bus passengers were forced off the bus on the Motetema/Monsterlos road before dawn on Monday, before the pro- Mpumalanga demonstrators set the bus alight.

The suspects had allegedly decided to support the call by demonstrators in Bushbuckridge who have been demanding that their area be included into Mpumalanga for the past two weeks.

National minister of safety and security, Sydney Mufamadi, and deputy minister of environmental affairs, Peter Mokaba, will address a rally at the Mapulaneng College of Education in Bushbuckridge on Wednesday.

Provincial working committees from Mpumalanga and Northern Province are also expected to attend the rally. .

May 13, 1997


South Africa;
Matriculants wander aimlessly because of poor career choice


BYLINE: Dumisane Lubisi, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Nelspruit - The lack of proper career guidance at schools has led to matriculants with the correct qualifications drifting around aimlessly, said deputy mayor of Nelspruit, Fatima Mabuza, on Tuesday.

Addressing the launch of a week-long provincial careers exhibition hosted by the Career Exhibition and Information Association in Nelspruit, Mabuza said wrong career choices cost millions of rands. 

"Someone who is in the wrong profession will also regret it for the rest of their lives," she said. The exhibition, which has been held for the past three years, attracted 33 exhibitors this year, compared to 21 exhibitors last year.

Twenty-six schools from the across the province have been invited to attend the exhibition.

Representative of the Association of Chatered Certified Accountants, Ndivhuho Nepfumbada, said pupils in Standards Six and Seven should should especially attend the exhibition as they still had to select subjects for their career choice. Design School Southern Africa's Tanya Bernnitt said that since the government began focusing on technical and science subjects, art was no longer a subject at some schools.

"Some youths have the capability of being artists, but are denied that privilege because arts is no longer considered as a subject," Bernnitt said.

Other exhibitors at this year's exhibition include the Lowveld Agricultural College, the Department of Environmental Affairs and Tourism, Rand Afrikaans Universiteit, the Medical University of Southern Africa, Technikon Pretoria, and other technikons and univerities.

The exhibition will continue until Fridaym May 16.

South Africa;
Post office fooled by robber posing as guard


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Africa, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Nelspruit - The management of the Nelspruit Post Office were outwitted by a robber posing as a security guard who "collected" over R20 000 cash and R66 000 in cheques on Monday, police said.

Police spokesperson, Captain Joseph Fundama, told African Eye News Service (South Africa) on Tuesday that an unknown man wearing a Coin Security guard uniform arrived at the post office at midday and claimed that he was on his daily "collection duty". 

Fundama said the management staff readily handed the suspect the money and the receipt expecting him to take it to the bank.

"The management was surprised when the real Coin Security personnel arrived later to collect the money," said Captain Fundama.

He said post office staff were unable to describe the suspect because they did not suspect any foul play.

No arrests have been made and police are still investigating.

Africa News


May 13, 1997


South Africa;
Almost impossible to weed out fraudulent licenses


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Nelspruit - Not even an extended campaign of police road blocks and spot license checks will be able to substantially reduce the number of fraudulent licenses currently being used on South Africa's roads, the Moldenhauer Commission into License Fraud heard in Nelspruit on Monday afternoon.

Besides the man-power necessary for such an extended campaign, witnesses said that majority of traffic officers and policemen didn't have the slightest idea how to identify either fraudulent or fake licenses.

"In fact, police and the Commissioner of Oaths regularly stamp fraudulent licenses as being the genuine item when they don't even look remotely like proper licenses," said chief traffic inspector Jacobus Breytenbach. 

"During my checks on licenses at Home Affairs, I discovered that less than one percent of all licenses from KwaNdebele are valid or legal. The rest of all fraudulent or fakes in one way or another."

The only way to "weed out" the hundreds of thousands of suspected fraudulent licenses was to appoint a special task team to physically check each one of the estimated 5-million licenses currently listed on the Home Affairs population register computer system, he added.

This team would have to receive special training to check for incorrect date stamps, signatures, serial numbers, technical information and colour inconsistencies.

A simultaneous switch to a system where all drivers have to be re- tested for their licenses every five to seven years would also help phase out any additional fraudulent licenses which were missed by the task team.

"But even then, we cannot constitutionally scrap suspected fraudulent licenses without really strong evidence or we'd open ourselves to civic law suits," Breytenbach said.

But, Breytenbach said, not even those licenses which were issued without bribery or fraud are all valid.

Serious inadequacies at virtually all test centres in KwaNdebele and KaNgwane prevented license applicants from being tested properly, he explained.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


417 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 13, 1997


Business and Finance;
Mpumalanga still studying international airport


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Nelspruit - Mpumlanga's provincial government is still conducting a feasibility study into the construction of the province's first international airport at Primkop, near Nelspruit, more than two years after the initiative was first launched.

Nelspruit is one of only seven towns which will be accorded full international airport rights under a new government initiative to tighten up customs control. 

Mpumalanga MEC for public works, roads and transport, Lackson Mathebula, said on Monday that the feasibility study was being done to determine whether there was enough of a demand for an international airport in Nelspruit.

Presenting his budget speech for 1997/98, Mathebula said the study would also determine the size of the airport and whether the selected site was technically suitable and safe before development began.

Thereafter, he said, the project would be handed over to the private sector to build, operate and transfer to his department.

Mathebula said his department had already invited and received proposals for the construction, operation and transfer of the airport.

He explained that his department was relying largely on private sector funding to develop the airport, but that his department had already budgeted to buy the land on which it would be built.

"It is important that government owns the land," Mathebula explained.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


418 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 14, 1997


Namibia;
Police nab 4 in major drug bust


BYLINE: Christof Maletsky, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Windhoek - The Namibian Police Drug Enforcement Unit achieved a major breakthrough in the fight against international drug smuggling when they arrested four people for possession of cocaine with a street value of N$3,2 million.

Nampol confiscated a cache of 6,412 kilograms of cocaine, the biggest haul in Namibia's history.

Four males, all travelling on Zambian passports, was arrested over a period of three weeks through an undercover operation spanning Windhoek and Keetmanshoop. 

The bust came as a result of a tip-off from a member of the public and close co-operation from Interpol.

In the first operation on April 30, Michael Bwalya (25) and Moses Mwiya (31) were arrested at Windhoek hospitality centre with 1,37 kg of cocaine. Bwalya's passport identified him as a student while Mwiya's described as a businessman.

Both were staying in Hillbrow, South Africa.

In the second operation on May 4, Fred Obed Malimba (25) from Sandton City was arrested at the Windhoek Bus Terminal following a tip-off by a vigilant member of the public. Malimba was arrested in possession of cocaine with a street value of N$2,3 million.

The final operation took place on May 10 when Romanus Mutale (37) was arrested at a travellers lodge at Keetmanshoop with 1,4kg cocaine.

All four have already appeared in court and their cases were postponed.

Police spokesperson Inspector Hieronymous Goraseb told a media briefing yesterday that drug syndicates had discovered a new method of operation, mailing drugs to their destinations through normal postal services.

Only in the operation at the bus terminal was the suspect in possession of the cocaine. In the other cases the drug had been mailed and the suspects were caught red-handed after collecting it.

Goraseb said parcels were sent from a South American country to Namibians who collected them for the suspects.

According to Chief Inspector Louis Mensah, drug smugglers arrive in the country and seek accommodation for a couple of days.

Having obtained the address and telephone number of their Namibian host, after leaving the smuggler would telephone the host asking him to collect a parcel at the post office which had been sent to the host's address.

The smuggler would then collect the packet at a later stage.

Mensah said the latest method of drug smuggling was very worrying as Namibians were allowing themselves to be used in the process.

Goraseb added that the Police could not ignore a Namibian's role in such a case and warned citizens to be on the alert for such operations.

He said the Police had worked 24 hours a day for three weeks on the case and are confident that they are on the brink of a major breakthrough against a drug smuggling syndicate using the suspects as "couriers".

In March, a 45-year-old woman was arrested with cocaine with a street value of N$1,4 million. She was nabbed while waiting for someone to pick her up at Windhoek International Airport following close co-operation with German customs officials.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


419 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 14, 1997


Namibia;
Government denies journalists' charges


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Windhoek - Government has denied recent accusations by the Journalists Association of Namibia regarding calls made by high-ranking officials about imposing restrictions on freedom of expression.

Minister of Information and Broadcasting, Ben Amathila, said in a statement the accusations were viewed as serious and there was no intention to interfere in the freedoms enshrined in the Namibian Constitution.

"The Government recently demonstrated its commitment to freedom of the media by amending the Privileges and Immunities of Parliament Bill after it was brought to its attention that certain clauses in the Bill impeded media freedom," Amathila said. 

At a function to mark World Press Freedom Day in Windhoek last Friday, JAN said it was concerned "about an increasingly intolerant attitude on the part of members of the Government towards the fundamental right to freedom of expression through the media" as enshrined in the Constitution.

JAN also dismissed recent assaults on the integrity of media practitioners as attempts aimed at undermining the credibility of the media in the eyes of the public.

Previously JAN had come out strongly against a statement by President Sam Nujoma in an interview with a local bi-weekly in which he described the media as unpatriotic and the "enemy".

"This is not a Namibian press.

It is foreigners who are leading the press here.

They are South African or have their own foreign tradition and culture ..." Nujoma said in the December interview.

Addressing a workshop in March, Nguno Wakolele, permanent secretary of the Ministry of Information threatened that the Constitution would be changed if the media failed to act responsibly.

"We all cherish this freedom (of expression) and we have to guard it like a fragile and perishable commodity," Wakolele said.

For his part, Amathila said every right entailed its own responsibility and therefore Government called on the media to be accountable in their reporting and to be sensitive to the views of all citizens.

"The past is still fresh in the memories of many Namibians and the media are in a position to stir up emotions which could place our peace and unity in jeopardy," he noted.

On Press Freedom Day, JAN also acknowledged Government's achievements and efforts so far in maintaining democracy and freedom of expression.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


420 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 14, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Economic Reforms Blamed For Straining Environment


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1112 words


 

VICTORIA FALLS, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Economic structural adjustment programmes, often at the urging of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, have been blamed for triggering survival mechanisms in the developing world's natural resources sector, thereby threatening the environment.

In a joint presentation at the 15th Commonwealth Forestry Conference, two experts said reforms had resulted in a proliferation of timber logging enterprises, cottage industries, illegal game hunting and illegal conversion of forest reserves to agricultural land.

Lidia Brito of Mozambique's Eduardo Mondlane University and Patrick Mushove of the Zimbabwe Forest Research Centre said Mozambique introduced the reforms after a vicious 16-year-old civil war which spurred massive migration. 

"In that process, national parks were converted to military bases, marginalizing the wildlife, the commercial hardwood was exploited without any control, thus facilitating the proliferation of small-scale and often illegal logging," they said.

In Zimbabwe, the national parks and safaris sub-sector was able to maintain adequate stocks for hunting and non-consumptive tourism, besides restraining human encroachment onto the parks.

However, the two said success was still far as illegal settlements on protected forests continued to haunt authorities.

They called for a general rehabilitation policy for Mozambique which would see the indigenous hardwood and tourist industries streamlined, decentralized and located within forest and wildlife producing districts to ensure maximum benefits for local communities.

"Among other things, the current timber permit system should be replaced by a concession regime that ensures concessionaire accountability for at least 10 years from the date it was granted," they said.

For Zimbabwe, the two argued in favour of the consolidation of institutional arrangements conducive to the sustainable functioning of the Campfire concept in wildlife areas and to the promotion of the same concept in timber and non-wood products obtainable from state farms.

They noted that wood carving was an important ancillary industry in both countries and was attached to the tourist industry. Therefore, they proposed that it be tolerated, formalized, supported and incorporated into local institutions.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 14, 1997


Libya;
UN To Investigate Kadhafi Breach Of Air Embargo


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

NEW YORK (PANA) - Libyan leader Moammar Kadhafi's flight to Niger and Nigeria last week, despite a United Nations air embargo on his country, is to be investigated by the Sanctions Committee of the United Nations Security Council.

Speaking Tuesday after a closed-door session of the council in New York, council President Park Soo Gil said its members had decided to refer the issue to the committee.

He said that the committee, expected to discuss the issue Thursday or Friday, would "listen to explanations that will be given by the three countries concerned with a view to establishing the fact." 

Kadhafi flew to Niger and Nigeria in four Libyan aircraft to hold prayers marking the Muslim new year.

However, the flight violated the U.N. air embargo imposed on Libya over its alleged involvement in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland. It was also under the embargo for the bombing of a French UTA airliner over Niger a year later.

Meanwhile, the U.S. ambassador to the U.N., Bill Richardson, has expressed his country's concern over the flight violations.

"I raised the Libyan issue," he told U.N. correspondents after briefing the council Tuesday.

"It is obvious that Mr. Kadhafi is in a joy ride, trying to defy the council and our hope is that the council and the Sanctions Committee would deal with this issue very soon," he added. In Washington, the U.S. State Department called for punitive action against Niger and Nigeria for their "complicity" in the violation of the sanctions.

State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns said that the U.S. had evidence that the trip was planned and worked out secretly by the governments of Niger, Nigeria and Libya.

He described the trip as a "conscious provocation, not only on the part of Libya but also of Niger and Nigeria."

Kadhafi's trip was the latest in a series of Libya's violation of the sanctions.

Council warned Libya in April against further violations after it flew pilgrims to Saudi Arabia.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.
