Africa News


May 14, 1997


Science and Health;
AIDS Expected To Cause Severe Cut In Population


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The impact and effect of AIDS is expected to cause a drastic reduction of tens of millions in the projected population figures of South Africa during the first quarter of the next century.

This is the dramatic finding of international experts in the latest edition of the World Population Data Sheet, published annually by the Washington-based Population Reference Bureau. 

The 1997 edition predicts that the population of South Africa in the year 2010 will be 45.7 million -- almost 12 million below the 1996 forecast of 57.5 million.

It further predicts that in the following 15 years to 2025 there will be a slight reduction in South Africa's population from 45.7 million to 45.5 million.

Should these predictions prove correct, it means that South Africa's population in 28 years from now will be almost the same as it is today. And the bureau points out that these predictions could be further affected by unpredictable factors such as famines, plagues and other natural disasters.

The report -- for which AIDS data has been gathered for over a decade -- goes on to point out that other countries in sub-Saharan Africa are facing the same situation as South Africa, among them Zimbabwe.

"The dramatic projection is based on work done by the United States Bureau of Census, and it is simply due to AIDS," the report adds.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


423 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 14, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Critical Agenda Prepared For OAU Summit


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - A critical agenda to review the past and chart the course for Africa's future politics and economics has been prepared for the 33rd Organisation of African Unity (OAU) summit to be held in Harare next month.

Addressing a news conference on Wednesday, Zimbabwe's foreign affairs minister, Stan Mudenge, said the three-day assembly of African heads of state and government starting on June 2, would discuss a wide range of issues covering politics, economics and health.

"Pan-Africanism has triumphed, we have triumphed on the political front and now we are on the economic war front," Mudenge said. 

The 53-member body, whose chairmanship goes to President Robert Mugabe for the next 12 months, has been praised for its role in ending colonial rule in most of the continent.

Also in the limelight during the summit would be Ghana, which celebrates 40 years of independence and was the first state, south of the Sahara, to achieve that status.

The celebration, however, takes place at a time when there are a number of countries still torn by conflicts.

"All this takes place against political developments of the Great Lakes, which will preoccupy the heads and we will look at Liberia, Sierra Leone, Somalia, Burundi, the peace process in Angola, the Middle East and the disagreement between Libya, France, Britain and America," Mudenge said.

The summit will look at the Lome Convention in light of the green paper that has been prepared by the European Union on the state of relations and trade with its 71 partners of the African, Caribbean and Pacific states (ACP) after the year 2000 when the convention expires.

The fight against malaria is also on the agenda.

"The World Health Organisation (WHO) is proposing the adoption of a declaration to fight Malaria," the minister said.

Malaria has re-emerged as a fatal diseases as a strain resistant to most first line drugs is being experienced by many countries, including Zimbabwe.

"We look forward to a busy time," Mudenge said.

Meanwhile, two candidates have forwarded their names for consideration for the post of Organisation of African Unity (OAU) Secretary-General when it falls vacant at the 33rd summit of African heads of state and government in Harare in June.

The incumbent, Salim Ahmed Salim of Tanzania who is seeking a third term, is being challenged the foreign minister of Cote d'Ivoire, Amara Essy.

Salim, who has been at the helm of the 53-member organisation since 1989, is a former deputy prime minister of Tanzania.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


424 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 14, 1997


Liberia;
Johnson-Sirleaf Ready For Presidential Polls


BYLINE: Paul Ejime,, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, the only female candidate contesting Liberia's forthcoming presidential election, said here Wednesday, she would use her national and international contacts to accelerate economic reconstruction post-war country Liberia if elected president.

"The great task in Liberia is that of economic reconstruction, to counter the deterioration of the past 10 to 15 years," she said at the monthly forum organised by the Pan-african News Agency (PANA) and the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN).

Johnson-Sirleaf, a former Liberian finance minister and until recently UNDP's assistant administrator and director of the regional bureau for Africa, said Liberia was in need of "a leader not a ruler." 

"Liberians are tired of war and will no longer support those who exploited and appropriated the resources of the country," she said, adding that the issue was not about money, but about "rebuilding, healing and national unity."

She said the task of mobilizing war-traumatised Liberians for national reconstruction required someone with a "good tract record and the sensitivity of a woman."

Johnson-Sirleaf, 58, who holds a master's degree in public administration from Harvard, is on the board of several African and international development institutions.

She was a pioneer member of the group of the World Bank's council of African advisers, and a recipient of the Grand Commander Star of African Redemption, Liberia's highest civilian award.

A founding member of Liberia's Action Party that challenged the military regime of late president Samuel Doe in the 1985 elections, Johnson-Sirleaf, recalled her political activism, which landed her in jail twice for a total of nine months between July 1985 and July 1986.

"I have been through it before and I feel myself equal to the task of leadership," she said, adding "as a political figure, private citizen and mother, I have been at the forefront of social, economic and political development in Africa and throughout the world for more than two decades."

Some 16 parties have sprung up in Liberia for the post-war elections earlier scheduled for May 30 under a peace accord singed by the warring factions in Liberia in Abuja.

But this date now appears unrealistic, with many of the parties calling for a postponement to allow for better preparation.

PANA learnt that a meeting of all Liberian political parties has been called for Thursday in Abuja, with Nigerian head of state and the ECOWAS chairman Gen. Sani Abacha, expected to agree on a new date for the elections after a civil war that has killed more than 150,000 people in Africa's first republic founded in 1847 by freed slaves from America.

Johnson-Sirleaf said her Unity Party was ready for the poll, provided it was held after adequate preparation and under conducive atmosphere to make the result "acceptable and credible."

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 14, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Kenya's National Team Leaves For Germany


BYLINE: Sam Mugo, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - Kenya's national football team, Harambee Stars, left Nairobi Tuesday night for a three-week training stint in Germany in preparation for their return leg Group I World Cup qualifier against Nigeria's Super Eagles in lagos on June 7.

In Germany, the team will be based in a small resort town of Gundelfigen where they are expected to play a series of friendly matches against the local sides.

The team will also have the opportunity to watch the European Champions' League final on May 28 between Germany's Borussia Dortmund and Juventus of Turin, Italy, at the Munich Olympic Stadium. 

Harambee Stars are to travel straight from Germany to Lagos to take on the Super Eagles who hope to bag the three points on offer in the forthcoming encounter.

"It's unfortunate that we drew in Nairobi (against Harambee Stars) but we are confident that we will get the points in Lagos and play a good game against Guinea," Nigeria's Turkey-based Dan Amokachi, was quoted as saying after the 2-1 victory his team obtained against Burkina Faso in April.

Nigeria, which is on top of Group I, plays its final qualifier against Guinea in Conakry while Kenya, which is second, plays its last game in Burkina Faso in August.

Harambee Stars German born coach, Reinhardt Fabisch, who is back to Kenya after a nine-year absence, is confident that his boys are capable of upsetting the Super Eagles and sneaking into the World Cup finals slated for France in 1998.

"If we can beat Nigeria then the first thing I will do when I get home is to enroll at the Alliance Francaise for French classes" to prepare for France 98, Fabisch said.

Meanwhile, the Kenya Football Federation (KFF) in conjunction with Minto Travels Company and Ethiopian Airlines have offered an attractive package for Harambee stars' fans wishing to travel to Lagos for the return match against the Super Eagles.

The package announced by the football administration body last week follows the increasing interest by Kenyan fans to travel to Lagos.

The travel group announced that fans will be required to pay us 770 U.S dollars (about 41,580 K. Shs) to cover air ticket and full board accommodation for one day, air transfers, visas, security and VIP tickets for the game which will be played at the National Stadium in Sulere.

Africa News


May 14, 1997


Cameroon-Elections;
Forty-Four Political Parties Vie For 180 Seats


BYLINE: Peter Efande, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

YAOUNDE, Cameroon (PANA) - Forty-four Cameroonian political parties are now flexing muscles for the upcoming legislative elections in which 180 seats are up for grabs on May 17.

Out of the country's 150 political parties, only 44 have been registered by the Ministry of Territorial Administration which is organizing the polls.

A source in the ministry told CAMNEWS that out of these registered parties, only 13 are represented in all the 74 the constituencies. These include the major parties -- the CPDM (Cameroon's People's Democratic Party), SDF (Social Democratic Front), UNDP (National Union For Democracy and Progress) and the CDU (Union for Democracy and Progress). 

Campaigns have gone into full swing as each party tries to convince voters. The government has allocated air time on radio and television to each party and foreign observers from France, the United States and the Commonwealth are already in the country to monitor the polls.

Apart from incumbent President Paul Biya who is running on the ticket of the ruling CPDM, the other party leaders have embarked on hectic campaigns countrywide.

As expected, most of them are already crying foul over the absence of an independent electoral commission.

They do not trust the "neutrality" of the Ministry of Territorial Administration, which they consider as an arm of the ruling CPDM government since the bosses in this Ministry belong to the ruling party.

Nonetheless, the campaigns have so far been devoid of violence. The Government has also promised to maintain peace during and after the elections. However, a curfew is still being maintained in the North-West Province where violent confrontation between the army and armed gangs left many people dead last month.

Only four political parties were represented in the defunct parliament. The CPDM had 88 seats as against 68 seats for UNDP, 18 seats for UPC and six seats for the MDR.

As in last year's local council elections, few analysts expect miracles in the political landscape after May 17. But many say the fact that the radical opposition led the SDF, which boycotted previous polls will now participate, could upset the status quo ante.

Since Cameroon's democratic wind of change started blowing in 1990, the SDF has left a hallmark in the country's political history.

Launched on May 26, 1990 in Bamenda, the SDF, with its charismatic Chairman John Fru Ndi, stands out as a political force to be reckoned with. The Party boycotted the 1992 legislative elections, thus giving the leeway for other parties to grab parliamentary seats in its strongholds.

However, in the 1992 Presidential elections, the SDF candidate came second to the CPDM's Paul Biya. Now, the SDF has said bygone to boycotts and is taking part in all elections.

Besides, the Party's national following was felt during last year's Council elections when it grabbed seats outside its strongholds in major parts of the country.

The SDF swept council seats in almost all corners of the republic, "even in Yaounde, the CPDM stronghold," says Tatah Mentan an eminent political scientist and lecturer at the Advanced School of Mass Communications in Yaounde.

But it remains to be seen whether the SDF is capable of unseating the ruling CPDM party which was created in 1985, also in Bamenda.

The CPDM is one of the parties that is represented in all the legislative constituencies in the country.

Although some of its big wigs failed in the current primaries, its Assistant Secretary-General, Gregoire Owona, says the party is set to maintain if not surpass its numerical strength in parliament.

Then comes the UNDP which has headquarters in the northern town of Garoua, hometown of former President Amadou Ahidjo.

It's leader, Bello Bouba Maigari was once a Prime Minister. He is considered to be a tactful politician who measures his words with icy precision.

The 1992 legislative elections saw his party reaping dividends in the South, West and North-West provinces when the SDF boycotted the polls. It had the second largest number of MP's in the defunct parliament after the CPDM, and commands most of the councils in its stronghold is in the northern provinces.

However, the UNDP has lately been rocked by resignations and carpet- crossing by some influential militants, especially Adamou Nganda an MP from Mbere and that of Mvouen Vincent Mohamadou (alternate MP from Bankim, to the CPDM Party.

Both accuse Maigari of being allergic to the aspirations of grassroots militants. Whatever the case, the May 17 legislative election results will show whether their resignations will have any effect on the party in their various constituencies.

The UPC -- the oldest political party in the country -- could have been a force to be reckoned with had internal strife not torn it into two bickering factions: the UPC Kodock and the UPC Ntumazah.

Now, the party is just a mere shadow of itself with the leaders of the various factions operating in their fiefs in the manner of ancient warlords.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


427 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 14, 1997


South Africa;
Security personnel 'feared for FW's life' after ANC unbanned


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Cape Town - Former president F W De Klerk told the Truth Commission today his personal security staff had feared - after he unbanned the ANC in 1990 - that he would be assassinated by disgruntled security force members.

He told the commission in Cape Town today that his government's reform policies after February 1990 had not been supported by "small" elements in the security forces.

Mr De Klerk also told the commission that several commentators and his political opponents continued to claim he had not apologised for apartheid. 

"This is simply not true. Let me place, once and for all, a renewed apology on record. "I apologise in my capacity as leader of the National Party to the millions of South Africans who:

* suffered the wrenching disruption of forced removals in respect of their homes, businesses and land;

* over the years suffered the shame of being arrested for pass law offences;

* over the decades, and indeed centuries, suffered the indignities and humiliation of racial discrimination;

* for a long time were prevented from exercising their full democratic rights in the land of their birth;

* were unable to achieve their full potential because of job reservation; and

* in any way suffered as a result of discriminatory legislation and policies."

Mr De Klerk said he had apologised on at least three previous occasions, but offered this renewed apology "in a spirit of true repentance in full knowledge of the tremendous harm that apartheid has done to millions of South Africans".

Mr De Klerk's remarks came during the National Party's second submission to the Truth Commission.

He said there was a perception that the NP was not accepting overall responsibility for its part in the conflict of the past, that NP politicians were leaving the security forces in the lurch and that they were "washing their hands" of things done in terms of their policies and decisions.

"Once again this is simply not true. Let me state clearly that the National Party and I accept full responsibility for all our policies, decisions and actions."

The NP stood by its security forces, who had implemented its policies and decisions "and all reasonable interpretations thereof".

But there were many things which had not been authorised by the NP and of which they were not aware, Mr De Klerk said. "The recent information of atrocities I find as shocking and abhorrent as anyone else."

Mr De Klerk said he could not accept that every statement made in amnesty applications was the truth, and that he was not in a position to pass judgment on these cases.

"Murders and assassinations cannot be justified. Anyone who did go as far as that did something totally unacceptable, and we stand by that."


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


428 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 14, 1997


South Africa;
Gangsters pact: Pagad calls on bid team to quit


BYLINE: Joseph Aranes, Lindsay Barnes and Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Cape Town - Pagad has called for the resignation of Olympic Bid Company staff and the provincial director of labour, Brian Williams, over the signing of an anti-crime initiative with alleged gangsters.

The agreement, signed with the Community Outreach Forum (Core) - the organisation of gangsters who say they have reformed - did not include an undertaking to stop dealing in drugs. 

The initiative involves using gangs to help fight crime in Cape Town to boost the city's 2004 Olympic bid. In the programme's manifesto, the gangsters declared their willingness to act as "protectors of communities", rid the city centre and Bo-Kaap of criminal activity and clear street youth gangs from the area by today.

People Against Gangsterism and Drugs national secretary Shariff Khan said his organisation was not anti-Olympic and acknowledged the Games to be a noble institution with noble efforts.

"But we are against a corrupt Olympics where known drug dealers and gangsters form part of the bidding process."

The situation was now that the Bid Company, the Government and big business had formed an alliance with gangsters at the expense of law-abiding citizens.

"It is now in the hands of drug dealers and gangsters to determine the destiny of a sane and sober society. As Pagad we say 'No' to this alliance and call for the resignation of all Olympic bid officials and of Mr Williams, who initiated the plan. If this situation is not rectified immediately, Pagad will call for a boycott of the Olympic bid and big businesses supporting the bid."

The Bid Company intends issuing a statement soon. It is understood the company hopes to hold discussions with Pagad.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 14, 1997


South Africa;
Black Nat MPs keep close eye on Roelf and FW


BYLINE: Clive Sawyer, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Cape Town - The actions this weekend of Roelf Meyer and National Party leader F W de Klerk will be monitored closely by a large group of black Nat MPs, who will meet next week to discuss whether they are satisfied with the outcome.

Most of the group are from the Western Cape and include those pushing for an enhanced leadership role for people of colour in the NP in the province, including a demand for a coloured premier. Sources denied that the discussions should be seen as a move towards the establishment of a formal black caucus within the NP. 

However, there was concern that disclosures about next week's talks would result in a backlash by the conservative white bloc within the party, which has been seen as the victor in the decision by Mr De Klerk to shut down Mr Meyer's taskforce investigating a political realignment.

The developments are part of continuing racial tensions within the party, particularly in the Western Cape, where there is pressure for the NP to reward people of colour who delivered it control of provincial and much of local government.

Meanwhile, signs are that efforts are being made to defuse tensions within the party prior to the weekend meeting of the Gauteng head council, which Mr De Klerk and Mr Meyer are to address.

Party sources said it appeared Mr De Klerk was succeeding in keeping most of the NP behind him through the crisis. And efforts were also made at this week's special meeting of the Gauteng executive to keep Mr Meyer on board within the party.

Interviewed after the Gauteng executive meeting, Mr Meyer said he had had a "very good discussion" with the executive. However, he had not yet made a decision on whether it would be best to stay in the party, leave it, or leave politics.

Evidence of the continuing divergence between Meyer loyalists in Gauteng and the rest of the party was a statement issued by the provincial NP youth in which they reiterated leader Paolo Andrade's view that the NP should disband to facilitate further developments towards a political realignment.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

430 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 14, 1997


South Africa;
The ANC and the truth (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Cape Town - The African National Congress has submitted the names of people who spied on it to the truth and reconciliation commission, but has asked that the list be kept secret.

The African National Congress has placed the Truth and Reconciliation Commission in an awkward dilemma by asking it to keep secret the identities of ANC members who spied for the former government.

The organisation's argument that the agents could face the danger of assassination or harassment if their names were disclosed is hardly a persuasive reason for subverting a fundamental function of the TRC - the fullest possible disclosure of human rights abuses that took place during the apartheid era. 

Security police and others who have confessed to horrendous crimes and have asked for amnesty have been publicly identified and they stand as much risk of assassination or other harassment in the future as would ANC members who spied on the organisation for the former government.

The ANC cannot ask for its confidential evidence to the TRC to be treated differently. Neither should argument over its request for secrecy be allowed to obscure an equally grave matter which the organisation appears to be unwilling to present to the TRC - the methods and processes by which it identified the agents and spies in its ranks, and the procedures by which some of them were punished and even executed.

It is common cause that some prisoners in ANC camps were appallingly treated. It has been admitted that some were found guilty and sentenced to death by tribunals on which nobody had any legal qualification or experience. What has still to be disclosed is the evidence which condemned these people to death or punishment and how it was obtained. That is essential to any informed assessment of the ANC's activities during the struggle and its violations of human rights.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 14, 1997


South Africa;
Sedick Christian: Good Samaritan


BYLINE: Sharkey Isaacs, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

Cape Town - An escape from death on board a cargo ship more than a quarter of a century ago prompted Sedick Christian, one of District Six's most colourful characters, to devote time for the rest of his life to helping poor people and those in distress.

Sedick, among other things, is currently struggling to provide decent burials for city vagrants and save them from the indignity of a pauper's funeral.

His work as a Good Samaritan began on the day he saved the life of a shipmate, and was badly injured himself, on board the cargo vessel SA Komatiland in Las Palmas in 1971.

The vessel had called at the island for maintenance repairs and a general paint spruce-up. Sedick, a professional seaman who had clawed his way up from galley boy to Bosun, had just finished a stint of duty when a deckhand, painting a mast, fell out from a bosun's chair. 

"He had not secured his harness properly," said Sedick,"and he would surely have been killed had I not gone directly beneath him to cushion his fall with my shoulders and back tilted at a 40 degree angle.

"While the seaman escaped with a broken arm, I was more seriously injured. I spent six weeks in hospital in Las Palmas with a back injury - but I had the satisfaction of knowing I had saved someone's life. The incident prompted me, from then on, to do something good for my fellow men and women."

In the past year Sedick has shouldered the responsibiltiy of organising the burials of three city vagrants after raising the money for their funerals.

Now 54 years old, he is caretaker of the area's Indian Plaza and a committee member of the District Six Night Shelter in Selkirk Street. He says he will only undertake charitable work on request.

He has found it is not always easy for a Good Samaritan to raise money for his work and, on at least one occasion, he has had to pay out of his own pocket to make up the deficit in covering the cost of a funeral.

"That was when Jennifer Jantjies, a vagrant in her 30s, was knocked down and killed by a taxi. The other vagrants in the area asked me to give her a decent burial.

"I approached various people, including a number of businesmen, for financial aid but could not raise the full amount - and I made up the deficit from my own pocket. Soon afterwards another vagrant, Anna Jones, who was 29, died from a disease and then Phillip Johnson, 49, collapsed and died after asking me to give him a birthday treat.

"Last Christmas I kept my promise to Phillip and gave his bergie friends a belated treat from the money which I had raised. I asked my wife, Amiena, to cook some food and I distributed it among the vagrants, telling them this was what Phillip had asked me to do before he died."

Speaking of his days as a mariner, he says the urge to go to sea was irresistible from the time he reached puberty.

He believes he could be a descendant of his namesake, Fletcher Christian of Mutiny on the Bounty fame, who was said to have fathered offspring among the South Pacific islanders.

Like Fletcher, he too was involved in a mutiny - but fortunately history was not repeated because it was on a different issue and on a much smaller scale. The dispute was amicably resolved through a bit of hard bargaining and negotiation with the officers and captain.

"After that, the German captain of the vessel was very wary of me and repeatedly wanted to know how Fletcher was related to me," he said with a laugh.

According to his seaman's papers, Sedick sailed in 15 ships in a 13-year career at sea which took him all over the world.

After giving up his career at sea, he took his first "landlubber" job as a stevedore supervisor and then became a forklift- and heavy duty crane-operator.

An interest in civic issues prompted him to stand as an independent candidate in the municipal elections last year. He did not win "but it was an interesting exercise from which one could only learn".

Before going to sea he appeared on stage as a harmonising vocalist with a popular District Six based singing group, the "original" Rockets.

His interest in entertainment still continues today and he recruits stage and variety artists for charity concerts.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 14, 1997


Business and Finance;
Cape painters land R15-m deal


BYLINE: Thabo Mabaso, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Cape Town - The Saldanha Steel Project has awarded a R15- million contract to a Cape Town black consortium to paint its steel manufacturing plant.

The consortium of nine painting contractors known as Group 10 Civils will begin painting next week and continue until September next year.

Saldanha steel project director Ben Nel said Group 10 Civils was awarded the contract because it had presented a professional bid. 

"We have a commitment to the Western Cape government to utilise emerging small businesses in the construction of the Saldanha project and Group 10 Civils were the perfect choice," Mr Nel told the Cape Argus during a ceremony to mark the signing of the contract.

He said 800 000 sq m of wall needed to be painted after the plant, to be called Corex 2000, had been constructed.

Mr Nel added that to date Saldanha steel had awarded contracts with a combined value of R250 million to black and small businesses.

Group 10 Civils spokesman Stan D'Oliviera said the company had set itself the objective of performing a world class job with regard to product and service management.

Other small black-owned companies would be judged on Group 10 Civils' performance, he said.

"Long after Corex 2000 has been painted and commissioned, this initiative will always be interpreted and remembered as the standard by which all other contracts will be measured. It will occupy a proud place in the history of our country's development," Mr Nel said.

"We were awarded the contract because of a competitive bid and because we demonstrated our technical capacity to execute the job, and we showed an ability to organise our workforce."

The Corex 2000 plant is the second of its kind in South Africa capable of producing liquid iron by using a variety of low-grade coals as fuel. The first plant is at Iscor's Pretoria works.

Western Cape Economic Affairs Minister Chris Nissen, who was also at the signing ceremony, praised Saldanha Steel for awarding the contract to a small black-owned company.

"If there is a company that is a leader of empowerment, then Saldanha Steel is certainly a leader in this field in the province. In many instances, they are even ahead of the provincial government which has a flawed tendering process," Mr Nissen said.

Africa News


May 14, 1997


South Africa;
ANC asked to seek 'abducted' witness at Winnie trial


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Cape Town - The Truth Commission has asked the African National Congress to help find Katiza Cebekhulu, who said he was abducted by the ANC to prevent his testifying against Winnie Madikizela-Mandela.

Mr Cebekhulu was one of the accused in the trial in which the coach of the Mandela Football Club, Jerry Richardson, was jailed for murdering 14-year-old activist Stompie Seipei. 

Mrs Madikizela-Mandela was fined R15 000 and given a suspended prison sentence as an accessory to the boy's kidnapping.

Mr Cebekhulu arrived in Zambia in March 1991 and was put in protective custody in Lusaka Central Prison. He told journalists from jail that he had been abducted in South Africa by the ANC, allegedly on the instructions of Mrs Madikizela-Mandela.

He said he wanted to be released from jail but did not want to return to South Africa, as he was afraid. He told journalists he knew what had happened to Gabriel Makgwa, a state witness in the trial who disappeared, but refused to say what.

He said he would disclose everything he knew about the death of Stompie after his release.

Deputy-President Thabo Mbeki, who led the ANC delegation to the Truth Commission on Monday and yesterday, said in reply to a question by commissioner Dumisa Ntsebeza that the ANC had been in contact with the Zambian government about Mr Cebekhulu, but had been told he was afraid to return.

"As far as we are concerned, he needs to come back We said there was nothing for him to fear." He did not know where Mr Cebekhulu was at present.

South Africa;
New witnesses to testify on huge bomb in Pretoria


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Cape Town - The African National Congress will give the Truth Commission names of new witnesses to testify about the huge car-bomb found and defused in Pretoria, days before the signing of the Pretoria Minute in 1990.

The ANC said new evidence had come to light suggesting its cadre who was jailed for the incident, Sipho Mabena, may have been tortured into a confession. 

The case was raised by Truth Commissioner Wynand Malan, who said the 114kg bomb - three times the size of the Church Street car-bomb which killed 19 and injured more than 200 - had been found in a taxi parked in the Hallmark parking garage on July 28, 1990. The garage is in the basement of a building used by the SA National Defence Force.

The bullet-riddled body of the part-time driver of the taxi, David Shongwe, was found later.

Mpumalanga premier Mathews Phosa urged the Truth Commission to investigate the case fully.

There were several "disturbing" aspects and one of the new witnesses had suggested Mabena may have been tortured into confessing he had planted the bomb.

Africa News


May 14, 1997


South Africa;
AG warning: there's no justice


BYLINE: Lindsay Barnes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Cape Town - Deliver the basics to the Western Cape justice system if you are serious about reducing crime, Attorney-General Frank Kahn has told the Government.

To date, too little had been done by the new government to address deep concerns about salaries, accommodation, re-

sources, staff, appointments and policy in the system, he said in his annual report tabled in Parliament yesterday.

The problem of inexperienced staff and outdated tools had to be addressed in the short term. The average age of prosecutors in magistrates' courts was 22 and their average experience was only six months, he said. 

And administrative infrastructures in the departments of police and justice lacked a national electronic database to keep track of criminals who committed crimes repeatedly. As a result, they were released on bail.

"Whereas strategic planning is essential for change, the Government should guard against ignoring the basic needs and tools of a good criminal justice system in the pursuit of a new vision."

The administration of justice was in crisis and it was vital that salaries and resources were addressed urgently.

In the 90-page document, Mr Kahn outlined extensive problems that needed to be dealt with urgently. They included:

* A shortage of personnel in the attorney-general's office because of lack of funds for expansion - as a result, there was insufficient investigation and preparation of cases related to gangs, organised crime and commercial cases.

* An unbearable workload on the 24 regional courts while they dealt with the most serious crimes; by the end of 1995 there were 3 000 cases outstanding on their rolls and this rose to 3 500 a year later.

* A delay in filling vacant posts that had seriously affected understaffed prosecutors' and magistrates' sections, and relief staff in lower courts were insufficient to cushion the vacancies.

* Rationalisation in the public service adding to the demotivation of staff.

* Prosecutors often doing their jobs under difficult and dangerous circumstances - security needed to be addressed.

* A need for more special courts dealing with rape and child victims.

* The police child protection unit not functioning in areas where most cases originated - Khayelitsha, Guguletu, Langa and Nyanga - resulting in investigations not being done properly.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 15, 1997


Sudan;
Government Says It Has Released All Political Prisoners


BYLINE: Yahya el Hassan, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 831 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - The Sudanese government has announced here that it has now released all political detainees and urged the country's opposition to reconsider their position towards the regime.

Speaking on state television Wednesday night, the country's justice minister, Abdel Basit Sabdarat, said " Sudan has no more political detainees, all have been freed." 

The minister said that as government prepares to produce a permanent constitution, it would like to involve as many politicians as possible in the process.

Those released include a former Deputy Prime Minister and interior minister, Sid-Ahmed al Hussein of the outlawed Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), Abdel Mahmoud Hajj Salih, a former Attorney General and Abdel Rahman Abdalla Nugdallah, a relative of former Prime Minister Sadiq al Mahdi and Mohamed Ismail al Azahari, son of the first Sudanese post- independence president, Ismail al Azahari of the DUP.

Commenting Thursday on the release of detainees, the Sudanese Foreign Minister, Ali Osman Mohamed Taha, told the country's news agency that the number of people released contradicted western claims that the government of Gen. Omar al Bashir, was holding a big number of people as political detainees.

He said the release of the prisoners was to mark "a new political era" in the Sudan.

The release of political detainees comes barely a month after the Khartoum government signed a peace agreement with minor Southern Sudanese warring groups, on April 22.

The political gesture has also coincided with preparations for a conference to promote peace in southern Sudan by the Inter-Governmental Authority on Drought and Development (IGADD).

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 15, 1997


South Africa;
Thousands Seek Asylum In South Africa


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa is being flooded with requests for asylum at a rate of more than 1,000 applications every month since September last year, according to the Department of Home Affairs.

The Department said in a statement on Wednesday it has received 26,000 applications for asylum in the past three years. Of these, more than 10,600 had been processed.

It said only six applicants had been granted full asylum, while 1,330 had been given asylum for a two-year period, renewable after re- evaluation. Just over another 2,000 people had been granted renewable six-month residence permits.

A total of more than 800 of the applications had been dismissed as "manifestly unfounded"; almost 4,400 had been rejected, nearly 900 had been referred to regional offices and more than 1,000 of the requests had been withdrawn.

A Home Affairs spokesman said that almost 15,300 applications for asylum still had to be considered. The refugees concerned were granted temporary residence in South Africa pending the outcome of their applications.

Most applications -- more than 4,000 -- came from Argentina. Nigeria was second with nearly 3,000 applications while Zaire placed third with nearly 2,800.Next in line were Somalia, Pakistan and Senegal.

Asylum in South Africa is granted only when a person is at risk of persecution in his own country because of religious beliefs, political unrest or war.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


438 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Tough Battle For OAU Top Post In June


BYLINE: Elliot Mahende, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Organisation of African Unity (OAU) Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim faces a tough battle in his bid for a third term at the helm of the pan-African body when the organisation meets for its 33rd summit in Harare early June. INL002 from SSS.066 (970515-17:40) QN PANAINL .PANADKR MSG065G/02E PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PAN(2)

A Tanzanian national, Salim is being challenged by Amara Essy, Cote d'Ivoire's foreign minister, in an election that diplomats and analysts say could split the summit along the Anglophone-Francophone fault line.

Zimbabwe's foreign minister, Stan Mudenge, confirmed the governments of Tanzania and Cote d'Ivoire were busy canvassing for support for their candidates but there was no indication yet as to how both candidates would fare. 

However, diplomats in Harare predicted that French-speaking Africa, which holds a slight majority over English-speaking countries in the 53- member OAU, could vote as a bloc for the Ivorian, creating serious problems for the former Tanzanian deputy prime minister.

"As of now, you can safely assume that the Anglophone-Francophone divide will come into play. France, of course, will urge its former colonies to vote for the Ivorian," said one diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

However, the French deputy ambassador to Zimbabwe, Alice-Anne Medard, said france, despite being a strong supporter of the OAU, had no role in the selection of the organisation's chief executive.

"France does not decide who should be Secretary-General because France is not an African country," she said.

Traditionally, there has been squabbling between French and English- speaking Africa when it comes to choosing the secretary-general.

The Paris connection is likely to be more assertive this time around, analysts say, because of the setbacks French foreign policy has suffered in Africa in recent years.

The rivalry between Washington and Paris, which stretches from differences over command of the NATO European sector, has also spilled to Africa where the United States is seen as encroaching on traditional French spheres of influence.

For all intents and purposes, France has already lost Rwanda to the English-speaking Tutsi-dominated Rwandan Patriotic Front government.

The fact that Laurent Kabila's rebels, in U.S.-style battle fatigues complete with Wellington boots, backed by Rwanda and English-speaking Uganda have virtually over-run Zaire has not helped French diplomacy in the region.

That there is no direct role for the French government in the negotiations for transfer of power in Zaire adds to the consternation in Paris.

The French minister of state for co-operation, Jacques Godfrain, writing in the daily newspaper Le Figaro, summed up France's African diplomatic set-backs when he said: "Over the past few months, no conversation in fashionable society, no refined intellect, no feature article has failed to deplore the fact that Africans are turning their backs on France."

As a demonstration of French interest in matters of the OAU, Medard said, the French government invited Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe to Paris in March for consultations in anticipation of his assumption of the chairmanship of the OAU.

At the level of secretary-general, however, there is nothing to show that Paris is overly enthusiastic about Salim, whom the French government threatened to veto in 1996 if he stood for the post of UN secretary-general because "il ne parle pas francais" (he does not speak french).

The French language is central to French foreign policy and it is hardly debatable that if the French government could have its way, it would want to see a French-speaker at the Addis Ababa-based continental body.

Analysts say there is also a feeling in some quarters that Salim, with two terms behind him, the last one of which he stood unopposed, has stayed long enough in the Ethiopian capital and that it is time somebody else, preferably from French-speaking Africa, took over.

And the 53-year-old Essy is no small candidate for the job either. With a diplomatic career spanning some 27 years, he has served in several countries including Argentina, Brazil, Cuba, Switzerland, and the United Nations.

He has participated in nine OAU summits and a number of ministerial meetings as well as all the summits of the Economic Community of West African States since 1990.

Salim, arguably one of Africa's finest diplomats, has reinvigorated the OAU and given it relevance at a time critics derided it as an anachronism and a toothless talk-shop.

Under him, an OAU mechanism for conflict prevention, resolution and management was created to give Africans a capacity to resolve their own conflicts. An early-warning mechanism on conflicts is also being set up.

The idea has since caught on with regional peacekeeping structures.

Supporters of Salim say he started a good project and needs a third four-year term to finish it. But others say "ca suffit" (it's enough).


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


439 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


Science and Health;
Birds Compete With Planes For The Skies In Uganda


BYLINE: David Musoke, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Besides combating rebels in the north, Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni has now to worry about birds which have become a nuisance at the country's gate-way, Entebbe International Airport.

Hundreds of birds swarming the runway recently delayed the Ugandan leader from taking off to the United Kingdom in his presidential jet.

When his patience ran out, Museveni ordered members of the Presidential Protection Unit (PPU) to drive away the birds so that his plane could take off.

"There were many kaloli (a local name for the marabou) birds on the runway which delayed the presidential jet from taking off for sometime," an official of the Uganda civil Aviation Authority (CCA) admitted. "But some PPU guards and an airport marshaller were ordered to scare them away." 

The official admitted that the only marshaller - a person who guides the aircraft in landing and taking off - had joined the guards in the birds scare and the presidential yet had to take off to the skies without his services.

Since Museveni's administration took power in Uganda in 1986, the number of international airlines operating in Entebbe airport, along the shores of Lake Victoria, has almost tripled to about 20 per week. Companies operating internal flights for tourists and non-governmental organisations have also increased.

But the population of the birds has also increased during the past several years around the airport.

The managing director of CAA, Ambrose Akandonda, said Entebbe airport's relative safety was increasingly being threatened by a surging bird population.

"The location of the airport makes it one of the most ideal airports in the east African region in case there has to be emergency landing. But this also makes it disadvantageous in that the location attracts numerous birds," he told reporters recently.

Several civilian and military aircraft have fallen victims to the roaming birds when their engines sucked the birds, forcing the pilots to make emergency landings.

The most recent scourge of the birds was a Uganda Airlines Boeing 737 with 101 passengers on board, which was forced to make an emergency landing shortly after take off for Dubai when one of its engines sucked in a marabou.

Fortunately, all the passengers and the eight-member crew escaped unhurt. But repairs to the plane's 13 rotor blades cost about 250 million Uganda shillings (250,000 U.S. dollars).

Other carriers, like Air France, Ethiopian Airlines and Sabena, had faced similar problems before.

Akandonda said CAA had begun shooting the birds at the airport to eliminate aviation accidents. It was also considering the introduction of falcons to hunt and kill off other birds.

Falcons are birds with pointed wings and long tails which can be trained to hunt other birds and small animals. Airports like JFK, in New York, with birds problems like Entebbe, use falcons, Akandonda said.

"We began shooting the nuisance birds last week. We are shooting marabou stocks, kites and water ducks. We shoot them mostly in the morning and evening hours when they are most concentrated," he said. "It is an effective method."

But environmentalists and lovers of birds are up in arms against the shooting of birds, saying it is illegal and must be stopped.

The commissioner for wildlife in the ministry of tourism, wildlife and antiquities, Moses Okua, said the Entebbe peninsula was gazetted a birds sanctuary long ago, "and rules do not permit killing the birds without authority from the Uganda Wildlife Authority."

He said CAA had not consulted, nor obtained permission from the relevant authority before deciding to shoot the unwelcome "guests" at Entebbe airport.

Okua said killing the birds was not a solution to the birds hazard. The problem should be looked at broadly, including things that attract birds near the airport.

CAA public relations manager James Bitwire said that the aviation authority had commissioned two experts from Makerere university to study the bird ecology in Entebbe and come out with recommendation on how to control the menace.

"The birds do not come to the run-way or the general airport areas to feed," said John Bulindi, the principal terminal manager at Entebbe airport. "They come here to relax and sun bathe after feeding from the vicinity."

Part of the key to solving the problem, he said, lies in cleaning the vicinity of anything that may attract these birds by way of food.

"In this role, we have to work with other concerned government ministries and private organisations, including Entebbe Municipal Council, which is charged with passing by-laws," Bulindi said.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


440 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


Business and Finance;
SADC Sets Up Data Bank


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The Southern African Development Community (SADC) Small Enterprise Promotion Council has set up a database at its headquarters in Botswana to provide information on the development of small and medium business enterprises within the 12-member group.

The project, according to SADC officials, is intended to disseminate information on the "best practices" in the management and operations of small and medium size business entities. 

It is intended that the database would also be supplemented by a proposed newsletter to report on the activities of the various working groups involved in the promotion of small businesses.

Officiating Thursday at the council's working group meeting on marketing, business linkages and cross border trade, Zambia's finance and economic development minister, Ronald Penza, urged officials to ensure that the database provided comprehensive information to keep members abreast with developments in the sector.

"This (database) is especially necessary at a time when many new initiatives in small business promotion are being introduced throughout the region," he said.

The council was formed in 1996 to help establish a strong regional network of the small and medium scale business sector which has been recognized as a major component of economies in all the SADC member- states.

SADC comprises Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


441 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


Kenya;
Kenya Supports Ban On Ivory Trade


BYLINE: Sam Mugo, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - The Kenya Wildlife Service (KWS) has said that it backs the continued ban on ivory trade and will defend that stand at all fora where it will be discussed.

This will be Kenya's official stand at a meeting of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (Cites) to be held in Harare, Zimbabwe in June.

The KWS head of corporate communications, John Mramba, said on Thursday that "our position remains the same - we are totally opposed to the resumption of trade in ivory." 

He added that the KWS was planning to hold a workshop next Thursday to finalize a technical document to back Kenya's stand at the Harare meeting.

Wildlife conservationists expected a heated "tug-of-tusks" debate in Harare following proposals by Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe that the ban on ivory trade be lifted because their elephant populations were too big.

The trade in ivory was banned in 1989 to save the African elephant from extinction, at the hands of poachers.

The three Southern African nations say they possess huge ivory stockpiles they seek to dispose off. Their demand has reportedly won support from the Cites secretariat and several Asian countries known to be markets for elephant tusks.

The KWS statement came three days after the London-based Environmental Investigations Agency, and conservationists Perez Olindo and Nehemiah Rotich of Kenya and Cosmas Mlay of Tanzania, asked Kenya to lead the onslaught against the emerging anti-ban tide.

Kenya rallied around other stockholders in the global wildlife sector to ban the trade, to save the population of the African elephant, which had declined by about 90 percent in just two decades at the hands of poachers.

Zambia, which originally sided with other Southern African states in pressing for the lifting of the ivory trade ban, has now changed its position and wants it maintained, to save its elephant population from extermination.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


442 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


East Africa;
OAU Team Evaluates Great Lakes Refugee Situation


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity (OAU) has dispatched a team to assess the situation of refugees and displaced persons in the Great Lakes region.

Abdul Mahmus Abdul-Halim, who heads the directorate of African affairs in the Sudanese foreign ministry, was quoted by the Sudan News agency (SUNA) on Thursday as saying the mission has been dispatched under the auspices of the OAU mechanism on conflict prevention, management and resolution. 

He said the delegation is being headed by Sudan's ambassador to Ethiopia, adding that this was testimony of Khartoum's prominent role in efforts to settle African conflicts.

Abdul-Halim said the delegation has so far visited Tanzania and was scheduled to tour Burundi, Rwanda and Zaire.

The four countries have been teeming with refugees since the assassination of Burundi's democratically-elected Hutu President, Melchior Ndadaye in October 1993 and the 1994 genocide in Rwanda.

The refugee situation has been further aggravated by the seven-month civil war in Zaire, being waged by Laurent Kabila's Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo (Zaire), which are threatening to seize Kinshasa.

The mission's report will be submitted to the next OAU Council of Ministers, which meets in Harare towards the end of May, to prepare for this year's OAU summit, to be held in the Zimbabwean capital from June 2-4.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


443 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


Nigeria;
Worldwide Protests Against Shell


BYLINE: Africa Policy Information Center (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 5560 words


 

Washington - On May 14, date of the annual shareholder meeting of Shell Oil in London, protests against the company for human rights and environmental abuses took place outside the meeting and around the world.

A resolution sponsored by the Pensions and Investment Research Consultants and the Ecumencial Council for Corporate Responsibility won 41 million of the total 357 million shares (more than 10%). Demonstrations took place in a number of cities in the U.S., Canada and elsewhere.

This posting includes excerpts from press releases from several groups involved in the protests and a special issue on Shell of Rachel's Environment & Health Weekly.  *************************************************************

RAINFOREST ACTION NETWORK * PROJECT UNDERGROUND * OILWATCH

May 13, 1997 Press Contact: Mark Westlund - ranmedia@ran.org

or Project Underground, 1847 Berkeley Way, Berkeley, CA 94703; phone: 510-705-8981; fax: 510-705-8983; e-mail: steve@moles.org. 

SHELL OIL UNDER RENEWED ATTACK AT LONDON ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING (excerpts from press release)

HUMAN RIGHTS GROUPS RELEASE INDEPENDENT ANNUAL REPORT

LONDON - The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, the world's largest international oil company, came under attack today from environmental and human rights activists for its activities in Peru and Nigeria, at the same time as the company prepares to fend off a shareholder resolution critical of its policies at its annual meeting tomorrow. In the United States, there will be demonstrations in at least eight cities demanding that Shell improve its human rights perfomance.

Coinciding with Shell's annual general meeting and the release of the company's first worldwide environmental report, Rainforest Action Network and Project Underground, released their own independent annual report that reveals Shell's destructive environmental practices in Peru and Nigeria. The report, with a blood-spattered Shell logo on the cover, criticizes the company's approach to gas development in Peru, and accuses Shell of making only cosmetic changes to its operations in Nigeria. Two representatives from Peru and Nigeria, Ledum Mites, president of the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People and Wrays Perez, secretary of AIDESEP, Peru's largest indigenous federation, will also attend the meeting.

...

Since 1958, Shell has extracted billions worth of oil and natural gas from the Niger River delta area of Nigeria, home to the Ogoni people. As a result, the Ogoni's traditional fishing and farming life has been devastated by oil pollution, and, according to the Wall Street Journal, the land has become a "ravaged environment." The United Nations Conference on Environment and Development has declared the Niger's mouth as the most endangered river delta in the world - a direct result of nearly four decades of oil exploitation.

Desiring profits from Shell and other major oil companies, the Nigerian government has been silencing the voices of protest in Ogoniland, to the point of executing human rights activist, poet, and 1995 Goldman Environmental Prize Winner, Ken Saro-Wiwa, and eight fellow activists. The report reveals new information about the destruction of the delta environment.

***********************************************************

SIERRA CLUB CRITICIZES SHELL'S IRRESPONSIBILITY IN NIGERIA

Group Stages Protest Outside Company Headquarters

May 14, 1997

CONTACT: Stephen Mills, Human Rights and Environment Campaign Director, Sierra Club, 408 C St., NE, Washington, D.C. 20002; tel: 202- 675-6691; e-mail: stephen.mills@sierraclub.org

Washington, D.C. -- Amid demonstrators chanting, "No Blood for Oil", outside Shell Oil's Washington, D.C. lobbying headquarters, members of the Sierra Club pledged today that the nation's oldest and largest grassroots environmental organization will continue its boycott of Shell Oil until the company's rhetoric matches its actions.

"Since the execution of Ken Saro-Wiwa, Shell has spent millions on public relations and advertising to respond to the public outcry for environmental justice in Ogoni," said Stephen Mills, Director of the Sierra Club's Human Rights and the Environment Campaign. "But they have yet to admit responsibility for their actions, to pay adequate compensation to villagers whose farms were destroyed, or to clean up their environmental mess in Ogoni. Our boycott campaign will continue until Shell's deeds match their words."

"If anything, the situation in Nigeria has worsened," said Mills. "The Ogoni region is now a military zone and MOSOP has been forced underground." MOSOP stands for the Movement for the Survival of Ogoni People, the environmental and human rights organization led by writer Ken Saro-Wiwa before he was hanged in November of 1995. "Teachers are arrested if they mention Ken Saro-Wiwa in the classroom, preachers are arrested if they mention Ken in church," said Mills.

"We have new reports that local security forces in Nigeria's main oil-producing region has forced people, often at gunpoint, to sign statements inviting Shell to return to Ogoniland," said Mills. "The fact is, Shell cannot return to Ogoni until they negotiate with MOSOP, and that will be impossible as long as MOSOP members are forbidden to assemble."

At its annual general meeting today in London Shell will be under pressure from church pension funds and Pirc, the U.K. investment advisory service which holds 12 percent of Shell's stock, to clarify its commitment to environmental protection and human rights. Among the key points in the Pirc shareholder resolution: make someone on the committee of managing directors personally responsible for seeing that Shell honors its commitments to the environment and human rights; establish an effective auditing process to guarantee that words and actions match; and publish a progress report to shareholders, specifically in relation to Shell's operations in Nigeria, by the end of 1997.

Shell's Board of Directors advice to shareholders to reject Pirc's resolution has only given environmental and human rights organizations more reason to doubt the company's recently issued business principles that call for a respect for human rights.

"Shell has made a great effort in recent weeks to praise its contributions to hospitals in Nigeria. What they won't tell you is that the Ogoni won't go near the hospitals because of their profound fear of the company," Mills added. "This is nothing more than an attempt to disguise the fact that Shell has yet to adequately address the Ogoni environmental demands that started this whole campaign."

Shell first found oil in Nigeria's Ogoniland in 1958. Since that time the company has extracted some $35 billion in oil from the lands of the Ogoni people. While royalties from these sales fill the coffers of the Nigerian military dictatorship, the rich farmland and rivers of Ogoniland have been poisoned by oil spills and the venting of toxic gases. Meanwhile most Ogoni today still lack running water , electricity, adequate schools or health care.

"Nineteen Ogoni men are now awaiting trial for the same murders for which Ken Saro-Wiwa was wrongly tried and hanged," said Mills, "some are suffering in detention from blindness, disease and torture. We are demanding that Shell use their considerable influence to see that the Ogoni 19 are released."

Environmental and human rights advocates believe Ken Saro- Wiwa was killed because of the international campaign he led against the pollution in his homeland caused by Shell, one of the largest revenue producers for the military junta that rules Nigeria. The Nigerian military government, an international pariah, has refused to release the body of Saro-Wiwa and eight others it executed, to the families. The regime maintains a strong presence in Ogoniland, beating and jailing any Ogoni who dares speak Saro-Wiwa's name or attempts to organize others to protect the environment.

The Nigeria Country Report on Human Rights, released in January by the U.S. Department of State, noted that "General Abacha's Government relied regularly on arbitrary detention and harassment to silence its many critics." That report is available on the internet at http://www.state.gov/www/issues/human_rights/1996_hrp_report  /nigeria.html.

At the protest the group distributed specially designed postcards for citizens to sign and send to Shell and President Clinton.

Also available today for comment: Dr. Owens Wiwa, brother of Ken Saro-Wiwa, (416) 657-6180.

For more information, please visit the Sierra Club website, http://www.sierraclub.org/human-rights

************************************************************

RACHEL'S ENVIRONMENT & HEALTH WEEKLY *546 (Electronic Edition) May 15, 1997

Environmental Research Foundation, P.O. Box 5036, Annapolis, MD 21403; Fax (410) 263-8944; Internet: erf@rachel.clark.net.

Back issues available by E-mail; to get instructions, send E-mail to INFO@rachel.clark.net with the single word HELP in the message; back issues also available via ftp from ftp.std.com/periodicals/rachel and from gopher.std.com and from http://www.monitor.net/rachel/ Subscribe: send E-mail to rachel-weekly-request@world.std.com with the single word SUBSCRIBE in the message. It's free.

CRIMES OF SHELL

The Shell oil corporation has blood on its hands, and a worldwide boycott of Shell products is under way. Two recent reports(1,2) on the Shell subsidiary in Nigeria, Africa, have documented massive environmental destruction in the Niger River delta region, where Shell has spilled some 56 million gallons of oil onto farmlands and into community water supplies.(1,pg.45) The destroyed land and water formerly provided sustenance for an indigenous people, the Ogoni. A recent video confirms these reports of Shell's environmental abuse and mismanagement in Ogoniland.(3)

But Shell's crimes are deeper still. When Ogoni activists organized to demand that Shell clean up spilled oil, and share oil profits more equitably with the Ogoni people, the Nigerian military dictatorship --with financial assistance, logistical support, and guns provided by Shell(1,pgs.23,43,91-92) -- conducted a campaign of terror in which at least 1800 Ogoni people were murdered, some of them tortured to death.(1,pg.95)

The Ogoni peoples' struggle against Shell burst into headlines November 10, 1995, when the Nigerian dictatorship executed 9 Ogoni environmental activists, including Ken Saro- Wiwa. Saro-Wiwa had received the Goldman Environmental Prize for Africa April 17, 1995 in recognition of his environmental work on behalf of the Ogoni people. Saro-Wiwa had also received the Right Livelihood Award December 9, 1994.(1,pg.95) Both awards are said to carry prestige equivalent to the Nobel peace prize. In addition to being an environmentalist and community leader, Saro-Wiwa was well-known in his homeland, and internationally, as a poet and essayist.(4) His last words, just as he was executed by hanging, were, "Lord, take my soul but the struggle continues!"

Within weeks of the executions, Shell contracted with the Nigerian dictatorship to build a large liquefied natural gas plant, thus sending a signal that it was business as usual for Shell and that Shell was continuing to support the military dictatorship.(2,pg.10)

According to the World Council of Churches, key witnesses for the prosecution at Ken Saro-Wiwa's trial have signed sworn affidavits saying they were bribed by Shell to testify against Saro-Wiwa.(1,pg.43)

Since late 1995, the dictatorship has been holding 19 more Ogoni environmental activists, charged with the same crime for which the Ogoni 9 were executed. The World Council of Churches reported in late 1996 that, "...as a result of the inhuman treatment, torture, denial of medical care, starvation and poor sanitary conditions, most of the detainees are in very poor health."(1,pg.75)

The Ogoni people --500,000 of them(1,pg.8) --inhabit a 404- square-mile-area called the Rivers State in Nigeria in west Africa. They represent 0.05% of the Nigerian population, so they are a tiny minority. Ken Saro-Wiwa compared the Ogoni to other indigenous people around the world: the Aborigines of Australia, the Maori of New Zealand, and the native people of North and South America. "Their common history is of the usurpation of their land and resources, the destruction of their culture, and the eventual decimation of the people," he wrote.(1,pg.19) Since 1958, $30 billion worth of oil has been taken from beneath the land of the Ogoni, yet essentially zero benefits have accrued to the Ogoni themselves. When the World Council of Churches sent observers to Ogoniland in 1995, they found no piped water supplies, no good roads, no electricity, no telephones, and no proper health care facilities.(1,pg.24) Further, they reported that, in oil-rich Ogoniland, gasoline is hand-pumped from a cement holding tank into large plastic containers, then poured into a smaller can with a long neck, from which the gasoline is finally poured into a vehicle's gas tank. Such is the state of modernization made possible by Shell's post-modern colonial venture.

Shell, a Dutch company, is the 10th largest corporation in the world, and No. 1 in profitability.(2,pg.4) Shell has 96 oil production wells in Ogoniland, 5 flow stations (large pumping stations), and numerous gas flares which have operated continuously for 35 years.(1,pg.31) In addition, Shell maintains many high-pressure oil pipelines criss-crossing Ogoniland, carrying oil from other parts of Nigeria to the shipping terminal at Bonny.(1,pg.32) In response to growing pressure for reform in Ogoniland in 1993, Shell ceased oil production there, but retained its network of pipelines carrying oil produced elsewhere in Nigeria. (The World Council of Churches finds evidence that Shell has not in fact ceased oil production in Ogoniland,(1,pgs.31-33) but Shell insists its production wells are idle.)

Between 1976 and 1980, Shell operations caused 784 separate oil spills in Nigeria.(1,pg.45). From 1982 to 1992, 27 additional spills were recorded. Since Shell "ceased oil production" in Ogoniland in 1993, Shell admits another 24 oil spills have occurred there.(1,pg.33)

Shell operates in 100 countries, but 40% of all its oil spills have occurred in Nigeria.(1,pg.28) Shell says the spills result from "sabotage" but the World Council of Churches reports "there has not been one single piece of evidence produced by Shell to back up its claims that oil spills in Ogoniland were caused by sabotage."(1,pg.39)

Shell controls at least 60% of all the oil reserves in Nigeria and oil accounts for 80% of Nigeria's total revenues and 90% of its foreign exchange earnings.(1,pg.44) As a result, Shell is an extremely powerful political force in Nigeria. The World Council of Churches has described a revolving door -- Shell executives becoming Nigerian political officials, and Nigerian political officials becoming Shell employees.(1,pg.44) However, Shell maintains that it has no political influence and cannot affect the fate of political prisoners in Nigeria.

Shell admits to 3000 polluted sites affected by oil operations on Ogoni soil. According to the World Council of Churches, Shell also admits to flaring 1.1 billion cubic feet of natural gas each day for 35 years, causing acid rain in the Niger delta during about 10% of the days each year.(1,pg.41) Furthermore, the flares produce a rain of fine particles, a cancer-causing soot that permeates everything --land water, homes, lungs.

Shell's environmental abuses in Ogoniland came as a shock to observers sent by the World Council of Churches. They wrote, "Having followed all the events in Ogoniland, reading all the reports and seeing the videos such as DRILLING FIELDS and DELTA FORCE3, did not prepare us for the devastation we saw at the numerous spill sites we visited," they wrote.(1,pg.24)

Observers from the World Council of Churches describe a site where Shell had spilled oil in 1969: "Even though this spill occurred 26 years ago, its devastating impact is still very apparent," they wrote.(1,pg.34) "The soil and oil are caked together into a thick black crust which covers the area. Liquid crude oil is still present in deep crevices (2 to 3 feet deep), formed in spots where trees once stood... The air remains polluted by the vapour from the spilled crude oil; this becomes particularly noticeable when the south-west wind blows. The oil spill seems to have polluted the creek nearby. The oil flowed into the body of water and we were told that it can still be seen floating on the surface of the creek water that people still drink. We were unable to move near the creek as the earth was dangerously soggy with a combination of soil, oil, and water... It is amazing that so much devastation exists after 26 years."(1,pg.34)

Since the death of Ken Saro-Wiwa, his brother, Dr. Owens Wiwa, has been touring the world describing the Ogoni peoples' struggle against the combined forces of Shell and the military dictators of Nigeria. Dr. Wiwa, an articulate, soft-spoken physician, was himself held prisoner (without charges) by Nigerian authorities on more than one occasion.(1,pg.93) He is now a political exile living in Toronto, Canada, though most of his time is spent on the road, urging people to boycott Shell products.

In late March of this year, U.S. environmental justice activists met in Atlanta, Georgia to discuss environmental justice struggles across the U.S. and abroad. Dr. Wiwa gave the keynote address. "Our people are dying at the hands of our government and Shell Oil," Dr. Wiwa told the assembled activists in Atlanta. Dr. Robert D. Bullard, a well-known environmental justice leader and author of CONFRONTING ENVIRONMENTAL RACISM: VOICES FROM THE GRASSROOTS, told the Atlanta meeting, "the quest for healthy and sustainable communities and environmental justice does not stop at U.S. borders... we have a moral and ethical obligation to direct our collective action and purchasing power to respond to Dr. Wiwa and the Ogoni's struggle in Nigeria, just as we responded to the oppression of apartheid in South Africa."

Asked recently what Americans could do to help the Ogoni people, Dr. Wiwa gave four recommendations:

1. Boycott Shell. Do not buy ANY Shell products.

2. Encourage selective purchasing contracts, such as the one now in force in Oakland, California. Last fall the Oakland City Council passed a city-wide ordinance prohib-iting the city from doing business with Nigeria. Dr. Wiwa is urging all city councils to adopt selective purchasing laws to prevent their city from investing in or trading with Nigeria OR ANY COMPANIES CARRYING OUT BUSINESS IN NIGERIA.

3. Pressure Congress to impose sanctions against Nigeria, just as the U.S. has recently done against Burma for human rights abuses.

4. Contact the president of Shell's U.S. subsidiary: Philip J. Carroll, Shell Oil Company, P.O. Box 2463, Houston, TX 77252; (800) 248-4257; fax (713) 241-4044.

Mr. Carroll may respond that Shell's U.S. subsidiary has nothing to do with what's happening in Nigeria. But 10% of Shell's profits come from its U.S. operations, so the U.S. subsidiary has major clout with its Dutch parent corporation. Refusal to exercise that clout is a moral failure. Up to now, Mr. Carroll himself has blood on his hands, in our view.

Even if Mr. Carroll cannot understand the moral argument, you could tell him you will be boycotting Shell's products until they clean up their environmental mess in Nigeria and fully compensate the Ogoni people for past damages and injustices. Mr. Carroll will certainly understand the meaning of "boycott."

To get breaking news about the campaign to end Shell's environmental and human rights abuses in Ogoniland, you could join the internet discussion group, Shell-Nigeria-action. To subscribe to the list, send email to listproc@essential.org with the message: subscribe shell-nigeria-action <your email address>. To post information to the list, address your message to: Shell-Nigeria-Action@essential.org.

For further information, contact:

1) Dr. Owens Wiwa: owens@igc.apc.org

2) Stephen Mills at Sierra Club in Washington, D.C. Telephone (202) 675-6691. Mr. Mills has organized a petition campaign that could use more volunteers.

3) Ann Leonard, Essential Action, P.O. Box 19405, Washington, DC 20036. Telephone (202) 387-8030. An important source of information.

What is the top priority? BOYCOTT SHELL.

--Peter Montague (National Writers Union, UAW Local 1981/AFL-CIO)
