444 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


South Africa;
Special treatment 'not improper' says Mabona


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1494 words


 

Nelspruit - It isn't a problem that parliamentary deputy speaker Baleka Mbete-Kgositsile was given special treatment and driven to Delmas to be tested for her learners and drivers licenses at State expense, the Moldenhauer Commission heard late on Wednesday afternoon.

While conceding that the trip was a personal matter, Mpumalanga safety and security MEC, Steve Mabona, insisted that the deputy speaker deserved the extra expense as a sign of respect for her position.

"Even though this was a personal matter, it was an official trip and it is right and proper that the taxpayer should pay for it because both Mbete-Kgositsile and I are civil servants 24-hours a day and have to be guarded," he said.

"I just cannot understand why this matter has been blown out of proportion ... I can think of no other reason than internal character assassination." 

Mabona, who testified for the first time on Wednesday after being booked off work for one week with stress, also denied that he was responsible for corruption committed by officials within his department because they were "undisciplined".

Mabona did confirm, however, that he had personally organised for Mbete-Kgositsile to be tested because of her "tight schedule" after she approached him and explained that she was having difficulty constantly travelling between Cape Town and Johannesburg for ANC national executive committee meetings.

He was unable, however, to explain why she had not instead been tested nearer her office in Cape Town or nearer the ANC headquarters in Johannesburg.

"Why Mpumalanga? It's out of her way. Why you and not some other more relevant MEC. Is this not just re-inforcing the image that it is easier to get your license in this province that elsewhere in South Africa," asked Commission chairman, chief magistrate Heinrich Moldenhauer.

Mabona was unable to explain why no official records had been kept of Mbete-Kgositsile's tests, why the necessary fees were only paid in 28 days after the license was issued and why notification of the license was only sent to the Department of Home Affairs six months after the licenses were issued instead of within the two days prescribed by law.

Mabona was also unable to explain why copies of all internal reports and other documentation, including copies of her test results, were faxed through to Mbete-Kgositsile immediately after the Sunday Times broke the story four weeks ago.

"I am shocked and at very surprised. This is wrong. and it is the first time I have seen this type of thing ... we have a problem with our management," he said.

Conceding that he was still not in complete control of his own department after three years, Mabona agreed that he was unable to instill discipline in his directors and other junior staff and was therefore unable to effectively fight corruption within the province.

Evoking biblical verses against the "devil's evil tricks" and the "wicked spiritual forces in this heavenly world", Mabona however denied that he was only paying lip service to the fight against corruption and instead again accused the press of sentationalising instances of corruption in the province.

Despite initially denying that there were any substantial irregularities, Mabona later rounded on provincial traffic director Henry Brazer during cross examination by magistrate Moldenhauer and said that a number of Brazer's actions while issuing the licenses to Mbete-Kgositsile were "very disturbing".

This included the use of incorrect application forms and license certificates and the lack of official records.

Mabona also accused Brazer of misleading him after the first press reports by insisting that everything had been legal and "above board", prompting Mabona to be overly critical of the press.

Mabona failed however to explain why he had failed to institute an immediate internal investigation into the issue after Sunday Times broke the story four weeks ago.

"Not everything in the press is true you know, maybe they were lying for their own purposes. The press is certainly not helping government by writing things such as this and I still believe that the issue was sensationalised," he said.

"There is a difference between a fake license and one issued irregularly."

Agreeing to retract some of his accusations of racist and other hidden agendas against the reporter who uncovered the story, Mabona however refused to apologise for all his "harsh statements".

Pointing out that neither he nor department head, advocate Stanley Soko, had managed to even get officials in their head office to sign attendance registers or log in and out when leaving the office, Mabona said that every time they tried to implement control measures officials objected to "being treated like children."

"There seem to be many problems and short comings in your department that you either do not know of or cannot control. This is costing South Africa huge amounts of money and lives on our roads," commented Moldenhauer. Pointing to previous evidence, Moldenhauer also asked why, if Mabona was against the recruitment of license applicants from KwaZulu Natal and the Eastern Cape by driving schools, he had organised for Mbete- Kgositsile to come from even further away in Cape Town to be tested.

Mabona denied that the two issues could be leaked, insisting that as a senior government official Mbete-Kgositsile's case was different.

"I have a serious problem when all these officials come here to this commission to complain. I am the politician here and I didn't even know about these things - is it people trying to sabotage the department?" he said.

Moldenhauer warned that he would not hesitate to take "the strongest possible action" should anyone who testified before the Commission be victimised or otherwise compromised.

Brazer is scheduled to testify on Thursday but Moldenhauer reserved the right to recall Mabona to clarify certain issues which had still not been resolved.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


445 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


South Africa;
Special unit to probe profiteering by top politicians


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Nelspruit - National Parks Board chairman and respected former homeland leader, Dr Enos Mabuza, is being probed by the most powerful government investigative unit in South Africa for a State farm he bought for R 6 000 in 1991 and mortgaged for almost R500 000 two years later.

Two previous provincial government investigations into the sale were stalled last year after records allegedly went missing and former homeland officials refused to co-operate with either the Auditor General or the province's director general, Frank Mbatha.

Reports on the issue in the Mail & Guardian however, prompted Judge W? Heath to bring his special investigative unit to Mpumalanga this week to begin interviewing officials and to visit Mabuza's farm and three other properties near Barberton.

All four farms were sold to "political incumbents" in 1991 without tender board approval or public auction and were sold for only the legal transfer costs of between R6045 and R7500 each. 

According to the Deeds of Registrar's Office, Mabuza mortgaged his property for R480 000 two years later, with agricultural economists pointing out that the farm's true market value would be far higher as banks always keep a 35% reserve on mortgaged properties to protect themselves.

Auditors are concerned that the State had made absolutely no money out of the deal, which was described as a "gesture of thanks for our service by a grateful people" at the time by Mabuza.

The three other recipients are still serving politicians, including South Africa's current ambassador to Mozambique Mangisi Zitha, member of Parliament Professor Simon Ripinga and member of Mpumalanga's House of Traditional Leaders Tikhontele Dlamini.

Fallout from the investigation could also include Mpumalanga's speaker of the Legislature, Elias Ginindza, who signed the power of attorney authorising the sale while he was minister of the interior in KaNgwane.

Judge Heath's special unit, which was created in November 1996 after the success of his commission into corruption in the Eastern Cape, has the same executive civil powers as a High Court and has already reputedly recovered or saved the government R10-billion through its "search & seizure" operations.

Assisted by a special tribunal of three High Court judges, the unit has the power to initiate its own investigations, serve summons for civil action and pass judgement to either reclaim former State assets or goods to their value.

Other than the investigation into Mabuza's farm, the unit has also just served an eviction notice on former PAC leader Clarence Makwetu after discovering that he is 'squatting' on a government owned farm in the Eastern Cape.

Although Makwetu has occupied the farm for years and has built a house on it, he never obtained a lease for the property. He may be required to demolish the house, at his own expense, before vacating the farm.

The unit has also discovered that former Transkei military leader, General Bantu Holomisa and his military council irregularly promoted themselves just one day before 1994's historic elections to qualify for better military pensions.

According to Judge Heath, the government is loosing an amount of roughly R342 400 per month because of the promotions.

Both Heath and his investigation unit head, Jon Dutton met with Mpumalanga's provincial Auditor General, various retired homeland officials who were involved in the sales and with the departments of Land Affairs and Local Government in Nelspruit on Wednesday.

They were however unable to meet with Premier Mathews Phosa to inform him that the unit would start operating in Mpumalanga, despite attempting to set up an appointment with him for two weeks.

"After the visit this week, we have also found a number of other issues which may need investigation in the province, including various other land deals," said Judge Heath.

A full team from the unit will set up office in the province within the next month or two.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 15, 1997


South Africa;
Cession riots spread to Delmas


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

DELMAS - A Telkom van was set alight and the roads in Botleng, near Delmas, barracaded with burning tyres by pupils and teachers demanding that schools in the area be transferred from Mpumalanga into Gauteng, police said on Thursday.

Provincial police spokesperson, Captain Benjamin Bhembe, said pupils were led by teacher, Jubi Makabane of Phaphamani High School, who said he wanted to meet with the Local Government MECs of both provinces to discuss the issue. 

"The protest was unauthorised and no notice was given to the authorities that the demonstration was to take place," Capt Bhembe said.

He said about 100 pupils went on the rampage from 8:45am to 3:50pm and stoned policemen who had to fire on the crowd with teargas and rubber bullets.

One demonstrator sustained minor injuries when he was shot in the foot.

Capt Bhembe said several violent incidents had taken place around Delmas since Tuesday when Botleng residents first marched to the Delmas town council offices demanding to be included in Gauteng.

He said no arrests had been made in connection with Wednesday's protests.

May 15, 1997


South Africa;
Poverty no excuse for violent crime


BYLINE: Noel Kuhlase, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 146 words


 

Nelspruit - Two men were sentenced to four years in jail by the Nelspruit regional court on Thursday for housebreaking and theft, despite claiming they needed the money.

One accused, Carlos Mandhazi (21) said he was from Mozambique and had stolen a 9mm pistol, .45 revolver, camera, two radios and two hunting knives so that he could get money to support his mother.

Solomon Nkosi (20) was also found guilty of breaking into a Komatipoort home and was also sentenced to four years in jail by Magistrate Willie Wilkens.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


448 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


South Africa;
Deputy speaker's license is invalid says man who tested her


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

Nelspruit - Both the licenses which were secretly issued to parliamentary deputy speaker Baleka Mbete-Kgositsile by Mpumalanga traffic authorities last year October are irregular, the Moldenhauer Commission was told on Thursday.

The commission was also told by provincial traffic director Henry Brazer that political interference had paralyzed his fight against corruption and that the MEC for safety and security, Steve Mabona, seemed to be staffing the department almost exclusively with people from KwaNdebele.

Mabona is a former KwaNdebele home-land minister.

Mbete-Kgositsile was issued the licenses last year by special arrangement of Mabona, who sent his state car and personal bodyguards to fetch the deputy speaker from Johannesburg to Delmas for the tests. 

Mpumalanga traffic director Henry Brazer confirmed on Thursday that he was booked off sick with heart problems on October 1, but drove 350km to Delmas to test Mbete-Kgositsile after he was "ordered" to by Mabona.

"I would not have driven to Delmas to give Mbete-Kgositsile a license if it had not been a direct order from the MEC, because it is an abnormal request," explained Brazer.

"But I was continually told that my position was threatened and Mabona himself told me on occasion that unless I obeyed orders he would have me replaced. So, how far do you question or oppose such a boss?"

Brazer however admitted that he failed to follow the all regulations as set out in the KaNgwane Road Traffic Act itself and had neglected to ask Mbete-Kgositsile to perform an emergency hand-brake stop and a three-point turn.

He also could not remember if he had tested her knowledge of all the traffic signs or even if he had asked her to stop and pull off from robots or traffic lights in Delmas, as testified by Mbete-Kgositsile two weeks ago.

According to separate evidence before the Commission, there are no traffic lights at all in Delmas.

Brazer readily admitted that he had actually only completed half of the practical driver performance test form while with Mbete-Kgositsile in Delmas but insisted that it was not a problem that he had filled the rest in later, because the test form was "only a rough guide". He could not remember where he actually completed the form.

"I agree that the Act stipulates that all the aspects of the test have to be done or the whole thing is void, but in my opinion the deputy speaker can drive very well," he insisted.

"She told me, and it was obvious, that she had driven a lot while in exile. I gave her a license on the basis of this."

During cross examination, Brazer also admitted that he had failed to file the test results and other documentation as required by law and that he only sent them to Home Affairs for registration on the Population Register after Sunday Times first reported on the issue.

Denying earlier charges by Mabona that he was incapable of making his own decisions, Brazer accused Mabona of allowing Driving Schools from KwaNdebele to gain virtual control of the traffic division by "bending over backwards and ordering us to co-operate with their every wish".

"Mabona is very sensitive about KwaNdebele and so I leave all issues from there for him to decide on. This doesn't mean that I couldn't run my department, it means that political interference made it almost impossible to achieve anything," he said.

Brazer also charged Mabona with irregularly appropriating portions of his budget for travel and hotel expenses for Mabona's bodyguards and other staff.

"This money, which may have run into the thousands of rands, was taken away from our already under financed section, meaning that our officers could no longer patrol the roads properly or work overtime," he charged.

"Departmental finance heads explained that Mabona's 1996/ 97 budget had been finished before the year end and so they were forced to appropriate ours."

The Commission concluded hearing testimony on Wednesday with a short statement from Mabona asking the commission to be very strict in its rulings, which will be delivered to Premier Mathews Phosa on Tuesday.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


449 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


South Africa;
Third straight week of violence in Bushbuckridge


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

BUSHBUCKRIDGE - Two bakkies were burnt at Marite near Bushbuckridge on Thursday as part of the ongoing riots in the area where residents are demanding to be incorporated into Mpumalanga, said Northern Province police spokesperson, Captain Thomas Ramatseba.

He said the bakkies, one of which was transporting furniture, were burnt after about 20 000 residents again rioted, believing national minister of constitutional affairs, Valli Moosa, failed for to address them for a third time. According to Bushbuckridge border committee member, Enos Maunye, the committee received a fax late Wednesday, stating that Moosa, deputy minister of environmental affairs, Trevor Mokaba, and minister for safety and security, Sydney Mufamadi, would no longer be able to make Thursday's meeting. 

The fax arrived too late to cancel Thursday's mass meeting.

ANC spokesperson, Ronnie Mamoepa, explained that the three ministers first had to table their annual budget reports before visiting the area.

Moosa was expected to address residents on May 1, but failed to do so, apparently sparking the initial riots and barricading of roads to the Kruger National Park.

He denied he was ever scheduled to address the meeting.

Meanwhile, the border committee has raised R15 000 to hire a lawyer to represent them in court when the border issue is taken further.

Maunye said the money had been raised by collecting donations of R100 from local businesses, and R10 from private homes.

Sgt Ramatseba said police were collecting rubble used by residents in Bushbuckridge to blockade roads, but that youths continued to line the streets, waiting for police to pass, so that more barricades could be erected.

Meanwhile, in Groblersdal, no incidents of violence have been reported in the past 24 hours, said Captain Frans Mojapelo.

"At Tafelkop, people tried to barricade a road with stones, but police were able to remove them and the road was reopened," he said.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


450 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


South Africa;
Political intervention encouraged corruption


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1254 words


 

Nelspruit - Political disregard for normal government procedures or discipline in Mpumalanga's department of safety & security are at the root of the province's rampant license fraud and corruption, the Moldenhauer Commission heard during its final day of hearings on Wednesday.

This same disregard for established procedures and alleged intimidation are what led to parliamentary deputy speaker Baleka Mbete-Kgositsile being issued invalid learners and drivers licenses, said the man who tested her, traffic director Henry Brazer.

Brazer, whose testimony has been postponed twice after he was hospitalised last week with a stress related heart ailment, told the Commission in Nelspruit that he would ordinarily never have given Mbete-Kgositsile special treatment or issued her with the two licenses.

He was, however, forced, to interrupt a two week sick leave and drive to Delmas to test the deputy speaker after receiving direct telephonic orders to do so from safety & security MEC, Steve Mabona, he said. 

Mabona has confirmed that he ordered Brazer to facilitate the test and also that he sent his state issue car and personal bodyguards to Johannesburg to drive Mbete-Kgositsile to Delmas.

Mabona and Brazer, however, attacked each other in their separate submissions to the Commission, both accusing the other of links with corrupt driving schools, of being "undisciplined" and of engaging in various forms of irregularities.

Brazer also charged that Mabona's political interference extended to the "unheard of" appropriation of a significant portion of the traffic division's 1996/ 97 budget to pay for hotel accommodation, vehicle hire and other travel expenses for Mabona, his bodyguards and other "civilian" personnel.

This had become necessary, he said, because Mabona's office had used up its entire annual budget by mid-year.

Although declining to put a figure on the appropriation, Brazer said it ran into the thousands of rands and had forced him to curtail the normal patrol duties of his traffic officers and had also forced his to slash overtime allowances.

The continual political interference also paralyzed Brazer's fight against corruption which, he insisted, was supported by files of documentation he submitted. a

Mabona also seemed to be staffing the department almost exclusively with people from KwaNdebele., creating "vehement" resistance from SiSwati and white staff and also creating a climate of fear that staff could be fired for dis-obeying Mabona's orders or resisting his wishes.

Mabona is a former KwaNdebele home-land minister.

"I would not have driven to Delmas to give Mbete-Kgositsile a license if it had not been a direct order from the MEC, because it is an abnormal request," explained Brazer.

"But I was continually told that my position was threatened and Mabona himself told me on occasion that unless I obeyed orders he would have me replaced. So, how far do you question or oppose such a boss?"

Brazer however admitted that he failed to follow the all regulations as set out in the KaNgwane Road Traffic Act itself and had neglected to ask Mbete-Kgositsile to perform an emergency hand-brake stop and a three-point turn.

He also could not remember if he had tested her knowledge of all the traffic signs or even if he had asked her to stop and pull off from robots or traffic lights in Delmas, as testified by Mbete-Kgositsile two weeks ago.

According to separate evidence before the Commission, there are no traffic lights at all in Delmas.

Brazer readily admitted that he had actually only completed half of the practical driver performance test form while with Mbete-Kgositsile in Delmas but insisted that it was not a problem that he had filled the rest in later, because the test form was "only a rough guide". He could not remember where he actually completed the form.

"I agree that the Act stipulates that all the aspects of the test have to be done or the whole thing is void, but in my opinion the deputy speaker can drive very well," he insisted.

"She told me, and it was obvious, that she had driven a lot while in exile. I gave her a license on the basis of this."

During cross examination, Brazer also admitted that he had failed to file the test results and other documentation as required by law and that he only sent them to Home Affairs for registration on the Population Register after Sunday Times first reported on the issue.

Denying earlier charges by Mabona that he was incapable of making his own decisions, Brazer accused Mabona of allowing Driving Schools from KwaNdebele to gain virtual control of the traffic division by "bending over backwards and ordering us to co-operate with their every wish".

"Mabona is very sensitive about KwaNdebele and so I leave all issues from there for him to decide on. This doesn't mean that I couldn't run my department, it means that political interference made it almost impossible to achieve anything," he said.

The Commission concluded hearing testimony on Wednesday with a short statement from Mabona asking the commission to be very strict in its rulings, which will be delivered to Premier Mathews Phosa on Tuesday.

Africa News


May 15, 1997


Zaire;
ICRC: More work for the tracing agency


BYLINE: International Committee of the Red Cross


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Geneva - The ICRC delegation in Kinshasa has seen a steep rise in the number of people anxious to restore contact with their families elsewhere in the country.

In the past three and a half weeks, some 1,100 people have visited the office to write Red Cross messages -- a tenfold increase compared with just a few weeks ago. Philippe Beauverd, head of the tracing agency in Kinshasa, said that people separated from their families because of the conflict were learning about the service by word of mouth. Incoming messages are being distributed in the capital's 24 districts by Zairian Red Cross personnel.

Meanwhile, the Zairian Red Cross has organized the distribution of food parcels to some 17,000 displaced Zairians living in Kinshasa. The food (basic rations for one month, including flour, oil, salt, sugar and beans) was provided by various organizations in the capital, and the operation financed by the ICRC.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


452 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


East Africa;
ICRC: Emergency operation for Rwandan refugees


BYLINE: International Committee of the Red Cross


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Geneva - The ICRC has launched a temporary and exceptional operation to assist thousands of Rwandan refugees who are crossing the Zaire River into Congo, many of them in an appalling state of health.

The refugees, who have walked through Zaire along jungle paths, are gathering near the Congolese fishing village of Liranga, where there is no drinking water, food or shelter for them.

The riverside village, surrounded by forests and swampland, is accessible only by boat or helicopter. An ICRC team from Brazzaville which carried out a survey in Liranga between 8 and 12 May found that over 3,000 refugees had been registered by the local authorities and several hundred more were arriving in the area each day. On the other side of the river, upwards of 20,000 are said to be waiting to cross -- provided they can pay local boatmen for the passage. Those with no money, or who are too sick to go any further, are left behind in Zaire. 

Karen Thibaud, a member of the ICRC team on the spot, said the refugees were physically exhausted and malnourished. "There are likely to be many more crossing in the coming days, and they will need help urgently. We shall try to meet their immediate needs, but if we are to assist them in the longer term they will have to leave this area, which is barely suitable as a place of transit."

On 12 May the ICRC sent a first helicopter-load of food to Liranga. The following day a cargo plane arrived in the Congolese capital, Brazzaville, with 11 tonnes of high-protein biscuits, medical supplies and water/sanitation material. This will be taken by a smaller aircraft to Lukolela, a missionary station with an airstrip some 80 kilometres south of Liranga.

The ICRC is in contact with the Congolese authorities, UNHCR and other organizations with a view to coordinating the operation for the refugees.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


453 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


United States and Africa;
Clinton Hope Relations with Niger Can Improve


BYLINE: United States Information Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1560 words


 

Washington - Remarks by Ambassador Joseph Diatta, Niger's new ambassador to the United States, and President Clinton during a White House presentation of the new ambassador's credentials.

(BEGIN DIATTA TEXT)

Mr. President,

Allow me first of all to transmit to you the friendly greetings of his Excellency Ibrahim Mainassara Bare, President of the Republic of Niger, together with his best wishes for your complete success in fulfilling the weighty responsibility of presiding over the destiny of the United States of America, this great nation that remains in the forefront of the struggle for peace, freedom, and progress throughout the world.

It is by such a standard that I measure the privilege and great honor conferred upon me by my accreditation to your Excellency as Ambassador of my country, which, as you know, has a tradition of friendship with yours that draws its vitality from the esteem and solidarity that prevail between the American people and the people of Niger.

This is amply demonstrated by the constant presence in Niger of numerous American Peace Corps volunteers, living and working side by side with the rural population to help them establish better living conditions. 

These volunteers, by their effectiveness and complete integration into our village communities, have won a special place in the hearts of the men and women of Niger.

This sincere friendship has made it possible to develop fruitful cooperation between our two countries, allowing the government of my country to benefit from the generous assistance of the United States in areas such as agriculture, health, management of natural resources, and food security, all sectors that contribute greatly to enhancing the capacity of the people to meet the challenge of sustainable development.

This fortunate bilateral cooperation is achieved just as harmoniously at the multilateral level, where our two governments, inspired by the principles of the United Nations Charter, regularly join forces to work for the establishment of an international order based on peace, respect for international law, and the advancement of peoples.

Mr. President,

After several consecutive years of unprecedented recession, the state of our national economy, with development indicators among the lowest in the world, continues to give cause for concern.

Nonetheless, thanks to the implementation of a courageous program of adjustment and economic reforms, recovery is starting to take hold. It is still insufficient, however, to make noticeable inroads in the poverty that ravages our society.

President Ibrahim Mainassara Bare and his government remain, therefore, determined to consolidate the conditions necessary for the recovery and restored growth of our national economy, in particular by continuing the efforts under way in the following priority areas:

-- Stepping up policies and measures to rehabilitate public finance and improve the macro-economic context, with the goal of consolidating our country's renewed credibility with the Bretton Woods institutions;

-- Improving significantly the standard of living in rural areas, with the goal of reducing poverty;

-- Promoting and developing private enterprise in profitable growth sectors, with the goal of creating capital and jobs as a basis for establishing genuine conditions of self-sustaining growth and achieving meaningful solutions to the thorny problem of poverty. To give this policy for the development of productive activities a real chance of success, a policy to encourage the mobilization of domestic savings and to attract the foreign capital needed to finance development will also be implemented.

Furthermore, the government is pursuing without letup its democratization process, as demonstrated by the establishment of democratically elected institutions, and by its determination to observe and enforce the observance of human rights and fundamental freedoms. Within such a democratic framework, the government hopes to ensure that its economic program will have the best chance of success and to enhance the cohesiveness of our society.

Mr. President,

As I begin my mission in your country, my hope is that the close cooperation existing between our two governments may be given new impetus in order to enrich the ties between us and improve our mutual understanding.

I should therefore like, for my part, to assure you that my colleagues at the Embassy and I myself will be eager to work in close cooperation with the appropriate authorities of your government, so that friendship and cooperation between the United States and Niger may reach a level commensurate with the aspirations and expectations of our respective peoples.

It is therefore with profound confidence in a promising future for our bilateral relations that I have the honor to deliver to your Excellency the letter of recall of my distinguished predecessor, Ambassador Adamou Seydou, as well as the letter by which his Excellency Ibrahim Mainassara Bare accredits me to you as Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the Republic of Niger.

Long live friendship and cooperation between Niger and the United States of America!

Thank you.

(END DIATTA TEXT)

(BEGIN CLINTON TEXT)

Mr. Ambassador:

I am pleased to accept the better of Credence issued by President Ibrahim Mainassara Bare, appointing you Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the Republic of Niger to the United States of America. I also acknowledge the better of Recall of your predecessor, Ambassador Adamou Seydou.

I extend a warm welcome to you upon your return to the United States. Many American colleagues fondly remember your previous assignment. I hope you will take every opportunity to renew those relationships and to build new ones. I also hope that working together, we can restore our relations to what they once were and more importantly, to what they should be.

On behalf of the American people, I offer my best wishes for good health and happiness to all the people of Niger. I also welcome this opportunity to express our respect and concern for them. We believe, and they believe, that only democracy and respect for human rights will bring the development and prosperity all Nigeriens so richly deserve.

Mr. Ambassador, I know you will be very busy, and I wish you every success in this important assignment. Again, congratulations and welcome.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


454 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


Southern Africa;
MISA Appoints New Executive Director


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Windhoek - The Regional Chairperson of the Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), Clara Olsen, has announced the appointment of Jeanette Minnie as the new executive director of MISA from August 1, 1997.

Minnie replaces Methaetsile Leepile, MISA's founding director, who is to become chief executive and fund manager of Samdef - the Southern African Media Development Fund, MISA's investment arm.

"Jeanette Minnie brings to the organisation a wealth of experience as an administrator and media activist", said Olsen. "Her appointment as CEO should give fresh impetus to the development of MISA into the next millennium". 

Minnie, a South African national, is the founding executive director of the Johannesburg-based Freedom of Expression Institute (FXI), which campaigns for freedom of information and freedom of expression in that country. Before that she served in the Campaign for Independent Broadcasting, which campaigned for the establishment of the Independent Broadcasting Authority (IBA) in South Africa. She is a past national organiser of the South African Union of Journalists (SAUJ) and project coordinator of the International Federation of Journalists' Southern Africa "Media for Democracy" project. As a journalist in the 1970s and 1980s, she worked for the South African Broadcasting Corporation and the 'Rand Daily Mail' newspaper.

Minnie has been the MISA Governing Council representative for South Africa since 1995. She also serves on the panel of judges of the SAUJ's Pringle Press Award and the Ruth First Journalism Award.

Minnie joins MISA at a time when the organisation is repositioning itself as the leading media watchdog and capacity building institution in the Southern African Development Community (SADC) region. Founded in 1992, MISA seeks to promote an independent, free and pluralistic press in line with the spirit of the Windhoek Declaration of 1991. Its headquarters are in Windhoek, Namibia. It currently has offices in seven of the 11 SADC countries in which it operates.

For further information, contact David Nthengwe, researcher, Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), Private Bag 13386, Windhoek, Namibia Tel. +264 61 232975, Fax. 248016 e-mail: research@ingrid.misa.org.na


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


455 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


South Africa;
Call for bunting display in city


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Cape Town - Cape Town businesses are being asked to deck the city in Olympic bid bunting to demonstrate support for a project that will launch a "30-year development programme" in the region.

The call to the business community to promote the bid in the final months of the race has been made by the Cape Chamber of Commerce and Industry. 

Chamber president Ali Gierdien said the Games were "a must" for the Peninsula, an opportunity to launch a "30-year development programme that will significantly improve our infrastructure and economic performance, underpin our tourism industry and serve to unite South Africans".

The Games should not be seen merely as a 14-day track and field event.

He added that the Chamber was "satisfied that Cape Town can afford the Games without impacting negatively on ratepayers". "Budgetary plans for capital as well as operating expenditure are evaluated by the Chamber on a continuous basis."

As far as the International Olympic Committee was concerned, Cape Town's technical capacity to host the Games had been accepted.

But visiting IOC members "essentially want to feel the vibe of the city, and judge whether we have what it takes to host Africa's first Olympic Games".

With this in mind, city businesses should approach the Bid Company for bunting and flags to create a colourful display of support.

All Material ) copyright Independent Newspapers 1997.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


456 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


Sports - General;
Cabinet team gears up to take fight for Games abroad


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Cape Town - A powerful government thrust is set to boost lobbying for the Olympic bid internationally, and to reinforce support at home as the countdown to the September 5 deadline ticks away.

While the Bid Company concentrates on visits to Cape Town by International Olympic Committee members about 54 of whose votes will be needed if the city is to win a high-powered committee of cabinet ministers and deputies is to take the message abroad, concentrating particularly on about 50 IOC members in Africa, Asia and Latin America. This will include strategic efforts by President Mandela and his deputy Thabo Mbeki. 

The committee will be chaired by Sport Minister Steve Tshwete, and will include Mineral and Energy Minister Penuell Maduna, Agriculture Minister Derek Hanekom, Water Affairs Minister Kader Asmal, Public Works Minister Jeff Radebe and Deputy Foreign Affairs Minister Aziz Pahad.

South Africa's embassies and high commissions throughout the world are being mobilised to promote Africa's Olympic hopes.

Mr Tshwete's committee - which is also to serve as a channel of communication between the Bid Company and the Cabinet will be advised by Sam Ramsamy, president of the National Olympic Committee of South Africa (Nocsa) and Mr Mbeki's legal adviser, Mojunku Gumbi.

The committee is to co-ordinate its activities with the Bid Company, and liaise daily with the deputy president's office.

The new committee's activities are to be financed, independently of the Government, through a special fund created from donations from foreign companies.

All ministers and deputy ministers travelling overseas in the next four months are to be briefed to promote the bid, and draw media attention to the developmental logic of South Africa's Olympic programme. The government team is also to go out of its way to highlight the fact that Africa has never been given a chance to host the Games in the modern Olympic movement's 100-year history.

Mr Tshwete yesterday described South Africa's chances of winning the bid as being "quite bright", but indicated that the Cabinet was anxious now to strengthen the bid during the critical lobbying phase, and to tackle the international doubts about political stability in the wake of Mr Mandela's eventual departure.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

May 15, 1997


South Africa;
TRC decision today on spy secrecy


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Cape Town - The African National Congress has discussed with the Truth Commission the public disclosure of agents and spies who confessed to having worked for the apartheid government in the early 1980s. 

The commission is to decide at its full meeting today how to respond to the ANC's request to keep the list confidential.

The list of names, including those of 22 people executed between 1982 and 1985, was attached as a confidential appendix to the ANC's submission earlier this week.

Nearly all the people on this list had been rehabilitated and were now either living normal lives or were dead, ANC acting secretary-general Cheryl Carolus said.

Africa News


May 15, 1997


South Africa;
NP parliament caucus faces crunch today


BYLINE: Clive Sawyer, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Cape Town - Seething tensions within the National Party about the disbanding of the Roelf Meyer task team were expected to be at the fore of today's meeting of the Nationalist parliamentary caucus.

Urgent talks have been held this week in an attempt to ensure that Mr Meyer accepts his fate within the party on the terms set by NP leader FW de Klerk - to stay on as an ordinary MP. 

The talks were held between Mr De Klerk and Olaus van Zyl of the Gauteng party executive, which on Monday decided to urge Mr Meyer to remain within the party.

Mr Meyer, Gauteng leader of the NP, will announce his decision on his political future at the provincial head council meeting on Saturday.

Indications are that his departure from the party would be unlikely, given the constitutional provision that MPs who quit their parties lose their parliamentary seats.

For Mr Meyer - and anyone who followed him - to leave would mean going into the political wilderness with few resources to continue a quest for political realignment.

Mr De Klerk issued a statement last night detailing plans for a meeting next week between an NP team headed by KwaZulu-Natal leader Danie Schutte and an Inkatha Freedom Party delegation led by Ben Ngubane, acting national chairman of the IFP.

"The purpose of the meeting will be to explore closer co- operation, the relationship between the two parties and how that relationship can be further developed," said Mr De Klerk.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


459 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


South Africa;
Buthelezi slates ANC 'silence' on murder of 420 IFP leaders


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Cape Town - The "silence" of the African National Congress about the murder of more than 420 leaders and thousands of supporters of the Inkatha Freedom Party is unacceptable, says IFP leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi.

In a statement yesterday, Chief Buthelezi said he welcomed the ANC's admission to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission that its units had plotted to assasinate him. 

"This vindicates my grievances at that time and the actions I took to protect my life and the stability of the government over which I presided.

"The fact that the ANC leadership intervened to stop the execution of these assassination plans proves that they were aware of them and their intervention may have been caused by the fact that I publicly exposed their plans timeously."

Chief Buthelezi also rejected the ANC's argument that it had never regarded the IFP as a military target, saying ANC documents, radio broadcasts and statements by senior ANC leaders had proved otherwise.

"South Africa must make a commitment to seek and expose the identity of those who killed IFP leaders, whose deaths were the product of a well-planned strategy and not of sporadic 'community violence'," he said.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


460 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


South Africa;
Lawyers advised against amnesty bid, says De Klerk


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Cape Town - National Party leader F W de Klerk told the Truth Commission he had considered carefully whether he should apply for amnesty, but had decided against it, partly on the advice of lawyers.

He was responding to a question by commission deputy chairman Alex Boraine, who said torture had been "routine and widespread" in South Africa under the previous government and many people had not been surprised at the confessions of senior policemen. 

Mr De Klerk said the commission's amnesty process was for people who believed they needed pardons for crimes.

"That (an amnesty application) is not the correct channel to express your sorrow, acceptance of responsibility, repentance for things that are not crimes, and I have not been involved in anything that can form a credible charge," he said.

Dr Boraine suggested suffering under apartheid laws could constitute "severe ill-treatment" and that Mr De Klerk may have made himself liable to legal action


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


461 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Belinda Davids: whirlwind ride to the top of the Cape music scene


BYLINE: Jermaine Craig, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

Cape Town - With starry-eyed dreams, she started out on her musical career as a tiny six-year-old performing at a gospel concert with her church choir. Today that little girl has become a confident young woman who is being widely tipped to make it big on the international music stage.

Belinda Davids has come a long way since her humble beginnings and has had a whirlwind trip to the top of the local music scene.

The bubbly 20-year-old from the Friendly City of Port Elizabeth has certainly made an impact on the local nightclub scene with her vibrant stage presence and a voice capable of mixing it up with the best musicians in the industry.

Since her musical debut in that modest church hall, she has progressed rapidly and recently released her debut album, called simply Belinda Davids, after having signed a record deal with Tusk Records. 

Her debut single, We Go Together, has received plenty of airtime on most radio stations and the music video of this song has also been aired on national television many times.

She has followed this up with her second single, My Life, which has also received plenty of airtime.

Belinda specialises in rhythm and blues music and loves nothing more than getting a nightclub crowd going with her upbeat dance numbers.

However, she has a versatile voice and is equally adept at belting out soulful ballads.

Gospel music was an integral part of her musical make-up while growing up, but the shape of her musical career was altered when she joined a jazz band in Port Elizabeth called Maiden Voyage at the age of 16 and started playing at nightclubs.

She showed tremendous promise and entered Radio Algoa's On the Go Show

talent search competition - which she duly won. From there her musical career really took off and she has been playing in clubs and concerts throughout the country, with her music generally being well received.

Belinda has recently decided to make Cape Town her home and is a well-known face on the Peninsula music scene, having played in many of Cape Town's premier jazz clubs, including Galaxy, Images, Niveau and Leibro.

For many years Cape Town musicians have bemoaned the fact that they are forced by nightclub management to play an endless number of cover songs, with little opportunity to play original music.

When performing, Belinda plays a high percentage of cover versions of popular songs, but feels it is important to also filter in some of her own music in order to get people used to her style.

"To get the vibe going at nightclubs you have to play cover versions. When people go out they want to dance and they want to dance to music they know.

"However, I sing my own music as much as I can because I want people to get used to it," says Belinda.

While in Cape Town, she has joined up with local jazz band Sounds of Soul and together they have been entertaining the crowds.

She moved to Cape Town to further her career, as she felt she could get more exposure in the city to help realise her dream of recording an album overseas.

In her line of work, being a nomad is pretty much part of the territory, but her move to the Mother City has represented a challenge she is relishing.

"Cape Town is a beautiful place, I really like it a lot. The prospects for jobs here are also much better. There are not too many clubs in PE and everyone there already knows me.

"Moving to Cape Town is a fresh experience for me. I like to go to places where people do not know me and can get to know me," said Belinda.

While she was growing up, Whitney Houston was a tremendous influence on her career and recently the music of Toni Braxton and Anita Baker has inspired her.

She lists Cape Town singer Vicky Sampson as her favourite local artist and is also a fan of the Gauteng duo MarcAlex.

Her face lights up as she says that she would dearly love to have American producer Brian McKnight produce an album for her in the US.

At the moment it is not inconceivable to imagine her working with these popular international artists - but at first the future did not look too rosy for Belinda.

She grew up in a family of seven children in the rough Port Elizabeth suburb of Gelvandale - notorious for its high crime rate and rampant gangsterism.

Most of her family still live in Port Elizabeth, but Belinda intends bringing her mother and five-month-old son Blake to Cape Town as soon as she establishes herself and can afford to buy a house here.

To unwind after a strenuous performance, Belinda enjoys cuddling up with a good book, travelling and partying.

If she had not been a musician, she says she would have been an accountant "because I like working with money".


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


462 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


Business and Finance;
SA gets tough with EU on farm goods exclusion


BYLINE: Alide Dasnois, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Cape Town - South Africa will lobby European Union member states to review Europe's trade offer, the Department of Trade and Industry's chief foreign trade director Faisel Ismail says.

Addressing a joint sitting yesterday of Parliament's trade and industry, agriculture and foreign affairs committees, Mr Ismail said suggestions by the European Union (EU) that 40 percent of South Africa's agricultural exports be excluded from a trade deal were seen as "ridiculous and a bit preposterous", even by some member states.

"Some of the goods on the list are not even produced in the EU," Mr Ismail said. 

Under the present trade regime, about 90 percent of South Africa's trade with the EU was already duty-free or subject to duties of about one percent.

"It is mainly agricultural products on which there are still heavy duties, and this is a relatively small part of South Africa's trade," Mr Ismail said. "Yet this is the area the EU has sought to exclude."

The Minister of Trade and Industry Alec Erwin had warned the EU negotiators that unless there was progress on this matter, South Africa would "find it hard to proceed with the trade agreement with any enthusiasm".

The Government also intended to raise the matter at a political level during visits to EU member states later this year, he said.

Mr Ismail said the South African negotiators were also arguing that the trade deal should be asymmetrical and that money should be set aside by the EU to help southern African countries over the difficult structural adjustment which would follow on the dismantling of tariff barriers in South Africa.

He hoped to have an answer on the creation of a structural adjustment fund by July, when Mr Erwin and EU commissioner Joao de Pinheiro would review progress in the trade talks.

Significant progress had been made in other areas, he said, culminating in approval last month by the EU and the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries of South Africa's qualified accession to the Lome Convention.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 15, 1997


South Africa;
Nat rulers never ordered assassinations, insists FW


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Cape Town - Former state president F W de Klerk has again vehemently denied that his government approved policies or strategies involving torture, murder or assassination, or that he was aware of illegal security force action.

Mr De Klerk, who faced tough and at times hostile questioning during his day-long testimony to the Truth Commission yesterday as head of the delegation presenting the National Party's second submission, said such policies would have been totally at odds with his Christian beliefs and the political ethos of the NP. 

"I couldn't live with such decisions. I stand by what I say before you and God: I was not party to such policies there was always an ethos that the law must be upheld, the courts must be upheld and people (transgressing the law) must be prosecuted I reject the imputation that there was this sort of immoral, everything-goes-in-a-state-of-war, the end justifies the means; that was not the philosophy with which I lived, with which I operated, and within which I served."

But he admitted that apartheid and the conflict had been "a dark blotch on our history" for which he expressed regret.

He also agreed that some of those who should have been the guardians of that ethos - including senior officers in the security forces and even a cabinet minister - had now applied for amnesty for gross human rights abuses.

Mr De Klerk was questioned by Glenn Goosen, director of the commission's investigative unit, about a State Security Council meeting in May 1986, at which Mr De Klerk was present, where an agenda item on the "Third Force" stated that then defence minister Magnus Malan and law and order minister Louis le Grange had been told to organise "a well-trained capacity to effectively wipe out terrorists".


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


464 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


South Africa;
Ambulance crews admit: It's a mess


BYLINE: Andrea Weiss, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Cape Town -Khayelitsha residents have a better chance of getting to hospital by wheelbarrow than by ambulance, say Cape Town ambulance crews.

This is because the crisis in the service has stretched resources to the limit, with the result that the injured and sick often have to wait hours for an ambulance.

The ambulance staff were reacting to the death of Thobeka Madayi in a wheelbarrow in a Khayelitsha street last week - revealed in the Cape Argus - after day hospital staff told her husband, Vuyani Magazi, to arrange his own transport. 

A disillusioned group of ambulancemen said the advice given to Mr Magazi by the Nolungile day hospital was based on harsh reality because, on average, only two or three ambulances served Khayelitsha.

The Cape Town municipality, which runs the service on behalf of the province, is seeking a meeting with Health Minister Ebrahim Rasool to discuss the state of the under-resourced service, which has an ageing fleet and a dearth of equipment.

The meeting will also be about who will run the service in future.

The service is run on an agency basis, but neither the municipality nor the Cape Metropolitan Council wants to run it, because it has been severely underfunded in the past. They want the province to take it over.

Ambulance chief Greg Pillay said staff were trying to make the best of a bad situation but were "amazingly" able to respond well to public emergencies, such as Saturday's N2 disaster in which 12 people died.

The ambulance staff said the service was under severe pressure, with fewer than 25 ambulances operating in greater Cape Town at any one time, a control room without computer equipment and more than 30 staff under psychological care.

The ambulancemen produced job cards showing the time seriously injured patients had had to wait for ambulance transfers from day hospitals in Khayelitsha. Some had spinal injuries, fractured femurs or gunshot wounds.

In one case, a call came in at 10.36am for a patient who had an abdominal injury and was unconscious, but the ambulance was not dispatched until 1.28pm. Ambulances serving Khayelitsha sometimes collected six or seven patients at a time.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.
