Africa News


May 15, 1997


United States and Africa;
Albright: U.S. to 'Keep Pursuing' Zaire Peace


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Washington - Comments on the Zaire talks by U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright during an interview on the "NewsHour with Jim Lehrer," May 14.

JIM LEHRER: Okay. Finally, before we go, Zaire--today's meeting between President Mobutu and Kabila, the rebel leader, didn't come off. What happened, Madam Secretary?

SEC. MADELEINE ALBRIGHT: Well, there were some hang-ups in terms of questions as to whether some of the aspects of the meeting. We are very disappointed that the meeting did not take place. It is very important that the two meet, and it is really important for Zaire to have a process where there can be a movement towards a government that has been elected, some kind of a peaceful transitional process, and we have to do something about the tragic situation to do with the refugees.

It is a very tough situation. We have obviously tried with the South Africans to bring the two together. We are going to keep all of the international community will be pursuing that because it's essential that they get together and we have some kind of a peaceful transition.

JIM LEHRER: Is there an agreement of any kind on the part of President Mobutu to step aside?

SEC. MADELEINE ALBRIGHT: I think that he is looking for ways to have a transition but I can't go into the details of that.

JIM LEHRER: If there--do you think there will be a meeting tomorrow?

SEC. MADELEINE ALBRIGHT: We hope so. As I said, we are very disappointed that one did not take place today, and we believe it is essential that the two meet.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


466 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


Zaire;
Kabila Balks at Transition Plan


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Washington - Disagreements over a transition plan proposed by South Africa led to cancellation of the Zaire peace talks, which were to have taken place aboard a South African naval vessel off the coast of the Congo on Wednesday. But South African President Nelson Mandela, using his considerable international stature, is persisting in efforts to halt the fight before it spreads to the Zaire capital, Kinshasa.

Although security concerns were cited as the reason for the 'no-show' by Laurent Kabila, whose Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire now control over two-thirds of the country, diplomats and other informed sources say it is Kabila's refusal to agree to a South African-proposed transition arrangement that is behind the current stalemate. 

Kabila arrived in Cape Town today aboard a plane sent by Mandela to bring the Zairean rebel leader from Angola, where he remained yesterday after refusing to meet Mandela and Mobutu Sese Seko, the ailing Zaire president, in Pointe Noire, Congo for talks aboard the South African ship Outeniqua.

South Africa presented a 10-point transition arrangement that would install an interim government with representatives from all the major Zairean political forces. The interim government would administer Zaire for a year and organize democratic elections, which would be the first in the country's history. The plan requires Mobutu to relinquish power immediately, but not directly to Kabila, as the Alliance is insisting.

The South African Broadcasting Corporation, which obtained a copy of the plan, is reporting that Mobutu would be required to step down within 24 hours after the agreement is signed.

Just before Kabila's arrival in Cape Town, his senior aide, Moise Nyarugabo Muhizi, reiterated that that the Alliance would talk only about a hand-over of power. "Today we give peace talks a last chance," he told the Associated Press.

With backing from neighboring Angola, Alliance forces poised outside Kinshasa are thought to be well-equipped for a final push to take the capital.

Meanwhile, South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki, the architect of the transition plan, has been having talks with top Mobutu supporters, including a delegation led by Foreign Minister Gerard Kamanda wa Kamanda aboard the ship. Mobutu reportedly returned to Kinshasa last night after a one hour meeting in Pointe Noir with Mandela and Mbeki.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


467 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. on Zaire: 'A problem of huge dimensions'


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3080 words


 

Washington - Text of questions and answers by State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns on Zaire at the Department's daily briefing May 15.

QUESTION: Zaire?

MR. BURNS: Yes.

QUESTION: What's your assessment of what's happening there? Do you think Kabila has been as cooperative as he could be?

MR. BURNS: Well, we understand that Mr. Kabila is meeting right now with President Mandela in Capetown. We also understand that President Mobutu has returned to Kinshasa. We understand that the situation in Kinshasa today is rather quiet. The South African Government has gone to enormous lengths to try to put these two people in the same room together. Now they are following a strategy of talking to both of them individually, which is a very good thing. 

We hope at some point, these two individuals will agree to meet together; or at least agree on a set of rules that would provide the foundation for a transition. We think that transition must be made.

QUESTION: Do you have further analysis, though, of the breakdown in the talks yesterday? Of who stood up --

MR. BURNS: We think the South African Government provided adequate measures, security measures and others, to set up a meeting. We, frankly, are extremely disappointed that the meeting did not take place. It was no fault of the South African Government. President Mobutu, as you know, was present and ready to meet. So that leaves Mr. Kabila.

Now, he has some concerns about his security; obviously, those are very important concerns. We don't begrudge him that. But at some point, if he is to be a part of the process of producing a peaceful transition and a peaceful outcome, he needs to sit down with Zairian government officials to work that out. That's what the South African Government is trying to do now, and we support the South African Government.

QUESTION: Are you dismayed that, given his behavior in the last 24 hours, that he is, as some commentators are suggesting, just bent on a military victory?

MR. BURNS: Well, we understand that Mr. Kabila promised President Mandela that his troops would stand down, pending further meetings. We hope that's the case. He said that the last time, and the troops continued their military offensive. So we'll have to judge him by his actions. We don't believe that his troops should move forward into Kinshasa without prior political talks that would decide on how the transition of power that is clearly coming is going to take place; because we think that Mr. Kabila and President Mobutu ought to have, above all, an interest in avoiding bloodshed and protecting the citizens of Zaire from an ongoing civil war.

QUESTION: Is the United States giving any thought to sending another special envoy?

MR. BURNS: I'm not aware of any plans to send a special envoy. We have our ambassador, Ambassador Simpson, in Kinshasa, ambassadors in all of the countries where these events are taking place - Don Steinberg in Angola; Ambassador Joseph in South Africa. So I think we're well represented.

QUESTION: Prior to the meeting or the time of the meeting yesterday, Mr. Kabila was meeting with the Angolan president. The Angolans have clearly had some influence over the rebel alliance. Have there been any conversations between U.S. officials and President dos Santos about the influence that the Angolans are - or the role that they are apparently playing in whether or not these talks take place? Or what Mr. Kablia --

MR. BURNS: Yes, we have very strongly encouraged President dos Santos, through Ambassador Steinberg in Rwanda, that the Angolan Government ought to join the efforts of all of us - the South Africans, the United States, France, the United Nations - to bring these parties together. We obviously would not want to see Angola stoke the fires of a civil war and encourage further military movement. We want to see cooperative behavior on the part of Angola with the wider peace efforts.

QUESTION: Have you detected any troop movement by Angola lately?

MR. BURNS: I really can't speak to that. I just don't have any information on Angolan troop movements. As you know, we have very strongly encouraged Angola and other neighbors of Zaire not to lend arms or troops to the fighting, but unfortunately there has been a great deal of evidence to the contrary.

QUESTION: Nick, what role is Howard Wolpe playing and where is he? You said before that there is no plan to send a special envoy. What do you call Howard Wolpe?

MR. BURNS: No plans to send - I think where Carol is coming from - may I interpret your question? Are you sending a special envoy from Washington, like Bill Richardson - no plans that I know of to do that. Howard Wolpe is a special presidential emissary. He has been in the region. He was in Lubumbashi two days ago meeting with Mr. Kabila. He is still in the region. I can try to track his movements for you if you are really interested.

QUESTION: And also, I think you or someone told us that Ambassador Richardson had spoken on the telephone with --

MR. BURNS: Two nights ago.

QUESTION: Two nights ago.

MR. BURNS: With Mobutu and Kabila.

QUESTION: Has he spoken since then?

MR. BURNS: I don't believe he has, but I can check on that.

QUESTION: Nick, as this transition takes place, as you say it inevitably will and must, has the United States taken any accounting of what are thought to be vast sums of money that Mobutu has in his control in various parts of the world? How much is involved? What should be done with such monies? How much of it came out of aid programs that never got to the Zairian people? Is that being worked on at all by the United States?

MR. BURNS: Well, just to take those questions one at a time, if I could. We are not aware, we in the U.S. Government, that President Mobutu has any substantial, or actually any financial assets here in the United States. He may; he may not. We are just not aware of what his financial holdings may be here. He obviously has sizable off-shore bank accounts. As you know, he has homes in Morocco and in France and in other countries. Obviously he must have financial holdings overseas. That is the answer to question one.

The answer to question two is that we have seen reports today by the rebel alliance that they are requesting a freezing of President Mobutu's assets overseas. Frankly, we've not been informed by the rebel alliance that they are expecting the United States to take any action in that regard. Perhaps it is directed at other countries.

Third, we are not aware of any evidence, of any diversion of U.S. assistance to Zaire to Mobutu's personal use. For a long time, for many decades, the United States did supply economic assistance, funds to Zaire. That stopped in the early 1990s, several years ago. We've not been providing Zaire with that kind of assistance. We would be extremely concerned were there any evidence that any of the money sent to Zaire by the United States in the '60s or '70s or '80s had been diverted, but there is no evidence of it. Obviously, that is a pertinent question. I understand why you are asking it, and we'll continue to keep that in the forefront of our own view here.

Now as to what should happen on this issue of his financial assets, I think that is an issue for the government of Zaire to work out with the rebel alliance and others.

QUESTION: I'm talking about aid money and not other kinds of money like from the CIA for example.

MR. BURNS: George, I always talk about - George, we're in public here. I'm talking about U.S. economic assistance from the U.S. Agency for International Development to Zaire. Of course, I could never comment on actions of the Central Intelligence Agency.

QUESTION: Not to nit-pick, but before you said money from the United States, and John Stockwell has said that Mobutu stole millions in the '70s of money that was supposed to be earmarked for other purposes.

MR. BURNS: George, I can't comment on anything pertaining to intelligence, but I can say that of the very large amount of money extended to the government of Zaire for many decades, through U.S. AID, we're not aware of any kind of diversion of those funds for the personal use of Mobutu.

Now, having said all of this, I should say this -- one of the reasons why the United States has been so concerned about Mobutu's stewardship of Zaire is that the country is bankrupt. It is bankrupt financially. The people of Zaire have not seen the benefits of the economic riches, the mining operations of that country. There is tremendous poverty in the country. A small group of people in and around the Mobutu ruling circle have enriched themselves. There's just no question about that, and no reason to deny it in public.

So we're dealing with a problem of huge dimensions inside Zaire, and it's partly responsible for the opposition to President Mobutu in Zaire.

QUESTION: Nick, on the question of the assets, are you saying that you're not aware that Mobutu has any assets in the United States because you just don't know about it, or have you actually done some looking?

MR. BURNS: Because we just don't know. I don't believe that our Bureau of African Affairs has checked with American banks or investment firms, or whether or not we even have access to that kind of information.

QUESTION: Well, is this something that you'd be interested in? I mean, do you feel like you have an obligation to find out if Mobutu has funds in this country?

MR. BURNS: At this point, we think it's very important that Mobutu, the government of Zaire, President Mobutu, and the rebel alliance -- they discuss these kinds of issues. This is a transitional issue. It's one of the issues that obviously will be discussed. It's not for the United States to offer public comment on how that issue should be adjudicated between these competing factions.

QUESTION: Are you worried that if the United States were to take an aggressive stance on this, that perhaps Mobutu would be less inclined to leave?

MR. BURNS: No, I don't believe so. I think it's just our appreciation that the United States cannot delve into every aspect of a country's political crisis as if it's all our business. This is something that he and other Zairian political leaders, including Mr. Kabila, need to work out. This is what they ought to be talking about, in part - all of these different questions. It's not helpful for us to throw rocks from the outside.

QUESTION: Our story from Geneva suggests that the rebels do want - are asking the United States to freeze whatever assets, if there are assets here.

MR. BURNS: Yes, I saw that same report.

QUESTION: But you haven't gotten some formal request?

MR. BURNS: I checked with Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Bill Twaddell just before coming out here. He said he's not aware, we are not aware of any request from the rebel alliance. Now, perhaps one will be forthcoming, I don't know. We'll just deal with that if it does.

QUESTION: Would you honor that?

MR. BURNS: Excuse me?

QUESTION: Would you honor that kind of request?

MR. BURNS: We'd have to look at the request and see what it was, but our general orientation, our general view is that the Zairians need to work out these problems. One cannot expect the United States to solve all problems of Zaire. The Zairians need to shoulder responsibility here. Betsy.

QUESTION: I saw one article that says that the amount of debt that Zaire now carries as a country is about $9 billion. You're saying that this transition is inevitable. Have there been discussions by this building, either with other countries or with international banking institutions, as to what the world response should be to a country that has a debt like that? Will we make any effort to help them deal with this crisis?

MR. BURNS: Actually, I think it's very difficult for the rest of the world to think of grand schemes to assist Zaire economically in the middle of a civil war and just prior to a fundamental political transition of power.

If there is a peaceful transition of power, and if the people who come into the government are devoted to stability and economic reform and democracy, if they want to hold elections, I think there would be great sentiment in the United States, in Europe, in Africa to help in the organization of elections. There would be great sentiment to help Zaire get back on its feet. That will all depend on the philosophy of the people who take over after this transition - the economic and political philosophy. We hope it's liberal economically, and democratic politically.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


468 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


Zaire;
Kabila Gives Mobutu Until Monday


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Washington - After more than two hours of talks in Cape Town, Zairean rebel leader Laurent Kabila agreed to give Zaire's President Mobutu Sese Seko until Monday to respond to peace proposals put forward by South African President Nelson Mandela.

In a meeting with reporters, neither leader was willing to provide details. "We are engaged in very sensitive and complicated negotiations and we don't want any party to hear about the discussions we had with the other from the media, as that would complicate matters further," Mandela said. Kabila said little and refused to state that his troops would ease up on their march towards Kinshasa, the Zaire capital. 

Disagreements over South Africa's draft transition plan led to cancellation of the Zaire peace talks, which were to have taken place aboard a South African naval vessel off the coast of the Congo on Wednesday. But Mandela, using his considerable international stature, persisted in efforts to halt the fight before it spreads to the Zaire capital.

Although security concerns were cited as the reason for the Wednesday 'no-show' by Kabila, whose Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire now control over two- thirds of the country, diplomats and other informed sources say it is Kabila's reluctance to accept the transition arrangement that is behind the current stalemate.

Kabila arrived in Cape Town Thursday aboard a plane sent by Mandela to bring the Zairean rebel leader from Angola, where he remained yesterday after refusing to meet Mandela and Mobutu Sese Seko, the ailing Zaire president, in Pointe Noire, Congo for talks aboard the South African ship Outeniqua.

South Africa presented a 10-point transition arrangement that would install an interim government with representatives from all the major Zairean political forces. The interim government would administer Zaire for a year and organize democratic elections, which would be the first in the country's history. The plan requires Mobutu to relinquish power immediately, but not directly to Kabila, as the Alliance is insisting.

The South African Broadcasting Corporation, which obtained a copy of the plan, is reporting that Mobutu would be required to step down within 24 hours after the agreement is signed.

Just before Kabila's arrival in Cape Town, his senior aide, Moise Nyarugabo Muhizi, reiterated that that the Alliance would talk only about a hand-over of power. "Today we give peace talks a last chance," he told the Associated Press.

With backing from neighboring Angola, Alliance forces poised outside Kinshasa are said to be well-equipped for a final push to take the capital.

Taking part in the meeting in Cape Town with Mandela and Kabila were Mohammed Sahnoun, the Algerian diplomat who serves as special representative for both the United Nations and the Organization of African Unity, and South AfricaDeputy President Thabo Mbeki, the architect of the transition plan.

Earlier in the day, Mbeki held talks aboard the South African ship with a delegation of Mobutu advisors led by Foreign Minister Gerard Kamanda wa Kamanda. Mobutu himself returned to Kinshasa Wednesday night after a one hour meeting in Pointe Noir with Mandela and Mbeki.

Mbeki remains optimistic in his public statements about the complicated negotiations he has been spearheading for several months. "The talks are not on the verge of collapse," he said. "There was a hiccup yesterday."


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


469 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


Business and Finance;
Kudu plan 'won't scuttle' Govt romance with Epupa


BYLINE: Tabby Moyo, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Windhoek - Government will not abandon its controversial Epupa dam project despite the just-announced agreement between NamPower and South Africa's Eskom and Shell Exploration and Production BV to develop an estimated N$2,2 billion 750 megawatt gas power plant in the vicinity of Oranjemund.

Namibia's power utility corporation announced yesterday that a well recently drilled at Kudu had confirmed that the present volumes of gas were more than sufficient for an initial development of the Kudu Gas Field to supply a power station with an output of approximately 750 MW over 20 years.

In a statement yesterday, Shell said the Kudu gas power plant would make Namibia self-sufficient in power during the foreseeable future while also allowing some export of electricity. 

"Further detailed studies and engineering data collection are being initiated together with concurrent discussions and negotiations to secure the market with the intention to reach a final investment decision in 1998," the statement said.

Asked to elaborate on the implication of the agreement, NamPower Managing Director Leake Hangala told The Namibian that the move would not in any way affect the disputed Epupa project.

He said the planned Epupa hydro-electric plant would remain an "excellent" venture for Namibia despite the new developments.

"The agreement will in fact enhance the Epupa project.

We have seen that there is a market for both the Kudu and Epupa," the NamPower chief said.

Hangala said a market for power existed both within and outside Namibia's borders.

NamPower has agreed to be a partner in the 750 MW gas power plant utilising gas from the Kudu Gas Field "if the technical, economic and financial investigations proved to be favourable".

Hangala said a joint study by the parties involved in the project indicated that the proposed power plant could be constructed in the vicinity of Oranjemund as an Independent Power Producer (IPP) with all the three establishments as equity partners.

A detailed feasibility study to examine the overall aspects of establishing the gas-powered plant, including technical, financial, economic and environmental aspects, is expected to be commissioned soon.

Asked if it would be possible for the equity partners to raise the funds needed for the power plant to become operational at the beginning of the year 2001, Hangala said he saw nothing that could prevent the corporations from making the needed financial resources available.

"The companies that will have equity in the project will obviously be able to mobilise the funds," he said.

It is envisaged that the development of both the Kudu Gas Fields and the power plant would support the establishment of energy or gas-based industries in Namibia such as mineral beneficiation, petrochemicals and possibly fertilisers.

The Namibian has established that Shell Exploration and Production Namibia are already involved in discussions with South Africa's Industrial Development Corporation (IDC) over the establishment of three multi-million-dollar gas-based plants.

These include the possibility of an iron plant in the Northern or Western Cape.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


470 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


Namibia;
Massive shopping centre for Katutura


BYLINE: Absalom Shigwedha, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Windhoek - A multi-million shopping complex is to be built at the Katutura Community Centre, it was announced yesterday.

The complex will be constructed by Super Deca Construction, which has entered into a lease agreement with the Namibia Red Cross Society (NRCS), the owner of the plot on which the centre will be situated. 

Work will start on June 10 and during construction 450 Namibians will be employed. The complex will cost N$30 million and is expected to be completed in March next year.

Shops to be housed in the complex include Pep Stores, Big Daddy, Ellerines, Supreme Furnishers, Guys and Girls, Style Clothing, Discom and Pages.

Among others, it will also include a huge parking area and a taxi rank.

At a media briefing yesterday NRCS's Secretary General Razia Essack-Kauaria said the centre had identified that the major focus of its drive to become financially self-sufficient "will be the development of our property".

"Therefore we called for proposals for this erf as we recognised that the size, location to the Khomasdal and Katutura communities, and potential to bring new economic energy into the community was evident," said Kauaria.

"While the NRCS will not be substantially enriched, we feel that this is the first step towards self-sustainability. We recognised that we had to enter into certain business ventures to enable us to accomplish our mission," Kauaria added.

The NRCS chief said they recognised the historical significance of the centre to residents of Katutura and Khomasdal and had requested the National Monuments Council to preserve two units as a museum for future generations.

"It seems fitting that a place that was once known for the suffering of our migrant workers under apartheid can now serve as a viable economic centre for our community," she added.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


471 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 15, 1997


Namibia;
Kudu plan 'won't scuttle' Govt romance with Epupa


BYLINE: Tabby Moyo, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Windhoek - Government will not abandon its controversial Epupa dam project despite the just-announced agreement between NamPower and South Africa's Eskom and Shell Exploration and Production BV to develop an estimated N$2,2 billion 750 megawatt gas power plant in the vicinity of Oranjemund.

Namibia's power utility corporation announced yesterday that a well recently drilled at Kudu had confirmed that the present volumes of gas were more than sufficient for an initial development of the Kudu Gas Field to supply a power station with an output of approximately 750 MW over 20 years.

In a statement yesterday, Shell said the Kudu gas power plant would make Namibia self-sufficient in power during the foreseeable future while also allowing some export of electricity.

He said the planned Epupa hydro-electric plant would remain an "excellent" venture for Namibia despite the new developments.

"The agreement will in fact enhance the Epupa project.

We have seen that there is a market for both the Kudu and Epupa," the NamPower chief said.

Hangala said a market for power existed both within and outside Namibia's borders.

NamPower has agreed to be a partner in the 750 MW gas power plant utilising gas from the Kudu Gas Field "if the technical, economic and financial investigations proved to be favourable".

Hangala said a joint study by the parties involved in the project indicated that the proposed power plant could be constructed in the vicinity of Oranjemund as an Independent Power Producer (IPP) with all the three establishments as equity partners.

A detailed feasibility study to examine the overall aspects of establishing the gas-powered plant, including technical, financial, economic and environmental aspects, is expected to be commissioned soon.

LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


472 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 16, 1997


Science and Health;
Zimbabwe Peasants Gain From Elephant Culling


BYLINE: Ndaba Nyoni, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1427 words


 

TSHOLOTSHO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Nine-year-old Sikhathele Nkomo tumbles helplessly to the ground as the mother tries to hold her up while the father talks to the nursing staff at the clinic.

Sikhathele is a victim of malaria, which has attacked hundreds of thousands of people in Zimbabwe and killed over 900 this year because of the generally above normal rains last season.

The father returns with the medicine and a cup of water and persuades his daughter to swallow the tablets, which she does with a lot of difficulty.

The mother then carries the feeble girl on her back and walks to their nearby home. 

In 1996, no less than 50 people in Sikhathele's village and neighborhood died of malaria not only because they sought treatment too late, but also because the closest clinic was some 15 km away.

She and over 10,000 members of her community are now beneficiaries of the Sikente Ward 10 CAMPFIRE Clinic built with proceeds from the organised sport hunting under the Communal Areas Management Programme for Indigenous Resources (CAMPFIRE) in drought-prone Tsholotsho district, in western Zimbabwe's Matabeleland north province.

In short, the Sikente clinic is an off-shoot of the controversial hunting of the elephant, an issue set to dominate debate at the June meeting of parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) in Harare.

Zimbabwe, supported by other southern African countries and sympathizers, is going to argue that it has an elephant population that is more than double the number that can be sustainably accommodated by the existing habitat and that the animal can be systematically culled for the benefit of local communities.

The country has between 65,000 and 70,000 elephants.

Zimbabwe will therefore be pushing for the down-listing of the elephant from Appendix 1, which prohibits international trade in elephant products, to Appendix 11, which provides for controlled international trade.

The Sikente clinic, which is still under construction, has so far cost just over 315,000 Zimdollars (28,636 U.S dollars) and was prematurely opened to the public in February to specifically deal with malaria cases.

It is now manned by three nurses and in February attended to 700 cases of malaria and over 800 cases in March. No malaria deaths have been reported in the area since the beginning of the year, yet health authorities say about 27 people die of the disease each week in the province.

"So many lives were lost because of the distance and this year a lot of lives have been saved...So I appeal to you to help us lift the international ban on ivory trade because my community would have benefited more by selling the ivory abroad," Sikente ward secretary Dennis Nkomo told a group of visiting journalists from Australia and the United Kingdom. "Maybe our clinic would be fully operational by now."

Sikente clinic is but one of the numerous projects that have been financed by the elephant in Tsholotsho district as some wards have even bought tractors for communal tillage programmes while several boreholes and pumps have also been acquired under CAMPFIRE.

One of the most successful ventures in the district is the Ehlekweni campfire project which shares a border with the 14,000 square-kilometer (5,405 square miles) Hwange National Park.

Because of proximity to the park, the local community has suffered most from elephant invasions of crop fields but has also benefited significantly from the sport hunting that is co- ordinated by the Rural District Council and the Department of National Parks and Wildlife Management.

Besides constructing a 50-km (31 miles) road from Rubizi to Pelandaba, to join the main road to Bulawayo, the Ehlekweni people have built a community hall, also used as a church, a general dealer's shop, a community guest house and water and toilet facilities.

The general dealer's shop ensures agricultural inputs and other basic groceries are within reach of the community, which lives in a remote area on the border with Botswana, about 300 km north-west of Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second city.

The CAMPFIRE project was launched in Tsholotsho district in 1989 and eight of the 20 wards participate in the programme.

Under the programme, of the revenue raised from sport hunting, of mainly elephant, 60 percent goes to the ward in which the animal would have been shot and it is the community which decides how to spend the money.

The Rural District Council takes 20 percent as administration fee while the other 20 percent also goes to council as management fee which is eventually ploughed back into the wards through development projects.

The council said as of April, it had raised some 5.5 million Zimdollars (495,406 U.S. dollars). While the council raised about 12,000 Zimdollars(1,090 U.S. dollars) from each elephant when the project started, each elephant head now cost 85,000 Zimdollars.

"The revenue from the sport hunting which, as you can see, has made a lot of difference in the quality of life of people in the district could have been much higher had there been international trade since all the tusks and skins are taken by the department of national parks and are losing quality with each passing day, Kembo Tshuma, the district CAMPFIRE manager, said.

Zimbabwe is said to have lost an estimated 320 million Zimdollars (29.1 million U.S. dollars) in potential revenue since the ban in international ivory trade started in 1989. The country has over 29 tons of ivory in its stocks.

While Zimbabwe may have justification for lifting the ban, some Western animal rights groups insist such a move would lead to increased poaching that would eventually wipe out the world's remaining elephant population.

Maybe Hwange national park warden Senanelo Moyo aptly summed it all up when he said: "It is those who keep their dogs and cats holed up in high rise apartments in New York and London and have never lived with wild animals who make the most noise."


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


473 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 16, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Africa Weekly Press Review


BYLINE: Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1414 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - With the rebel attack on Kinshasa seemingly imminent, African newspapers have again focused on the country and the reluctance of its president, Mobutu Sese Seko, to leave office immediately.

Lusaka-based Daily Post said, early this week, that the two- track negotiations by the United States and South African on Zaire's civil rule "may come unstuck."

That prediction became fact Wednesday: Zaire's Number One "rebel," Laurent Kabila, failed to meet Mobutu and South African President Nelson Mandela on board a naval ship for a second round of negotiations on Mobutu's immediate political departure.

The Post noted that the negotiators had "as their professed primary aim" the prevention of a further bloodbath in Zaire. At the same time, it added, the negotiators appeared anxious to find a dignified exit for Mobutu. 

"But the two approaches are turning out to be mutually exclusive and now threaten to render the negotiators' painstaking efforts useless," It said. "The more they attempt to accommodate President Mobutu, the more determined Laurent Kabila and his Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo become to remove the ailing dictator by force," it said.

"Why a dignified exist for Mobutu?" The Monitor, published in Addis Ababa, asked. "A dignified exit for a robber baron -- that's what the current call by the West for a dignified exist for Mobutu amounts to."

Just as with Ethiopia six years ago when rebels threatened to storm Addis Ababa, The Monitor said, with Zaire "concern mounts in Western capitals for a dignified exist" of Mobutu.

Abidjan's Le Jour also pondered over the neat exit being prepared for Mobutu since, it said, for cash strapped Kinshasa residents, the country's money "has been stolen and the social infrastructure (made) non-existent because Mobutu has only taken care of his relatives," to the detriment of the country.

For its part, Sud Quotidien, published in Dakar, concerned itself with parliament's appointment of Archbishop Laurent Mosengwo as Zaire's interim head of state.

"Mosengwo's comeback is a new indication of the disarray within the political class in Kinshasa, but which does not affect Marshall Mobutu," it said.

The fact that Mobutu seems to be "a spent force," it said, "has not stripped him of his capacity for maneuvering."

By allowing Mosengwo's return to the fore of Zaire's polity, it said, "Mobutu is presenting his usual game plan: using men like pawns in a chess game, and putting his personal touch to it by politically killing and resurrecting them to perpetuate his own reign."

It advised Mosengwo to take the job only after serious thought, because like Tshisekedi, "used as a pawn" in a game he could not master, Mosengwo risked "being burnt at the stakes of Kinshasa's Byzantine politics."

It said that Mosengwo would likely suffer this fate "without being able to change anything" of the resolve by the anti-Mobutu alliance to seize power. The result, it said, would be that Mosengwo would "end up complicating a situation which could be wisely simplified."

Nairobi's Standard sees in Mobutu "a daring Man in spite of himself." It said: "Many African leaders in his position would have scampered into exile at the first signs of trouble. But Mobutu is taking his time in what is either dogged intransigence or a gamble with fate."

It continued, "Why does Mobutu postpone his exit? The signs of the apocalypse are clear enough, except perhaps, only to Mobutu."

The paper suggests that the man probably wants to prove a point: "that although he might have experienced military losses, with a knock-knee and thieving army that excels more in looting than defending the country, personally, he is not a coward."

Whatever the reason, and although Mobutu is known for his survival mien, it said, "this time the noose is tightening around his neck."

Sooner or later, it continued, "he will have to do what many dictators before him have done."

Mobutu, it added, "could be the proverbial cock which leaves no hen untouched, but this time the head-cock will know there are other cocks in the neighborhood."

Kampala's New Vision advised these other cocks, Africa's new or emerging leaders, to resist self-aggrandizement typified by Mobutu.

"Africa's new leadership should ensure that situations that militate against democracy, causing leaders to flee to exile, are eradicated. They would also do well to put in place conditions that guarantee the smooth transfer of power," it said.

"We need to support a new breed of leaders who are prepared to champion democracy, and put in place political changes that ensure transparency and accountability," it said.

"Today," it went on, "all African people should make decisions of who should lead them if they are to resist the tragedies of dictatorship. Regimes like the collapsing Mobutu kleptocracy cannot fit in the new picture of a democratic Africa."

As Zaire's war reaches a crescendo Liberia's appears on the verge of ending with the comparative whimper of national elections.

So, the decision by West African leaders to reinforce their peace monitoring force in Liberia to 13,000 men was, to Sud Quotidien, a confirmation of the leaders' "new commitment to the complete resolution" of that crisis.

Formerly, this consensus was missing, it said, because the conflicting interests of Francophone and Anglophone countries "had always hindered the various attempts at a peaceful settlement" of the war.

Nonetheless, it said "what matters today is the common will of Ecowas (the Economic Community of West African States) to put Liberia on the path of peace."

And the troops reinforcement, which now includes a few more French-speaking states, is designed to do just that by guaranteeing peaceful elections after seven years of war.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


474 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 16, 1997


West Africa;
Benin, Ghana, Togo Meet On Togolese Refugees


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Some 50,000 out of 135,000 Togolese refugees in Ghana have voluntarily returned home under a repatriation programme being implemented by the International Organisation of Migration.

Another 3,465 of the remainder have registered to return home voluntarily, Ghana's interior minister, Nii Okaija Adamafio, said Thursday. 

He was opening the third Quadripartite Meeting on the Voluntary Repatriation of Togolese Refugees in Accra.

Adamafio said the decision to grant asylum to refugees from Togo and Liberia was difficult, bearing in mind the social and economic costs to Ghana.

"We, however, accepted them in the true spirit of African solidarity and brotherliness," he said.

He said the government will continue to do all in its power to ensure the safety and welfare of the refugees, but would "definitely not tolerate any acts of criminality on their part."

The representative in Ghana for the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, Chrysantus Ache, said his office would review the special cases of refugees who will still be in the country after June, when the last batch of the registered refugees should have returned.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


475 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 16, 1997


Zaire;
Meet Kabila, Mobutu's Long Sworn Enemy


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

LUBUMBASHI, Zaire (PANA) - The man poised to enter Kinshasa as a hero, to many, is Laurent Kabila, whose forces have forced President Mobutu Sese Seko into exile.

Kabila reappeared forcefully onto the Zairean political scene in October 1996, after living a somewhat quiet life in the country's political backwaters for almost three decades.

Kabila was born 63 years ago in the town of Ankoro on the banks of the Congo River in North Katanga, now Shaba Province. He is of the Luba ethnic group located in Zaire's Kasai Oriental Province. 

He studied philosophy in France and later became a member of the Assembly of North Katanga. As a young Marxist-Maoist revolutionary during the heady days of communist power, Kabila drew his political inspiration from his idol, the late Congolese (now Zaire) prime minister, Patrice Lummumba.

Kabila's adoption of communism led to collision with the post- independence capitalist forces in Zaire, whose nominal leader was Zaire's first president, Joseph Kasavubu. Kasavubu was then supported by Joseph Mobutu, then a prominent voice as a colonel in the army.

After Lumumba was murdered by his enemies, led by Moise Tshombe, Kabila joined forces with the National Liberation Council of the Congo, a rebel movement inspired by Lumumba.

In April 1964 Kabila with Gaston Soumialot, another revolutionary, launched the "Simba" rebellion in the Rusizi area near the town of Uvira, which they captured.

However, lack of motivation, treachery and dissension within the ranks of the movement led to the collapse of the group. It was no match for the Zairean government military offensive launched with the help of the United States and Belgium. It was U.S. Airforce planes that flew Belgian paratroopers to Stanleyville (now Kisangani) to support Mobutu to save Zaire from "Communism."

After a fierce onslaught by the government, Kabila and his rebels fled in 1964. In November 1965, Mobutu now a general declared himself president after a coup. Mobutu an ethnic Ngbandi from Equator Province became a staunch supporter of the West during the Cold War.

Kabila and Soumialot countered Mobutu by forming the People's Revolutionary Party (PRP) in October 1967. The party had an armed wing called the People's Armed Forces, a rebel group based at Fizi in the Baraka Mountains near Lake Tanganyika.

Kabila believed in radical revolutions to achieve his aims rather than round table discussions. At one time, he fought alongside the legendary Che Guevara. Critics have called Kabila the longtime opposition leader to Mobutu. Kabila is now arguably the doyen of African rebel leaders. His recent rebellion has been the swiftest and most successful uprising in Africa.

Kabila's Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo (Zaire) is well organised, motivated and has displayed tactical precision, even when pitted against European mercenaries.

The alliance is a combination of local forces and, recently, deserting soldiers from the demoralized and hopeless government soldiers. But the core of the alliance includes Kabila's resurrected PRP which still retains Marxist strategies.

It has a large number of Zairean Tutsi called the Banyamulenge from the Alliance Democratique Des Peuple, whose leader is Deogratias Bugera from Rutshuru. The group also includes the Banyamasisi who were chased from their homes by Mobutu's government administrators in North and South Kivu Provinces.

The other member of the alliance is the Mouvement Revolutionnaire Pour la Liberation du Zaire whose leader is Masusu Nindaga. The party is mainly supported by the Bashi ethnic group found around Bukavu and South Kivu.

Then there is also the Conseil National de Resistance Pour la Democracie with rebel leaders from eastern kasai. The rebel party was previously led by the late Andrei Kisase Nandu, a Luba who was Kabila's second in command. The rebel group also included the Mouvement d'Action Pour La Renaissance de Kongo, headed by Daniel Monguya. He is a politician from Bandundu Province, near Kinshasa, now living in exile.

Kabila has won recognition and respect internationally for his declared mission to return order, peace and development to Zaire, arguably Africa's most maligned and mismanaged country.

He has given an indication of how he hopes to achieve this by reviving public institutions in the areas occupied by the Alliance.

Kabilla's revolution hopes to reverse thee decades of rot incarnated by Marshall Mobutu Sese Seko's dictatorship in Zaire, African's third largest state and one of the world richest countries.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


476 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 16, 1997


Zambia;
Chiluba Says He Will Not Groom Successor


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba, who is serving his second and last five-year term of office, has said that he will not groom a successor.

"Time will tell who succeeds me but certainly ten years in office is enough and I have to step aside for someone to bring in new ideas," he said Thursday in an interview Thursday on Zambia television. 

Chiluba also threatened to sack any of his ministers or party members of his Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) who are said to be already campaigning for the presidency.

He said that it would be folly for members of the party to preoccupy themselves with the presidential campaigns so early at the expense of the public.

"When time comes we (MMD) will have show what we have done for the people. Those ministers and party national committee members found campaigning directly or by proxy will have to leave and I will appoint others to do the work," he said.

There have been reports of clandestine campaigns by some ministers and party officials for the presidency.

Finance Minister Ronald Penza, who is among Chiluba's ministers said to be involved in the campaigns, came out in the open last week and denied involvement.

Others, said by insiders to be involved in the campaigns, include Vice President Godfrey Miyanda, the outspoken minister without portfolio, Michael Sata, and Defence Minister Ben Mwila.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


477 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 16, 1997


Uganda;
Uganda Shifts Its Mission From Zaire


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Uganda, which is suspected to be aiding rebels seeking to overthrow Zaire's president Mobutu Sese Seko, has shifted its embassy from Kinshasa to Brazzaville in neighbouring Congo.

This was revealed on Friday by the government-owned Ugandan daily, New Vision, which quoted the country's Minister for Foreign Affairs in-charge of Regional Cooperation, Rebecca Kadaga, as saying the move was aimed at protecting the mission's staff. 

The minister of state said the mission was transferred to the Congolese capital last month due to an impending attack on Kinshasa by Laurent Kabila's Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL).

She said, however, that only the Ambassador, Kamanda Bataringaya and his deputy would operate from Brazzaville while the other members of staff have been recalled to Kampala.

Kadaga said the embassy would move back to Kinshasa when the dust settles in the Zairean capital.

The ADFL has threatened to storm the city if the ailing Mobutu, who has ruled the country for more than three decades, refuses to relinquish power by Monday.

Over the past seven months since the war erupted in eastern Zaire, authorities in Kinshasa have repeatedly accused Rwanda and Uganda and, at a certain moment, Burundi, of fighting alongside or giving logistical support to the ADFL.

The three countries have refuted the allegation, saying they have their own internal problems to deal with and did not have the resources for fighting other people's wars.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


478 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 16, 1997


South Africa;
TRC to name 41 cadres executed in Angola camps


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Cape Town - The names are to be released of 41 African National Congress cadres executed for serious crimes - including rape, murder and mutiny - and six who died after "excessively harsh" disciplinary treatment in Angola camps.

The Truth Commission will reveal the names as soon as all the families have been informed. 

The names of another seven cadres, alleged by the ANC to have been self-confessed spies of the South African government in the early 1980s and subsequently "rehabilitated", will be made public once the commission is satisfied the allegations are fair and those concerned have been properly informed. The names were in an appendix to the ANC's submission to the commission this week which it initially asked to be kept confidential.

Senior minister Mac Maharaj told the commission the ANC was concerned that the lives of these former spies could be disrupted, but acting secretary-general Cheryl Carolus said yesterday that the ANC was more concerned for their families.

The confidential appendix includes the names of nine Umkhonto weSizwe cadres executed for serious breaches of discipline and 23 cadres executed on orders of a tribunal.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


479 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 16, 1997


South Africa;
Shame on you Cape Town (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Cape Town - The greatness of a nation consists not so much in the extent of its territory but in the extent and justice of its compassion - inscription on the famous horse memorial in Port Elizabeth

Last Friday, readers were shocked by a photograph on the front page of this newspaper of a heartbroken husband standing next to a rusty wheelbarrow containing the body of his wife who had died while he was desperately trying to get someone to help him get her to hospital.

Today, we publish an account of a baby who died of gastro enteritis and pneumonia - both preventable and treatable diseases - in a taxi on the way to hospital.

Budgets have been cut and depleted staffs of hospitals and clinics and are operating under stressful circumstances. 

The once highly acclaimed Peninsula ambulance service is so stretched that disillusioned crews said this week it probably would be quicker to get to hospital from Khayelitsha in a wheelbarrow - or a taxi.

In short, the primary health care system is breaking down so badly that people are dying on the street.

These problems need to be addressed urgently but there appears to be another disquieting thread running through reports reaching our offices in recent months from people forced to rely on the public health system: it seems as if compassion has been forgotten in the chaos.

Provincial health minister Ebrahim Rasool had some hard things to say this week about unprofessional attitudes at day hospitals and called for resolve to make the city's health system a decent, caring one.

Shame on you Cape Town. When and why did you cease to care? Remember, it matters not whether a city is part of a great democracy with the most enlightened constitution in the world; nor whether its name goes up in lights as the most desirable holiday destination on earth; nor whether it hosts the most successful Olympic Games in history; it all counts for nothing if it has lost its soul.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


480 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 16, 1997


South Africa;
Crisis in Khayelitsha as pupils, teachers revolt


BYLINE: Sabata Ngcai, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Cape Town - Schooling at two prominent Khayelitsha schools has come to a halt, plunging troubled black education into deeper crisis.

At Luhlaza Secondary School, the trouble has been triggered by a fist-fight between two male teachers in front of pupils. At Masiyile High School, the problem centres around delays in dividing the overcrowded school into three schools. 

There have been no teachers at Luhlaza since Friday last week. Trouble began a few weeks ago when the Western Cape Education Department ordered a probe into the fight. It was recommended that one of the teachers be suspended pending the outcome of the investigation.

But pupils were angered by the plan to suspend the man, claiming he was a "good teacher", and instead demanded that the principal leave. Last week they toyi-toyied in support of the teacher facing suspension and called on the other teacher involved in the fight to leave.

The crisis culminated in school staff being held hostage by pupils on Thursday last week. They were rescued by police later in the day. Teachers are now said to be too scared to return to the school.

Luhlaza is a township school renowned for its stability and good results.

At Masiyile, chaos has erupted after teachers, parents and students accused the department of "dragging its feet" in dividing the over-populated school.

This week teachers staged a sit-in in the staff room, washed their cars and sunned themselves while pupils walked up and down.

The school has 4 000 pupils, 36 classes and 94 teachers. Teachers said each classroom had between 90 and 120 pupils. At a press conference at the school yesterday, the Parents', Teachers' and Students' Association (PTSA) said the department had agreed to divide the school into three, with some pupils to be transferred to schools in Maitland and District Six.

The department promised that the transfers would start on May 1, but failed to meet the deadline. "The department is now reneging on the agreement at the expense of our children," the PTSA said. The department could not be reached for comment.

The PTSA last week marched to the offices of provincial Premier Hernus Kriel and Education Minister Martha Olckers to submit memoranda, giving Monday this week as a deadline to attend to the problem. There has been no reply, so teachers have embarked on an indefinite sit-in and are threatening to march to the office of national Minister of Education Sibusiso Bengu next week.

Masiyile is renowned for its choir. In 1995 it was invited by the Japanese government to represent South Africa at a music festival commemorating the dropping of the atomic bomb on Hiroshima.

Until recently the school was one of the most stable in the region.

The problems began with overcrowding, and last year a row erupted when the principal fled after angry pupils accused her of witchcraft. The principal took a voluntary severance package at the end of last year.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


481 of 1004 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 16, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Lungile Jacobs: even a full-time career can't stop the music


BYLINE: David Yutar, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1320 words


 

Cape Town - If a chaotic desk is a sign of a great mind at work, then Lungile Jacobs, director of the UCT Choir for Africa, must be a genius.

Sitting behind piles of papers from which it seems all semblance of order has been deliberately removed, the amiable Lungile talks about the African tradition of music.

He's laid back, relaxed on the eve of conducting three works in the 1997 Caltex-Cape Argus massed choir festival at the Good Hope Centre on Sunday.

Apart from being a talented baritone himself and both conductor and composer of choral works, Jacobs occupies a full- time post as schools liaison officer in the development and public affairs office at the University of Cape Town. 

A young man (he is about to turn 29) he looks just like a student himself, dressed as he is in a peaked cap (back to front) jeans and slops.

"I try not to look like the teachers as much as possible, because once students start associating you with teachers they feel less free to talk to you," he said.

Jacobs advises students about post-matriculation studies and studying at UCT.

"To us, music is not something that you learn at school. Every activity that we do has music ...

"When a child is born the birth is celebrated with music, as with the reaching of manhood, obtaining work and marriage too. Every ceremony is accompanied by music and the music differs for each. And the essence of African music is that no two performances can be the same."

Turning to Lungile's career, which comes first - the PR work or the music?

"That's a very good question ... unfortunately, there isn't an opportunity for me to become a full-time musician in this country, especially with my first love being choral music."

Born in Port Elizabeth and educated first in the Eastern Cape and later at UCT's College of Music, Lungile made his debut with the CTSO in 1990, singing Non Piu Andrai from The Marriage of Figaro.

His father was a jazz saxophonist and his mother a singer in her youth.

"Oh and my uncle ... when I left PE I spent two years with my uncle who was a choral director and I think that was where most of the influence came from, because he would ask me to transcribe a lot of music."

But, in fact, a career in music was the furthest thing from the young Lungile's mind when he was growing up.

"From Standard 5 I only wanted to become a pharmacist. The problem with growing up in the '80s is that we never had career guidance in our schools.

"Because I admired the only black person in PE who was a pharmacist and had a chemist in the township, he was my role model and that was all I knew I wanted to be."

Later, when in Standard 9, Lungile developed a keen interest in medical technology. But fate drew him inexorably towards his real talents.

Since Standard 2 he had loved singing and was a member of the school choir.

"From about Standard 9, I knew how to write the tonic sol-fa (scale) and I would always be scribbling things but I didn't know how to put it together.

"When my class teacher saw this she said, 'Why don't you follow a career in music?'"

Jacobs, who had never given music a thought, was discouraged by not having had any formal musical education.

"When I told my folks about it, my mum was not impressed!"

She continued to discourage him until he began to win prizes in competitions with his obvious talent.

He spent six months at the University of Fort Hare "just learning about music" and picking up the basics.

Only in 1989, when he majored in singing, did he also start to play an instrument - the piano - for the first time.

At this point in our interview, he gets an urgent call from a Khayelitsha school.

The students are on strike and since Lungile has previously ran an SRC workshop with them, they want him to come post-haste and mediate in a crisis with the police.

Speaking in Xhosa, he assures them he will be there as soon as possible.

Music. Choir directing. Composing. A full-time PR job and now mediating in school crises! How on earth does he get the time?

"You have no idea how full my schedule is! I normally leave the office at six and have a rehearsal at seven which lasts until about nine or 10. Then when I get home I still have to cook!"

Jacobs tells me that unfortunately there is no choral school in the country so he has to buy books and teach himself about choral directing.

"This country has got what is probably the richest choral singing in the world but there is no choral school!"

What music does he listen to when at leisure?

"I listen a lot and my taste varies from Ladysmith Black Mambazo to Beethoven's string quartets. It depends on the mood. But when I want to be at peace with myself, I put on choral music because there's no instrument better than the voice."

The interview ends with Lungile Jacobs treating me to a snatch of the Humming Chorus from Madam Butterfly.

On June 16, the UCT Choir for Africa will leave on a tour of Norway.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 16, 1997


South Africa;
Controversial Crossroads strongman summoned


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Cape Town - Controversial former Crossroads "mayor" Johnson Ngxobongwana is one of four people subpoenaed by the Truth Commission to answer questions about events in KTC and other Peninsula informal settlements.

A "Section 29" subpoena was served this week on Mr Ngxobongwana, who is a National Party MP in the Western Cape legislature, and he is due to appear before the commission's investigative unit on May 29. 

Another Peninsula squatter leader, Prince Gobingca, who stood as an election candidate in 1994 as a member of former Ciskei military ruler Brigadier Oupa Gqozo's African Democratic Movement, was also subpoenaed and is due to appear on May 28.

Senior Superintendent William Rudolf Liebenberg, a former head of the police's Western Cape "terrorism detection unit", has been subpoenaed for June 3, and former police colonel Trevor Vermeulen is due to appear on June 4.

Their testimony, which will relate mainly to events in these areas during the mid-to-late 1980s, will take place behind closed doors, ahead of the public "special event" hearing starting on June 10.

This hearing will focus on events such as the the orgy of violence which engulfed Crossroads, KTC and satellite settlements in May and June 1986, when "Witdoek" vigilante groups, allegedly loyal to such conservative leaders as Mr Ngxobongwana and supported by the police, went on the rampage and destroyed hundreds of shacks, leaving an estimated 70 people dead and 70 000 homeless.

Africa News


May 16, 1997


South Africa;
We'll get to bottom of Lubowski spy claim, says Boraine


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Cape Town - The Truth Commission is determined to establish whether assassinated Swapo lawyer Anton Lubowski was a paid spy of the South African government, as alleged by former Defence Minister Magnus Malan.

Mr Lubowski's family and friends have rejected the sensational claim, first made by General Malan in parliament in 1989 and repeated during his testimony to the commission last week. 

His sister wrote an impassioned letter to a Cape Town newspaper after General Malan's testimony, accusing the Truth Commission of not doing enough to discover the truth about her brother's murder.

Commission deputy-chairman Alex Boraine yesterday said he was saddened by the letter and that several of the commissioners, including himself, had spent "very considerable time" on the issue.

He said commission investigators would examine the documents - alleged receipts - on which General Malan had based his claim and which were now in the archives of the Harms Commission. The Truth Commission would also talk to Judge Louis Harms to see whether he could shed any light on the matter.

Africa News


May 16, 1997


Business and Finance;
Imports threaten SA shoe industry's survival


BYLINE: Llewellyn Jones, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Cape Town - The domestic footwear industry could disappear if it is not given more time to restructure, says Sid Finlayson, managing director of Bolton Footwear in Great Brak River.

Bolton Footwear produces men's and ladies' branded shoes - Watson, Bally, Young Klinik, Patrick, Paolo Falcone, Lemaitre, Step-on-Air and Hang Ten - aimed mostly at the middle to upper end of the market.

It also owns three Mercedes Benz dealerships in Knysna, George and Oudtshoorn. 

Last week the company, a subsidiary of Bolton Industrial Holdings which also controls Cargo Carriers, reported a 14 percent fall in net profits to R4,9 million for the year to February.

The blame for the industry's woes has been placed squarely on imports from countries which are not members of the World Trade Organisation (WTO).

"From almost nothing six years ago, imports from these countries have grown to about 42 million pairs of shoes a year - almost all from China," Mr Finlayson said.

This compares to an annual domestic consumption of about 100 million pairs of shoes.

Mr Finlayson said the Department of Trade and Industry's proposed restrictions on imports of footwear from non-WTO countries were laudable and would help stabilise the industry, but needed to go further.

The restrictions, which have still to be applied, will limit imports of shoes from non-WTO countries to 15 million pairs a year - a figure which will be reviewed every year.

Mr Finlayson said this would show immediate benefits at the lower-priced end of the market - the area targeted by present imports, and an area which Bolton Footwear has avoided.

He said the company had seen competition coming and had focused on the middle to upper sectors of the market.

"But you can't restructure the industry on a 12-month promise - it will take at least five years to restructure," Mr Finlayson said.

The restructuring included upgrading technology, work re- organisation, and training and retraining of workers.

He said about 15 000 jobs had been lost throughout the industry - in tanning, material suppliers and footwear manufacture.

"Our company has shed about 120 jobs since the middle of last year."

Mr Finlayson said footwear production in South Africa had shrunk to the extent that it was only just capable of maintaining the structure of related support businesses, the tanning industry and material suppliers.

"If those people disappear - we will disappear with them."


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Olympic Bid: Nats accuse ANC

Cape Town - The National Party has accused the Government of trying to create the impression the Cape Town Olympic bid belongs to the African National Congress.

Nick Koornhof, NP spokesman on sport, said today the bid company also had failed to give the bid a multi-party character.
